<li class="L32" rel="L32">PRIDE AND PREJUDICE</li>

<li class="L37" rel="L37"></li>
<li class="L38" rel="L38">Chapter 1</li>
<li class="L39" rel="L39"></li>
<li class="L40" rel="L40"></li>
<li class="L41" rel="L41">It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession</li>
<li class="L42" rel="L42">of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.</li>
<li class="L43" rel="L43"></li>
<li class="L44" rel="L44">However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his</li>
<li class="L45" rel="L45">first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds</li>
<li class="L46" rel="L46">of the surrounding families, that he is considered the rightful property</li>
<li class="L47" rel="L47">of some one or other of their daughters.</li>
<li class="L48" rel="L48"></li>
<li class="L49" rel="L49">“My dear Mr. Bennet,” said his lady to him one day, “have you heard that</li>
<li class="L50" rel="L50">Netherfield Park is let at last?”</li>
<li class="L51" rel="L51"></li>
<li class="L52" rel="L52">Mr. Bennet replied that he had not.</li>
<li class="L53" rel="L53"></li>
<li class="L54" rel="L54">“But it is,” returned she; “for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she</li>
<li class="L55" rel="L55">told me all about it.”</li>
<li class="L56" rel="L56"></li>
<li class="L57" rel="L57">Mr. Bennet made no answer.</li>
<li class="L58" rel="L58"></li>
<li class="L59" rel="L59">“Do you not want to know who has taken it?” cried his wife impatiently.</li>
<li class="L60" rel="L60"></li>
<li class="L61" rel="L61">“_You_ want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it.”</li>
<li class="L62" rel="L62"></li>
<li class="L63" rel="L63">This was invitation enough.</li>
<li class="L64" rel="L64"></li>
<li class="L65" rel="L65">“Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken</li>
<li class="L66" rel="L66">by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came</li>
<li class="L67" rel="L67">down on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much</li>
<li class="L68" rel="L68">delighted with it, that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he</li>
<li class="L69" rel="L69">is to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to</li>
<li class="L70" rel="L70">be in the house by the end of next week.”</li>
<li class="L71" rel="L71"></li>
<li class="L72" rel="L72">“What is his name?”</li>
<li class="L73" rel="L73"></li>
<li class="L74" rel="L74">“Bingley.”</li>
<li class="L75" rel="L75"></li>
<li class="L76" rel="L76">“Is he married or single?”</li>
<li class="L77" rel="L77"></li>
<li class="L78" rel="L78">“Oh! Single, my dear, to be sure! A single man of large fortune; four or</li>
<li class="L79" rel="L79">five thousand a year. What a fine thing for our girls!”</li>
<li class="L80" rel="L80"></li>
<li class="L81" rel="L81">“How so? How can it affect them?”</li>
<li class="L82" rel="L82"></li>
<li class="L83" rel="L83">“My dear Mr. Bennet,” replied his wife, “how can you be so tiresome! You</li>
<li class="L84" rel="L84">must know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them.”</li>
<li class="L85" rel="L85"></li>
<li class="L86" rel="L86">“Is that his design in settling here?”</li>
<li class="L87" rel="L87"></li>
<li class="L88" rel="L88">“Design! Nonsense, how can you talk so! But it is very likely that he</li>
<li class="L89" rel="L89">_may_ fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as</li>
<li class="L90" rel="L90">soon as he comes.”</li>
<li class="L91" rel="L91"></li>
<li class="L92" rel="L92">“I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go, or you may send</li>
<li class="L93" rel="L93">them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better, for as you are</li>
<li class="L94" rel="L94">as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley may like you the best of the</li>
<li class="L95" rel="L95">party.”</li>
<li class="L96" rel="L96"></li>
<li class="L97" rel="L97">“My dear, you flatter me. I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but</li>
<li class="L98" rel="L98">I do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now. When a woman has five</li>
<li class="L99" rel="L99">grown-up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty.”</li>
<li class="L100" rel="L100"></li>
<li class="L101" rel="L101">“In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of.”</li>
<li class="L102" rel="L102"></li>
<li class="L103" rel="L103">“But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into</li>
<li class="L104" rel="L104">the neighbourhood.”</li>
<li class="L105" rel="L105"></li>
<li class="L106" rel="L106">“It is more than I engage for, I assure you.”</li>
<li class="L107" rel="L107"></li>
<li class="L108" rel="L108">“But consider your daughters. Only think what an establishment it would</li>
<li class="L109" rel="L109">be for one of them. Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to</li>
<li class="L110" rel="L110">go, merely on that account, for in general, you know, they visit no</li>
<li class="L111" rel="L111">newcomers. Indeed you must go, for it will be impossible for _us_ to</li>
<li class="L112" rel="L112">visit him if you do not.”</li>
<li class="L113" rel="L113"></li>
<li class="L114" rel="L114">“You are over-scrupulous, surely. I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very</li>
<li class="L115" rel="L115">glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my</li>
<li class="L116" rel="L116">hearty consent to his marrying whichever he chooses of the girls; though</li>
<li class="L117" rel="L117">I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy.”</li>
<li class="L118" rel="L118"></li>
<li class="L119" rel="L119">“I desire you will do no such thing. Lizzy is not a bit better than the</li>
<li class="L120" rel="L120">others; and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so</li>
<li class="L121" rel="L121">good-humoured as Lydia. But you are always giving _her_ the preference.”</li>
<li class="L122" rel="L122"></li>
<li class="L123" rel="L123">“They have none of them much to recommend them,” replied he; “they are</li>
<li class="L124" rel="L124">all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of</li>
<li class="L125" rel="L125">quickness than her sisters.”</li>
<li class="L126" rel="L126"></li>
<li class="L127" rel="L127">“Mr. Bennet, how _can_ you abuse your own children in such a way? You</li>
<li class="L128" rel="L128">take delight in vexing me. You have no compassion for my poor nerves.”</li>
<li class="L129" rel="L129"></li>
<li class="L130" rel="L130">“You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for your nerves. They</li>
<li class="L131" rel="L131">are my old friends. I have heard you mention them with consideration</li>
<li class="L132" rel="L132">these last twenty years at least.”</li>
<li class="L133" rel="L133"></li>
<li class="L134" rel="L134">“Ah, you do not know what I suffer.”</li>
<li class="L135" rel="L135"></li>
<li class="L136" rel="L136">“But I hope you will get over it, and live to see many young men of four</li>
<li class="L137" rel="L137">thousand a year come into the neighbourhood.”</li>
<li class="L138" rel="L138"></li>
<li class="L139" rel="L139">“It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come, since you will not</li>
<li class="L140" rel="L140">visit them.”</li>
<li class="L141" rel="L141"></li>
<li class="L142" rel="L142">“Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them</li>
<li class="L143" rel="L143">all.”</li>
<li class="L144" rel="L144"></li>
<li class="L145" rel="L145">Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour,</li>
<li class="L146" rel="L146">reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had</li>
<li class="L147" rel="L147">been insufficient to make his wife understand his character. _Her_ mind</li>
<li class="L148" rel="L148">was less difficult to develop. She was a woman of mean understanding,</li>
<li class="L149" rel="L149">little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented,</li>
<li class="L150" rel="L150">she fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her</li>
<li class="L151" rel="L151">daughters married; its solace was visiting and news.</li>
<li class="L152" rel="L152"></li>
<li class="L153" rel="L153"></li>
<li class="L154" rel="L154"></li>
<li class="L155" rel="L155">Chapter 2</li>
<li class="L156" rel="L156"></li>
<li class="L157" rel="L157"></li>
<li class="L158" rel="L158">Mr. Bennet was among the earliest of those who waited on Mr. Bingley. He</li>
<li class="L159" rel="L159">had always intended to visit him, though to the last always assuring</li>
<li class="L160" rel="L160">his wife that he should not go; and till the evening after the visit was</li>
<li class="L161" rel="L161">paid she had no knowledge of it. It was then disclosed in the following</li>
<li class="L162" rel="L162">manner. Observing his second daughter employed in trimming a hat, he</li>
<li class="L163" rel="L163">suddenly addressed her with:</li>
<li class="L164" rel="L164"></li>
<li class="L165" rel="L165">“I hope Mr. Bingley will like it, Lizzy.”</li>
<li class="L166" rel="L166"></li>
<li class="L167" rel="L167">“We are not in a way to know _what_ Mr. Bingley likes,” said her mother</li>
<li class="L168" rel="L168">resentfully, “since we are not to visit.”</li>
<li class="L169" rel="L169"></li>
<li class="L170" rel="L170">“But you forget, mamma,” said Elizabeth, “that we shall meet him at the</li>
<li class="L171" rel="L171">assemblies, and that Mrs. Long promised to introduce him.”</li>
<li class="L172" rel="L172"></li>
<li class="L173" rel="L173">“I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing. She has two nieces</li>
<li class="L174" rel="L174">of her own. She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion</li>
<li class="L175" rel="L175">of her.”</li>
<li class="L176" rel="L176"></li>
<li class="L177" rel="L177">“No more have I,” said Mr. Bennet; “and I am glad to find that you do</li>
<li class="L178" rel="L178">not depend on her serving you.”</li>
<li class="L179" rel="L179"></li>
<li class="L180" rel="L180">Mrs. Bennet deigned not to make any reply, but, unable to contain</li>
<li class="L181" rel="L181">herself, began scolding one of her daughters.</li>
<li class="L182" rel="L182"></li>
<li class="L183" rel="L183">“Don&#39;t keep coughing so, Kitty, for Heaven&#39;s sake! Have a little</li>
<li class="L184" rel="L184">compassion on my nerves. You tear them to pieces.”</li>
<li class="L185" rel="L185"></li>
<li class="L186" rel="L186">“Kitty has no discretion in her coughs,” said her father; “she times</li>
<li class="L187" rel="L187">them ill.”</li>
<li class="L188" rel="L188"></li>
<li class="L189" rel="L189">“I do not cough for my own amusement,” replied Kitty fretfully. “When is</li>
<li class="L190" rel="L190">your next ball to be, Lizzy?”</li>
<li class="L191" rel="L191"></li>
<li class="L192" rel="L192">“To-morrow fortnight.”</li>
<li class="L193" rel="L193"></li>
<li class="L194" rel="L194">“Aye, so it is,” cried her mother, “and Mrs. Long does not come back</li>
<li class="L195" rel="L195">till the day before; so it will be impossible for her to introduce him,</li>
<li class="L196" rel="L196">for she will not know him herself.”</li>
<li class="L197" rel="L197"></li>
<li class="L198" rel="L198">“Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce</li>
<li class="L199" rel="L199">Mr. Bingley to _her_.”</li>
<li class="L200" rel="L200"></li>
<li class="L201" rel="L201">“Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I am not acquainted with him</li>
<li class="L202" rel="L202">myself; how can you be so teasing?”</li>
<li class="L203" rel="L203"></li>
<li class="L204" rel="L204">“I honour your circumspection. A fortnight&#39;s acquaintance is certainly</li>
<li class="L205" rel="L205">very little. One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a</li>
<li class="L206" rel="L206">fortnight. But if _we_ do not venture somebody else will; and after all,</li>
<li class="L207" rel="L207">Mrs. Long and her neices must stand their chance; and, therefore, as</li>
<li class="L208" rel="L208">she will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I will</li>
<li class="L209" rel="L209">take it on myself.”</li>
<li class="L210" rel="L210"></li>
<li class="L211" rel="L211">The girls stared at their father. Mrs. Bennet said only, “Nonsense,</li>
<li class="L212" rel="L212">nonsense!”</li>
<li class="L213" rel="L213"></li>
<li class="L214" rel="L214">“What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation?” cried he. “Do</li>
<li class="L215" rel="L215">you consider the forms of introduction, and the stress that is laid on</li>
<li class="L216" rel="L216">them, as nonsense? I cannot quite agree with you _there_. What say you,</li>
<li class="L217" rel="L217">Mary? For you are a young lady of deep reflection, I know, and read</li>
<li class="L218" rel="L218">great books and make extracts.”</li>
<li class="L219" rel="L219"></li>
<li class="L220" rel="L220">Mary wished to say something sensible, but knew not how.</li>
<li class="L221" rel="L221"></li>
<li class="L222" rel="L222">“While Mary is adjusting her ideas,” he continued, “let us return to Mr.</li>
<li class="L223" rel="L223">Bingley.”</li>
<li class="L224" rel="L224"></li>
<li class="L225" rel="L225">“I am sick of Mr. Bingley,” cried his wife.</li>
<li class="L226" rel="L226"></li>
<li class="L227" rel="L227">“I am sorry to hear _that_; but why did not you tell me that before? If</li>
<li class="L228" rel="L228">I had known as much this morning I certainly would not have called</li>
<li class="L229" rel="L229">on him. It is very unlucky; but as I have actually paid the visit, we</li>
<li class="L230" rel="L230">cannot escape the acquaintance now.”</li>
<li class="L231" rel="L231"></li>
<li class="L232" rel="L232">The astonishment of the ladies was just what he wished; that of Mrs.</li>
<li class="L233" rel="L233">Bennet perhaps surpassing the rest; though, when the first tumult of joy</li>
<li class="L234" rel="L234">was over, she began to declare that it was what she had expected all the</li>
<li class="L235" rel="L235">while.</li>
<li class="L236" rel="L236"></li>
<li class="L237" rel="L237">“How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I should</li>
<li class="L238" rel="L238">persuade you at last. I was sure you loved your girls too well to</li>
<li class="L239" rel="L239">neglect such an acquaintance. Well, how pleased I am! and it is such a</li>
<li class="L240" rel="L240">good joke, too, that you should have gone this morning and never said a</li>
<li class="L241" rel="L241">word about it till now.”</li>
<li class="L242" rel="L242"></li>
<li class="L243" rel="L243">“Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you choose,” said Mr. Bennet; and,</li>
<li class="L244" rel="L244">as he spoke, he left the room, fatigued with the raptures of his wife.</li>
<li class="L245" rel="L245"></li>
<li class="L246" rel="L246">“What an excellent father you have, girls!” said she, when the door was</li>
<li class="L247" rel="L247">shut. “I do not know how you will ever make him amends for his kindness;</li>
<li class="L248" rel="L248">or me, either, for that matter. At our time of life it is not so</li>
<li class="L249" rel="L249">pleasant, I can tell you, to be making new acquaintances every day; but</li>
<li class="L250" rel="L250">for your sakes, we would do anything. Lydia, my love, though you _are_</li>
<li class="L251" rel="L251">the youngest, I dare say Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the next</li>
<li class="L252" rel="L252">ball.”</li>
<li class="L253" rel="L253"></li>
<li class="L254" rel="L254">“Oh!” said Lydia stoutly, “I am not afraid; for though I _am_ the</li>
<li class="L255" rel="L255">youngest, I&#39;m the tallest.”</li>
<li class="L256" rel="L256"></li>
<li class="L257" rel="L257">The rest of the evening was spent in conjecturing how soon he would</li>
<li class="L258" rel="L258">return Mr. Bennet&#39;s visit, and determining when they should ask him to</li>
<li class="L259" rel="L259">dinner.</li>
<li class="L260" rel="L260"></li>
<li class="L261" rel="L261"></li>
<li class="L262" rel="L262"></li>
<li class="L263" rel="L263">Chapter 3</li>
<li class="L264" rel="L264"></li>
<li class="L265" rel="L265"></li>
<li class="L266" rel="L266">Not all that Mrs. Bennet, however, with the assistance of her five</li>
<li class="L267" rel="L267">daughters, could ask on the subject, was sufficient to draw from her</li>
<li class="L268" rel="L268">husband any satisfactory description of Mr. Bingley. They attacked him</li>
<li class="L269" rel="L269">in various ways--with barefaced questions, ingenious suppositions, and</li>
<li class="L270" rel="L270">distant surmises; but he eluded the skill of them all, and they were at</li>
<li class="L271" rel="L271">last obliged to accept the second-hand intelligence of their neighbour,</li>
<li class="L272" rel="L272">Lady Lucas. Her report was highly favourable. Sir William had been</li>
<li class="L273" rel="L273">delighted with him. He was quite young, wonderfully handsome, extremely</li>
<li class="L274" rel="L274">agreeable, and, to crown the whole, he meant to be at the next assembly</li>
<li class="L275" rel="L275">with a large party. Nothing could be more delightful! To be fond of</li>
<li class="L276" rel="L276">dancing was a certain step towards falling in love; and very lively</li>
<li class="L277" rel="L277">hopes of Mr. Bingley&#39;s heart were entertained.</li>
<li class="L278" rel="L278"></li>
<li class="L279" rel="L279">“If I can but see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield,”</li>
<li class="L280" rel="L280"> said Mrs. Bennet to her husband, “and all the others equally well</li>
<li class="L281" rel="L281">married, I shall have nothing to wish for.”</li>
<li class="L282" rel="L282"></li>
<li class="L283" rel="L283">In a few days Mr. Bingley returned Mr. Bennet&#39;s visit, and sat about</li>
<li class="L284" rel="L284">ten minutes with him in his library. He had entertained hopes of being</li>
<li class="L285" rel="L285">admitted to a sight of the young ladies, of whose beauty he had</li>
<li class="L286" rel="L286">heard much; but he saw only the father. The ladies were somewhat more</li>
<li class="L287" rel="L287">fortunate, for they had the advantage of ascertaining from an upper</li>
<li class="L288" rel="L288">window that he wore a blue coat, and rode a black horse.</li>
<li class="L289" rel="L289"></li>
<li class="L290" rel="L290">An invitation to dinner was soon afterwards dispatched; and already</li>
<li class="L291" rel="L291">had Mrs. Bennet planned the courses that were to do credit to her</li>
<li class="L292" rel="L292">housekeeping, when an answer arrived which deferred it all. Mr. Bingley</li>
<li class="L293" rel="L293">was obliged to be in town the following day, and, consequently, unable</li>
<li class="L294" rel="L294">to accept the honour of their invitation, etc. Mrs. Bennet was quite</li>
<li class="L295" rel="L295">disconcerted. She could not imagine what business he could have in town</li>
<li class="L296" rel="L296">so soon after his arrival in Hertfordshire; and she began to fear that</li>
<li class="L297" rel="L297">he might be always flying about from one place to another, and never</li>
<li class="L298" rel="L298">settled at Netherfield as he ought to be. Lady Lucas quieted her fears</li>
<li class="L299" rel="L299">a little by starting the idea of his being gone to London only to get</li>
<li class="L300" rel="L300">a large party for the ball; and a report soon followed that Mr. Bingley</li>
<li class="L301" rel="L301">was to bring twelve ladies and seven gentlemen with him to the assembly.</li>
<li class="L302" rel="L302">The girls grieved over such a number of ladies, but were comforted the</li>
<li class="L303" rel="L303">day before the ball by hearing, that instead of twelve he brought only</li>
<li class="L304" rel="L304">six with him from London--his five sisters and a cousin. And when</li>
<li class="L305" rel="L305">the party entered the assembly room it consisted of only five</li>
<li class="L306" rel="L306">altogether--Mr. Bingley, his two sisters, the husband of the eldest, and</li>
<li class="L307" rel="L307">another young man.</li>
<li class="L308" rel="L308"></li>
<li class="L309" rel="L309">Mr. Bingley was good-looking and gentlemanlike; he had a pleasant</li>
<li class="L310" rel="L310">countenance, and easy, unaffected manners. His sisters were fine women,</li>
<li class="L311" rel="L311">with an air of decided fashion. His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, merely</li>
<li class="L312" rel="L312">looked the gentleman; but his friend Mr. Darcy soon drew the attention</li>
<li class="L313" rel="L313">of the room by his fine, tall person, handsome features, noble mien, and</li>
<li class="L314" rel="L314">the report which was in general circulation within five minutes</li>
<li class="L315" rel="L315">after his entrance, of his having ten thousand a year. The gentlemen</li>
<li class="L316" rel="L316">pronounced him to be a fine figure of a man, the ladies declared he</li>
<li class="L317" rel="L317">was much handsomer than Mr. Bingley, and he was looked at with great</li>
<li class="L318" rel="L318">admiration for about half the evening, till his manners gave a disgust</li>
<li class="L319" rel="L319">which turned the tide of his popularity; for he was discovered to be</li>
<li class="L320" rel="L320">proud; to be above his company, and above being pleased; and not all</li>
<li class="L321" rel="L321">his large estate in Derbyshire could then save him from having a most</li>
<li class="L322" rel="L322">forbidding, disagreeable countenance, and being unworthy to be compared</li>
<li class="L323" rel="L323">with his friend.</li>
<li class="L324" rel="L324"></li>
<li class="L325" rel="L325">Mr. Bingley had soon made himself acquainted with all the principal</li>
<li class="L326" rel="L326">people in the room; he was lively and unreserved, danced every dance,</li>
<li class="L327" rel="L327">was angry that the ball closed so early, and talked of giving</li>
<li class="L328" rel="L328">one himself at Netherfield. Such amiable qualities must speak for</li>
<li class="L329" rel="L329">themselves. What a contrast between him and his friend! Mr. Darcy danced</li>
<li class="L330" rel="L330">only once with Mrs. Hurst and once with Miss Bingley, declined being</li>
<li class="L331" rel="L331">introduced to any other lady, and spent the rest of the evening in</li>
<li class="L332" rel="L332">walking about the room, speaking occasionally to one of his own party.</li>
<li class="L333" rel="L333">His character was decided. He was the proudest, most disagreeable man</li>
<li class="L334" rel="L334">in the world, and everybody hoped that he would never come there again.</li>
<li class="L335" rel="L335">Amongst the most violent against him was Mrs. Bennet, whose dislike of</li>
<li class="L336" rel="L336">his general behaviour was sharpened into particular resentment by his</li>
<li class="L337" rel="L337">having slighted one of her daughters.</li>
<li class="L338" rel="L338"></li>
<li class="L339" rel="L339">Elizabeth Bennet had been obliged, by the scarcity of gentlemen, to sit</li>
<li class="L340" rel="L340">down for two dances; and during part of that time, Mr. Darcy had been</li>
<li class="L341" rel="L341">standing near enough for her to hear a conversation between him and Mr.</li>
<li class="L342" rel="L342">Bingley, who came from the dance for a few minutes, to press his friend</li>
<li class="L343" rel="L343">to join it.</li>
<li class="L344" rel="L344"></li>
<li class="L345" rel="L345">“Come, Darcy,” said he, “I must have you dance. I hate to see you</li>
<li class="L346" rel="L346">standing about by yourself in this stupid manner. You had much better</li>
<li class="L347" rel="L347">dance.”</li>
<li class="L348" rel="L348"></li>
<li class="L349" rel="L349">“I certainly shall not. You know how I detest it, unless I am</li>
<li class="L350" rel="L350">particularly acquainted with my partner. At such an assembly as this</li>
<li class="L351" rel="L351">it would be insupportable. Your sisters are engaged, and there is not</li>
<li class="L352" rel="L352">another woman in the room whom it would not be a punishment to me to</li>
<li class="L353" rel="L353">stand up with.”</li>
<li class="L354" rel="L354"></li>
<li class="L355" rel="L355">“I would not be so fastidious as you are,” cried Mr. Bingley, “for a</li>
<li class="L356" rel="L356">kingdom! Upon my honour, I never met with so many pleasant girls in</li>
<li class="L357" rel="L357">my life as I have this evening; and there are several of them you see</li>
<li class="L358" rel="L358">uncommonly pretty.”</li>
<li class="L359" rel="L359"></li>
<li class="L360" rel="L360">“_You_ are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room,” said Mr.</li>
<li class="L361" rel="L361">Darcy, looking at the eldest Miss Bennet.</li>
<li class="L362" rel="L362"></li>
<li class="L363" rel="L363">“Oh! She is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld! But there is one</li>
<li class="L364" rel="L364">of her sisters sitting down just behind you, who is very pretty, and I</li>
<li class="L365" rel="L365">dare say very agreeable. Do let me ask my partner to introduce you.”</li>
<li class="L366" rel="L366"></li>
<li class="L367" rel="L367">“Which do you mean?” and turning round he looked for a moment at</li>
<li class="L368" rel="L368">Elizabeth, till catching her eye, he withdrew his own and coldly said:</li>
<li class="L369" rel="L369">“She is tolerable, but not handsome enough to tempt _me_; I am in no</li>
<li class="L370" rel="L370">humour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted</li>
<li class="L371" rel="L371">by other men. You had better return to your partner and enjoy her</li>
<li class="L372" rel="L372">smiles, for you are wasting your time with me.”</li>
<li class="L373" rel="L373"></li>
<li class="L374" rel="L374">Mr. Bingley followed his advice. Mr. Darcy walked off; and Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L375" rel="L375">remained with no very cordial feelings toward him. She told the story,</li>
<li class="L376" rel="L376">however, with great spirit among her friends; for she had a lively,</li>
<li class="L377" rel="L377">playful disposition, which delighted in anything ridiculous.</li>
<li class="L378" rel="L378"></li>
<li class="L379" rel="L379">The evening altogether passed off pleasantly to the whole family. Mrs.</li>
<li class="L380" rel="L380">Bennet had seen her eldest daughter much admired by the Netherfield</li>
<li class="L381" rel="L381">party. Mr. Bingley had danced with her twice, and she had been</li>
<li class="L382" rel="L382">distinguished by his sisters. Jane was as much gratified by this as</li>
<li class="L383" rel="L383">her mother could be, though in a quieter way. Elizabeth felt Jane&#39;s</li>
<li class="L384" rel="L384">pleasure. Mary had heard herself mentioned to Miss Bingley as the most</li>
<li class="L385" rel="L385">accomplished girl in the neighbourhood; and Catherine and Lydia had been</li>
<li class="L386" rel="L386">fortunate enough never to be without partners, which was all that they</li>
<li class="L387" rel="L387">had yet learnt to care for at a ball. They returned, therefore, in good</li>
<li class="L388" rel="L388">spirits to Longbourn, the village where they lived, and of which they</li>
<li class="L389" rel="L389">were the principal inhabitants. They found Mr. Bennet still up. With</li>
<li class="L390" rel="L390">a book he was regardless of time; and on the present occasion he had a</li>
<li class="L391" rel="L391">good deal of curiosity as to the event of an evening which had raised</li>
<li class="L392" rel="L392">such splendid expectations. He had rather hoped that his wife&#39;s views on</li>
<li class="L393" rel="L393">the stranger would be disappointed; but he soon found out that he had a</li>
<li class="L394" rel="L394">different story to hear.</li>
<li class="L395" rel="L395"></li>
<li class="L396" rel="L396">“Oh! my dear Mr. Bennet,” as she entered the room, “we have had a most</li>
<li class="L397" rel="L397">delightful evening, a most excellent ball. I wish you had been there.</li>
<li class="L398" rel="L398">Jane was so admired, nothing could be like it. Everybody said how well</li>
<li class="L399" rel="L399">she looked; and Mr. Bingley thought her quite beautiful, and danced with</li>
<li class="L400" rel="L400">her twice! Only think of _that_, my dear; he actually danced with her</li>
<li class="L401" rel="L401">twice! and she was the only creature in the room that he asked a second</li>
<li class="L402" rel="L402">time. First of all, he asked Miss Lucas. I was so vexed to see him stand</li>
<li class="L403" rel="L403">up with her! But, however, he did not admire her at all; indeed, nobody</li>
<li class="L404" rel="L404">can, you know; and he seemed quite struck with Jane as she was going</li>
<li class="L405" rel="L405">down the dance. So he inquired who she was, and got introduced, and</li>
<li class="L406" rel="L406">asked her for the two next. Then the two third he danced with Miss King,</li>
<li class="L407" rel="L407">and the two fourth with Maria Lucas, and the two fifth with Jane again,</li>
<li class="L408" rel="L408">and the two sixth with Lizzy, and the _Boulanger_--”</li>
<li class="L409" rel="L409"></li>
<li class="L410" rel="L410">“If he had had any compassion for _me_,” cried her husband impatiently,</li>
<li class="L411" rel="L411">“he would not have danced half so much! For God&#39;s sake, say no more of</li>
<li class="L412" rel="L412">his partners. Oh that he had sprained his ankle in the first dance!”</li>
<li class="L413" rel="L413"></li>
<li class="L414" rel="L414">“Oh! my dear, I am quite delighted with him. He is so excessively</li>
<li class="L415" rel="L415">handsome! And his sisters are charming women. I never in my life saw</li>
<li class="L416" rel="L416">anything more elegant than their dresses. I dare say the lace upon Mrs.</li>
<li class="L417" rel="L417">Hurst&#39;s gown--”</li>
<li class="L418" rel="L418"></li>
<li class="L419" rel="L419">Here she was interrupted again. Mr. Bennet protested against any</li>
<li class="L420" rel="L420">description of finery. She was therefore obliged to seek another branch</li>
<li class="L421" rel="L421">of the subject, and related, with much bitterness of spirit and some</li>
<li class="L422" rel="L422">exaggeration, the shocking rudeness of Mr. Darcy.</li>
<li class="L423" rel="L423"></li>
<li class="L424" rel="L424">“But I can assure you,” she added, “that Lizzy does not lose much by not</li>
<li class="L425" rel="L425">suiting _his_ fancy; for he is a most disagreeable, horrid man, not at</li>
<li class="L426" rel="L426">all worth pleasing. So high and so conceited that there was no enduring</li>
<li class="L427" rel="L427">him! He walked here, and he walked there, fancying himself so very</li>
<li class="L428" rel="L428">great! Not handsome enough to dance with! I wish you had been there, my</li>
<li class="L429" rel="L429">dear, to have given him one of your set-downs. I quite detest the man.”</li>
<li class="L430" rel="L430"></li>
<li class="L431" rel="L431"></li>
<li class="L432" rel="L432"></li>
<li class="L433" rel="L433">Chapter 4</li>
<li class="L434" rel="L434"></li>
<li class="L435" rel="L435"></li>
<li class="L436" rel="L436">When Jane and Elizabeth were alone, the former, who had been cautious in</li>
<li class="L437" rel="L437">her praise of Mr. Bingley before, expressed to her sister just how very</li>
<li class="L438" rel="L438">much she admired him.</li>
<li class="L439" rel="L439"></li>
<li class="L440" rel="L440">“He is just what a young man ought to be,” said she, “sensible,</li>
<li class="L441" rel="L441">good-humoured, lively; and I never saw such happy manners!--so much</li>
<li class="L442" rel="L442">ease, with such perfect good breeding!”</li>
<li class="L443" rel="L443"></li>
<li class="L444" rel="L444">“He is also handsome,” replied Elizabeth, “which a young man ought</li>
<li class="L445" rel="L445">likewise to be, if he possibly can. His character is thereby complete.”</li>
<li class="L446" rel="L446"></li>
<li class="L447" rel="L447">“I was very much flattered by his asking me to dance a second time. I</li>
<li class="L448" rel="L448">did not expect such a compliment.”</li>
<li class="L449" rel="L449"></li>
<li class="L450" rel="L450">“Did not you? I did for you. But that is one great difference between</li>
<li class="L451" rel="L451">us. Compliments always take _you_ by surprise, and _me_ never. What</li>
<li class="L452" rel="L452">could be more natural than his asking you again? He could not help</li>
<li class="L453" rel="L453">seeing that you were about five times as pretty as every other woman</li>
<li class="L454" rel="L454">in the room. No thanks to his gallantry for that. Well, he certainly is</li>
<li class="L455" rel="L455">very agreeable, and I give you leave to like him. You have liked many a</li>
<li class="L456" rel="L456">stupider person.”</li>
<li class="L457" rel="L457"></li>
<li class="L458" rel="L458">“Dear Lizzy!”</li>
<li class="L459" rel="L459"></li>
<li class="L460" rel="L460">“Oh! you are a great deal too apt, you know, to like people in general.</li>
<li class="L461" rel="L461">You never see a fault in anybody. All the world are good and agreeable</li>
<li class="L462" rel="L462">in your eyes. I never heard you speak ill of a human being in your</li>
<li class="L463" rel="L463">life.”</li>
<li class="L464" rel="L464"></li>
<li class="L465" rel="L465">“I would not wish to be hasty in censuring anyone; but I always speak</li>
<li class="L466" rel="L466">what I think.”</li>
<li class="L467" rel="L467"></li>
<li class="L468" rel="L468">“I know you do; and it is _that_ which makes the wonder. With _your_</li>
<li class="L469" rel="L469">good sense, to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of</li>
<li class="L470" rel="L470">others! Affectation of candour is common enough--one meets with it</li>
<li class="L471" rel="L471">everywhere. But to be candid without ostentation or design--to take the</li>
<li class="L472" rel="L472">good of everybody&#39;s character and make it still better, and say nothing</li>
<li class="L473" rel="L473">of the bad--belongs to you alone. And so you like this man&#39;s sisters,</li>
<li class="L474" rel="L474">too, do you? Their manners are not equal to his.”</li>
<li class="L475" rel="L475"></li>
<li class="L476" rel="L476">“Certainly not--at first. But they are very pleasing women when you</li>
<li class="L477" rel="L477">converse with them. Miss Bingley is to live with her brother, and keep</li>
<li class="L478" rel="L478">his house; and I am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming</li>
<li class="L479" rel="L479">neighbour in her.”</li>
<li class="L480" rel="L480"></li>
<li class="L481" rel="L481">Elizabeth listened in silence, but was not convinced; their behaviour at</li>
<li class="L482" rel="L482">the assembly had not been calculated to please in general; and with more</li>
<li class="L483" rel="L483">quickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than her sister,</li>
<li class="L484" rel="L484">and with a judgement too unassailed by any attention to herself, she</li>
<li class="L485" rel="L485">was very little disposed to approve them. They were in fact very fine</li>
<li class="L486" rel="L486">ladies; not deficient in good humour when they were pleased, nor in the</li>
<li class="L487" rel="L487">power of making themselves agreeable when they chose it, but proud and</li>
<li class="L488" rel="L488">conceited. They were rather handsome, had been educated in one of the</li>
<li class="L489" rel="L489">first private seminaries in town, had a fortune of twenty thousand</li>
<li class="L490" rel="L490">pounds, were in the habit of spending more than they ought, and of</li>
<li class="L491" rel="L491">associating with people of rank, and were therefore in every respect</li>
<li class="L492" rel="L492">entitled to think well of themselves, and meanly of others. They were of</li>
<li class="L493" rel="L493">a respectable family in the north of England; a circumstance more deeply</li>
<li class="L494" rel="L494">impressed on their memories than that their brother&#39;s fortune and their</li>
<li class="L495" rel="L495">own had been acquired by trade.</li>
<li class="L496" rel="L496"></li>
<li class="L497" rel="L497">Mr. Bingley inherited property to the amount of nearly a hundred</li>
<li class="L498" rel="L498">thousand pounds from his father, who had intended to purchase an</li>
<li class="L499" rel="L499">estate, but did not live to do it. Mr. Bingley intended it likewise, and</li>
<li class="L500" rel="L500">sometimes made choice of his county; but as he was now provided with a</li>
<li class="L501" rel="L501">good house and the liberty of a manor, it was doubtful to many of those</li>
<li class="L502" rel="L502">who best knew the easiness of his temper, whether he might not spend the</li>
<li class="L503" rel="L503">remainder of his days at Netherfield, and leave the next generation to</li>
<li class="L504" rel="L504">purchase.</li>
<li class="L505" rel="L505"></li>
<li class="L506" rel="L506">His sisters were anxious for his having an estate of his own; but,</li>
<li class="L507" rel="L507">though he was now only established as a tenant, Miss Bingley was by no</li>
<li class="L508" rel="L508">means unwilling to preside at his table--nor was Mrs. Hurst, who had</li>
<li class="L509" rel="L509">married a man of more fashion than fortune, less disposed to consider</li>
<li class="L510" rel="L510">his house as her home when it suited her. Mr. Bingley had not been of</li>
<li class="L511" rel="L511">age two years, when he was tempted by an accidental recommendation</li>
<li class="L512" rel="L512">to look at Netherfield House. He did look at it, and into it for</li>
<li class="L513" rel="L513">half-an-hour--was pleased with the situation and the principal</li>
<li class="L514" rel="L514">rooms, satisfied with what the owner said in its praise, and took it</li>
<li class="L515" rel="L515">immediately.</li>
<li class="L516" rel="L516"></li>
<li class="L517" rel="L517">Between him and Darcy there was a very steady friendship, in spite of</li>
<li class="L518" rel="L518">great opposition of character. Bingley was endeared to Darcy by the</li>
<li class="L519" rel="L519">easiness, openness, and ductility of his temper, though no disposition</li>
<li class="L520" rel="L520">could offer a greater contrast to his own, and though with his own he</li>
<li class="L521" rel="L521">never appeared dissatisfied. On the strength of Darcy&#39;s regard, Bingley</li>
<li class="L522" rel="L522">had the firmest reliance, and of his judgement the highest opinion.</li>
<li class="L523" rel="L523">In understanding, Darcy was the superior. Bingley was by no means</li>
<li class="L524" rel="L524">deficient, but Darcy was clever. He was at the same time haughty,</li>
<li class="L525" rel="L525">reserved, and fastidious, and his manners, though well-bred, were not</li>
<li class="L526" rel="L526">inviting. In that respect his friend had greatly the advantage. Bingley</li>
<li class="L527" rel="L527">was sure of being liked wherever he appeared, Darcy was continually</li>
<li class="L528" rel="L528">giving offense.</li>
<li class="L529" rel="L529"></li>
<li class="L530" rel="L530">The manner in which they spoke of the Meryton assembly was sufficiently</li>
<li class="L531" rel="L531">characteristic. Bingley had never met with more pleasant people or</li>
<li class="L532" rel="L532">prettier girls in his life; everybody had been most kind and attentive</li>
<li class="L533" rel="L533">to him; there had been no formality, no stiffness; he had soon felt</li>
<li class="L534" rel="L534">acquainted with all the room; and, as to Miss Bennet, he could not</li>
<li class="L535" rel="L535">conceive an angel more beautiful. Darcy, on the contrary, had seen a</li>
<li class="L536" rel="L536">collection of people in whom there was little beauty and no fashion, for</li>
<li class="L537" rel="L537">none of whom he had felt the smallest interest, and from none received</li>
<li class="L538" rel="L538">either attention or pleasure. Miss Bennet he acknowledged to be pretty,</li>
<li class="L539" rel="L539">but she smiled too much.</li>
<li class="L540" rel="L540"></li>
<li class="L541" rel="L541">Mrs. Hurst and her sister allowed it to be so--but still they admired</li>
<li class="L542" rel="L542">her and liked her, and pronounced her to be a sweet girl, and one</li>
<li class="L543" rel="L543">whom they would not object to know more of. Miss Bennet was therefore</li>
<li class="L544" rel="L544">established as a sweet girl, and their brother felt authorized by such</li>
<li class="L545" rel="L545">commendation to think of her as he chose.</li>
<li class="L546" rel="L546"></li>
<li class="L547" rel="L547"></li>
<li class="L548" rel="L548"></li>
<li class="L549" rel="L549">Chapter 5</li>
<li class="L550" rel="L550"></li>
<li class="L551" rel="L551"></li>
<li class="L552" rel="L552">Within a short walk of Longbourn lived a family with whom the Bennets</li>
<li class="L553" rel="L553">were particularly intimate. Sir William Lucas had been formerly in trade</li>
<li class="L554" rel="L554">in Meryton, where he had made a tolerable fortune, and risen to the</li>
<li class="L555" rel="L555">honour of knighthood by an address to the king during his mayoralty.</li>
<li class="L556" rel="L556">The distinction had perhaps been felt too strongly. It had given him a</li>
<li class="L557" rel="L557">disgust to his business, and to his residence in a small market town;</li>
<li class="L558" rel="L558">and, in quitting them both, he had removed with his family to a house</li>
<li class="L559" rel="L559">about a mile from Meryton, denominated from that period Lucas Lodge,</li>
<li class="L560" rel="L560">where he could think with pleasure of his own importance, and,</li>
<li class="L561" rel="L561">unshackled by business, occupy himself solely in being civil to all</li>
<li class="L562" rel="L562">the world. For, though elated by his rank, it did not render him</li>
<li class="L563" rel="L563">supercilious; on the contrary, he was all attention to everybody. By</li>
<li class="L564" rel="L564">nature inoffensive, friendly, and obliging, his presentation at St.</li>
<li class="L565" rel="L565">James&#39;s had made him courteous.</li>
<li class="L566" rel="L566"></li>
<li class="L567" rel="L567">Lady Lucas was a very good kind of woman, not too clever to be a</li>
<li class="L568" rel="L568">valuable neighbour to Mrs. Bennet. They had several children. The eldest</li>
<li class="L569" rel="L569">of them, a sensible, intelligent young woman, about twenty-seven, was</li>
<li class="L570" rel="L570">Elizabeth&#39;s intimate friend.</li>
<li class="L571" rel="L571"></li>
<li class="L572" rel="L572">That the Miss Lucases and the Miss Bennets should meet to talk over</li>
<li class="L573" rel="L573">a ball was absolutely necessary; and the morning after the assembly</li>
<li class="L574" rel="L574">brought the former to Longbourn to hear and to communicate.</li>
<li class="L575" rel="L575"></li>
<li class="L576" rel="L576">“_You_ began the evening well, Charlotte,” said Mrs. Bennet with civil</li>
<li class="L577" rel="L577">self-command to Miss Lucas. “_You_ were Mr. Bingley&#39;s first choice.”</li>
<li class="L578" rel="L578"></li>
<li class="L579" rel="L579">“Yes; but he seemed to like his second better.”</li>
<li class="L580" rel="L580"></li>
<li class="L581" rel="L581">“Oh! you mean Jane, I suppose, because he danced with her twice. To be</li>
<li class="L582" rel="L582">sure that _did_ seem as if he admired her--indeed I rather believe he</li>
<li class="L583" rel="L583">_did_--I heard something about it--but I hardly know what--something</li>
<li class="L584" rel="L584">about Mr. Robinson.”</li>
<li class="L585" rel="L585"></li>
<li class="L586" rel="L586">“Perhaps you mean what I overheard between him and Mr. Robinson; did not</li>
<li class="L587" rel="L587">I mention it to you? Mr. Robinson&#39;s asking him how he liked our Meryton</li>
<li class="L588" rel="L588">assemblies, and whether he did not think there were a great many</li>
<li class="L589" rel="L589">pretty women in the room, and _which_ he thought the prettiest? and his</li>
<li class="L590" rel="L590">answering immediately to the last question: &#39;Oh! the eldest Miss Bennet,</li>
<li class="L591" rel="L591">beyond a doubt; there cannot be two opinions on that point.&#39;”</li>
<li class="L592" rel="L592"></li>
<li class="L593" rel="L593">“Upon my word! Well, that is very decided indeed--that does seem as</li>
<li class="L594" rel="L594">if--but, however, it may all come to nothing, you know.”</li>
<li class="L595" rel="L595"></li>
<li class="L596" rel="L596">“_My_ overhearings were more to the purpose than _yours_, Eliza,” said</li>
<li class="L597" rel="L597">Charlotte. “Mr. Darcy is not so well worth listening to as his friend,</li>
<li class="L598" rel="L598">is he?--poor Eliza!--to be only just _tolerable_.”</li>
<li class="L599" rel="L599"></li>
<li class="L600" rel="L600">“I beg you would not put it into Lizzy&#39;s head to be vexed by his</li>
<li class="L601" rel="L601">ill-treatment, for he is such a disagreeable man, that it would be quite</li>
<li class="L602" rel="L602">a misfortune to be liked by him. Mrs. Long told me last night that he</li>
<li class="L603" rel="L603">sat close to her for half-an-hour without once opening his lips.”</li>
<li class="L604" rel="L604"></li>
<li class="L605" rel="L605">“Are you quite sure, ma&#39;am?--is not there a little mistake?” said Jane.</li>
<li class="L606" rel="L606">“I certainly saw Mr. Darcy speaking to her.”</li>
<li class="L607" rel="L607"></li>
<li class="L608" rel="L608">“Aye--because she asked him at last how he liked Netherfield, and he</li>
<li class="L609" rel="L609">could not help answering her; but she said he seemed quite angry at</li>
<li class="L610" rel="L610">being spoke to.”</li>
<li class="L611" rel="L611"></li>
<li class="L612" rel="L612">“Miss Bingley told me,” said Jane, “that he never speaks much,</li>
<li class="L613" rel="L613">unless among his intimate acquaintances. With _them_ he is remarkably</li>
<li class="L614" rel="L614">agreeable.”</li>
<li class="L615" rel="L615"></li>
<li class="L616" rel="L616">“I do not believe a word of it, my dear. If he had been so very</li>
<li class="L617" rel="L617">agreeable, he would have talked to Mrs. Long. But I can guess how it</li>
<li class="L618" rel="L618">was; everybody says that he is eat up with pride, and I dare say he had</li>
<li class="L619" rel="L619">heard somehow that Mrs. Long does not keep a carriage, and had come to</li>
<li class="L620" rel="L620">the ball in a hack chaise.”</li>
<li class="L621" rel="L621"></li>
<li class="L622" rel="L622">“I do not mind his not talking to Mrs. Long,” said Miss Lucas, “but I</li>
<li class="L623" rel="L623">wish he had danced with Eliza.”</li>
<li class="L624" rel="L624"></li>
<li class="L625" rel="L625">“Another time, Lizzy,” said her mother, “I would not dance with _him_,</li>
<li class="L626" rel="L626">if I were you.”</li>
<li class="L627" rel="L627"></li>
<li class="L628" rel="L628">“I believe, ma&#39;am, I may safely promise you _never_ to dance with him.”</li>
<li class="L629" rel="L629"></li>
<li class="L630" rel="L630">“His pride,” said Miss Lucas, “does not offend _me_ so much as pride</li>
<li class="L631" rel="L631">often does, because there is an excuse for it. One cannot wonder that so</li>
<li class="L632" rel="L632">very fine a young man, with family, fortune, everything in his favour,</li>
<li class="L633" rel="L633">should think highly of himself. If I may so express it, he has a _right_</li>
<li class="L634" rel="L634">to be proud.”</li>
<li class="L635" rel="L635"></li>
<li class="L636" rel="L636">“That is very true,” replied Elizabeth, “and I could easily forgive</li>
<li class="L637" rel="L637">_his_ pride, if he had not mortified _mine_.”</li>
<li class="L638" rel="L638"></li>
<li class="L639" rel="L639">“Pride,” observed Mary, who piqued herself upon the solidity of her</li>
<li class="L640" rel="L640">reflections, “is a very common failing, I believe. By all that I have</li>
<li class="L641" rel="L641">ever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed; that human</li>
<li class="L642" rel="L642">nature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us</li>
<li class="L643" rel="L643">who do not cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some</li>
<li class="L644" rel="L644">quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different</li>
<li class="L645" rel="L645">things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may</li>
<li class="L646" rel="L646">be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of</li>
<li class="L647" rel="L647">ourselves, vanity to what we would have others think of us.”</li>
<li class="L648" rel="L648"></li>
<li class="L649" rel="L649">“If I were as rich as Mr. Darcy,” cried a young Lucas, who came with</li>
<li class="L650" rel="L650">his sisters, “I should not care how proud I was. I would keep a pack of</li>
<li class="L651" rel="L651">foxhounds, and drink a bottle of wine a day.”</li>
<li class="L652" rel="L652"></li>
<li class="L653" rel="L653">“Then you would drink a great deal more than you ought,” said Mrs.</li>
<li class="L654" rel="L654">Bennet; “and if I were to see you at it, I should take away your bottle</li>
<li class="L655" rel="L655">directly.”</li>
<li class="L656" rel="L656"></li>
<li class="L657" rel="L657">The boy protested that she should not; she continued to declare that she</li>
<li class="L658" rel="L658">would, and the argument ended only with the visit.</li>
<li class="L659" rel="L659"></li>
<li class="L660" rel="L660"></li>
<li class="L661" rel="L661"></li>
<li class="L662" rel="L662">Chapter 6</li>
<li class="L663" rel="L663"></li>
<li class="L664" rel="L664"></li>
<li class="L665" rel="L665">The ladies of Longbourn soon waited on those of Netherfield. The visit</li>
<li class="L666" rel="L666">was soon returned in due form. Miss Bennet&#39;s pleasing manners grew on</li>
<li class="L667" rel="L667">the goodwill of Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley; and though the mother was</li>
<li class="L668" rel="L668">found to be intolerable, and the younger sisters not worth speaking to,</li>
<li class="L669" rel="L669">a wish of being better acquainted with _them_ was expressed towards</li>
<li class="L670" rel="L670">the two eldest. By Jane, this attention was received with the greatest</li>
<li class="L671" rel="L671">pleasure, but Elizabeth still saw superciliousness in their treatment</li>
<li class="L672" rel="L672">of everybody, hardly excepting even her sister, and could not like them;</li>
<li class="L673" rel="L673">though their kindness to Jane, such as it was, had a value as arising in</li>
<li class="L674" rel="L674">all probability from the influence of their brother&#39;s admiration. It</li>
<li class="L675" rel="L675">was generally evident whenever they met, that he _did_ admire her and</li>
<li class="L676" rel="L676">to _her_ it was equally evident that Jane was yielding to the preference</li>
<li class="L677" rel="L677">which she had begun to entertain for him from the first, and was in a</li>
<li class="L678" rel="L678">way to be very much in love; but she considered with pleasure that it</li>
<li class="L679" rel="L679">was not likely to be discovered by the world in general, since Jane</li>
<li class="L680" rel="L680">united, with great strength of feeling, a composure of temper and a</li>
<li class="L681" rel="L681">uniform cheerfulness of manner which would guard her from the suspicions</li>
<li class="L682" rel="L682">of the impertinent. She mentioned this to her friend Miss Lucas.</li>
<li class="L683" rel="L683"></li>
<li class="L684" rel="L684">“It may perhaps be pleasant,” replied Charlotte, “to be able to impose</li>
<li class="L685" rel="L685">on the public in such a case; but it is sometimes a disadvantage to be</li>
<li class="L686" rel="L686">so very guarded. If a woman conceals her affection with the same skill</li>
<li class="L687" rel="L687">from the object of it, she may lose the opportunity of fixing him; and</li>
<li class="L688" rel="L688">it will then be but poor consolation to believe the world equally in</li>
<li class="L689" rel="L689">the dark. There is so much of gratitude or vanity in almost every</li>
<li class="L690" rel="L690">attachment, that it is not safe to leave any to itself. We can all</li>
<li class="L691" rel="L691">_begin_ freely--a slight preference is natural enough; but there are</li>
<li class="L692" rel="L692">very few of us who have heart enough to be really in love without</li>
<li class="L693" rel="L693">encouragement. In nine cases out of ten a women had better show _more_</li>
<li class="L694" rel="L694">affection than she feels. Bingley likes your sister undoubtedly; but he</li>
<li class="L695" rel="L695">may never do more than like her, if she does not help him on.”</li>
<li class="L696" rel="L696"></li>
<li class="L697" rel="L697">“But she does help him on, as much as her nature will allow. If I can</li>
<li class="L698" rel="L698">perceive her regard for him, he must be a simpleton, indeed, not to</li>
<li class="L699" rel="L699">discover it too.”</li>
<li class="L700" rel="L700"></li>
<li class="L701" rel="L701">“Remember, Eliza, that he does not know Jane&#39;s disposition as you do.”</li>
<li class="L702" rel="L702"></li>
<li class="L703" rel="L703">“But if a woman is partial to a man, and does not endeavour to conceal</li>
<li class="L704" rel="L704">it, he must find it out.”</li>
<li class="L705" rel="L705"></li>
<li class="L706" rel="L706">“Perhaps he must, if he sees enough of her. But, though Bingley and Jane</li>
<li class="L707" rel="L707">meet tolerably often, it is never for many hours together; and, as they</li>
<li class="L708" rel="L708">always see each other in large mixed parties, it is impossible that</li>
<li class="L709" rel="L709">every moment should be employed in conversing together. Jane should</li>
<li class="L710" rel="L710">therefore make the most of every half-hour in which she can command his</li>
<li class="L711" rel="L711">attention. When she is secure of him, there will be more leisure for</li>
<li class="L712" rel="L712">falling in love as much as she chooses.”</li>
<li class="L713" rel="L713"></li>
<li class="L714" rel="L714">“Your plan is a good one,” replied Elizabeth, “where nothing is in</li>
<li class="L715" rel="L715">question but the desire of being well married, and if I were determined</li>
<li class="L716" rel="L716">to get a rich husband, or any husband, I dare say I should adopt it. But</li>
<li class="L717" rel="L717">these are not Jane&#39;s feelings; she is not acting by design. As yet,</li>
<li class="L718" rel="L718">she cannot even be certain of the degree of her own regard nor of its</li>
<li class="L719" rel="L719">reasonableness. She has known him only a fortnight. She danced four</li>
<li class="L720" rel="L720">dances with him at Meryton; she saw him one morning at his own house,</li>
<li class="L721" rel="L721">and has since dined with him in company four times. This is not quite</li>
<li class="L722" rel="L722">enough to make her understand his character.”</li>
<li class="L723" rel="L723"></li>
<li class="L724" rel="L724">“Not as you represent it. Had she merely _dined_ with him, she might</li>
<li class="L725" rel="L725">only have discovered whether he had a good appetite; but you must</li>
<li class="L726" rel="L726">remember that four evenings have also been spent together--and four</li>
<li class="L727" rel="L727">evenings may do a great deal.”</li>
<li class="L728" rel="L728"></li>
<li class="L729" rel="L729">“Yes; these four evenings have enabled them to ascertain that they</li>
<li class="L730" rel="L730">both like Vingt-un better than Commerce; but with respect to any other</li>
<li class="L731" rel="L731">leading characteristic, I do not imagine that much has been unfolded.”</li>
<li class="L732" rel="L732"></li>
<li class="L733" rel="L733">“Well,” said Charlotte, “I wish Jane success with all my heart; and</li>
<li class="L734" rel="L734">if she were married to him to-morrow, I should think she had as good a</li>
<li class="L735" rel="L735">chance of happiness as if she were to be studying his character for a</li>
<li class="L736" rel="L736">twelvemonth. Happiness in marriage is entirely a matter of chance. If</li>
<li class="L737" rel="L737">the dispositions of the parties are ever so well known to each other or</li>
<li class="L738" rel="L738">ever so similar beforehand, it does not advance their felicity in the</li>
<li class="L739" rel="L739">least. They always continue to grow sufficiently unlike afterwards to</li>
<li class="L740" rel="L740">have their share of vexation; and it is better to know as little as</li>
<li class="L741" rel="L741">possible of the defects of the person with whom you are to pass your</li>
<li class="L742" rel="L742">life.”</li>
<li class="L743" rel="L743"></li>
<li class="L744" rel="L744">“You make me laugh, Charlotte; but it is not sound. You know it is not</li>
<li class="L745" rel="L745">sound, and that you would never act in this way yourself.”</li>
<li class="L746" rel="L746"></li>
<li class="L747" rel="L747">Occupied in observing Mr. Bingley&#39;s attentions to her sister, Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L748" rel="L748">was far from suspecting that she was herself becoming an object of some</li>
<li class="L749" rel="L749">interest in the eyes of his friend. Mr. Darcy had at first scarcely</li>
<li class="L750" rel="L750">allowed her to be pretty; he had looked at her without admiration at the</li>
<li class="L751" rel="L751">ball; and when they next met, he looked at her only to criticise. But no</li>
<li class="L752" rel="L752">sooner had he made it clear to himself and his friends that she hardly</li>
<li class="L753" rel="L753">had a good feature in her face, than he began to find it was rendered</li>
<li class="L754" rel="L754">uncommonly intelligent by the beautiful expression of her dark eyes. To</li>
<li class="L755" rel="L755">this discovery succeeded some others equally mortifying. Though he had</li>
<li class="L756" rel="L756">detected with a critical eye more than one failure of perfect symmetry</li>
<li class="L757" rel="L757">in her form, he was forced to acknowledge her figure to be light and</li>
<li class="L758" rel="L758">pleasing; and in spite of his asserting that her manners were not those</li>
<li class="L759" rel="L759">of the fashionable world, he was caught by their easy playfulness. Of</li>
<li class="L760" rel="L760">this she was perfectly unaware; to her he was only the man who made</li>
<li class="L761" rel="L761">himself agreeable nowhere, and who had not thought her handsome enough</li>
<li class="L762" rel="L762">to dance with.</li>
<li class="L763" rel="L763"></li>
<li class="L764" rel="L764">He began to wish to know more of her, and as a step towards conversing</li>
<li class="L765" rel="L765">with her himself, attended to her conversation with others. His doing so</li>
<li class="L766" rel="L766">drew her notice. It was at Sir William Lucas&#39;s, where a large party were</li>
<li class="L767" rel="L767">assembled.</li>
<li class="L768" rel="L768"></li>
<li class="L769" rel="L769">“What does Mr. Darcy mean,” said she to Charlotte, “by listening to my</li>
<li class="L770" rel="L770">conversation with Colonel Forster?”</li>
<li class="L771" rel="L771"></li>
<li class="L772" rel="L772">“That is a question which Mr. Darcy only can answer.”</li>
<li class="L773" rel="L773"></li>
<li class="L774" rel="L774">“But if he does it any more I shall certainly let him know that I see</li>
<li class="L775" rel="L775">what he is about. He has a very satirical eye, and if I do not begin by</li>
<li class="L776" rel="L776">being impertinent myself, I shall soon grow afraid of him.”</li>
<li class="L777" rel="L777"></li>
<li class="L778" rel="L778">On his approaching them soon afterwards, though without seeming to have</li>
<li class="L779" rel="L779">any intention of speaking, Miss Lucas defied her friend to mention such</li>
<li class="L780" rel="L780">a subject to him; which immediately provoking Elizabeth to do it, she</li>
<li class="L781" rel="L781">turned to him and said:</li>
<li class="L782" rel="L782"></li>
<li class="L783" rel="L783">“Did you not think, Mr. Darcy, that I expressed myself uncommonly</li>
<li class="L784" rel="L784">well just now, when I was teasing Colonel Forster to give us a ball at</li>
<li class="L785" rel="L785">Meryton?”</li>
<li class="L786" rel="L786"></li>
<li class="L787" rel="L787">“With great energy; but it is always a subject which makes a lady</li>
<li class="L788" rel="L788">energetic.”</li>
<li class="L789" rel="L789"></li>
<li class="L790" rel="L790">“You are severe on us.”</li>
<li class="L791" rel="L791"></li>
<li class="L792" rel="L792">“It will be _her_ turn soon to be teased,” said Miss Lucas. “I am going</li>
<li class="L793" rel="L793">to open the instrument, Eliza, and you know what follows.”</li>
<li class="L794" rel="L794"></li>
<li class="L795" rel="L795">“You are a very strange creature by way of a friend!--always wanting me</li>
<li class="L796" rel="L796">to play and sing before anybody and everybody! If my vanity had taken</li>
<li class="L797" rel="L797">a musical turn, you would have been invaluable; but as it is, I would</li>
<li class="L798" rel="L798">really rather not sit down before those who must be in the habit of</li>
<li class="L799" rel="L799">hearing the very best performers.” On Miss Lucas&#39;s persevering, however,</li>
<li class="L800" rel="L800">she added, “Very well, if it must be so, it must.” And gravely glancing</li>
<li class="L801" rel="L801">at Mr. Darcy, “There is a fine old saying, which everybody here is of</li>
<li class="L802" rel="L802">course familiar with: &#39;Keep your breath to cool your porridge&#39;; and I</li>
<li class="L803" rel="L803">shall keep mine to swell my song.”</li>
<li class="L804" rel="L804"></li>
<li class="L805" rel="L805">Her performance was pleasing, though by no means capital. After a song</li>
<li class="L806" rel="L806">or two, and before she could reply to the entreaties of several that</li>
<li class="L807" rel="L807">she would sing again, she was eagerly succeeded at the instrument by her</li>
<li class="L808" rel="L808">sister Mary, who having, in consequence of being the only plain one in</li>
<li class="L809" rel="L809">the family, worked hard for knowledge and accomplishments, was always</li>
<li class="L810" rel="L810">impatient for display.</li>
<li class="L811" rel="L811"></li>
<li class="L812" rel="L812">Mary had neither genius nor taste; and though vanity had given her</li>
<li class="L813" rel="L813">application, it had given her likewise a pedantic air and conceited</li>
<li class="L814" rel="L814">manner, which would have injured a higher degree of excellence than she</li>
<li class="L815" rel="L815">had reached. Elizabeth, easy and unaffected, had been listened to with</li>
<li class="L816" rel="L816">much more pleasure, though not playing half so well; and Mary, at the</li>
<li class="L817" rel="L817">end of a long concerto, was glad to purchase praise and gratitude by</li>
<li class="L818" rel="L818">Scotch and Irish airs, at the request of her younger sisters, who,</li>
<li class="L819" rel="L819">with some of the Lucases, and two or three officers, joined eagerly in</li>
<li class="L820" rel="L820">dancing at one end of the room.</li>
<li class="L821" rel="L821"></li>
<li class="L822" rel="L822">Mr. Darcy stood near them in silent indignation at such a mode of</li>
<li class="L823" rel="L823">passing the evening, to the exclusion of all conversation, and was too</li>
<li class="L824" rel="L824">much engrossed by his thoughts to perceive that Sir William Lucas was</li>
<li class="L825" rel="L825">his neighbour, till Sir William thus began:</li>
<li class="L826" rel="L826"></li>
<li class="L827" rel="L827">“What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy! There</li>
<li class="L828" rel="L828">is nothing like dancing after all. I consider it as one of the first</li>
<li class="L829" rel="L829">refinements of polished society.”</li>
<li class="L830" rel="L830"></li>
<li class="L831" rel="L831">“Certainly, sir; and it has the advantage also of being in vogue amongst</li>
<li class="L832" rel="L832">the less polished societies of the world. Every savage can dance.”</li>
<li class="L833" rel="L833"></li>
<li class="L834" rel="L834">Sir William only smiled. “Your friend performs delightfully,” he</li>
<li class="L835" rel="L835">continued after a pause, on seeing Bingley join the group; “and I doubt</li>
<li class="L836" rel="L836">not that you are an adept in the science yourself, Mr. Darcy.”</li>
<li class="L837" rel="L837"></li>
<li class="L838" rel="L838">“You saw me dance at Meryton, I believe, sir.”</li>
<li class="L839" rel="L839"></li>
<li class="L840" rel="L840">“Yes, indeed, and received no inconsiderable pleasure from the sight. Do</li>
<li class="L841" rel="L841">you often dance at St. James&#39;s?”</li>
<li class="L842" rel="L842"></li>
<li class="L843" rel="L843">“Never, sir.”</li>
<li class="L844" rel="L844"></li>
<li class="L845" rel="L845">“Do you not think it would be a proper compliment to the place?”</li>
<li class="L846" rel="L846"></li>
<li class="L847" rel="L847">“It is a compliment which I never pay to any place if I can avoid it.”</li>
<li class="L848" rel="L848"></li>
<li class="L849" rel="L849">“You have a house in town, I conclude?”</li>
<li class="L850" rel="L850"></li>
<li class="L851" rel="L851">Mr. Darcy bowed.</li>
<li class="L852" rel="L852"></li>
<li class="L853" rel="L853">“I had once had some thought of fixing in town myself--for I am fond</li>
<li class="L854" rel="L854">of superior society; but I did not feel quite certain that the air of</li>
<li class="L855" rel="L855">London would agree with Lady Lucas.”</li>
<li class="L856" rel="L856"></li>
<li class="L857" rel="L857">He paused in hopes of an answer; but his companion was not disposed</li>
<li class="L858" rel="L858">to make any; and Elizabeth at that instant moving towards them, he was</li>
<li class="L859" rel="L859">struck with the action of doing a very gallant thing, and called out to</li>
<li class="L860" rel="L860">her:</li>
<li class="L861" rel="L861"></li>
<li class="L862" rel="L862">“My dear Miss Eliza, why are you not dancing? Mr. Darcy, you must allow</li>
<li class="L863" rel="L863">me to present this young lady to you as a very desirable partner. You</li>
<li class="L864" rel="L864">cannot refuse to dance, I am sure when so much beauty is before you.”</li>
<li class="L865" rel="L865"> And, taking her hand, he would have given it to Mr. Darcy who, though</li>
<li class="L866" rel="L866">extremely surprised, was not unwilling to receive it, when she instantly</li>
<li class="L867" rel="L867">drew back, and said with some discomposure to Sir William:</li>
<li class="L868" rel="L868"></li>
<li class="L869" rel="L869">“Indeed, sir, I have not the least intention of dancing. I entreat you</li>
<li class="L870" rel="L870">not to suppose that I moved this way in order to beg for a partner.”</li>
<li class="L871" rel="L871"></li>
<li class="L872" rel="L872">Mr. Darcy, with grave propriety, requested to be allowed the honour of</li>
<li class="L873" rel="L873">her hand, but in vain. Elizabeth was determined; nor did Sir William at</li>
<li class="L874" rel="L874">all shake her purpose by his attempt at persuasion.</li>
<li class="L875" rel="L875"></li>
<li class="L876" rel="L876">“You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny</li>
<li class="L877" rel="L877">me the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the</li>
<li class="L878" rel="L878">amusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us</li>
<li class="L879" rel="L879">for one half-hour.”</li>
<li class="L880" rel="L880"></li>
<li class="L881" rel="L881">“Mr. Darcy is all politeness,” said Elizabeth, smiling.</li>
<li class="L882" rel="L882"></li>
<li class="L883" rel="L883">“He is, indeed; but, considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza,</li>
<li class="L884" rel="L884">we cannot wonder at his complaisance--for who would object to such a</li>
<li class="L885" rel="L885">partner?”</li>
<li class="L886" rel="L886"></li>
<li class="L887" rel="L887">Elizabeth looked archly, and turned away. Her resistance had not</li>
<li class="L888" rel="L888">injured her with the gentleman, and he was thinking of her with some</li>
<li class="L889" rel="L889">complacency, when thus accosted by Miss Bingley:</li>
<li class="L890" rel="L890"></li>
<li class="L891" rel="L891">“I can guess the subject of your reverie.”</li>
<li class="L892" rel="L892"></li>
<li class="L893" rel="L893">“I should imagine not.”</li>
<li class="L894" rel="L894"></li>
<li class="L895" rel="L895">“You are considering how insupportable it would be to pass many evenings</li>
<li class="L896" rel="L896">in this manner--in such society; and indeed I am quite of your opinion.</li>
<li class="L897" rel="L897">I was never more annoyed! The insipidity, and yet the noise--the</li>
<li class="L898" rel="L898">nothingness, and yet the self-importance of all those people! What would</li>
<li class="L899" rel="L899">I give to hear your strictures on them!”</li>
<li class="L900" rel="L900"></li>
<li class="L901" rel="L901">“Your conjecture is totally wrong, I assure you. My mind was more</li>
<li class="L902" rel="L902">agreeably engaged. I have been meditating on the very great pleasure</li>
<li class="L903" rel="L903">which a pair of fine eyes in the face of a pretty woman can bestow.”</li>
<li class="L904" rel="L904"></li>
<li class="L905" rel="L905">Miss Bingley immediately fixed her eyes on his face, and desired he</li>
<li class="L906" rel="L906">would tell her what lady had the credit of inspiring such reflections.</li>
<li class="L907" rel="L907">Mr. Darcy replied with great intrepidity:</li>
<li class="L908" rel="L908"></li>
<li class="L909" rel="L909">“Miss Elizabeth Bennet.”</li>
<li class="L910" rel="L910"></li>
<li class="L911" rel="L911">“Miss Elizabeth Bennet!” repeated Miss Bingley. “I am all astonishment.</li>
<li class="L912" rel="L912">How long has she been such a favourite?--and pray, when am I to wish you</li>
<li class="L913" rel="L913">joy?”</li>
<li class="L914" rel="L914"></li>
<li class="L915" rel="L915">“That is exactly the question which I expected you to ask. A lady&#39;s</li>
<li class="L916" rel="L916">imagination is very rapid; it jumps from admiration to love, from love</li>
<li class="L917" rel="L917">to matrimony, in a moment. I knew you would be wishing me joy.”</li>
<li class="L918" rel="L918"></li>
<li class="L919" rel="L919">“Nay, if you are serious about it, I shall consider the matter is</li>
<li class="L920" rel="L920">absolutely settled. You will be having a charming mother-in-law, indeed;</li>
<li class="L921" rel="L921">and, of course, she will always be at Pemberley with you.”</li>
<li class="L922" rel="L922"></li>
<li class="L923" rel="L923">He listened to her with perfect indifference while she chose to</li>
<li class="L924" rel="L924">entertain herself in this manner; and as his composure convinced her</li>
<li class="L925" rel="L925">that all was safe, her wit flowed long.</li>
<li class="L926" rel="L926"></li>
<li class="L927" rel="L927"></li>
<li class="L928" rel="L928"></li>
<li class="L929" rel="L929">Chapter 7</li>
<li class="L930" rel="L930"></li>
<li class="L931" rel="L931"></li>
<li class="L932" rel="L932">Mr. Bennet&#39;s property consisted almost entirely in an estate of two</li>
<li class="L933" rel="L933">thousand a year, which, unfortunately for his daughters, was entailed,</li>
<li class="L934" rel="L934">in default of heirs male, on a distant relation; and their mother&#39;s</li>
<li class="L935" rel="L935">fortune, though ample for her situation in life, could but ill supply</li>
<li class="L936" rel="L936">the deficiency of his. Her father had been an attorney in Meryton, and</li>
<li class="L937" rel="L937">had left her four thousand pounds.</li>
<li class="L938" rel="L938"></li>
<li class="L939" rel="L939">She had a sister married to a Mr. Phillips, who had been a clerk to</li>
<li class="L940" rel="L940">their father and succeeded him in the business, and a brother settled in</li>
<li class="L941" rel="L941">London in a respectable line of trade.</li>
<li class="L942" rel="L942"></li>
<li class="L943" rel="L943">The village of Longbourn was only one mile from Meryton; a most</li>
<li class="L944" rel="L944">convenient distance for the young ladies, who were usually tempted</li>
<li class="L945" rel="L945">thither three or four times a week, to pay their duty to their aunt and</li>
<li class="L946" rel="L946">to a milliner&#39;s shop just over the way. The two youngest of the family,</li>
<li class="L947" rel="L947">Catherine and Lydia, were particularly frequent in these attentions;</li>
<li class="L948" rel="L948">their minds were more vacant than their sisters&#39;, and when nothing</li>
<li class="L949" rel="L949">better offered, a walk to Meryton was necessary to amuse their morning</li>
<li class="L950" rel="L950">hours and furnish conversation for the evening; and however bare of news</li>
<li class="L951" rel="L951">the country in general might be, they always contrived to learn some</li>
<li class="L952" rel="L952">from their aunt. At present, indeed, they were well supplied both with</li>
<li class="L953" rel="L953">news and happiness by the recent arrival of a militia regiment in the</li>
<li class="L954" rel="L954">neighbourhood; it was to remain the whole winter, and Meryton was the</li>
<li class="L955" rel="L955">headquarters.</li>
<li class="L956" rel="L956"></li>
<li class="L957" rel="L957">Their visits to Mrs. Phillips were now productive of the most</li>
<li class="L958" rel="L958">interesting intelligence. Every day added something to their knowledge</li>
<li class="L959" rel="L959">of the officers&#39; names and connections. Their lodgings were not long a</li>
<li class="L960" rel="L960">secret, and at length they began to know the officers themselves. Mr.</li>
<li class="L961" rel="L961">Phillips visited them all, and this opened to his nieces a store of</li>
<li class="L962" rel="L962">felicity unknown before. They could talk of nothing but officers; and</li>
<li class="L963" rel="L963">Mr. Bingley&#39;s large fortune, the mention of which gave animation</li>
<li class="L964" rel="L964">to their mother, was worthless in their eyes when opposed to the</li>
<li class="L965" rel="L965">regimentals of an ensign.</li>
<li class="L966" rel="L966"></li>
<li class="L967" rel="L967">After listening one morning to their effusions on this subject, Mr.</li>
<li class="L968" rel="L968">Bennet coolly observed:</li>
<li class="L969" rel="L969"></li>
<li class="L970" rel="L970">“From all that I can collect by your manner of talking, you must be two</li>
<li class="L971" rel="L971">of the silliest girls in the country. I have suspected it some time, but</li>
<li class="L972" rel="L972">I am now convinced.”</li>
<li class="L973" rel="L973"></li>
<li class="L974" rel="L974">Catherine was disconcerted, and made no answer; but Lydia, with perfect</li>
<li class="L975" rel="L975">indifference, continued to express her admiration of Captain Carter,</li>
<li class="L976" rel="L976">and her hope of seeing him in the course of the day, as he was going the</li>
<li class="L977" rel="L977">next morning to London.</li>
<li class="L978" rel="L978"></li>
<li class="L979" rel="L979">“I am astonished, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “that you should be so</li>
<li class="L980" rel="L980">ready to think your own children silly. If I wished to think slightingly</li>
<li class="L981" rel="L981">of anybody&#39;s children, it should not be of my own, however.”</li>
<li class="L982" rel="L982"></li>
<li class="L983" rel="L983">“If my children are silly, I must hope to be always sensible of it.”</li>
<li class="L984" rel="L984"></li>
<li class="L985" rel="L985">“Yes--but as it happens, they are all of them very clever.”</li>
<li class="L986" rel="L986"></li>
<li class="L987" rel="L987">“This is the only point, I flatter myself, on which we do not agree. I</li>
<li class="L988" rel="L988">had hoped that our sentiments coincided in every particular, but I must</li>
<li class="L989" rel="L989">so far differ from you as to think our two youngest daughters uncommonly</li>
<li class="L990" rel="L990">foolish.”</li>
<li class="L991" rel="L991"></li>
<li class="L992" rel="L992">“My dear Mr. Bennet, you must not expect such girls to have the sense of</li>
<li class="L993" rel="L993">their father and mother. When they get to our age, I dare say they will</li>
<li class="L994" rel="L994">not think about officers any more than we do. I remember the time when</li>
<li class="L995" rel="L995">I liked a red coat myself very well--and, indeed, so I do still at my</li>
<li class="L996" rel="L996">heart; and if a smart young colonel, with five or six thousand a year,</li>
<li class="L997" rel="L997">should want one of my girls I shall not say nay to him; and I thought</li>
<li class="L998" rel="L998">Colonel Forster looked very becoming the other night at Sir William&#39;s in</li>
<li class="L999" rel="L999">his regimentals.”</li>
<li class="L1000" rel="L1000"></li>
<li class="L1001" rel="L1001">“Mamma,” cried Lydia, “my aunt says that Colonel Forster and Captain</li>
<li class="L1002" rel="L1002">Carter do not go so often to Miss Watson&#39;s as they did when they first</li>
<li class="L1003" rel="L1003">came; she sees them now very often standing in Clarke&#39;s library.”</li>
<li class="L1004" rel="L1004"></li>
<li class="L1005" rel="L1005">Mrs. Bennet was prevented replying by the entrance of the footman with</li>
<li class="L1006" rel="L1006">a note for Miss Bennet; it came from Netherfield, and the servant waited</li>
<li class="L1007" rel="L1007">for an answer. Mrs. Bennet&#39;s eyes sparkled with pleasure, and she was</li>
<li class="L1008" rel="L1008">eagerly calling out, while her daughter read,</li>
<li class="L1009" rel="L1009"></li>
<li class="L1010" rel="L1010">“Well, Jane, who is it from? What is it about? What does he say? Well,</li>
<li class="L1011" rel="L1011">Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.”</li>
<li class="L1012" rel="L1012"></li>
<li class="L1013" rel="L1013">“It is from Miss Bingley,” said Jane, and then read it aloud.</li>
<li class="L1014" rel="L1014"></li>
<li class="L1015" rel="L1015">“MY DEAR FRIEND,--</li>
<li class="L1016" rel="L1016"></li>
<li class="L1017" rel="L1017">“If you are not so compassionate as to dine to-day with Louisa and me,</li>
<li class="L1018" rel="L1018">we shall be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives,</li>
<li class="L1019" rel="L1019">for a whole day&#39;s tete-a-tete between two women can never end without a</li>
<li class="L1020" rel="L1020">quarrel. Come as soon as you can on receipt of this. My brother and the</li>
<li class="L1021" rel="L1021">gentlemen are to dine with the officers.--Yours ever,</li>
<li class="L1022" rel="L1022"></li>
<li class="L1023" rel="L1023">“CAROLINE BINGLEY”</li>
<li class="L1024" rel="L1024"></li>
