<li class="L1025" rel="L1025">“With the officers!” cried Lydia. “I wonder my aunt did not tell us of</li>
<li class="L1026" rel="L1026">_that_.”</li>
<li class="L1027" rel="L1027"></li>
<li class="L1028" rel="L1028">“Dining out,” said Mrs. Bennet, “that is very unlucky.”</li>
<li class="L1029" rel="L1029"></li>
<li class="L1030" rel="L1030">“Can I have the carriage?” said Jane.</li>
<li class="L1031" rel="L1031"></li>
<li class="L1032" rel="L1032">“No, my dear, you had better go on horseback, because it seems likely to</li>
<li class="L1033" rel="L1033">rain; and then you must stay all night.”</li>
<li class="L1034" rel="L1034"></li>
<li class="L1035" rel="L1035">“That would be a good scheme,” said Elizabeth, “if you were sure that</li>
<li class="L1036" rel="L1036">they would not offer to send her home.”</li>
<li class="L1037" rel="L1037"></li>
<li class="L1038" rel="L1038">“Oh! but the gentlemen will have Mr. Bingley&#39;s chaise to go to Meryton,</li>
<li class="L1039" rel="L1039">and the Hursts have no horses to theirs.”</li>
<li class="L1040" rel="L1040"></li>
<li class="L1041" rel="L1041">“I had much rather go in the coach.”</li>
<li class="L1042" rel="L1042"></li>
<li class="L1043" rel="L1043">“But, my dear, your father cannot spare the horses, I am sure. They are</li>
<li class="L1044" rel="L1044">wanted in the farm, Mr. Bennet, are they not?”</li>
<li class="L1045" rel="L1045"></li>
<li class="L1046" rel="L1046">“They are wanted in the farm much oftener than I can get them.”</li>
<li class="L1047" rel="L1047"></li>
<li class="L1048" rel="L1048">“But if you have got them to-day,” said Elizabeth, “my mother&#39;s purpose</li>
<li class="L1049" rel="L1049">will be answered.”</li>
<li class="L1050" rel="L1050"></li>
<li class="L1051" rel="L1051">She did at last extort from her father an acknowledgment that the horses</li>
<li class="L1052" rel="L1052">were engaged. Jane was therefore obliged to go on horseback, and her</li>
<li class="L1053" rel="L1053">mother attended her to the door with many cheerful prognostics of a</li>
<li class="L1054" rel="L1054">bad day. Her hopes were answered; Jane had not been gone long before</li>
<li class="L1055" rel="L1055">it rained hard. Her sisters were uneasy for her, but her mother was</li>
<li class="L1056" rel="L1056">delighted. The rain continued the whole evening without intermission;</li>
<li class="L1057" rel="L1057">Jane certainly could not come back.</li>
<li class="L1058" rel="L1058"></li>
<li class="L1059" rel="L1059">“This was a lucky idea of mine, indeed!” said Mrs. Bennet more than</li>
<li class="L1060" rel="L1060">once, as if the credit of making it rain were all her own. Till the</li>
<li class="L1061" rel="L1061">next morning, however, she was not aware of all the felicity of her</li>
<li class="L1062" rel="L1062">contrivance. Breakfast was scarcely over when a servant from Netherfield</li>
<li class="L1063" rel="L1063">brought the following note for Elizabeth:</li>
<li class="L1064" rel="L1064"></li>
<li class="L1065" rel="L1065">“MY DEAREST LIZZY,--</li>
<li class="L1066" rel="L1066"></li>
<li class="L1067" rel="L1067">“I find myself very unwell this morning, which, I suppose, is to be</li>
<li class="L1068" rel="L1068">imputed to my getting wet through yesterday. My kind friends will not</li>
<li class="L1069" rel="L1069">hear of my returning till I am better. They insist also on my seeing Mr.</li>
<li class="L1070" rel="L1070">Jones--therefore do not be alarmed if you should hear of his having been</li>
<li class="L1071" rel="L1071">to me--and, excepting a sore throat and headache, there is not much the</li>
<li class="L1072" rel="L1072">matter with me.--Yours, etc.”</li>
<li class="L1073" rel="L1073"></li>
<li class="L1074" rel="L1074">“Well, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet, when Elizabeth had read the note</li>
<li class="L1075" rel="L1075">aloud, “if your daughter should have a dangerous fit of illness--if she</li>
<li class="L1076" rel="L1076">should die, it would be a comfort to know that it was all in pursuit of</li>
<li class="L1077" rel="L1077">Mr. Bingley, and under your orders.”</li>
<li class="L1078" rel="L1078"></li>
<li class="L1079" rel="L1079">“Oh! I am not afraid of her dying. People do not die of little trifling</li>
<li class="L1080" rel="L1080">colds. She will be taken good care of. As long as she stays there, it is</li>
<li class="L1081" rel="L1081">all very well. I would go and see her if I could have the carriage.”</li>
<li class="L1082" rel="L1082"></li>
<li class="L1083" rel="L1083">Elizabeth, feeling really anxious, was determined to go to her, though</li>
<li class="L1084" rel="L1084">the carriage was not to be had; and as she was no horsewoman, walking</li>
<li class="L1085" rel="L1085">was her only alternative. She declared her resolution.</li>
<li class="L1086" rel="L1086"></li>
<li class="L1087" rel="L1087">“How can you be so silly,” cried her mother, “as to think of such a</li>
<li class="L1088" rel="L1088">thing, in all this dirt! You will not be fit to be seen when you get</li>
<li class="L1089" rel="L1089">there.”</li>
<li class="L1090" rel="L1090"></li>
<li class="L1091" rel="L1091">“I shall be very fit to see Jane--which is all I want.”</li>
<li class="L1092" rel="L1092"></li>
<li class="L1093" rel="L1093">“Is this a hint to me, Lizzy,” said her father, “to send for the</li>
<li class="L1094" rel="L1094">horses?”</li>
<li class="L1095" rel="L1095"></li>
<li class="L1096" rel="L1096">“No, indeed, I do not wish to avoid the walk. The distance is nothing</li>
<li class="L1097" rel="L1097">when one has a motive; only three miles. I shall be back by dinner.”</li>
<li class="L1098" rel="L1098"></li>
<li class="L1099" rel="L1099">“I admire the activity of your benevolence,” observed Mary, “but every</li>
<li class="L1100" rel="L1100">impulse of feeling should be guided by reason; and, in my opinion,</li>
<li class="L1101" rel="L1101">exertion should always be in proportion to what is required.”</li>
<li class="L1102" rel="L1102"></li>
<li class="L1103" rel="L1103">“We will go as far as Meryton with you,” said Catherine and Lydia.</li>
<li class="L1104" rel="L1104">Elizabeth accepted their company, and the three young ladies set off</li>
<li class="L1105" rel="L1105">together.</li>
<li class="L1106" rel="L1106"></li>
<li class="L1107" rel="L1107">“If we make haste,” said Lydia, as they walked along, “perhaps we may</li>
<li class="L1108" rel="L1108">see something of Captain Carter before he goes.”</li>
<li class="L1109" rel="L1109"></li>
<li class="L1110" rel="L1110">In Meryton they parted; the two youngest repaired to the lodgings of one</li>
<li class="L1111" rel="L1111">of the officers&#39; wives, and Elizabeth continued her walk alone, crossing</li>
<li class="L1112" rel="L1112">field after field at a quick pace, jumping over stiles and springing</li>
<li class="L1113" rel="L1113">over puddles with impatient activity, and finding herself at last</li>
<li class="L1114" rel="L1114">within view of the house, with weary ankles, dirty stockings, and a face</li>
<li class="L1115" rel="L1115">glowing with the warmth of exercise.</li>
<li class="L1116" rel="L1116"></li>
<li class="L1117" rel="L1117">She was shown into the breakfast-parlour, where all but Jane were</li>
<li class="L1118" rel="L1118">assembled, and where her appearance created a great deal of surprise.</li>
<li class="L1119" rel="L1119">That she should have walked three miles so early in the day, in such</li>
<li class="L1120" rel="L1120">dirty weather, and by herself, was almost incredible to Mrs. Hurst and</li>
<li class="L1121" rel="L1121">Miss Bingley; and Elizabeth was convinced that they held her in contempt</li>
<li class="L1122" rel="L1122">for it. She was received, however, very politely by them; and in their</li>
<li class="L1123" rel="L1123">brother&#39;s manners there was something better than politeness; there</li>
<li class="L1124" rel="L1124">was good humour and kindness. Mr. Darcy said very little, and Mr.</li>
<li class="L1125" rel="L1125">Hurst nothing at all. The former was divided between admiration of the</li>
<li class="L1126" rel="L1126">brilliancy which exercise had given to her complexion, and doubt as</li>
<li class="L1127" rel="L1127">to the occasion&#39;s justifying her coming so far alone. The latter was</li>
<li class="L1128" rel="L1128">thinking only of his breakfast.</li>
<li class="L1129" rel="L1129"></li>
<li class="L1130" rel="L1130">Her inquiries after her sister were not very favourably answered. Miss</li>
<li class="L1131" rel="L1131">Bennet had slept ill, and though up, was very feverish, and not</li>
<li class="L1132" rel="L1132">well enough to leave her room. Elizabeth was glad to be taken to her</li>
<li class="L1133" rel="L1133">immediately; and Jane, who had only been withheld by the fear of giving</li>
<li class="L1134" rel="L1134">alarm or inconvenience from expressing in her note how much she longed</li>
<li class="L1135" rel="L1135">for such a visit, was delighted at her entrance. She was not equal,</li>
<li class="L1136" rel="L1136">however, to much conversation, and when Miss Bingley left them</li>
<li class="L1137" rel="L1137">together, could attempt little besides expressions of gratitude for the</li>
<li class="L1138" rel="L1138">extraordinary kindness she was treated with. Elizabeth silently attended</li>
<li class="L1139" rel="L1139">her.</li>
<li class="L1140" rel="L1140"></li>
<li class="L1141" rel="L1141">When breakfast was over they were joined by the sisters; and Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L1142" rel="L1142">began to like them herself, when she saw how much affection and</li>
<li class="L1143" rel="L1143">solicitude they showed for Jane. The apothecary came, and having</li>
<li class="L1144" rel="L1144">examined his patient, said, as might be supposed, that she had caught</li>
<li class="L1145" rel="L1145">a violent cold, and that they must endeavour to get the better of it;</li>
<li class="L1146" rel="L1146">advised her to return to bed, and promised her some draughts. The advice</li>
<li class="L1147" rel="L1147">was followed readily, for the feverish symptoms increased, and her head</li>
<li class="L1148" rel="L1148">ached acutely. Elizabeth did not quit her room for a moment; nor were</li>
<li class="L1149" rel="L1149">the other ladies often absent; the gentlemen being out, they had, in</li>
<li class="L1150" rel="L1150">fact, nothing to do elsewhere.</li>
<li class="L1151" rel="L1151"></li>
<li class="L1152" rel="L1152">When the clock struck three, Elizabeth felt that she must go, and very</li>
<li class="L1153" rel="L1153">unwillingly said so. Miss Bingley offered her the carriage, and she only</li>
<li class="L1154" rel="L1154">wanted a little pressing to accept it, when Jane testified such concern</li>
<li class="L1155" rel="L1155">in parting with her, that Miss Bingley was obliged to convert the offer</li>
<li class="L1156" rel="L1156">of the chaise to an invitation to remain at Netherfield for the present.</li>
<li class="L1157" rel="L1157">Elizabeth most thankfully consented, and a servant was dispatched to</li>
<li class="L1158" rel="L1158">Longbourn to acquaint the family with her stay and bring back a supply</li>
<li class="L1159" rel="L1159">of clothes.</li>
<li class="L1160" rel="L1160"></li>
<li class="L1161" rel="L1161"></li>
<li class="L1162" rel="L1162"></li>
<li class="L1163" rel="L1163">Chapter 8</li>
<li class="L1164" rel="L1164"></li>
<li class="L1165" rel="L1165"></li>
<li class="L1166" rel="L1166">At five o&#39;clock the two ladies retired to dress, and at half-past six</li>
<li class="L1167" rel="L1167">Elizabeth was summoned to dinner. To the civil inquiries which then</li>
<li class="L1168" rel="L1168">poured in, and amongst which she had the pleasure of distinguishing the</li>
<li class="L1169" rel="L1169">much superior solicitude of Mr. Bingley&#39;s, she could not make a very</li>
<li class="L1170" rel="L1170">favourable answer. Jane was by no means better. The sisters, on hearing</li>
<li class="L1171" rel="L1171">this, repeated three or four times how much they were grieved, how</li>
<li class="L1172" rel="L1172">shocking it was to have a bad cold, and how excessively they disliked</li>
<li class="L1173" rel="L1173">being ill themselves; and then thought no more of the matter: and their</li>
<li class="L1174" rel="L1174">indifference towards Jane when not immediately before them restored</li>
<li class="L1175" rel="L1175">Elizabeth to the enjoyment of all her former dislike.</li>
<li class="L1176" rel="L1176"></li>
<li class="L1177" rel="L1177">Their brother, indeed, was the only one of the party whom she could</li>
<li class="L1178" rel="L1178">regard with any complacency. His anxiety for Jane was evident, and his</li>
<li class="L1179" rel="L1179">attentions to herself most pleasing, and they prevented her feeling</li>
<li class="L1180" rel="L1180">herself so much an intruder as she believed she was considered by the</li>
<li class="L1181" rel="L1181">others. She had very little notice from any but him. Miss Bingley was</li>
<li class="L1182" rel="L1182">engrossed by Mr. Darcy, her sister scarcely less so; and as for Mr.</li>
<li class="L1183" rel="L1183">Hurst, by whom Elizabeth sat, he was an indolent man, who lived only to</li>
<li class="L1184" rel="L1184">eat, drink, and play at cards; who, when he found her to prefer a plain</li>
<li class="L1185" rel="L1185">dish to a ragout, had nothing to say to her.</li>
<li class="L1186" rel="L1186"></li>
<li class="L1187" rel="L1187">When dinner was over, she returned directly to Jane, and Miss Bingley</li>
<li class="L1188" rel="L1188">began abusing her as soon as she was out of the room. Her manners were</li>
<li class="L1189" rel="L1189">pronounced to be very bad indeed, a mixture of pride and impertinence;</li>
<li class="L1190" rel="L1190">she had no conversation, no style, no beauty. Mrs. Hurst thought the</li>
<li class="L1191" rel="L1191">same, and added:</li>
<li class="L1192" rel="L1192"></li>
<li class="L1193" rel="L1193">“She has nothing, in short, to recommend her, but being an excellent</li>
<li class="L1194" rel="L1194">walker. I shall never forget her appearance this morning. She really</li>
<li class="L1195" rel="L1195">looked almost wild.”</li>
<li class="L1196" rel="L1196"></li>
<li class="L1197" rel="L1197">“She did, indeed, Louisa. I could hardly keep my countenance. Very</li>
<li class="L1198" rel="L1198">nonsensical to come at all! Why must _she_ be scampering about the</li>
<li class="L1199" rel="L1199">country, because her sister had a cold? Her hair, so untidy, so blowsy!”</li>
<li class="L1200" rel="L1200"></li>
<li class="L1201" rel="L1201">“Yes, and her petticoat; I hope you saw her petticoat, six inches deep</li>
<li class="L1202" rel="L1202">in mud, I am absolutely certain; and the gown which had been let down to</li>
<li class="L1203" rel="L1203">hide it not doing its office.”</li>
<li class="L1204" rel="L1204"></li>
<li class="L1205" rel="L1205">“Your picture may be very exact, Louisa,” said Bingley; “but this was</li>
<li class="L1206" rel="L1206">all lost upon me. I thought Miss Elizabeth Bennet looked remarkably</li>
<li class="L1207" rel="L1207">well when she came into the room this morning. Her dirty petticoat quite</li>
<li class="L1208" rel="L1208">escaped my notice.”</li>
<li class="L1209" rel="L1209"></li>
<li class="L1210" rel="L1210">“_You_ observed it, Mr. Darcy, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley; “and I am</li>
<li class="L1211" rel="L1211">inclined to think that you would not wish to see _your_ sister make such</li>
<li class="L1212" rel="L1212">an exhibition.”</li>
<li class="L1213" rel="L1213"></li>
<li class="L1214" rel="L1214">“Certainly not.”</li>
<li class="L1215" rel="L1215"></li>
<li class="L1216" rel="L1216">“To walk three miles, or four miles, or five miles, or whatever it is,</li>
<li class="L1217" rel="L1217">above her ankles in dirt, and alone, quite alone! What could she mean by</li>
<li class="L1218" rel="L1218">it? It seems to me to show an abominable sort of conceited independence,</li>
<li class="L1219" rel="L1219">a most country-town indifference to decorum.”</li>
<li class="L1220" rel="L1220"></li>
<li class="L1221" rel="L1221">“It shows an affection for her sister that is very pleasing,” said</li>
<li class="L1222" rel="L1222">Bingley.</li>
<li class="L1223" rel="L1223"></li>
<li class="L1224" rel="L1224">“I am afraid, Mr. Darcy,” observed Miss Bingley in a half whisper, “that</li>
<li class="L1225" rel="L1225">this adventure has rather affected your admiration of her fine eyes.”</li>
<li class="L1226" rel="L1226"></li>
<li class="L1227" rel="L1227">“Not at all,” he replied; “they were brightened by the exercise.” A</li>
<li class="L1228" rel="L1228">short pause followed this speech, and Mrs. Hurst began again:</li>
<li class="L1229" rel="L1229"></li>
<li class="L1230" rel="L1230">“I have an excessive regard for Miss Jane Bennet, she is really a very</li>
<li class="L1231" rel="L1231">sweet girl, and I wish with all my heart she were well settled. But with</li>
<li class="L1232" rel="L1232">such a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is</li>
<li class="L1233" rel="L1233">no chance of it.”</li>
<li class="L1234" rel="L1234"></li>
<li class="L1235" rel="L1235">“I think I have heard you say that their uncle is an attorney in</li>
<li class="L1236" rel="L1236">Meryton.”</li>
<li class="L1237" rel="L1237"></li>
<li class="L1238" rel="L1238">“Yes; and they have another, who lives somewhere near Cheapside.”</li>
<li class="L1239" rel="L1239"></li>
<li class="L1240" rel="L1240">“That is capital,” added her sister, and they both laughed heartily.</li>
<li class="L1241" rel="L1241"></li>
<li class="L1242" rel="L1242">“If they had uncles enough to fill _all_ Cheapside,” cried Bingley, “it</li>
<li class="L1243" rel="L1243">would not make them one jot less agreeable.”</li>
<li class="L1244" rel="L1244"></li>
<li class="L1245" rel="L1245">“But it must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any</li>
<li class="L1246" rel="L1246">consideration in the world,” replied Darcy.</li>
<li class="L1247" rel="L1247"></li>
<li class="L1248" rel="L1248">To this speech Bingley made no answer; but his sisters gave it their</li>
<li class="L1249" rel="L1249">hearty assent, and indulged their mirth for some time at the expense of</li>
<li class="L1250" rel="L1250">their dear friend&#39;s vulgar relations.</li>
<li class="L1251" rel="L1251"></li>
<li class="L1252" rel="L1252">With a renewal of tenderness, however, they returned to her room on</li>
<li class="L1253" rel="L1253">leaving the dining-parlour, and sat with her till summoned to coffee.</li>
<li class="L1254" rel="L1254">She was still very poorly, and Elizabeth would not quit her at all, till</li>
<li class="L1255" rel="L1255">late in the evening, when she had the comfort of seeing her sleep, and</li>
<li class="L1256" rel="L1256">when it seemed to her rather right than pleasant that she should go</li>
<li class="L1257" rel="L1257">downstairs herself. On entering the drawing-room she found the whole</li>
<li class="L1258" rel="L1258">party at loo, and was immediately invited to join them; but suspecting</li>
<li class="L1259" rel="L1259">them to be playing high she declined it, and making her sister the</li>
<li class="L1260" rel="L1260">excuse, said she would amuse herself for the short time she could stay</li>
<li class="L1261" rel="L1261">below, with a book. Mr. Hurst looked at her with astonishment.</li>
<li class="L1262" rel="L1262"></li>
<li class="L1263" rel="L1263">“Do you prefer reading to cards?” said he; “that is rather singular.”</li>
<li class="L1264" rel="L1264"></li>
<li class="L1265" rel="L1265">“Miss Eliza Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, “despises cards. She is a great</li>
<li class="L1266" rel="L1266">reader, and has no pleasure in anything else.”</li>
<li class="L1267" rel="L1267"></li>
<li class="L1268" rel="L1268">“I deserve neither such praise nor such censure,” cried Elizabeth; “I am</li>
<li class="L1269" rel="L1269">_not_ a great reader, and I have pleasure in many things.”</li>
<li class="L1270" rel="L1270"></li>
<li class="L1271" rel="L1271">“In nursing your sister I am sure you have pleasure,” said Bingley; “and</li>
<li class="L1272" rel="L1272">I hope it will be soon increased by seeing her quite well.”</li>
<li class="L1273" rel="L1273"></li>
<li class="L1274" rel="L1274">Elizabeth thanked him from her heart, and then walked towards the</li>
<li class="L1275" rel="L1275">table where a few books were lying. He immediately offered to fetch her</li>
<li class="L1276" rel="L1276">others--all that his library afforded.</li>
<li class="L1277" rel="L1277"></li>
<li class="L1278" rel="L1278">“And I wish my collection were larger for your benefit and my own</li>
<li class="L1279" rel="L1279">credit; but I am an idle fellow, and though I have not many, I have more</li>
<li class="L1280" rel="L1280">than I ever looked into.”</li>
<li class="L1281" rel="L1281"></li>
<li class="L1282" rel="L1282">Elizabeth assured him that she could suit herself perfectly with those</li>
<li class="L1283" rel="L1283">in the room.</li>
<li class="L1284" rel="L1284"></li>
<li class="L1285" rel="L1285">“I am astonished,” said Miss Bingley, “that my father should have left</li>
<li class="L1286" rel="L1286">so small a collection of books. What a delightful library you have at</li>
<li class="L1287" rel="L1287">Pemberley, Mr. Darcy!”</li>
<li class="L1288" rel="L1288"></li>
<li class="L1289" rel="L1289">“It ought to be good,” he replied, “it has been the work of many</li>
<li class="L1290" rel="L1290">generations.”</li>
<li class="L1291" rel="L1291"></li>
<li class="L1292" rel="L1292">“And then you have added so much to it yourself, you are always buying</li>
<li class="L1293" rel="L1293">books.”</li>
<li class="L1294" rel="L1294"></li>
<li class="L1295" rel="L1295">“I cannot comprehend the neglect of a family library in such days as</li>
<li class="L1296" rel="L1296">these.”</li>
<li class="L1297" rel="L1297"></li>
<li class="L1298" rel="L1298">“Neglect! I am sure you neglect nothing that can add to the beauties of</li>
<li class="L1299" rel="L1299">that noble place. Charles, when you build _your_ house, I wish it may be</li>
<li class="L1300" rel="L1300">half as delightful as Pemberley.”</li>
<li class="L1301" rel="L1301"></li>
<li class="L1302" rel="L1302">“I wish it may.”</li>
<li class="L1303" rel="L1303"></li>
<li class="L1304" rel="L1304">“But I would really advise you to make your purchase in that</li>
<li class="L1305" rel="L1305">neighbourhood, and take Pemberley for a kind of model. There is not a</li>
<li class="L1306" rel="L1306">finer county in England than Derbyshire.”</li>
<li class="L1307" rel="L1307"></li>
<li class="L1308" rel="L1308">“With all my heart; I will buy Pemberley itself if Darcy will sell it.”</li>
<li class="L1309" rel="L1309"></li>
<li class="L1310" rel="L1310">“I am talking of possibilities, Charles.”</li>
<li class="L1311" rel="L1311"></li>
<li class="L1312" rel="L1312">“Upon my word, Caroline, I should think it more possible to get</li>
<li class="L1313" rel="L1313">Pemberley by purchase than by imitation.”</li>
<li class="L1314" rel="L1314"></li>
<li class="L1315" rel="L1315">Elizabeth was so much caught with what passed, as to leave her very</li>
<li class="L1316" rel="L1316">little attention for her book; and soon laying it wholly aside, she drew</li>
<li class="L1317" rel="L1317">near the card-table, and stationed herself between Mr. Bingley and his</li>
<li class="L1318" rel="L1318">eldest sister, to observe the game.</li>
<li class="L1319" rel="L1319"></li>
<li class="L1320" rel="L1320">“Is Miss Darcy much grown since the spring?” said Miss Bingley; “will</li>
<li class="L1321" rel="L1321">she be as tall as I am?”</li>
<li class="L1322" rel="L1322"></li>
<li class="L1323" rel="L1323">“I think she will. She is now about Miss Elizabeth Bennet&#39;s height, or</li>
<li class="L1324" rel="L1324">rather taller.”</li>
<li class="L1325" rel="L1325"></li>
<li class="L1326" rel="L1326">“How I long to see her again! I never met with anybody who delighted me</li>
<li class="L1327" rel="L1327">so much. Such a countenance, such manners! And so extremely accomplished</li>
<li class="L1328" rel="L1328">for her age! Her performance on the pianoforte is exquisite.”</li>
<li class="L1329" rel="L1329"></li>
<li class="L1330" rel="L1330">“It is amazing to me,” said Bingley, “how young ladies can have patience</li>
<li class="L1331" rel="L1331">to be so very accomplished as they all are.”</li>
<li class="L1332" rel="L1332"></li>
<li class="L1333" rel="L1333">“All young ladies accomplished! My dear Charles, what do you mean?”</li>
<li class="L1334" rel="L1334"></li>
<li class="L1335" rel="L1335">“Yes, all of them, I think. They all paint tables, cover screens, and</li>
<li class="L1336" rel="L1336">net purses. I scarcely know anyone who cannot do all this, and I am sure</li>
<li class="L1337" rel="L1337">I never heard a young lady spoken of for the first time, without being</li>
<li class="L1338" rel="L1338">informed that she was very accomplished.”</li>
<li class="L1339" rel="L1339"></li>
<li class="L1340" rel="L1340">“Your list of the common extent of accomplishments,” said Darcy, “has</li>
<li class="L1341" rel="L1341">too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no</li>
<li class="L1342" rel="L1342">otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen. But I am very</li>
<li class="L1343" rel="L1343">far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I</li>
<li class="L1344" rel="L1344">cannot boast of knowing more than half-a-dozen, in the whole range of my</li>
<li class="L1345" rel="L1345">acquaintance, that are really accomplished.”</li>
<li class="L1346" rel="L1346"></li>
<li class="L1347" rel="L1347">“Nor I, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley.</li>
<li class="L1348" rel="L1348"></li>
<li class="L1349" rel="L1349">“Then,” observed Elizabeth, “you must comprehend a great deal in your</li>
<li class="L1350" rel="L1350">idea of an accomplished woman.”</li>
<li class="L1351" rel="L1351"></li>
<li class="L1352" rel="L1352">“Yes, I do comprehend a great deal in it.”</li>
<li class="L1353" rel="L1353"></li>
<li class="L1354" rel="L1354">“Oh! certainly,” cried his faithful assistant, “no one can be really</li>
<li class="L1355" rel="L1355">esteemed accomplished who does not greatly surpass what is usually met</li>
<li class="L1356" rel="L1356">with. A woman must have a thorough knowledge of music, singing, drawing,</li>
<li class="L1357" rel="L1357">dancing, and the modern languages, to deserve the word; and besides</li>
<li class="L1358" rel="L1358">all this, she must possess a certain something in her air and manner of</li>
<li class="L1359" rel="L1359">walking, the tone of her voice, her address and expressions, or the word</li>
<li class="L1360" rel="L1360">will be but half-deserved.”</li>
<li class="L1361" rel="L1361"></li>
<li class="L1362" rel="L1362">“All this she must possess,” added Darcy, “and to all this she must</li>
<li class="L1363" rel="L1363">yet add something more substantial, in the improvement of her mind by</li>
<li class="L1364" rel="L1364">extensive reading.”</li>
<li class="L1365" rel="L1365"></li>
<li class="L1366" rel="L1366">“I am no longer surprised at your knowing _only_ six accomplished women.</li>
<li class="L1367" rel="L1367">I rather wonder now at your knowing _any_.”</li>
<li class="L1368" rel="L1368"></li>
<li class="L1369" rel="L1369">“Are you so severe upon your own sex as to doubt the possibility of all</li>
<li class="L1370" rel="L1370">this?”</li>
<li class="L1371" rel="L1371"></li>
<li class="L1372" rel="L1372">“I never saw such a woman. I never saw such capacity, and taste, and</li>
<li class="L1373" rel="L1373">application, and elegance, as you describe united.”</li>
<li class="L1374" rel="L1374"></li>
<li class="L1375" rel="L1375">Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley both cried out against the injustice of her</li>
<li class="L1376" rel="L1376">implied doubt, and were both protesting that they knew many women who</li>
<li class="L1377" rel="L1377">answered this description, when Mr. Hurst called them to order, with</li>
<li class="L1378" rel="L1378">bitter complaints of their inattention to what was going forward. As all</li>
<li class="L1379" rel="L1379">conversation was thereby at an end, Elizabeth soon afterwards left the</li>
<li class="L1380" rel="L1380">room.</li>
<li class="L1381" rel="L1381"></li>
<li class="L1382" rel="L1382">“Elizabeth Bennet,” said Miss Bingley, when the door was closed on her,</li>
<li class="L1383" rel="L1383">“is one of those young ladies who seek to recommend themselves to the</li>
<li class="L1384" rel="L1384">other sex by undervaluing their own; and with many men, I dare say, it</li>
<li class="L1385" rel="L1385">succeeds. But, in my opinion, it is a paltry device, a very mean art.”</li>
<li class="L1386" rel="L1386"></li>
<li class="L1387" rel="L1387">“Undoubtedly,” replied Darcy, to whom this remark was chiefly addressed,</li>
<li class="L1388" rel="L1388">“there is a meanness in _all_ the arts which ladies sometimes condescend</li>
<li class="L1389" rel="L1389">to employ for captivation. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is</li>
<li class="L1390" rel="L1390">despicable.”</li>
<li class="L1391" rel="L1391"></li>
<li class="L1392" rel="L1392">Miss Bingley was not so entirely satisfied with this reply as to</li>
<li class="L1393" rel="L1393">continue the subject.</li>
<li class="L1394" rel="L1394"></li>
<li class="L1395" rel="L1395">Elizabeth joined them again only to say that her sister was worse, and</li>
<li class="L1396" rel="L1396">that she could not leave her. Bingley urged Mr. Jones being sent for</li>
<li class="L1397" rel="L1397">immediately; while his sisters, convinced that no country advice could</li>
<li class="L1398" rel="L1398">be of any service, recommended an express to town for one of the most</li>
<li class="L1399" rel="L1399">eminent physicians. This she would not hear of; but she was not so</li>
<li class="L1400" rel="L1400">unwilling to comply with their brother&#39;s proposal; and it was settled</li>
<li class="L1401" rel="L1401">that Mr. Jones should be sent for early in the morning, if Miss Bennet</li>
<li class="L1402" rel="L1402">were not decidedly better. Bingley was quite uncomfortable; his sisters</li>
<li class="L1403" rel="L1403">declared that they were miserable. They solaced their wretchedness,</li>
<li class="L1404" rel="L1404">however, by duets after supper, while he could find no better relief</li>
<li class="L1405" rel="L1405">to his feelings than by giving his housekeeper directions that every</li>
<li class="L1406" rel="L1406">attention might be paid to the sick lady and her sister.</li>
<li class="L1407" rel="L1407"></li>
<li class="L1408" rel="L1408"></li>
<li class="L1409" rel="L1409"></li>
<li class="L1410" rel="L1410">Chapter 9</li>
<li class="L1411" rel="L1411"></li>
<li class="L1412" rel="L1412"></li>
<li class="L1413" rel="L1413">Elizabeth passed the chief of the night in her sister&#39;s room, and in the</li>
<li class="L1414" rel="L1414">morning had the pleasure of being able to send a tolerable answer to the</li>
<li class="L1415" rel="L1415">inquiries which she very early received from Mr. Bingley by a housemaid,</li>
<li class="L1416" rel="L1416">and some time afterwards from the two elegant ladies who waited on his</li>
<li class="L1417" rel="L1417">sisters. In spite of this amendment, however, she requested to have a</li>
<li class="L1418" rel="L1418">note sent to Longbourn, desiring her mother to visit Jane, and form her</li>
<li class="L1419" rel="L1419">own judgement of her situation. The note was immediately dispatched, and</li>
<li class="L1420" rel="L1420">its contents as quickly complied with. Mrs. Bennet, accompanied by her</li>
<li class="L1421" rel="L1421">two youngest girls, reached Netherfield soon after the family breakfast.</li>
<li class="L1422" rel="L1422"></li>
<li class="L1423" rel="L1423">Had she found Jane in any apparent danger, Mrs. Bennet would have been</li>
<li class="L1424" rel="L1424">very miserable; but being satisfied on seeing her that her illness was</li>
<li class="L1425" rel="L1425">not alarming, she had no wish of her recovering immediately, as her</li>
<li class="L1426" rel="L1426">restoration to health would probably remove her from Netherfield. She</li>
<li class="L1427" rel="L1427">would not listen, therefore, to her daughter&#39;s proposal of being carried</li>
<li class="L1428" rel="L1428">home; neither did the apothecary, who arrived about the same time, think</li>
<li class="L1429" rel="L1429">it at all advisable. After sitting a little while with Jane, on Miss</li>
<li class="L1430" rel="L1430">Bingley&#39;s appearance and invitation, the mother and three daughters all</li>
<li class="L1431" rel="L1431">attended her into the breakfast parlour. Bingley met them with hopes</li>
<li class="L1432" rel="L1432">that Mrs. Bennet had not found Miss Bennet worse than she expected.</li>
<li class="L1433" rel="L1433"></li>
<li class="L1434" rel="L1434">“Indeed I have, sir,” was her answer. “She is a great deal too ill to be</li>
<li class="L1435" rel="L1435">moved. Mr. Jones says we must not think of moving her. We must trespass</li>
<li class="L1436" rel="L1436">a little longer on your kindness.”</li>
<li class="L1437" rel="L1437"></li>
<li class="L1438" rel="L1438">“Removed!” cried Bingley. “It must not be thought of. My sister, I am</li>
<li class="L1439" rel="L1439">sure, will not hear of her removal.”</li>
<li class="L1440" rel="L1440"></li>
<li class="L1441" rel="L1441">“You may depend upon it, Madam,” said Miss Bingley, with cold civility,</li>
<li class="L1442" rel="L1442">“that Miss Bennet will receive every possible attention while she</li>
<li class="L1443" rel="L1443">remains with us.”</li>
<li class="L1444" rel="L1444"></li>
<li class="L1445" rel="L1445">Mrs. Bennet was profuse in her acknowledgments.</li>
<li class="L1446" rel="L1446"></li>
<li class="L1447" rel="L1447">“I am sure,” she added, “if it was not for such good friends I do not</li>
<li class="L1448" rel="L1448">know what would become of her, for she is very ill indeed, and suffers</li>
<li class="L1449" rel="L1449">a vast deal, though with the greatest patience in the world, which is</li>
<li class="L1450" rel="L1450">always the way with her, for she has, without exception, the sweetest</li>
<li class="L1451" rel="L1451">temper I have ever met with. I often tell my other girls they are</li>
<li class="L1452" rel="L1452">nothing to _her_. You have a sweet room here, Mr. Bingley, and a</li>
<li class="L1453" rel="L1453">charming prospect over the gravel walk. I do not know a place in the</li>
<li class="L1454" rel="L1454">country that is equal to Netherfield. You will not think of quitting it</li>
<li class="L1455" rel="L1455">in a hurry, I hope, though you have but a short lease.”</li>
<li class="L1456" rel="L1456"></li>
<li class="L1457" rel="L1457">“Whatever I do is done in a hurry,” replied he; “and therefore if I</li>
<li class="L1458" rel="L1458">should resolve to quit Netherfield, I should probably be off in five</li>
<li class="L1459" rel="L1459">minutes. At present, however, I consider myself as quite fixed here.”</li>
<li class="L1460" rel="L1460"></li>
<li class="L1461" rel="L1461">“That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,” said Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L1462" rel="L1462"></li>
<li class="L1463" rel="L1463">“You begin to comprehend me, do you?” cried he, turning towards her.</li>
<li class="L1464" rel="L1464"></li>
<li class="L1465" rel="L1465">“Oh! yes--I understand you perfectly.”</li>
<li class="L1466" rel="L1466"></li>
<li class="L1467" rel="L1467">“I wish I might take this for a compliment; but to be so easily seen</li>
<li class="L1468" rel="L1468">through I am afraid is pitiful.”</li>
<li class="L1469" rel="L1469"></li>
<li class="L1470" rel="L1470">“That is as it happens. It does not follow that a deep, intricate</li>
<li class="L1471" rel="L1471">character is more or less estimable than such a one as yours.”</li>
<li class="L1472" rel="L1472"></li>
<li class="L1473" rel="L1473">“Lizzy,” cried her mother, “remember where you are, and do not run on in</li>
<li class="L1474" rel="L1474">the wild manner that you are suffered to do at home.”</li>
<li class="L1475" rel="L1475"></li>
<li class="L1476" rel="L1476">“I did not know before,” continued Bingley immediately, “that you were a</li>
<li class="L1477" rel="L1477">studier of character. It must be an amusing study.”</li>
<li class="L1478" rel="L1478"></li>
<li class="L1479" rel="L1479">“Yes, but intricate characters are the _most_ amusing. They have at</li>
<li class="L1480" rel="L1480">least that advantage.”</li>
<li class="L1481" rel="L1481"></li>
<li class="L1482" rel="L1482">“The country,” said Darcy, “can in general supply but a few subjects for</li>
<li class="L1483" rel="L1483">such a study. In a country neighbourhood you move in a very confined and</li>
<li class="L1484" rel="L1484">unvarying society.”</li>
<li class="L1485" rel="L1485"></li>
<li class="L1486" rel="L1486">“But people themselves alter so much, that there is something new to be</li>
<li class="L1487" rel="L1487">observed in them for ever.”</li>
<li class="L1488" rel="L1488"></li>
<li class="L1489" rel="L1489">“Yes, indeed,” cried Mrs. Bennet, offended by his manner of mentioning</li>
<li class="L1490" rel="L1490">a country neighbourhood. “I assure you there is quite as much of _that_</li>
<li class="L1491" rel="L1491">going on in the country as in town.”</li>
<li class="L1492" rel="L1492"></li>
<li class="L1493" rel="L1493">Everybody was surprised, and Darcy, after looking at her for a moment,</li>
<li class="L1494" rel="L1494">turned silently away. Mrs. Bennet, who fancied she had gained a complete</li>
<li class="L1495" rel="L1495">victory over him, continued her triumph.</li>
<li class="L1496" rel="L1496"></li>
<li class="L1497" rel="L1497">“I cannot see that London has any great advantage over the country, for</li>
<li class="L1498" rel="L1498">my part, except the shops and public places. The country is a vast deal</li>
<li class="L1499" rel="L1499">pleasanter, is it not, Mr. Bingley?”</li>
<li class="L1500" rel="L1500"></li>
<li class="L1501" rel="L1501">“When I am in the country,” he replied, “I never wish to leave it;</li>
<li class="L1502" rel="L1502">and when I am in town it is pretty much the same. They have each their</li>
<li class="L1503" rel="L1503">advantages, and I can be equally happy in either.”</li>
<li class="L1504" rel="L1504"></li>
<li class="L1505" rel="L1505">“Aye--that is because you have the right disposition. But that</li>
<li class="L1506" rel="L1506">gentleman,” looking at Darcy, “seemed to think the country was nothing</li>
<li class="L1507" rel="L1507">at all.”</li>
<li class="L1508" rel="L1508"></li>
<li class="L1509" rel="L1509">“Indeed, Mamma, you are mistaken,” said Elizabeth, blushing for her</li>
<li class="L1510" rel="L1510">mother. “You quite mistook Mr. Darcy. He only meant that there was not</li>
<li class="L1511" rel="L1511">such a variety of people to be met with in the country as in the town,</li>
<li class="L1512" rel="L1512">which you must acknowledge to be true.”</li>
<li class="L1513" rel="L1513"></li>
<li class="L1514" rel="L1514">“Certainly, my dear, nobody said there were; but as to not meeting</li>
<li class="L1515" rel="L1515">with many people in this neighbourhood, I believe there are few</li>
<li class="L1516" rel="L1516">neighbourhoods larger. I know we dine with four-and-twenty families.”</li>
<li class="L1517" rel="L1517"></li>
<li class="L1518" rel="L1518">Nothing but concern for Elizabeth could enable Bingley to keep his</li>
<li class="L1519" rel="L1519">countenance. His sister was less delicate, and directed her eyes towards</li>
<li class="L1520" rel="L1520">Mr. Darcy with a very expressive smile. Elizabeth, for the sake of</li>
<li class="L1521" rel="L1521">saying something that might turn her mother&#39;s thoughts, now asked her if</li>
<li class="L1522" rel="L1522">Charlotte Lucas had been at Longbourn since _her_ coming away.</li>
<li class="L1523" rel="L1523"></li>
<li class="L1524" rel="L1524">“Yes, she called yesterday with her father. What an agreeable man Sir</li>
<li class="L1525" rel="L1525">William is, Mr. Bingley, is not he? So much the man of fashion! So</li>
<li class="L1526" rel="L1526">genteel and easy! He has always something to say to everybody. _That_</li>
<li class="L1527" rel="L1527">is my idea of good breeding; and those persons who fancy themselves very</li>
<li class="L1528" rel="L1528">important, and never open their mouths, quite mistake the matter.”</li>
<li class="L1529" rel="L1529"></li>
<li class="L1530" rel="L1530">“Did Charlotte dine with you?”</li>
<li class="L1531" rel="L1531"></li>
<li class="L1532" rel="L1532">“No, she would go home. I fancy she was wanted about the mince-pies. For</li>
<li class="L1533" rel="L1533">my part, Mr. Bingley, I always keep servants that can do their own work;</li>
<li class="L1534" rel="L1534">_my_ daughters are brought up very differently. But everybody is to</li>
<li class="L1535" rel="L1535">judge for themselves, and the Lucases are a very good sort of girls,</li>
<li class="L1536" rel="L1536">I assure you. It is a pity they are not handsome! Not that I think</li>
<li class="L1537" rel="L1537">Charlotte so _very_ plain--but then she is our particular friend.”</li>
<li class="L1538" rel="L1538"></li>
<li class="L1539" rel="L1539">“She seems a very pleasant young woman.”</li>
<li class="L1540" rel="L1540"></li>
<li class="L1541" rel="L1541">“Oh! dear, yes; but you must own she is very plain. Lady Lucas herself</li>
<li class="L1542" rel="L1542">has often said so, and envied me Jane&#39;s beauty. I do not like to boast</li>
<li class="L1543" rel="L1543">of my own child, but to be sure, Jane--one does not often see anybody</li>
<li class="L1544" rel="L1544">better looking. It is what everybody says. I do not trust my own</li>
<li class="L1545" rel="L1545">partiality. When she was only fifteen, there was a man at my brother</li>
<li class="L1546" rel="L1546">Gardiner&#39;s in town so much in love with her that my sister-in-law was</li>
<li class="L1547" rel="L1547">sure he would make her an offer before we came away. But, however, he</li>
<li class="L1548" rel="L1548">did not. Perhaps he thought her too young. However, he wrote some verses</li>
<li class="L1549" rel="L1549">on her, and very pretty they were.”</li>
<li class="L1550" rel="L1550"></li>
<li class="L1551" rel="L1551">“And so ended his affection,” said Elizabeth impatiently. “There has</li>
<li class="L1552" rel="L1552">been many a one, I fancy, overcome in the same way. I wonder who first</li>
<li class="L1553" rel="L1553">discovered the efficacy of poetry in driving away love!”</li>
<li class="L1554" rel="L1554"></li>
<li class="L1555" rel="L1555">“I have been used to consider poetry as the _food_ of love,” said Darcy.</li>
<li class="L1556" rel="L1556"></li>
<li class="L1557" rel="L1557">“Of a fine, stout, healthy love it may. Everything nourishes what is</li>
<li class="L1558" rel="L1558">strong already. But if it be only a slight, thin sort of inclination, I</li>
<li class="L1559" rel="L1559">am convinced that one good sonnet will starve it entirely away.”</li>
<li class="L1560" rel="L1560"></li>
<li class="L1561" rel="L1561">Darcy only smiled; and the general pause which ensued made Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L1562" rel="L1562">tremble lest her mother should be exposing herself again. She longed to</li>
<li class="L1563" rel="L1563">speak, but could think of nothing to say; and after a short silence Mrs.</li>
<li class="L1564" rel="L1564">Bennet began repeating her thanks to Mr. Bingley for his kindness to</li>
<li class="L1565" rel="L1565">Jane, with an apology for troubling him also with Lizzy. Mr. Bingley was</li>
<li class="L1566" rel="L1566">unaffectedly civil in his answer, and forced his younger sister to be</li>
<li class="L1567" rel="L1567">civil also, and say what the occasion required. She performed her part</li>
<li class="L1568" rel="L1568">indeed without much graciousness, but Mrs. Bennet was satisfied, and</li>
<li class="L1569" rel="L1569">soon afterwards ordered her carriage. Upon this signal, the youngest of</li>
<li class="L1570" rel="L1570">her daughters put herself forward. The two girls had been whispering to</li>
<li class="L1571" rel="L1571">each other during the whole visit, and the result of it was, that the</li>
<li class="L1572" rel="L1572">youngest should tax Mr. Bingley with having promised on his first coming</li>
<li class="L1573" rel="L1573">into the country to give a ball at Netherfield.</li>
<li class="L1574" rel="L1574"></li>
<li class="L1575" rel="L1575">Lydia was a stout, well-grown girl of fifteen, with a fine complexion</li>
<li class="L1576" rel="L1576">and good-humoured countenance; a favourite with her mother, whose</li>
<li class="L1577" rel="L1577">affection had brought her into public at an early age. She had high</li>
<li class="L1578" rel="L1578">animal spirits, and a sort of natural self-consequence, which the</li>
<li class="L1579" rel="L1579">attention of the officers, to whom her uncle&#39;s good dinners, and her own</li>
<li class="L1580" rel="L1580">easy manners recommended her, had increased into assurance. She was very</li>
<li class="L1581" rel="L1581">equal, therefore, to address Mr. Bingley on the subject of the ball, and</li>
<li class="L1582" rel="L1582">abruptly reminded him of his promise; adding, that it would be the most</li>
<li class="L1583" rel="L1583">shameful thing in the world if he did not keep it. His answer to this</li>
<li class="L1584" rel="L1584">sudden attack was delightful to their mother&#39;s ear:</li>
<li class="L1585" rel="L1585"></li>
<li class="L1586" rel="L1586">“I am perfectly ready, I assure you, to keep my engagement; and when</li>
<li class="L1587" rel="L1587">your sister is recovered, you shall, if you please, name the very day of</li>
<li class="L1588" rel="L1588">the ball. But you would not wish to be dancing when she is ill.”</li>
<li class="L1589" rel="L1589"></li>
<li class="L1590" rel="L1590">Lydia declared herself satisfied. “Oh! yes--it would be much better to</li>
<li class="L1591" rel="L1591">wait till Jane was well, and by that time most likely Captain Carter</li>
<li class="L1592" rel="L1592">would be at Meryton again. And when you have given _your_ ball,” she</li>
<li class="L1593" rel="L1593">added, “I shall insist on their giving one also. I shall tell Colonel</li>
<li class="L1594" rel="L1594">Forster it will be quite a shame if he does not.”</li>
<li class="L1595" rel="L1595"></li>
<li class="L1596" rel="L1596">Mrs. Bennet and her daughters then departed, and Elizabeth returned</li>
<li class="L1597" rel="L1597">instantly to Jane, leaving her own and her relations&#39; behaviour to the</li>
<li class="L1598" rel="L1598">remarks of the two ladies and Mr. Darcy; the latter of whom, however,</li>
<li class="L1599" rel="L1599">could not be prevailed on to join in their censure of _her_, in spite of</li>
<li class="L1600" rel="L1600">all Miss Bingley&#39;s witticisms on _fine eyes_.</li>
<li class="L1601" rel="L1601"></li>
<li class="L1602" rel="L1602"></li>
<li class="L1603" rel="L1603"></li>
<li class="L1604" rel="L1604">Chapter 10</li>
<li class="L1605" rel="L1605"></li>
<li class="L1606" rel="L1606"></li>
<li class="L1607" rel="L1607">The day passed much as the day before had done. Mrs. Hurst and Miss</li>
<li class="L1608" rel="L1608">Bingley had spent some hours of the morning with the invalid, who</li>
<li class="L1609" rel="L1609">continued, though slowly, to mend; and in the evening Elizabeth joined</li>
<li class="L1610" rel="L1610">their party in the drawing-room. The loo-table, however, did not appear.</li>
<li class="L1611" rel="L1611">Mr. Darcy was writing, and Miss Bingley, seated near him, was watching</li>
<li class="L1612" rel="L1612">the progress of his letter and repeatedly calling off his attention by</li>
<li class="L1613" rel="L1613">messages to his sister. Mr. Hurst and Mr. Bingley were at piquet, and</li>
<li class="L1614" rel="L1614">Mrs. Hurst was observing their game.</li>
<li class="L1615" rel="L1615"></li>
<li class="L1616" rel="L1616">Elizabeth took up some needlework, and was sufficiently amused in</li>
<li class="L1617" rel="L1617">attending to what passed between Darcy and his companion. The perpetual</li>
<li class="L1618" rel="L1618">commendations of the lady, either on his handwriting, or on the evenness</li>
<li class="L1619" rel="L1619">of his lines, or on the length of his letter, with the perfect unconcern</li>
<li class="L1620" rel="L1620">with which her praises were received, formed a curious dialogue, and was</li>
<li class="L1621" rel="L1621">exactly in union with her opinion of each.</li>
<li class="L1622" rel="L1622"></li>
<li class="L1623" rel="L1623">“How delighted Miss Darcy will be to receive such a letter!”</li>
<li class="L1624" rel="L1624"></li>
<li class="L1625" rel="L1625">He made no answer.</li>
<li class="L1626" rel="L1626"></li>
<li class="L1627" rel="L1627">“You write uncommonly fast.”</li>
<li class="L1628" rel="L1628"></li>
<li class="L1629" rel="L1629">“You are mistaken. I write rather slowly.”</li>
<li class="L1630" rel="L1630"></li>
<li class="L1631" rel="L1631">“How many letters you must have occasion to write in the course of a</li>
<li class="L1632" rel="L1632">year! Letters of business, too! How odious I should think them!”</li>
<li class="L1633" rel="L1633"></li>
<li class="L1634" rel="L1634">“It is fortunate, then, that they fall to my lot instead of yours.”</li>
<li class="L1635" rel="L1635"></li>
<li class="L1636" rel="L1636">“Pray tell your sister that I long to see her.”</li>
<li class="L1637" rel="L1637"></li>
<li class="L1638" rel="L1638">“I have already told her so once, by your desire.”</li>
<li class="L1639" rel="L1639"></li>
<li class="L1640" rel="L1640">“I am afraid you do not like your pen. Let me mend it for you. I mend</li>
<li class="L1641" rel="L1641">pens remarkably well.”</li>
<li class="L1642" rel="L1642"></li>
<li class="L1643" rel="L1643">“Thank you--but I always mend my own.”</li>
<li class="L1644" rel="L1644"></li>
<li class="L1645" rel="L1645">“How can you contrive to write so even?”</li>
<li class="L1646" rel="L1646"></li>
<li class="L1647" rel="L1647">He was silent.</li>
<li class="L1648" rel="L1648"></li>
<li class="L1649" rel="L1649">“Tell your sister I am delighted to hear of her improvement on the harp;</li>
<li class="L1650" rel="L1650">and pray let her know that I am quite in raptures with her beautiful</li>
<li class="L1651" rel="L1651">little design for a table, and I think it infinitely superior to Miss</li>
<li class="L1652" rel="L1652">Grantley&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L1653" rel="L1653"></li>
<li class="L1654" rel="L1654">“Will you give me leave to defer your raptures till I write again? At</li>
<li class="L1655" rel="L1655">present I have not room to do them justice.”</li>
<li class="L1656" rel="L1656"></li>
<li class="L1657" rel="L1657">“Oh! it is of no consequence. I shall see her in January. But do you</li>
<li class="L1658" rel="L1658">always write such charming long letters to her, Mr. Darcy?”</li>
<li class="L1659" rel="L1659"></li>
<li class="L1660" rel="L1660">“They are generally long; but whether always charming it is not for me</li>
<li class="L1661" rel="L1661">to determine.”</li>
<li class="L1662" rel="L1662"></li>
<li class="L1663" rel="L1663">“It is a rule with me, that a person who can write a long letter with</li>
<li class="L1664" rel="L1664">ease, cannot write ill.”</li>
<li class="L1665" rel="L1665"></li>
<li class="L1666" rel="L1666">“That will not do for a compliment to Darcy, Caroline,” cried her</li>
<li class="L1667" rel="L1667">brother, “because he does _not_ write with ease. He studies too much for</li>
<li class="L1668" rel="L1668">words of four syllables. Do not you, Darcy?”</li>
<li class="L1669" rel="L1669"></li>
<li class="L1670" rel="L1670">“My style of writing is very different from yours.”</li>
<li class="L1671" rel="L1671"></li>
<li class="L1672" rel="L1672">“Oh!” cried Miss Bingley, “Charles writes in the most careless way</li>
<li class="L1673" rel="L1673">imaginable. He leaves out half his words, and blots the rest.”</li>
<li class="L1674" rel="L1674"></li>
<li class="L1675" rel="L1675">“My ideas flow so rapidly that I have not time to express them--by which</li>
<li class="L1676" rel="L1676">means my letters sometimes convey no ideas at all to my correspondents.”</li>
<li class="L1677" rel="L1677"></li>
<li class="L1678" rel="L1678">“Your humility, Mr. Bingley,” said Elizabeth, “must disarm reproof.”</li>
<li class="L1679" rel="L1679"></li>
<li class="L1680" rel="L1680">“Nothing is more deceitful,” said Darcy, “than the appearance of</li>
<li class="L1681" rel="L1681">humility. It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an</li>
<li class="L1682" rel="L1682">indirect boast.”</li>
<li class="L1683" rel="L1683"></li>
<li class="L1684" rel="L1684">“And which of the two do you call _my_ little recent piece of modesty?”</li>
<li class="L1685" rel="L1685"></li>
<li class="L1686" rel="L1686">“The indirect boast; for you are really proud of your defects in</li>
<li class="L1687" rel="L1687">writing, because you consider them as proceeding from a rapidity of</li>
<li class="L1688" rel="L1688">thought and carelessness of execution, which, if not estimable, you</li>
<li class="L1689" rel="L1689">think at least highly interesting. The power of doing anything with</li>
<li class="L1690" rel="L1690">quickness is always prized much by the possessor, and often without any</li>
<li class="L1691" rel="L1691">attention to the imperfection of the performance. When you told Mrs.</li>
<li class="L1692" rel="L1692">Bennet this morning that if you ever resolved upon quitting Netherfield</li>
<li class="L1693" rel="L1693">you should be gone in five minutes, you meant it to be a sort of</li>
<li class="L1694" rel="L1694">panegyric, of compliment to yourself--and yet what is there so very</li>
<li class="L1695" rel="L1695">laudable in a precipitance which must leave very necessary business</li>
<li class="L1696" rel="L1696">undone, and can be of no real advantage to yourself or anyone else?”</li>
<li class="L1697" rel="L1697"></li>
<li class="L1698" rel="L1698">“Nay,” cried Bingley, “this is too much, to remember at night all the</li>
<li class="L1699" rel="L1699">foolish things that were said in the morning. And yet, upon my honour,</li>
<li class="L1700" rel="L1700">I believe what I said of myself to be true, and I believe it at this</li>
<li class="L1701" rel="L1701">moment. At least, therefore, I did not assume the character of needless</li>
<li class="L1702" rel="L1702">precipitance merely to show off before the ladies.”</li>
<li class="L1703" rel="L1703"></li>
<li class="L1704" rel="L1704">“I dare say you believed it; but I am by no means convinced that</li>
<li class="L1705" rel="L1705">you would be gone with such celerity. Your conduct would be quite as</li>
<li class="L1706" rel="L1706">dependent on chance as that of any man I know; and if, as you were</li>
<li class="L1707" rel="L1707">mounting your horse, a friend were to say, &#39;Bingley, you had better</li>
<li class="L1708" rel="L1708">stay till next week,&#39; you would probably do it, you would probably not</li>
<li class="L1709" rel="L1709">go--and at another word, might stay a month.”</li>
<li class="L1710" rel="L1710"></li>
<li class="L1711" rel="L1711">“You have only proved by this,” cried Elizabeth, “that Mr. Bingley did</li>
<li class="L1712" rel="L1712">not do justice to his own disposition. You have shown him off now much</li>
<li class="L1713" rel="L1713">more than he did himself.”</li>
<li class="L1714" rel="L1714"></li>
<li class="L1715" rel="L1715">“I am exceedingly gratified,” said Bingley, “by your converting what my</li>
<li class="L1716" rel="L1716">friend says into a compliment on the sweetness of my temper. But I am</li>
<li class="L1717" rel="L1717">afraid you are giving it a turn which that gentleman did by no means</li>
<li class="L1718" rel="L1718">intend; for he would certainly think better of me, if under such a</li>
<li class="L1719" rel="L1719">circumstance I were to give a flat denial, and ride off as fast as I</li>
<li class="L1720" rel="L1720">could.”</li>
<li class="L1721" rel="L1721"></li>
<li class="L1722" rel="L1722">“Would Mr. Darcy then consider the rashness of your original intentions</li>
<li class="L1723" rel="L1723">as atoned for by your obstinacy in adhering to it?”</li>
<li class="L1724" rel="L1724"></li>
<li class="L1725" rel="L1725">“Upon my word, I cannot exactly explain the matter; Darcy must speak for</li>
<li class="L1726" rel="L1726">himself.”</li>
<li class="L1727" rel="L1727"></li>
<li class="L1728" rel="L1728">“You expect me to account for opinions which you choose to call mine,</li>
<li class="L1729" rel="L1729">but which I have never acknowledged. Allowing the case, however, to</li>
<li class="L1730" rel="L1730">stand according to your representation, you must remember, Miss Bennet,</li>
<li class="L1731" rel="L1731">that the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and</li>
<li class="L1732" rel="L1732">the delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering</li>
<li class="L1733" rel="L1733">one argument in favour of its propriety.”</li>
<li class="L1734" rel="L1734"></li>
<li class="L1735" rel="L1735">“To yield readily--easily--to the _persuasion_ of a friend is no merit</li>
<li class="L1736" rel="L1736">with you.”</li>
<li class="L1737" rel="L1737"></li>
<li class="L1738" rel="L1738">“To yield without conviction is no compliment to the understanding of</li>
<li class="L1739" rel="L1739">either.”</li>
<li class="L1740" rel="L1740"></li>
<li class="L1741" rel="L1741">“You appear to me, Mr. Darcy, to allow nothing for the influence of</li>
<li class="L1742" rel="L1742">friendship and affection. A regard for the requester would often make</li>
<li class="L1743" rel="L1743">one readily yield to a request, without waiting for arguments to reason</li>
<li class="L1744" rel="L1744">one into it. I am not particularly speaking of such a case as you have</li>
<li class="L1745" rel="L1745">supposed about Mr. Bingley. We may as well wait, perhaps, till the</li>
<li class="L1746" rel="L1746">circumstance occurs before we discuss the discretion of his behaviour</li>
<li class="L1747" rel="L1747">thereupon. But in general and ordinary cases between friend and friend,</li>
<li class="L1748" rel="L1748">where one of them is desired by the other to change a resolution of no</li>
<li class="L1749" rel="L1749">very great moment, should you think ill of that person for complying</li>
<li class="L1750" rel="L1750">with the desire, without waiting to be argued into it?”</li>
<li class="L1751" rel="L1751"></li>
<li class="L1752" rel="L1752">“Will it not be advisable, before we proceed on this subject, to</li>
<li class="L1753" rel="L1753">arrange with rather more precision the degree of importance which is to</li>
<li class="L1754" rel="L1754">appertain to this request, as well as the degree of intimacy subsisting</li>
<li class="L1755" rel="L1755">between the parties?”</li>
<li class="L1756" rel="L1756"></li>
<li class="L1757" rel="L1757">“By all means,” cried Bingley; “let us hear all the particulars, not</li>
<li class="L1758" rel="L1758">forgetting their comparative height and size; for that will have more</li>
<li class="L1759" rel="L1759">weight in the argument, Miss Bennet, than you may be aware of. I assure</li>
<li class="L1760" rel="L1760">you, that if Darcy were not such a great tall fellow, in comparison with</li>
<li class="L1761" rel="L1761">myself, I should not pay him half so much deference. I declare I do not</li>
<li class="L1762" rel="L1762">know a more awful object than Darcy, on particular occasions, and in</li>
<li class="L1763" rel="L1763">particular places; at his own house especially, and of a Sunday evening,</li>
<li class="L1764" rel="L1764">when he has nothing to do.”</li>
<li class="L1765" rel="L1765"></li>
<li class="L1766" rel="L1766">Mr. Darcy smiled; but Elizabeth thought she could perceive that he was</li>
<li class="L1767" rel="L1767">rather offended, and therefore checked her laugh. Miss Bingley warmly</li>
<li class="L1768" rel="L1768">resented the indignity he had received, in an expostulation with her</li>
<li class="L1769" rel="L1769">brother for talking such nonsense.</li>
<li class="L1770" rel="L1770"></li>
<li class="L1771" rel="L1771">“I see your design, Bingley,” said his friend. “You dislike an argument,</li>
<li class="L1772" rel="L1772">and want to silence this.”</li>
<li class="L1773" rel="L1773"></li>
<li class="L1774" rel="L1774">“Perhaps I do. Arguments are too much like disputes. If you and Miss</li>
<li class="L1775" rel="L1775">Bennet will defer yours till I am out of the room, I shall be very</li>
<li class="L1776" rel="L1776">thankful; and then you may say whatever you like of me.”</li>
<li class="L1777" rel="L1777"></li>
<li class="L1778" rel="L1778">“What you ask,” said Elizabeth, “is no sacrifice on my side; and Mr.</li>
<li class="L1779" rel="L1779">Darcy had much better finish his letter.”</li>
<li class="L1780" rel="L1780"></li>
<li class="L1781" rel="L1781">Mr. Darcy took her advice, and did finish his letter.</li>
<li class="L1782" rel="L1782"></li>
<li class="L1783" rel="L1783">When that business was over, he applied to Miss Bingley and Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L1784" rel="L1784">for an indulgence of some music. Miss Bingley moved with some alacrity</li>
<li class="L1785" rel="L1785">to the pianoforte; and, after a polite request that Elizabeth would lead</li>
<li class="L1786" rel="L1786">the way which the other as politely and more earnestly negatived, she</li>
<li class="L1787" rel="L1787">seated herself.</li>
<li class="L1788" rel="L1788"></li>
<li class="L1789" rel="L1789">Mrs. Hurst sang with her sister, and while they were thus employed,</li>
<li class="L1790" rel="L1790">Elizabeth could not help observing, as she turned over some music-books</li>
<li class="L1791" rel="L1791">that lay on the instrument, how frequently Mr. Darcy&#39;s eyes were fixed</li>
<li class="L1792" rel="L1792">on her. She hardly knew how to suppose that she could be an object of</li>
<li class="L1793" rel="L1793">admiration to so great a man; and yet that he should look at her</li>
<li class="L1794" rel="L1794">because he disliked her, was still more strange. She could only imagine,</li>
<li class="L1795" rel="L1795">however, at last that she drew his notice because there was something</li>
<li class="L1796" rel="L1796">more wrong and reprehensible, according to his ideas of right, than in</li>
<li class="L1797" rel="L1797">any other person present. The supposition did not pain her. She liked</li>
<li class="L1798" rel="L1798">him too little to care for his approbation.</li>
<li class="L1799" rel="L1799"></li>
<li class="L1800" rel="L1800">After playing some Italian songs, Miss Bingley varied the charm by</li>
<li class="L1801" rel="L1801">a lively Scotch air; and soon afterwards Mr. Darcy, drawing near</li>
<li class="L1802" rel="L1802">Elizabeth, said to her:</li>
<li class="L1803" rel="L1803"></li>
<li class="L1804" rel="L1804">“Do not you feel a great inclination, Miss Bennet, to seize such an</li>
<li class="L1805" rel="L1805">opportunity of dancing a reel?”</li>
<li class="L1806" rel="L1806"></li>
<li class="L1807" rel="L1807">She smiled, but made no answer. He repeated the question, with some</li>
<li class="L1808" rel="L1808">surprise at her silence.</li>
<li class="L1809" rel="L1809"></li>
<li class="L1810" rel="L1810">“Oh!” said she, “I heard you before, but I could not immediately</li>
<li class="L1811" rel="L1811">determine what to say in reply. You wanted me, I know, to say &#39;Yes,&#39;</li>
<li class="L1812" rel="L1812">that you might have the pleasure of despising my taste; but I always</li>
<li class="L1813" rel="L1813">delight in overthrowing those kind of schemes, and cheating a person of</li>
<li class="L1814" rel="L1814">their premeditated contempt. I have, therefore, made up my mind to tell</li>
<li class="L1815" rel="L1815">you, that I do not want to dance a reel at all--and now despise me if</li>
<li class="L1816" rel="L1816">you dare.”</li>
<li class="L1817" rel="L1817"></li>
<li class="L1818" rel="L1818">“Indeed I do not dare.”</li>
<li class="L1819" rel="L1819"></li>
<li class="L1820" rel="L1820">Elizabeth, having rather expected to affront him, was amazed at his</li>
<li class="L1821" rel="L1821">gallantry; but there was a mixture of sweetness and archness in her</li>
<li class="L1822" rel="L1822">manner which made it difficult for her to affront anybody; and Darcy</li>
<li class="L1823" rel="L1823">had never been so bewitched by any woman as he was by her. He really</li>
<li class="L1824" rel="L1824">believed, that were it not for the inferiority of her connections, he</li>
<li class="L1825" rel="L1825">should be in some danger.</li>
<li class="L1826" rel="L1826"></li>
<li class="L1827" rel="L1827">Miss Bingley saw, or suspected enough to be jealous; and her great</li>
<li class="L1828" rel="L1828">anxiety for the recovery of her dear friend Jane received some</li>
<li class="L1829" rel="L1829">assistance from her desire of getting rid of Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L1830" rel="L1830"></li>
<li class="L1831" rel="L1831">She often tried to provoke Darcy into disliking her guest, by talking of</li>
<li class="L1832" rel="L1832">their supposed marriage, and planning his happiness in such an alliance.</li>
<li class="L1833" rel="L1833"></li>
<li class="L1834" rel="L1834">“I hope,” said she, as they were walking together in the shrubbery</li>
<li class="L1835" rel="L1835">the next day, “you will give your mother-in-law a few hints, when this</li>
<li class="L1836" rel="L1836">desirable event takes place, as to the advantage of holding her tongue;</li>
<li class="L1837" rel="L1837">and if you can compass it, do cure the younger girls of running after</li>
<li class="L1838" rel="L1838">officers. And, if I may mention so delicate a subject, endeavour to</li>
<li class="L1839" rel="L1839">check that little something, bordering on conceit and impertinence,</li>
<li class="L1840" rel="L1840">which your lady possesses.”</li>
<li class="L1841" rel="L1841"></li>
<li class="L1842" rel="L1842">“Have you anything else to propose for my domestic felicity?”</li>
<li class="L1843" rel="L1843"></li>
<li class="L1844" rel="L1844">“Oh! yes. Do let the portraits of your uncle and aunt Phillips be placed</li>
<li class="L1845" rel="L1845">in the gallery at Pemberley. Put them next to your great-uncle the</li>
<li class="L1846" rel="L1846">judge. They are in the same profession, you know, only in different</li>
<li class="L1847" rel="L1847">lines. As for your Elizabeth&#39;s picture, you must not have it taken, for</li>
<li class="L1848" rel="L1848">what painter could do justice to those beautiful eyes?”</li>
<li class="L1849" rel="L1849"></li>
<li class="L1850" rel="L1850">“It would not be easy, indeed, to catch their expression, but their</li>
<li class="L1851" rel="L1851">colour and shape, and the eyelashes, so remarkably fine, might be</li>
<li class="L1852" rel="L1852">copied.”</li>
<li class="L1853" rel="L1853"></li>
<li class="L1854" rel="L1854">At that moment they were met from another walk by Mrs. Hurst and</li>
<li class="L1855" rel="L1855">Elizabeth herself.</li>
<li class="L1856" rel="L1856"></li>
<li class="L1857" rel="L1857">“I did not know that you intended to walk,” said Miss Bingley, in some</li>
<li class="L1858" rel="L1858">confusion, lest they had been overheard.</li>
<li class="L1859" rel="L1859"></li>
<li class="L1860" rel="L1860">“You used us abominably ill,” answered Mrs. Hurst, “running away without</li>
<li class="L1861" rel="L1861">telling us that you were coming out.”</li>
<li class="L1862" rel="L1862"></li>
<li class="L1863" rel="L1863">Then taking the disengaged arm of Mr. Darcy, she left Elizabeth to walk</li>
<li class="L1864" rel="L1864">by herself. The path just admitted three. Mr. Darcy felt their rudeness,</li>
<li class="L1865" rel="L1865">and immediately said:</li>
<li class="L1866" rel="L1866"></li>
<li class="L1867" rel="L1867">“This walk is not wide enough for our party. We had better go into the</li>
<li class="L1868" rel="L1868">avenue.”</li>
<li class="L1869" rel="L1869"></li>
<li class="L1870" rel="L1870">But Elizabeth, who had not the least inclination to remain with them,</li>
<li class="L1871" rel="L1871">laughingly answered:</li>
<li class="L1872" rel="L1872"></li>
<li class="L1873" rel="L1873">“No, no; stay where you are. You are charmingly grouped, and appear</li>
<li class="L1874" rel="L1874">to uncommon advantage. The picturesque would be spoilt by admitting a</li>
<li class="L1875" rel="L1875">fourth. Good-bye.”</li>
<li class="L1876" rel="L1876"></li>
<li class="L1877" rel="L1877">She then ran gaily off, rejoicing as she rambled about, in the hope of</li>
<li class="L1878" rel="L1878">being at home again in a day or two. Jane was already so much recovered</li>
<li class="L1879" rel="L1879">as to intend leaving her room for a couple of hours that evening.</li>
<li class="L1880" rel="L1880"></li>
<li class="L1881" rel="L1881"></li>
<li class="L1882" rel="L1882"></li>
<li class="L1883" rel="L1883">Chapter 11</li>
<li class="L1884" rel="L1884"></li>
<li class="L1885" rel="L1885"></li>
<li class="L1886" rel="L1886">When the ladies removed after dinner, Elizabeth ran up to her</li>
<li class="L1887" rel="L1887">sister, and seeing her well guarded from cold, attended her into the</li>
<li class="L1888" rel="L1888">drawing-room, where she was welcomed by her two friends with many</li>
<li class="L1889" rel="L1889">professions of pleasure; and Elizabeth had never seen them so agreeable</li>
<li class="L1890" rel="L1890">as they were during the hour which passed before the gentlemen appeared.</li>
<li class="L1891" rel="L1891">Their powers of conversation were considerable. They could describe an</li>
<li class="L1892" rel="L1892">entertainment with accuracy, relate an anecdote with humour, and laugh</li>
<li class="L1893" rel="L1893">at their acquaintance with spirit.</li>
<li class="L1894" rel="L1894"></li>
<li class="L1895" rel="L1895">But when the gentlemen entered, Jane was no longer the first object;</li>
<li class="L1896" rel="L1896">Miss Bingley&#39;s eyes were instantly turned toward Darcy, and she had</li>
<li class="L1897" rel="L1897">something to say to him before he had advanced many steps. He addressed</li>
<li class="L1898" rel="L1898">himself to Miss Bennet, with a polite congratulation; Mr. Hurst also</li>
<li class="L1899" rel="L1899">made her a slight bow, and said he was “very glad;” but diffuseness</li>
<li class="L1900" rel="L1900">and warmth remained for Bingley&#39;s salutation. He was full of joy and</li>
<li class="L1901" rel="L1901">attention. The first half-hour was spent in piling up the fire, lest she</li>
<li class="L1902" rel="L1902">should suffer from the change of room; and she removed at his desire</li>
<li class="L1903" rel="L1903">to the other side of the fireplace, that she might be further from</li>
<li class="L1904" rel="L1904">the door. He then sat down by her, and talked scarcely to anyone</li>
<li class="L1905" rel="L1905">else. Elizabeth, at work in the opposite corner, saw it all with great</li>
<li class="L1906" rel="L1906">delight.</li>
<li class="L1907" rel="L1907"></li>
<li class="L1908" rel="L1908">When tea was over, Mr. Hurst reminded his sister-in-law of the</li>
<li class="L1909" rel="L1909">card-table--but in vain. She had obtained private intelligence that Mr.</li>
<li class="L1910" rel="L1910">Darcy did not wish for cards; and Mr. Hurst soon found even his open</li>
<li class="L1911" rel="L1911">petition rejected. She assured him that no one intended to play, and</li>
<li class="L1912" rel="L1912">the silence of the whole party on the subject seemed to justify her. Mr.</li>
<li class="L1913" rel="L1913">Hurst had therefore nothing to do, but to stretch himself on one of the</li>
<li class="L1914" rel="L1914">sofas and go to sleep. Darcy took up a book; Miss Bingley did the same;</li>
<li class="L1915" rel="L1915">and Mrs. Hurst, principally occupied in playing with her bracelets</li>
<li class="L1916" rel="L1916">and rings, joined now and then in her brother&#39;s conversation with Miss</li>
<li class="L1917" rel="L1917">Bennet.</li>
<li class="L1918" rel="L1918"></li>
<li class="L1919" rel="L1919">Miss Bingley&#39;s attention was quite as much engaged in watching Mr.</li>
<li class="L1920" rel="L1920">Darcy&#39;s progress through _his_ book, as in reading her own; and she</li>
<li class="L1921" rel="L1921">was perpetually either making some inquiry, or looking at his page. She</li>
<li class="L1922" rel="L1922">could not win him, however, to any conversation; he merely answered her</li>
<li class="L1923" rel="L1923">question, and read on. At length, quite exhausted by the attempt to be</li>
<li class="L1924" rel="L1924">amused with her own book, which she had only chosen because it was the</li>
<li class="L1925" rel="L1925">second volume of his, she gave a great yawn and said, “How pleasant</li>
<li class="L1926" rel="L1926">it is to spend an evening in this way! I declare after all there is no</li>
<li class="L1927" rel="L1927">enjoyment like reading! How much sooner one tires of anything than of a</li>
<li class="L1928" rel="L1928">book! When I have a house of my own, I shall be miserable if I have not</li>
<li class="L1929" rel="L1929">an excellent library.”</li>
<li class="L1930" rel="L1930"></li>
<li class="L1931" rel="L1931">No one made any reply. She then yawned again, threw aside her book, and</li>
<li class="L1932" rel="L1932">cast her eyes round the room in quest for some amusement; when hearing</li>
<li class="L1933" rel="L1933">her brother mentioning a ball to Miss Bennet, she turned suddenly</li>
<li class="L1934" rel="L1934">towards him and said:</li>
<li class="L1935" rel="L1935"></li>
<li class="L1936" rel="L1936">“By the bye, Charles, are you really serious in meditating a dance at</li>
<li class="L1937" rel="L1937">Netherfield? I would advise you, before you determine on it, to consult</li>
<li class="L1938" rel="L1938">the wishes of the present party; I am much mistaken if there are</li>
<li class="L1939" rel="L1939">not some among us to whom a ball would be rather a punishment than a</li>
<li class="L1940" rel="L1940">pleasure.”</li>
<li class="L1941" rel="L1941"></li>
<li class="L1942" rel="L1942">“If you mean Darcy,” cried her brother, “he may go to bed, if he</li>
<li class="L1943" rel="L1943">chooses, before it begins--but as for the ball, it is quite a settled</li>
<li class="L1944" rel="L1944">thing; and as soon as Nicholls has made white soup enough, I shall send</li>
<li class="L1945" rel="L1945">round my cards.”</li>
<li class="L1946" rel="L1946"></li>
<li class="L1947" rel="L1947">“I should like balls infinitely better,” she replied, “if they were</li>
<li class="L1948" rel="L1948">carried on in a different manner; but there is something insufferably</li>
<li class="L1949" rel="L1949">tedious in the usual process of such a meeting. It would surely be much</li>
<li class="L1950" rel="L1950">more rational if conversation instead of dancing were made the order of</li>
<li class="L1951" rel="L1951">the day.”</li>
<li class="L1952" rel="L1952"></li>
<li class="L1953" rel="L1953">“Much more rational, my dear Caroline, I dare say, but it would not be</li>
<li class="L1954" rel="L1954">near so much like a ball.”</li>
<li class="L1955" rel="L1955"></li>
<li class="L1956" rel="L1956">Miss Bingley made no answer, and soon afterwards she got up and walked</li>
<li class="L1957" rel="L1957">about the room. Her figure was elegant, and she walked well; but</li>
<li class="L1958" rel="L1958">Darcy, at whom it was all aimed, was still inflexibly studious. In</li>
<li class="L1959" rel="L1959">the desperation of her feelings, she resolved on one effort more, and,</li>
<li class="L1960" rel="L1960">turning to Elizabeth, said:</li>
<li class="L1961" rel="L1961"></li>
<li class="L1962" rel="L1962">“Miss Eliza Bennet, let me persuade you to follow my example, and take a</li>
<li class="L1963" rel="L1963">turn about the room. I assure you it is very refreshing after sitting so</li>
<li class="L1964" rel="L1964">long in one attitude.”</li>
<li class="L1965" rel="L1965"></li>
<li class="L1966" rel="L1966">Elizabeth was surprised, but agreed to it immediately. Miss Bingley</li>
<li class="L1967" rel="L1967">succeeded no less in the real object of her civility; Mr. Darcy looked</li>
<li class="L1968" rel="L1968">up. He was as much awake to the novelty of attention in that quarter as</li>
<li class="L1969" rel="L1969">Elizabeth herself could be, and unconsciously closed his book. He was</li>
<li class="L1970" rel="L1970">directly invited to join their party, but he declined it, observing that</li>
<li class="L1971" rel="L1971">he could imagine but two motives for their choosing to walk up and down</li>
<li class="L1972" rel="L1972">the room together, with either of which motives his joining them would</li>
<li class="L1973" rel="L1973">interfere. “What could he mean? She was dying to know what could be his</li>
<li class="L1974" rel="L1974">meaning?”--and asked Elizabeth whether she could at all understand him?</li>
<li class="L1975" rel="L1975"></li>
<li class="L1976" rel="L1976">“Not at all,” was her answer; “but depend upon it, he means to be severe</li>
<li class="L1977" rel="L1977">on us, and our surest way of disappointing him will be to ask nothing</li>
<li class="L1978" rel="L1978">about it.”</li>
<li class="L1979" rel="L1979"></li>
<li class="L1980" rel="L1980">Miss Bingley, however, was incapable of disappointing Mr. Darcy in</li>
<li class="L1981" rel="L1981">anything, and persevered therefore in requiring an explanation of his</li>
<li class="L1982" rel="L1982">two motives.</li>
<li class="L1983" rel="L1983"></li>
<li class="L1984" rel="L1984">“I have not the smallest objection to explaining them,” said he, as soon</li>
<li class="L1985" rel="L1985">as she allowed him to speak. “You either choose this method of passing</li>
<li class="L1986" rel="L1986">the evening because you are in each other&#39;s confidence, and have secret</li>
<li class="L1987" rel="L1987">affairs to discuss, or because you are conscious that your figures</li>
<li class="L1988" rel="L1988">appear to the greatest advantage in walking; if the first, I would be</li>
<li class="L1989" rel="L1989">completely in your way, and if the second, I can admire you much better</li>
<li class="L1990" rel="L1990">as I sit by the fire.”</li>
<li class="L1991" rel="L1991"></li>
<li class="L1992" rel="L1992">“Oh! shocking!” cried Miss Bingley. “I never heard anything so</li>
<li class="L1993" rel="L1993">abominable. How shall we punish him for such a speech?”</li>
<li class="L1994" rel="L1994"></li>
<li class="L1995" rel="L1995">“Nothing so easy, if you have but the inclination,” said Elizabeth. “We</li>
<li class="L1996" rel="L1996">can all plague and punish one another. Tease him--laugh at him. Intimate</li>
<li class="L1997" rel="L1997">as you are, you must know how it is to be done.”</li>
