<li class="L1998" rel="L1998"></li>
<li class="L1999" rel="L1999">“But upon my honour, I do _not_. I do assure you that my intimacy has</li>
<li class="L2000" rel="L2000">not yet taught me _that_. Tease calmness of manner and presence of</li>
<li class="L2001" rel="L2001">mind! No, no; I feel he may defy us there. And as to laughter, we will</li>
<li class="L2002" rel="L2002">not expose ourselves, if you please, by attempting to laugh without a</li>
<li class="L2003" rel="L2003">subject. Mr. Darcy may hug himself.”</li>
<li class="L2004" rel="L2004"></li>
<li class="L2005" rel="L2005">“Mr. Darcy is not to be laughed at!” cried Elizabeth. “That is an</li>
<li class="L2006" rel="L2006">uncommon advantage, and uncommon I hope it will continue, for it would</li>
<li class="L2007" rel="L2007">be a great loss to _me_ to have many such acquaintances. I dearly love a</li>
<li class="L2008" rel="L2008">laugh.”</li>
<li class="L2009" rel="L2009"></li>
<li class="L2010" rel="L2010">“Miss Bingley,” said he, “has given me more credit than can be.</li>
<li class="L2011" rel="L2011">The wisest and the best of men--nay, the wisest and best of their</li>
<li class="L2012" rel="L2012">actions--may be rendered ridiculous by a person whose first object in</li>
<li class="L2013" rel="L2013">life is a joke.”</li>
<li class="L2014" rel="L2014"></li>
<li class="L2015" rel="L2015">“Certainly,” replied Elizabeth--“there are such people, but I hope I</li>
<li class="L2016" rel="L2016">am not one of _them_. I hope I never ridicule what is wise and good.</li>
<li class="L2017" rel="L2017">Follies and nonsense, whims and inconsistencies, _do_ divert me, I own,</li>
<li class="L2018" rel="L2018">and I laugh at them whenever I can. But these, I suppose, are precisely</li>
<li class="L2019" rel="L2019">what you are without.”</li>
<li class="L2020" rel="L2020"></li>
<li class="L2021" rel="L2021">“Perhaps that is not possible for anyone. But it has been the study</li>
<li class="L2022" rel="L2022">of my life to avoid those weaknesses which often expose a strong</li>
<li class="L2023" rel="L2023">understanding to ridicule.”</li>
<li class="L2024" rel="L2024"></li>
<li class="L2025" rel="L2025">“Such as vanity and pride.”</li>
<li class="L2026" rel="L2026"></li>
<li class="L2027" rel="L2027">“Yes, vanity is a weakness indeed. But pride--where there is a real</li>
<li class="L2028" rel="L2028">superiority of mind, pride will be always under good regulation.”</li>
<li class="L2029" rel="L2029"></li>
<li class="L2030" rel="L2030">Elizabeth turned away to hide a smile.</li>
<li class="L2031" rel="L2031"></li>
<li class="L2032" rel="L2032">“Your examination of Mr. Darcy is over, I presume,” said Miss Bingley;</li>
<li class="L2033" rel="L2033">“and pray what is the result?”</li>
<li class="L2034" rel="L2034"></li>
<li class="L2035" rel="L2035">“I am perfectly convinced by it that Mr. Darcy has no defect. He owns it</li>
<li class="L2036" rel="L2036">himself without disguise.”</li>
<li class="L2037" rel="L2037"></li>
<li class="L2038" rel="L2038">“No,” said Darcy, “I have made no such pretension. I have faults enough,</li>
<li class="L2039" rel="L2039">but they are not, I hope, of understanding. My temper I dare not vouch</li>
<li class="L2040" rel="L2040">for. It is, I believe, too little yielding--certainly too little for the</li>
<li class="L2041" rel="L2041">convenience of the world. I cannot forget the follies and vices of others</li>
<li class="L2042" rel="L2042">so soon as I ought, nor their offenses against myself. My feelings</li>
<li class="L2043" rel="L2043">are not puffed about with every attempt to move them. My temper</li>
<li class="L2044" rel="L2044">would perhaps be called resentful. My good opinion once lost, is lost</li>
<li class="L2045" rel="L2045">forever.”</li>
<li class="L2046" rel="L2046"></li>
<li class="L2047" rel="L2047">“_That_ is a failing indeed!” cried Elizabeth. “Implacable resentment</li>
<li class="L2048" rel="L2048">_is_ a shade in a character. But you have chosen your fault well. I</li>
<li class="L2049" rel="L2049">really cannot _laugh_ at it. You are safe from me.”</li>
<li class="L2050" rel="L2050"></li>
<li class="L2051" rel="L2051">“There is, I believe, in every disposition a tendency to some particular</li>
<li class="L2052" rel="L2052">evil--a natural defect, which not even the best education can overcome.”</li>
<li class="L2053" rel="L2053"></li>
<li class="L2054" rel="L2054">“And _your_ defect is to hate everybody.”</li>
<li class="L2055" rel="L2055"></li>
<li class="L2056" rel="L2056">“And yours,” he replied with a smile, “is willfully to misunderstand</li>
<li class="L2057" rel="L2057">them.”</li>
<li class="L2058" rel="L2058"></li>
<li class="L2059" rel="L2059">“Do let us have a little music,” cried Miss Bingley, tired of a</li>
<li class="L2060" rel="L2060">conversation in which she had no share. “Louisa, you will not mind my</li>
<li class="L2061" rel="L2061">waking Mr. Hurst?”</li>
<li class="L2062" rel="L2062"></li>
<li class="L2063" rel="L2063">Her sister had not the smallest objection, and the pianoforte was</li>
<li class="L2064" rel="L2064">opened; and Darcy, after a few moments&#39; recollection, was not sorry for</li>
<li class="L2065" rel="L2065">it. He began to feel the danger of paying Elizabeth too much attention.</li>
<li class="L2066" rel="L2066"></li>
<li class="L2067" rel="L2067"></li>
<li class="L2068" rel="L2068"></li>
<li class="L2069" rel="L2069">Chapter 12</li>
<li class="L2070" rel="L2070"></li>
<li class="L2071" rel="L2071"></li>
<li class="L2072" rel="L2072">In consequence of an agreement between the sisters, Elizabeth wrote the</li>
<li class="L2073" rel="L2073">next morning to their mother, to beg that the carriage might be sent for</li>
<li class="L2074" rel="L2074">them in the course of the day. But Mrs. Bennet, who had calculated on</li>
<li class="L2075" rel="L2075">her daughters remaining at Netherfield till the following Tuesday, which</li>
<li class="L2076" rel="L2076">would exactly finish Jane&#39;s week, could not bring herself to receive</li>
<li class="L2077" rel="L2077">them with pleasure before. Her answer, therefore, was not propitious, at</li>
<li class="L2078" rel="L2078">least not to Elizabeth&#39;s wishes, for she was impatient to get home. Mrs.</li>
<li class="L2079" rel="L2079">Bennet sent them word that they could not possibly have the carriage</li>
<li class="L2080" rel="L2080">before Tuesday; and in her postscript it was added, that if Mr. Bingley</li>
<li class="L2081" rel="L2081">and his sister pressed them to stay longer, she could spare them</li>
<li class="L2082" rel="L2082">very well. Against staying longer, however, Elizabeth was positively</li>
<li class="L2083" rel="L2083">resolved--nor did she much expect it would be asked; and fearful, on the</li>
<li class="L2084" rel="L2084">contrary, as being considered as intruding themselves needlessly long,</li>
<li class="L2085" rel="L2085">she urged Jane to borrow Mr. Bingley&#39;s carriage immediately, and at</li>
<li class="L2086" rel="L2086">length it was settled that their original design of leaving Netherfield</li>
<li class="L2087" rel="L2087">that morning should be mentioned, and the request made.</li>
<li class="L2088" rel="L2088"></li>
<li class="L2089" rel="L2089">The communication excited many professions of concern; and enough was</li>
<li class="L2090" rel="L2090">said of wishing them to stay at least till the following day to work</li>
<li class="L2091" rel="L2091">on Jane; and till the morrow their going was deferred. Miss Bingley was</li>
<li class="L2092" rel="L2092">then sorry that she had proposed the delay, for her jealousy and dislike</li>
<li class="L2093" rel="L2093">of one sister much exceeded her affection for the other.</li>
<li class="L2094" rel="L2094"></li>
<li class="L2095" rel="L2095">The master of the house heard with real sorrow that they were to go so</li>
<li class="L2096" rel="L2096">soon, and repeatedly tried to persuade Miss Bennet that it would not be</li>
<li class="L2097" rel="L2097">safe for her--that she was not enough recovered; but Jane was firm where</li>
<li class="L2098" rel="L2098">she felt herself to be right.</li>
<li class="L2099" rel="L2099"></li>
<li class="L2100" rel="L2100">To Mr. Darcy it was welcome intelligence--Elizabeth had been at</li>
<li class="L2101" rel="L2101">Netherfield long enough. She attracted him more than he liked--and Miss</li>
<li class="L2102" rel="L2102">Bingley was uncivil to _her_, and more teasing than usual to himself.</li>
<li class="L2103" rel="L2103">He wisely resolved to be particularly careful that no sign of admiration</li>
<li class="L2104" rel="L2104">should _now_ escape him, nothing that could elevate her with the hope</li>
<li class="L2105" rel="L2105">of influencing his felicity; sensible that if such an idea had been</li>
<li class="L2106" rel="L2106">suggested, his behaviour during the last day must have material weight</li>
<li class="L2107" rel="L2107">in confirming or crushing it. Steady to his purpose, he scarcely spoke</li>
<li class="L2108" rel="L2108">ten words to her through the whole of Saturday, and though they were</li>
<li class="L2109" rel="L2109">at one time left by themselves for half-an-hour, he adhered most</li>
<li class="L2110" rel="L2110">conscientiously to his book, and would not even look at her.</li>
<li class="L2111" rel="L2111"></li>
<li class="L2112" rel="L2112">On Sunday, after morning service, the separation, so agreeable to almost</li>
<li class="L2113" rel="L2113">all, took place. Miss Bingley&#39;s civility to Elizabeth increased at last</li>
<li class="L2114" rel="L2114">very rapidly, as well as her affection for Jane; and when they parted,</li>
<li class="L2115" rel="L2115">after assuring the latter of the pleasure it would always give her</li>
<li class="L2116" rel="L2116">to see her either at Longbourn or Netherfield, and embracing her most</li>
<li class="L2117" rel="L2117">tenderly, she even shook hands with the former. Elizabeth took leave of</li>
<li class="L2118" rel="L2118">the whole party in the liveliest of spirits.</li>
<li class="L2119" rel="L2119"></li>
<li class="L2120" rel="L2120">They were not welcomed home very cordially by their mother. Mrs. Bennet</li>
<li class="L2121" rel="L2121">wondered at their coming, and thought them very wrong to give so much</li>
<li class="L2122" rel="L2122">trouble, and was sure Jane would have caught cold again. But their</li>
<li class="L2123" rel="L2123">father, though very laconic in his expressions of pleasure, was really</li>
<li class="L2124" rel="L2124">glad to see them; he had felt their importance in the family circle. The</li>
<li class="L2125" rel="L2125">evening conversation, when they were all assembled, had lost much of</li>
<li class="L2126" rel="L2126">its animation, and almost all its sense by the absence of Jane and</li>
<li class="L2127" rel="L2127">Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L2128" rel="L2128"></li>
<li class="L2129" rel="L2129">They found Mary, as usual, deep in the study of thorough-bass and human</li>
<li class="L2130" rel="L2130">nature; and had some extracts to admire, and some new observations of</li>
<li class="L2131" rel="L2131">threadbare morality to listen to. Catherine and Lydia had information</li>
<li class="L2132" rel="L2132">for them of a different sort. Much had been done and much had been said</li>
<li class="L2133" rel="L2133">in the regiment since the preceding Wednesday; several of the officers</li>
<li class="L2134" rel="L2134">had dined lately with their uncle, a private had been flogged, and it</li>
<li class="L2135" rel="L2135">had actually been hinted that Colonel Forster was going to be married.</li>
<li class="L2136" rel="L2136"></li>
<li class="L2137" rel="L2137"></li>
<li class="L2138" rel="L2138"></li>
<li class="L2139" rel="L2139">Chapter 13</li>
<li class="L2140" rel="L2140"></li>
<li class="L2141" rel="L2141"></li>
<li class="L2142" rel="L2142">“I hope, my dear,” said Mr. Bennet to his wife, as they were at</li>
<li class="L2143" rel="L2143">breakfast the next morning, “that you have ordered a good dinner to-day,</li>
<li class="L2144" rel="L2144">because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.”</li>
<li class="L2145" rel="L2145"></li>
<li class="L2146" rel="L2146">“Who do you mean, my dear? I know of nobody that is coming, I am sure,</li>
<li class="L2147" rel="L2147">unless Charlotte Lucas should happen to call in--and I hope _my_ dinners</li>
<li class="L2148" rel="L2148">are good enough for her. I do not believe she often sees such at home.”</li>
<li class="L2149" rel="L2149"></li>
<li class="L2150" rel="L2150">“The person of whom I speak is a gentleman, and a stranger.”</li>
<li class="L2151" rel="L2151"></li>
<li class="L2152" rel="L2152">Mrs. Bennet&#39;s eyes sparkled. “A gentleman and a stranger! It is Mr.</li>
<li class="L2153" rel="L2153">Bingley, I am sure! Well, I am sure I shall be extremely glad to see Mr.</li>
<li class="L2154" rel="L2154">Bingley. But--good Lord! how unlucky! There is not a bit of fish to be</li>
<li class="L2155" rel="L2155">got to-day. Lydia, my love, ring the bell--I must speak to Hill this</li>
<li class="L2156" rel="L2156">moment.”</li>
<li class="L2157" rel="L2157"></li>
<li class="L2158" rel="L2158">“It is _not_ Mr. Bingley,” said her husband; “it is a person whom I</li>
<li class="L2159" rel="L2159">never saw in the whole course of my life.”</li>
<li class="L2160" rel="L2160"></li>
<li class="L2161" rel="L2161">This roused a general astonishment; and he had the pleasure of being</li>
<li class="L2162" rel="L2162">eagerly questioned by his wife and his five daughters at once.</li>
<li class="L2163" rel="L2163"></li>
<li class="L2164" rel="L2164">After amusing himself some time with their curiosity, he thus explained:</li>
<li class="L2165" rel="L2165"></li>
<li class="L2166" rel="L2166">“About a month ago I received this letter; and about a fortnight ago</li>
<li class="L2167" rel="L2167">I answered it, for I thought it a case of some delicacy, and requiring</li>
<li class="L2168" rel="L2168">early attention. It is from my cousin, Mr. Collins, who, when I am dead,</li>
<li class="L2169" rel="L2169">may turn you all out of this house as soon as he pleases.”</li>
<li class="L2170" rel="L2170"></li>
<li class="L2171" rel="L2171">“Oh! my dear,” cried his wife, “I cannot bear to hear that mentioned.</li>
<li class="L2172" rel="L2172">Pray do not talk of that odious man. I do think it is the hardest thing</li>
<li class="L2173" rel="L2173">in the world, that your estate should be entailed away from your own</li>
<li class="L2174" rel="L2174">children; and I am sure, if I had been you, I should have tried long ago</li>
<li class="L2175" rel="L2175">to do something or other about it.”</li>
<li class="L2176" rel="L2176"></li>
<li class="L2177" rel="L2177">Jane and Elizabeth tried to explain to her the nature of an entail. They</li>
<li class="L2178" rel="L2178">had often attempted to do it before, but it was a subject on which</li>
<li class="L2179" rel="L2179">Mrs. Bennet was beyond the reach of reason, and she continued to rail</li>
<li class="L2180" rel="L2180">bitterly against the cruelty of settling an estate away from a family of</li>
<li class="L2181" rel="L2181">five daughters, in favour of a man whom nobody cared anything about.</li>
<li class="L2182" rel="L2182"></li>
<li class="L2183" rel="L2183">“It certainly is a most iniquitous affair,” said Mr. Bennet, “and</li>
<li class="L2184" rel="L2184">nothing can clear Mr. Collins from the guilt of inheriting Longbourn.</li>
<li class="L2185" rel="L2185">But if you will listen to his letter, you may perhaps be a little</li>
<li class="L2186" rel="L2186">softened by his manner of expressing himself.”</li>
<li class="L2187" rel="L2187"></li>
<li class="L2188" rel="L2188">“No, that I am sure I shall not; and I think it is very impertinent of</li>
<li class="L2189" rel="L2189">him to write to you at all, and very hypocritical. I hate such false</li>
<li class="L2190" rel="L2190">friends. Why could he not keep on quarreling with you, as his father did</li>
<li class="L2191" rel="L2191">before him?”</li>
<li class="L2192" rel="L2192"></li>
<li class="L2193" rel="L2193">“Why, indeed; he does seem to have had some filial scruples on that</li>
<li class="L2194" rel="L2194">head, as you will hear.”</li>
<li class="L2195" rel="L2195"></li>
<li class="L2196" rel="L2196">“Hunsford, near Westerham, Kent, 15th October.</li>
<li class="L2197" rel="L2197"></li>
<li class="L2198" rel="L2198">“Dear Sir,--</li>
<li class="L2199" rel="L2199"></li>
<li class="L2200" rel="L2200">“The disagreement subsisting between yourself and my late honoured</li>
<li class="L2201" rel="L2201">father always gave me much uneasiness, and since I have had the</li>
<li class="L2202" rel="L2202">misfortune to lose him, I have frequently wished to heal the breach; but</li>
<li class="L2203" rel="L2203">for some time I was kept back by my own doubts, fearing lest it might</li>
<li class="L2204" rel="L2204">seem disrespectful to his memory for me to be on good terms with anyone</li>
<li class="L2205" rel="L2205">with whom it had always pleased him to be at variance.--&#39;There, Mrs.</li>
<li class="L2206" rel="L2206">Bennet.&#39;--My mind, however, is now made up on the subject, for having</li>
<li class="L2207" rel="L2207">received ordination at Easter, I have been so fortunate as to be</li>
<li class="L2208" rel="L2208">distinguished by the patronage of the Right Honourable Lady Catherine de</li>
<li class="L2209" rel="L2209">Bourgh, widow of Sir Lewis de Bourgh, whose bounty and beneficence has</li>
<li class="L2210" rel="L2210">preferred me to the valuable rectory of this parish, where it shall be</li>
<li class="L2211" rel="L2211">my earnest endeavour to demean myself with grateful respect towards her</li>
<li class="L2212" rel="L2212">ladyship, and be ever ready to perform those rites and ceremonies which</li>
<li class="L2213" rel="L2213">are instituted by the Church of England. As a clergyman, moreover, I</li>
<li class="L2214" rel="L2214">feel it my duty to promote and establish the blessing of peace in</li>
<li class="L2215" rel="L2215">all families within the reach of my influence; and on these grounds I</li>
<li class="L2216" rel="L2216">flatter myself that my present overtures are highly commendable, and</li>
<li class="L2217" rel="L2217">that the circumstance of my being next in the entail of Longbourn estate</li>
<li class="L2218" rel="L2218">will be kindly overlooked on your side, and not lead you to reject the</li>
<li class="L2219" rel="L2219">offered olive-branch. I cannot be otherwise than concerned at being the</li>
<li class="L2220" rel="L2220">means of injuring your amiable daughters, and beg leave to apologise for</li>
<li class="L2221" rel="L2221">it, as well as to assure you of my readiness to make them every possible</li>
<li class="L2222" rel="L2222">amends--but of this hereafter. If you should have no objection to</li>
<li class="L2223" rel="L2223">receive me into your house, I propose myself the satisfaction of waiting</li>
<li class="L2224" rel="L2224">on you and your family, Monday, November 18th, by four o&#39;clock, and</li>
<li class="L2225" rel="L2225">shall probably trespass on your hospitality till the Saturday se&#39;ennight</li>
<li class="L2226" rel="L2226">following, which I can do without any inconvenience, as Lady Catherine</li>
<li class="L2227" rel="L2227">is far from objecting to my occasional absence on a Sunday, provided</li>
<li class="L2228" rel="L2228">that some other clergyman is engaged to do the duty of the day.--I</li>
<li class="L2229" rel="L2229">remain, dear sir, with respectful compliments to your lady and</li>
<li class="L2230" rel="L2230">daughters, your well-wisher and friend,</li>
<li class="L2231" rel="L2231"></li>
<li class="L2232" rel="L2232">“WILLIAM COLLINS”</li>
<li class="L2233" rel="L2233"></li>
<li class="L2234" rel="L2234">“At four o&#39;clock, therefore, we may expect this peace-making gentleman,”</li>
<li class="L2235" rel="L2235"> said Mr. Bennet, as he folded up the letter. “He seems to be a most</li>
<li class="L2236" rel="L2236">conscientious and polite young man, upon my word, and I doubt not will</li>
<li class="L2237" rel="L2237">prove a valuable acquaintance, especially if Lady Catherine should be so</li>
<li class="L2238" rel="L2238">indulgent as to let him come to us again.”</li>
<li class="L2239" rel="L2239"></li>
<li class="L2240" rel="L2240">“There is some sense in what he says about the girls, however, and if</li>
<li class="L2241" rel="L2241">he is disposed to make them any amends, I shall not be the person to</li>
<li class="L2242" rel="L2242">discourage him.”</li>
<li class="L2243" rel="L2243"></li>
<li class="L2244" rel="L2244">“Though it is difficult,” said Jane, “to guess in what way he can mean</li>
<li class="L2245" rel="L2245">to make us the atonement he thinks our due, the wish is certainly to his</li>
<li class="L2246" rel="L2246">credit.”</li>
<li class="L2247" rel="L2247"></li>
<li class="L2248" rel="L2248">Elizabeth was chiefly struck by his extraordinary deference for Lady</li>
<li class="L2249" rel="L2249">Catherine, and his kind intention of christening, marrying, and burying</li>
<li class="L2250" rel="L2250">his parishioners whenever it were required.</li>
<li class="L2251" rel="L2251"></li>
<li class="L2252" rel="L2252">“He must be an oddity, I think,” said she. “I cannot make him</li>
<li class="L2253" rel="L2253">out.--There is something very pompous in his style.--And what can he</li>
<li class="L2254" rel="L2254">mean by apologising for being next in the entail?--We cannot suppose he</li>
<li class="L2255" rel="L2255">would help it if he could.--Could he be a sensible man, sir?”</li>
<li class="L2256" rel="L2256"></li>
<li class="L2257" rel="L2257">“No, my dear, I think not. I have great hopes of finding him quite the</li>
<li class="L2258" rel="L2258">reverse. There is a mixture of servility and self-importance in his</li>
<li class="L2259" rel="L2259">letter, which promises well. I am impatient to see him.”</li>
<li class="L2260" rel="L2260"></li>
<li class="L2261" rel="L2261">“In point of composition,” said Mary, “the letter does not seem</li>
<li class="L2262" rel="L2262">defective. The idea of the olive-branch perhaps is not wholly new, yet I</li>
<li class="L2263" rel="L2263">think it is well expressed.”</li>
<li class="L2264" rel="L2264"></li>
<li class="L2265" rel="L2265">To Catherine and Lydia, neither the letter nor its writer were in any</li>
<li class="L2266" rel="L2266">degree interesting. It was next to impossible that their cousin should</li>
<li class="L2267" rel="L2267">come in a scarlet coat, and it was now some weeks since they had</li>
<li class="L2268" rel="L2268">received pleasure from the society of a man in any other colour. As for</li>
<li class="L2269" rel="L2269">their mother, Mr. Collins&#39;s letter had done away much of her ill-will,</li>
<li class="L2270" rel="L2270">and she was preparing to see him with a degree of composure which</li>
<li class="L2271" rel="L2271">astonished her husband and daughters.</li>
<li class="L2272" rel="L2272"></li>
<li class="L2273" rel="L2273">Mr. Collins was punctual to his time, and was received with great</li>
<li class="L2274" rel="L2274">politeness by the whole family. Mr. Bennet indeed said little; but the</li>
<li class="L2275" rel="L2275">ladies were ready enough to talk, and Mr. Collins seemed neither in</li>
<li class="L2276" rel="L2276">need of encouragement, nor inclined to be silent himself. He was a</li>
<li class="L2277" rel="L2277">tall, heavy-looking young man of five-and-twenty. His air was grave and</li>
<li class="L2278" rel="L2278">stately, and his manners were very formal. He had not been long seated</li>
<li class="L2279" rel="L2279">before he complimented Mrs. Bennet on having so fine a family of</li>
<li class="L2280" rel="L2280">daughters; said he had heard much of their beauty, but that in this</li>
<li class="L2281" rel="L2281">instance fame had fallen short of the truth; and added, that he did</li>
<li class="L2282" rel="L2282">not doubt her seeing them all in due time disposed of in marriage. This</li>
<li class="L2283" rel="L2283">gallantry was not much to the taste of some of his hearers; but Mrs.</li>
<li class="L2284" rel="L2284">Bennet, who quarreled with no compliments, answered most readily.</li>
<li class="L2285" rel="L2285"></li>
<li class="L2286" rel="L2286">“You are very kind, I am sure; and I wish with all my heart it may</li>
<li class="L2287" rel="L2287">prove so, for else they will be destitute enough. Things are settled so</li>
<li class="L2288" rel="L2288">oddly.”</li>
<li class="L2289" rel="L2289"></li>
<li class="L2290" rel="L2290">“You allude, perhaps, to the entail of this estate.”</li>
<li class="L2291" rel="L2291"></li>
<li class="L2292" rel="L2292">“Ah! sir, I do indeed. It is a grievous affair to my poor girls, you</li>
<li class="L2293" rel="L2293">must confess. Not that I mean to find fault with _you_, for such things</li>
<li class="L2294" rel="L2294">I know are all chance in this world. There is no knowing how estates</li>
<li class="L2295" rel="L2295">will go when once they come to be entailed.”</li>
<li class="L2296" rel="L2296"></li>
<li class="L2297" rel="L2297">“I am very sensible, madam, of the hardship to my fair cousins, and</li>
<li class="L2298" rel="L2298">could say much on the subject, but that I am cautious of appearing</li>
<li class="L2299" rel="L2299">forward and precipitate. But I can assure the young ladies that I come</li>
<li class="L2300" rel="L2300">prepared to admire them. At present I will not say more; but, perhaps,</li>
<li class="L2301" rel="L2301">when we are better acquainted--”</li>
<li class="L2302" rel="L2302"></li>
<li class="L2303" rel="L2303">He was interrupted by a summons to dinner; and the girls smiled on each</li>
<li class="L2304" rel="L2304">other. They were not the only objects of Mr. Collins&#39;s admiration. The</li>
<li class="L2305" rel="L2305">hall, the dining-room, and all its furniture, were examined and praised;</li>
<li class="L2306" rel="L2306">and his commendation of everything would have touched Mrs. Bennet&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2307" rel="L2307">heart, but for the mortifying supposition of his viewing it all as his</li>
<li class="L2308" rel="L2308">own future property. The dinner too in its turn was highly admired; and</li>
<li class="L2309" rel="L2309">he begged to know to which of his fair cousins the excellency of its</li>
<li class="L2310" rel="L2310">cooking was owing. But he was set right there by Mrs. Bennet, who</li>
<li class="L2311" rel="L2311">assured him with some asperity that they were very well able to keep a</li>
<li class="L2312" rel="L2312">good cook, and that her daughters had nothing to do in the kitchen. He</li>
<li class="L2313" rel="L2313">begged pardon for having displeased her. In a softened tone she declared</li>
<li class="L2314" rel="L2314">herself not at all offended; but he continued to apologise for about a</li>
<li class="L2315" rel="L2315">quarter of an hour.</li>
<li class="L2316" rel="L2316"></li>
<li class="L2317" rel="L2317"></li>
<li class="L2318" rel="L2318"></li>
<li class="L2319" rel="L2319">Chapter 14</li>
<li class="L2320" rel="L2320"></li>
<li class="L2321" rel="L2321"></li>
<li class="L2322" rel="L2322">During dinner, Mr. Bennet scarcely spoke at all; but when the servants</li>
<li class="L2323" rel="L2323">were withdrawn, he thought it time to have some conversation with his</li>
<li class="L2324" rel="L2324">guest, and therefore started a subject in which he expected him to</li>
<li class="L2325" rel="L2325">shine, by observing that he seemed very fortunate in his patroness. Lady</li>
<li class="L2326" rel="L2326">Catherine de Bourgh&#39;s attention to his wishes, and consideration for</li>
<li class="L2327" rel="L2327">his comfort, appeared very remarkable. Mr. Bennet could not have chosen</li>
<li class="L2328" rel="L2328">better. Mr. Collins was eloquent in her praise. The subject elevated him</li>
<li class="L2329" rel="L2329">to more than usual solemnity of manner, and with a most important aspect</li>
<li class="L2330" rel="L2330">he protested that “he had never in his life witnessed such behaviour in</li>
<li class="L2331" rel="L2331">a person of rank--such affability and condescension, as he had himself</li>
<li class="L2332" rel="L2332">experienced from Lady Catherine. She had been graciously pleased to</li>
<li class="L2333" rel="L2333">approve of both of the discourses which he had already had the honour of</li>
<li class="L2334" rel="L2334">preaching before her. She had also asked him twice to dine at Rosings,</li>
<li class="L2335" rel="L2335">and had sent for him only the Saturday before, to make up her pool of</li>
<li class="L2336" rel="L2336">quadrille in the evening. Lady Catherine was reckoned proud by many</li>
<li class="L2337" rel="L2337">people he knew, but _he_ had never seen anything but affability in her.</li>
<li class="L2338" rel="L2338">She had always spoken to him as she would to any other gentleman; she</li>
<li class="L2339" rel="L2339">made not the smallest objection to his joining in the society of the</li>
<li class="L2340" rel="L2340">neighbourhood nor to his leaving the parish occasionally for a week or</li>
<li class="L2341" rel="L2341">two, to visit his relations. She had even condescended to advise him to</li>
<li class="L2342" rel="L2342">marry as soon as he could, provided he chose with discretion; and had</li>
<li class="L2343" rel="L2343">once paid him a visit in his humble parsonage, where she had perfectly</li>
<li class="L2344" rel="L2344">approved all the alterations he had been making, and had even vouchsafed</li>
<li class="L2345" rel="L2345">to suggest some herself--some shelves in the closet up stairs.”</li>
<li class="L2346" rel="L2346"></li>
<li class="L2347" rel="L2347">“That is all very proper and civil, I am sure,” said Mrs. Bennet, “and</li>
<li class="L2348" rel="L2348">I dare say she is a very agreeable woman. It is a pity that great ladies</li>
<li class="L2349" rel="L2349">in general are not more like her. Does she live near you, sir?”</li>
<li class="L2350" rel="L2350"></li>
<li class="L2351" rel="L2351">“The garden in which stands my humble abode is separated only by a lane</li>
<li class="L2352" rel="L2352">from Rosings Park, her ladyship&#39;s residence.”</li>
<li class="L2353" rel="L2353"></li>
<li class="L2354" rel="L2354">“I think you said she was a widow, sir? Has she any family?”</li>
<li class="L2355" rel="L2355"></li>
<li class="L2356" rel="L2356">“She has only one daughter, the heiress of Rosings, and of very</li>
<li class="L2357" rel="L2357">extensive property.”</li>
<li class="L2358" rel="L2358"></li>
<li class="L2359" rel="L2359">“Ah!” said Mrs. Bennet, shaking her head, “then she is better off than</li>
<li class="L2360" rel="L2360">many girls. And what sort of young lady is she? Is she handsome?”</li>
<li class="L2361" rel="L2361"></li>
<li class="L2362" rel="L2362">“She is a most charming young lady indeed. Lady Catherine herself says</li>
<li class="L2363" rel="L2363">that, in point of true beauty, Miss de Bourgh is far superior to the</li>
<li class="L2364" rel="L2364">handsomest of her sex, because there is that in her features which marks</li>
<li class="L2365" rel="L2365">the young lady of distinguished birth. She is unfortunately of a sickly</li>
<li class="L2366" rel="L2366">constitution, which has prevented her from making that progress in many</li>
<li class="L2367" rel="L2367">accomplishments which she could not have otherwise failed of, as I am</li>
<li class="L2368" rel="L2368">informed by the lady who superintended her education, and who still</li>
<li class="L2369" rel="L2369">resides with them. But she is perfectly amiable, and often condescends</li>
<li class="L2370" rel="L2370">to drive by my humble abode in her little phaeton and ponies.”</li>
<li class="L2371" rel="L2371"></li>
<li class="L2372" rel="L2372">“Has she been presented? I do not remember her name among the ladies at</li>
<li class="L2373" rel="L2373">court.”</li>
<li class="L2374" rel="L2374"></li>
<li class="L2375" rel="L2375">“Her indifferent state of health unhappily prevents her being in town;</li>
<li class="L2376" rel="L2376">and by that means, as I told Lady Catherine one day, has deprived the</li>
<li class="L2377" rel="L2377">British court of its brightest ornament. Her ladyship seemed pleased</li>
<li class="L2378" rel="L2378">with the idea; and you may imagine that I am happy on every occasion to</li>
<li class="L2379" rel="L2379">offer those little delicate compliments which are always acceptable</li>
<li class="L2380" rel="L2380">to ladies. I have more than once observed to Lady Catherine, that</li>
<li class="L2381" rel="L2381">her charming daughter seemed born to be a duchess, and that the most</li>
<li class="L2382" rel="L2382">elevated rank, instead of giving her consequence, would be adorned by</li>
<li class="L2383" rel="L2383">her. These are the kind of little things which please her ladyship, and</li>
<li class="L2384" rel="L2384">it is a sort of attention which I conceive myself peculiarly bound to</li>
<li class="L2385" rel="L2385">pay.”</li>
<li class="L2386" rel="L2386"></li>
<li class="L2387" rel="L2387">“You judge very properly,” said Mr. Bennet, “and it is happy for you</li>
<li class="L2388" rel="L2388">that you possess the talent of flattering with delicacy. May I ask</li>
<li class="L2389" rel="L2389">whether these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the</li>
<li class="L2390" rel="L2390">moment, or are the result of previous study?”</li>
<li class="L2391" rel="L2391"></li>
<li class="L2392" rel="L2392">“They arise chiefly from what is passing at the time, and though I</li>
<li class="L2393" rel="L2393">sometimes amuse myself with suggesting and arranging such little elegant</li>
<li class="L2394" rel="L2394">compliments as may be adapted to ordinary occasions, I always wish to</li>
<li class="L2395" rel="L2395">give them as unstudied an air as possible.”</li>
<li class="L2396" rel="L2396"></li>
<li class="L2397" rel="L2397">Mr. Bennet&#39;s expectations were fully answered. His cousin was as absurd</li>
<li class="L2398" rel="L2398">as he had hoped, and he listened to him with the keenest enjoyment,</li>
<li class="L2399" rel="L2399">maintaining at the same time the most resolute composure of countenance,</li>
<li class="L2400" rel="L2400">and, except in an occasional glance at Elizabeth, requiring no partner</li>
<li class="L2401" rel="L2401">in his pleasure.</li>
<li class="L2402" rel="L2402"></li>
<li class="L2403" rel="L2403">By tea-time, however, the dose had been enough, and Mr. Bennet was glad</li>
<li class="L2404" rel="L2404">to take his guest into the drawing-room again, and, when tea was over,</li>
<li class="L2405" rel="L2405">glad to invite him to read aloud to the ladies. Mr. Collins readily</li>
<li class="L2406" rel="L2406">assented, and a book was produced; but, on beholding it (for everything</li>
<li class="L2407" rel="L2407">announced it to be from a circulating library), he started back, and</li>
<li class="L2408" rel="L2408">begging pardon, protested that he never read novels. Kitty stared at</li>
<li class="L2409" rel="L2409">him, and Lydia exclaimed. Other books were produced, and after some</li>
<li class="L2410" rel="L2410">deliberation he chose Fordyce&#39;s Sermons. Lydia gaped as he opened the</li>
<li class="L2411" rel="L2411">volume, and before he had, with very monotonous solemnity, read three</li>
<li class="L2412" rel="L2412">pages, she interrupted him with:</li>
<li class="L2413" rel="L2413"></li>
<li class="L2414" rel="L2414">“Do you know, mamma, that my uncle Phillips talks of turning away</li>
<li class="L2415" rel="L2415">Richard; and if he does, Colonel Forster will hire him. My aunt told me</li>
<li class="L2416" rel="L2416">so herself on Saturday. I shall walk to Meryton to-morrow to hear more</li>
<li class="L2417" rel="L2417">about it, and to ask when Mr. Denny comes back from town.”</li>
<li class="L2418" rel="L2418"></li>
<li class="L2419" rel="L2419">Lydia was bid by her two eldest sisters to hold her tongue; but Mr.</li>
<li class="L2420" rel="L2420">Collins, much offended, laid aside his book, and said:</li>
<li class="L2421" rel="L2421"></li>
<li class="L2422" rel="L2422">“I have often observed how little young ladies are interested by books</li>
<li class="L2423" rel="L2423">of a serious stamp, though written solely for their benefit. It amazes</li>
<li class="L2424" rel="L2424">me, I confess; for, certainly, there can be nothing so advantageous to</li>
<li class="L2425" rel="L2425">them as instruction. But I will no longer importune my young cousin.”</li>
<li class="L2426" rel="L2426"></li>
<li class="L2427" rel="L2427">Then turning to Mr. Bennet, he offered himself as his antagonist at</li>
<li class="L2428" rel="L2428">backgammon. Mr. Bennet accepted the challenge, observing that he acted</li>
<li class="L2429" rel="L2429">very wisely in leaving the girls to their own trifling amusements.</li>
<li class="L2430" rel="L2430">Mrs. Bennet and her daughters apologised most civilly for Lydia&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2431" rel="L2431">interruption, and promised that it should not occur again, if he would</li>
<li class="L2432" rel="L2432">resume his book; but Mr. Collins, after assuring them that he bore his</li>
<li class="L2433" rel="L2433">young cousin no ill-will, and should never resent her behaviour as any</li>
<li class="L2434" rel="L2434">affront, seated himself at another table with Mr. Bennet, and prepared</li>
<li class="L2435" rel="L2435">for backgammon.</li>
<li class="L2436" rel="L2436"></li>
<li class="L2437" rel="L2437"></li>
<li class="L2438" rel="L2438"></li>
<li class="L2439" rel="L2439">Chapter 15</li>
<li class="L2440" rel="L2440"></li>
<li class="L2441" rel="L2441"></li>
<li class="L2442" rel="L2442">Mr. Collins was not a sensible man, and the deficiency of nature had</li>
<li class="L2443" rel="L2443">been but little assisted by education or society; the greatest part</li>
<li class="L2444" rel="L2444">of his life having been spent under the guidance of an illiterate and</li>
<li class="L2445" rel="L2445">miserly father; and though he belonged to one of the universities, he</li>
<li class="L2446" rel="L2446">had merely kept the necessary terms, without forming at it any useful</li>
<li class="L2447" rel="L2447">acquaintance. The subjection in which his father had brought him up had</li>
<li class="L2448" rel="L2448">given him originally great humility of manner; but it was now a</li>
<li class="L2449" rel="L2449">good deal counteracted by the self-conceit of a weak head, living in</li>
<li class="L2450" rel="L2450">retirement, and the consequential feelings of early and unexpected</li>
<li class="L2451" rel="L2451">prosperity. A fortunate chance had recommended him to Lady Catherine de</li>
<li class="L2452" rel="L2452">Bourgh when the living of Hunsford was vacant; and the respect which</li>
<li class="L2453" rel="L2453">he felt for her high rank, and his veneration for her as his patroness,</li>
<li class="L2454" rel="L2454">mingling with a very good opinion of himself, of his authority as a</li>
<li class="L2455" rel="L2455">clergyman, and his right as a rector, made him altogether a mixture of</li>
<li class="L2456" rel="L2456">pride and obsequiousness, self-importance and humility.</li>
<li class="L2457" rel="L2457"></li>
<li class="L2458" rel="L2458">Having now a good house and a very sufficient income, he intended to</li>
<li class="L2459" rel="L2459">marry; and in seeking a reconciliation with the Longbourn family he had</li>
<li class="L2460" rel="L2460">a wife in view, as he meant to choose one of the daughters, if he found</li>
<li class="L2461" rel="L2461">them as handsome and amiable as they were represented by common report.</li>
<li class="L2462" rel="L2462">This was his plan of amends--of atonement--for inheriting their father&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2463" rel="L2463">estate; and he thought it an excellent one, full of eligibility and</li>
<li class="L2464" rel="L2464">suitableness, and excessively generous and disinterested on his own</li>
<li class="L2465" rel="L2465">part.</li>
<li class="L2466" rel="L2466"></li>
<li class="L2467" rel="L2467">His plan did not vary on seeing them. Miss Bennet&#39;s lovely face</li>
<li class="L2468" rel="L2468">confirmed his views, and established all his strictest notions of what</li>
<li class="L2469" rel="L2469">was due to seniority; and for the first evening _she_ was his settled</li>
<li class="L2470" rel="L2470">choice. The next morning, however, made an alteration; for in a</li>
<li class="L2471" rel="L2471">quarter of an hour&#39;s tete-a-tete with Mrs. Bennet before breakfast, a</li>
<li class="L2472" rel="L2472">conversation beginning with his parsonage-house, and leading naturally</li>
<li class="L2473" rel="L2473">to the avowal of his hopes, that a mistress might be found for it at</li>
<li class="L2474" rel="L2474">Longbourn, produced from her, amid very complaisant smiles and general</li>
<li class="L2475" rel="L2475">encouragement, a caution against the very Jane he had fixed on. “As to</li>
<li class="L2476" rel="L2476">her _younger_ daughters, she could not take upon her to say--she could</li>
<li class="L2477" rel="L2477">not positively answer--but she did not _know_ of any prepossession; her</li>
<li class="L2478" rel="L2478">_eldest_ daughter, she must just mention--she felt it incumbent on her</li>
<li class="L2479" rel="L2479">to hint, was likely to be very soon engaged.”</li>
<li class="L2480" rel="L2480"></li>
<li class="L2481" rel="L2481">Mr. Collins had only to change from Jane to Elizabeth--and it was soon</li>
<li class="L2482" rel="L2482">done--done while Mrs. Bennet was stirring the fire. Elizabeth, equally</li>
<li class="L2483" rel="L2483">next to Jane in birth and beauty, succeeded her of course.</li>
<li class="L2484" rel="L2484"></li>
<li class="L2485" rel="L2485">Mrs. Bennet treasured up the hint, and trusted that she might soon have</li>
<li class="L2486" rel="L2486">two daughters married; and the man whom she could not bear to speak of</li>
<li class="L2487" rel="L2487">the day before was now high in her good graces.</li>
<li class="L2488" rel="L2488"></li>
<li class="L2489" rel="L2489">Lydia&#39;s intention of walking to Meryton was not forgotten; every sister</li>
<li class="L2490" rel="L2490">except Mary agreed to go with her; and Mr. Collins was to attend them,</li>
<li class="L2491" rel="L2491">at the request of Mr. Bennet, who was most anxious to get rid of him,</li>
<li class="L2492" rel="L2492">and have his library to himself; for thither Mr. Collins had followed</li>
<li class="L2493" rel="L2493">him after breakfast; and there he would continue, nominally engaged with</li>
<li class="L2494" rel="L2494">one of the largest folios in the collection, but really talking to Mr.</li>
<li class="L2495" rel="L2495">Bennet, with little cessation, of his house and garden at Hunsford. Such</li>
<li class="L2496" rel="L2496">doings discomposed Mr. Bennet exceedingly. In his library he had been</li>
<li class="L2497" rel="L2497">always sure of leisure and tranquillity; and though prepared, as he told</li>
<li class="L2498" rel="L2498">Elizabeth, to meet with folly and conceit in every other room of the</li>
<li class="L2499" rel="L2499">house, he was used to be free from them there; his civility, therefore,</li>
<li class="L2500" rel="L2500">was most prompt in inviting Mr. Collins to join his daughters in their</li>
<li class="L2501" rel="L2501">walk; and Mr. Collins, being in fact much better fitted for a walker</li>
<li class="L2502" rel="L2502">than a reader, was extremely pleased to close his large book, and go.</li>
<li class="L2503" rel="L2503"></li>
<li class="L2504" rel="L2504">In pompous nothings on his side, and civil assents on that of his</li>
<li class="L2505" rel="L2505">cousins, their time passed till they entered Meryton. The attention of</li>
<li class="L2506" rel="L2506">the younger ones was then no longer to be gained by him. Their eyes were</li>
<li class="L2507" rel="L2507">immediately wandering up in the street in quest of the officers, and</li>
<li class="L2508" rel="L2508">nothing less than a very smart bonnet indeed, or a really new muslin in</li>
<li class="L2509" rel="L2509">a shop window, could recall them.</li>
<li class="L2510" rel="L2510"></li>
<li class="L2511" rel="L2511">But the attention of every lady was soon caught by a young man, whom</li>
<li class="L2512" rel="L2512">they had never seen before, of most gentlemanlike appearance, walking</li>
<li class="L2513" rel="L2513">with another officer on the other side of the way. The officer was</li>
<li class="L2514" rel="L2514">the very Mr. Denny concerning whose return from London Lydia came</li>
<li class="L2515" rel="L2515">to inquire, and he bowed as they passed. All were struck with the</li>
<li class="L2516" rel="L2516">stranger&#39;s air, all wondered who he could be; and Kitty and Lydia,</li>
<li class="L2517" rel="L2517">determined if possible to find out, led the way across the street, under</li>
<li class="L2518" rel="L2518">pretense of wanting something in an opposite shop, and fortunately</li>
<li class="L2519" rel="L2519">had just gained the pavement when the two gentlemen, turning back, had</li>
<li class="L2520" rel="L2520">reached the same spot. Mr. Denny addressed them directly, and entreated</li>
<li class="L2521" rel="L2521">permission to introduce his friend, Mr. Wickham, who had returned with</li>
<li class="L2522" rel="L2522">him the day before from town, and he was happy to say had accepted a</li>
<li class="L2523" rel="L2523">commission in their corps. This was exactly as it should be; for the</li>
<li class="L2524" rel="L2524">young man wanted only regimentals to make him completely charming.</li>
<li class="L2525" rel="L2525">His appearance was greatly in his favour; he had all the best part of</li>
<li class="L2526" rel="L2526">beauty, a fine countenance, a good figure, and very pleasing address.</li>
<li class="L2527" rel="L2527">The introduction was followed up on his side by a happy readiness</li>
<li class="L2528" rel="L2528">of conversation--a readiness at the same time perfectly correct and</li>
<li class="L2529" rel="L2529">unassuming; and the whole party were still standing and talking together</li>
<li class="L2530" rel="L2530">very agreeably, when the sound of horses drew their notice, and Darcy</li>
<li class="L2531" rel="L2531">and Bingley were seen riding down the street. On distinguishing the</li>
<li class="L2532" rel="L2532">ladies of the group, the two gentlemen came directly towards them, and</li>
<li class="L2533" rel="L2533">began the usual civilities. Bingley was the principal spokesman, and</li>
<li class="L2534" rel="L2534">Miss Bennet the principal object. He was then, he said, on his way to</li>
<li class="L2535" rel="L2535">Longbourn on purpose to inquire after her. Mr. Darcy corroborated</li>
<li class="L2536" rel="L2536">it with a bow, and was beginning to determine not to fix his eyes</li>
<li class="L2537" rel="L2537">on Elizabeth, when they were suddenly arrested by the sight of the</li>
<li class="L2538" rel="L2538">stranger, and Elizabeth happening to see the countenance of both as they</li>
<li class="L2539" rel="L2539">looked at each other, was all astonishment at the effect of the meeting.</li>
<li class="L2540" rel="L2540">Both changed colour, one looked white, the other red. Mr. Wickham,</li>
<li class="L2541" rel="L2541">after a few moments, touched his hat--a salutation which Mr. Darcy just</li>
<li class="L2542" rel="L2542">deigned to return. What could be the meaning of it? It was impossible to</li>
<li class="L2543" rel="L2543">imagine; it was impossible not to long to know.</li>
<li class="L2544" rel="L2544"></li>
<li class="L2545" rel="L2545">In another minute, Mr. Bingley, but without seeming to have noticed what</li>
<li class="L2546" rel="L2546">passed, took leave and rode on with his friend.</li>
<li class="L2547" rel="L2547"></li>
<li class="L2548" rel="L2548">Mr. Denny and Mr. Wickham walked with the young ladies to the door of</li>
<li class="L2549" rel="L2549">Mr. Phillip&#39;s house, and then made their bows, in spite of Miss Lydia&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2550" rel="L2550">pressing entreaties that they should come in, and even in spite of</li>
<li class="L2551" rel="L2551">Mrs. Phillips&#39;s throwing up the parlour window and loudly seconding the</li>
<li class="L2552" rel="L2552">invitation.</li>
<li class="L2553" rel="L2553"></li>
<li class="L2554" rel="L2554">Mrs. Phillips was always glad to see her nieces; and the two eldest,</li>
<li class="L2555" rel="L2555">from their recent absence, were particularly welcome, and she was</li>
<li class="L2556" rel="L2556">eagerly expressing her surprise at their sudden return home, which, as</li>
<li class="L2557" rel="L2557">their own carriage had not fetched them, she should have known nothing</li>
<li class="L2558" rel="L2558">about, if she had not happened to see Mr. Jones&#39;s shop-boy in the</li>
<li class="L2559" rel="L2559">street, who had told her that they were not to send any more draughts to</li>
<li class="L2560" rel="L2560">Netherfield because the Miss Bennets were come away, when her civility</li>
<li class="L2561" rel="L2561">was claimed towards Mr. Collins by Jane&#39;s introduction of him. She</li>
<li class="L2562" rel="L2562">received him with her very best politeness, which he returned with</li>
<li class="L2563" rel="L2563">as much more, apologising for his intrusion, without any previous</li>
<li class="L2564" rel="L2564">acquaintance with her, which he could not help flattering himself,</li>
<li class="L2565" rel="L2565">however, might be justified by his relationship to the young ladies who</li>
<li class="L2566" rel="L2566">introduced him to her notice. Mrs. Phillips was quite awed by such an</li>
<li class="L2567" rel="L2567">excess of good breeding; but her contemplation of one stranger was soon</li>
<li class="L2568" rel="L2568">put to an end by exclamations and inquiries about the other; of whom,</li>
<li class="L2569" rel="L2569">however, she could only tell her nieces what they already knew, that</li>
<li class="L2570" rel="L2570">Mr. Denny had brought him from London, and that he was to have a</li>
<li class="L2571" rel="L2571">lieutenant&#39;s commission in the ----shire. She had been watching him the</li>
<li class="L2572" rel="L2572">last hour, she said, as he walked up and down the street, and had Mr.</li>
<li class="L2573" rel="L2573">Wickham appeared, Kitty and Lydia would certainly have continued the</li>
<li class="L2574" rel="L2574">occupation, but unluckily no one passed windows now except a few of the</li>
<li class="L2575" rel="L2575">officers, who, in comparison with the stranger, were become “stupid,</li>
<li class="L2576" rel="L2576">disagreeable fellows.” Some of them were to dine with the Phillipses</li>
<li class="L2577" rel="L2577">the next day, and their aunt promised to make her husband call on Mr.</li>
<li class="L2578" rel="L2578">Wickham, and give him an invitation also, if the family from Longbourn</li>
<li class="L2579" rel="L2579">would come in the evening. This was agreed to, and Mrs. Phillips</li>
<li class="L2580" rel="L2580">protested that they would have a nice comfortable noisy game of lottery</li>
<li class="L2581" rel="L2581">tickets, and a little bit of hot supper afterwards. The prospect of such</li>
<li class="L2582" rel="L2582">delights was very cheering, and they parted in mutual good spirits. Mr.</li>
<li class="L2583" rel="L2583">Collins repeated his apologies in quitting the room, and was assured</li>
<li class="L2584" rel="L2584">with unwearying civility that they were perfectly needless.</li>
<li class="L2585" rel="L2585"></li>
<li class="L2586" rel="L2586">As they walked home, Elizabeth related to Jane what she had seen pass</li>
<li class="L2587" rel="L2587">between the two gentlemen; but though Jane would have defended either</li>
<li class="L2588" rel="L2588">or both, had they appeared to be in the wrong, she could no more explain</li>
<li class="L2589" rel="L2589">such behaviour than her sister.</li>
<li class="L2590" rel="L2590"></li>
<li class="L2591" rel="L2591">Mr. Collins on his return highly gratified Mrs. Bennet by admiring</li>
<li class="L2592" rel="L2592">Mrs. Phillips&#39;s manners and politeness. He protested that, except Lady</li>
<li class="L2593" rel="L2593">Catherine and her daughter, he had never seen a more elegant woman;</li>
<li class="L2594" rel="L2594">for she had not only received him with the utmost civility, but even</li>
<li class="L2595" rel="L2595">pointedly included him in her invitation for the next evening, although</li>
<li class="L2596" rel="L2596">utterly unknown to her before. Something, he supposed, might be</li>
<li class="L2597" rel="L2597">attributed to his connection with them, but yet he had never met with so</li>
<li class="L2598" rel="L2598">much attention in the whole course of his life.</li>
<li class="L2599" rel="L2599"></li>
<li class="L2600" rel="L2600"></li>
<li class="L2601" rel="L2601"></li>
<li class="L2602" rel="L2602">Chapter 16</li>
<li class="L2603" rel="L2603"></li>
<li class="L2604" rel="L2604"></li>
<li class="L2605" rel="L2605">As no objection was made to the young people&#39;s engagement with their</li>
<li class="L2606" rel="L2606">aunt, and all Mr. Collins&#39;s scruples of leaving Mr. and Mrs. Bennet for</li>
<li class="L2607" rel="L2607">a single evening during his visit were most steadily resisted, the coach</li>
<li class="L2608" rel="L2608">conveyed him and his five cousins at a suitable hour to Meryton; and</li>
<li class="L2609" rel="L2609">the girls had the pleasure of hearing, as they entered the drawing-room,</li>
<li class="L2610" rel="L2610">that Mr. Wickham had accepted their uncle&#39;s invitation, and was then in</li>
<li class="L2611" rel="L2611">the house.</li>
<li class="L2612" rel="L2612"></li>
<li class="L2613" rel="L2613">When this information was given, and they had all taken their seats, Mr.</li>
<li class="L2614" rel="L2614">Collins was at leisure to look around him and admire, and he was so much</li>
<li class="L2615" rel="L2615">struck with the size and furniture of the apartment, that he declared he</li>
<li class="L2616" rel="L2616">might almost have supposed himself in the small summer breakfast</li>
<li class="L2617" rel="L2617">parlour at Rosings; a comparison that did not at first convey much</li>
<li class="L2618" rel="L2618">gratification; but when Mrs. Phillips understood from him what</li>
<li class="L2619" rel="L2619">Rosings was, and who was its proprietor--when she had listened to the</li>
<li class="L2620" rel="L2620">description of only one of Lady Catherine&#39;s drawing-rooms, and found</li>
<li class="L2621" rel="L2621">that the chimney-piece alone had cost eight hundred pounds, she felt all</li>
<li class="L2622" rel="L2622">the force of the compliment, and would hardly have resented a comparison</li>
<li class="L2623" rel="L2623">with the housekeeper&#39;s room.</li>
<li class="L2624" rel="L2624"></li>
<li class="L2625" rel="L2625">In describing to her all the grandeur of Lady Catherine and her mansion,</li>
<li class="L2626" rel="L2626">with occasional digressions in praise of his own humble abode, and</li>
<li class="L2627" rel="L2627">the improvements it was receiving, he was happily employed until the</li>
<li class="L2628" rel="L2628">gentlemen joined them; and he found in Mrs. Phillips a very attentive</li>
<li class="L2629" rel="L2629">listener, whose opinion of his consequence increased with what she</li>
<li class="L2630" rel="L2630">heard, and who was resolving to retail it all among her neighbours as</li>
<li class="L2631" rel="L2631">soon as she could. To the girls, who could not listen to their cousin,</li>
<li class="L2632" rel="L2632">and who had nothing to do but to wish for an instrument, and examine</li>
<li class="L2633" rel="L2633">their own indifferent imitations of china on the mantelpiece, the</li>
<li class="L2634" rel="L2634">interval of waiting appeared very long. It was over at last, however.</li>
<li class="L2635" rel="L2635">The gentlemen did approach, and when Mr. Wickham walked into the room,</li>
<li class="L2636" rel="L2636">Elizabeth felt that she had neither been seeing him before, nor thinking</li>
<li class="L2637" rel="L2637">of him since, with the smallest degree of unreasonable admiration.</li>
<li class="L2638" rel="L2638">The officers of the ----shire were in general a very creditable,</li>
<li class="L2639" rel="L2639">gentlemanlike set, and the best of them were of the present party; but</li>
<li class="L2640" rel="L2640">Mr. Wickham was as far beyond them all in person, countenance, air, and</li>
<li class="L2641" rel="L2641">walk, as _they_ were superior to the broad-faced, stuffy uncle Phillips,</li>
<li class="L2642" rel="L2642">breathing port wine, who followed them into the room.</li>
<li class="L2643" rel="L2643"></li>
<li class="L2644" rel="L2644">Mr. Wickham was the happy man towards whom almost every female eye was</li>
<li class="L2645" rel="L2645">turned, and Elizabeth was the happy woman by whom he finally seated</li>
<li class="L2646" rel="L2646">himself; and the agreeable manner in which he immediately fell into</li>
<li class="L2647" rel="L2647">conversation, though it was only on its being a wet night, made her feel</li>
<li class="L2648" rel="L2648">that the commonest, dullest, most threadbare topic might be rendered</li>
<li class="L2649" rel="L2649">interesting by the skill of the speaker.</li>
<li class="L2650" rel="L2650"></li>
<li class="L2651" rel="L2651">With such rivals for the notice of the fair as Mr. Wickham and the</li>
<li class="L2652" rel="L2652">officers, Mr. Collins seemed to sink into insignificance; to the young</li>
<li class="L2653" rel="L2653">ladies he certainly was nothing; but he had still at intervals a kind</li>
<li class="L2654" rel="L2654">listener in Mrs. Phillips, and was by her watchfulness, most abundantly</li>
<li class="L2655" rel="L2655">supplied with coffee and muffin. When the card-tables were placed, he</li>
<li class="L2656" rel="L2656">had the opportunity of obliging her in turn, by sitting down to whist.</li>
<li class="L2657" rel="L2657"></li>
<li class="L2658" rel="L2658">“I know little of the game at present,” said he, “but I shall be glad</li>
<li class="L2659" rel="L2659">to improve myself, for in my situation in life--” Mrs. Phillips was very</li>
<li class="L2660" rel="L2660">glad for his compliance, but could not wait for his reason.</li>
<li class="L2661" rel="L2661"></li>
<li class="L2662" rel="L2662">Mr. Wickham did not play at whist, and with ready delight was he</li>
<li class="L2663" rel="L2663">received at the other table between Elizabeth and Lydia. At first there</li>
<li class="L2664" rel="L2664">seemed danger of Lydia&#39;s engrossing him entirely, for she was a most</li>
<li class="L2665" rel="L2665">determined talker; but being likewise extremely fond of lottery tickets,</li>
<li class="L2666" rel="L2666">she soon grew too much interested in the game, too eager in making bets</li>
<li class="L2667" rel="L2667">and exclaiming after prizes to have attention for anyone in particular.</li>
<li class="L2668" rel="L2668">Allowing for the common demands of the game, Mr. Wickham was therefore</li>
<li class="L2669" rel="L2669">at leisure to talk to Elizabeth, and she was very willing to hear</li>
<li class="L2670" rel="L2670">him, though what she chiefly wished to hear she could not hope to be</li>
<li class="L2671" rel="L2671">told--the history of his acquaintance with Mr. Darcy. She dared not</li>
<li class="L2672" rel="L2672">even mention that gentleman. Her curiosity, however, was unexpectedly</li>
<li class="L2673" rel="L2673">relieved. Mr. Wickham began the subject himself. He inquired how far</li>
<li class="L2674" rel="L2674">Netherfield was from Meryton; and, after receiving her answer, asked in</li>
<li class="L2675" rel="L2675">a hesitating manner how long Mr. Darcy had been staying there.</li>
<li class="L2676" rel="L2676"></li>
<li class="L2677" rel="L2677">“About a month,” said Elizabeth; and then, unwilling to let the subject</li>
<li class="L2678" rel="L2678">drop, added, “He is a man of very large property in Derbyshire, I</li>
<li class="L2679" rel="L2679">understand.”</li>
<li class="L2680" rel="L2680"></li>
<li class="L2681" rel="L2681">“Yes,” replied Mr. Wickham; “his estate there is a noble one. A clear</li>
<li class="L2682" rel="L2682">ten thousand per annum. You could not have met with a person more</li>
<li class="L2683" rel="L2683">capable of giving you certain information on that head than myself, for</li>
<li class="L2684" rel="L2684">I have been connected with his family in a particular manner from my</li>
<li class="L2685" rel="L2685">infancy.”</li>
<li class="L2686" rel="L2686"></li>
<li class="L2687" rel="L2687">Elizabeth could not but look surprised.</li>
<li class="L2688" rel="L2688"></li>
<li class="L2689" rel="L2689">“You may well be surprised, Miss Bennet, at such an assertion, after</li>
<li class="L2690" rel="L2690">seeing, as you probably might, the very cold manner of our meeting</li>
<li class="L2691" rel="L2691">yesterday. Are you much acquainted with Mr. Darcy?”</li>
<li class="L2692" rel="L2692"></li>
<li class="L2693" rel="L2693">“As much as I ever wish to be,” cried Elizabeth very warmly. “I have</li>
<li class="L2694" rel="L2694">spent four days in the same house with him, and I think him very</li>
<li class="L2695" rel="L2695">disagreeable.”</li>
<li class="L2696" rel="L2696"></li>
<li class="L2697" rel="L2697">“I have no right to give _my_ opinion,” said Wickham, “as to his being</li>
<li class="L2698" rel="L2698">agreeable or otherwise. I am not qualified to form one. I have known him</li>
<li class="L2699" rel="L2699">too long and too well to be a fair judge. It is impossible for _me_</li>
<li class="L2700" rel="L2700">to be impartial. But I believe your opinion of him would in general</li>
<li class="L2701" rel="L2701">astonish--and perhaps you would not express it quite so strongly</li>
<li class="L2702" rel="L2702">anywhere else. Here you are in your own family.”</li>
<li class="L2703" rel="L2703"></li>
<li class="L2704" rel="L2704">“Upon my word, I say no more _here_ than I might say in any house in</li>
<li class="L2705" rel="L2705">the neighbourhood, except Netherfield. He is not at all liked in</li>
<li class="L2706" rel="L2706">Hertfordshire. Everybody is disgusted with his pride. You will not find</li>
<li class="L2707" rel="L2707">him more favourably spoken of by anyone.”</li>
<li class="L2708" rel="L2708"></li>
<li class="L2709" rel="L2709">“I cannot pretend to be sorry,” said Wickham, after a short</li>
<li class="L2710" rel="L2710">interruption, “that he or that any man should not be estimated beyond</li>
<li class="L2711" rel="L2711">their deserts; but with _him_ I believe it does not often happen. The</li>
<li class="L2712" rel="L2712">world is blinded by his fortune and consequence, or frightened by his</li>
<li class="L2713" rel="L2713">high and imposing manners, and sees him only as he chooses to be seen.”</li>
<li class="L2714" rel="L2714"></li>
<li class="L2715" rel="L2715">“I should take him, even on _my_ slight acquaintance, to be an</li>
<li class="L2716" rel="L2716">ill-tempered man.” Wickham only shook his head.</li>
<li class="L2717" rel="L2717"></li>
<li class="L2718" rel="L2718">“I wonder,” said he, at the next opportunity of speaking, “whether he is</li>
<li class="L2719" rel="L2719">likely to be in this country much longer.”</li>
<li class="L2720" rel="L2720"></li>
<li class="L2721" rel="L2721">“I do not at all know; but I _heard_ nothing of his going away when I</li>
<li class="L2722" rel="L2722">was at Netherfield. I hope your plans in favour of the ----shire will</li>
<li class="L2723" rel="L2723">not be affected by his being in the neighbourhood.”</li>
<li class="L2724" rel="L2724"></li>
<li class="L2725" rel="L2725">“Oh! no--it is not for _me_ to be driven away by Mr. Darcy. If _he_</li>
<li class="L2726" rel="L2726">wishes to avoid seeing _me_, he must go. We are not on friendly terms,</li>
<li class="L2727" rel="L2727">and it always gives me pain to meet him, but I have no reason for</li>
<li class="L2728" rel="L2728">avoiding _him_ but what I might proclaim before all the world, a sense</li>
<li class="L2729" rel="L2729">of very great ill-usage, and most painful regrets at his being what he</li>
<li class="L2730" rel="L2730">is. His father, Miss Bennet, the late Mr. Darcy, was one of the best men</li>
<li class="L2731" rel="L2731">that ever breathed, and the truest friend I ever had; and I can never</li>
<li class="L2732" rel="L2732">be in company with this Mr. Darcy without being grieved to the soul by</li>
<li class="L2733" rel="L2733">a thousand tender recollections. His behaviour to myself has been</li>
<li class="L2734" rel="L2734">scandalous; but I verily believe I could forgive him anything and</li>
<li class="L2735" rel="L2735">everything, rather than his disappointing the hopes and disgracing the</li>
<li class="L2736" rel="L2736">memory of his father.”</li>
<li class="L2737" rel="L2737"></li>
<li class="L2738" rel="L2738">Elizabeth found the interest of the subject increase, and listened with</li>
<li class="L2739" rel="L2739">all her heart; but the delicacy of it prevented further inquiry.</li>
<li class="L2740" rel="L2740"></li>
<li class="L2741" rel="L2741">Mr. Wickham began to speak on more general topics, Meryton, the</li>
<li class="L2742" rel="L2742">neighbourhood, the society, appearing highly pleased with all that</li>
<li class="L2743" rel="L2743">he had yet seen, and speaking of the latter with gentle but very</li>
<li class="L2744" rel="L2744">intelligible gallantry.</li>
<li class="L2745" rel="L2745"></li>
<li class="L2746" rel="L2746">“It was the prospect of constant society, and good society,” he added,</li>
<li class="L2747" rel="L2747">“which was my chief inducement to enter the ----shire. I knew it to be</li>
<li class="L2748" rel="L2748">a most respectable, agreeable corps, and my friend Denny tempted me</li>
<li class="L2749" rel="L2749">further by his account of their present quarters, and the very great</li>
<li class="L2750" rel="L2750">attentions and excellent acquaintances Meryton had procured them.</li>
<li class="L2751" rel="L2751">Society, I own, is necessary to me. I have been a disappointed man, and</li>
<li class="L2752" rel="L2752">my spirits will not bear solitude. I _must_ have employment and society.</li>
<li class="L2753" rel="L2753">A military life is not what I was intended for, but circumstances have</li>
<li class="L2754" rel="L2754">now made it eligible. The church _ought_ to have been my profession--I</li>
<li class="L2755" rel="L2755">was brought up for the church, and I should at this time have been in</li>
<li class="L2756" rel="L2756">possession of a most valuable living, had it pleased the gentleman we</li>
<li class="L2757" rel="L2757">were speaking of just now.”</li>
<li class="L2758" rel="L2758"></li>
<li class="L2759" rel="L2759">“Indeed!”</li>
<li class="L2760" rel="L2760"></li>
<li class="L2761" rel="L2761">“Yes--the late Mr. Darcy bequeathed me the next presentation of the best</li>
<li class="L2762" rel="L2762">living in his gift. He was my godfather, and excessively attached to me.</li>
<li class="L2763" rel="L2763">I cannot do justice to his kindness. He meant to provide for me amply,</li>
<li class="L2764" rel="L2764">and thought he had done it; but when the living fell, it was given</li>
<li class="L2765" rel="L2765">elsewhere.”</li>
<li class="L2766" rel="L2766"></li>
<li class="L2767" rel="L2767">“Good heavens!” cried Elizabeth; “but how could _that_ be? How could his</li>
<li class="L2768" rel="L2768">will be disregarded? Why did you not seek legal redress?”</li>
<li class="L2769" rel="L2769"></li>
<li class="L2770" rel="L2770">“There was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to</li>
<li class="L2771" rel="L2771">give me no hope from law. A man of honour could not have doubted the</li>
<li class="L2772" rel="L2772">intention, but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt it--or to treat it as a merely</li>
<li class="L2773" rel="L2773">conditional recommendation, and to assert that I had forfeited all claim</li>
<li class="L2774" rel="L2774">to it by extravagance, imprudence--in short anything or nothing. Certain</li>
<li class="L2775" rel="L2775">it is, that the living became vacant two years ago, exactly as I was</li>
<li class="L2776" rel="L2776">of an age to hold it, and that it was given to another man; and no</li>
<li class="L2777" rel="L2777">less certain is it, that I cannot accuse myself of having really done</li>
<li class="L2778" rel="L2778">anything to deserve to lose it. I have a warm, unguarded temper, and</li>
<li class="L2779" rel="L2779">I may have spoken my opinion _of_ him, and _to_ him, too freely. I can</li>
<li class="L2780" rel="L2780">recall nothing worse. But the fact is, that we are very different sort</li>
<li class="L2781" rel="L2781">of men, and that he hates me.”</li>
<li class="L2782" rel="L2782"></li>
<li class="L2783" rel="L2783">“This is quite shocking! He deserves to be publicly disgraced.”</li>
<li class="L2784" rel="L2784"></li>
<li class="L2785" rel="L2785">“Some time or other he _will_ be--but it shall not be by _me_. Till I</li>
<li class="L2786" rel="L2786">can forget his father, I can never defy or expose _him_.”</li>
<li class="L2787" rel="L2787"></li>
<li class="L2788" rel="L2788">Elizabeth honoured him for such feelings, and thought him handsomer than</li>
<li class="L2789" rel="L2789">ever as he expressed them.</li>
<li class="L2790" rel="L2790"></li>
<li class="L2791" rel="L2791">“But what,” said she, after a pause, “can have been his motive? What can</li>
<li class="L2792" rel="L2792">have induced him to behave so cruelly?”</li>
<li class="L2793" rel="L2793"></li>
<li class="L2794" rel="L2794">“A thorough, determined dislike of me--a dislike which I cannot but</li>
<li class="L2795" rel="L2795">attribute in some measure to jealousy. Had the late Mr. Darcy liked me</li>
<li class="L2796" rel="L2796">less, his son might have borne with me better; but his father&#39;s uncommon</li>
<li class="L2797" rel="L2797">attachment to me irritated him, I believe, very early in life. He had</li>
<li class="L2798" rel="L2798">not a temper to bear the sort of competition in which we stood--the sort</li>
<li class="L2799" rel="L2799">of preference which was often given me.”</li>
<li class="L2800" rel="L2800"></li>
<li class="L2801" rel="L2801">“I had not thought Mr. Darcy so bad as this--though I have never liked</li>
<li class="L2802" rel="L2802">him. I had not thought so very ill of him. I had supposed him to be</li>
<li class="L2803" rel="L2803">despising his fellow-creatures in general, but did not suspect him of</li>
<li class="L2804" rel="L2804">descending to such malicious revenge, such injustice, such inhumanity as</li>
<li class="L2805" rel="L2805">this.”</li>
<li class="L2806" rel="L2806"></li>
<li class="L2807" rel="L2807">After a few minutes&#39; reflection, however, she continued, “I _do_</li>
<li class="L2808" rel="L2808">remember his boasting one day, at Netherfield, of the implacability of</li>
<li class="L2809" rel="L2809">his resentments, of his having an unforgiving temper. His disposition</li>
<li class="L2810" rel="L2810">must be dreadful.”</li>
<li class="L2811" rel="L2811"></li>
<li class="L2812" rel="L2812">“I will not trust myself on the subject,” replied Wickham; “I can hardly</li>
<li class="L2813" rel="L2813">be just to him.”</li>
<li class="L2814" rel="L2814"></li>
<li class="L2815" rel="L2815">Elizabeth was again deep in thought, and after a time exclaimed, “To</li>
<li class="L2816" rel="L2816">treat in such a manner the godson, the friend, the favourite of his</li>
<li class="L2817" rel="L2817">father!” She could have added, “A young man, too, like _you_, whose very</li>
<li class="L2818" rel="L2818">countenance may vouch for your being amiable”--but she contented herself</li>
<li class="L2819" rel="L2819">with, “and one, too, who had probably been his companion from childhood,</li>
<li class="L2820" rel="L2820">connected together, as I think you said, in the closest manner!”</li>
<li class="L2821" rel="L2821"></li>
<li class="L2822" rel="L2822">“We were born in the same parish, within the same park; the greatest</li>
<li class="L2823" rel="L2823">part of our youth was passed together; inmates of the same house,</li>
<li class="L2824" rel="L2824">sharing the same amusements, objects of the same parental care. _My_</li>
<li class="L2825" rel="L2825">father began life in the profession which your uncle, Mr. Phillips,</li>
<li class="L2826" rel="L2826">appears to do so much credit to--but he gave up everything to be of</li>
<li class="L2827" rel="L2827">use to the late Mr. Darcy and devoted all his time to the care of the</li>
<li class="L2828" rel="L2828">Pemberley property. He was most highly esteemed by Mr. Darcy, a most</li>
<li class="L2829" rel="L2829">intimate, confidential friend. Mr. Darcy often acknowledged himself to</li>
<li class="L2830" rel="L2830">be under the greatest obligations to my father&#39;s active superintendence,</li>
<li class="L2831" rel="L2831">and when, immediately before my father&#39;s death, Mr. Darcy gave him a</li>
<li class="L2832" rel="L2832">voluntary promise of providing for me, I am convinced that he felt it to</li>
<li class="L2833" rel="L2833">be as much a debt of gratitude to _him_, as of his affection to myself.”</li>
<li class="L2834" rel="L2834"></li>
<li class="L2835" rel="L2835">“How strange!” cried Elizabeth. “How abominable! I wonder that the very</li>
<li class="L2836" rel="L2836">pride of this Mr. Darcy has not made him just to you! If from no better</li>
<li class="L2837" rel="L2837">motive, that he should not have been too proud to be dishonest--for</li>
<li class="L2838" rel="L2838">dishonesty I must call it.”</li>
<li class="L2839" rel="L2839"></li>
<li class="L2840" rel="L2840">“It _is_ wonderful,” replied Wickham, “for almost all his actions may</li>
<li class="L2841" rel="L2841">be traced to pride; and pride had often been his best friend. It has</li>
<li class="L2842" rel="L2842">connected him nearer with virtue than with any other feeling. But we are</li>
<li class="L2843" rel="L2843">none of us consistent, and in his behaviour to me there were stronger</li>
<li class="L2844" rel="L2844">impulses even than pride.”</li>
<li class="L2845" rel="L2845"></li>
<li class="L2846" rel="L2846">“Can such abominable pride as his have ever done him good?”</li>
<li class="L2847" rel="L2847"></li>
<li class="L2848" rel="L2848">“Yes. It has often led him to be liberal and generous, to give his money</li>
<li class="L2849" rel="L2849">freely, to display hospitality, to assist his tenants, and relieve the</li>
<li class="L2850" rel="L2850">poor. Family pride, and _filial_ pride--for he is very proud of what</li>
<li class="L2851" rel="L2851">his father was--have done this. Not to appear to disgrace his family,</li>
<li class="L2852" rel="L2852">to degenerate from the popular qualities, or lose the influence of the</li>
<li class="L2853" rel="L2853">Pemberley House, is a powerful motive. He has also _brotherly_ pride,</li>
<li class="L2854" rel="L2854">which, with _some_ brotherly affection, makes him a very kind and</li>
<li class="L2855" rel="L2855">careful guardian of his sister, and you will hear him generally cried up</li>
<li class="L2856" rel="L2856">as the most attentive and best of brothers.”</li>
<li class="L2857" rel="L2857"></li>
<li class="L2858" rel="L2858">“What sort of girl is Miss Darcy?”</li>
<li class="L2859" rel="L2859"></li>
<li class="L2860" rel="L2860">He shook his head. “I wish I could call her amiable. It gives me pain to</li>
<li class="L2861" rel="L2861">speak ill of a Darcy. But she is too much like her brother--very, very</li>
<li class="L2862" rel="L2862">proud. As a child, she was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond</li>
<li class="L2863" rel="L2863">of me; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement. But she is</li>
<li class="L2864" rel="L2864">nothing to me now. She is a handsome girl, about fifteen or sixteen,</li>
<li class="L2865" rel="L2865">and, I understand, highly accomplished. Since her father&#39;s death, her</li>
<li class="L2866" rel="L2866">home has been London, where a lady lives with her, and superintends her</li>
<li class="L2867" rel="L2867">education.”</li>
<li class="L2868" rel="L2868"></li>
<li class="L2869" rel="L2869">After many pauses and many trials of other subjects, Elizabeth could not</li>
<li class="L2870" rel="L2870">help reverting once more to the first, and saying:</li>
<li class="L2871" rel="L2871"></li>
<li class="L2872" rel="L2872">“I am astonished at his intimacy with Mr. Bingley! How can Mr. Bingley,</li>
<li class="L2873" rel="L2873">who seems good humour itself, and is, I really believe, truly amiable,</li>
<li class="L2874" rel="L2874">be in friendship with such a man? How can they suit each other? Do you</li>
<li class="L2875" rel="L2875">know Mr. Bingley?”</li>
<li class="L2876" rel="L2876"></li>
<li class="L2877" rel="L2877">“Not at all.”</li>
<li class="L2878" rel="L2878"></li>
<li class="L2879" rel="L2879">“He is a sweet-tempered, amiable, charming man. He cannot know what Mr.</li>
<li class="L2880" rel="L2880">Darcy is.”</li>
<li class="L2881" rel="L2881"></li>
<li class="L2882" rel="L2882">“Probably not; but Mr. Darcy can please where he chooses. He does not</li>
<li class="L2883" rel="L2883">want abilities. He can be a conversible companion if he thinks it worth</li>
<li class="L2884" rel="L2884">his while. Among those who are at all his equals in consequence, he is</li>
<li class="L2885" rel="L2885">a very different man from what he is to the less prosperous. His</li>
<li class="L2886" rel="L2886">pride never deserts him; but with the rich he is liberal-minded, just,</li>
<li class="L2887" rel="L2887">sincere, rational, honourable, and perhaps agreeable--allowing something</li>
<li class="L2888" rel="L2888">for fortune and figure.”</li>
<li class="L2889" rel="L2889"></li>
<li class="L2890" rel="L2890">The whist party soon afterwards breaking up, the players gathered round</li>
<li class="L2891" rel="L2891">the other table and Mr. Collins took his station between his cousin</li>
<li class="L2892" rel="L2892">Elizabeth and Mrs. Phillips. The usual inquiries as to his success were</li>
<li class="L2893" rel="L2893">made by the latter. It had not been very great; he had lost every</li>
<li class="L2894" rel="L2894">point; but when Mrs. Phillips began to express her concern thereupon,</li>
<li class="L2895" rel="L2895">he assured her with much earnest gravity that it was not of the least</li>
<li class="L2896" rel="L2896">importance, that he considered the money as a mere trifle, and begged</li>
<li class="L2897" rel="L2897">that she would not make herself uneasy.</li>
<li class="L2898" rel="L2898"></li>
<li class="L2899" rel="L2899">“I know very well, madam,” said he, “that when persons sit down to a</li>
