<li class="L2900" rel="L2900">card-table, they must take their chances of these things, and happily I</li>
<li class="L2901" rel="L2901">am not in such circumstances as to make five shillings any object. There</li>
<li class="L2902" rel="L2902">are undoubtedly many who could not say the same, but thanks to Lady</li>
<li class="L2903" rel="L2903">Catherine de Bourgh, I am removed far beyond the necessity of regarding</li>
<li class="L2904" rel="L2904">little matters.”</li>
<li class="L2905" rel="L2905"></li>
<li class="L2906" rel="L2906">Mr. Wickham&#39;s attention was caught; and after observing Mr. Collins for</li>
<li class="L2907" rel="L2907">a few moments, he asked Elizabeth in a low voice whether her relation</li>
<li class="L2908" rel="L2908">was very intimately acquainted with the family of de Bourgh.</li>
<li class="L2909" rel="L2909"></li>
<li class="L2910" rel="L2910">“Lady Catherine de Bourgh,” she replied, “has very lately given him</li>
<li class="L2911" rel="L2911">a living. I hardly know how Mr. Collins was first introduced to her</li>
<li class="L2912" rel="L2912">notice, but he certainly has not known her long.”</li>
<li class="L2913" rel="L2913"></li>
<li class="L2914" rel="L2914">“You know of course that Lady Catherine de Bourgh and Lady Anne Darcy</li>
<li class="L2915" rel="L2915">were sisters; consequently that she is aunt to the present Mr. Darcy.”</li>
<li class="L2916" rel="L2916"></li>
<li class="L2917" rel="L2917">“No, indeed, I did not. I knew nothing at all of Lady Catherine&#39;s</li>
<li class="L2918" rel="L2918">connections. I never heard of her existence till the day before</li>
<li class="L2919" rel="L2919">yesterday.”</li>
<li class="L2920" rel="L2920"></li>
<li class="L2921" rel="L2921">“Her daughter, Miss de Bourgh, will have a very large fortune, and it is</li>
<li class="L2922" rel="L2922">believed that she and her cousin will unite the two estates.”</li>
<li class="L2923" rel="L2923"></li>
<li class="L2924" rel="L2924">This information made Elizabeth smile, as she thought of poor Miss</li>
<li class="L2925" rel="L2925">Bingley. Vain indeed must be all her attentions, vain and useless her</li>
<li class="L2926" rel="L2926">affection for his sister and her praise of himself, if he were already</li>
<li class="L2927" rel="L2927">self-destined for another.</li>
<li class="L2928" rel="L2928"></li>
<li class="L2929" rel="L2929">“Mr. Collins,” said she, “speaks highly both of Lady Catherine and her</li>
<li class="L2930" rel="L2930">daughter; but from some particulars that he has related of her ladyship,</li>
<li class="L2931" rel="L2931">I suspect his gratitude misleads him, and that in spite of her being his</li>
<li class="L2932" rel="L2932">patroness, she is an arrogant, conceited woman.”</li>
<li class="L2933" rel="L2933"></li>
<li class="L2934" rel="L2934">“I believe her to be both in a great degree,” replied Wickham; “I have</li>
<li class="L2935" rel="L2935">not seen her for many years, but I very well remember that I never liked</li>
<li class="L2936" rel="L2936">her, and that her manners were dictatorial and insolent. She has the</li>
<li class="L2937" rel="L2937">reputation of being remarkably sensible and clever; but I rather believe</li>
<li class="L2938" rel="L2938">she derives part of her abilities from her rank and fortune, part from</li>
<li class="L2939" rel="L2939">her authoritative manner, and the rest from the pride for her</li>
<li class="L2940" rel="L2940">nephew, who chooses that everyone connected with him should have an</li>
<li class="L2941" rel="L2941">understanding of the first class.”</li>
<li class="L2942" rel="L2942"></li>
<li class="L2943" rel="L2943">Elizabeth allowed that he had given a very rational account of it, and</li>
<li class="L2944" rel="L2944">they continued talking together, with mutual satisfaction till supper</li>
<li class="L2945" rel="L2945">put an end to cards, and gave the rest of the ladies their share of Mr.</li>
<li class="L2946" rel="L2946">Wickham&#39;s attentions. There could be no conversation in the noise</li>
<li class="L2947" rel="L2947">of Mrs. Phillips&#39;s supper party, but his manners recommended him to</li>
<li class="L2948" rel="L2948">everybody. Whatever he said, was said well; and whatever he did, done</li>
<li class="L2949" rel="L2949">gracefully. Elizabeth went away with her head full of him. She could</li>
<li class="L2950" rel="L2950">think of nothing but of Mr. Wickham, and of what he had told her, all</li>
<li class="L2951" rel="L2951">the way home; but there was not time for her even to mention his name</li>
<li class="L2952" rel="L2952">as they went, for neither Lydia nor Mr. Collins were once silent. Lydia</li>
<li class="L2953" rel="L2953">talked incessantly of lottery tickets, of the fish she had lost and the</li>
<li class="L2954" rel="L2954">fish she had won; and Mr. Collins in describing the civility of Mr. and</li>
<li class="L2955" rel="L2955">Mrs. Phillips, protesting that he did not in the least regard his losses</li>
<li class="L2956" rel="L2956">at whist, enumerating all the dishes at supper, and repeatedly fearing</li>
<li class="L2957" rel="L2957">that he crowded his cousins, had more to say than he could well manage</li>
<li class="L2958" rel="L2958">before the carriage stopped at Longbourn House.</li>
<li class="L2959" rel="L2959"></li>
<li class="L2960" rel="L2960"></li>
<li class="L2961" rel="L2961"></li>
<li class="L2962" rel="L2962">Chapter 17</li>
<li class="L2963" rel="L2963"></li>
<li class="L2964" rel="L2964"></li>
<li class="L2965" rel="L2965">Elizabeth related to Jane the next day what had passed between Mr.</li>
<li class="L2966" rel="L2966">Wickham and herself. Jane listened with astonishment and concern; she</li>
<li class="L2967" rel="L2967">knew not how to believe that Mr. Darcy could be so unworthy of Mr.</li>
<li class="L2968" rel="L2968">Bingley&#39;s regard; and yet, it was not in her nature to question the</li>
<li class="L2969" rel="L2969">veracity of a young man of such amiable appearance as Wickham. The</li>
<li class="L2970" rel="L2970">possibility of his having endured such unkindness, was enough to</li>
<li class="L2971" rel="L2971">interest all her tender feelings; and nothing remained therefore to be</li>
<li class="L2972" rel="L2972">done, but to think well of them both, to defend the conduct of each,</li>
<li class="L2973" rel="L2973">and throw into the account of accident or mistake whatever could not be</li>
<li class="L2974" rel="L2974">otherwise explained.</li>
<li class="L2975" rel="L2975"></li>
<li class="L2976" rel="L2976">“They have both,” said she, “been deceived, I dare say, in some way</li>
<li class="L2977" rel="L2977">or other, of which we can form no idea. Interested people have perhaps</li>
<li class="L2978" rel="L2978">misrepresented each to the other. It is, in short, impossible for us to</li>
<li class="L2979" rel="L2979">conjecture the causes or circumstances which may have alienated them,</li>
<li class="L2980" rel="L2980">without actual blame on either side.”</li>
<li class="L2981" rel="L2981"></li>
<li class="L2982" rel="L2982">“Very true, indeed; and now, my dear Jane, what have you got to say on</li>
<li class="L2983" rel="L2983">behalf of the interested people who have probably been concerned in the</li>
<li class="L2984" rel="L2984">business? Do clear _them_ too, or we shall be obliged to think ill of</li>
<li class="L2985" rel="L2985">somebody.”</li>
<li class="L2986" rel="L2986"></li>
<li class="L2987" rel="L2987">“Laugh as much as you choose, but you will not laugh me out of my</li>
<li class="L2988" rel="L2988">opinion. My dearest Lizzy, do but consider in what a disgraceful light</li>
<li class="L2989" rel="L2989">it places Mr. Darcy, to be treating his father&#39;s favourite in such</li>
<li class="L2990" rel="L2990">a manner, one whom his father had promised to provide for. It is</li>
<li class="L2991" rel="L2991">impossible. No man of common humanity, no man who had any value for his</li>
<li class="L2992" rel="L2992">character, could be capable of it. Can his most intimate friends be so</li>
<li class="L2993" rel="L2993">excessively deceived in him? Oh! no.”</li>
<li class="L2994" rel="L2994"></li>
<li class="L2995" rel="L2995">“I can much more easily believe Mr. Bingley&#39;s being imposed on, than</li>
<li class="L2996" rel="L2996">that Mr. Wickham should invent such a history of himself as he gave me</li>
<li class="L2997" rel="L2997">last night; names, facts, everything mentioned without ceremony. If it</li>
<li class="L2998" rel="L2998">be not so, let Mr. Darcy contradict it. Besides, there was truth in his</li>
<li class="L2999" rel="L2999">looks.”</li>
<li class="L3000" rel="L3000"></li>
<li class="L3001" rel="L3001">“It is difficult indeed--it is distressing. One does not know what to</li>
<li class="L3002" rel="L3002">think.”</li>
<li class="L3003" rel="L3003"></li>
<li class="L3004" rel="L3004">“I beg your pardon; one knows exactly what to think.”</li>
<li class="L3005" rel="L3005"></li>
<li class="L3006" rel="L3006">But Jane could think with certainty on only one point--that Mr. Bingley,</li>
<li class="L3007" rel="L3007">if he _had_ been imposed on, would have much to suffer when the affair</li>
<li class="L3008" rel="L3008">became public.</li>
<li class="L3009" rel="L3009"></li>
<li class="L3010" rel="L3010">The two young ladies were summoned from the shrubbery, where this</li>
<li class="L3011" rel="L3011">conversation passed, by the arrival of the very persons of whom they had</li>
<li class="L3012" rel="L3012">been speaking; Mr. Bingley and his sisters came to give their personal</li>
<li class="L3013" rel="L3013">invitation for the long-expected ball at Netherfield, which was fixed</li>
<li class="L3014" rel="L3014">for the following Tuesday. The two ladies were delighted to see their</li>
<li class="L3015" rel="L3015">dear friend again, called it an age since they had met, and repeatedly</li>
<li class="L3016" rel="L3016">asked what she had been doing with herself since their separation. To</li>
<li class="L3017" rel="L3017">the rest of the family they paid little attention; avoiding Mrs. Bennet</li>
<li class="L3018" rel="L3018">as much as possible, saying not much to Elizabeth, and nothing at all to</li>
<li class="L3019" rel="L3019">the others. They were soon gone again, rising from their seats with an</li>
<li class="L3020" rel="L3020">activity which took their brother by surprise, and hurrying off as if</li>
<li class="L3021" rel="L3021">eager to escape from Mrs. Bennet&#39;s civilities.</li>
<li class="L3022" rel="L3022"></li>
<li class="L3023" rel="L3023">The prospect of the Netherfield ball was extremely agreeable to every</li>
<li class="L3024" rel="L3024">female of the family. Mrs. Bennet chose to consider it as given in</li>
<li class="L3025" rel="L3025">compliment to her eldest daughter, and was particularly flattered</li>
<li class="L3026" rel="L3026">by receiving the invitation from Mr. Bingley himself, instead of a</li>
<li class="L3027" rel="L3027">ceremonious card. Jane pictured to herself a happy evening in the</li>
<li class="L3028" rel="L3028">society of her two friends, and the attentions of their brother; and</li>
<li class="L3029" rel="L3029">Elizabeth thought with pleasure of dancing a great deal with Mr.</li>
<li class="L3030" rel="L3030">Wickham, and of seeing a confirmation of everything in Mr. Darcy&#39;s look</li>
<li class="L3031" rel="L3031">and behaviour. The happiness anticipated by Catherine and Lydia depended</li>
<li class="L3032" rel="L3032">less on any single event, or any particular person, for though they</li>
<li class="L3033" rel="L3033">each, like Elizabeth, meant to dance half the evening with Mr. Wickham,</li>
<li class="L3034" rel="L3034">he was by no means the only partner who could satisfy them, and a ball</li>
<li class="L3035" rel="L3035">was, at any rate, a ball. And even Mary could assure her family that she</li>
<li class="L3036" rel="L3036">had no disinclination for it.</li>
<li class="L3037" rel="L3037"></li>
<li class="L3038" rel="L3038">“While I can have my mornings to myself,” said she, “it is enough--I</li>
<li class="L3039" rel="L3039">think it is no sacrifice to join occasionally in evening engagements.</li>
<li class="L3040" rel="L3040">Society has claims on us all; and I profess myself one of those</li>
<li class="L3041" rel="L3041">who consider intervals of recreation and amusement as desirable for</li>
<li class="L3042" rel="L3042">everybody.”</li>
<li class="L3043" rel="L3043"></li>
<li class="L3044" rel="L3044">Elizabeth&#39;s spirits were so high on this occasion, that though she did</li>
<li class="L3045" rel="L3045">not often speak unnecessarily to Mr. Collins, she could not help asking</li>
<li class="L3046" rel="L3046">him whether he intended to accept Mr. Bingley&#39;s invitation, and if</li>
<li class="L3047" rel="L3047">he did, whether he would think it proper to join in the evening&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3048" rel="L3048">amusement; and she was rather surprised to find that he entertained no</li>
<li class="L3049" rel="L3049">scruple whatever on that head, and was very far from dreading a rebuke</li>
<li class="L3050" rel="L3050">either from the Archbishop, or Lady Catherine de Bourgh, by venturing to</li>
<li class="L3051" rel="L3051">dance.</li>
<li class="L3052" rel="L3052"></li>
<li class="L3053" rel="L3053">“I am by no means of the opinion, I assure you,” said he, “that a ball</li>
<li class="L3054" rel="L3054">of this kind, given by a young man of character, to respectable people,</li>
<li class="L3055" rel="L3055">can have any evil tendency; and I am so far from objecting to dancing</li>
<li class="L3056" rel="L3056">myself, that I shall hope to be honoured with the hands of all my fair</li>
<li class="L3057" rel="L3057">cousins in the course of the evening; and I take this opportunity of</li>
<li class="L3058" rel="L3058">soliciting yours, Miss Elizabeth, for the two first dances especially,</li>
<li class="L3059" rel="L3059">a preference which I trust my cousin Jane will attribute to the right</li>
<li class="L3060" rel="L3060">cause, and not to any disrespect for her.”</li>
<li class="L3061" rel="L3061"></li>
<li class="L3062" rel="L3062">Elizabeth felt herself completely taken in. She had fully proposed being</li>
<li class="L3063" rel="L3063">engaged by Mr. Wickham for those very dances; and to have Mr. Collins</li>
<li class="L3064" rel="L3064">instead! her liveliness had never been worse timed. There was no help</li>
<li class="L3065" rel="L3065">for it, however. Mr. Wickham&#39;s happiness and her own were perforce</li>
<li class="L3066" rel="L3066">delayed a little longer, and Mr. Collins&#39;s proposal accepted with as</li>
<li class="L3067" rel="L3067">good a grace as she could. She was not the better pleased with his</li>
<li class="L3068" rel="L3068">gallantry from the idea it suggested of something more. It now first</li>
<li class="L3069" rel="L3069">struck her, that _she_ was selected from among her sisters as worthy</li>
<li class="L3070" rel="L3070">of being mistress of Hunsford Parsonage, and of assisting to form a</li>
<li class="L3071" rel="L3071">quadrille table at Rosings, in the absence of more eligible visitors.</li>
<li class="L3072" rel="L3072">The idea soon reached to conviction, as she observed his increasing</li>
<li class="L3073" rel="L3073">civilities toward herself, and heard his frequent attempt at a</li>
<li class="L3074" rel="L3074">compliment on her wit and vivacity; and though more astonished than</li>
<li class="L3075" rel="L3075">gratified herself by this effect of her charms, it was not long before</li>
<li class="L3076" rel="L3076">her mother gave her to understand that the probability of their marriage</li>
<li class="L3077" rel="L3077">was extremely agreeable to _her_. Elizabeth, however, did not choose</li>
<li class="L3078" rel="L3078">to take the hint, being well aware that a serious dispute must be the</li>
<li class="L3079" rel="L3079">consequence of any reply. Mr. Collins might never make the offer, and</li>
<li class="L3080" rel="L3080">till he did, it was useless to quarrel about him.</li>
<li class="L3081" rel="L3081"></li>
<li class="L3082" rel="L3082">If there had not been a Netherfield ball to prepare for and talk of, the</li>
<li class="L3083" rel="L3083">younger Miss Bennets would have been in a very pitiable state at this</li>
<li class="L3084" rel="L3084">time, for from the day of the invitation, to the day of the ball, there</li>
<li class="L3085" rel="L3085">was such a succession of rain as prevented their walking to Meryton</li>
<li class="L3086" rel="L3086">once. No aunt, no officers, no news could be sought after--the very</li>
<li class="L3087" rel="L3087">shoe-roses for Netherfield were got by proxy. Even Elizabeth might have</li>
<li class="L3088" rel="L3088">found some trial of her patience in weather which totally suspended the</li>
<li class="L3089" rel="L3089">improvement of her acquaintance with Mr. Wickham; and nothing less than</li>
<li class="L3090" rel="L3090">a dance on Tuesday, could have made such a Friday, Saturday, Sunday, and</li>
<li class="L3091" rel="L3091">Monday endurable to Kitty and Lydia.</li>
<li class="L3092" rel="L3092"></li>
<li class="L3093" rel="L3093"></li>
<li class="L3094" rel="L3094"></li>
<li class="L3095" rel="L3095">Chapter 18</li>
<li class="L3096" rel="L3096"></li>
<li class="L3097" rel="L3097"></li>
<li class="L3098" rel="L3098">Till Elizabeth entered the drawing-room at Netherfield, and looked in</li>
<li class="L3099" rel="L3099">vain for Mr. Wickham among the cluster of red coats there assembled, a</li>
<li class="L3100" rel="L3100">doubt of his being present had never occurred to her. The certainty</li>
<li class="L3101" rel="L3101">of meeting him had not been checked by any of those recollections that</li>
<li class="L3102" rel="L3102">might not unreasonably have alarmed her. She had dressed with more than</li>
<li class="L3103" rel="L3103">usual care, and prepared in the highest spirits for the conquest of all</li>
<li class="L3104" rel="L3104">that remained unsubdued of his heart, trusting that it was not more than</li>
<li class="L3105" rel="L3105">might be won in the course of the evening. But in an instant arose</li>
<li class="L3106" rel="L3106">the dreadful suspicion of his being purposely omitted for Mr. Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3107" rel="L3107">pleasure in the Bingleys&#39; invitation to the officers; and though</li>
<li class="L3108" rel="L3108">this was not exactly the case, the absolute fact of his absence was</li>
<li class="L3109" rel="L3109">pronounced by his friend Denny, to whom Lydia eagerly applied, and who</li>
<li class="L3110" rel="L3110">told them that Wickham had been obliged to go to town on business the</li>
<li class="L3111" rel="L3111">day before, and was not yet returned; adding, with a significant smile,</li>
<li class="L3112" rel="L3112">“I do not imagine his business would have called him away just now, if</li>
<li class="L3113" rel="L3113">he had not wanted to avoid a certain gentleman here.”</li>
<li class="L3114" rel="L3114"></li>
<li class="L3115" rel="L3115">This part of his intelligence, though unheard by Lydia, was caught by</li>
<li class="L3116" rel="L3116">Elizabeth, and, as it assured her that Darcy was not less answerable for</li>
<li class="L3117" rel="L3117">Wickham&#39;s absence than if her first surmise had been just, every</li>
<li class="L3118" rel="L3118">feeling of displeasure against the former was so sharpened by immediate</li>
<li class="L3119" rel="L3119">disappointment, that she could hardly reply with tolerable civility to</li>
<li class="L3120" rel="L3120">the polite inquiries which he directly afterwards approached to make.</li>
<li class="L3121" rel="L3121">Attendance, forbearance, patience with Darcy, was injury to Wickham. She</li>
<li class="L3122" rel="L3122">was resolved against any sort of conversation with him, and turned away</li>
<li class="L3123" rel="L3123">with a degree of ill-humour which she could not wholly surmount even in</li>
<li class="L3124" rel="L3124">speaking to Mr. Bingley, whose blind partiality provoked her.</li>
<li class="L3125" rel="L3125"></li>
<li class="L3126" rel="L3126">But Elizabeth was not formed for ill-humour; and though every prospect</li>
<li class="L3127" rel="L3127">of her own was destroyed for the evening, it could not dwell long on her</li>
<li class="L3128" rel="L3128">spirits; and having told all her griefs to Charlotte Lucas, whom she had</li>
<li class="L3129" rel="L3129">not seen for a week, she was soon able to make a voluntary transition</li>
<li class="L3130" rel="L3130">to the oddities of her cousin, and to point him out to her particular</li>
<li class="L3131" rel="L3131">notice. The first two dances, however, brought a return of distress;</li>
<li class="L3132" rel="L3132">they were dances of mortification. Mr. Collins, awkward and solemn,</li>
<li class="L3133" rel="L3133">apologising instead of attending, and often moving wrong without being</li>
<li class="L3134" rel="L3134">aware of it, gave her all the shame and misery which a disagreeable</li>
<li class="L3135" rel="L3135">partner for a couple of dances can give. The moment of her release from</li>
<li class="L3136" rel="L3136">him was ecstasy.</li>
<li class="L3137" rel="L3137"></li>
<li class="L3138" rel="L3138">She danced next with an officer, and had the refreshment of talking of</li>
<li class="L3139" rel="L3139">Wickham, and of hearing that he was universally liked. When those dances</li>
<li class="L3140" rel="L3140">were over, she returned to Charlotte Lucas, and was in conversation with</li>
<li class="L3141" rel="L3141">her, when she found herself suddenly addressed by Mr. Darcy who took</li>
<li class="L3142" rel="L3142">her so much by surprise in his application for her hand, that,</li>
<li class="L3143" rel="L3143">without knowing what she did, she accepted him. He walked away again</li>
<li class="L3144" rel="L3144">immediately, and she was left to fret over her own want of presence of</li>
<li class="L3145" rel="L3145">mind; Charlotte tried to console her:</li>
<li class="L3146" rel="L3146"></li>
<li class="L3147" rel="L3147">“I dare say you will find him very agreeable.”</li>
<li class="L3148" rel="L3148"></li>
<li class="L3149" rel="L3149">“Heaven forbid! _That_ would be the greatest misfortune of all! To find</li>
<li class="L3150" rel="L3150">a man agreeable whom one is determined to hate! Do not wish me such an</li>
<li class="L3151" rel="L3151">evil.”</li>
<li class="L3152" rel="L3152"></li>
<li class="L3153" rel="L3153">When the dancing recommenced, however, and Darcy approached to claim her</li>
<li class="L3154" rel="L3154">hand, Charlotte could not help cautioning her in a whisper, not to be a</li>
<li class="L3155" rel="L3155">simpleton, and allow her fancy for Wickham to make her appear unpleasant</li>
<li class="L3156" rel="L3156">in the eyes of a man ten times his consequence. Elizabeth made no</li>
<li class="L3157" rel="L3157">answer, and took her place in the set, amazed at the dignity to which</li>
<li class="L3158" rel="L3158">she was arrived in being allowed to stand opposite to Mr. Darcy, and</li>
<li class="L3159" rel="L3159">reading in her neighbours&#39; looks, their equal amazement in beholding</li>
<li class="L3160" rel="L3160">it. They stood for some time without speaking a word; and she began to</li>
<li class="L3161" rel="L3161">imagine that their silence was to last through the two dances, and at</li>
<li class="L3162" rel="L3162">first was resolved not to break it; till suddenly fancying that it would</li>
<li class="L3163" rel="L3163">be the greater punishment to her partner to oblige him to talk, she made</li>
<li class="L3164" rel="L3164">some slight observation on the dance. He replied, and was again</li>
<li class="L3165" rel="L3165">silent. After a pause of some minutes, she addressed him a second time</li>
<li class="L3166" rel="L3166">with:--“It is _your_ turn to say something now, Mr. Darcy. I talked</li>
<li class="L3167" rel="L3167">about the dance, and _you_ ought to make some sort of remark on the size</li>
<li class="L3168" rel="L3168">of the room, or the number of couples.”</li>
<li class="L3169" rel="L3169"></li>
<li class="L3170" rel="L3170">He smiled, and assured her that whatever she wished him to say should be</li>
<li class="L3171" rel="L3171">said.</li>
<li class="L3172" rel="L3172"></li>
<li class="L3173" rel="L3173">“Very well. That reply will do for the present. Perhaps by and by I may</li>
<li class="L3174" rel="L3174">observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones. But</li>
<li class="L3175" rel="L3175">_now_ we may be silent.”</li>
<li class="L3176" rel="L3176"></li>
<li class="L3177" rel="L3177">“Do you talk by rule, then, while you are dancing?”</li>
<li class="L3178" rel="L3178"></li>
<li class="L3179" rel="L3179">“Sometimes. One must speak a little, you know. It would look odd to be</li>
<li class="L3180" rel="L3180">entirely silent for half an hour together; and yet for the advantage of</li>
<li class="L3181" rel="L3181">_some_, conversation ought to be so arranged, as that they may have the</li>
<li class="L3182" rel="L3182">trouble of saying as little as possible.”</li>
<li class="L3183" rel="L3183"></li>
<li class="L3184" rel="L3184">“Are you consulting your own feelings in the present case, or do you</li>
<li class="L3185" rel="L3185">imagine that you are gratifying mine?”</li>
<li class="L3186" rel="L3186"></li>
<li class="L3187" rel="L3187">“Both,” replied Elizabeth archly; “for I have always seen a great</li>
<li class="L3188" rel="L3188">similarity in the turn of our minds. We are each of an unsocial,</li>
<li class="L3189" rel="L3189">taciturn disposition, unwilling to speak, unless we expect to say</li>
<li class="L3190" rel="L3190">something that will amaze the whole room, and be handed down to</li>
<li class="L3191" rel="L3191">posterity with all the eclat of a proverb.”</li>
<li class="L3192" rel="L3192"></li>
<li class="L3193" rel="L3193">“This is no very striking resemblance of your own character, I am sure,”</li>
<li class="L3194" rel="L3194"> said he. “How near it may be to _mine_, I cannot pretend to say. _You_</li>
<li class="L3195" rel="L3195">think it a faithful portrait undoubtedly.”</li>
<li class="L3196" rel="L3196"></li>
<li class="L3197" rel="L3197">“I must not decide on my own performance.”</li>
<li class="L3198" rel="L3198"></li>
<li class="L3199" rel="L3199">He made no answer, and they were again silent till they had gone down</li>
<li class="L3200" rel="L3200">the dance, when he asked her if she and her sisters did not very often</li>
<li class="L3201" rel="L3201">walk to Meryton. She answered in the affirmative, and, unable to resist</li>
<li class="L3202" rel="L3202">the temptation, added, “When you met us there the other day, we had just</li>
<li class="L3203" rel="L3203">been forming a new acquaintance.”</li>
<li class="L3204" rel="L3204"></li>
<li class="L3205" rel="L3205">The effect was immediate. A deeper shade of _hauteur_ overspread his</li>
<li class="L3206" rel="L3206">features, but he said not a word, and Elizabeth, though blaming herself</li>
<li class="L3207" rel="L3207">for her own weakness, could not go on. At length Darcy spoke, and in a</li>
<li class="L3208" rel="L3208">constrained manner said, “Mr. Wickham is blessed with such happy manners</li>
<li class="L3209" rel="L3209">as may ensure his _making_ friends--whether he may be equally capable of</li>
<li class="L3210" rel="L3210">_retaining_ them, is less certain.”</li>
<li class="L3211" rel="L3211"></li>
<li class="L3212" rel="L3212">“He has been so unlucky as to lose _your_ friendship,” replied Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L3213" rel="L3213">with emphasis, “and in a manner which he is likely to suffer from all</li>
<li class="L3214" rel="L3214">his life.”</li>
<li class="L3215" rel="L3215"></li>
<li class="L3216" rel="L3216">Darcy made no answer, and seemed desirous of changing the subject. At</li>
<li class="L3217" rel="L3217">that moment, Sir William Lucas appeared close to them, meaning to pass</li>
<li class="L3218" rel="L3218">through the set to the other side of the room; but on perceiving Mr.</li>
<li class="L3219" rel="L3219">Darcy, he stopped with a bow of superior courtesy to compliment him on</li>
<li class="L3220" rel="L3220">his dancing and his partner.</li>
<li class="L3221" rel="L3221"></li>
<li class="L3222" rel="L3222">“I have been most highly gratified indeed, my dear sir. Such very</li>
<li class="L3223" rel="L3223">superior dancing is not often seen. It is evident that you belong to the</li>
<li class="L3224" rel="L3224">first circles. Allow me to say, however, that your fair partner does not</li>
<li class="L3225" rel="L3225">disgrace you, and that I must hope to have this pleasure often repeated,</li>
<li class="L3226" rel="L3226">especially when a certain desirable event, my dear Eliza (glancing at</li>
<li class="L3227" rel="L3227">her sister and Bingley) shall take place. What congratulations will then</li>
<li class="L3228" rel="L3228">flow in! I appeal to Mr. Darcy:--but let me not interrupt you, sir. You</li>
<li class="L3229" rel="L3229">will not thank me for detaining you from the bewitching converse of that</li>
<li class="L3230" rel="L3230">young lady, whose bright eyes are also upbraiding me.”</li>
<li class="L3231" rel="L3231"></li>
<li class="L3232" rel="L3232">The latter part of this address was scarcely heard by Darcy; but Sir</li>
<li class="L3233" rel="L3233">William&#39;s allusion to his friend seemed to strike him forcibly, and his</li>
<li class="L3234" rel="L3234">eyes were directed with a very serious expression towards Bingley and</li>
<li class="L3235" rel="L3235">Jane, who were dancing together. Recovering himself, however, shortly,</li>
<li class="L3236" rel="L3236">he turned to his partner, and said, “Sir William&#39;s interruption has made</li>
<li class="L3237" rel="L3237">me forget what we were talking of.”</li>
<li class="L3238" rel="L3238"></li>
<li class="L3239" rel="L3239">“I do not think we were speaking at all. Sir William could not have</li>
<li class="L3240" rel="L3240">interrupted two people in the room who had less to say for themselves.</li>
<li class="L3241" rel="L3241">We have tried two or three subjects already without success, and what we</li>
<li class="L3242" rel="L3242">are to talk of next I cannot imagine.”</li>
<li class="L3243" rel="L3243"></li>
<li class="L3244" rel="L3244">“What think you of books?” said he, smiling.</li>
<li class="L3245" rel="L3245"></li>
<li class="L3246" rel="L3246">“Books--oh! no. I am sure we never read the same, or not with the same</li>
<li class="L3247" rel="L3247">feelings.”</li>
<li class="L3248" rel="L3248"></li>
<li class="L3249" rel="L3249">“I am sorry you think so; but if that be the case, there can at least be</li>
<li class="L3250" rel="L3250">no want of subject. We may compare our different opinions.”</li>
<li class="L3251" rel="L3251"></li>
<li class="L3252" rel="L3252">“No--I cannot talk of books in a ball-room; my head is always full of</li>
<li class="L3253" rel="L3253">something else.”</li>
<li class="L3254" rel="L3254"></li>
<li class="L3255" rel="L3255">“The _present_ always occupies you in such scenes--does it?” said he,</li>
<li class="L3256" rel="L3256">with a look of doubt.</li>
<li class="L3257" rel="L3257"></li>
<li class="L3258" rel="L3258">“Yes, always,” she replied, without knowing what she said, for her</li>
<li class="L3259" rel="L3259">thoughts had wandered far from the subject, as soon afterwards appeared</li>
<li class="L3260" rel="L3260">by her suddenly exclaiming, “I remember hearing you once say, Mr. Darcy,</li>
<li class="L3261" rel="L3261">that you hardly ever forgave, that your resentment once created was</li>
<li class="L3262" rel="L3262">unappeasable. You are very cautious, I suppose, as to its _being</li>
<li class="L3263" rel="L3263">created_.”</li>
<li class="L3264" rel="L3264"></li>
<li class="L3265" rel="L3265">“I am,” said he, with a firm voice.</li>
<li class="L3266" rel="L3266"></li>
<li class="L3267" rel="L3267">“And never allow yourself to be blinded by prejudice?”</li>
<li class="L3268" rel="L3268"></li>
<li class="L3269" rel="L3269">“I hope not.”</li>
<li class="L3270" rel="L3270"></li>
<li class="L3271" rel="L3271">“It is particularly incumbent on those who never change their opinion,</li>
<li class="L3272" rel="L3272">to be secure of judging properly at first.”</li>
<li class="L3273" rel="L3273"></li>
<li class="L3274" rel="L3274">“May I ask to what these questions tend?”</li>
<li class="L3275" rel="L3275"></li>
<li class="L3276" rel="L3276">“Merely to the illustration of _your_ character,” said she, endeavouring</li>
<li class="L3277" rel="L3277">to shake off her gravity. “I am trying to make it out.”</li>
<li class="L3278" rel="L3278"></li>
<li class="L3279" rel="L3279">“And what is your success?”</li>
<li class="L3280" rel="L3280"></li>
<li class="L3281" rel="L3281">She shook her head. “I do not get on at all. I hear such different</li>
<li class="L3282" rel="L3282">accounts of you as puzzle me exceedingly.”</li>
<li class="L3283" rel="L3283"></li>
<li class="L3284" rel="L3284">“I can readily believe,” answered he gravely, “that reports may vary</li>
<li class="L3285" rel="L3285">greatly with respect to me; and I could wish, Miss Bennet, that you were</li>
<li class="L3286" rel="L3286">not to sketch my character at the present moment, as there is reason to</li>
<li class="L3287" rel="L3287">fear that the performance would reflect no credit on either.”</li>
<li class="L3288" rel="L3288"></li>
<li class="L3289" rel="L3289">“But if I do not take your likeness now, I may never have another</li>
<li class="L3290" rel="L3290">opportunity.”</li>
<li class="L3291" rel="L3291"></li>
<li class="L3292" rel="L3292">“I would by no means suspend any pleasure of yours,” he coldly replied.</li>
<li class="L3293" rel="L3293">She said no more, and they went down the other dance and parted in</li>
<li class="L3294" rel="L3294">silence; and on each side dissatisfied, though not to an equal degree,</li>
<li class="L3295" rel="L3295">for in Darcy&#39;s breast there was a tolerably powerful feeling towards</li>
<li class="L3296" rel="L3296">her, which soon procured her pardon, and directed all his anger against</li>
<li class="L3297" rel="L3297">another.</li>
<li class="L3298" rel="L3298"></li>
<li class="L3299" rel="L3299">They had not long separated, when Miss Bingley came towards her, and</li>
<li class="L3300" rel="L3300">with an expression of civil disdain accosted her:</li>
<li class="L3301" rel="L3301"></li>
<li class="L3302" rel="L3302">“So, Miss Eliza, I hear you are quite delighted with George Wickham!</li>
<li class="L3303" rel="L3303">Your sister has been talking to me about him, and asking me a thousand</li>
<li class="L3304" rel="L3304">questions; and I find that the young man quite forgot to tell you, among</li>
<li class="L3305" rel="L3305">his other communication, that he was the son of old Wickham, the late</li>
<li class="L3306" rel="L3306">Mr. Darcy&#39;s steward. Let me recommend you, however, as a friend, not to</li>
<li class="L3307" rel="L3307">give implicit confidence to all his assertions; for as to Mr. Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3308" rel="L3308">using him ill, it is perfectly false; for, on the contrary, he has</li>
<li class="L3309" rel="L3309">always been remarkably kind to him, though George Wickham has treated</li>
<li class="L3310" rel="L3310">Mr. Darcy in a most infamous manner. I do not know the particulars, but</li>
<li class="L3311" rel="L3311">I know very well that Mr. Darcy is not in the least to blame, that he</li>
<li class="L3312" rel="L3312">cannot bear to hear George Wickham mentioned, and that though my brother</li>
<li class="L3313" rel="L3313">thought that he could not well avoid including him in his invitation to</li>
<li class="L3314" rel="L3314">the officers, he was excessively glad to find that he had taken himself</li>
<li class="L3315" rel="L3315">out of the way. His coming into the country at all is a most insolent</li>
<li class="L3316" rel="L3316">thing, indeed, and I wonder how he could presume to do it. I pity you,</li>
<li class="L3317" rel="L3317">Miss Eliza, for this discovery of your favourite&#39;s guilt; but really,</li>
<li class="L3318" rel="L3318">considering his descent, one could not expect much better.”</li>
<li class="L3319" rel="L3319"></li>
<li class="L3320" rel="L3320">“His guilt and his descent appear by your account to be the same,” said</li>
<li class="L3321" rel="L3321">Elizabeth angrily; “for I have heard you accuse him of nothing worse</li>
<li class="L3322" rel="L3322">than of being the son of Mr. Darcy&#39;s steward, and of _that_, I can</li>
<li class="L3323" rel="L3323">assure you, he informed me himself.”</li>
<li class="L3324" rel="L3324"></li>
<li class="L3325" rel="L3325">“I beg your pardon,” replied Miss Bingley, turning away with a sneer.</li>
<li class="L3326" rel="L3326">“Excuse my interference--it was kindly meant.”</li>
<li class="L3327" rel="L3327"></li>
<li class="L3328" rel="L3328">“Insolent girl!” said Elizabeth to herself. “You are much mistaken</li>
<li class="L3329" rel="L3329">if you expect to influence me by such a paltry attack as this. I see</li>
<li class="L3330" rel="L3330">nothing in it but your own wilful ignorance and the malice of Mr.</li>
<li class="L3331" rel="L3331">Darcy.” She then sought her eldest sister, who had undertaken to make</li>
<li class="L3332" rel="L3332">inquiries on the same subject of Bingley. Jane met her with a smile of</li>
<li class="L3333" rel="L3333">such sweet complacency, a glow of such happy expression, as sufficiently</li>
<li class="L3334" rel="L3334">marked how well she was satisfied with the occurrences of the evening.</li>
<li class="L3335" rel="L3335">Elizabeth instantly read her feelings, and at that moment solicitude for</li>
<li class="L3336" rel="L3336">Wickham, resentment against his enemies, and everything else, gave way</li>
<li class="L3337" rel="L3337">before the hope of Jane&#39;s being in the fairest way for happiness.</li>
<li class="L3338" rel="L3338"></li>
<li class="L3339" rel="L3339">“I want to know,” said she, with a countenance no less smiling than her</li>
<li class="L3340" rel="L3340">sister&#39;s, “what you have learnt about Mr. Wickham. But perhaps you have</li>
<li class="L3341" rel="L3341">been too pleasantly engaged to think of any third person; in which case</li>
<li class="L3342" rel="L3342">you may be sure of my pardon.”</li>
<li class="L3343" rel="L3343"></li>
<li class="L3344" rel="L3344">“No,” replied Jane, “I have not forgotten him; but I have nothing</li>
<li class="L3345" rel="L3345">satisfactory to tell you. Mr. Bingley does not know the whole of</li>
<li class="L3346" rel="L3346">his history, and is quite ignorant of the circumstances which have</li>
<li class="L3347" rel="L3347">principally offended Mr. Darcy; but he will vouch for the good conduct,</li>
<li class="L3348" rel="L3348">the probity, and honour of his friend, and is perfectly convinced that</li>
<li class="L3349" rel="L3349">Mr. Wickham has deserved much less attention from Mr. Darcy than he has</li>
<li class="L3350" rel="L3350">received; and I am sorry to say by his account as well as his sister&#39;s,</li>
<li class="L3351" rel="L3351">Mr. Wickham is by no means a respectable young man. I am afraid he has</li>
<li class="L3352" rel="L3352">been very imprudent, and has deserved to lose Mr. Darcy&#39;s regard.”</li>
<li class="L3353" rel="L3353"></li>
<li class="L3354" rel="L3354">“Mr. Bingley does not know Mr. Wickham himself?”</li>
<li class="L3355" rel="L3355"></li>
<li class="L3356" rel="L3356">“No; he never saw him till the other morning at Meryton.”</li>
<li class="L3357" rel="L3357"></li>
<li class="L3358" rel="L3358">“This account then is what he has received from Mr. Darcy. I am</li>
<li class="L3359" rel="L3359">satisfied. But what does he say of the living?”</li>
<li class="L3360" rel="L3360"></li>
<li class="L3361" rel="L3361">“He does not exactly recollect the circumstances, though he has heard</li>
<li class="L3362" rel="L3362">them from Mr. Darcy more than once, but he believes that it was left to</li>
<li class="L3363" rel="L3363">him _conditionally_ only.”</li>
<li class="L3364" rel="L3364"></li>
<li class="L3365" rel="L3365">“I have not a doubt of Mr. Bingley&#39;s sincerity,” said Elizabeth warmly;</li>
<li class="L3366" rel="L3366">“but you must excuse my not being convinced by assurances only. Mr.</li>
<li class="L3367" rel="L3367">Bingley&#39;s defense of his friend was a very able one, I dare say; but</li>
<li class="L3368" rel="L3368">since he is unacquainted with several parts of the story, and has learnt</li>
<li class="L3369" rel="L3369">the rest from that friend himself, I shall venture to still think of</li>
<li class="L3370" rel="L3370">both gentlemen as I did before.”</li>
<li class="L3371" rel="L3371"></li>
<li class="L3372" rel="L3372">She then changed the discourse to one more gratifying to each, and on</li>
<li class="L3373" rel="L3373">which there could be no difference of sentiment. Elizabeth listened with</li>
<li class="L3374" rel="L3374">delight to the happy, though modest hopes which Jane entertained of Mr.</li>
<li class="L3375" rel="L3375">Bingley&#39;s regard, and said all in her power to heighten her confidence</li>
<li class="L3376" rel="L3376">in it. On their being joined by Mr. Bingley himself, Elizabeth withdrew</li>
<li class="L3377" rel="L3377">to Miss Lucas; to whose inquiry after the pleasantness of her last</li>
<li class="L3378" rel="L3378">partner she had scarcely replied, before Mr. Collins came up to them,</li>
<li class="L3379" rel="L3379">and told her with great exultation that he had just been so fortunate as</li>
<li class="L3380" rel="L3380">to make a most important discovery.</li>
<li class="L3381" rel="L3381"></li>
<li class="L3382" rel="L3382">“I have found out,” said he, “by a singular accident, that there is now</li>
<li class="L3383" rel="L3383">in the room a near relation of my patroness. I happened to overhear the</li>
<li class="L3384" rel="L3384">gentleman himself mentioning to the young lady who does the honours of</li>
<li class="L3385" rel="L3385">the house the names of his cousin Miss de Bourgh, and of her mother Lady</li>
<li class="L3386" rel="L3386">Catherine. How wonderfully these sort of things occur! Who would have</li>
<li class="L3387" rel="L3387">thought of my meeting with, perhaps, a nephew of Lady Catherine de</li>
<li class="L3388" rel="L3388">Bourgh in this assembly! I am most thankful that the discovery is made</li>
<li class="L3389" rel="L3389">in time for me to pay my respects to him, which I am now going to</li>
<li class="L3390" rel="L3390">do, and trust he will excuse my not having done it before. My total</li>
<li class="L3391" rel="L3391">ignorance of the connection must plead my apology.”</li>
<li class="L3392" rel="L3392"></li>
<li class="L3393" rel="L3393">“You are not going to introduce yourself to Mr. Darcy!”</li>
<li class="L3394" rel="L3394"></li>
<li class="L3395" rel="L3395">“Indeed I am. I shall entreat his pardon for not having done it earlier.</li>
<li class="L3396" rel="L3396">I believe him to be Lady Catherine&#39;s _nephew_. It will be in my power to</li>
<li class="L3397" rel="L3397">assure him that her ladyship was quite well yesterday se&#39;nnight.”</li>
<li class="L3398" rel="L3398"></li>
<li class="L3399" rel="L3399">Elizabeth tried hard to dissuade him from such a scheme, assuring him</li>
<li class="L3400" rel="L3400">that Mr. Darcy would consider his addressing him without introduction</li>
<li class="L3401" rel="L3401">as an impertinent freedom, rather than a compliment to his aunt; that</li>
<li class="L3402" rel="L3402">it was not in the least necessary there should be any notice on either</li>
<li class="L3403" rel="L3403">side; and that if it were, it must belong to Mr. Darcy, the superior in</li>
<li class="L3404" rel="L3404">consequence, to begin the acquaintance. Mr. Collins listened to her</li>
<li class="L3405" rel="L3405">with the determined air of following his own inclination, and, when she</li>
<li class="L3406" rel="L3406">ceased speaking, replied thus:</li>
<li class="L3407" rel="L3407"></li>
<li class="L3408" rel="L3408">“My dear Miss Elizabeth, I have the highest opinion in the world in</li>
<li class="L3409" rel="L3409">your excellent judgement in all matters within the scope of your</li>
<li class="L3410" rel="L3410">understanding; but permit me to say, that there must be a wide</li>
<li class="L3411" rel="L3411">difference between the established forms of ceremony amongst the laity,</li>
<li class="L3412" rel="L3412">and those which regulate the clergy; for, give me leave to observe that</li>
<li class="L3413" rel="L3413">I consider the clerical office as equal in point of dignity with</li>
<li class="L3414" rel="L3414">the highest rank in the kingdom--provided that a proper humility of</li>
<li class="L3415" rel="L3415">behaviour is at the same time maintained. You must therefore allow me to</li>
<li class="L3416" rel="L3416">follow the dictates of my conscience on this occasion, which leads me to</li>
<li class="L3417" rel="L3417">perform what I look on as a point of duty. Pardon me for neglecting to</li>
<li class="L3418" rel="L3418">profit by your advice, which on every other subject shall be my constant</li>
<li class="L3419" rel="L3419">guide, though in the case before us I consider myself more fitted by</li>
<li class="L3420" rel="L3420">education and habitual study to decide on what is right than a young</li>
<li class="L3421" rel="L3421">lady like yourself.” And with a low bow he left her to attack Mr.</li>
<li class="L3422" rel="L3422">Darcy, whose reception of his advances she eagerly watched, and whose</li>
<li class="L3423" rel="L3423">astonishment at being so addressed was very evident. Her cousin prefaced</li>
<li class="L3424" rel="L3424">his speech with a solemn bow and though she could not hear a word of</li>
<li class="L3425" rel="L3425">it, she felt as if hearing it all, and saw in the motion of his lips the</li>
<li class="L3426" rel="L3426">words “apology,” “Hunsford,” and “Lady Catherine de Bourgh.” It vexed</li>
<li class="L3427" rel="L3427">her to see him expose himself to such a man. Mr. Darcy was eyeing him</li>
<li class="L3428" rel="L3428">with unrestrained wonder, and when at last Mr. Collins allowed him time</li>
<li class="L3429" rel="L3429">to speak, replied with an air of distant civility. Mr. Collins, however,</li>
<li class="L3430" rel="L3430">was not discouraged from speaking again, and Mr. Darcy&#39;s contempt seemed</li>
<li class="L3431" rel="L3431">abundantly increasing with the length of his second speech, and at the</li>
<li class="L3432" rel="L3432">end of it he only made him a slight bow, and moved another way. Mr.</li>
<li class="L3433" rel="L3433">Collins then returned to Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L3434" rel="L3434"></li>
<li class="L3435" rel="L3435">“I have no reason, I assure you,” said he, “to be dissatisfied with my</li>
<li class="L3436" rel="L3436">reception. Mr. Darcy seemed much pleased with the attention. He answered</li>
<li class="L3437" rel="L3437">me with the utmost civility, and even paid me the compliment of saying</li>
<li class="L3438" rel="L3438">that he was so well convinced of Lady Catherine&#39;s discernment as to be</li>
<li class="L3439" rel="L3439">certain she could never bestow a favour unworthily. It was really a very</li>
<li class="L3440" rel="L3440">handsome thought. Upon the whole, I am much pleased with him.”</li>
<li class="L3441" rel="L3441"></li>
<li class="L3442" rel="L3442">As Elizabeth had no longer any interest of her own to pursue, she turned</li>
<li class="L3443" rel="L3443">her attention almost entirely on her sister and Mr. Bingley; and the</li>
<li class="L3444" rel="L3444">train of agreeable reflections which her observations gave birth to,</li>
<li class="L3445" rel="L3445">made her perhaps almost as happy as Jane. She saw her in idea settled in</li>
<li class="L3446" rel="L3446">that very house, in all the felicity which a marriage of true affection</li>
<li class="L3447" rel="L3447">could bestow; and she felt capable, under such circumstances, of</li>
<li class="L3448" rel="L3448">endeavouring even to like Bingley&#39;s two sisters. Her mother&#39;s thoughts</li>
<li class="L3449" rel="L3449">she plainly saw were bent the same way, and she determined not to</li>
<li class="L3450" rel="L3450">venture near her, lest she might hear too much. When they sat down to</li>
<li class="L3451" rel="L3451">supper, therefore, she considered it a most unlucky perverseness which</li>
<li class="L3452" rel="L3452">placed them within one of each other; and deeply was she vexed to find</li>
<li class="L3453" rel="L3453">that her mother was talking to that one person (Lady Lucas) freely,</li>
<li class="L3454" rel="L3454">openly, and of nothing else but her expectation that Jane would soon</li>
<li class="L3455" rel="L3455">be married to Mr. Bingley. It was an animating subject, and Mrs. Bennet</li>
<li class="L3456" rel="L3456">seemed incapable of fatigue while enumerating the advantages of the</li>
<li class="L3457" rel="L3457">match. His being such a charming young man, and so rich, and living but</li>
<li class="L3458" rel="L3458">three miles from them, were the first points of self-gratulation; and</li>
<li class="L3459" rel="L3459">then it was such a comfort to think how fond the two sisters were of</li>
<li class="L3460" rel="L3460">Jane, and to be certain that they must desire the connection as much as</li>
<li class="L3461" rel="L3461">she could do. It was, moreover, such a promising thing for her younger</li>
<li class="L3462" rel="L3462">daughters, as Jane&#39;s marrying so greatly must throw them in the way of</li>
<li class="L3463" rel="L3463">other rich men; and lastly, it was so pleasant at her time of life to be</li>
<li class="L3464" rel="L3464">able to consign her single daughters to the care of their sister, that</li>
<li class="L3465" rel="L3465">she might not be obliged to go into company more than she liked. It was</li>
<li class="L3466" rel="L3466">necessary to make this circumstance a matter of pleasure, because on</li>
<li class="L3467" rel="L3467">such occasions it is the etiquette; but no one was less likely than Mrs.</li>
<li class="L3468" rel="L3468">Bennet to find comfort in staying home at any period of her life. She</li>
<li class="L3469" rel="L3469">concluded with many good wishes that Lady Lucas might soon be equally</li>
<li class="L3470" rel="L3470">fortunate, though evidently and triumphantly believing there was no</li>
<li class="L3471" rel="L3471">chance of it.</li>
<li class="L3472" rel="L3472"></li>
<li class="L3473" rel="L3473">In vain did Elizabeth endeavour to check the rapidity of her mother&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3474" rel="L3474">words, or persuade her to describe her felicity in a less audible</li>
<li class="L3475" rel="L3475">whisper; for, to her inexpressible vexation, she could perceive that the</li>
<li class="L3476" rel="L3476">chief of it was overheard by Mr. Darcy, who sat opposite to them. Her</li>
<li class="L3477" rel="L3477">mother only scolded her for being nonsensical.</li>
<li class="L3478" rel="L3478"></li>
<li class="L3479" rel="L3479">“What is Mr. Darcy to me, pray, that I should be afraid of him? I am</li>
<li class="L3480" rel="L3480">sure we owe him no such particular civility as to be obliged to say</li>
<li class="L3481" rel="L3481">nothing _he_ may not like to hear.”</li>
<li class="L3482" rel="L3482"></li>
<li class="L3483" rel="L3483">“For heaven&#39;s sake, madam, speak lower. What advantage can it be for you</li>
<li class="L3484" rel="L3484">to offend Mr. Darcy? You will never recommend yourself to his friend by</li>
<li class="L3485" rel="L3485">so doing!”</li>
<li class="L3486" rel="L3486"></li>
<li class="L3487" rel="L3487">Nothing that she could say, however, had any influence. Her mother would</li>
<li class="L3488" rel="L3488">talk of her views in the same intelligible tone. Elizabeth blushed and</li>
<li class="L3489" rel="L3489">blushed again with shame and vexation. She could not help frequently</li>
<li class="L3490" rel="L3490">glancing her eye at Mr. Darcy, though every glance convinced her of what</li>
<li class="L3491" rel="L3491">she dreaded; for though he was not always looking at her mother, she was</li>
<li class="L3492" rel="L3492">convinced that his attention was invariably fixed by her. The expression</li>
<li class="L3493" rel="L3493">of his face changed gradually from indignant contempt to a composed and</li>
<li class="L3494" rel="L3494">steady gravity.</li>
<li class="L3495" rel="L3495"></li>
<li class="L3496" rel="L3496">At length, however, Mrs. Bennet had no more to say; and Lady Lucas, who</li>
<li class="L3497" rel="L3497">had been long yawning at the repetition of delights which she saw no</li>
<li class="L3498" rel="L3498">likelihood of sharing, was left to the comforts of cold ham and</li>
<li class="L3499" rel="L3499">chicken. Elizabeth now began to revive. But not long was the interval of</li>
<li class="L3500" rel="L3500">tranquillity; for, when supper was over, singing was talked of, and</li>
<li class="L3501" rel="L3501">she had the mortification of seeing Mary, after very little entreaty,</li>
<li class="L3502" rel="L3502">preparing to oblige the company. By many significant looks and silent</li>
<li class="L3503" rel="L3503">entreaties, did she endeavour to prevent such a proof of complaisance,</li>
<li class="L3504" rel="L3504">but in vain; Mary would not understand them; such an opportunity of</li>
<li class="L3505" rel="L3505">exhibiting was delightful to her, and she began her song. Elizabeth&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3506" rel="L3506">eyes were fixed on her with most painful sensations, and she watched her</li>
<li class="L3507" rel="L3507">progress through the several stanzas with an impatience which was very</li>
<li class="L3508" rel="L3508">ill rewarded at their close; for Mary, on receiving, amongst the thanks</li>
<li class="L3509" rel="L3509">of the table, the hint of a hope that she might be prevailed on to</li>
<li class="L3510" rel="L3510">favour them again, after the pause of half a minute began another.</li>
<li class="L3511" rel="L3511">Mary&#39;s powers were by no means fitted for such a display; her voice was</li>
<li class="L3512" rel="L3512">weak, and her manner affected. Elizabeth was in agonies. She looked at</li>
<li class="L3513" rel="L3513">Jane, to see how she bore it; but Jane was very composedly talking to</li>
<li class="L3514" rel="L3514">Bingley. She looked at his two sisters, and saw them making signs</li>
<li class="L3515" rel="L3515">of derision at each other, and at Darcy, who continued, however,</li>
<li class="L3516" rel="L3516">imperturbably grave. She looked at her father to entreat his</li>
<li class="L3517" rel="L3517">interference, lest Mary should be singing all night. He took the hint,</li>
<li class="L3518" rel="L3518">and when Mary had finished her second song, said aloud, “That will do</li>
<li class="L3519" rel="L3519">extremely well, child. You have delighted us long enough. Let the other</li>
<li class="L3520" rel="L3520">young ladies have time to exhibit.”</li>
<li class="L3521" rel="L3521"></li>
<li class="L3522" rel="L3522">Mary, though pretending not to hear, was somewhat disconcerted; and</li>
<li class="L3523" rel="L3523">Elizabeth, sorry for her, and sorry for her father&#39;s speech, was afraid</li>
<li class="L3524" rel="L3524">her anxiety had done no good. Others of the party were now applied to.</li>
<li class="L3525" rel="L3525"></li>
<li class="L3526" rel="L3526">“If I,” said Mr. Collins, “were so fortunate as to be able to sing, I</li>
<li class="L3527" rel="L3527">should have great pleasure, I am sure, in obliging the company with an</li>
<li class="L3528" rel="L3528">air; for I consider music as a very innocent diversion, and perfectly</li>
<li class="L3529" rel="L3529">compatible with the profession of a clergyman. I do not mean, however,</li>
<li class="L3530" rel="L3530">to assert that we can be justified in devoting too much of our time</li>
<li class="L3531" rel="L3531">to music, for there are certainly other things to be attended to. The</li>
<li class="L3532" rel="L3532">rector of a parish has much to do. In the first place, he must make</li>
<li class="L3533" rel="L3533">such an agreement for tithes as may be beneficial to himself and not</li>
<li class="L3534" rel="L3534">offensive to his patron. He must write his own sermons; and the time</li>
<li class="L3535" rel="L3535">that remains will not be too much for his parish duties, and the care</li>
<li class="L3536" rel="L3536">and improvement of his dwelling, which he cannot be excused from making</li>
<li class="L3537" rel="L3537">as comfortable as possible. And I do not think it of light importance</li>
<li class="L3538" rel="L3538">that he should have attentive and conciliatory manners towards everybody,</li>
<li class="L3539" rel="L3539">especially towards those to whom he owes his preferment. I cannot acquit</li>
<li class="L3540" rel="L3540">him of that duty; nor could I think well of the man who should omit an</li>
<li class="L3541" rel="L3541">occasion of testifying his respect towards anybody connected with the</li>
<li class="L3542" rel="L3542">family.” And with a bow to Mr. Darcy, he concluded his speech, which had</li>
<li class="L3543" rel="L3543">been spoken so loud as to be heard by half the room. Many stared--many</li>
<li class="L3544" rel="L3544">smiled; but no one looked more amused than Mr. Bennet himself, while his</li>
<li class="L3545" rel="L3545">wife seriously commended Mr. Collins for having spoken so sensibly,</li>
<li class="L3546" rel="L3546">and observed in a half-whisper to Lady Lucas, that he was a remarkably</li>
<li class="L3547" rel="L3547">clever, good kind of young man.</li>
<li class="L3548" rel="L3548"></li>
<li class="L3549" rel="L3549">To Elizabeth it appeared that, had her family made an agreement to</li>
<li class="L3550" rel="L3550">expose themselves as much as they could during the evening, it would</li>
<li class="L3551" rel="L3551">have been impossible for them to play their parts with more spirit or</li>
<li class="L3552" rel="L3552">finer success; and happy did she think it for Bingley and her sister</li>
<li class="L3553" rel="L3553">that some of the exhibition had escaped his notice, and that his</li>
<li class="L3554" rel="L3554">feelings were not of a sort to be much distressed by the folly which he</li>
<li class="L3555" rel="L3555">must have witnessed. That his two sisters and Mr. Darcy, however, should</li>
<li class="L3556" rel="L3556">have such an opportunity of ridiculing her relations, was bad enough,</li>
<li class="L3557" rel="L3557">and she could not determine whether the silent contempt of the</li>
<li class="L3558" rel="L3558">gentleman, or the insolent smiles of the ladies, were more intolerable.</li>
<li class="L3559" rel="L3559"></li>
<li class="L3560" rel="L3560">The rest of the evening brought her little amusement. She was teased by</li>
<li class="L3561" rel="L3561">Mr. Collins, who continued most perseveringly by her side, and though</li>
<li class="L3562" rel="L3562">he could not prevail on her to dance with him again, put it out of her</li>
<li class="L3563" rel="L3563">power to dance with others. In vain did she entreat him to stand up with</li>
<li class="L3564" rel="L3564">somebody else, and offer to introduce him to any young lady in the room.</li>
<li class="L3565" rel="L3565">He assured her, that as to dancing, he was perfectly indifferent to it;</li>
<li class="L3566" rel="L3566">that his chief object was by delicate attentions to recommend himself to</li>
<li class="L3567" rel="L3567">her and that he should therefore make a point of remaining close to her</li>
<li class="L3568" rel="L3568">the whole evening. There was no arguing upon such a project. She owed</li>
<li class="L3569" rel="L3569">her greatest relief to her friend Miss Lucas, who often joined them, and</li>
<li class="L3570" rel="L3570">good-naturedly engaged Mr. Collins&#39;s conversation to herself.</li>
<li class="L3571" rel="L3571"></li>
<li class="L3572" rel="L3572">She was at least free from the offense of Mr. Darcy&#39;s further notice;</li>
<li class="L3573" rel="L3573">though often standing within a very short distance of her, quite</li>
<li class="L3574" rel="L3574">disengaged, he never came near enough to speak. She felt it to be the</li>
<li class="L3575" rel="L3575">probable consequence of her allusions to Mr. Wickham, and rejoiced in</li>
<li class="L3576" rel="L3576">it.</li>
<li class="L3577" rel="L3577"></li>
<li class="L3578" rel="L3578">The Longbourn party were the last of all the company to depart, and, by</li>
<li class="L3579" rel="L3579">a manoeuvre of Mrs. Bennet, had to wait for their carriage a quarter of</li>
<li class="L3580" rel="L3580">an hour after everybody else was gone, which gave them time to see how</li>
<li class="L3581" rel="L3581">heartily they were wished away by some of the family. Mrs. Hurst and her</li>
<li class="L3582" rel="L3582">sister scarcely opened their mouths, except to complain of fatigue, and</li>
<li class="L3583" rel="L3583">were evidently impatient to have the house to themselves. They repulsed</li>
<li class="L3584" rel="L3584">every attempt of Mrs. Bennet at conversation, and by so doing threw a</li>
<li class="L3585" rel="L3585">languor over the whole party, which was very little relieved by the</li>
<li class="L3586" rel="L3586">long speeches of Mr. Collins, who was complimenting Mr. Bingley and his</li>
<li class="L3587" rel="L3587">sisters on the elegance of their entertainment, and the hospitality and</li>
<li class="L3588" rel="L3588">politeness which had marked their behaviour to their guests. Darcy said</li>
<li class="L3589" rel="L3589">nothing at all. Mr. Bennet, in equal silence, was enjoying the scene.</li>
<li class="L3590" rel="L3590">Mr. Bingley and Jane were standing together, a little detached from the</li>
<li class="L3591" rel="L3591">rest, and talked only to each other. Elizabeth preserved as steady a</li>
<li class="L3592" rel="L3592">silence as either Mrs. Hurst or Miss Bingley; and even Lydia was too</li>
<li class="L3593" rel="L3593">much fatigued to utter more than the occasional exclamation of “Lord,</li>
<li class="L3594" rel="L3594">how tired I am!” accompanied by a violent yawn.</li>
<li class="L3595" rel="L3595"></li>
<li class="L3596" rel="L3596">When at length they arose to take leave, Mrs. Bennet was most pressingly</li>
<li class="L3597" rel="L3597">civil in her hope of seeing the whole family soon at Longbourn, and</li>
<li class="L3598" rel="L3598">addressed herself especially to Mr. Bingley, to assure him how happy he</li>
<li class="L3599" rel="L3599">would make them by eating a family dinner with them at any time, without</li>
<li class="L3600" rel="L3600">the ceremony of a formal invitation. Bingley was all grateful pleasure,</li>
<li class="L3601" rel="L3601">and he readily engaged for taking the earliest opportunity of waiting on</li>
<li class="L3602" rel="L3602">her, after his return from London, whither he was obliged to go the next</li>
<li class="L3603" rel="L3603">day for a short time.</li>
<li class="L3604" rel="L3604"></li>
<li class="L3605" rel="L3605">Mrs. Bennet was perfectly satisfied, and quitted the house under the</li>
<li class="L3606" rel="L3606">delightful persuasion that, allowing for the necessary preparations of</li>
<li class="L3607" rel="L3607">settlements, new carriages, and wedding clothes, she should undoubtedly</li>
<li class="L3608" rel="L3608">see her daughter settled at Netherfield in the course of three or four</li>
<li class="L3609" rel="L3609">months. Of having another daughter married to Mr. Collins, she thought</li>
<li class="L3610" rel="L3610">with equal certainty, and with considerable, though not equal, pleasure.</li>
<li class="L3611" rel="L3611">Elizabeth was the least dear to her of all her children; and though the</li>
<li class="L3612" rel="L3612">man and the match were quite good enough for _her_, the worth of each</li>
<li class="L3613" rel="L3613">was eclipsed by Mr. Bingley and Netherfield.</li>
<li class="L3614" rel="L3614"></li>
<li class="L3615" rel="L3615"></li>
<li class="L3616" rel="L3616"></li>
<li class="L3617" rel="L3617">Chapter 19</li>
<li class="L3618" rel="L3618"></li>
<li class="L3619" rel="L3619"></li>
<li class="L3620" rel="L3620">The next day opened a new scene at Longbourn. Mr. Collins made his</li>
<li class="L3621" rel="L3621">declaration in form. Having resolved to do it without loss of time, as</li>
<li class="L3622" rel="L3622">his leave of absence extended only to the following Saturday, and having</li>
<li class="L3623" rel="L3623">no feelings of diffidence to make it distressing to himself even at</li>
<li class="L3624" rel="L3624">the moment, he set about it in a very orderly manner, with all the</li>
<li class="L3625" rel="L3625">observances, which he supposed a regular part of the business. On</li>
<li class="L3626" rel="L3626">finding Mrs. Bennet, Elizabeth, and one of the younger girls together,</li>
<li class="L3627" rel="L3627">soon after breakfast, he addressed the mother in these words:</li>
<li class="L3628" rel="L3628"></li>
<li class="L3629" rel="L3629">“May I hope, madam, for your interest with your fair daughter Elizabeth,</li>
<li class="L3630" rel="L3630">when I solicit for the honour of a private audience with her in the</li>
<li class="L3631" rel="L3631">course of this morning?”</li>
<li class="L3632" rel="L3632"></li>
<li class="L3633" rel="L3633">Before Elizabeth had time for anything but a blush of surprise, Mrs.</li>
<li class="L3634" rel="L3634">Bennet answered instantly, “Oh dear!--yes--certainly. I am sure Lizzy</li>
<li class="L3635" rel="L3635">will be very happy--I am sure she can have no objection. Come, Kitty, I</li>
<li class="L3636" rel="L3636">want you up stairs.” And, gathering her work together, she was hastening</li>
<li class="L3637" rel="L3637">away, when Elizabeth called out:</li>
<li class="L3638" rel="L3638"></li>
<li class="L3639" rel="L3639">“Dear madam, do not go. I beg you will not go. Mr. Collins must excuse</li>
<li class="L3640" rel="L3640">me. He can have nothing to say to me that anybody need not hear. I am</li>
<li class="L3641" rel="L3641">going away myself.”</li>
<li class="L3642" rel="L3642"></li>
<li class="L3643" rel="L3643">“No, no, nonsense, Lizzy. I desire you to stay where you are.” And upon</li>
<li class="L3644" rel="L3644">Elizabeth&#39;s seeming really, with vexed and embarrassed looks, about to</li>
<li class="L3645" rel="L3645">escape, she added: “Lizzy, I _insist_ upon your staying and hearing Mr.</li>
<li class="L3646" rel="L3646">Collins.”</li>
<li class="L3647" rel="L3647"></li>
<li class="L3648" rel="L3648">Elizabeth would not oppose such an injunction--and a moment&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3649" rel="L3649">consideration making her also sensible that it would be wisest to get it</li>
<li class="L3650" rel="L3650">over as soon and as quietly as possible, she sat down again and tried to</li>
<li class="L3651" rel="L3651">conceal, by incessant employment the feelings which were divided between</li>
<li class="L3652" rel="L3652">distress and diversion. Mrs. Bennet and Kitty walked off, and as soon as</li>
<li class="L3653" rel="L3653">they were gone, Mr. Collins began.</li>
<li class="L3654" rel="L3654"></li>
<li class="L3655" rel="L3655">“Believe me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, so far from</li>
<li class="L3656" rel="L3656">doing you any disservice, rather adds to your other perfections. You</li>
<li class="L3657" rel="L3657">would have been less amiable in my eyes had there _not_ been this little</li>
<li class="L3658" rel="L3658">unwillingness; but allow me to assure you, that I have your respected</li>
<li class="L3659" rel="L3659">mother&#39;s permission for this address. You can hardly doubt the</li>
<li class="L3660" rel="L3660">purport of my discourse, however your natural delicacy may lead you to</li>
<li class="L3661" rel="L3661">dissemble; my attentions have been too marked to be mistaken. Almost as</li>
<li class="L3662" rel="L3662">soon as I entered the house, I singled you out as the companion of</li>
<li class="L3663" rel="L3663">my future life. But before I am run away with by my feelings on this</li>
<li class="L3664" rel="L3664">subject, perhaps it would be advisable for me to state my reasons for</li>
<li class="L3665" rel="L3665">marrying--and, moreover, for coming into Hertfordshire with the design</li>
<li class="L3666" rel="L3666">of selecting a wife, as I certainly did.”</li>
<li class="L3667" rel="L3667"></li>
<li class="L3668" rel="L3668">The idea of Mr. Collins, with all his solemn composure, being run away</li>
<li class="L3669" rel="L3669">with by his feelings, made Elizabeth so near laughing, that she could</li>
<li class="L3670" rel="L3670">not use the short pause he allowed in any attempt to stop him further,</li>
<li class="L3671" rel="L3671">and he continued:</li>
<li class="L3672" rel="L3672"></li>
<li class="L3673" rel="L3673">“My reasons for marrying are, first, that I think it a right thing for</li>
<li class="L3674" rel="L3674">every clergyman in easy circumstances (like myself) to set the example</li>
<li class="L3675" rel="L3675">of matrimony in his parish; secondly, that I am convinced that it will</li>
<li class="L3676" rel="L3676">add very greatly to my happiness; and thirdly--which perhaps I ought</li>
<li class="L3677" rel="L3677">to have mentioned earlier, that it is the particular advice and</li>
<li class="L3678" rel="L3678">recommendation of the very noble lady whom I have the honour of calling</li>
<li class="L3679" rel="L3679">patroness. Twice has she condescended to give me her opinion (unasked</li>
<li class="L3680" rel="L3680">too!) on this subject; and it was but the very Saturday night before I</li>
<li class="L3681" rel="L3681">left Hunsford--between our pools at quadrille, while Mrs. Jenkinson was</li>
<li class="L3682" rel="L3682">arranging Miss de Bourgh&#39;s footstool, that she said, &#39;Mr. Collins, you</li>
<li class="L3683" rel="L3683">must marry. A clergyman like you must marry. Choose properly, choose</li>
<li class="L3684" rel="L3684">a gentlewoman for _my_ sake; and for your _own_, let her be an active,</li>
<li class="L3685" rel="L3685">useful sort of person, not brought up high, but able to make a small</li>
<li class="L3686" rel="L3686">income go a good way. This is my advice. Find such a woman as soon as</li>
<li class="L3687" rel="L3687">you can, bring her to Hunsford, and I will visit her.&#39; Allow me, by the</li>
<li class="L3688" rel="L3688">way, to observe, my fair cousin, that I do not reckon the notice</li>
<li class="L3689" rel="L3689">and kindness of Lady Catherine de Bourgh as among the least of the</li>
<li class="L3690" rel="L3690">advantages in my power to offer. You will find her manners beyond</li>
<li class="L3691" rel="L3691">anything I can describe; and your wit and vivacity, I think, must be</li>
<li class="L3692" rel="L3692">acceptable to her, especially when tempered with the silence and</li>
<li class="L3693" rel="L3693">respect which her rank will inevitably excite. Thus much for my general</li>
<li class="L3694" rel="L3694">intention in favour of matrimony; it remains to be told why my views</li>
<li class="L3695" rel="L3695">were directed towards Longbourn instead of my own neighbourhood, where I</li>
<li class="L3696" rel="L3696">can assure you there are many amiable young women. But the fact is, that</li>
<li class="L3697" rel="L3697">being, as I am, to inherit this estate after the death of your honoured</li>
<li class="L3698" rel="L3698">father (who, however, may live many years longer), I could not satisfy</li>
<li class="L3699" rel="L3699">myself without resolving to choose a wife from among his daughters, that</li>
<li class="L3700" rel="L3700">the loss to them might be as little as possible, when the melancholy</li>
<li class="L3701" rel="L3701">event takes place--which, however, as I have already said, may not</li>
<li class="L3702" rel="L3702">be for several years. This has been my motive, my fair cousin, and</li>
<li class="L3703" rel="L3703">I flatter myself it will not sink me in your esteem. And now nothing</li>
<li class="L3704" rel="L3704">remains for me but to assure you in the most animated language of the</li>
<li class="L3705" rel="L3705">violence of my affection. To fortune I am perfectly indifferent, and</li>
<li class="L3706" rel="L3706">shall make no demand of that nature on your father, since I am well</li>
<li class="L3707" rel="L3707">aware that it could not be complied with; and that one thousand pounds</li>
<li class="L3708" rel="L3708">in the four per cents, which will not be yours till after your mother&#39;s</li>
<li class="L3709" rel="L3709">decease, is all that you may ever be entitled to. On that head,</li>
<li class="L3710" rel="L3710">therefore, I shall be uniformly silent; and you may assure yourself that</li>
<li class="L3711" rel="L3711">no ungenerous reproach shall ever pass my lips when we are married.”</li>
<li class="L3712" rel="L3712"></li>
<li class="L3713" rel="L3713">It was absolutely necessary to interrupt him now.</li>
<li class="L3714" rel="L3714"></li>
<li class="L3715" rel="L3715">“You are too hasty, sir,” she cried. “You forget that I have made no</li>
<li class="L3716" rel="L3716">answer. Let me do it without further loss of time. Accept my thanks for</li>
<li class="L3717" rel="L3717">the compliment you are paying me. I am very sensible of the honour of</li>
<li class="L3718" rel="L3718">your proposals, but it is impossible for me to do otherwise than to</li>
<li class="L3719" rel="L3719">decline them.”</li>
<li class="L3720" rel="L3720"></li>
<li class="L3721" rel="L3721">“I am not now to learn,” replied Mr. Collins, with a formal wave of the</li>
<li class="L3722" rel="L3722">hand, “that it is usual with young ladies to reject the addresses of the</li>
<li class="L3723" rel="L3723">man whom they secretly mean to accept, when he first applies for their</li>
<li class="L3724" rel="L3724">favour; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second, or even a</li>
<li class="L3725" rel="L3725">third time. I am therefore by no means discouraged by what you have just</li>
<li class="L3726" rel="L3726">said, and shall hope to lead you to the altar ere long.”</li>
<li class="L3727" rel="L3727"></li>
<li class="L3728" rel="L3728">“Upon my word, sir,” cried Elizabeth, “your hope is a rather</li>
<li class="L3729" rel="L3729">extraordinary one after my declaration. I do assure you that I am not</li>
<li class="L3730" rel="L3730">one of those young ladies (if such young ladies there are) who are so</li>
<li class="L3731" rel="L3731">daring as to risk their happiness on the chance of being asked a second</li>
<li class="L3732" rel="L3732">time. I am perfectly serious in my refusal. You could not make _me_</li>
<li class="L3733" rel="L3733">happy, and I am convinced that I am the last woman in the world who</li>
<li class="L3734" rel="L3734">could make you so. Nay, were your friend Lady Catherine to know me, I</li>
<li class="L3735" rel="L3735">am persuaded she would find me in every respect ill qualified for the</li>
<li class="L3736" rel="L3736">situation.”</li>
<li class="L3737" rel="L3737"></li>
<li class="L3738" rel="L3738">“Were it certain that Lady Catherine would think so,” said Mr. Collins</li>
<li class="L3739" rel="L3739">very gravely--“but I cannot imagine that her ladyship would at all</li>
<li class="L3740" rel="L3740">disapprove of you. And you may be certain when I have the honour of</li>
<li class="L3741" rel="L3741">seeing her again, I shall speak in the very highest terms of your</li>
<li class="L3742" rel="L3742">modesty, economy, and other amiable qualification.”</li>
<li class="L3743" rel="L3743"></li>
<li class="L3744" rel="L3744">“Indeed, Mr. Collins, all praise of me will be unnecessary. You</li>
<li class="L3745" rel="L3745">must give me leave to judge for myself, and pay me the compliment</li>
<li class="L3746" rel="L3746">of believing what I say. I wish you very happy and very rich, and by</li>
<li class="L3747" rel="L3747">refusing your hand, do all in my power to prevent your being otherwise.</li>
<li class="L3748" rel="L3748">In making me the offer, you must have satisfied the delicacy of your</li>
<li class="L3749" rel="L3749">feelings with regard to my family, and may take possession of Longbourn</li>
<li class="L3750" rel="L3750">estate whenever it falls, without any self-reproach. This matter may</li>
<li class="L3751" rel="L3751">be considered, therefore, as finally settled.” And rising as she</li>
<li class="L3752" rel="L3752">thus spoke, she would have quitted the room, had Mr. Collins not thus</li>
<li class="L3753" rel="L3753">addressed her:</li>
<li class="L3754" rel="L3754"></li>
<li class="L3755" rel="L3755">“When I do myself the honour of speaking to you next on the subject, I</li>
<li class="L3756" rel="L3756">shall hope to receive a more favourable answer than you have now given</li>
<li class="L3757" rel="L3757">me; though I am far from accusing you of cruelty at present, because I</li>
<li class="L3758" rel="L3758">know it to be the established custom of your sex to reject a man on</li>
<li class="L3759" rel="L3759">the first application, and perhaps you have even now said as much to</li>
<li class="L3760" rel="L3760">encourage my suit as would be consistent with the true delicacy of the</li>
<li class="L3761" rel="L3761">female character.”</li>
<li class="L3762" rel="L3762"></li>
<li class="L3763" rel="L3763">“Really, Mr. Collins,” cried Elizabeth with some warmth, “you puzzle me</li>
<li class="L3764" rel="L3764">exceedingly. If what I have hitherto said can appear to you in the form</li>
<li class="L3765" rel="L3765">of encouragement, I know not how to express my refusal in such a way as</li>
<li class="L3766" rel="L3766">to convince you of its being one.”</li>
<li class="L3767" rel="L3767"></li>
<li class="L3768" rel="L3768">“You must give me leave to flatter myself, my dear cousin, that your</li>
<li class="L3769" rel="L3769">refusal of my addresses is merely words of course. My reasons for</li>
<li class="L3770" rel="L3770">believing it are briefly these: It does not appear to me that my hand is</li>
<li class="L3771" rel="L3771">unworthy of your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would</li>
<li class="L3772" rel="L3772">be any other than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connections</li>
<li class="L3773" rel="L3773">with the family of de Bourgh, and my relationship to your own, are</li>
<li class="L3774" rel="L3774">circumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it into further</li>
<li class="L3775" rel="L3775">consideration, that in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no</li>
<li class="L3776" rel="L3776">means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you. Your</li>
<li class="L3777" rel="L3777">portion is unhappily so small that it will in all likelihood undo</li>
<li class="L3778" rel="L3778">the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications. As I must</li>
