<li class="L3779" rel="L3779">therefore conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me,</li>
<li class="L3780" rel="L3780">I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by</li>
<li class="L3781" rel="L3781">suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.”</li>
<li class="L3782" rel="L3782"></li>
<li class="L3783" rel="L3783">“I do assure you, sir, that I have no pretensions whatever to that kind</li>
<li class="L3784" rel="L3784">of elegance which consists in tormenting a respectable man. I would</li>
<li class="L3785" rel="L3785">rather be paid the compliment of being believed sincere. I thank you</li>
<li class="L3786" rel="L3786">again and again for the honour you have done me in your proposals, but</li>
<li class="L3787" rel="L3787">to accept them is absolutely impossible. My feelings in every respect</li>
<li class="L3788" rel="L3788">forbid it. Can I speak plainer? Do not consider me now as an elegant</li>
<li class="L3789" rel="L3789">female, intending to plague you, but as a rational creature, speaking</li>
<li class="L3790" rel="L3790">the truth from her heart.”</li>
<li class="L3791" rel="L3791"></li>
<li class="L3792" rel="L3792">“You are uniformly charming!” cried he, with an air of awkward</li>
<li class="L3793" rel="L3793">gallantry; “and I am persuaded that when sanctioned by the express</li>
<li class="L3794" rel="L3794">authority of both your excellent parents, my proposals will not fail of</li>
<li class="L3795" rel="L3795">being acceptable.”</li>
<li class="L3796" rel="L3796"></li>
<li class="L3797" rel="L3797">To such perseverance in wilful self-deception Elizabeth would make</li>
<li class="L3798" rel="L3798">no reply, and immediately and in silence withdrew; determined, if</li>
<li class="L3799" rel="L3799">he persisted in considering her repeated refusals as flattering</li>
<li class="L3800" rel="L3800">encouragement, to apply to her father, whose negative might be uttered</li>
<li class="L3801" rel="L3801">in such a manner as to be decisive, and whose behaviour at least could</li>
<li class="L3802" rel="L3802">not be mistaken for the affectation and coquetry of an elegant female.</li>
<li class="L3803" rel="L3803"></li>
<li class="L3804" rel="L3804"></li>
<li class="L3805" rel="L3805"></li>
<li class="L3806" rel="L3806">Chapter 20</li>
<li class="L3807" rel="L3807"></li>
<li class="L3808" rel="L3808"></li>
<li class="L3809" rel="L3809">Mr. Collins was not left long to the silent contemplation of his</li>
<li class="L3810" rel="L3810">successful love; for Mrs. Bennet, having dawdled about in the vestibule</li>
<li class="L3811" rel="L3811">to watch for the end of the conference, no sooner saw Elizabeth open</li>
<li class="L3812" rel="L3812">the door and with quick step pass her towards the staircase, than she</li>
<li class="L3813" rel="L3813">entered the breakfast-room, and congratulated both him and herself in</li>
<li class="L3814" rel="L3814">warm terms on the happy prospect of their nearer connection. Mr. Collins</li>
<li class="L3815" rel="L3815">received and returned these felicitations with equal pleasure, and then</li>
<li class="L3816" rel="L3816">proceeded to relate the particulars of their interview, with the result</li>
<li class="L3817" rel="L3817">of which he trusted he had every reason to be satisfied, since the</li>
<li class="L3818" rel="L3818">refusal which his cousin had steadfastly given him would naturally flow</li>
<li class="L3819" rel="L3819">from her bashful modesty and the genuine delicacy of her character.</li>
<li class="L3820" rel="L3820"></li>
<li class="L3821" rel="L3821">This information, however, startled Mrs. Bennet; she would have been</li>
<li class="L3822" rel="L3822">glad to be equally satisfied that her daughter had meant to encourage</li>
<li class="L3823" rel="L3823">him by protesting against his proposals, but she dared not believe it,</li>
<li class="L3824" rel="L3824">and could not help saying so.</li>
<li class="L3825" rel="L3825"></li>
<li class="L3826" rel="L3826">“But, depend upon it, Mr. Collins,” she added, “that Lizzy shall be</li>
<li class="L3827" rel="L3827">brought to reason. I will speak to her about it directly. She is a very</li>
<li class="L3828" rel="L3828">headstrong, foolish girl, and does not know her own interest but I will</li>
<li class="L3829" rel="L3829">_make_ her know it.”</li>
<li class="L3830" rel="L3830"></li>
<li class="L3831" rel="L3831">“Pardon me for interrupting you, madam,” cried Mr. Collins; “but if</li>
<li class="L3832" rel="L3832">she is really headstrong and foolish, I know not whether she would</li>
<li class="L3833" rel="L3833">altogether be a very desirable wife to a man in my situation, who</li>
<li class="L3834" rel="L3834">naturally looks for happiness in the marriage state. If therefore she</li>
<li class="L3835" rel="L3835">actually persists in rejecting my suit, perhaps it were better not</li>
<li class="L3836" rel="L3836">to force her into accepting me, because if liable to such defects of</li>
<li class="L3837" rel="L3837">temper, she could not contribute much to my felicity.”</li>
<li class="L3838" rel="L3838"></li>
<li class="L3839" rel="L3839">“Sir, you quite misunderstand me,” said Mrs. Bennet, alarmed. “Lizzy is</li>
<li class="L3840" rel="L3840">only headstrong in such matters as these. In everything else she is as</li>
<li class="L3841" rel="L3841">good-natured a girl as ever lived. I will go directly to Mr. Bennet, and</li>
<li class="L3842" rel="L3842">we shall very soon settle it with her, I am sure.”</li>
<li class="L3843" rel="L3843"></li>
<li class="L3844" rel="L3844">She would not give him time to reply, but hurrying instantly to her</li>
<li class="L3845" rel="L3845">husband, called out as she entered the library, “Oh! Mr. Bennet, you</li>
<li class="L3846" rel="L3846">are wanted immediately; we are all in an uproar. You must come and make</li>
<li class="L3847" rel="L3847">Lizzy marry Mr. Collins, for she vows she will not have him, and if you</li>
<li class="L3848" rel="L3848">do not make haste he will change his mind and not have _her_.”</li>
<li class="L3849" rel="L3849"></li>
<li class="L3850" rel="L3850">Mr. Bennet raised his eyes from his book as she entered, and fixed them</li>
<li class="L3851" rel="L3851">on her face with a calm unconcern which was not in the least altered by</li>
<li class="L3852" rel="L3852">her communication.</li>
<li class="L3853" rel="L3853"></li>
<li class="L3854" rel="L3854">“I have not the pleasure of understanding you,” said he, when she had</li>
<li class="L3855" rel="L3855">finished her speech. “Of what are you talking?”</li>
<li class="L3856" rel="L3856"></li>
<li class="L3857" rel="L3857">“Of Mr. Collins and Lizzy. Lizzy declares she will not have Mr. Collins,</li>
<li class="L3858" rel="L3858">and Mr. Collins begins to say that he will not have Lizzy.”</li>
<li class="L3859" rel="L3859"></li>
<li class="L3860" rel="L3860">“And what am I to do on the occasion? It seems an hopeless business.”</li>
<li class="L3861" rel="L3861"></li>
<li class="L3862" rel="L3862">“Speak to Lizzy about it yourself. Tell her that you insist upon her</li>
<li class="L3863" rel="L3863">marrying him.”</li>
<li class="L3864" rel="L3864"></li>
<li class="L3865" rel="L3865">“Let her be called down. She shall hear my opinion.”</li>
<li class="L3866" rel="L3866"></li>
<li class="L3867" rel="L3867">Mrs. Bennet rang the bell, and Miss Elizabeth was summoned to the</li>
<li class="L3868" rel="L3868">library.</li>
<li class="L3869" rel="L3869"></li>
<li class="L3870" rel="L3870">“Come here, child,” cried her father as she appeared. “I have sent for</li>
<li class="L3871" rel="L3871">you on an affair of importance. I understand that Mr. Collins has made</li>
<li class="L3872" rel="L3872">you an offer of marriage. Is it true?” Elizabeth replied that it was.</li>
<li class="L3873" rel="L3873">“Very well--and this offer of marriage you have refused?”</li>
<li class="L3874" rel="L3874"></li>
<li class="L3875" rel="L3875">“I have, sir.”</li>
<li class="L3876" rel="L3876"></li>
<li class="L3877" rel="L3877">“Very well. We now come to the point. Your mother insists upon your</li>
<li class="L3878" rel="L3878">accepting it. Is it not so, Mrs. Bennet?”</li>
<li class="L3879" rel="L3879"></li>
<li class="L3880" rel="L3880">“Yes, or I will never see her again.”</li>
<li class="L3881" rel="L3881"></li>
<li class="L3882" rel="L3882">“An unhappy alternative is before you, Elizabeth. From this day you must</li>
<li class="L3883" rel="L3883">be a stranger to one of your parents. Your mother will never see you</li>
<li class="L3884" rel="L3884">again if you do _not_ marry Mr. Collins, and I will never see you again</li>
<li class="L3885" rel="L3885">if you _do_.”</li>
<li class="L3886" rel="L3886"></li>
<li class="L3887" rel="L3887">Elizabeth could not but smile at such a conclusion of such a beginning,</li>
<li class="L3888" rel="L3888">but Mrs. Bennet, who had persuaded herself that her husband regarded the</li>
<li class="L3889" rel="L3889">affair as she wished, was excessively disappointed.</li>
<li class="L3890" rel="L3890"></li>
<li class="L3891" rel="L3891">“What do you mean, Mr. Bennet, in talking this way? You promised me to</li>
<li class="L3892" rel="L3892">_insist_ upon her marrying him.”</li>
<li class="L3893" rel="L3893"></li>
<li class="L3894" rel="L3894">“My dear,” replied her husband, “I have two small favours to request.</li>
<li class="L3895" rel="L3895">First, that you will allow me the free use of my understanding on the</li>
<li class="L3896" rel="L3896">present occasion; and secondly, of my room. I shall be glad to have the</li>
<li class="L3897" rel="L3897">library to myself as soon as may be.”</li>
<li class="L3898" rel="L3898"></li>
<li class="L3899" rel="L3899">Not yet, however, in spite of her disappointment in her husband, did</li>
<li class="L3900" rel="L3900">Mrs. Bennet give up the point. She talked to Elizabeth again and again;</li>
<li class="L3901" rel="L3901">coaxed and threatened her by turns. She endeavoured to secure Jane</li>
<li class="L3902" rel="L3902">in her interest; but Jane, with all possible mildness, declined</li>
<li class="L3903" rel="L3903">interfering; and Elizabeth, sometimes with real earnestness, and</li>
<li class="L3904" rel="L3904">sometimes with playful gaiety, replied to her attacks. Though her manner</li>
<li class="L3905" rel="L3905">varied, however, her determination never did.</li>
<li class="L3906" rel="L3906"></li>
<li class="L3907" rel="L3907">Mr. Collins, meanwhile, was meditating in solitude on what had passed.</li>
<li class="L3908" rel="L3908">He thought too well of himself to comprehend on what motives his cousin</li>
<li class="L3909" rel="L3909">could refuse him; and though his pride was hurt, he suffered in no other</li>
<li class="L3910" rel="L3910">way. His regard for her was quite imaginary; and the possibility of her</li>
<li class="L3911" rel="L3911">deserving her mother&#39;s reproach prevented his feeling any regret.</li>
<li class="L3912" rel="L3912"></li>
<li class="L3913" rel="L3913">While the family were in this confusion, Charlotte Lucas came to spend</li>
<li class="L3914" rel="L3914">the day with them. She was met in the vestibule by Lydia, who, flying to</li>
<li class="L3915" rel="L3915">her, cried in a half whisper, “I am glad you are come, for there is such</li>
<li class="L3916" rel="L3916">fun here! What do you think has happened this morning? Mr. Collins has</li>
<li class="L3917" rel="L3917">made an offer to Lizzy, and she will not have him.”</li>
<li class="L3918" rel="L3918"></li>
<li class="L3919" rel="L3919">Charlotte hardly had time to answer, before they were joined by Kitty,</li>
<li class="L3920" rel="L3920">who came to tell the same news; and no sooner had they entered the</li>
<li class="L3921" rel="L3921">breakfast-room, where Mrs. Bennet was alone, than she likewise began on</li>
<li class="L3922" rel="L3922">the subject, calling on Miss Lucas for her compassion, and entreating</li>
<li class="L3923" rel="L3923">her to persuade her friend Lizzy to comply with the wishes of all her</li>
<li class="L3924" rel="L3924">family. “Pray do, my dear Miss Lucas,” she added in a melancholy tone,</li>
<li class="L3925" rel="L3925">“for nobody is on my side, nobody takes part with me. I am cruelly used,</li>
<li class="L3926" rel="L3926">nobody feels for my poor nerves.”</li>
<li class="L3927" rel="L3927"></li>
<li class="L3928" rel="L3928">Charlotte&#39;s reply was spared by the entrance of Jane and Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L3929" rel="L3929"></li>
<li class="L3930" rel="L3930">“Aye, there she comes,” continued Mrs. Bennet, “looking as unconcerned</li>
<li class="L3931" rel="L3931">as may be, and caring no more for us than if we were at York, provided</li>
<li class="L3932" rel="L3932">she can have her own way. But I tell you, Miss Lizzy--if you take it</li>
<li class="L3933" rel="L3933">into your head to go on refusing every offer of marriage in this way,</li>
<li class="L3934" rel="L3934">you will never get a husband at all--and I am sure I do not know who is</li>
<li class="L3935" rel="L3935">to maintain you when your father is dead. I shall not be able to keep</li>
<li class="L3936" rel="L3936">you--and so I warn you. I have done with you from this very day. I told</li>
<li class="L3937" rel="L3937">you in the library, you know, that I should never speak to you again,</li>
<li class="L3938" rel="L3938">and you will find me as good as my word. I have no pleasure in talking</li>
<li class="L3939" rel="L3939">to undutiful children. Not that I have much pleasure, indeed, in talking</li>
<li class="L3940" rel="L3940">to anybody. People who suffer as I do from nervous complaints can have</li>
<li class="L3941" rel="L3941">no great inclination for talking. Nobody can tell what I suffer! But it</li>
<li class="L3942" rel="L3942">is always so. Those who do not complain are never pitied.”</li>
<li class="L3943" rel="L3943"></li>
<li class="L3944" rel="L3944">Her daughters listened in silence to this effusion, sensible that</li>
<li class="L3945" rel="L3945">any attempt to reason with her or soothe her would only increase the</li>
<li class="L3946" rel="L3946">irritation. She talked on, therefore, without interruption from any of</li>
<li class="L3947" rel="L3947">them, till they were joined by Mr. Collins, who entered the room with</li>
<li class="L3948" rel="L3948">an air more stately than usual, and on perceiving whom, she said to</li>
<li class="L3949" rel="L3949">the girls, “Now, I do insist upon it, that you, all of you, hold</li>
<li class="L3950" rel="L3950">your tongues, and let me and Mr. Collins have a little conversation</li>
<li class="L3951" rel="L3951">together.”</li>
<li class="L3952" rel="L3952"></li>
<li class="L3953" rel="L3953">Elizabeth passed quietly out of the room, Jane and Kitty followed, but</li>
<li class="L3954" rel="L3954">Lydia stood her ground, determined to hear all she could; and Charlotte,</li>
<li class="L3955" rel="L3955">detained first by the civility of Mr. Collins, whose inquiries after</li>
<li class="L3956" rel="L3956">herself and all her family were very minute, and then by a little</li>
<li class="L3957" rel="L3957">curiosity, satisfied herself with walking to the window and pretending</li>
<li class="L3958" rel="L3958">not to hear. In a doleful voice Mrs. Bennet began the projected</li>
<li class="L3959" rel="L3959">conversation: “Oh! Mr. Collins!”</li>
<li class="L3960" rel="L3960"></li>
<li class="L3961" rel="L3961">“My dear madam,” replied he, “let us be for ever silent on this point.</li>
<li class="L3962" rel="L3962">Far be it from me,” he presently continued, in a voice that marked his</li>
<li class="L3963" rel="L3963">displeasure, “to resent the behaviour of your daughter. Resignation</li>
<li class="L3964" rel="L3964">to inevitable evils is the duty of us all; the peculiar duty of a</li>
<li class="L3965" rel="L3965">young man who has been so fortunate as I have been in early preferment;</li>
<li class="L3966" rel="L3966">and I trust I am resigned. Perhaps not the less so from feeling a doubt</li>
<li class="L3967" rel="L3967">of my positive happiness had my fair cousin honoured me with her hand;</li>
<li class="L3968" rel="L3968">for I have often observed that resignation is never so perfect as</li>
<li class="L3969" rel="L3969">when the blessing denied begins to lose somewhat of its value in our</li>
<li class="L3970" rel="L3970">estimation. You will not, I hope, consider me as showing any disrespect</li>
<li class="L3971" rel="L3971">to your family, my dear madam, by thus withdrawing my pretensions to</li>
<li class="L3972" rel="L3972">your daughter&#39;s favour, without having paid yourself and Mr. Bennet the</li>
<li class="L3973" rel="L3973">compliment of requesting you to interpose your authority in my</li>
<li class="L3974" rel="L3974">behalf. My conduct may, I fear, be objectionable in having accepted my</li>
<li class="L3975" rel="L3975">dismission from your daughter&#39;s lips instead of your own. But we are all</li>
<li class="L3976" rel="L3976">liable to error. I have certainly meant well through the whole affair.</li>
<li class="L3977" rel="L3977">My object has been to secure an amiable companion for myself, with due</li>
<li class="L3978" rel="L3978">consideration for the advantage of all your family, and if my _manner_</li>
<li class="L3979" rel="L3979">has been at all reprehensible, I here beg leave to apologise.”</li>
<li class="L3980" rel="L3980"></li>
<li class="L3981" rel="L3981"></li>
<li class="L3982" rel="L3982"></li>
<li class="L3983" rel="L3983">Chapter 21</li>
<li class="L3984" rel="L3984"></li>
<li class="L3985" rel="L3985"></li>
<li class="L3986" rel="L3986">The discussion of Mr. Collins&#39;s offer was now nearly at an end, and</li>
<li class="L3987" rel="L3987">Elizabeth had only to suffer from the uncomfortable feelings necessarily</li>
<li class="L3988" rel="L3988">attending it, and occasionally from some peevish allusions of her</li>
<li class="L3989" rel="L3989">mother. As for the gentleman himself, _his_ feelings were chiefly</li>
<li class="L3990" rel="L3990">expressed, not by embarrassment or dejection, or by trying to avoid her,</li>
<li class="L3991" rel="L3991">but by stiffness of manner and resentful silence. He scarcely ever spoke</li>
<li class="L3992" rel="L3992">to her, and the assiduous attentions which he had been so sensible of</li>
<li class="L3993" rel="L3993">himself were transferred for the rest of the day to Miss Lucas, whose</li>
<li class="L3994" rel="L3994">civility in listening to him was a seasonable relief to them all, and</li>
<li class="L3995" rel="L3995">especially to her friend.</li>
<li class="L3996" rel="L3996"></li>
<li class="L3997" rel="L3997">The morrow produced no abatement of Mrs. Bennet&#39;s ill-humour or ill</li>
<li class="L3998" rel="L3998">health. Mr. Collins was also in the same state of angry pride. Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L3999" rel="L3999">had hoped that his resentment might shorten his visit, but his plan did</li>
<li class="L4000" rel="L4000">not appear in the least affected by it. He was always to have gone on</li>
<li class="L4001" rel="L4001">Saturday, and to Saturday he meant to stay.</li>
<li class="L4002" rel="L4002"></li>
<li class="L4003" rel="L4003">After breakfast, the girls walked to Meryton to inquire if Mr. Wickham</li>
<li class="L4004" rel="L4004">were returned, and to lament over his absence from the Netherfield ball.</li>
<li class="L4005" rel="L4005">He joined them on their entering the town, and attended them to their</li>
<li class="L4006" rel="L4006">aunt&#39;s where his regret and vexation, and the concern of everybody, was</li>
<li class="L4007" rel="L4007">well talked over. To Elizabeth, however, he voluntarily acknowledged</li>
<li class="L4008" rel="L4008">that the necessity of his absence _had_ been self-imposed.</li>
<li class="L4009" rel="L4009"></li>
<li class="L4010" rel="L4010">“I found,” said he, “as the time drew near that I had better not meet</li>
<li class="L4011" rel="L4011">Mr. Darcy; that to be in the same room, the same party with him for so</li>
<li class="L4012" rel="L4012">many hours together, might be more than I could bear, and that scenes</li>
<li class="L4013" rel="L4013">might arise unpleasant to more than myself.”</li>
<li class="L4014" rel="L4014"></li>
<li class="L4015" rel="L4015">She highly approved his forbearance, and they had leisure for a full</li>
<li class="L4016" rel="L4016">discussion of it, and for all the commendation which they civilly</li>
<li class="L4017" rel="L4017">bestowed on each other, as Wickham and another officer walked back with</li>
<li class="L4018" rel="L4018">them to Longbourn, and during the walk he particularly attended to</li>
<li class="L4019" rel="L4019">her. His accompanying them was a double advantage; she felt all the</li>
<li class="L4020" rel="L4020">compliment it offered to herself, and it was most acceptable as an</li>
<li class="L4021" rel="L4021">occasion of introducing him to her father and mother.</li>
<li class="L4022" rel="L4022"></li>
<li class="L4023" rel="L4023">Soon after their return, a letter was delivered to Miss Bennet; it came</li>
<li class="L4024" rel="L4024">from Netherfield. The envelope contained a sheet of elegant, little,</li>
<li class="L4025" rel="L4025">hot-pressed paper, well covered with a lady&#39;s fair, flowing hand; and</li>
<li class="L4026" rel="L4026">Elizabeth saw her sister&#39;s countenance change as she read it, and saw</li>
<li class="L4027" rel="L4027">her dwelling intently on some particular passages. Jane recollected</li>
<li class="L4028" rel="L4028">herself soon, and putting the letter away, tried to join with her usual</li>
<li class="L4029" rel="L4029">cheerfulness in the general conversation; but Elizabeth felt an anxiety</li>
<li class="L4030" rel="L4030">on the subject which drew off her attention even from Wickham; and no</li>
<li class="L4031" rel="L4031">sooner had he and his companion taken leave, than a glance from Jane</li>
<li class="L4032" rel="L4032">invited her to follow her up stairs. When they had gained their own room,</li>
<li class="L4033" rel="L4033">Jane, taking out the letter, said:</li>
<li class="L4034" rel="L4034"></li>
<li class="L4035" rel="L4035">“This is from Caroline Bingley; what it contains has surprised me a good</li>
<li class="L4036" rel="L4036">deal. The whole party have left Netherfield by this time, and are on</li>
<li class="L4037" rel="L4037">their way to town--and without any intention of coming back again. You</li>
<li class="L4038" rel="L4038">shall hear what she says.”</li>
<li class="L4039" rel="L4039"></li>
<li class="L4040" rel="L4040">She then read the first sentence aloud, which comprised the information</li>
<li class="L4041" rel="L4041">of their having just resolved to follow their brother to town directly,</li>
<li class="L4042" rel="L4042">and of their meaning to dine in Grosvenor Street, where Mr. Hurst had a</li>
<li class="L4043" rel="L4043">house. The next was in these words: “I do not pretend to regret anything</li>
<li class="L4044" rel="L4044">I shall leave in Hertfordshire, except your society, my dearest friend;</li>
<li class="L4045" rel="L4045">but we will hope, at some future period, to enjoy many returns of that</li>
<li class="L4046" rel="L4046">delightful intercourse we have known, and in the meanwhile may</li>
<li class="L4047" rel="L4047">lessen the pain of separation by a very frequent and most unreserved</li>
<li class="L4048" rel="L4048">correspondence. I depend on you for that.” To these highflown</li>
<li class="L4049" rel="L4049">expressions Elizabeth listened with all the insensibility of distrust;</li>
<li class="L4050" rel="L4050">and though the suddenness of their removal surprised her, she saw</li>
<li class="L4051" rel="L4051">nothing in it really to lament; it was not to be supposed that their</li>
<li class="L4052" rel="L4052">absence from Netherfield would prevent Mr. Bingley&#39;s being there; and as</li>
<li class="L4053" rel="L4053">to the loss of their society, she was persuaded that Jane must cease to</li>
<li class="L4054" rel="L4054">regard it, in the enjoyment of his.</li>
<li class="L4055" rel="L4055"></li>
<li class="L4056" rel="L4056">“It is unlucky,” said she, after a short pause, “that you should not be</li>
<li class="L4057" rel="L4057">able to see your friends before they leave the country. But may we not</li>
<li class="L4058" rel="L4058">hope that the period of future happiness to which Miss Bingley looks</li>
<li class="L4059" rel="L4059">forward may arrive earlier than she is aware, and that the delightful</li>
<li class="L4060" rel="L4060">intercourse you have known as friends will be renewed with yet greater</li>
<li class="L4061" rel="L4061">satisfaction as sisters? Mr. Bingley will not be detained in London by</li>
<li class="L4062" rel="L4062">them.”</li>
<li class="L4063" rel="L4063"></li>
<li class="L4064" rel="L4064">“Caroline decidedly says that none of the party will return into</li>
<li class="L4065" rel="L4065">Hertfordshire this winter. I will read it to you:”</li>
<li class="L4066" rel="L4066"></li>
<li class="L4067" rel="L4067">“When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the business which</li>
<li class="L4068" rel="L4068">took him to London might be concluded in three or four days; but as we</li>
<li class="L4069" rel="L4069">are certain it cannot be so, and at the same time convinced that when</li>
<li class="L4070" rel="L4070">Charles gets to town he will be in no hurry to leave it again, we have</li>
<li class="L4071" rel="L4071">determined on following him thither, that he may not be obliged to spend</li>
<li class="L4072" rel="L4072">his vacant hours in a comfortless hotel. Many of my acquaintances are</li>
<li class="L4073" rel="L4073">already there for the winter; I wish that I could hear that you, my</li>
<li class="L4074" rel="L4074">dearest friend, had any intention of making one of the crowd--but of</li>
<li class="L4075" rel="L4075">that I despair. I sincerely hope your Christmas in Hertfordshire may</li>
<li class="L4076" rel="L4076">abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings, and that your</li>
<li class="L4077" rel="L4077">beaux will be so numerous as to prevent your feeling the loss of the</li>
<li class="L4078" rel="L4078">three of whom we shall deprive you.”</li>
<li class="L4079" rel="L4079"></li>
<li class="L4080" rel="L4080">“It is evident by this,” added Jane, “that he comes back no more this</li>
<li class="L4081" rel="L4081">winter.”</li>
<li class="L4082" rel="L4082"></li>
<li class="L4083" rel="L4083">“It is only evident that Miss Bingley does not mean that he _should_.”</li>
<li class="L4084" rel="L4084"></li>
<li class="L4085" rel="L4085">“Why will you think so? It must be his own doing. He is his own</li>
<li class="L4086" rel="L4086">master. But you do not know _all_. I _will_ read you the passage which</li>
<li class="L4087" rel="L4087">particularly hurts me. I will have no reserves from _you_.”</li>
<li class="L4088" rel="L4088"></li>
<li class="L4089" rel="L4089">“Mr. Darcy is impatient to see his sister; and, to confess the truth,</li>
<li class="L4090" rel="L4090">_we_ are scarcely less eager to meet her again. I really do not think</li>
<li class="L4091" rel="L4091">Georgiana Darcy has her equal for beauty, elegance, and accomplishments;</li>
<li class="L4092" rel="L4092">and the affection she inspires in Louisa and myself is heightened into</li>
<li class="L4093" rel="L4093">something still more interesting, from the hope we dare entertain of</li>
<li class="L4094" rel="L4094">her being hereafter our sister. I do not know whether I ever before</li>
<li class="L4095" rel="L4095">mentioned to you my feelings on this subject; but I will not leave the</li>
<li class="L4096" rel="L4096">country without confiding them, and I trust you will not esteem them</li>
<li class="L4097" rel="L4097">unreasonable. My brother admires her greatly already; he will have</li>
<li class="L4098" rel="L4098">frequent opportunity now of seeing her on the most intimate footing;</li>
<li class="L4099" rel="L4099">her relations all wish the connection as much as his own; and a sister&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4100" rel="L4100">partiality is not misleading me, I think, when I call Charles most</li>
<li class="L4101" rel="L4101">capable of engaging any woman&#39;s heart. With all these circumstances to</li>
<li class="L4102" rel="L4102">favour an attachment, and nothing to prevent it, am I wrong, my dearest</li>
<li class="L4103" rel="L4103">Jane, in indulging the hope of an event which will secure the happiness</li>
<li class="L4104" rel="L4104">of so many?”</li>
<li class="L4105" rel="L4105"></li>
<li class="L4106" rel="L4106">“What do you think of _this_ sentence, my dear Lizzy?” said Jane as she</li>
<li class="L4107" rel="L4107">finished it. “Is it not clear enough? Does it not expressly declare that</li>
<li class="L4108" rel="L4108">Caroline neither expects nor wishes me to be her sister; that she is</li>
<li class="L4109" rel="L4109">perfectly convinced of her brother&#39;s indifference; and that if she</li>
<li class="L4110" rel="L4110">suspects the nature of my feelings for him, she means (most kindly!) to</li>
<li class="L4111" rel="L4111">put me on my guard? Can there be any other opinion on the subject?”</li>
<li class="L4112" rel="L4112"></li>
<li class="L4113" rel="L4113">“Yes, there can; for mine is totally different. Will you hear it?”</li>
<li class="L4114" rel="L4114"></li>
<li class="L4115" rel="L4115">“Most willingly.”</li>
<li class="L4116" rel="L4116"></li>
<li class="L4117" rel="L4117">“You shall have it in a few words. Miss Bingley sees that her brother is</li>
<li class="L4118" rel="L4118">in love with you, and wants him to marry Miss Darcy. She follows him</li>
<li class="L4119" rel="L4119">to town in hope of keeping him there, and tries to persuade you that he</li>
<li class="L4120" rel="L4120">does not care about you.”</li>
<li class="L4121" rel="L4121"></li>
<li class="L4122" rel="L4122">Jane shook her head.</li>
<li class="L4123" rel="L4123"></li>
<li class="L4124" rel="L4124">“Indeed, Jane, you ought to believe me. No one who has ever seen you</li>
<li class="L4125" rel="L4125">together can doubt his affection. Miss Bingley, I am sure, cannot. She</li>
<li class="L4126" rel="L4126">is not such a simpleton. Could she have seen half as much love in Mr.</li>
<li class="L4127" rel="L4127">Darcy for herself, she would have ordered her wedding clothes. But the</li>
<li class="L4128" rel="L4128">case is this: We are not rich enough or grand enough for them; and she</li>
<li class="L4129" rel="L4129">is the more anxious to get Miss Darcy for her brother, from the notion</li>
<li class="L4130" rel="L4130">that when there has been _one_ intermarriage, she may have less trouble</li>
<li class="L4131" rel="L4131">in achieving a second; in which there is certainly some ingenuity, and</li>
<li class="L4132" rel="L4132">I dare say it would succeed, if Miss de Bourgh were out of the way. But,</li>
<li class="L4133" rel="L4133">my dearest Jane, you cannot seriously imagine that because Miss Bingley</li>
<li class="L4134" rel="L4134">tells you her brother greatly admires Miss Darcy, he is in the smallest</li>
<li class="L4135" rel="L4135">degree less sensible of _your_ merit than when he took leave of you on</li>
<li class="L4136" rel="L4136">Tuesday, or that it will be in her power to persuade him that, instead</li>
<li class="L4137" rel="L4137">of being in love with you, he is very much in love with her friend.”</li>
<li class="L4138" rel="L4138"></li>
<li class="L4139" rel="L4139">“If we thought alike of Miss Bingley,” replied Jane, “your</li>
<li class="L4140" rel="L4140">representation of all this might make me quite easy. But I know the</li>
<li class="L4141" rel="L4141">foundation is unjust. Caroline is incapable of wilfully deceiving</li>
<li class="L4142" rel="L4142">anyone; and all that I can hope in this case is that she is deceiving</li>
<li class="L4143" rel="L4143">herself.”</li>
<li class="L4144" rel="L4144"></li>
<li class="L4145" rel="L4145">“That is right. You could not have started a more happy idea, since you</li>
<li class="L4146" rel="L4146">will not take comfort in mine. Believe her to be deceived, by all means.</li>
<li class="L4147" rel="L4147">You have now done your duty by her, and must fret no longer.”</li>
<li class="L4148" rel="L4148"></li>
<li class="L4149" rel="L4149">“But, my dear sister, can I be happy, even supposing the best, in</li>
<li class="L4150" rel="L4150">accepting a man whose sisters and friends are all wishing him to marry</li>
<li class="L4151" rel="L4151">elsewhere?”</li>
<li class="L4152" rel="L4152"></li>
<li class="L4153" rel="L4153">“You must decide for yourself,” said Elizabeth; “and if, upon mature</li>
<li class="L4154" rel="L4154">deliberation, you find that the misery of disobliging his two sisters is</li>
<li class="L4155" rel="L4155">more than equivalent to the happiness of being his wife, I advise you by</li>
<li class="L4156" rel="L4156">all means to refuse him.”</li>
<li class="L4157" rel="L4157"></li>
<li class="L4158" rel="L4158">“How can you talk so?” said Jane, faintly smiling. “You must know that</li>
<li class="L4159" rel="L4159">though I should be exceedingly grieved at their disapprobation, I could</li>
<li class="L4160" rel="L4160">not hesitate.”</li>
<li class="L4161" rel="L4161"></li>
<li class="L4162" rel="L4162">“I did not think you would; and that being the case, I cannot consider</li>
<li class="L4163" rel="L4163">your situation with much compassion.”</li>
<li class="L4164" rel="L4164"></li>
<li class="L4165" rel="L4165">“But if he returns no more this winter, my choice will never be</li>
<li class="L4166" rel="L4166">required. A thousand things may arise in six months!”</li>
<li class="L4167" rel="L4167"></li>
<li class="L4168" rel="L4168">The idea of his returning no more Elizabeth treated with the utmost</li>
<li class="L4169" rel="L4169">contempt. It appeared to her merely the suggestion of Caroline&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4170" rel="L4170">interested wishes, and she could not for a moment suppose that those</li>
<li class="L4171" rel="L4171">wishes, however openly or artfully spoken, could influence a young man</li>
<li class="L4172" rel="L4172">so totally independent of everyone.</li>
<li class="L4173" rel="L4173"></li>
<li class="L4174" rel="L4174">She represented to her sister as forcibly as possible what she felt</li>
<li class="L4175" rel="L4175">on the subject, and had soon the pleasure of seeing its happy effect.</li>
<li class="L4176" rel="L4176">Jane&#39;s temper was not desponding, and she was gradually led to hope,</li>
<li class="L4177" rel="L4177">though the diffidence of affection sometimes overcame the hope, that</li>
<li class="L4178" rel="L4178">Bingley would return to Netherfield and answer every wish of her heart.</li>
<li class="L4179" rel="L4179"></li>
<li class="L4180" rel="L4180">They agreed that Mrs. Bennet should only hear of the departure of the</li>
<li class="L4181" rel="L4181">family, without being alarmed on the score of the gentleman&#39;s conduct;</li>
<li class="L4182" rel="L4182">but even this partial communication gave her a great deal of concern,</li>
<li class="L4183" rel="L4183">and she bewailed it as exceedingly unlucky that the ladies should happen</li>
<li class="L4184" rel="L4184">to go away just as they were all getting so intimate together. After</li>
<li class="L4185" rel="L4185">lamenting it, however, at some length, she had the consolation that Mr.</li>
<li class="L4186" rel="L4186">Bingley would be soon down again and soon dining at Longbourn, and the</li>
<li class="L4187" rel="L4187">conclusion of all was the comfortable declaration, that though he had</li>
<li class="L4188" rel="L4188">been invited only to a family dinner, she would take care to have two</li>
<li class="L4189" rel="L4189">full courses.</li>
<li class="L4190" rel="L4190"></li>
<li class="L4191" rel="L4191"></li>
<li class="L4192" rel="L4192"></li>
<li class="L4193" rel="L4193">Chapter 22</li>
<li class="L4194" rel="L4194"></li>
<li class="L4195" rel="L4195"></li>
<li class="L4196" rel="L4196">The Bennets were engaged to dine with the Lucases and again during the</li>
<li class="L4197" rel="L4197">chief of the day was Miss Lucas so kind as to listen to Mr. Collins.</li>
<li class="L4198" rel="L4198">Elizabeth took an opportunity of thanking her. “It keeps him in good</li>
<li class="L4199" rel="L4199">humour,” said she, “and I am more obliged to you than I can express.”</li>
<li class="L4200" rel="L4200"> Charlotte assured her friend of her satisfaction in being useful, and</li>
<li class="L4201" rel="L4201">that it amply repaid her for the little sacrifice of her time. This was</li>
<li class="L4202" rel="L4202">very amiable, but Charlotte&#39;s kindness extended farther than Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L4203" rel="L4203">had any conception of; its object was nothing else than to secure her</li>
<li class="L4204" rel="L4204">from any return of Mr. Collins&#39;s addresses, by engaging them towards</li>
<li class="L4205" rel="L4205">herself. Such was Miss Lucas&#39;s scheme; and appearances were so</li>
<li class="L4206" rel="L4206">favourable, that when they parted at night, she would have felt almost</li>
<li class="L4207" rel="L4207">secure of success if he had not been to leave Hertfordshire so very</li>
<li class="L4208" rel="L4208">soon. But here she did injustice to the fire and independence of his</li>
<li class="L4209" rel="L4209">character, for it led him to escape out of Longbourn House the next</li>
<li class="L4210" rel="L4210">morning with admirable slyness, and hasten to Lucas Lodge to throw</li>
<li class="L4211" rel="L4211">himself at her feet. He was anxious to avoid the notice of his cousins,</li>
<li class="L4212" rel="L4212">from a conviction that if they saw him depart, they could not fail to</li>
<li class="L4213" rel="L4213">conjecture his design, and he was not willing to have the attempt known</li>
<li class="L4214" rel="L4214">till its success might be known likewise; for though feeling almost</li>
<li class="L4215" rel="L4215">secure, and with reason, for Charlotte had been tolerably encouraging,</li>
<li class="L4216" rel="L4216">he was comparatively diffident since the adventure of Wednesday.</li>
<li class="L4217" rel="L4217">His reception, however, was of the most flattering kind. Miss Lucas</li>
<li class="L4218" rel="L4218">perceived him from an upper window as he walked towards the house, and</li>
<li class="L4219" rel="L4219">instantly set out to meet him accidentally in the lane. But little had</li>
<li class="L4220" rel="L4220">she dared to hope that so much love and eloquence awaited her there.</li>
<li class="L4221" rel="L4221"></li>
<li class="L4222" rel="L4222">In as short a time as Mr. Collins&#39;s long speeches would allow,</li>
<li class="L4223" rel="L4223">everything was settled between them to the satisfaction of both; and as</li>
<li class="L4224" rel="L4224">they entered the house he earnestly entreated her to name the day that</li>
<li class="L4225" rel="L4225">was to make him the happiest of men; and though such a solicitation must</li>
<li class="L4226" rel="L4226">be waived for the present, the lady felt no inclination to trifle with</li>
<li class="L4227" rel="L4227">his happiness. The stupidity with which he was favoured by nature must</li>
<li class="L4228" rel="L4228">guard his courtship from any charm that could make a woman wish for its</li>
<li class="L4229" rel="L4229">continuance; and Miss Lucas, who accepted him solely from the pure</li>
<li class="L4230" rel="L4230">and disinterested desire of an establishment, cared not how soon that</li>
<li class="L4231" rel="L4231">establishment were gained.</li>
<li class="L4232" rel="L4232"></li>
<li class="L4233" rel="L4233">Sir William and Lady Lucas were speedily applied to for their consent;</li>
<li class="L4234" rel="L4234">and it was bestowed with a most joyful alacrity. Mr. Collins&#39;s present</li>
<li class="L4235" rel="L4235">circumstances made it a most eligible match for their daughter, to whom</li>
<li class="L4236" rel="L4236">they could give little fortune; and his prospects of future wealth were</li>
<li class="L4237" rel="L4237">exceedingly fair. Lady Lucas began directly to calculate, with more</li>
<li class="L4238" rel="L4238">interest than the matter had ever excited before, how many years longer</li>
<li class="L4239" rel="L4239">Mr. Bennet was likely to live; and Sir William gave it as his decided</li>
<li class="L4240" rel="L4240">opinion, that whenever Mr. Collins should be in possession of the</li>
<li class="L4241" rel="L4241">Longbourn estate, it would be highly expedient that both he and his wife</li>
<li class="L4242" rel="L4242">should make their appearance at St. James&#39;s. The whole family, in short,</li>
<li class="L4243" rel="L4243">were properly overjoyed on the occasion. The younger girls formed hopes</li>
<li class="L4244" rel="L4244">of _coming out_ a year or two sooner than they might otherwise have</li>
<li class="L4245" rel="L4245">done; and the boys were relieved from their apprehension of Charlotte&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4246" rel="L4246">dying an old maid. Charlotte herself was tolerably composed. She had</li>
<li class="L4247" rel="L4247">gained her point, and had time to consider of it. Her reflections were</li>
<li class="L4248" rel="L4248">in general satisfactory. Mr. Collins, to be sure, was neither sensible</li>
<li class="L4249" rel="L4249">nor agreeable; his society was irksome, and his attachment to her must</li>
<li class="L4250" rel="L4250">be imaginary. But still he would be her husband. Without thinking highly</li>
<li class="L4251" rel="L4251">either of men or matrimony, marriage had always been her object; it was</li>
<li class="L4252" rel="L4252">the only provision for well-educated young women of small fortune,</li>
<li class="L4253" rel="L4253">and however uncertain of giving happiness, must be their pleasantest</li>
<li class="L4254" rel="L4254">preservative from want. This preservative she had now obtained; and at</li>
<li class="L4255" rel="L4255">the age of twenty-seven, without having ever been handsome, she felt all</li>
<li class="L4256" rel="L4256">the good luck of it. The least agreeable circumstance in the business</li>
<li class="L4257" rel="L4257">was the surprise it must occasion to Elizabeth Bennet, whose friendship</li>
<li class="L4258" rel="L4258">she valued beyond that of any other person. Elizabeth would wonder,</li>
<li class="L4259" rel="L4259">and probably would blame her; and though her resolution was not to be</li>
<li class="L4260" rel="L4260">shaken, her feelings must be hurt by such a disapprobation. She resolved</li>
<li class="L4261" rel="L4261">to give her the information herself, and therefore charged Mr. Collins,</li>
<li class="L4262" rel="L4262">when he returned to Longbourn to dinner, to drop no hint of what had</li>
<li class="L4263" rel="L4263">passed before any of the family. A promise of secrecy was of course very</li>
<li class="L4264" rel="L4264">dutifully given, but it could not be kept without difficulty; for the</li>
<li class="L4265" rel="L4265">curiosity excited by his long absence burst forth in such very direct</li>
<li class="L4266" rel="L4266">questions on his return as required some ingenuity to evade, and he was</li>
<li class="L4267" rel="L4267">at the same time exercising great self-denial, for he was longing to</li>
<li class="L4268" rel="L4268">publish his prosperous love.</li>
<li class="L4269" rel="L4269"></li>
<li class="L4270" rel="L4270">As he was to begin his journey too early on the morrow to see any of the</li>
<li class="L4271" rel="L4271">family, the ceremony of leave-taking was performed when the ladies moved</li>
<li class="L4272" rel="L4272">for the night; and Mrs. Bennet, with great politeness and cordiality,</li>
<li class="L4273" rel="L4273">said how happy they should be to see him at Longbourn again, whenever</li>
<li class="L4274" rel="L4274">his engagements might allow him to visit them.</li>
<li class="L4275" rel="L4275"></li>
<li class="L4276" rel="L4276">“My dear madam,” he replied, “this invitation is particularly</li>
<li class="L4277" rel="L4277">gratifying, because it is what I have been hoping to receive; and</li>
<li class="L4278" rel="L4278">you may be very certain that I shall avail myself of it as soon as</li>
<li class="L4279" rel="L4279">possible.”</li>
<li class="L4280" rel="L4280"></li>
<li class="L4281" rel="L4281">They were all astonished; and Mr. Bennet, who could by no means wish for</li>
<li class="L4282" rel="L4282">so speedy a return, immediately said:</li>
<li class="L4283" rel="L4283"></li>
<li class="L4284" rel="L4284">“But is there not danger of Lady Catherine&#39;s disapprobation here, my</li>
<li class="L4285" rel="L4285">good sir? You had better neglect your relations than run the risk of</li>
<li class="L4286" rel="L4286">offending your patroness.”</li>
<li class="L4287" rel="L4287"></li>
<li class="L4288" rel="L4288">“My dear sir,” replied Mr. Collins, “I am particularly obliged to you</li>
<li class="L4289" rel="L4289">for this friendly caution, and you may depend upon my not taking so</li>
<li class="L4290" rel="L4290">material a step without her ladyship&#39;s concurrence.”</li>
<li class="L4291" rel="L4291"></li>
<li class="L4292" rel="L4292">“You cannot be too much upon your guard. Risk anything rather than her</li>
<li class="L4293" rel="L4293">displeasure; and if you find it likely to be raised by your coming to us</li>
<li class="L4294" rel="L4294">again, which I should think exceedingly probable, stay quietly at home,</li>
<li class="L4295" rel="L4295">and be satisfied that _we_ shall take no offence.”</li>
<li class="L4296" rel="L4296"></li>
<li class="L4297" rel="L4297">“Believe me, my dear sir, my gratitude is warmly excited by such</li>
<li class="L4298" rel="L4298">affectionate attention; and depend upon it, you will speedily receive</li>
<li class="L4299" rel="L4299">from me a letter of thanks for this, and for every other mark of your</li>
<li class="L4300" rel="L4300">regard during my stay in Hertfordshire. As for my fair cousins, though</li>
<li class="L4301" rel="L4301">my absence may not be long enough to render it necessary, I shall now</li>
<li class="L4302" rel="L4302">take the liberty of wishing them health and happiness, not excepting my</li>
<li class="L4303" rel="L4303">cousin Elizabeth.”</li>
<li class="L4304" rel="L4304"></li>
<li class="L4305" rel="L4305">With proper civilities the ladies then withdrew; all of them equally</li>
<li class="L4306" rel="L4306">surprised that he meditated a quick return. Mrs. Bennet wished to</li>
<li class="L4307" rel="L4307">understand by it that he thought of paying his addresses to one of her</li>
<li class="L4308" rel="L4308">younger girls, and Mary might have been prevailed on to accept him.</li>
<li class="L4309" rel="L4309">She rated his abilities much higher than any of the others; there was</li>
<li class="L4310" rel="L4310">a solidity in his reflections which often struck her, and though by no</li>
<li class="L4311" rel="L4311">means so clever as herself, she thought that if encouraged to read</li>
<li class="L4312" rel="L4312">and improve himself by such an example as hers, he might become a very</li>
<li class="L4313" rel="L4313">agreeable companion. But on the following morning, every hope of this</li>
<li class="L4314" rel="L4314">kind was done away. Miss Lucas called soon after breakfast, and in a</li>
<li class="L4315" rel="L4315">private conference with Elizabeth related the event of the day before.</li>
<li class="L4316" rel="L4316"></li>
<li class="L4317" rel="L4317">The possibility of Mr. Collins&#39;s fancying himself in love with her</li>
<li class="L4318" rel="L4318">friend had once occurred to Elizabeth within the last day or two; but</li>
<li class="L4319" rel="L4319">that Charlotte could encourage him seemed almost as far from</li>
<li class="L4320" rel="L4320">possibility as she could encourage him herself, and her astonishment was</li>
<li class="L4321" rel="L4321">consequently so great as to overcome at first the bounds of decorum, and</li>
<li class="L4322" rel="L4322">she could not help crying out:</li>
<li class="L4323" rel="L4323"></li>
<li class="L4324" rel="L4324">“Engaged to Mr. Collins! My dear Charlotte--impossible!”</li>
<li class="L4325" rel="L4325"></li>
<li class="L4326" rel="L4326">The steady countenance which Miss Lucas had commanded in telling her</li>
<li class="L4327" rel="L4327">story, gave way to a momentary confusion here on receiving so direct a</li>
<li class="L4328" rel="L4328">reproach; though, as it was no more than she expected, she soon regained</li>
<li class="L4329" rel="L4329">her composure, and calmly replied:</li>
<li class="L4330" rel="L4330"></li>
<li class="L4331" rel="L4331">“Why should you be surprised, my dear Eliza? Do you think it incredible</li>
<li class="L4332" rel="L4332">that Mr. Collins should be able to procure any woman&#39;s good opinion,</li>
<li class="L4333" rel="L4333">because he was not so happy as to succeed with you?”</li>
<li class="L4334" rel="L4334"></li>
<li class="L4335" rel="L4335">But Elizabeth had now recollected herself, and making a strong effort</li>
<li class="L4336" rel="L4336">for it, was able to assure with tolerable firmness that the prospect of</li>
<li class="L4337" rel="L4337">their relationship was highly grateful to her, and that she wished her</li>
<li class="L4338" rel="L4338">all imaginable happiness.</li>
<li class="L4339" rel="L4339"></li>
<li class="L4340" rel="L4340">“I see what you are feeling,” replied Charlotte. “You must be surprised,</li>
<li class="L4341" rel="L4341">very much surprised--so lately as Mr. Collins was wishing to marry</li>
<li class="L4342" rel="L4342">you. But when you have had time to think it over, I hope you will be</li>
<li class="L4343" rel="L4343">satisfied with what I have done. I am not romantic, you know; I never</li>
<li class="L4344" rel="L4344">was. I ask only a comfortable home; and considering Mr. Collins&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4345" rel="L4345">character, connection, and situation in life, I am convinced that my</li>
<li class="L4346" rel="L4346">chance of happiness with him is as fair as most people can boast on</li>
<li class="L4347" rel="L4347">entering the marriage state.”</li>
<li class="L4348" rel="L4348"></li>
<li class="L4349" rel="L4349">Elizabeth quietly answered “Undoubtedly;” and after an awkward pause,</li>
<li class="L4350" rel="L4350">they returned to the rest of the family. Charlotte did not stay much</li>
<li class="L4351" rel="L4351">longer, and Elizabeth was then left to reflect on what she had heard.</li>
<li class="L4352" rel="L4352">It was a long time before she became at all reconciled to the idea of so</li>
<li class="L4353" rel="L4353">unsuitable a match. The strangeness of Mr. Collins&#39;s making two offers</li>
<li class="L4354" rel="L4354">of marriage within three days was nothing in comparison of his being now</li>
<li class="L4355" rel="L4355">accepted. She had always felt that Charlotte&#39;s opinion of matrimony was</li>
<li class="L4356" rel="L4356">not exactly like her own, but she had not supposed it to be possible</li>
<li class="L4357" rel="L4357">that, when called into action, she would have sacrificed every better</li>
<li class="L4358" rel="L4358">feeling to worldly advantage. Charlotte the wife of Mr. Collins was a</li>
<li class="L4359" rel="L4359">most humiliating picture! And to the pang of a friend disgracing herself</li>
<li class="L4360" rel="L4360">and sunk in her esteem, was added the distressing conviction that it</li>
<li class="L4361" rel="L4361">was impossible for that friend to be tolerably happy in the lot she had</li>
<li class="L4362" rel="L4362">chosen.</li>
<li class="L4363" rel="L4363"></li>
<li class="L4364" rel="L4364"></li>
<li class="L4365" rel="L4365"></li>
<li class="L4366" rel="L4366">Chapter 23</li>
<li class="L4367" rel="L4367"></li>
<li class="L4368" rel="L4368"></li>
<li class="L4369" rel="L4369">Elizabeth was sitting with her mother and sisters, reflecting on what</li>
<li class="L4370" rel="L4370">she had heard, and doubting whether she was authorised to mention</li>
<li class="L4371" rel="L4371">it, when Sir William Lucas himself appeared, sent by his daughter, to</li>
<li class="L4372" rel="L4372">announce her engagement to the family. With many compliments to them,</li>
<li class="L4373" rel="L4373">and much self-gratulation on the prospect of a connection between the</li>
<li class="L4374" rel="L4374">houses, he unfolded the matter--to an audience not merely wondering, but</li>
<li class="L4375" rel="L4375">incredulous; for Mrs. Bennet, with more perseverance than politeness,</li>
<li class="L4376" rel="L4376">protested he must be entirely mistaken; and Lydia, always unguarded and</li>
<li class="L4377" rel="L4377">often uncivil, boisterously exclaimed:</li>
<li class="L4378" rel="L4378"></li>
<li class="L4379" rel="L4379">“Good Lord! Sir William, how can you tell such a story? Do not you know</li>
<li class="L4380" rel="L4380">that Mr. Collins wants to marry Lizzy?”</li>
<li class="L4381" rel="L4381"></li>
<li class="L4382" rel="L4382">Nothing less than the complaisance of a courtier could have borne</li>
<li class="L4383" rel="L4383">without anger such treatment; but Sir William&#39;s good breeding carried</li>
<li class="L4384" rel="L4384">him through it all; and though he begged leave to be positive as to the</li>
<li class="L4385" rel="L4385">truth of his information, he listened to all their impertinence with the</li>
<li class="L4386" rel="L4386">most forbearing courtesy.</li>
<li class="L4387" rel="L4387"></li>
<li class="L4388" rel="L4388">Elizabeth, feeling it incumbent on her to relieve him from so unpleasant</li>
<li class="L4389" rel="L4389">a situation, now put herself forward to confirm his account, by</li>
<li class="L4390" rel="L4390">mentioning her prior knowledge of it from Charlotte herself; and</li>
<li class="L4391" rel="L4391">endeavoured to put a stop to the exclamations of her mother and sisters</li>
<li class="L4392" rel="L4392">by the earnestness of her congratulations to Sir William, in which she</li>
<li class="L4393" rel="L4393">was readily joined by Jane, and by making a variety of remarks on the</li>
<li class="L4394" rel="L4394">happiness that might be expected from the match, the excellent character</li>
<li class="L4395" rel="L4395">of Mr. Collins, and the convenient distance of Hunsford from London.</li>
<li class="L4396" rel="L4396"></li>
<li class="L4397" rel="L4397">Mrs. Bennet was in fact too much overpowered to say a great deal while</li>
<li class="L4398" rel="L4398">Sir William remained; but no sooner had he left them than her feelings</li>
<li class="L4399" rel="L4399">found a rapid vent. In the first place, she persisted in disbelieving</li>
<li class="L4400" rel="L4400">the whole of the matter; secondly, she was very sure that Mr. Collins</li>
<li class="L4401" rel="L4401">had been taken in; thirdly, she trusted that they would never be</li>
<li class="L4402" rel="L4402">happy together; and fourthly, that the match might be broken off. Two</li>
<li class="L4403" rel="L4403">inferences, however, were plainly deduced from the whole: one, that</li>
<li class="L4404" rel="L4404">Elizabeth was the real cause of the mischief; and the other that she</li>
<li class="L4405" rel="L4405">herself had been barbarously misused by them all; and on these two</li>
<li class="L4406" rel="L4406">points she principally dwelt during the rest of the day. Nothing could</li>
<li class="L4407" rel="L4407">console and nothing could appease her. Nor did that day wear out her</li>
<li class="L4408" rel="L4408">resentment. A week elapsed before she could see Elizabeth without</li>
<li class="L4409" rel="L4409">scolding her, a month passed away before she could speak to Sir William</li>
<li class="L4410" rel="L4410">or Lady Lucas without being rude, and many months were gone before she</li>
<li class="L4411" rel="L4411">could at all forgive their daughter.</li>
<li class="L4412" rel="L4412"></li>
<li class="L4413" rel="L4413">Mr. Bennet&#39;s emotions were much more tranquil on the occasion, and such</li>
<li class="L4414" rel="L4414">as he did experience he pronounced to be of a most agreeable sort; for</li>
<li class="L4415" rel="L4415">it gratified him, he said, to discover that Charlotte Lucas, whom he had</li>
<li class="L4416" rel="L4416">been used to think tolerably sensible, was as foolish as his wife, and</li>
<li class="L4417" rel="L4417">more foolish than his daughter!</li>
<li class="L4418" rel="L4418"></li>
<li class="L4419" rel="L4419">Jane confessed herself a little surprised at the match; but she said</li>
<li class="L4420" rel="L4420">less of her astonishment than of her earnest desire for their happiness;</li>
<li class="L4421" rel="L4421">nor could Elizabeth persuade her to consider it as improbable. Kitty</li>
<li class="L4422" rel="L4422">and Lydia were far from envying Miss Lucas, for Mr. Collins was only a</li>
<li class="L4423" rel="L4423">clergyman; and it affected them in no other way than as a piece of news</li>
<li class="L4424" rel="L4424">to spread at Meryton.</li>
<li class="L4425" rel="L4425"></li>
<li class="L4426" rel="L4426">Lady Lucas could not be insensible of triumph on being able to retort</li>
<li class="L4427" rel="L4427">on Mrs. Bennet the comfort of having a daughter well married; and she</li>
<li class="L4428" rel="L4428">called at Longbourn rather oftener than usual to say how happy she was,</li>
<li class="L4429" rel="L4429">though Mrs. Bennet&#39;s sour looks and ill-natured remarks might have been</li>
<li class="L4430" rel="L4430">enough to drive happiness away.</li>
<li class="L4431" rel="L4431"></li>
<li class="L4432" rel="L4432">Between Elizabeth and Charlotte there was a restraint which kept them</li>
<li class="L4433" rel="L4433">mutually silent on the subject; and Elizabeth felt persuaded that</li>
<li class="L4434" rel="L4434">no real confidence could ever subsist between them again. Her</li>
<li class="L4435" rel="L4435">disappointment in Charlotte made her turn with fonder regard to her</li>
<li class="L4436" rel="L4436">sister, of whose rectitude and delicacy she was sure her opinion could</li>
<li class="L4437" rel="L4437">never be shaken, and for whose happiness she grew daily more anxious,</li>
<li class="L4438" rel="L4438">as Bingley had now been gone a week and nothing more was heard of his</li>
<li class="L4439" rel="L4439">return.</li>
<li class="L4440" rel="L4440"></li>
<li class="L4441" rel="L4441">Jane had sent Caroline an early answer to her letter, and was counting</li>
<li class="L4442" rel="L4442">the days till she might reasonably hope to hear again. The promised</li>
<li class="L4443" rel="L4443">letter of thanks from Mr. Collins arrived on Tuesday, addressed to</li>
<li class="L4444" rel="L4444">their father, and written with all the solemnity of gratitude which a</li>
<li class="L4445" rel="L4445">twelvemonth&#39;s abode in the family might have prompted. After discharging</li>
<li class="L4446" rel="L4446">his conscience on that head, he proceeded to inform them, with many</li>
<li class="L4447" rel="L4447">rapturous expressions, of his happiness in having obtained the affection</li>
<li class="L4448" rel="L4448">of their amiable neighbour, Miss Lucas, and then explained that it was</li>
<li class="L4449" rel="L4449">merely with the view of enjoying her society that he had been so ready</li>
<li class="L4450" rel="L4450">to close with their kind wish of seeing him again at Longbourn, whither</li>
<li class="L4451" rel="L4451">he hoped to be able to return on Monday fortnight; for Lady Catherine,</li>
<li class="L4452" rel="L4452">he added, so heartily approved his marriage, that she wished it to take</li>
<li class="L4453" rel="L4453">place as soon as possible, which he trusted would be an unanswerable</li>
<li class="L4454" rel="L4454">argument with his amiable Charlotte to name an early day for making him</li>
<li class="L4455" rel="L4455">the happiest of men.</li>
<li class="L4456" rel="L4456"></li>
<li class="L4457" rel="L4457">Mr. Collins&#39;s return into Hertfordshire was no longer a matter of</li>
<li class="L4458" rel="L4458">pleasure to Mrs. Bennet. On the contrary, she was as much disposed to</li>
<li class="L4459" rel="L4459">complain of it as her husband. It was very strange that he should come</li>
<li class="L4460" rel="L4460">to Longbourn instead of to Lucas Lodge; it was also very inconvenient</li>
<li class="L4461" rel="L4461">and exceedingly troublesome. She hated having visitors in the house</li>
<li class="L4462" rel="L4462">while her health was so indifferent, and lovers were of all people the</li>
<li class="L4463" rel="L4463">most disagreeable. Such were the gentle murmurs of Mrs. Bennet, and</li>
<li class="L4464" rel="L4464">they gave way only to the greater distress of Mr. Bingley&#39;s continued</li>
<li class="L4465" rel="L4465">absence.</li>
<li class="L4466" rel="L4466"></li>
<li class="L4467" rel="L4467">Neither Jane nor Elizabeth were comfortable on this subject. Day after</li>
<li class="L4468" rel="L4468">day passed away without bringing any other tidings of him than the</li>
<li class="L4469" rel="L4469">report which shortly prevailed in Meryton of his coming no more to</li>
<li class="L4470" rel="L4470">Netherfield the whole winter; a report which highly incensed Mrs.</li>
<li class="L4471" rel="L4471">Bennet, and which she never failed to contradict as a most scandalous</li>
<li class="L4472" rel="L4472">falsehood.</li>
<li class="L4473" rel="L4473"></li>
<li class="L4474" rel="L4474">Even Elizabeth began to fear--not that Bingley was indifferent--but that</li>
<li class="L4475" rel="L4475">his sisters would be successful in keeping him away. Unwilling as</li>
<li class="L4476" rel="L4476">she was to admit an idea so destructive of Jane&#39;s happiness, and so</li>
<li class="L4477" rel="L4477">dishonorable to the stability of her lover, she could not prevent its</li>
<li class="L4478" rel="L4478">frequently occurring. The united efforts of his two unfeeling sisters</li>
<li class="L4479" rel="L4479">and of his overpowering friend, assisted by the attractions of Miss</li>
<li class="L4480" rel="L4480">Darcy and the amusements of London might be too much, she feared, for</li>
<li class="L4481" rel="L4481">the strength of his attachment.</li>
<li class="L4482" rel="L4482"></li>
<li class="L4483" rel="L4483">As for Jane, _her_ anxiety under this suspense was, of course, more</li>
<li class="L4484" rel="L4484">painful than Elizabeth&#39;s, but whatever she felt she was desirous of</li>
<li class="L4485" rel="L4485">concealing, and between herself and Elizabeth, therefore, the subject</li>
<li class="L4486" rel="L4486">was never alluded to. But as no such delicacy restrained her mother,</li>
<li class="L4487" rel="L4487">an hour seldom passed in which she did not talk of Bingley, express her</li>
<li class="L4488" rel="L4488">impatience for his arrival, or even require Jane to confess that if he</li>
<li class="L4489" rel="L4489">did not come back she would think herself very ill used. It needed</li>
<li class="L4490" rel="L4490">all Jane&#39;s steady mildness to bear these attacks with tolerable</li>
<li class="L4491" rel="L4491">tranquillity.</li>
<li class="L4492" rel="L4492"></li>
<li class="L4493" rel="L4493">Mr. Collins returned most punctually on Monday fortnight, but his</li>
<li class="L4494" rel="L4494">reception at Longbourn was not quite so gracious as it had been on his</li>
<li class="L4495" rel="L4495">first introduction. He was too happy, however, to need much attention;</li>
<li class="L4496" rel="L4496">and luckily for the others, the business of love-making relieved them</li>
<li class="L4497" rel="L4497">from a great deal of his company. The chief of every day was spent by</li>
<li class="L4498" rel="L4498">him at Lucas Lodge, and he sometimes returned to Longbourn only in time</li>
<li class="L4499" rel="L4499">to make an apology for his absence before the family went to bed.</li>
<li class="L4500" rel="L4500"></li>
<li class="L4501" rel="L4501">Mrs. Bennet was really in a most pitiable state. The very mention of</li>
<li class="L4502" rel="L4502">anything concerning the match threw her into an agony of ill-humour,</li>
<li class="L4503" rel="L4503">and wherever she went she was sure of hearing it talked of. The sight</li>
<li class="L4504" rel="L4504">of Miss Lucas was odious to her. As her successor in that house, she</li>
<li class="L4505" rel="L4505">regarded her with jealous abhorrence. Whenever Charlotte came to see</li>
<li class="L4506" rel="L4506">them, she concluded her to be anticipating the hour of possession; and</li>
<li class="L4507" rel="L4507">whenever she spoke in a low voice to Mr. Collins, was convinced that</li>
<li class="L4508" rel="L4508">they were talking of the Longbourn estate, and resolving to turn herself</li>
<li class="L4509" rel="L4509">and her daughters out of the house, as soon as Mr. Bennet were dead. She</li>
<li class="L4510" rel="L4510">complained bitterly of all this to her husband.</li>
<li class="L4511" rel="L4511"></li>
<li class="L4512" rel="L4512">“Indeed, Mr. Bennet,” said she, “it is very hard to think that Charlotte</li>
<li class="L4513" rel="L4513">Lucas should ever be mistress of this house, that I should be forced to</li>
<li class="L4514" rel="L4514">make way for _her_, and live to see her take her place in it!”</li>
<li class="L4515" rel="L4515"></li>
<li class="L4516" rel="L4516">“My dear, do not give way to such gloomy thoughts. Let us hope for</li>
<li class="L4517" rel="L4517">better things. Let us flatter ourselves that I may be the survivor.”</li>
<li class="L4518" rel="L4518"></li>
<li class="L4519" rel="L4519">This was not very consoling to Mrs. Bennet, and therefore, instead of</li>
<li class="L4520" rel="L4520">making any answer, she went on as before.</li>
<li class="L4521" rel="L4521"></li>
<li class="L4522" rel="L4522">“I cannot bear to think that they should have all this estate. If it was</li>
<li class="L4523" rel="L4523">not for the entail, I should not mind it.”</li>
<li class="L4524" rel="L4524"></li>
<li class="L4525" rel="L4525">“What should not you mind?”</li>
<li class="L4526" rel="L4526"></li>
<li class="L4527" rel="L4527">“I should not mind anything at all.”</li>
<li class="L4528" rel="L4528"></li>
<li class="L4529" rel="L4529">“Let us be thankful that you are preserved from a state of such</li>
<li class="L4530" rel="L4530">insensibility.”</li>
<li class="L4531" rel="L4531"></li>
<li class="L4532" rel="L4532">“I never can be thankful, Mr. Bennet, for anything about the entail. How</li>
<li class="L4533" rel="L4533">anyone could have the conscience to entail away an estate from one&#39;s own</li>
<li class="L4534" rel="L4534">daughters, I cannot understand; and all for the sake of Mr. Collins too!</li>
<li class="L4535" rel="L4535">Why should _he_ have it more than anybody else?”</li>
<li class="L4536" rel="L4536"></li>
<li class="L4537" rel="L4537">“I leave it to yourself to determine,” said Mr. Bennet.</li>
<li class="L4538" rel="L4538"></li>
<li class="L4539" rel="L4539"></li>
<li class="L4540" rel="L4540"></li>
<li class="L4541" rel="L4541">Chapter 24</li>
<li class="L4542" rel="L4542"></li>
<li class="L4543" rel="L4543"></li>
<li class="L4544" rel="L4544">Miss Bingley&#39;s letter arrived, and put an end to doubt. The very first</li>
<li class="L4545" rel="L4545">sentence conveyed the assurance of their being all settled in London for</li>
<li class="L4546" rel="L4546">the winter, and concluded with her brother&#39;s regret at not having had</li>
<li class="L4547" rel="L4547">time to pay his respects to his friends in Hertfordshire before he left</li>
<li class="L4548" rel="L4548">the country.</li>
<li class="L4549" rel="L4549"></li>
<li class="L4550" rel="L4550">Hope was over, entirely over; and when Jane could attend to the rest</li>
<li class="L4551" rel="L4551">of the letter, she found little, except the professed affection of the</li>
<li class="L4552" rel="L4552">writer, that could give her any comfort. Miss Darcy&#39;s praise occupied</li>
<li class="L4553" rel="L4553">the chief of it. Her many attractions were again dwelt on, and Caroline</li>
<li class="L4554" rel="L4554">boasted joyfully of their increasing intimacy, and ventured to predict</li>
<li class="L4555" rel="L4555">the accomplishment of the wishes which had been unfolded in her former</li>
<li class="L4556" rel="L4556">letter. She wrote also with great pleasure of her brother&#39;s being an</li>
<li class="L4557" rel="L4557">inmate of Mr. Darcy&#39;s house, and mentioned with raptures some plans of</li>
<li class="L4558" rel="L4558">the latter with regard to new furniture.</li>
<li class="L4559" rel="L4559"></li>
<li class="L4560" rel="L4560">Elizabeth, to whom Jane very soon communicated the chief of all this,</li>
<li class="L4561" rel="L4561">heard it in silent indignation. Her heart was divided between concern</li>
<li class="L4562" rel="L4562">for her sister, and resentment against all others. To Caroline&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4563" rel="L4563">assertion of her brother&#39;s being partial to Miss Darcy she paid no</li>
<li class="L4564" rel="L4564">credit. That he was really fond of Jane, she doubted no more than she</li>
<li class="L4565" rel="L4565">had ever done; and much as she had always been disposed to like him, she</li>
<li class="L4566" rel="L4566">could not think without anger, hardly without contempt, on that easiness</li>
<li class="L4567" rel="L4567">of temper, that want of proper resolution, which now made him the slave</li>
<li class="L4568" rel="L4568">of his designing friends, and led him to sacrifice of his own happiness</li>
<li class="L4569" rel="L4569">to the caprice of their inclination. Had his own happiness, however,</li>
<li class="L4570" rel="L4570">been the only sacrifice, he might have been allowed to sport with it in</li>
<li class="L4571" rel="L4571">whatever manner he thought best, but her sister&#39;s was involved in it, as</li>
<li class="L4572" rel="L4572">she thought he must be sensible himself. It was a subject, in short,</li>
<li class="L4573" rel="L4573">on which reflection would be long indulged, and must be unavailing. She</li>
<li class="L4574" rel="L4574">could think of nothing else; and yet whether Bingley&#39;s regard had really</li>
<li class="L4575" rel="L4575">died away, or were suppressed by his friends&#39; interference; whether</li>
<li class="L4576" rel="L4576">he had been aware of Jane&#39;s attachment, or whether it had escaped his</li>
<li class="L4577" rel="L4577">observation; whatever were the case, though her opinion of him must be</li>
<li class="L4578" rel="L4578">materially affected by the difference, her sister&#39;s situation remained</li>
<li class="L4579" rel="L4579">the same, her peace equally wounded.</li>
<li class="L4580" rel="L4580"></li>
<li class="L4581" rel="L4581">A day or two passed before Jane had courage to speak of her feelings to</li>
<li class="L4582" rel="L4582">Elizabeth; but at last, on Mrs. Bennet&#39;s leaving them together, after a</li>
<li class="L4583" rel="L4583">longer irritation than usual about Netherfield and its master, she could</li>
<li class="L4584" rel="L4584">not help saying:</li>
<li class="L4585" rel="L4585"></li>
<li class="L4586" rel="L4586">“Oh, that my dear mother had more command over herself! She can have no</li>
<li class="L4587" rel="L4587">idea of the pain she gives me by her continual reflections on him. But</li>
<li class="L4588" rel="L4588">I will not repine. It cannot last long. He will be forgot, and we shall</li>
<li class="L4589" rel="L4589">all be as we were before.”</li>
<li class="L4590" rel="L4590"></li>
<li class="L4591" rel="L4591">Elizabeth looked at her sister with incredulous solicitude, but said</li>
<li class="L4592" rel="L4592">nothing.</li>
<li class="L4593" rel="L4593"></li>
<li class="L4594" rel="L4594">“You doubt me,” cried Jane, slightly colouring; “indeed, you have</li>
<li class="L4595" rel="L4595">no reason. He may live in my memory as the most amiable man of my</li>
<li class="L4596" rel="L4596">acquaintance, but that is all. I have nothing either to hope or fear,</li>
<li class="L4597" rel="L4597">and nothing to reproach him with. Thank God! I have not _that_ pain. A</li>
<li class="L4598" rel="L4598">little time, therefore--I shall certainly try to get the better.”</li>
<li class="L4599" rel="L4599"></li>
<li class="L4600" rel="L4600">With a stronger voice she soon added, “I have this comfort immediately,</li>
<li class="L4601" rel="L4601">that it has not been more than an error of fancy on my side, and that it</li>
<li class="L4602" rel="L4602">has done no harm to anyone but myself.”</li>
<li class="L4603" rel="L4603"></li>
<li class="L4604" rel="L4604">“My dear Jane!” exclaimed Elizabeth, “you are too good. Your sweetness</li>
<li class="L4605" rel="L4605">and disinterestedness are really angelic; I do not know what to say</li>
<li class="L4606" rel="L4606">to you. I feel as if I had never done you justice, or loved you as you</li>
<li class="L4607" rel="L4607">deserve.”</li>
<li class="L4608" rel="L4608"></li>
<li class="L4609" rel="L4609">Miss Bennet eagerly disclaimed all extraordinary merit, and threw back</li>
<li class="L4610" rel="L4610">the praise on her sister&#39;s warm affection.</li>
<li class="L4611" rel="L4611"></li>
<li class="L4612" rel="L4612">“Nay,” said Elizabeth, “this is not fair. _You_ wish to think all the</li>
<li class="L4613" rel="L4613">world respectable, and are hurt if I speak ill of anybody. I only want</li>
<li class="L4614" rel="L4614">to think _you_ perfect, and you set yourself against it. Do not</li>
<li class="L4615" rel="L4615">be afraid of my running into any excess, of my encroaching on your</li>
<li class="L4616" rel="L4616">privilege of universal good-will. You need not. There are few people</li>
<li class="L4617" rel="L4617">whom I really love, and still fewer of whom I think well. The more I see</li>
<li class="L4618" rel="L4618">of the world, the more am I dissatisfied with it; and every day confirms</li>
<li class="L4619" rel="L4619">my belief of the inconsistency of all human characters, and of the</li>
<li class="L4620" rel="L4620">little dependence that can be placed on the appearance of merit or</li>
<li class="L4621" rel="L4621">sense. I have met with two instances lately, one I will not mention; the</li>
<li class="L4622" rel="L4622">other is Charlotte&#39;s marriage. It is unaccountable! In every view it is</li>
<li class="L4623" rel="L4623">unaccountable!”</li>
<li class="L4624" rel="L4624"></li>
<li class="L4625" rel="L4625">“My dear Lizzy, do not give way to such feelings as these. They will</li>
<li class="L4626" rel="L4626">ruin your happiness. You do not make allowance enough for difference</li>
<li class="L4627" rel="L4627">of situation and temper. Consider Mr. Collins&#39;s respectability, and</li>
<li class="L4628" rel="L4628">Charlotte&#39;s steady, prudent character. Remember that she is one of a</li>
<li class="L4629" rel="L4629">large family; that as to fortune, it is a most eligible match; and be</li>
<li class="L4630" rel="L4630">ready to believe, for everybody&#39;s sake, that she may feel something like</li>
<li class="L4631" rel="L4631">regard and esteem for our cousin.”</li>
<li class="L4632" rel="L4632"></li>
<li class="L4633" rel="L4633">“To oblige you, I would try to believe almost anything, but no one else</li>
<li class="L4634" rel="L4634">could be benefited by such a belief as this; for were I persuaded that</li>
<li class="L4635" rel="L4635">Charlotte had any regard for him, I should only think worse of her</li>
<li class="L4636" rel="L4636">understanding than I now do of her heart. My dear Jane, Mr. Collins is a</li>
<li class="L4637" rel="L4637">conceited, pompous, narrow-minded, silly man; you know he is, as well as</li>
<li class="L4638" rel="L4638">I do; and you must feel, as well as I do, that the woman who married him</li>
<li class="L4639" rel="L4639">cannot have a proper way of thinking. You shall not defend her, though</li>
<li class="L4640" rel="L4640">it is Charlotte Lucas. You shall not, for the sake of one individual,</li>
<li class="L4641" rel="L4641">change the meaning of principle and integrity, nor endeavour to persuade</li>
<li class="L4642" rel="L4642">yourself or me, that selfishness is prudence, and insensibility of</li>
<li class="L4643" rel="L4643">danger security for happiness.”</li>
<li class="L4644" rel="L4644"></li>
<li class="L4645" rel="L4645">“I must think your language too strong in speaking of both,” replied</li>
<li class="L4646" rel="L4646">Jane; “and I hope you will be convinced of it by seeing them happy</li>
<li class="L4647" rel="L4647">together. But enough of this. You alluded to something else. You</li>
<li class="L4648" rel="L4648">mentioned _two_ instances. I cannot misunderstand you, but I entreat</li>
<li class="L4649" rel="L4649">you, dear Lizzy, not to pain me by thinking _that person_ to blame, and</li>
<li class="L4650" rel="L4650">saying your opinion of him is sunk. We must not be so ready to fancy</li>
<li class="L4651" rel="L4651">ourselves intentionally injured. We must not expect a lively young man</li>
<li class="L4652" rel="L4652">to be always so guarded and circumspect. It is very often nothing but</li>
<li class="L4653" rel="L4653">our own vanity that deceives us. Women fancy admiration means more than</li>
<li class="L4654" rel="L4654">it does.”</li>
<li class="L4655" rel="L4655"></li>
<li class="L4656" rel="L4656">“And men take care that they should.”</li>
<li class="L4657" rel="L4657"></li>
<li class="L4658" rel="L4658">“If it is designedly done, they cannot be justified; but I have no idea</li>
<li class="L4659" rel="L4659">of there being so much design in the world as some persons imagine.”</li>
<li class="L4660" rel="L4660"></li>
<li class="L4661" rel="L4661">“I am far from attributing any part of Mr. Bingley&#39;s conduct to design,”</li>
<li class="L4662" rel="L4662"> said Elizabeth; “but without scheming to do wrong, or to make others</li>
<li class="L4663" rel="L4663">unhappy, there may be error, and there may be misery. Thoughtlessness,</li>
<li class="L4664" rel="L4664">want of attention to other people&#39;s feelings, and want of resolution,</li>
<li class="L4665" rel="L4665">will do the business.”</li>
<li class="L4666" rel="L4666"></li>
<li class="L4667" rel="L4667">“And do you impute it to either of those?”</li>
<li class="L4668" rel="L4668"></li>
<li class="L4669" rel="L4669">“Yes; to the last. But if I go on, I shall displease you by saying what</li>
<li class="L4670" rel="L4670">I think of persons you esteem. Stop me whilst you can.”</li>
<li class="L4671" rel="L4671"></li>
<li class="L4672" rel="L4672">“You persist, then, in supposing his sisters influence him?”</li>
<li class="L4673" rel="L4673"></li>
<li class="L4674" rel="L4674">“Yes, in conjunction with his friend.”</li>
<li class="L4675" rel="L4675"></li>
<li class="L4676" rel="L4676">“I cannot believe it. Why should they try to influence him? They can</li>
