<li class="L4677" rel="L4677">only wish his happiness; and if he is attached to me, no other woman can</li>
<li class="L4678" rel="L4678">secure it.”</li>
<li class="L4679" rel="L4679"></li>
<li class="L4680" rel="L4680">“Your first position is false. They may wish many things besides his</li>
<li class="L4681" rel="L4681">happiness; they may wish his increase of wealth and consequence; they</li>
<li class="L4682" rel="L4682">may wish him to marry a girl who has all the importance of money, great</li>
<li class="L4683" rel="L4683">connections, and pride.”</li>
<li class="L4684" rel="L4684"></li>
<li class="L4685" rel="L4685">“Beyond a doubt, they _do_ wish him to choose Miss Darcy,” replied Jane;</li>
<li class="L4686" rel="L4686">“but this may be from better feelings than you are supposing. They have</li>
<li class="L4687" rel="L4687">known her much longer than they have known me; no wonder if they love</li>
<li class="L4688" rel="L4688">her better. But, whatever may be their own wishes, it is very unlikely</li>
<li class="L4689" rel="L4689">they should have opposed their brother&#39;s. What sister would think</li>
<li class="L4690" rel="L4690">herself at liberty to do it, unless there were something very</li>
<li class="L4691" rel="L4691">objectionable? If they believed him attached to me, they would not try</li>
<li class="L4692" rel="L4692">to part us; if he were so, they could not succeed. By supposing such an</li>
<li class="L4693" rel="L4693">affection, you make everybody acting unnaturally and wrong, and me most</li>
<li class="L4694" rel="L4694">unhappy. Do not distress me by the idea. I am not ashamed of having been</li>
<li class="L4695" rel="L4695">mistaken--or, at least, it is light, it is nothing in comparison of what</li>
<li class="L4696" rel="L4696">I should feel in thinking ill of him or his sisters. Let me take it in</li>
<li class="L4697" rel="L4697">the best light, in the light in which it may be understood.”</li>
<li class="L4698" rel="L4698"></li>
<li class="L4699" rel="L4699">Elizabeth could not oppose such a wish; and from this time Mr. Bingley&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4700" rel="L4700">name was scarcely ever mentioned between them.</li>
<li class="L4701" rel="L4701"></li>
<li class="L4702" rel="L4702">Mrs. Bennet still continued to wonder and repine at his returning no</li>
<li class="L4703" rel="L4703">more, and though a day seldom passed in which Elizabeth did not account</li>
<li class="L4704" rel="L4704">for it clearly, there was little chance of her ever considering it with</li>
<li class="L4705" rel="L4705">less perplexity. Her daughter endeavoured to convince her of what she</li>
<li class="L4706" rel="L4706">did not believe herself, that his attentions to Jane had been merely the</li>
<li class="L4707" rel="L4707">effect of a common and transient liking, which ceased when he saw her</li>
<li class="L4708" rel="L4708">no more; but though the probability of the statement was admitted at</li>
<li class="L4709" rel="L4709">the time, she had the same story to repeat every day. Mrs. Bennet&#39;s best</li>
<li class="L4710" rel="L4710">comfort was that Mr. Bingley must be down again in the summer.</li>
<li class="L4711" rel="L4711"></li>
<li class="L4712" rel="L4712">Mr. Bennet treated the matter differently. “So, Lizzy,” said he one day,</li>
<li class="L4713" rel="L4713">“your sister is crossed in love, I find. I congratulate her. Next to</li>
<li class="L4714" rel="L4714">being married, a girl likes to be crossed a little in love now and then.</li>
<li class="L4715" rel="L4715">It is something to think of, and it gives her a sort of distinction</li>
<li class="L4716" rel="L4716">among her companions. When is your turn to come? You will hardly bear to</li>
<li class="L4717" rel="L4717">be long outdone by Jane. Now is your time. Here are officers enough in</li>
<li class="L4718" rel="L4718">Meryton to disappoint all the young ladies in the country. Let Wickham</li>
<li class="L4719" rel="L4719">be _your_ man. He is a pleasant fellow, and would jilt you creditably.”</li>
<li class="L4720" rel="L4720"></li>
<li class="L4721" rel="L4721">“Thank you, sir, but a less agreeable man would satisfy me. We must not</li>
<li class="L4722" rel="L4722">all expect Jane&#39;s good fortune.”</li>
<li class="L4723" rel="L4723"></li>
<li class="L4724" rel="L4724">“True,” said Mr. Bennet, “but it is a comfort to think that whatever of</li>
<li class="L4725" rel="L4725">that kind may befall you, you have an affectionate mother who will make</li>
<li class="L4726" rel="L4726">the most of it.”</li>
<li class="L4727" rel="L4727"></li>
<li class="L4728" rel="L4728">Mr. Wickham&#39;s society was of material service in dispelling the gloom</li>
<li class="L4729" rel="L4729">which the late perverse occurrences had thrown on many of the Longbourn</li>
<li class="L4730" rel="L4730">family. They saw him often, and to his other recommendations was now</li>
<li class="L4731" rel="L4731">added that of general unreserve. The whole of what Elizabeth had already</li>
<li class="L4732" rel="L4732">heard, his claims on Mr. Darcy, and all that he had suffered from him,</li>
<li class="L4733" rel="L4733">was now openly acknowledged and publicly canvassed; and everybody was</li>
<li class="L4734" rel="L4734">pleased to know how much they had always disliked Mr. Darcy before they</li>
<li class="L4735" rel="L4735">had known anything of the matter.</li>
<li class="L4736" rel="L4736"></li>
<li class="L4737" rel="L4737">Miss Bennet was the only creature who could suppose there might be</li>
<li class="L4738" rel="L4738">any extenuating circumstances in the case, unknown to the society</li>
<li class="L4739" rel="L4739">of Hertfordshire; her mild and steady candour always pleaded for</li>
<li class="L4740" rel="L4740">allowances, and urged the possibility of mistakes--but by everybody else</li>
<li class="L4741" rel="L4741">Mr. Darcy was condemned as the worst of men.</li>
<li class="L4742" rel="L4742"></li>
<li class="L4743" rel="L4743"></li>
<li class="L4744" rel="L4744"></li>
<li class="L4745" rel="L4745">Chapter 25</li>
<li class="L4746" rel="L4746"></li>
<li class="L4747" rel="L4747"></li>
<li class="L4748" rel="L4748">After a week spent in professions of love and schemes of felicity,</li>
<li class="L4749" rel="L4749">Mr. Collins was called from his amiable Charlotte by the arrival of</li>
<li class="L4750" rel="L4750">Saturday. The pain of separation, however, might be alleviated on his</li>
<li class="L4751" rel="L4751">side, by preparations for the reception of his bride; as he had reason</li>
<li class="L4752" rel="L4752">to hope, that shortly after his return into Hertfordshire, the day would</li>
<li class="L4753" rel="L4753">be fixed that was to make him the happiest of men. He took leave of his</li>
<li class="L4754" rel="L4754">relations at Longbourn with as much solemnity as before; wished his fair</li>
<li class="L4755" rel="L4755">cousins health and happiness again, and promised their father another</li>
<li class="L4756" rel="L4756">letter of thanks.</li>
<li class="L4757" rel="L4757"></li>
<li class="L4758" rel="L4758">On the following Monday, Mrs. Bennet had the pleasure of receiving</li>
<li class="L4759" rel="L4759">her brother and his wife, who came as usual to spend the Christmas</li>
<li class="L4760" rel="L4760">at Longbourn. Mr. Gardiner was a sensible, gentlemanlike man, greatly</li>
<li class="L4761" rel="L4761">superior to his sister, as well by nature as education. The Netherfield</li>
<li class="L4762" rel="L4762">ladies would have had difficulty in believing that a man who lived</li>
<li class="L4763" rel="L4763">by trade, and within view of his own warehouses, could have been so</li>
<li class="L4764" rel="L4764">well-bred and agreeable. Mrs. Gardiner, who was several years younger</li>
<li class="L4765" rel="L4765">than Mrs. Bennet and Mrs. Phillips, was an amiable, intelligent, elegant</li>
<li class="L4766" rel="L4766">woman, and a great favourite with all her Longbourn nieces. Between the</li>
<li class="L4767" rel="L4767">two eldest and herself especially, there subsisted a particular regard.</li>
<li class="L4768" rel="L4768">They had frequently been staying with her in town.</li>
<li class="L4769" rel="L4769"></li>
<li class="L4770" rel="L4770">The first part of Mrs. Gardiner&#39;s business on her arrival was to</li>
<li class="L4771" rel="L4771">distribute her presents and describe the newest fashions. When this was</li>
<li class="L4772" rel="L4772">done she had a less active part to play. It became her turn to listen.</li>
<li class="L4773" rel="L4773">Mrs. Bennet had many grievances to relate, and much to complain of. They</li>
<li class="L4774" rel="L4774">had all been very ill-used since she last saw her sister. Two of her</li>
<li class="L4775" rel="L4775">girls had been upon the point of marriage, and after all there was</li>
<li class="L4776" rel="L4776">nothing in it.</li>
<li class="L4777" rel="L4777"></li>
<li class="L4778" rel="L4778">“I do not blame Jane,” she continued, “for Jane would have got Mr.</li>
<li class="L4779" rel="L4779">Bingley if she could. But Lizzy! Oh, sister! It is very hard to think</li>
<li class="L4780" rel="L4780">that she might have been Mr. Collins&#39;s wife by this time, had it not</li>
<li class="L4781" rel="L4781">been for her own perverseness. He made her an offer in this very room,</li>
<li class="L4782" rel="L4782">and she refused him. The consequence of it is, that Lady Lucas will have</li>
<li class="L4783" rel="L4783">a daughter married before I have, and that the Longbourn estate is just</li>
<li class="L4784" rel="L4784">as much entailed as ever. The Lucases are very artful people indeed,</li>
<li class="L4785" rel="L4785">sister. They are all for what they can get. I am sorry to say it of</li>
<li class="L4786" rel="L4786">them, but so it is. It makes me very nervous and poorly, to be thwarted</li>
<li class="L4787" rel="L4787">so in my own family, and to have neighbours who think of themselves</li>
<li class="L4788" rel="L4788">before anybody else. However, your coming just at this time is the</li>
<li class="L4789" rel="L4789">greatest of comforts, and I am very glad to hear what you tell us, of</li>
<li class="L4790" rel="L4790">long sleeves.”</li>
<li class="L4791" rel="L4791"></li>
<li class="L4792" rel="L4792">Mrs. Gardiner, to whom the chief of this news had been given before,</li>
<li class="L4793" rel="L4793">in the course of Jane and Elizabeth&#39;s correspondence with her, made her</li>
<li class="L4794" rel="L4794">sister a slight answer, and, in compassion to her nieces, turned the</li>
<li class="L4795" rel="L4795">conversation.</li>
<li class="L4796" rel="L4796"></li>
<li class="L4797" rel="L4797">When alone with Elizabeth afterwards, she spoke more on the subject. “It</li>
<li class="L4798" rel="L4798">seems likely to have been a desirable match for Jane,” said she. “I am</li>
<li class="L4799" rel="L4799">sorry it went off. But these things happen so often! A young man, such</li>
<li class="L4800" rel="L4800">as you describe Mr. Bingley, so easily falls in love with a pretty girl</li>
<li class="L4801" rel="L4801">for a few weeks, and when accident separates them, so easily forgets</li>
<li class="L4802" rel="L4802">her, that these sort of inconsistencies are very frequent.”</li>
<li class="L4803" rel="L4803"></li>
<li class="L4804" rel="L4804">“An excellent consolation in its way,” said Elizabeth, “but it will not</li>
<li class="L4805" rel="L4805">do for _us_. We do not suffer by _accident_. It does not often</li>
<li class="L4806" rel="L4806">happen that the interference of friends will persuade a young man of</li>
<li class="L4807" rel="L4807">independent fortune to think no more of a girl whom he was violently in</li>
<li class="L4808" rel="L4808">love with only a few days before.”</li>
<li class="L4809" rel="L4809"></li>
<li class="L4810" rel="L4810">“But that expression of &#39;violently in love&#39; is so hackneyed, so</li>
<li class="L4811" rel="L4811">doubtful, so indefinite, that it gives me very little idea. It is as</li>
<li class="L4812" rel="L4812">often applied to feelings which arise from a half-hour&#39;s acquaintance,</li>
<li class="L4813" rel="L4813">as to a real, strong attachment. Pray, how _violent was_ Mr. Bingley&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4814" rel="L4814">love?”</li>
<li class="L4815" rel="L4815"></li>
<li class="L4816" rel="L4816">“I never saw a more promising inclination; he was growing quite</li>
<li class="L4817" rel="L4817">inattentive to other people, and wholly engrossed by her. Every time</li>
<li class="L4818" rel="L4818">they met, it was more decided and remarkable. At his own ball he</li>
<li class="L4819" rel="L4819">offended two or three young ladies, by not asking them to dance; and I</li>
<li class="L4820" rel="L4820">spoke to him twice myself, without receiving an answer. Could there be</li>
<li class="L4821" rel="L4821">finer symptoms? Is not general incivility the very essence of love?”</li>
<li class="L4822" rel="L4822"></li>
<li class="L4823" rel="L4823">“Oh, yes!--of that kind of love which I suppose him to have felt. Poor</li>
<li class="L4824" rel="L4824">Jane! I am sorry for her, because, with her disposition, she may not get</li>
<li class="L4825" rel="L4825">over it immediately. It had better have happened to _you_, Lizzy; you</li>
<li class="L4826" rel="L4826">would have laughed yourself out of it sooner. But do you think she</li>
<li class="L4827" rel="L4827">would be prevailed upon to go back with us? Change of scene might be</li>
<li class="L4828" rel="L4828">of service--and perhaps a little relief from home may be as useful as</li>
<li class="L4829" rel="L4829">anything.”</li>
<li class="L4830" rel="L4830"></li>
<li class="L4831" rel="L4831">Elizabeth was exceedingly pleased with this proposal, and felt persuaded</li>
<li class="L4832" rel="L4832">of her sister&#39;s ready acquiescence.</li>
<li class="L4833" rel="L4833"></li>
<li class="L4834" rel="L4834">“I hope,” added Mrs. Gardiner, “that no consideration with regard to</li>
<li class="L4835" rel="L4835">this young man will influence her. We live in so different a part of</li>
<li class="L4836" rel="L4836">town, all our connections are so different, and, as you well know, we go</li>
<li class="L4837" rel="L4837">out so little, that it is very improbable that they should meet at all,</li>
<li class="L4838" rel="L4838">unless he really comes to see her.”</li>
<li class="L4839" rel="L4839"></li>
<li class="L4840" rel="L4840">“And _that_ is quite impossible; for he is now in the custody of his</li>
<li class="L4841" rel="L4841">friend, and Mr. Darcy would no more suffer him to call on Jane in such</li>
<li class="L4842" rel="L4842">a part of London! My dear aunt, how could you think of it? Mr. Darcy may</li>
<li class="L4843" rel="L4843">perhaps have _heard_ of such a place as Gracechurch Street, but he</li>
<li class="L4844" rel="L4844">would hardly think a month&#39;s ablution enough to cleanse him from its</li>
<li class="L4845" rel="L4845">impurities, were he once to enter it; and depend upon it, Mr. Bingley</li>
<li class="L4846" rel="L4846">never stirs without him.”</li>
<li class="L4847" rel="L4847"></li>
<li class="L4848" rel="L4848">“So much the better. I hope they will not meet at all. But does not Jane</li>
<li class="L4849" rel="L4849">correspond with his sister? _She_ will not be able to help calling.”</li>
<li class="L4850" rel="L4850"></li>
<li class="L4851" rel="L4851">“She will drop the acquaintance entirely.”</li>
<li class="L4852" rel="L4852"></li>
<li class="L4853" rel="L4853">But in spite of the certainty in which Elizabeth affected to place this</li>
<li class="L4854" rel="L4854">point, as well as the still more interesting one of Bingley&#39;s being</li>
<li class="L4855" rel="L4855">withheld from seeing Jane, she felt a solicitude on the subject which</li>
<li class="L4856" rel="L4856">convinced her, on examination, that she did not consider it entirely</li>
<li class="L4857" rel="L4857">hopeless. It was possible, and sometimes she thought it probable, that</li>
<li class="L4858" rel="L4858">his affection might be reanimated, and the influence of his friends</li>
<li class="L4859" rel="L4859">successfully combated by the more natural influence of Jane&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4860" rel="L4860">attractions.</li>
<li class="L4861" rel="L4861"></li>
<li class="L4862" rel="L4862">Miss Bennet accepted her aunt&#39;s invitation with pleasure; and the</li>
<li class="L4863" rel="L4863">Bingleys were no otherwise in her thoughts at the same time, than as she</li>
<li class="L4864" rel="L4864">hoped by Caroline&#39;s not living in the same house with her brother,</li>
<li class="L4865" rel="L4865">she might occasionally spend a morning with her, without any danger of</li>
<li class="L4866" rel="L4866">seeing him.</li>
<li class="L4867" rel="L4867"></li>
<li class="L4868" rel="L4868">The Gardiners stayed a week at Longbourn; and what with the Phillipses,</li>
<li class="L4869" rel="L4869">the Lucases, and the officers, there was not a day without its</li>
<li class="L4870" rel="L4870">engagement. Mrs. Bennet had so carefully provided for the entertainment</li>
<li class="L4871" rel="L4871">of her brother and sister, that they did not once sit down to a family</li>
<li class="L4872" rel="L4872">dinner. When the engagement was for home, some of the officers always</li>
<li class="L4873" rel="L4873">made part of it--of which officers Mr. Wickham was sure to be one; and</li>
<li class="L4874" rel="L4874">on these occasions, Mrs. Gardiner, rendered suspicious by Elizabeth&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4875" rel="L4875">warm commendation, narrowly observed them both. Without supposing them,</li>
<li class="L4876" rel="L4876">from what she saw, to be very seriously in love, their preference</li>
<li class="L4877" rel="L4877">of each other was plain enough to make her a little uneasy; and</li>
<li class="L4878" rel="L4878">she resolved to speak to Elizabeth on the subject before she left</li>
<li class="L4879" rel="L4879">Hertfordshire, and represent to her the imprudence of encouraging such</li>
<li class="L4880" rel="L4880">an attachment.</li>
<li class="L4881" rel="L4881"></li>
<li class="L4882" rel="L4882">To Mrs. Gardiner, Wickham had one means of affording pleasure,</li>
<li class="L4883" rel="L4883">unconnected with his general powers. About ten or a dozen years ago,</li>
<li class="L4884" rel="L4884">before her marriage, she had spent a considerable time in that very</li>
<li class="L4885" rel="L4885">part of Derbyshire to which he belonged. They had, therefore, many</li>
<li class="L4886" rel="L4886">acquaintances in common; and though Wickham had been little there since</li>
<li class="L4887" rel="L4887">the death of Darcy&#39;s father, it was yet in his power to give her fresher</li>
<li class="L4888" rel="L4888">intelligence of her former friends than she had been in the way of</li>
<li class="L4889" rel="L4889">procuring.</li>
<li class="L4890" rel="L4890"></li>
<li class="L4891" rel="L4891">Mrs. Gardiner had seen Pemberley, and known the late Mr. Darcy by</li>
<li class="L4892" rel="L4892">character perfectly well. Here consequently was an inexhaustible subject</li>
<li class="L4893" rel="L4893">of discourse. In comparing her recollection of Pemberley with the minute</li>
<li class="L4894" rel="L4894">description which Wickham could give, and in bestowing her tribute of</li>
<li class="L4895" rel="L4895">praise on the character of its late possessor, she was delighting both</li>
<li class="L4896" rel="L4896">him and herself. On being made acquainted with the present Mr. Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4897" rel="L4897">treatment of him, she tried to remember some of that gentleman&#39;s</li>
<li class="L4898" rel="L4898">reputed disposition when quite a lad which might agree with it, and</li>
<li class="L4899" rel="L4899">was confident at last that she recollected having heard Mr. Fitzwilliam</li>
<li class="L4900" rel="L4900">Darcy formerly spoken of as a very proud, ill-natured boy.</li>
<li class="L4901" rel="L4901"></li>
<li class="L4902" rel="L4902"></li>
<li class="L4903" rel="L4903"></li>
<li class="L4904" rel="L4904">Chapter 26</li>
<li class="L4905" rel="L4905"></li>
<li class="L4906" rel="L4906"></li>
<li class="L4907" rel="L4907">Mrs. Gardiner&#39;s caution to Elizabeth was punctually and kindly given</li>
<li class="L4908" rel="L4908">on the first favourable opportunity of speaking to her alone; after</li>
<li class="L4909" rel="L4909">honestly telling her what she thought, she thus went on:</li>
<li class="L4910" rel="L4910"></li>
<li class="L4911" rel="L4911">“You are too sensible a girl, Lizzy, to fall in love merely because</li>
<li class="L4912" rel="L4912">you are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking</li>
<li class="L4913" rel="L4913">openly. Seriously, I would have you be on your guard. Do not involve</li>
<li class="L4914" rel="L4914">yourself or endeavour to involve him in an affection which the want</li>
<li class="L4915" rel="L4915">of fortune would make so very imprudent. I have nothing to say against</li>
<li class="L4916" rel="L4916">_him_; he is a most interesting young man; and if he had the fortune he</li>
<li class="L4917" rel="L4917">ought to have, I should think you could not do better. But as it is, you</li>
<li class="L4918" rel="L4918">must not let your fancy run away with you. You have sense, and we all</li>
<li class="L4919" rel="L4919">expect you to use it. Your father would depend on _your_ resolution and</li>
<li class="L4920" rel="L4920">good conduct, I am sure. You must not disappoint your father.”</li>
<li class="L4921" rel="L4921"></li>
<li class="L4922" rel="L4922">“My dear aunt, this is being serious indeed.”</li>
<li class="L4923" rel="L4923"></li>
<li class="L4924" rel="L4924">“Yes, and I hope to engage you to be serious likewise.”</li>
<li class="L4925" rel="L4925"></li>
<li class="L4926" rel="L4926">“Well, then, you need not be under any alarm. I will take care of</li>
<li class="L4927" rel="L4927">myself, and of Mr. Wickham too. He shall not be in love with me, if I</li>
<li class="L4928" rel="L4928">can prevent it.”</li>
<li class="L4929" rel="L4929"></li>
<li class="L4930" rel="L4930">“Elizabeth, you are not serious now.”</li>
<li class="L4931" rel="L4931"></li>
<li class="L4932" rel="L4932">“I beg your pardon, I will try again. At present I am not in love with</li>
<li class="L4933" rel="L4933">Mr. Wickham; no, I certainly am not. But he is, beyond all comparison,</li>
<li class="L4934" rel="L4934">the most agreeable man I ever saw--and if he becomes really attached to</li>
<li class="L4935" rel="L4935">me--I believe it will be better that he should not. I see the imprudence</li>
<li class="L4936" rel="L4936">of it. Oh! _that_ abominable Mr. Darcy! My father&#39;s opinion of me does</li>
<li class="L4937" rel="L4937">me the greatest honour, and I should be miserable to forfeit it. My</li>
<li class="L4938" rel="L4938">father, however, is partial to Mr. Wickham. In short, my dear aunt, I</li>
<li class="L4939" rel="L4939">should be very sorry to be the means of making any of you unhappy; but</li>
<li class="L4940" rel="L4940">since we see every day that where there is affection, young people</li>
<li class="L4941" rel="L4941">are seldom withheld by immediate want of fortune from entering into</li>
<li class="L4942" rel="L4942">engagements with each other, how can I promise to be wiser than so many</li>
<li class="L4943" rel="L4943">of my fellow-creatures if I am tempted, or how am I even to know that it</li>
<li class="L4944" rel="L4944">would be wisdom to resist? All that I can promise you, therefore, is not</li>
<li class="L4945" rel="L4945">to be in a hurry. I will not be in a hurry to believe myself his first</li>
<li class="L4946" rel="L4946">object. When I am in company with him, I will not be wishing. In short,</li>
<li class="L4947" rel="L4947">I will do my best.”</li>
<li class="L4948" rel="L4948"></li>
<li class="L4949" rel="L4949">“Perhaps it will be as well if you discourage his coming here so very</li>
<li class="L4950" rel="L4950">often. At least, you should not _remind_ your mother of inviting him.”</li>
<li class="L4951" rel="L4951"></li>
<li class="L4952" rel="L4952">“As I did the other day,” said Elizabeth with a conscious smile: “very</li>
<li class="L4953" rel="L4953">true, it will be wise in me to refrain from _that_. But do not imagine</li>
<li class="L4954" rel="L4954">that he is always here so often. It is on your account that he has been</li>
<li class="L4955" rel="L4955">so frequently invited this week. You know my mother&#39;s ideas as to the</li>
<li class="L4956" rel="L4956">necessity of constant company for her friends. But really, and upon my</li>
<li class="L4957" rel="L4957">honour, I will try to do what I think to be the wisest; and now I hope</li>
<li class="L4958" rel="L4958">you are satisfied.”</li>
<li class="L4959" rel="L4959"></li>
<li class="L4960" rel="L4960">Her aunt assured her that she was, and Elizabeth having thanked her for</li>
<li class="L4961" rel="L4961">the kindness of her hints, they parted; a wonderful instance of advice</li>
<li class="L4962" rel="L4962">being given on such a point, without being resented.</li>
<li class="L4963" rel="L4963"></li>
<li class="L4964" rel="L4964">Mr. Collins returned into Hertfordshire soon after it had been quitted</li>
<li class="L4965" rel="L4965">by the Gardiners and Jane; but as he took up his abode with the Lucases,</li>
<li class="L4966" rel="L4966">his arrival was no great inconvenience to Mrs. Bennet. His marriage was</li>
<li class="L4967" rel="L4967">now fast approaching, and she was at length so far resigned as to think</li>
<li class="L4968" rel="L4968">it inevitable, and even repeatedly to say, in an ill-natured tone, that</li>
<li class="L4969" rel="L4969">she “_wished_ they might be happy.” Thursday was to be the wedding day,</li>
<li class="L4970" rel="L4970">and on Wednesday Miss Lucas paid her farewell visit; and when she</li>
<li class="L4971" rel="L4971">rose to take leave, Elizabeth, ashamed of her mother&#39;s ungracious and</li>
<li class="L4972" rel="L4972">reluctant good wishes, and sincerely affected herself, accompanied her</li>
<li class="L4973" rel="L4973">out of the room. As they went downstairs together, Charlotte said:</li>
<li class="L4974" rel="L4974"></li>
<li class="L4975" rel="L4975">“I shall depend on hearing from you very often, Eliza.”</li>
<li class="L4976" rel="L4976"></li>
<li class="L4977" rel="L4977">“_That_ you certainly shall.”</li>
<li class="L4978" rel="L4978"></li>
<li class="L4979" rel="L4979">“And I have another favour to ask you. Will you come and see me?”</li>
<li class="L4980" rel="L4980"></li>
<li class="L4981" rel="L4981">“We shall often meet, I hope, in Hertfordshire.”</li>
<li class="L4982" rel="L4982"></li>
<li class="L4983" rel="L4983">“I am not likely to leave Kent for some time. Promise me, therefore, to</li>
<li class="L4984" rel="L4984">come to Hunsford.”</li>
<li class="L4985" rel="L4985"></li>
<li class="L4986" rel="L4986">Elizabeth could not refuse, though she foresaw little pleasure in the</li>
<li class="L4987" rel="L4987">visit.</li>
<li class="L4988" rel="L4988"></li>
<li class="L4989" rel="L4989">“My father and Maria are coming to me in March,” added Charlotte, “and I</li>
<li class="L4990" rel="L4990">hope you will consent to be of the party. Indeed, Eliza, you will be as</li>
<li class="L4991" rel="L4991">welcome as either of them.”</li>
<li class="L4992" rel="L4992"></li>
<li class="L4993" rel="L4993">The wedding took place; the bride and bridegroom set off for Kent from</li>
<li class="L4994" rel="L4994">the church door, and everybody had as much to say, or to hear, on</li>
<li class="L4995" rel="L4995">the subject as usual. Elizabeth soon heard from her friend; and their</li>
<li class="L4996" rel="L4996">correspondence was as regular and frequent as it had ever been; that</li>
<li class="L4997" rel="L4997">it should be equally unreserved was impossible. Elizabeth could never</li>
<li class="L4998" rel="L4998">address her without feeling that all the comfort of intimacy was over,</li>
<li class="L4999" rel="L4999">and though determined not to slacken as a correspondent, it was for the</li>
<li class="L5000" rel="L5000">sake of what had been, rather than what was. Charlotte&#39;s first letters</li>
<li class="L5001" rel="L5001">were received with a good deal of eagerness; there could not but be</li>
<li class="L5002" rel="L5002">curiosity to know how she would speak of her new home, how she would</li>
<li class="L5003" rel="L5003">like Lady Catherine, and how happy she would dare pronounce herself to</li>
<li class="L5004" rel="L5004">be; though, when the letters were read, Elizabeth felt that Charlotte</li>
<li class="L5005" rel="L5005">expressed herself on every point exactly as she might have foreseen. She</li>
<li class="L5006" rel="L5006">wrote cheerfully, seemed surrounded with comforts, and mentioned nothing</li>
<li class="L5007" rel="L5007">which she could not praise. The house, furniture, neighbourhood, and</li>
<li class="L5008" rel="L5008">roads, were all to her taste, and Lady Catherine&#39;s behaviour was most</li>
<li class="L5009" rel="L5009">friendly and obliging. It was Mr. Collins&#39;s picture of Hunsford and</li>
<li class="L5010" rel="L5010">Rosings rationally softened; and Elizabeth perceived that she must wait</li>
<li class="L5011" rel="L5011">for her own visit there to know the rest.</li>
<li class="L5012" rel="L5012"></li>
<li class="L5013" rel="L5013">Jane had already written a few lines to her sister to announce their</li>
<li class="L5014" rel="L5014">safe arrival in London; and when she wrote again, Elizabeth hoped it</li>
<li class="L5015" rel="L5015">would be in her power to say something of the Bingleys.</li>
<li class="L5016" rel="L5016"></li>
<li class="L5017" rel="L5017">Her impatience for this second letter was as well rewarded as impatience</li>
<li class="L5018" rel="L5018">generally is. Jane had been a week in town without either seeing or</li>
<li class="L5019" rel="L5019">hearing from Caroline. She accounted for it, however, by supposing that</li>
<li class="L5020" rel="L5020">her last letter to her friend from Longbourn had by some accident been</li>
<li class="L5021" rel="L5021">lost.</li>
<li class="L5022" rel="L5022"></li>
<li class="L5023" rel="L5023">“My aunt,” she continued, “is going to-morrow into that part of the</li>
<li class="L5024" rel="L5024">town, and I shall take the opportunity of calling in Grosvenor Street.”</li>
<li class="L5025" rel="L5025"></li>
<li class="L5026" rel="L5026">She wrote again when the visit was paid, and she had seen Miss Bingley.</li>
<li class="L5027" rel="L5027">“I did not think Caroline in spirits,” were her words, “but she was very</li>
<li class="L5028" rel="L5028">glad to see me, and reproached me for giving her no notice of my coming</li>
<li class="L5029" rel="L5029">to London. I was right, therefore, my last letter had never reached</li>
<li class="L5030" rel="L5030">her. I inquired after their brother, of course. He was well, but so much</li>
<li class="L5031" rel="L5031">engaged with Mr. Darcy that they scarcely ever saw him. I found that</li>
<li class="L5032" rel="L5032">Miss Darcy was expected to dinner. I wish I could see her. My visit was</li>
<li class="L5033" rel="L5033">not long, as Caroline and Mrs. Hurst were going out. I dare say I shall</li>
<li class="L5034" rel="L5034">see them soon here.”</li>
<li class="L5035" rel="L5035"></li>
<li class="L5036" rel="L5036">Elizabeth shook her head over this letter. It convinced her that</li>
<li class="L5037" rel="L5037">accident only could discover to Mr. Bingley her sister&#39;s being in town.</li>
<li class="L5038" rel="L5038"></li>
<li class="L5039" rel="L5039">Four weeks passed away, and Jane saw nothing of him. She endeavoured to</li>
<li class="L5040" rel="L5040">persuade herself that she did not regret it; but she could no longer be</li>
<li class="L5041" rel="L5041">blind to Miss Bingley&#39;s inattention. After waiting at home every morning</li>
<li class="L5042" rel="L5042">for a fortnight, and inventing every evening a fresh excuse for her, the</li>
<li class="L5043" rel="L5043">visitor did at last appear; but the shortness of her stay, and yet more,</li>
<li class="L5044" rel="L5044">the alteration of her manner would allow Jane to deceive herself no</li>
<li class="L5045" rel="L5045">longer. The letter which she wrote on this occasion to her sister will</li>
<li class="L5046" rel="L5046">prove what she felt.</li>
<li class="L5047" rel="L5047"></li>
<li class="L5048" rel="L5048">“My dearest Lizzy will, I am sure, be incapable of triumphing in her</li>
<li class="L5049" rel="L5049">better judgement, at my expense, when I confess myself to have been</li>
<li class="L5050" rel="L5050">entirely deceived in Miss Bingley&#39;s regard for me. But, my dear sister,</li>
<li class="L5051" rel="L5051">though the event has proved you right, do not think me obstinate if I</li>
<li class="L5052" rel="L5052">still assert that, considering what her behaviour was, my confidence was</li>
<li class="L5053" rel="L5053">as natural as your suspicion. I do not at all comprehend her reason for</li>
<li class="L5054" rel="L5054">wishing to be intimate with me; but if the same circumstances were to</li>
<li class="L5055" rel="L5055">happen again, I am sure I should be deceived again. Caroline did not</li>
<li class="L5056" rel="L5056">return my visit till yesterday; and not a note, not a line, did I</li>
<li class="L5057" rel="L5057">receive in the meantime. When she did come, it was very evident that</li>
<li class="L5058" rel="L5058">she had no pleasure in it; she made a slight, formal apology, for not</li>
<li class="L5059" rel="L5059">calling before, said not a word of wishing to see me again, and was</li>
<li class="L5060" rel="L5060">in every respect so altered a creature, that when she went away I was</li>
<li class="L5061" rel="L5061">perfectly resolved to continue the acquaintance no longer. I pity,</li>
<li class="L5062" rel="L5062">though I cannot help blaming her. She was very wrong in singling me out</li>
<li class="L5063" rel="L5063">as she did; I can safely say that every advance to intimacy began on</li>
<li class="L5064" rel="L5064">her side. But I pity her, because she must feel that she has been acting</li>
<li class="L5065" rel="L5065">wrong, and because I am very sure that anxiety for her brother is the</li>
<li class="L5066" rel="L5066">cause of it. I need not explain myself farther; and though _we_ know</li>
<li class="L5067" rel="L5067">this anxiety to be quite needless, yet if she feels it, it will easily</li>
<li class="L5068" rel="L5068">account for her behaviour to me; and so deservedly dear as he is to</li>
<li class="L5069" rel="L5069">his sister, whatever anxiety she must feel on his behalf is natural and</li>
<li class="L5070" rel="L5070">amiable. I cannot but wonder, however, at her having any such fears now,</li>
<li class="L5071" rel="L5071">because, if he had at all cared about me, we must have met, long ago.</li>
<li class="L5072" rel="L5072">He knows of my being in town, I am certain, from something she said</li>
<li class="L5073" rel="L5073">herself; and yet it would seem, by her manner of talking, as if she</li>
<li class="L5074" rel="L5074">wanted to persuade herself that he is really partial to Miss Darcy. I</li>
<li class="L5075" rel="L5075">cannot understand it. If I were not afraid of judging harshly, I should</li>
<li class="L5076" rel="L5076">be almost tempted to say that there is a strong appearance of duplicity</li>
<li class="L5077" rel="L5077">in all this. But I will endeavour to banish every painful thought,</li>
<li class="L5078" rel="L5078">and think only of what will make me happy--your affection, and the</li>
<li class="L5079" rel="L5079">invariable kindness of my dear uncle and aunt. Let me hear from you very</li>
<li class="L5080" rel="L5080">soon. Miss Bingley said something of his never returning to Netherfield</li>
<li class="L5081" rel="L5081">again, of giving up the house, but not with any certainty. We had better</li>
<li class="L5082" rel="L5082">not mention it. I am extremely glad that you have such pleasant accounts</li>
<li class="L5083" rel="L5083">from our friends at Hunsford. Pray go to see them, with Sir William and</li>
<li class="L5084" rel="L5084">Maria. I am sure you will be very comfortable there.--Yours, etc.”</li>
<li class="L5085" rel="L5085"></li>
<li class="L5086" rel="L5086">This letter gave Elizabeth some pain; but her spirits returned as she</li>
<li class="L5087" rel="L5087">considered that Jane would no longer be duped, by the sister at least.</li>
<li class="L5088" rel="L5088">All expectation from the brother was now absolutely over. She would not</li>
<li class="L5089" rel="L5089">even wish for a renewal of his attentions. His character sunk on</li>
<li class="L5090" rel="L5090">every review of it; and as a punishment for him, as well as a possible</li>
<li class="L5091" rel="L5091">advantage to Jane, she seriously hoped he might really soon marry Mr.</li>
<li class="L5092" rel="L5092">Darcy&#39;s sister, as by Wickham&#39;s account, she would make him abundantly</li>
<li class="L5093" rel="L5093">regret what he had thrown away.</li>
<li class="L5094" rel="L5094"></li>
<li class="L5095" rel="L5095">Mrs. Gardiner about this time reminded Elizabeth of her promise</li>
<li class="L5096" rel="L5096">concerning that gentleman, and required information; and Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L5097" rel="L5097">had such to send as might rather give contentment to her aunt than to</li>
<li class="L5098" rel="L5098">herself. His apparent partiality had subsided, his attentions were over,</li>
<li class="L5099" rel="L5099">he was the admirer of some one else. Elizabeth was watchful enough to</li>
<li class="L5100" rel="L5100">see it all, but she could see it and write of it without material pain.</li>
<li class="L5101" rel="L5101">Her heart had been but slightly touched, and her vanity was satisfied</li>
<li class="L5102" rel="L5102">with believing that _she_ would have been his only choice, had fortune</li>
<li class="L5103" rel="L5103">permitted it. The sudden acquisition of ten thousand pounds was the most</li>
<li class="L5104" rel="L5104">remarkable charm of the young lady to whom he was now rendering himself</li>
<li class="L5105" rel="L5105">agreeable; but Elizabeth, less clear-sighted perhaps in this case than</li>
<li class="L5106" rel="L5106">in Charlotte&#39;s, did not quarrel with him for his wish of independence.</li>
<li class="L5107" rel="L5107">Nothing, on the contrary, could be more natural; and while able to</li>
<li class="L5108" rel="L5108">suppose that it cost him a few struggles to relinquish her, she was</li>
<li class="L5109" rel="L5109">ready to allow it a wise and desirable measure for both, and could very</li>
<li class="L5110" rel="L5110">sincerely wish him happy.</li>
<li class="L5111" rel="L5111"></li>
<li class="L5112" rel="L5112">All this was acknowledged to Mrs. Gardiner; and after relating the</li>
<li class="L5113" rel="L5113">circumstances, she thus went on: “I am now convinced, my dear aunt, that</li>
<li class="L5114" rel="L5114">I have never been much in love; for had I really experienced that pure</li>
<li class="L5115" rel="L5115">and elevating passion, I should at present detest his very name, and</li>
<li class="L5116" rel="L5116">wish him all manner of evil. But my feelings are not only cordial</li>
<li class="L5117" rel="L5117">towards _him_; they are even impartial towards Miss King. I cannot find</li>
<li class="L5118" rel="L5118">out that I hate her at all, or that I am in the least unwilling to</li>
<li class="L5119" rel="L5119">think her a very good sort of girl. There can be no love in all this. My</li>
<li class="L5120" rel="L5120">watchfulness has been effectual; and though I certainly should be a more</li>
<li class="L5121" rel="L5121">interesting object to all my acquaintances were I distractedly in love</li>
<li class="L5122" rel="L5122">with him, I cannot say that I regret my comparative insignificance.</li>
<li class="L5123" rel="L5123">Importance may sometimes be purchased too dearly. Kitty and Lydia take</li>
<li class="L5124" rel="L5124">his defection much more to heart than I do. They are young in the</li>
<li class="L5125" rel="L5125">ways of the world, and not yet open to the mortifying conviction that</li>
<li class="L5126" rel="L5126">handsome young men must have something to live on as well as the plain.”</li>
<li class="L5127" rel="L5127"></li>
<li class="L5128" rel="L5128"></li>
<li class="L5129" rel="L5129"></li>
<li class="L5130" rel="L5130">Chapter 27</li>
<li class="L5131" rel="L5131"></li>
<li class="L5132" rel="L5132"></li>
<li class="L5133" rel="L5133">With no greater events than these in the Longbourn family, and otherwise</li>
<li class="L5134" rel="L5134">diversified by little beyond the walks to Meryton, sometimes dirty and</li>
<li class="L5135" rel="L5135">sometimes cold, did January and February pass away. March was to take</li>
<li class="L5136" rel="L5136">Elizabeth to Hunsford. She had not at first thought very seriously of</li>
<li class="L5137" rel="L5137">going thither; but Charlotte, she soon found, was depending on the plan</li>
<li class="L5138" rel="L5138">and she gradually learned to consider it herself with greater pleasure</li>
<li class="L5139" rel="L5139">as well as greater certainty. Absence had increased her desire of seeing</li>
<li class="L5140" rel="L5140">Charlotte again, and weakened her disgust of Mr. Collins. There</li>
<li class="L5141" rel="L5141">was novelty in the scheme, and as, with such a mother and such</li>
<li class="L5142" rel="L5142">uncompanionable sisters, home could not be faultless, a little change</li>
<li class="L5143" rel="L5143">was not unwelcome for its own sake. The journey would moreover give her</li>
<li class="L5144" rel="L5144">a peep at Jane; and, in short, as the time drew near, she would have</li>
<li class="L5145" rel="L5145">been very sorry for any delay. Everything, however, went on smoothly,</li>
<li class="L5146" rel="L5146">and was finally settled according to Charlotte&#39;s first sketch. She was</li>
<li class="L5147" rel="L5147">to accompany Sir William and his second daughter. The improvement</li>
<li class="L5148" rel="L5148">of spending a night in London was added in time, and the plan became</li>
<li class="L5149" rel="L5149">perfect as plan could be.</li>
<li class="L5150" rel="L5150"></li>
<li class="L5151" rel="L5151">The only pain was in leaving her father, who would certainly miss her,</li>
<li class="L5152" rel="L5152">and who, when it came to the point, so little liked her going, that he</li>
<li class="L5153" rel="L5153">told her to write to him, and almost promised to answer her letter.</li>
<li class="L5154" rel="L5154"></li>
<li class="L5155" rel="L5155">The farewell between herself and Mr. Wickham was perfectly friendly; on</li>
<li class="L5156" rel="L5156">his side even more. His present pursuit could not make him forget that</li>
<li class="L5157" rel="L5157">Elizabeth had been the first to excite and to deserve his attention, the</li>
<li class="L5158" rel="L5158">first to listen and to pity, the first to be admired; and in his manner</li>
<li class="L5159" rel="L5159">of bidding her adieu, wishing her every enjoyment, reminding her of</li>
<li class="L5160" rel="L5160">what she was to expect in Lady Catherine de Bourgh, and trusting their</li>
<li class="L5161" rel="L5161">opinion of her--their opinion of everybody--would always coincide, there</li>
<li class="L5162" rel="L5162">was a solicitude, an interest which she felt must ever attach her to</li>
<li class="L5163" rel="L5163">him with a most sincere regard; and she parted from him convinced that,</li>
<li class="L5164" rel="L5164">whether married or single, he must always be her model of the amiable</li>
<li class="L5165" rel="L5165">and pleasing.</li>
<li class="L5166" rel="L5166"></li>
<li class="L5167" rel="L5167">Her fellow-travellers the next day were not of a kind to make her</li>
<li class="L5168" rel="L5168">think him less agreeable. Sir William Lucas, and his daughter Maria, a</li>
<li class="L5169" rel="L5169">good-humoured girl, but as empty-headed as himself, had nothing to say</li>
<li class="L5170" rel="L5170">that could be worth hearing, and were listened to with about as much</li>
<li class="L5171" rel="L5171">delight as the rattle of the chaise. Elizabeth loved absurdities, but</li>
<li class="L5172" rel="L5172">she had known Sir William&#39;s too long. He could tell her nothing new of</li>
<li class="L5173" rel="L5173">the wonders of his presentation and knighthood; and his civilities were</li>
<li class="L5174" rel="L5174">worn out, like his information.</li>
<li class="L5175" rel="L5175"></li>
<li class="L5176" rel="L5176">It was a journey of only twenty-four miles, and they began it so early</li>
<li class="L5177" rel="L5177">as to be in Gracechurch Street by noon. As they drove to Mr. Gardiner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L5178" rel="L5178">door, Jane was at a drawing-room window watching their arrival; when</li>
<li class="L5179" rel="L5179">they entered the passage she was there to welcome them, and Elizabeth,</li>
<li class="L5180" rel="L5180">looking earnestly in her face, was pleased to see it healthful and</li>
<li class="L5181" rel="L5181">lovely as ever. On the stairs were a troop of little boys and girls,</li>
<li class="L5182" rel="L5182">whose eagerness for their cousin&#39;s appearance would not allow them to</li>
<li class="L5183" rel="L5183">wait in the drawing-room, and whose shyness, as they had not seen</li>
<li class="L5184" rel="L5184">her for a twelvemonth, prevented their coming lower. All was joy and</li>
<li class="L5185" rel="L5185">kindness. The day passed most pleasantly away; the morning in bustle and</li>
<li class="L5186" rel="L5186">shopping, and the evening at one of the theatres.</li>
<li class="L5187" rel="L5187"></li>
<li class="L5188" rel="L5188">Elizabeth then contrived to sit by her aunt. Their first object was her</li>
<li class="L5189" rel="L5189">sister; and she was more grieved than astonished to hear, in reply to</li>
<li class="L5190" rel="L5190">her minute inquiries, that though Jane always struggled to support her</li>
<li class="L5191" rel="L5191">spirits, there were periods of dejection. It was reasonable, however,</li>
<li class="L5192" rel="L5192">to hope that they would not continue long. Mrs. Gardiner gave her the</li>
<li class="L5193" rel="L5193">particulars also of Miss Bingley&#39;s visit in Gracechurch Street, and</li>
<li class="L5194" rel="L5194">repeated conversations occurring at different times between Jane and</li>
<li class="L5195" rel="L5195">herself, which proved that the former had, from her heart, given up the</li>
<li class="L5196" rel="L5196">acquaintance.</li>
<li class="L5197" rel="L5197"></li>
<li class="L5198" rel="L5198">Mrs. Gardiner then rallied her niece on Wickham&#39;s desertion, and</li>
<li class="L5199" rel="L5199">complimented her on bearing it so well.</li>
<li class="L5200" rel="L5200"></li>
<li class="L5201" rel="L5201">“But my dear Elizabeth,” she added, “what sort of girl is Miss King? I</li>
<li class="L5202" rel="L5202">should be sorry to think our friend mercenary.”</li>
<li class="L5203" rel="L5203"></li>
<li class="L5204" rel="L5204">“Pray, my dear aunt, what is the difference in matrimonial affairs,</li>
<li class="L5205" rel="L5205">between the mercenary and the prudent motive? Where does discretion end,</li>
<li class="L5206" rel="L5206">and avarice begin? Last Christmas you were afraid of his marrying me,</li>
<li class="L5207" rel="L5207">because it would be imprudent; and now, because he is trying to get</li>
<li class="L5208" rel="L5208">a girl with only ten thousand pounds, you want to find out that he is</li>
<li class="L5209" rel="L5209">mercenary.”</li>
<li class="L5210" rel="L5210"></li>
<li class="L5211" rel="L5211">“If you will only tell me what sort of girl Miss King is, I shall know</li>
<li class="L5212" rel="L5212">what to think.”</li>
<li class="L5213" rel="L5213"></li>
<li class="L5214" rel="L5214">“She is a very good kind of girl, I believe. I know no harm of her.”</li>
<li class="L5215" rel="L5215"></li>
<li class="L5216" rel="L5216">“But he paid her not the smallest attention till her grandfather&#39;s death</li>
<li class="L5217" rel="L5217">made her mistress of this fortune.”</li>
<li class="L5218" rel="L5218"></li>
<li class="L5219" rel="L5219">“No--why should he? If it were not allowable for him to gain _my_</li>
<li class="L5220" rel="L5220">affections because I had no money, what occasion could there be for</li>
<li class="L5221" rel="L5221">making love to a girl whom he did not care about, and who was equally</li>
<li class="L5222" rel="L5222">poor?”</li>
<li class="L5223" rel="L5223"></li>
<li class="L5224" rel="L5224">“But there seems an indelicacy in directing his attentions towards her</li>
<li class="L5225" rel="L5225">so soon after this event.”</li>
<li class="L5226" rel="L5226"></li>
<li class="L5227" rel="L5227">“A man in distressed circumstances has not time for all those elegant</li>
<li class="L5228" rel="L5228">decorums which other people may observe. If _she_ does not object to it,</li>
<li class="L5229" rel="L5229">why should _we_?”</li>
<li class="L5230" rel="L5230"></li>
<li class="L5231" rel="L5231">“_Her_ not objecting does not justify _him_. It only shows her being</li>
<li class="L5232" rel="L5232">deficient in something herself--sense or feeling.”</li>
<li class="L5233" rel="L5233"></li>
<li class="L5234" rel="L5234">“Well,” cried Elizabeth, “have it as you choose. _He_ shall be</li>
<li class="L5235" rel="L5235">mercenary, and _she_ shall be foolish.”</li>
<li class="L5236" rel="L5236"></li>
<li class="L5237" rel="L5237">“No, Lizzy, that is what I do _not_ choose. I should be sorry, you know,</li>
<li class="L5238" rel="L5238">to think ill of a young man who has lived so long in Derbyshire.”</li>
<li class="L5239" rel="L5239"></li>
<li class="L5240" rel="L5240">“Oh! if that is all, I have a very poor opinion of young men who live in</li>
<li class="L5241" rel="L5241">Derbyshire; and their intimate friends who live in Hertfordshire are not</li>
<li class="L5242" rel="L5242">much better. I am sick of them all. Thank Heaven! I am going to-morrow</li>
<li class="L5243" rel="L5243">where I shall find a man who has not one agreeable quality, who has</li>
<li class="L5244" rel="L5244">neither manner nor sense to recommend him. Stupid men are the only ones</li>
<li class="L5245" rel="L5245">worth knowing, after all.”</li>
<li class="L5246" rel="L5246"></li>
<li class="L5247" rel="L5247">“Take care, Lizzy; that speech savours strongly of disappointment.”</li>
<li class="L5248" rel="L5248"></li>
<li class="L5249" rel="L5249">Before they were separated by the conclusion of the play, she had the</li>
<li class="L5250" rel="L5250">unexpected happiness of an invitation to accompany her uncle and aunt in</li>
<li class="L5251" rel="L5251">a tour of pleasure which they proposed taking in the summer.</li>
<li class="L5252" rel="L5252"></li>
<li class="L5253" rel="L5253">“We have not determined how far it shall carry us,” said Mrs. Gardiner,</li>
<li class="L5254" rel="L5254">“but, perhaps, to the Lakes.”</li>
<li class="L5255" rel="L5255"></li>
<li class="L5256" rel="L5256">No scheme could have been more agreeable to Elizabeth, and her</li>
<li class="L5257" rel="L5257">acceptance of the invitation was most ready and grateful. “Oh, my dear,</li>
<li class="L5258" rel="L5258">dear aunt,” she rapturously cried, “what delight! what felicity! You</li>
<li class="L5259" rel="L5259">give me fresh life and vigour. Adieu to disappointment and spleen. What</li>
<li class="L5260" rel="L5260">are young men to rocks and mountains? Oh! what hours of transport</li>
<li class="L5261" rel="L5261">we shall spend! And when we _do_ return, it shall not be like other</li>
<li class="L5262" rel="L5262">travellers, without being able to give one accurate idea of anything. We</li>
<li class="L5263" rel="L5263">_will_ know where we have gone--we _will_ recollect what we have seen.</li>
<li class="L5264" rel="L5264">Lakes, mountains, and rivers shall not be jumbled together in our</li>
<li class="L5265" rel="L5265">imaginations; nor when we attempt to describe any particular scene,</li>
<li class="L5266" rel="L5266">will we begin quarreling about its relative situation. Let _our_</li>
<li class="L5267" rel="L5267">first effusions be less insupportable than those of the generality of</li>
<li class="L5268" rel="L5268">travellers.”</li>
<li class="L5269" rel="L5269"></li>
<li class="L5270" rel="L5270"></li>
<li class="L5271" rel="L5271"></li>
<li class="L5272" rel="L5272">Chapter 28</li>
<li class="L5273" rel="L5273"></li>
<li class="L5274" rel="L5274"></li>
<li class="L5275" rel="L5275">Every object in the next day&#39;s journey was new and interesting to</li>
<li class="L5276" rel="L5276">Elizabeth; and her spirits were in a state of enjoyment; for she had</li>
<li class="L5277" rel="L5277">seen her sister looking so well as to banish all fear for her health,</li>
<li class="L5278" rel="L5278">and the prospect of her northern tour was a constant source of delight.</li>
<li class="L5279" rel="L5279"></li>
<li class="L5280" rel="L5280">When they left the high road for the lane to Hunsford, every eye was in</li>
<li class="L5281" rel="L5281">search of the Parsonage, and every turning expected to bring it in view.</li>
<li class="L5282" rel="L5282">The palings of Rosings Park was their boundary on one side. Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L5283" rel="L5283">smiled at the recollection of all that she had heard of its inhabitants.</li>
<li class="L5284" rel="L5284"></li>
<li class="L5285" rel="L5285">At length the Parsonage was discernible. The garden sloping to the</li>
<li class="L5286" rel="L5286">road, the house standing in it, the green pales, and the laurel hedge,</li>
<li class="L5287" rel="L5287">everything declared they were arriving. Mr. Collins and Charlotte</li>
<li class="L5288" rel="L5288">appeared at the door, and the carriage stopped at the small gate which</li>
<li class="L5289" rel="L5289">led by a short gravel walk to the house, amidst the nods and smiles of</li>
<li class="L5290" rel="L5290">the whole party. In a moment they were all out of the chaise, rejoicing</li>
<li class="L5291" rel="L5291">at the sight of each other. Mrs. Collins welcomed her friend with the</li>
<li class="L5292" rel="L5292">liveliest pleasure, and Elizabeth was more and more satisfied with</li>
<li class="L5293" rel="L5293">coming when she found herself so affectionately received. She saw</li>
<li class="L5294" rel="L5294">instantly that her cousin&#39;s manners were not altered by his marriage;</li>
<li class="L5295" rel="L5295">his formal civility was just what it had been, and he detained her some</li>
<li class="L5296" rel="L5296">minutes at the gate to hear and satisfy his inquiries after all her</li>
<li class="L5297" rel="L5297">family. They were then, with no other delay than his pointing out the</li>
<li class="L5298" rel="L5298">neatness of the entrance, taken into the house; and as soon as they</li>
<li class="L5299" rel="L5299">were in the parlour, he welcomed them a second time, with ostentatious</li>
<li class="L5300" rel="L5300">formality to his humble abode, and punctually repeated all his wife&#39;s</li>
<li class="L5301" rel="L5301">offers of refreshment.</li>
<li class="L5302" rel="L5302"></li>
<li class="L5303" rel="L5303">Elizabeth was prepared to see him in his glory; and she could not help</li>
<li class="L5304" rel="L5304">in fancying that in displaying the good proportion of the room, its</li>
<li class="L5305" rel="L5305">aspect and its furniture, he addressed himself particularly to her,</li>
<li class="L5306" rel="L5306">as if wishing to make her feel what she had lost in refusing him. But</li>
<li class="L5307" rel="L5307">though everything seemed neat and comfortable, she was not able to</li>
<li class="L5308" rel="L5308">gratify him by any sigh of repentance, and rather looked with wonder at</li>
<li class="L5309" rel="L5309">her friend that she could have so cheerful an air with such a companion.</li>
<li class="L5310" rel="L5310">When Mr. Collins said anything of which his wife might reasonably be</li>
<li class="L5311" rel="L5311">ashamed, which certainly was not unseldom, she involuntarily turned her</li>
<li class="L5312" rel="L5312">eye on Charlotte. Once or twice she could discern a faint blush; but</li>
<li class="L5313" rel="L5313">in general Charlotte wisely did not hear. After sitting long enough to</li>
<li class="L5314" rel="L5314">admire every article of furniture in the room, from the sideboard to</li>
<li class="L5315" rel="L5315">the fender, to give an account of their journey, and of all that had</li>
<li class="L5316" rel="L5316">happened in London, Mr. Collins invited them to take a stroll in the</li>
<li class="L5317" rel="L5317">garden, which was large and well laid out, and to the cultivation of</li>
<li class="L5318" rel="L5318">which he attended himself. To work in this garden was one of his most</li>
<li class="L5319" rel="L5319">respectable pleasures; and Elizabeth admired the command of countenance</li>
<li class="L5320" rel="L5320">with which Charlotte talked of the healthfulness of the exercise, and</li>
<li class="L5321" rel="L5321">owned she encouraged it as much as possible. Here, leading the way</li>
<li class="L5322" rel="L5322">through every walk and cross walk, and scarcely allowing them an</li>
<li class="L5323" rel="L5323">interval to utter the praises he asked for, every view was pointed out</li>
<li class="L5324" rel="L5324">with a minuteness which left beauty entirely behind. He could number the</li>
<li class="L5325" rel="L5325">fields in every direction, and could tell how many trees there were in</li>
<li class="L5326" rel="L5326">the most distant clump. But of all the views which his garden, or which</li>
<li class="L5327" rel="L5327">the country or kingdom could boast, none were to be compared with the</li>
<li class="L5328" rel="L5328">prospect of Rosings, afforded by an opening in the trees that bordered</li>
<li class="L5329" rel="L5329">the park nearly opposite the front of his house. It was a handsome</li>
<li class="L5330" rel="L5330">modern building, well situated on rising ground.</li>
<li class="L5331" rel="L5331"></li>
<li class="L5332" rel="L5332">From his garden, Mr. Collins would have led them round his two meadows;</li>
<li class="L5333" rel="L5333">but the ladies, not having shoes to encounter the remains of a white</li>
<li class="L5334" rel="L5334">frost, turned back; and while Sir William accompanied him, Charlotte</li>
<li class="L5335" rel="L5335">took her sister and friend over the house, extremely well pleased,</li>
<li class="L5336" rel="L5336">probably, to have the opportunity of showing it without her husband&#39;s</li>
<li class="L5337" rel="L5337">help. It was rather small, but well built and convenient; and everything</li>
<li class="L5338" rel="L5338">was fitted up and arranged with a neatness and consistency of which</li>
<li class="L5339" rel="L5339">Elizabeth gave Charlotte all the credit. When Mr. Collins could be</li>
<li class="L5340" rel="L5340">forgotten, there was really an air of great comfort throughout, and by</li>
<li class="L5341" rel="L5341">Charlotte&#39;s evident enjoyment of it, Elizabeth supposed he must be often</li>
<li class="L5342" rel="L5342">forgotten.</li>
<li class="L5343" rel="L5343"></li>
<li class="L5344" rel="L5344">She had already learnt that Lady Catherine was still in the country. It</li>
<li class="L5345" rel="L5345">was spoken of again while they were at dinner, when Mr. Collins joining</li>
<li class="L5346" rel="L5346">in, observed:</li>
<li class="L5347" rel="L5347"></li>
<li class="L5348" rel="L5348">“Yes, Miss Elizabeth, you will have the honour of seeing Lady Catherine</li>
<li class="L5349" rel="L5349">de Bourgh on the ensuing Sunday at church, and I need not say you will</li>
<li class="L5350" rel="L5350">be delighted with her. She is all affability and condescension, and I</li>
<li class="L5351" rel="L5351">doubt not but you will be honoured with some portion of her notice</li>
<li class="L5352" rel="L5352">when service is over. I have scarcely any hesitation in saying she</li>
<li class="L5353" rel="L5353">will include you and my sister Maria in every invitation with which she</li>
<li class="L5354" rel="L5354">honours us during your stay here. Her behaviour to my dear Charlotte is</li>
<li class="L5355" rel="L5355">charming. We dine at Rosings twice every week, and are never allowed</li>
<li class="L5356" rel="L5356">to walk home. Her ladyship&#39;s carriage is regularly ordered for us. I</li>
<li class="L5357" rel="L5357">_should_ say, one of her ladyship&#39;s carriages, for she has several.”</li>
<li class="L5358" rel="L5358"></li>
<li class="L5359" rel="L5359">“Lady Catherine is a very respectable, sensible woman indeed,” added</li>
<li class="L5360" rel="L5360">Charlotte, “and a most attentive neighbour.”</li>
<li class="L5361" rel="L5361"></li>
<li class="L5362" rel="L5362">“Very true, my dear, that is exactly what I say. She is the sort of</li>
<li class="L5363" rel="L5363">woman whom one cannot regard with too much deference.”</li>
<li class="L5364" rel="L5364"></li>
<li class="L5365" rel="L5365">The evening was spent chiefly in talking over Hertfordshire news,</li>
<li class="L5366" rel="L5366">and telling again what had already been written; and when it closed,</li>
<li class="L5367" rel="L5367">Elizabeth, in the solitude of her chamber, had to meditate upon</li>
<li class="L5368" rel="L5368">Charlotte&#39;s degree of contentment, to understand her address in guiding,</li>
<li class="L5369" rel="L5369">and composure in bearing with, her husband, and to acknowledge that it</li>
<li class="L5370" rel="L5370">was all done very well. She had also to anticipate how her visit</li>
<li class="L5371" rel="L5371">would pass, the quiet tenor of their usual employments, the vexatious</li>
<li class="L5372" rel="L5372">interruptions of Mr. Collins, and the gaieties of their intercourse with</li>
<li class="L5373" rel="L5373">Rosings. A lively imagination soon settled it all.</li>
<li class="L5374" rel="L5374"></li>
<li class="L5375" rel="L5375">About the middle of the next day, as she was in her room getting ready</li>
<li class="L5376" rel="L5376">for a walk, a sudden noise below seemed to speak the whole house in</li>
<li class="L5377" rel="L5377">confusion; and, after listening a moment, she heard somebody running</li>
<li class="L5378" rel="L5378">up stairs in a violent hurry, and calling loudly after her. She opened</li>
<li class="L5379" rel="L5379">the door and met Maria in the landing place, who, breathless with</li>
<li class="L5380" rel="L5380">agitation, cried out--</li>
<li class="L5381" rel="L5381"></li>
<li class="L5382" rel="L5382">“Oh, my dear Eliza! pray make haste and come into the dining-room, for</li>
<li class="L5383" rel="L5383">there is such a sight to be seen! I will not tell you what it is. Make</li>
<li class="L5384" rel="L5384">haste, and come down this moment.”</li>
<li class="L5385" rel="L5385"></li>
<li class="L5386" rel="L5386">Elizabeth asked questions in vain; Maria would tell her nothing more,</li>
<li class="L5387" rel="L5387">and down they ran into the dining-room, which fronted the lane, in</li>
<li class="L5388" rel="L5388">quest of this wonder; It was two ladies stopping in a low phaeton at the</li>
<li class="L5389" rel="L5389">garden gate.</li>
<li class="L5390" rel="L5390"></li>
<li class="L5391" rel="L5391">“And is this all?” cried Elizabeth. “I expected at least that the pigs</li>
<li class="L5392" rel="L5392">were got into the garden, and here is nothing but Lady Catherine and her</li>
<li class="L5393" rel="L5393">daughter.”</li>
<li class="L5394" rel="L5394"></li>
<li class="L5395" rel="L5395">“La! my dear,” said Maria, quite shocked at the mistake, “it is not</li>
<li class="L5396" rel="L5396">Lady Catherine. The old lady is Mrs. Jenkinson, who lives with them;</li>
<li class="L5397" rel="L5397">the other is Miss de Bourgh. Only look at her. She is quite a little</li>
<li class="L5398" rel="L5398">creature. Who would have thought that she could be so thin and small?”</li>
<li class="L5399" rel="L5399"></li>
<li class="L5400" rel="L5400">“She is abominably rude to keep Charlotte out of doors in all this wind.</li>
<li class="L5401" rel="L5401">Why does she not come in?”</li>
<li class="L5402" rel="L5402"></li>
<li class="L5403" rel="L5403">“Oh, Charlotte says she hardly ever does. It is the greatest of favours</li>
<li class="L5404" rel="L5404">when Miss de Bourgh comes in.”</li>
<li class="L5405" rel="L5405"></li>
<li class="L5406" rel="L5406">“I like her appearance,” said Elizabeth, struck with other ideas. “She</li>
<li class="L5407" rel="L5407">looks sickly and cross. Yes, she will do for him very well. She will</li>
<li class="L5408" rel="L5408">make him a very proper wife.”</li>
<li class="L5409" rel="L5409"></li>
<li class="L5410" rel="L5410">Mr. Collins and Charlotte were both standing at the gate in conversation</li>
<li class="L5411" rel="L5411">with the ladies; and Sir William, to Elizabeth&#39;s high diversion, was</li>
<li class="L5412" rel="L5412">stationed in the doorway, in earnest contemplation of the greatness</li>
<li class="L5413" rel="L5413">before him, and constantly bowing whenever Miss de Bourgh looked that</li>
<li class="L5414" rel="L5414">way.</li>
<li class="L5415" rel="L5415"></li>
<li class="L5416" rel="L5416">At length there was nothing more to be said; the ladies drove on, and</li>
<li class="L5417" rel="L5417">the others returned into the house. Mr. Collins no sooner saw the two</li>
<li class="L5418" rel="L5418">girls than he began to congratulate them on their good fortune, which</li>
<li class="L5419" rel="L5419">Charlotte explained by letting them know that the whole party was asked</li>
<li class="L5420" rel="L5420">to dine at Rosings the next day.</li>
<li class="L5421" rel="L5421"></li>
<li class="L5422" rel="L5422"></li>
<li class="L5423" rel="L5423"></li>
<li class="L5424" rel="L5424">Chapter 29</li>
<li class="L5425" rel="L5425"></li>
<li class="L5426" rel="L5426"></li>
<li class="L5427" rel="L5427">Mr. Collins&#39;s triumph, in consequence of this invitation, was complete.</li>
<li class="L5428" rel="L5428">The power of displaying the grandeur of his patroness to his wondering</li>
<li class="L5429" rel="L5429">visitors, and of letting them see her civility towards himself and his</li>
<li class="L5430" rel="L5430">wife, was exactly what he had wished for; and that an opportunity</li>
<li class="L5431" rel="L5431">of doing it should be given so soon, was such an instance of Lady</li>
<li class="L5432" rel="L5432">Catherine&#39;s condescension, as he knew not how to admire enough.</li>
<li class="L5433" rel="L5433"></li>
<li class="L5434" rel="L5434">“I confess,” said he, “that I should not have been at all surprised by</li>
<li class="L5435" rel="L5435">her ladyship&#39;s asking us on Sunday to drink tea and spend the evening at</li>
<li class="L5436" rel="L5436">Rosings. I rather expected, from my knowledge of her affability, that it</li>
<li class="L5437" rel="L5437">would happen. But who could have foreseen such an attention as this? Who</li>
<li class="L5438" rel="L5438">could have imagined that we should receive an invitation to dine there</li>
<li class="L5439" rel="L5439">(an invitation, moreover, including the whole party) so immediately</li>
<li class="L5440" rel="L5440">after your arrival!”</li>
<li class="L5441" rel="L5441"></li>
<li class="L5442" rel="L5442">“I am the less surprised at what has happened,” replied Sir William,</li>
<li class="L5443" rel="L5443">“from that knowledge of what the manners of the great really are, which</li>
<li class="L5444" rel="L5444">my situation in life has allowed me to acquire. About the court, such</li>
<li class="L5445" rel="L5445">instances of elegant breeding are not uncommon.”</li>
<li class="L5446" rel="L5446"></li>
<li class="L5447" rel="L5447">Scarcely anything was talked of the whole day or next morning but their</li>
<li class="L5448" rel="L5448">visit to Rosings. Mr. Collins was carefully instructing them in what</li>
<li class="L5449" rel="L5449">they were to expect, that the sight of such rooms, so many servants, and</li>
<li class="L5450" rel="L5450">so splendid a dinner, might not wholly overpower them.</li>
<li class="L5451" rel="L5451"></li>
<li class="L5452" rel="L5452">When the ladies were separating for the toilette, he said to Elizabeth--</li>
<li class="L5453" rel="L5453"></li>
<li class="L5454" rel="L5454">“Do not make yourself uneasy, my dear cousin, about your apparel. Lady</li>
<li class="L5455" rel="L5455">Catherine is far from requiring that elegance of dress in us which</li>
<li class="L5456" rel="L5456">becomes herself and her daughter. I would advise you merely to put on</li>
<li class="L5457" rel="L5457">whatever of your clothes is superior to the rest--there is no occasion</li>
<li class="L5458" rel="L5458">for anything more. Lady Catherine will not think the worse of you</li>
<li class="L5459" rel="L5459">for being simply dressed. She likes to have the distinction of rank</li>
<li class="L5460" rel="L5460">preserved.”</li>
<li class="L5461" rel="L5461"></li>
<li class="L5462" rel="L5462">While they were dressing, he came two or three times to their different</li>
<li class="L5463" rel="L5463">doors, to recommend their being quick, as Lady Catherine very much</li>
<li class="L5464" rel="L5464">objected to be kept waiting for her dinner. Such formidable accounts of</li>
<li class="L5465" rel="L5465">her ladyship, and her manner of living, quite frightened Maria Lucas</li>
<li class="L5466" rel="L5466">who had been little used to company, and she looked forward to her</li>
<li class="L5467" rel="L5467">introduction at Rosings with as much apprehension as her father had done</li>
<li class="L5468" rel="L5468">to his presentation at St. James&#39;s.</li>
<li class="L5469" rel="L5469"></li>
<li class="L5470" rel="L5470">As the weather was fine, they had a pleasant walk of about half a</li>
<li class="L5471" rel="L5471">mile across the park. Every park has its beauty and its prospects; and</li>
<li class="L5472" rel="L5472">Elizabeth saw much to be pleased with, though she could not be in such</li>
<li class="L5473" rel="L5473">raptures as Mr. Collins expected the scene to inspire, and was but</li>
<li class="L5474" rel="L5474">slightly affected by his enumeration of the windows in front of the</li>
<li class="L5475" rel="L5475">house, and his relation of what the glazing altogether had originally</li>
<li class="L5476" rel="L5476">cost Sir Lewis de Bourgh.</li>
<li class="L5477" rel="L5477"></li>
<li class="L5478" rel="L5478">When they ascended the steps to the hall, Maria&#39;s alarm was every</li>
<li class="L5479" rel="L5479">moment increasing, and even Sir William did not look perfectly calm.</li>
<li class="L5480" rel="L5480">Elizabeth&#39;s courage did not fail her. She had heard nothing of Lady</li>
<li class="L5481" rel="L5481">Catherine that spoke her awful from any extraordinary talents or</li>
<li class="L5482" rel="L5482">miraculous virtue, and the mere stateliness of money or rank she thought</li>
<li class="L5483" rel="L5483">she could witness without trepidation.</li>
<li class="L5484" rel="L5484"></li>
<li class="L5485" rel="L5485">From the entrance-hall, of which Mr. Collins pointed out, with a</li>
<li class="L5486" rel="L5486">rapturous air, the fine proportion and the finished ornaments, they</li>
<li class="L5487" rel="L5487">followed the servants through an ante-chamber, to the room where Lady</li>
<li class="L5488" rel="L5488">Catherine, her daughter, and Mrs. Jenkinson were sitting. Her ladyship,</li>
<li class="L5489" rel="L5489">with great condescension, arose to receive them; and as Mrs. Collins had</li>
<li class="L5490" rel="L5490">settled it with her husband that the office of introduction should</li>
<li class="L5491" rel="L5491">be hers, it was performed in a proper manner, without any of those</li>
<li class="L5492" rel="L5492">apologies and thanks which he would have thought necessary.</li>
<li class="L5493" rel="L5493"></li>
<li class="L5494" rel="L5494">In spite of having been at St. James&#39;s, Sir William was so completely</li>
<li class="L5495" rel="L5495">awed by the grandeur surrounding him, that he had but just courage</li>
<li class="L5496" rel="L5496">enough to make a very low bow, and take his seat without saying a word;</li>
<li class="L5497" rel="L5497">and his daughter, frightened almost out of her senses, sat on the edge</li>
<li class="L5498" rel="L5498">of her chair, not knowing which way to look. Elizabeth found herself</li>
<li class="L5499" rel="L5499">quite equal to the scene, and could observe the three ladies before her</li>
<li class="L5500" rel="L5500">composedly. Lady Catherine was a tall, large woman, with strongly-marked</li>
<li class="L5501" rel="L5501">features, which might once have been handsome. Her air was not</li>
<li class="L5502" rel="L5502">conciliating, nor was her manner of receiving them such as to make her</li>
<li class="L5503" rel="L5503">visitors forget their inferior rank. She was not rendered formidable by</li>
<li class="L5504" rel="L5504">silence; but whatever she said was spoken in so authoritative a tone,</li>
<li class="L5505" rel="L5505">as marked her self-importance, and brought Mr. Wickham immediately to</li>
<li class="L5506" rel="L5506">Elizabeth&#39;s mind; and from the observation of the day altogether, she</li>
<li class="L5507" rel="L5507">believed Lady Catherine to be exactly what he represented.</li>
<li class="L5508" rel="L5508"></li>
<li class="L5509" rel="L5509">When, after examining the mother, in whose countenance and deportment</li>
<li class="L5510" rel="L5510">she soon found some resemblance of Mr. Darcy, she turned her eyes on the</li>
<li class="L5511" rel="L5511">daughter, she could almost have joined in Maria&#39;s astonishment at her</li>
<li class="L5512" rel="L5512">being so thin and so small. There was neither in figure nor face any</li>
<li class="L5513" rel="L5513">likeness between the ladies. Miss de Bourgh was pale and sickly; her</li>
<li class="L5514" rel="L5514">features, though not plain, were insignificant; and she spoke very</li>
<li class="L5515" rel="L5515">little, except in a low voice, to Mrs. Jenkinson, in whose appearance</li>
<li class="L5516" rel="L5516">there was nothing remarkable, and who was entirely engaged in listening</li>
<li class="L5517" rel="L5517">to what she said, and placing a screen in the proper direction before</li>
<li class="L5518" rel="L5518">her eyes.</li>
<li class="L5519" rel="L5519"></li>
<li class="L5520" rel="L5520">After sitting a few minutes, they were all sent to one of the windows to</li>
<li class="L5521" rel="L5521">admire the view, Mr. Collins attending them to point out its beauties,</li>
<li class="L5522" rel="L5522">and Lady Catherine kindly informing them that it was much better worth</li>
<li class="L5523" rel="L5523">looking at in the summer.</li>
<li class="L5524" rel="L5524"></li>
<li class="L5525" rel="L5525">The dinner was exceedingly handsome, and there were all the servants and</li>
<li class="L5526" rel="L5526">all the articles of plate which Mr. Collins had promised; and, as he had</li>
<li class="L5527" rel="L5527">likewise foretold, he took his seat at the bottom of the table, by her</li>
<li class="L5528" rel="L5528">ladyship&#39;s desire, and looked as if he felt that life could furnish</li>
<li class="L5529" rel="L5529">nothing greater. He carved, and ate, and praised with delighted</li>
<li class="L5530" rel="L5530">alacrity; and every dish was commended, first by him and then by Sir</li>
<li class="L5531" rel="L5531">William, who was now enough recovered to echo whatever his son-in-law</li>
<li class="L5532" rel="L5532">said, in a manner which Elizabeth wondered Lady Catherine could bear.</li>
<li class="L5533" rel="L5533">But Lady Catherine seemed gratified by their excessive admiration, and</li>
<li class="L5534" rel="L5534">gave most gracious smiles, especially when any dish on the table proved</li>
<li class="L5535" rel="L5535">a novelty to them. The party did not supply much conversation. Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L5536" rel="L5536">was ready to speak whenever there was an opening, but she was seated</li>
<li class="L5537" rel="L5537">between Charlotte and Miss de Bourgh--the former of whom was engaged in</li>
<li class="L5538" rel="L5538">listening to Lady Catherine, and the latter said not a word to her all</li>
<li class="L5539" rel="L5539">dinner-time. Mrs. Jenkinson was chiefly employed in watching how little</li>
<li class="L5540" rel="L5540">Miss de Bourgh ate, pressing her to try some other dish, and fearing</li>
<li class="L5541" rel="L5541">she was indisposed. Maria thought speaking out of the question, and the</li>
<li class="L5542" rel="L5542">gentlemen did nothing but eat and admire.</li>
<li class="L5543" rel="L5543"></li>
<li class="L5544" rel="L5544">When the ladies returned to the drawing-room, there was little to</li>
<li class="L5545" rel="L5545">be done but to hear Lady Catherine talk, which she did without any</li>
<li class="L5546" rel="L5546">intermission till coffee came in, delivering her opinion on every</li>
<li class="L5547" rel="L5547">subject in so decisive a manner, as proved that she was not used to</li>
<li class="L5548" rel="L5548">have her judgement controverted. She inquired into Charlotte&#39;s domestic</li>
<li class="L5549" rel="L5549">concerns familiarly and minutely, gave her a great deal of advice as</li>
<li class="L5550" rel="L5550">to the management of them all; told her how everything ought to be</li>
<li class="L5551" rel="L5551">regulated in so small a family as hers, and instructed her as to the</li>
<li class="L5552" rel="L5552">care of her cows and her poultry. Elizabeth found that nothing was</li>
<li class="L5553" rel="L5553">beneath this great lady&#39;s attention, which could furnish her with an</li>
<li class="L5554" rel="L5554">occasion of dictating to others. In the intervals of her discourse</li>
<li class="L5555" rel="L5555">with Mrs. Collins, she addressed a variety of questions to Maria and</li>
<li class="L5556" rel="L5556">Elizabeth, but especially to the latter, of whose connections she knew</li>
<li class="L5557" rel="L5557">the least, and who she observed to Mrs. Collins was a very genteel,</li>
<li class="L5558" rel="L5558">pretty kind of girl. She asked her, at different times, how many sisters</li>
<li class="L5559" rel="L5559">she had, whether they were older or younger than herself, whether any of</li>
<li class="L5560" rel="L5560">them were likely to be married, whether they were handsome, where they</li>
<li class="L5561" rel="L5561">had been educated, what carriage her father kept, and what had been</li>
<li class="L5562" rel="L5562">her mother&#39;s maiden name? Elizabeth felt all the impertinence of</li>
<li class="L5563" rel="L5563">her questions but answered them very composedly. Lady Catherine then</li>
