<li class="L5564" rel="L5564">observed,</li>
<li class="L5565" rel="L5565"></li>
<li class="L5566" rel="L5566">“Your father&#39;s estate is entailed on Mr. Collins, I think. For your</li>
<li class="L5567" rel="L5567">sake,” turning to Charlotte, “I am glad of it; but otherwise I see no</li>
<li class="L5568" rel="L5568">occasion for entailing estates from the female line. It was not thought</li>
<li class="L5569" rel="L5569">necessary in Sir Lewis de Bourgh&#39;s family. Do you play and sing, Miss</li>
<li class="L5570" rel="L5570">Bennet?”</li>
<li class="L5571" rel="L5571"></li>
<li class="L5572" rel="L5572">“A little.”</li>
<li class="L5573" rel="L5573"></li>
<li class="L5574" rel="L5574">“Oh! then--some time or other we shall be happy to hear you. Our</li>
<li class="L5575" rel="L5575">instrument is a capital one, probably superior to----You shall try it</li>
<li class="L5576" rel="L5576">some day. Do your sisters play and sing?”</li>
<li class="L5577" rel="L5577"></li>
<li class="L5578" rel="L5578">“One of them does.”</li>
<li class="L5579" rel="L5579"></li>
<li class="L5580" rel="L5580">“Why did not you all learn? You ought all to have learned. The Miss</li>
<li class="L5581" rel="L5581">Webbs all play, and their father has not so good an income as yours. Do</li>
<li class="L5582" rel="L5582">you draw?”</li>
<li class="L5583" rel="L5583"></li>
<li class="L5584" rel="L5584">“No, not at all.”</li>
<li class="L5585" rel="L5585"></li>
<li class="L5586" rel="L5586">“What, none of you?”</li>
<li class="L5587" rel="L5587"></li>
<li class="L5588" rel="L5588">“Not one.”</li>
<li class="L5589" rel="L5589"></li>
<li class="L5590" rel="L5590">“That is very strange. But I suppose you had no opportunity. Your mother</li>
<li class="L5591" rel="L5591">should have taken you to town every spring for the benefit of masters.”</li>
<li class="L5592" rel="L5592"></li>
<li class="L5593" rel="L5593">“My mother would have had no objection, but my father hates London.”</li>
<li class="L5594" rel="L5594"></li>
<li class="L5595" rel="L5595">“Has your governess left you?”</li>
<li class="L5596" rel="L5596"></li>
<li class="L5597" rel="L5597">“We never had any governess.”</li>
<li class="L5598" rel="L5598"></li>
<li class="L5599" rel="L5599">“No governess! How was that possible? Five daughters brought up at home</li>
<li class="L5600" rel="L5600">without a governess! I never heard of such a thing. Your mother must</li>
<li class="L5601" rel="L5601">have been quite a slave to your education.”</li>
<li class="L5602" rel="L5602"></li>
<li class="L5603" rel="L5603">Elizabeth could hardly help smiling as she assured her that had not been</li>
<li class="L5604" rel="L5604">the case.</li>
<li class="L5605" rel="L5605"></li>
<li class="L5606" rel="L5606">“Then, who taught you? who attended to you? Without a governess, you</li>
<li class="L5607" rel="L5607">must have been neglected.”</li>
<li class="L5608" rel="L5608"></li>
<li class="L5609" rel="L5609">“Compared with some families, I believe we were; but such of us as</li>
<li class="L5610" rel="L5610">wished to learn never wanted the means. We were always encouraged to</li>
<li class="L5611" rel="L5611">read, and had all the masters that were necessary. Those who chose to be</li>
<li class="L5612" rel="L5612">idle, certainly might.”</li>
<li class="L5613" rel="L5613"></li>
<li class="L5614" rel="L5614">“Aye, no doubt; but that is what a governess will prevent, and if I had</li>
<li class="L5615" rel="L5615">known your mother, I should have advised her most strenuously to engage</li>
<li class="L5616" rel="L5616">one. I always say that nothing is to be done in education without steady</li>
<li class="L5617" rel="L5617">and regular instruction, and nobody but a governess can give it. It is</li>
<li class="L5618" rel="L5618">wonderful how many families I have been the means of supplying in that</li>
<li class="L5619" rel="L5619">way. I am always glad to get a young person well placed out. Four nieces</li>
<li class="L5620" rel="L5620">of Mrs. Jenkinson are most delightfully situated through my means; and</li>
<li class="L5621" rel="L5621">it was but the other day that I recommended another young person,</li>
<li class="L5622" rel="L5622">who was merely accidentally mentioned to me, and the family are quite</li>
<li class="L5623" rel="L5623">delighted with her. Mrs. Collins, did I tell you of Lady Metcalf&#39;s</li>
<li class="L5624" rel="L5624">calling yesterday to thank me? She finds Miss Pope a treasure. &#39;Lady</li>
<li class="L5625" rel="L5625">Catherine,&#39; said she, &#39;you have given me a treasure.&#39; Are any of your</li>
<li class="L5626" rel="L5626">younger sisters out, Miss Bennet?”</li>
<li class="L5627" rel="L5627"></li>
<li class="L5628" rel="L5628">“Yes, ma&#39;am, all.”</li>
<li class="L5629" rel="L5629"></li>
<li class="L5630" rel="L5630">“All! What, all five out at once? Very odd! And you only the second. The</li>
<li class="L5631" rel="L5631">younger ones out before the elder ones are married! Your younger sisters</li>
<li class="L5632" rel="L5632">must be very young?”</li>
<li class="L5633" rel="L5633"></li>
<li class="L5634" rel="L5634">“Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. Perhaps _she_ is full young to be</li>
<li class="L5635" rel="L5635">much in company. But really, ma&#39;am, I think it would be very hard upon</li>
<li class="L5636" rel="L5636">younger sisters, that they should not have their share of society and</li>
<li class="L5637" rel="L5637">amusement, because the elder may not have the means or inclination to</li>
<li class="L5638" rel="L5638">marry early. The last-born has as good a right to the pleasures of youth</li>
<li class="L5639" rel="L5639">as the first. And to be kept back on _such_ a motive! I think it would</li>
<li class="L5640" rel="L5640">not be very likely to promote sisterly affection or delicacy of mind.”</li>
<li class="L5641" rel="L5641"></li>
<li class="L5642" rel="L5642">“Upon my word,” said her ladyship, “you give your opinion very decidedly</li>
<li class="L5643" rel="L5643">for so young a person. Pray, what is your age?”</li>
<li class="L5644" rel="L5644"></li>
<li class="L5645" rel="L5645">“With three younger sisters grown up,” replied Elizabeth, smiling, “your</li>
<li class="L5646" rel="L5646">ladyship can hardly expect me to own it.”</li>
<li class="L5647" rel="L5647"></li>
<li class="L5648" rel="L5648">Lady Catherine seemed quite astonished at not receiving a direct answer;</li>
<li class="L5649" rel="L5649">and Elizabeth suspected herself to be the first creature who had ever</li>
<li class="L5650" rel="L5650">dared to trifle with so much dignified impertinence.</li>
<li class="L5651" rel="L5651"></li>
<li class="L5652" rel="L5652">“You cannot be more than twenty, I am sure, therefore you need not</li>
<li class="L5653" rel="L5653">conceal your age.”</li>
<li class="L5654" rel="L5654"></li>
<li class="L5655" rel="L5655">“I am not one-and-twenty.”</li>
<li class="L5656" rel="L5656"></li>
<li class="L5657" rel="L5657">When the gentlemen had joined them, and tea was over, the card-tables</li>
<li class="L5658" rel="L5658">were placed. Lady Catherine, Sir William, and Mr. and Mrs. Collins sat</li>
<li class="L5659" rel="L5659">down to quadrille; and as Miss de Bourgh chose to play at cassino, the</li>
<li class="L5660" rel="L5660">two girls had the honour of assisting Mrs. Jenkinson to make up her</li>
<li class="L5661" rel="L5661">party. Their table was superlatively stupid. Scarcely a syllable was</li>
<li class="L5662" rel="L5662">uttered that did not relate to the game, except when Mrs. Jenkinson</li>
<li class="L5663" rel="L5663">expressed her fears of Miss de Bourgh&#39;s being too hot or too cold, or</li>
<li class="L5664" rel="L5664">having too much or too little light. A great deal more passed at the</li>
<li class="L5665" rel="L5665">other table. Lady Catherine was generally speaking--stating the mistakes</li>
<li class="L5666" rel="L5666">of the three others, or relating some anecdote of herself. Mr. Collins</li>
<li class="L5667" rel="L5667">was employed in agreeing to everything her ladyship said, thanking her</li>
<li class="L5668" rel="L5668">for every fish he won, and apologising if he thought he won too many.</li>
<li class="L5669" rel="L5669">Sir William did not say much. He was storing his memory with anecdotes</li>
<li class="L5670" rel="L5670">and noble names.</li>
<li class="L5671" rel="L5671"></li>
<li class="L5672" rel="L5672">When Lady Catherine and her daughter had played as long as they chose,</li>
<li class="L5673" rel="L5673">the tables were broken up, the carriage was offered to Mrs. Collins,</li>
<li class="L5674" rel="L5674">gratefully accepted and immediately ordered. The party then gathered</li>
<li class="L5675" rel="L5675">round the fire to hear Lady Catherine determine what weather they were</li>
<li class="L5676" rel="L5676">to have on the morrow. From these instructions they were summoned by</li>
<li class="L5677" rel="L5677">the arrival of the coach; and with many speeches of thankfulness on Mr.</li>
<li class="L5678" rel="L5678">Collins&#39;s side and as many bows on Sir William&#39;s they departed. As soon</li>
<li class="L5679" rel="L5679">as they had driven from the door, Elizabeth was called on by her cousin</li>
<li class="L5680" rel="L5680">to give her opinion of all that she had seen at Rosings, which, for</li>
<li class="L5681" rel="L5681">Charlotte&#39;s sake, she made more favourable than it really was. But her</li>
<li class="L5682" rel="L5682">commendation, though costing her some trouble, could by no means satisfy</li>
<li class="L5683" rel="L5683">Mr. Collins, and he was very soon obliged to take her ladyship&#39;s praise</li>
<li class="L5684" rel="L5684">into his own hands.</li>
<li class="L5685" rel="L5685"></li>
<li class="L5686" rel="L5686"></li>
<li class="L5687" rel="L5687"></li>
<li class="L5688" rel="L5688">Chapter 30</li>
<li class="L5689" rel="L5689"></li>
<li class="L5690" rel="L5690"></li>
<li class="L5691" rel="L5691">Sir William stayed only a week at Hunsford, but his visit was long</li>
<li class="L5692" rel="L5692">enough to convince him of his daughter&#39;s being most comfortably settled,</li>
<li class="L5693" rel="L5693">and of her possessing such a husband and such a neighbour as were not</li>
<li class="L5694" rel="L5694">often met with. While Sir William was with them, Mr. Collins devoted his</li>
<li class="L5695" rel="L5695">morning to driving him out in his gig, and showing him the country; but</li>
<li class="L5696" rel="L5696">when he went away, the whole family returned to their usual employments,</li>
<li class="L5697" rel="L5697">and Elizabeth was thankful to find that they did not see more of her</li>
<li class="L5698" rel="L5698">cousin by the alteration, for the chief of the time between breakfast</li>
<li class="L5699" rel="L5699">and dinner was now passed by him either at work in the garden or in</li>
<li class="L5700" rel="L5700">reading and writing, and looking out of the window in his own book-room,</li>
<li class="L5701" rel="L5701">which fronted the road. The room in which the ladies sat was backwards.</li>
<li class="L5702" rel="L5702">Elizabeth had at first rather wondered that Charlotte should not prefer</li>
<li class="L5703" rel="L5703">the dining-parlour for common use; it was a better sized room, and had a</li>
<li class="L5704" rel="L5704">more pleasant aspect; but she soon saw that her friend had an excellent</li>
<li class="L5705" rel="L5705">reason for what she did, for Mr. Collins would undoubtedly have been</li>
<li class="L5706" rel="L5706">much less in his own apartment, had they sat in one equally lively; and</li>
<li class="L5707" rel="L5707">she gave Charlotte credit for the arrangement.</li>
<li class="L5708" rel="L5708"></li>
<li class="L5709" rel="L5709">From the drawing-room they could distinguish nothing in the lane, and</li>
<li class="L5710" rel="L5710">were indebted to Mr. Collins for the knowledge of what carriages went</li>
<li class="L5711" rel="L5711">along, and how often especially Miss de Bourgh drove by in her phaeton,</li>
<li class="L5712" rel="L5712">which he never failed coming to inform them of, though it happened</li>
<li class="L5713" rel="L5713">almost every day. She not unfrequently stopped at the Parsonage, and</li>
<li class="L5714" rel="L5714">had a few minutes&#39; conversation with Charlotte, but was scarcely ever</li>
<li class="L5715" rel="L5715">prevailed upon to get out.</li>
<li class="L5716" rel="L5716"></li>
<li class="L5717" rel="L5717">Very few days passed in which Mr. Collins did not walk to Rosings, and</li>
<li class="L5718" rel="L5718">not many in which his wife did not think it necessary to go likewise;</li>
<li class="L5719" rel="L5719">and till Elizabeth recollected that there might be other family livings</li>
<li class="L5720" rel="L5720">to be disposed of, she could not understand the sacrifice of so many</li>
<li class="L5721" rel="L5721">hours. Now and then they were honoured with a call from her ladyship,</li>
<li class="L5722" rel="L5722">and nothing escaped her observation that was passing in the room during</li>
<li class="L5723" rel="L5723">these visits. She examined into their employments, looked at their work,</li>
<li class="L5724" rel="L5724">and advised them to do it differently; found fault with the arrangement</li>
<li class="L5725" rel="L5725">of the furniture; or detected the housemaid in negligence; and if she</li>
<li class="L5726" rel="L5726">accepted any refreshment, seemed to do it only for the sake of finding</li>
<li class="L5727" rel="L5727">out that Mrs. Collins&#39;s joints of meat were too large for her family.</li>
<li class="L5728" rel="L5728"></li>
<li class="L5729" rel="L5729">Elizabeth soon perceived, that though this great lady was not in</li>
<li class="L5730" rel="L5730">commission of the peace of the county, she was a most active magistrate</li>
<li class="L5731" rel="L5731">in her own parish, the minutest concerns of which were carried to her</li>
<li class="L5732" rel="L5732">by Mr. Collins; and whenever any of the cottagers were disposed to</li>
<li class="L5733" rel="L5733">be quarrelsome, discontented, or too poor, she sallied forth into the</li>
<li class="L5734" rel="L5734">village to settle their differences, silence their complaints, and scold</li>
<li class="L5735" rel="L5735">them into harmony and plenty.</li>
<li class="L5736" rel="L5736"></li>
<li class="L5737" rel="L5737">The entertainment of dining at Rosings was repeated about twice a week;</li>
<li class="L5738" rel="L5738">and, allowing for the loss of Sir William, and there being only one</li>
<li class="L5739" rel="L5739">card-table in the evening, every such entertainment was the counterpart</li>
<li class="L5740" rel="L5740">of the first. Their other engagements were few, as the style of living</li>
<li class="L5741" rel="L5741">in the neighbourhood in general was beyond Mr. Collins&#39;s reach. This,</li>
<li class="L5742" rel="L5742">however, was no evil to Elizabeth, and upon the whole she spent her time</li>
<li class="L5743" rel="L5743">comfortably enough; there were half-hours of pleasant conversation with</li>
<li class="L5744" rel="L5744">Charlotte, and the weather was so fine for the time of year that she had</li>
<li class="L5745" rel="L5745">often great enjoyment out of doors. Her favourite walk, and where she</li>
<li class="L5746" rel="L5746">frequently went while the others were calling on Lady Catherine, was</li>
<li class="L5747" rel="L5747">along the open grove which edged that side of the park, where there was</li>
<li class="L5748" rel="L5748">a nice sheltered path, which no one seemed to value but herself, and</li>
<li class="L5749" rel="L5749">where she felt beyond the reach of Lady Catherine&#39;s curiosity.</li>
<li class="L5750" rel="L5750"></li>
<li class="L5751" rel="L5751">In this quiet way, the first fortnight of her visit soon passed away.</li>
<li class="L5752" rel="L5752">Easter was approaching, and the week preceding it was to bring an</li>
<li class="L5753" rel="L5753">addition to the family at Rosings, which in so small a circle must be</li>
<li class="L5754" rel="L5754">important. Elizabeth had heard soon after her arrival that Mr. Darcy was</li>
<li class="L5755" rel="L5755">expected there in the course of a few weeks, and though there were not</li>
<li class="L5756" rel="L5756">many of her acquaintances whom she did not prefer, his coming would</li>
<li class="L5757" rel="L5757">furnish one comparatively new to look at in their Rosings parties, and</li>
<li class="L5758" rel="L5758">she might be amused in seeing how hopeless Miss Bingley&#39;s designs on him</li>
<li class="L5759" rel="L5759">were, by his behaviour to his cousin, for whom he was evidently</li>
<li class="L5760" rel="L5760">destined by Lady Catherine, who talked of his coming with the greatest</li>
<li class="L5761" rel="L5761">satisfaction, spoke of him in terms of the highest admiration, and</li>
<li class="L5762" rel="L5762">seemed almost angry to find that he had already been frequently seen by</li>
<li class="L5763" rel="L5763">Miss Lucas and herself.</li>
<li class="L5764" rel="L5764"></li>
<li class="L5765" rel="L5765">His arrival was soon known at the Parsonage; for Mr. Collins was walking</li>
<li class="L5766" rel="L5766">the whole morning within view of the lodges opening into Hunsford Lane,</li>
<li class="L5767" rel="L5767">in order to have the earliest assurance of it, and after making his</li>
<li class="L5768" rel="L5768">bow as the carriage turned into the Park, hurried home with the great</li>
<li class="L5769" rel="L5769">intelligence. On the following morning he hastened to Rosings to pay his</li>
<li class="L5770" rel="L5770">respects. There were two nephews of Lady Catherine to require them, for</li>
<li class="L5771" rel="L5771">Mr. Darcy had brought with him a Colonel Fitzwilliam, the younger son of</li>
<li class="L5772" rel="L5772">his uncle Lord ----, and, to the great surprise of all the party, when</li>
<li class="L5773" rel="L5773">Mr. Collins returned, the gentlemen accompanied him. Charlotte had seen</li>
<li class="L5774" rel="L5774">them from her husband&#39;s room, crossing the road, and immediately running</li>
<li class="L5775" rel="L5775">into the other, told the girls what an honour they might expect, adding:</li>
<li class="L5776" rel="L5776"></li>
<li class="L5777" rel="L5777">“I may thank you, Eliza, for this piece of civility. Mr. Darcy would</li>
<li class="L5778" rel="L5778">never have come so soon to wait upon me.”</li>
<li class="L5779" rel="L5779"></li>
<li class="L5780" rel="L5780">Elizabeth had scarcely time to disclaim all right to the compliment,</li>
<li class="L5781" rel="L5781">before their approach was announced by the door-bell, and shortly</li>
<li class="L5782" rel="L5782">afterwards the three gentlemen entered the room. Colonel Fitzwilliam,</li>
<li class="L5783" rel="L5783">who led the way, was about thirty, not handsome, but in person and</li>
<li class="L5784" rel="L5784">address most truly the gentleman. Mr. Darcy looked just as he had been</li>
<li class="L5785" rel="L5785">used to look in Hertfordshire--paid his compliments, with his usual</li>
<li class="L5786" rel="L5786">reserve, to Mrs. Collins, and whatever might be his feelings toward her</li>
<li class="L5787" rel="L5787">friend, met her with every appearance of composure. Elizabeth merely</li>
<li class="L5788" rel="L5788">curtseyed to him without saying a word.</li>
<li class="L5789" rel="L5789"></li>
<li class="L5790" rel="L5790">Colonel Fitzwilliam entered into conversation directly with the</li>
<li class="L5791" rel="L5791">readiness and ease of a well-bred man, and talked very pleasantly; but</li>
<li class="L5792" rel="L5792">his cousin, after having addressed a slight observation on the house and</li>
<li class="L5793" rel="L5793">garden to Mrs. Collins, sat for some time without speaking to anybody.</li>
<li class="L5794" rel="L5794">At length, however, his civility was so far awakened as to inquire of</li>
<li class="L5795" rel="L5795">Elizabeth after the health of her family. She answered him in the usual</li>
<li class="L5796" rel="L5796">way, and after a moment&#39;s pause, added:</li>
<li class="L5797" rel="L5797"></li>
<li class="L5798" rel="L5798">“My eldest sister has been in town these three months. Have you never</li>
<li class="L5799" rel="L5799">happened to see her there?”</li>
<li class="L5800" rel="L5800"></li>
<li class="L5801" rel="L5801">She was perfectly sensible that he never had; but she wished to see</li>
<li class="L5802" rel="L5802">whether he would betray any consciousness of what had passed between</li>
<li class="L5803" rel="L5803">the Bingleys and Jane, and she thought he looked a little confused as he</li>
<li class="L5804" rel="L5804">answered that he had never been so fortunate as to meet Miss Bennet. The</li>
<li class="L5805" rel="L5805">subject was pursued no farther, and the gentlemen soon afterwards went</li>
<li class="L5806" rel="L5806">away.</li>
<li class="L5807" rel="L5807"></li>
<li class="L5808" rel="L5808"></li>
<li class="L5809" rel="L5809"></li>
<li class="L5810" rel="L5810">Chapter 31</li>
<li class="L5811" rel="L5811"></li>
<li class="L5812" rel="L5812"></li>
<li class="L5813" rel="L5813">Colonel Fitzwilliam&#39;s manners were very much admired at the Parsonage,</li>
<li class="L5814" rel="L5814">and the ladies all felt that he must add considerably to the pleasures</li>
<li class="L5815" rel="L5815">of their engagements at Rosings. It was some days, however, before they</li>
<li class="L5816" rel="L5816">received any invitation thither--for while there were visitors in the</li>
<li class="L5817" rel="L5817">house, they could not be necessary; and it was not till Easter-day,</li>
<li class="L5818" rel="L5818">almost a week after the gentlemen&#39;s arrival, that they were honoured by</li>
<li class="L5819" rel="L5819">such an attention, and then they were merely asked on leaving church to</li>
<li class="L5820" rel="L5820">come there in the evening. For the last week they had seen very little</li>
<li class="L5821" rel="L5821">of Lady Catherine or her daughter. Colonel Fitzwilliam had called at the</li>
<li class="L5822" rel="L5822">Parsonage more than once during the time, but Mr. Darcy they had seen</li>
<li class="L5823" rel="L5823">only at church.</li>
<li class="L5824" rel="L5824"></li>
<li class="L5825" rel="L5825">The invitation was accepted of course, and at a proper hour they joined</li>
<li class="L5826" rel="L5826">the party in Lady Catherine&#39;s drawing-room. Her ladyship received</li>
<li class="L5827" rel="L5827">them civilly, but it was plain that their company was by no means so</li>
<li class="L5828" rel="L5828">acceptable as when she could get nobody else; and she was, in fact,</li>
<li class="L5829" rel="L5829">almost engrossed by her nephews, speaking to them, especially to Darcy,</li>
<li class="L5830" rel="L5830">much more than to any other person in the room.</li>
<li class="L5831" rel="L5831"></li>
<li class="L5832" rel="L5832">Colonel Fitzwilliam seemed really glad to see them; anything was a</li>
<li class="L5833" rel="L5833">welcome relief to him at Rosings; and Mrs. Collins&#39;s pretty friend had</li>
<li class="L5834" rel="L5834">moreover caught his fancy very much. He now seated himself by her, and</li>
<li class="L5835" rel="L5835">talked so agreeably of Kent and Hertfordshire, of travelling and staying</li>
<li class="L5836" rel="L5836">at home, of new books and music, that Elizabeth had never been half so</li>
<li class="L5837" rel="L5837">well entertained in that room before; and they conversed with so much</li>
<li class="L5838" rel="L5838">spirit and flow, as to draw the attention of Lady Catherine herself,</li>
<li class="L5839" rel="L5839">as well as of Mr. Darcy. _His_ eyes had been soon and repeatedly turned</li>
<li class="L5840" rel="L5840">towards them with a look of curiosity; and that her ladyship, after a</li>
<li class="L5841" rel="L5841">while, shared the feeling, was more openly acknowledged, for she did not</li>
<li class="L5842" rel="L5842">scruple to call out:</li>
<li class="L5843" rel="L5843"></li>
<li class="L5844" rel="L5844">“What is that you are saying, Fitzwilliam? What is it you are talking</li>
<li class="L5845" rel="L5845">of? What are you telling Miss Bennet? Let me hear what it is.”</li>
<li class="L5846" rel="L5846"></li>
<li class="L5847" rel="L5847">“We are speaking of music, madam,” said he, when no longer able to avoid</li>
<li class="L5848" rel="L5848">a reply.</li>
<li class="L5849" rel="L5849"></li>
<li class="L5850" rel="L5850">“Of music! Then pray speak aloud. It is of all subjects my delight. I</li>
<li class="L5851" rel="L5851">must have my share in the conversation if you are speaking of music.</li>
<li class="L5852" rel="L5852">There are few people in England, I suppose, who have more true enjoyment</li>
<li class="L5853" rel="L5853">of music than myself, or a better natural taste. If I had ever learnt,</li>
<li class="L5854" rel="L5854">I should have been a great proficient. And so would Anne, if her health</li>
<li class="L5855" rel="L5855">had allowed her to apply. I am confident that she would have performed</li>
<li class="L5856" rel="L5856">delightfully. How does Georgiana get on, Darcy?”</li>
<li class="L5857" rel="L5857"></li>
<li class="L5858" rel="L5858">Mr. Darcy spoke with affectionate praise of his sister&#39;s proficiency.</li>
<li class="L5859" rel="L5859"></li>
<li class="L5860" rel="L5860">“I am very glad to hear such a good account of her,” said Lady</li>
<li class="L5861" rel="L5861">Catherine; “and pray tell her from me, that she cannot expect to excel</li>
<li class="L5862" rel="L5862">if she does not practice a good deal.”</li>
<li class="L5863" rel="L5863"></li>
<li class="L5864" rel="L5864">“I assure you, madam,” he replied, “that she does not need such advice.</li>
<li class="L5865" rel="L5865">She practises very constantly.”</li>
<li class="L5866" rel="L5866"></li>
<li class="L5867" rel="L5867">“So much the better. It cannot be done too much; and when I next write</li>
<li class="L5868" rel="L5868">to her, I shall charge her not to neglect it on any account. I often</li>
<li class="L5869" rel="L5869">tell young ladies that no excellence in music is to be acquired without</li>
<li class="L5870" rel="L5870">constant practice. I have told Miss Bennet several times, that she</li>
<li class="L5871" rel="L5871">will never play really well unless she practises more; and though Mrs.</li>
<li class="L5872" rel="L5872">Collins has no instrument, she is very welcome, as I have often told</li>
<li class="L5873" rel="L5873">her, to come to Rosings every day, and play on the pianoforte in Mrs.</li>
<li class="L5874" rel="L5874">Jenkinson&#39;s room. She would be in nobody&#39;s way, you know, in that part</li>
<li class="L5875" rel="L5875">of the house.”</li>
<li class="L5876" rel="L5876"></li>
<li class="L5877" rel="L5877">Mr. Darcy looked a little ashamed of his aunt&#39;s ill-breeding, and made</li>
<li class="L5878" rel="L5878">no answer.</li>
<li class="L5879" rel="L5879"></li>
<li class="L5880" rel="L5880">When coffee was over, Colonel Fitzwilliam reminded Elizabeth of having</li>
<li class="L5881" rel="L5881">promised to play to him; and she sat down directly to the instrument. He</li>
<li class="L5882" rel="L5882">drew a chair near her. Lady Catherine listened to half a song, and then</li>
<li class="L5883" rel="L5883">talked, as before, to her other nephew; till the latter walked away</li>
<li class="L5884" rel="L5884">from her, and making with his usual deliberation towards the pianoforte</li>
<li class="L5885" rel="L5885">stationed himself so as to command a full view of the fair performer&#39;s</li>
<li class="L5886" rel="L5886">countenance. Elizabeth saw what he was doing, and at the first</li>
<li class="L5887" rel="L5887">convenient pause, turned to him with an arch smile, and said:</li>
<li class="L5888" rel="L5888"></li>
<li class="L5889" rel="L5889">“You mean to frighten me, Mr. Darcy, by coming in all this state to hear</li>
<li class="L5890" rel="L5890">me? I will not be alarmed though your sister _does_ play so well. There</li>
<li class="L5891" rel="L5891">is a stubbornness about me that never can bear to be frightened at the</li>
<li class="L5892" rel="L5892">will of others. My courage always rises at every attempt to intimidate</li>
<li class="L5893" rel="L5893">me.”</li>
<li class="L5894" rel="L5894"></li>
<li class="L5895" rel="L5895">“I shall not say you are mistaken,” he replied, “because you could not</li>
<li class="L5896" rel="L5896">really believe me to entertain any design of alarming you; and I have</li>
<li class="L5897" rel="L5897">had the pleasure of your acquaintance long enough to know that you find</li>
<li class="L5898" rel="L5898">great enjoyment in occasionally professing opinions which in fact are</li>
<li class="L5899" rel="L5899">not your own.”</li>
<li class="L5900" rel="L5900"></li>
<li class="L5901" rel="L5901">Elizabeth laughed heartily at this picture of herself, and said to</li>
<li class="L5902" rel="L5902">Colonel Fitzwilliam, “Your cousin will give you a very pretty notion of</li>
<li class="L5903" rel="L5903">me, and teach you not to believe a word I say. I am particularly unlucky</li>
<li class="L5904" rel="L5904">in meeting with a person so able to expose my real character, in a part</li>
<li class="L5905" rel="L5905">of the world where I had hoped to pass myself off with some degree of</li>
<li class="L5906" rel="L5906">credit. Indeed, Mr. Darcy, it is very ungenerous in you to mention all</li>
<li class="L5907" rel="L5907">that you knew to my disadvantage in Hertfordshire--and, give me leave to</li>
<li class="L5908" rel="L5908">say, very impolitic too--for it is provoking me to retaliate, and such</li>
<li class="L5909" rel="L5909">things may come out as will shock your relations to hear.”</li>
<li class="L5910" rel="L5910"></li>
<li class="L5911" rel="L5911">“I am not afraid of you,” said he, smilingly.</li>
<li class="L5912" rel="L5912"></li>
<li class="L5913" rel="L5913">“Pray let me hear what you have to accuse him of,” cried Colonel</li>
<li class="L5914" rel="L5914">Fitzwilliam. “I should like to know how he behaves among strangers.”</li>
<li class="L5915" rel="L5915"></li>
<li class="L5916" rel="L5916">“You shall hear then--but prepare yourself for something very dreadful.</li>
<li class="L5917" rel="L5917">The first time of my ever seeing him in Hertfordshire, you must know,</li>
<li class="L5918" rel="L5918">was at a ball--and at this ball, what do you think he did? He danced</li>
<li class="L5919" rel="L5919">only four dances, though gentlemen were scarce; and, to my certain</li>
<li class="L5920" rel="L5920">knowledge, more than one young lady was sitting down in want of a</li>
<li class="L5921" rel="L5921">partner. Mr. Darcy, you cannot deny the fact.”</li>
<li class="L5922" rel="L5922"></li>
<li class="L5923" rel="L5923">“I had not at that time the honour of knowing any lady in the assembly</li>
<li class="L5924" rel="L5924">beyond my own party.”</li>
<li class="L5925" rel="L5925"></li>
<li class="L5926" rel="L5926">“True; and nobody can ever be introduced in a ball-room. Well, Colonel</li>
<li class="L5927" rel="L5927">Fitzwilliam, what do I play next? My fingers wait your orders.”</li>
<li class="L5928" rel="L5928"></li>
<li class="L5929" rel="L5929">“Perhaps,” said Darcy, “I should have judged better, had I sought an</li>
<li class="L5930" rel="L5930">introduction; but I am ill-qualified to recommend myself to strangers.”</li>
<li class="L5931" rel="L5931"></li>
<li class="L5932" rel="L5932">“Shall we ask your cousin the reason of this?” said Elizabeth, still</li>
<li class="L5933" rel="L5933">addressing Colonel Fitzwilliam. “Shall we ask him why a man of sense and</li>
<li class="L5934" rel="L5934">education, and who has lived in the world, is ill qualified to recommend</li>
<li class="L5935" rel="L5935">himself to strangers?”</li>
<li class="L5936" rel="L5936"></li>
<li class="L5937" rel="L5937">“I can answer your question,” said Fitzwilliam, “without applying to</li>
<li class="L5938" rel="L5938">him. It is because he will not give himself the trouble.”</li>
<li class="L5939" rel="L5939"></li>
<li class="L5940" rel="L5940">“I certainly have not the talent which some people possess,” said Darcy,</li>
<li class="L5941" rel="L5941">“of conversing easily with those I have never seen before. I cannot</li>
<li class="L5942" rel="L5942">catch their tone of conversation, or appear interested in their</li>
<li class="L5943" rel="L5943">concerns, as I often see done.”</li>
<li class="L5944" rel="L5944"></li>
<li class="L5945" rel="L5945">“My fingers,” said Elizabeth, “do not move over this instrument in the</li>
<li class="L5946" rel="L5946">masterly manner which I see so many women&#39;s do. They have not the same</li>
<li class="L5947" rel="L5947">force or rapidity, and do not produce the same expression. But then I</li>
<li class="L5948" rel="L5948">have always supposed it to be my own fault--because I will not take the</li>
<li class="L5949" rel="L5949">trouble of practising. It is not that I do not believe _my_ fingers as</li>
<li class="L5950" rel="L5950">capable as any other woman&#39;s of superior execution.”</li>
<li class="L5951" rel="L5951"></li>
<li class="L5952" rel="L5952">Darcy smiled and said, “You are perfectly right. You have employed your</li>
<li class="L5953" rel="L5953">time much better. No one admitted to the privilege of hearing you can</li>
<li class="L5954" rel="L5954">think anything wanting. We neither of us perform to strangers.”</li>
<li class="L5955" rel="L5955"></li>
<li class="L5956" rel="L5956">Here they were interrupted by Lady Catherine, who called out to know</li>
<li class="L5957" rel="L5957">what they were talking of. Elizabeth immediately began playing again.</li>
<li class="L5958" rel="L5958">Lady Catherine approached, and, after listening for a few minutes, said</li>
<li class="L5959" rel="L5959">to Darcy:</li>
<li class="L5960" rel="L5960"></li>
<li class="L5961" rel="L5961">“Miss Bennet would not play at all amiss if she practised more, and</li>
<li class="L5962" rel="L5962">could have the advantage of a London master. She has a very good notion</li>
<li class="L5963" rel="L5963">of fingering, though her taste is not equal to Anne&#39;s. Anne would have</li>
<li class="L5964" rel="L5964">been a delightful performer, had her health allowed her to learn.”</li>
<li class="L5965" rel="L5965"></li>
<li class="L5966" rel="L5966">Elizabeth looked at Darcy to see how cordially he assented to his</li>
<li class="L5967" rel="L5967">cousin&#39;s praise; but neither at that moment nor at any other could she</li>
<li class="L5968" rel="L5968">discern any symptom of love; and from the whole of his behaviour to Miss</li>
<li class="L5969" rel="L5969">de Bourgh she derived this comfort for Miss Bingley, that he might have</li>
<li class="L5970" rel="L5970">been just as likely to marry _her_, had she been his relation.</li>
<li class="L5971" rel="L5971"></li>
<li class="L5972" rel="L5972">Lady Catherine continued her remarks on Elizabeth&#39;s performance, mixing</li>
<li class="L5973" rel="L5973">with them many instructions on execution and taste. Elizabeth received</li>
<li class="L5974" rel="L5974">them with all the forbearance of civility, and, at the request of the</li>
<li class="L5975" rel="L5975">gentlemen, remained at the instrument till her ladyship&#39;s carriage was</li>
<li class="L5976" rel="L5976">ready to take them all home.</li>
<li class="L5977" rel="L5977"></li>
<li class="L5978" rel="L5978"></li>
<li class="L5979" rel="L5979"></li>
<li class="L5980" rel="L5980">Chapter 32</li>
<li class="L5981" rel="L5981"></li>
<li class="L5982" rel="L5982"></li>
<li class="L5983" rel="L5983">Elizabeth was sitting by herself the next morning, and writing to Jane</li>
<li class="L5984" rel="L5984">while Mrs. Collins and Maria were gone on business into the village,</li>
<li class="L5985" rel="L5985">when she was startled by a ring at the door, the certain signal of a</li>
<li class="L5986" rel="L5986">visitor. As she had heard no carriage, she thought it not unlikely to</li>
<li class="L5987" rel="L5987">be Lady Catherine, and under that apprehension was putting away her</li>
<li class="L5988" rel="L5988">half-finished letter that she might escape all impertinent questions,</li>
<li class="L5989" rel="L5989">when the door opened, and, to her very great surprise, Mr. Darcy, and</li>
<li class="L5990" rel="L5990">Mr. Darcy only, entered the room.</li>
<li class="L5991" rel="L5991"></li>
<li class="L5992" rel="L5992">He seemed astonished too on finding her alone, and apologised for his</li>
<li class="L5993" rel="L5993">intrusion by letting her know that he had understood all the ladies were</li>
<li class="L5994" rel="L5994">to be within.</li>
<li class="L5995" rel="L5995"></li>
<li class="L5996" rel="L5996">They then sat down, and when her inquiries after Rosings were made,</li>
<li class="L5997" rel="L5997">seemed in danger of sinking into total silence. It was absolutely</li>
<li class="L5998" rel="L5998">necessary, therefore, to think of something, and in this emergence</li>
<li class="L5999" rel="L5999">recollecting _when_ she had seen him last in Hertfordshire, and</li>
<li class="L6000" rel="L6000">feeling curious to know what he would say on the subject of their hasty</li>
<li class="L6001" rel="L6001">departure, she observed:</li>
<li class="L6002" rel="L6002"></li>
<li class="L6003" rel="L6003">“How very suddenly you all quitted Netherfield last November, Mr. Darcy!</li>
<li class="L6004" rel="L6004">It must have been a most agreeable surprise to Mr. Bingley to see you</li>
<li class="L6005" rel="L6005">all after him so soon; for, if I recollect right, he went but the day</li>
<li class="L6006" rel="L6006">before. He and his sisters were well, I hope, when you left London?”</li>
<li class="L6007" rel="L6007"></li>
<li class="L6008" rel="L6008">“Perfectly so, I thank you.”</li>
<li class="L6009" rel="L6009"></li>
<li class="L6010" rel="L6010">She found that she was to receive no other answer, and, after a short</li>
<li class="L6011" rel="L6011">pause added:</li>
<li class="L6012" rel="L6012"></li>
<li class="L6013" rel="L6013">“I think I have understood that Mr. Bingley has not much idea of ever</li>
<li class="L6014" rel="L6014">returning to Netherfield again?”</li>
<li class="L6015" rel="L6015"></li>
<li class="L6016" rel="L6016">“I have never heard him say so; but it is probable that he may spend</li>
<li class="L6017" rel="L6017">very little of his time there in the future. He has many friends, and</li>
<li class="L6018" rel="L6018">is at a time of life when friends and engagements are continually</li>
<li class="L6019" rel="L6019">increasing.”</li>
<li class="L6020" rel="L6020"></li>
<li class="L6021" rel="L6021">“If he means to be but little at Netherfield, it would be better for</li>
<li class="L6022" rel="L6022">the neighbourhood that he should give up the place entirely, for then we</li>
<li class="L6023" rel="L6023">might possibly get a settled family there. But, perhaps, Mr. Bingley did</li>
<li class="L6024" rel="L6024">not take the house so much for the convenience of the neighbourhood as</li>
<li class="L6025" rel="L6025">for his own, and we must expect him to keep it or quit it on the same</li>
<li class="L6026" rel="L6026">principle.”</li>
<li class="L6027" rel="L6027"></li>
<li class="L6028" rel="L6028">“I should not be surprised,” said Darcy, “if he were to give it up as</li>
<li class="L6029" rel="L6029">soon as any eligible purchase offers.”</li>
<li class="L6030" rel="L6030"></li>
<li class="L6031" rel="L6031">Elizabeth made no answer. She was afraid of talking longer of his</li>
<li class="L6032" rel="L6032">friend; and, having nothing else to say, was now determined to leave the</li>
<li class="L6033" rel="L6033">trouble of finding a subject to him.</li>
<li class="L6034" rel="L6034"></li>
<li class="L6035" rel="L6035">He took the hint, and soon began with, “This seems a very comfortable</li>
<li class="L6036" rel="L6036">house. Lady Catherine, I believe, did a great deal to it when Mr.</li>
<li class="L6037" rel="L6037">Collins first came to Hunsford.”</li>
<li class="L6038" rel="L6038"></li>
<li class="L6039" rel="L6039">“I believe she did--and I am sure she could not have bestowed her</li>
<li class="L6040" rel="L6040">kindness on a more grateful object.”</li>
<li class="L6041" rel="L6041"></li>
<li class="L6042" rel="L6042">“Mr. Collins appears to be very fortunate in his choice of a wife.”</li>
<li class="L6043" rel="L6043"></li>
<li class="L6044" rel="L6044">“Yes, indeed, his friends may well rejoice in his having met with one</li>
<li class="L6045" rel="L6045">of the very few sensible women who would have accepted him, or have made</li>
<li class="L6046" rel="L6046">him happy if they had. My friend has an excellent understanding--though</li>
<li class="L6047" rel="L6047">I am not certain that I consider her marrying Mr. Collins as the</li>
<li class="L6048" rel="L6048">wisest thing she ever did. She seems perfectly happy, however, and in a</li>
<li class="L6049" rel="L6049">prudential light it is certainly a very good match for her.”</li>
<li class="L6050" rel="L6050"></li>
<li class="L6051" rel="L6051">“It must be very agreeable for her to be settled within so easy a</li>
<li class="L6052" rel="L6052">distance of her own family and friends.”</li>
<li class="L6053" rel="L6053"></li>
<li class="L6054" rel="L6054">“An easy distance, do you call it? It is nearly fifty miles.”</li>
<li class="L6055" rel="L6055"></li>
<li class="L6056" rel="L6056">“And what is fifty miles of good road? Little more than half a day&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6057" rel="L6057">journey. Yes, I call it a _very_ easy distance.”</li>
<li class="L6058" rel="L6058"></li>
<li class="L6059" rel="L6059">“I should never have considered the distance as one of the _advantages_</li>
<li class="L6060" rel="L6060">of the match,” cried Elizabeth. “I should never have said Mrs. Collins</li>
<li class="L6061" rel="L6061">was settled _near_ her family.”</li>
<li class="L6062" rel="L6062"></li>
<li class="L6063" rel="L6063">“It is a proof of your own attachment to Hertfordshire. Anything beyond</li>
<li class="L6064" rel="L6064">the very neighbourhood of Longbourn, I suppose, would appear far.”</li>
<li class="L6065" rel="L6065"></li>
<li class="L6066" rel="L6066">As he spoke there was a sort of smile which Elizabeth fancied she</li>
<li class="L6067" rel="L6067">understood; he must be supposing her to be thinking of Jane and</li>
<li class="L6068" rel="L6068">Netherfield, and she blushed as she answered:</li>
<li class="L6069" rel="L6069"></li>
<li class="L6070" rel="L6070">“I do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her</li>
<li class="L6071" rel="L6071">family. The far and the near must be relative, and depend on many</li>
<li class="L6072" rel="L6072">varying circumstances. Where there is fortune to make the expenses of</li>
<li class="L6073" rel="L6073">travelling unimportant, distance becomes no evil. But that is not the</li>
<li class="L6074" rel="L6074">case _here_. Mr. and Mrs. Collins have a comfortable income, but not</li>
<li class="L6075" rel="L6075">such a one as will allow of frequent journeys--and I am persuaded my</li>
<li class="L6076" rel="L6076">friend would not call herself _near_ her family under less than _half_</li>
<li class="L6077" rel="L6077">the present distance.”</li>
<li class="L6078" rel="L6078"></li>
<li class="L6079" rel="L6079">Mr. Darcy drew his chair a little towards her, and said, “_You_ cannot</li>
<li class="L6080" rel="L6080">have a right to such very strong local attachment. _You_ cannot have</li>
<li class="L6081" rel="L6081">been always at Longbourn.”</li>
<li class="L6082" rel="L6082"></li>
<li class="L6083" rel="L6083">Elizabeth looked surprised. The gentleman experienced some change of</li>
<li class="L6084" rel="L6084">feeling; he drew back his chair, took a newspaper from the table, and</li>
<li class="L6085" rel="L6085">glancing over it, said, in a colder voice:</li>
<li class="L6086" rel="L6086"></li>
<li class="L6087" rel="L6087">“Are you pleased with Kent?”</li>
<li class="L6088" rel="L6088"></li>
<li class="L6089" rel="L6089">A short dialogue on the subject of the country ensued, on either side</li>
<li class="L6090" rel="L6090">calm and concise--and soon put an end to by the entrance of Charlotte</li>
<li class="L6091" rel="L6091">and her sister, just returned from her walk. The tete-a-tete surprised</li>
<li class="L6092" rel="L6092">them. Mr. Darcy related the mistake which had occasioned his intruding</li>
<li class="L6093" rel="L6093">on Miss Bennet, and after sitting a few minutes longer without saying</li>
<li class="L6094" rel="L6094">much to anybody, went away.</li>
<li class="L6095" rel="L6095"></li>
<li class="L6096" rel="L6096">“What can be the meaning of this?” said Charlotte, as soon as he was</li>
<li class="L6097" rel="L6097">gone. “My dear, Eliza, he must be in love with you, or he would never</li>
<li class="L6098" rel="L6098">have called us in this familiar way.”</li>
<li class="L6099" rel="L6099"></li>
<li class="L6100" rel="L6100">But when Elizabeth told of his silence, it did not seem very likely,</li>
<li class="L6101" rel="L6101">even to Charlotte&#39;s wishes, to be the case; and after various</li>
<li class="L6102" rel="L6102">conjectures, they could at last only suppose his visit to proceed from</li>
<li class="L6103" rel="L6103">the difficulty of finding anything to do, which was the more probable</li>
<li class="L6104" rel="L6104">from the time of year. All field sports were over. Within doors there</li>
<li class="L6105" rel="L6105">was Lady Catherine, books, and a billiard-table, but gentlemen cannot</li>
<li class="L6106" rel="L6106">always be within doors; and in the nearness of the Parsonage, or the</li>
<li class="L6107" rel="L6107">pleasantness of the walk to it, or of the people who lived in it, the</li>
<li class="L6108" rel="L6108">two cousins found a temptation from this period of walking thither</li>
<li class="L6109" rel="L6109">almost every day. They called at various times of the morning, sometimes</li>
<li class="L6110" rel="L6110">separately, sometimes together, and now and then accompanied by their</li>
<li class="L6111" rel="L6111">aunt. It was plain to them all that Colonel Fitzwilliam came because he</li>
<li class="L6112" rel="L6112">had pleasure in their society, a persuasion which of course recommended</li>
<li class="L6113" rel="L6113">him still more; and Elizabeth was reminded by her own satisfaction in</li>
<li class="L6114" rel="L6114">being with him, as well as by his evident admiration of her, of her</li>
<li class="L6115" rel="L6115">former favourite George Wickham; and though, in comparing them, she saw</li>
<li class="L6116" rel="L6116">there was less captivating softness in Colonel Fitzwilliam&#39;s manners,</li>
<li class="L6117" rel="L6117">she believed he might have the best informed mind.</li>
<li class="L6118" rel="L6118"></li>
<li class="L6119" rel="L6119">But why Mr. Darcy came so often to the Parsonage, it was more difficult</li>
<li class="L6120" rel="L6120">to understand. It could not be for society, as he frequently sat there</li>
<li class="L6121" rel="L6121">ten minutes together without opening his lips; and when he did speak,</li>
<li class="L6122" rel="L6122">it seemed the effect of necessity rather than of choice--a sacrifice</li>
<li class="L6123" rel="L6123">to propriety, not a pleasure to himself. He seldom appeared really</li>
<li class="L6124" rel="L6124">animated. Mrs. Collins knew not what to make of him. Colonel</li>
<li class="L6125" rel="L6125">Fitzwilliam&#39;s occasionally laughing at his stupidity, proved that he was</li>
<li class="L6126" rel="L6126">generally different, which her own knowledge of him could not have told</li>
<li class="L6127" rel="L6127">her; and as she would liked to have believed this change the effect</li>
<li class="L6128" rel="L6128">of love, and the object of that love her friend Eliza, she set herself</li>
<li class="L6129" rel="L6129">seriously to work to find it out. She watched him whenever they were at</li>
<li class="L6130" rel="L6130">Rosings, and whenever he came to Hunsford; but without much success. He</li>
<li class="L6131" rel="L6131">certainly looked at her friend a great deal, but the expression of that</li>
<li class="L6132" rel="L6132">look was disputable. It was an earnest, steadfast gaze, but she often</li>
<li class="L6133" rel="L6133">doubted whether there were much admiration in it, and sometimes it</li>
<li class="L6134" rel="L6134">seemed nothing but absence of mind.</li>
<li class="L6135" rel="L6135"></li>
<li class="L6136" rel="L6136">She had once or twice suggested to Elizabeth the possibility of his</li>
<li class="L6137" rel="L6137">being partial to her, but Elizabeth always laughed at the idea; and Mrs.</li>
<li class="L6138" rel="L6138">Collins did not think it right to press the subject, from the danger of</li>
<li class="L6139" rel="L6139">raising expectations which might only end in disappointment; for in her</li>
<li class="L6140" rel="L6140">opinion it admitted not of a doubt, that all her friend&#39;s dislike would</li>
<li class="L6141" rel="L6141">vanish, if she could suppose him to be in her power.</li>
<li class="L6142" rel="L6142"></li>
<li class="L6143" rel="L6143"></li>
<li class="L6144" rel="L6144">In her kind schemes for Elizabeth, she sometimes planned her marrying</li>
<li class="L6145" rel="L6145">Colonel Fitzwilliam. He was beyond comparison the most pleasant man; he</li>
<li class="L6146" rel="L6146">certainly admired her, and his situation in life was most eligible; but,</li>
<li class="L6147" rel="L6147">to counterbalance these advantages, Mr. Darcy had considerable patronage</li>
<li class="L6148" rel="L6148">in the church, and his cousin could have none at all.</li>
<li class="L6149" rel="L6149"></li>
<li class="L6150" rel="L6150"></li>
<li class="L6151" rel="L6151"></li>
<li class="L6152" rel="L6152">Chapter 33</li>
<li class="L6153" rel="L6153"></li>
<li class="L6154" rel="L6154"></li>
<li class="L6155" rel="L6155">More than once did Elizabeth, in her ramble within the park,</li>
<li class="L6156" rel="L6156">unexpectedly meet Mr. Darcy. She felt all the perverseness of the</li>
<li class="L6157" rel="L6157">mischance that should bring him where no one else was brought, and, to</li>
<li class="L6158" rel="L6158">prevent its ever happening again, took care to inform him at first that</li>
<li class="L6159" rel="L6159">it was a favourite haunt of hers. How it could occur a second time,</li>
<li class="L6160" rel="L6160">therefore, was very odd! Yet it did, and even a third. It seemed like</li>
<li class="L6161" rel="L6161">wilful ill-nature, or a voluntary penance, for on these occasions it was</li>
<li class="L6162" rel="L6162">not merely a few formal inquiries and an awkward pause and then away,</li>
<li class="L6163" rel="L6163">but he actually thought it necessary to turn back and walk with her. He</li>
<li class="L6164" rel="L6164">never said a great deal, nor did she give herself the trouble of talking</li>
<li class="L6165" rel="L6165">or of listening much; but it struck her in the course of their third</li>
<li class="L6166" rel="L6166">rencontre that he was asking some odd unconnected questions--about</li>
<li class="L6167" rel="L6167">her pleasure in being at Hunsford, her love of solitary walks, and her</li>
<li class="L6168" rel="L6168">opinion of Mr. and Mrs. Collins&#39;s happiness; and that in speaking of</li>
<li class="L6169" rel="L6169">Rosings and her not perfectly understanding the house, he seemed to</li>
<li class="L6170" rel="L6170">expect that whenever she came into Kent again she would be staying</li>
<li class="L6171" rel="L6171">_there_ too. His words seemed to imply it. Could he have Colonel</li>
<li class="L6172" rel="L6172">Fitzwilliam in his thoughts? She supposed, if he meant anything, he must</li>
<li class="L6173" rel="L6173">mean an allusion to what might arise in that quarter. It distressed</li>
<li class="L6174" rel="L6174">her a little, and she was quite glad to find herself at the gate in the</li>
<li class="L6175" rel="L6175">pales opposite the Parsonage.</li>
<li class="L6176" rel="L6176"></li>
<li class="L6177" rel="L6177">She was engaged one day as she walked, in perusing Jane&#39;s last letter,</li>
<li class="L6178" rel="L6178">and dwelling on some passages which proved that Jane had not written in</li>
<li class="L6179" rel="L6179">spirits, when, instead of being again surprised by Mr. Darcy, she saw</li>
<li class="L6180" rel="L6180">on looking up that Colonel Fitzwilliam was meeting her. Putting away the</li>
<li class="L6181" rel="L6181">letter immediately and forcing a smile, she said:</li>
<li class="L6182" rel="L6182"></li>
<li class="L6183" rel="L6183">“I did not know before that you ever walked this way.”</li>
<li class="L6184" rel="L6184"></li>
<li class="L6185" rel="L6185">“I have been making the tour of the park,” he replied, “as I generally</li>
<li class="L6186" rel="L6186">do every year, and intend to close it with a call at the Parsonage. Are</li>
<li class="L6187" rel="L6187">you going much farther?”</li>
<li class="L6188" rel="L6188"></li>
<li class="L6189" rel="L6189">“No, I should have turned in a moment.”</li>
<li class="L6190" rel="L6190"></li>
<li class="L6191" rel="L6191">And accordingly she did turn, and they walked towards the Parsonage</li>
<li class="L6192" rel="L6192">together.</li>
<li class="L6193" rel="L6193"></li>
<li class="L6194" rel="L6194">“Do you certainly leave Kent on Saturday?” said she.</li>
<li class="L6195" rel="L6195"></li>
<li class="L6196" rel="L6196">“Yes--if Darcy does not put it off again. But I am at his disposal. He</li>
<li class="L6197" rel="L6197">arranges the business just as he pleases.”</li>
<li class="L6198" rel="L6198"></li>
<li class="L6199" rel="L6199">“And if not able to please himself in the arrangement, he has at least</li>
<li class="L6200" rel="L6200">pleasure in the great power of choice. I do not know anybody who seems</li>
<li class="L6201" rel="L6201">more to enjoy the power of doing what he likes than Mr. Darcy.”</li>
<li class="L6202" rel="L6202"></li>
<li class="L6203" rel="L6203">“He likes to have his own way very well,” replied Colonel Fitzwilliam.</li>
<li class="L6204" rel="L6204">“But so we all do. It is only that he has better means of having it</li>
<li class="L6205" rel="L6205">than many others, because he is rich, and many others are poor. I speak</li>
<li class="L6206" rel="L6206">feelingly. A younger son, you know, must be inured to self-denial and</li>
<li class="L6207" rel="L6207">dependence.”</li>
<li class="L6208" rel="L6208"></li>
<li class="L6209" rel="L6209">“In my opinion, the younger son of an earl can know very little of</li>
<li class="L6210" rel="L6210">either. Now seriously, what have you ever known of self-denial and</li>
<li class="L6211" rel="L6211">dependence? When have you been prevented by want of money from going</li>
<li class="L6212" rel="L6212">wherever you chose, or procuring anything you had a fancy for?”</li>
<li class="L6213" rel="L6213"></li>
<li class="L6214" rel="L6214">“These are home questions--and perhaps I cannot say that I have</li>
<li class="L6215" rel="L6215">experienced many hardships of that nature. But in matters of greater</li>
<li class="L6216" rel="L6216">weight, I may suffer from want of money. Younger sons cannot marry where</li>
<li class="L6217" rel="L6217">they like.”</li>
<li class="L6218" rel="L6218"></li>
<li class="L6219" rel="L6219">“Unless where they like women of fortune, which I think they very often</li>
<li class="L6220" rel="L6220">do.”</li>
<li class="L6221" rel="L6221"></li>
<li class="L6222" rel="L6222">“Our habits of expense make us too dependent, and there are not many</li>
<li class="L6223" rel="L6223">in my rank of life who can afford to marry without some attention to</li>
<li class="L6224" rel="L6224">money.”</li>
<li class="L6225" rel="L6225"></li>
<li class="L6226" rel="L6226">“Is this,” thought Elizabeth, “meant for me?” and she coloured at the</li>
<li class="L6227" rel="L6227">idea; but, recovering herself, said in a lively tone, “And pray, what</li>
<li class="L6228" rel="L6228">is the usual price of an earl&#39;s younger son? Unless the elder brother is</li>
<li class="L6229" rel="L6229">very sickly, I suppose you would not ask above fifty thousand pounds.”</li>
<li class="L6230" rel="L6230"></li>
<li class="L6231" rel="L6231">He answered her in the same style, and the subject dropped. To interrupt</li>
<li class="L6232" rel="L6232">a silence which might make him fancy her affected with what had passed,</li>
<li class="L6233" rel="L6233">she soon afterwards said:</li>
<li class="L6234" rel="L6234"></li>
<li class="L6235" rel="L6235">“I imagine your cousin brought you down with him chiefly for the sake of</li>
<li class="L6236" rel="L6236">having someone at his disposal. I wonder he does not marry, to secure a</li>
<li class="L6237" rel="L6237">lasting convenience of that kind. But, perhaps, his sister does as well</li>
<li class="L6238" rel="L6238">for the present, and, as she is under his sole care, he may do what he</li>
<li class="L6239" rel="L6239">likes with her.”</li>
<li class="L6240" rel="L6240"></li>
<li class="L6241" rel="L6241">“No,” said Colonel Fitzwilliam, “that is an advantage which he must</li>
<li class="L6242" rel="L6242">divide with me. I am joined with him in the guardianship of Miss Darcy.”</li>
<li class="L6243" rel="L6243"></li>
<li class="L6244" rel="L6244">“Are you indeed? And pray what sort of guardians do you make? Does your</li>
<li class="L6245" rel="L6245">charge give you much trouble? Young ladies of her age are sometimes a</li>
<li class="L6246" rel="L6246">little difficult to manage, and if she has the true Darcy spirit, she</li>
<li class="L6247" rel="L6247">may like to have her own way.”</li>
<li class="L6248" rel="L6248"></li>
<li class="L6249" rel="L6249">As she spoke she observed him looking at her earnestly; and the manner</li>
<li class="L6250" rel="L6250">in which he immediately asked her why she supposed Miss Darcy likely to</li>
<li class="L6251" rel="L6251">give them any uneasiness, convinced her that she had somehow or other</li>
<li class="L6252" rel="L6252">got pretty near the truth. She directly replied:</li>
<li class="L6253" rel="L6253"></li>
<li class="L6254" rel="L6254">“You need not be frightened. I never heard any harm of her; and I dare</li>
<li class="L6255" rel="L6255">say she is one of the most tractable creatures in the world. She is a</li>
<li class="L6256" rel="L6256">very great favourite with some ladies of my acquaintance, Mrs. Hurst and</li>
<li class="L6257" rel="L6257">Miss Bingley. I think I have heard you say that you know them.”</li>
<li class="L6258" rel="L6258"></li>
<li class="L6259" rel="L6259">“I know them a little. Their brother is a pleasant gentlemanlike man--he</li>
<li class="L6260" rel="L6260">is a great friend of Darcy&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L6261" rel="L6261"></li>
<li class="L6262" rel="L6262">“Oh! yes,” said Elizabeth drily; “Mr. Darcy is uncommonly kind to Mr.</li>
<li class="L6263" rel="L6263">Bingley, and takes a prodigious deal of care of him.”</li>
<li class="L6264" rel="L6264"></li>
<li class="L6265" rel="L6265">“Care of him! Yes, I really believe Darcy _does_ take care of him in</li>
<li class="L6266" rel="L6266">those points where he most wants care. From something that he told me in</li>
<li class="L6267" rel="L6267">our journey hither, I have reason to think Bingley very much indebted to</li>
<li class="L6268" rel="L6268">him. But I ought to beg his pardon, for I have no right to suppose that</li>
<li class="L6269" rel="L6269">Bingley was the person meant. It was all conjecture.”</li>
<li class="L6270" rel="L6270"></li>
<li class="L6271" rel="L6271">“What is it you mean?”</li>
<li class="L6272" rel="L6272"></li>
<li class="L6273" rel="L6273">“It is a circumstance which Darcy could not wish to be generally known,</li>
<li class="L6274" rel="L6274">because if it were to get round to the lady&#39;s family, it would be an</li>
<li class="L6275" rel="L6275">unpleasant thing.”</li>
<li class="L6276" rel="L6276"></li>
<li class="L6277" rel="L6277">“You may depend upon my not mentioning it.”</li>
<li class="L6278" rel="L6278"></li>
<li class="L6279" rel="L6279">“And remember that I have not much reason for supposing it to be</li>
<li class="L6280" rel="L6280">Bingley. What he told me was merely this: that he congratulated himself</li>
<li class="L6281" rel="L6281">on having lately saved a friend from the inconveniences of a most</li>
<li class="L6282" rel="L6282">imprudent marriage, but without mentioning names or any other</li>
<li class="L6283" rel="L6283">particulars, and I only suspected it to be Bingley from believing</li>
<li class="L6284" rel="L6284">him the kind of young man to get into a scrape of that sort, and from</li>
<li class="L6285" rel="L6285">knowing them to have been together the whole of last summer.”</li>
<li class="L6286" rel="L6286"></li>
<li class="L6287" rel="L6287">“Did Mr. Darcy give you reasons for this interference?”</li>
<li class="L6288" rel="L6288"></li>
<li class="L6289" rel="L6289">“I understood that there were some very strong objections against the</li>
<li class="L6290" rel="L6290">lady.”</li>
<li class="L6291" rel="L6291"></li>
<li class="L6292" rel="L6292">“And what arts did he use to separate them?”</li>
<li class="L6293" rel="L6293"></li>
<li class="L6294" rel="L6294">“He did not talk to me of his own arts,” said Fitzwilliam, smiling. “He</li>
<li class="L6295" rel="L6295">only told me what I have now told you.”</li>
<li class="L6296" rel="L6296"></li>
<li class="L6297" rel="L6297">Elizabeth made no answer, and walked on, her heart swelling with</li>
<li class="L6298" rel="L6298">indignation. After watching her a little, Fitzwilliam asked her why she</li>
<li class="L6299" rel="L6299">was so thoughtful.</li>
<li class="L6300" rel="L6300"></li>
<li class="L6301" rel="L6301">“I am thinking of what you have been telling me,” said she. “Your</li>
<li class="L6302" rel="L6302">cousin&#39;s conduct does not suit my feelings. Why was he to be the judge?”</li>
<li class="L6303" rel="L6303"></li>
<li class="L6304" rel="L6304">“You are rather disposed to call his interference officious?”</li>
<li class="L6305" rel="L6305"></li>
<li class="L6306" rel="L6306">“I do not see what right Mr. Darcy had to decide on the propriety of his</li>
<li class="L6307" rel="L6307">friend&#39;s inclination, or why, upon his own judgement alone, he was to</li>
<li class="L6308" rel="L6308">determine and direct in what manner his friend was to be happy.</li>
<li class="L6309" rel="L6309">But,” she continued, recollecting herself, “as we know none of the</li>
<li class="L6310" rel="L6310">particulars, it is not fair to condemn him. It is not to be supposed</li>
<li class="L6311" rel="L6311">that there was much affection in the case.”</li>
<li class="L6312" rel="L6312"></li>
<li class="L6313" rel="L6313">“That is not an unnatural surmise,” said Fitzwilliam, “but it is a</li>
<li class="L6314" rel="L6314">lessening of the honour of my cousin&#39;s triumph very sadly.”</li>
<li class="L6315" rel="L6315"></li>
<li class="L6316" rel="L6316">This was spoken jestingly; but it appeared to her so just a picture</li>
<li class="L6317" rel="L6317">of Mr. Darcy, that she would not trust herself with an answer, and</li>
<li class="L6318" rel="L6318">therefore, abruptly changing the conversation talked on indifferent</li>
<li class="L6319" rel="L6319">matters until they reached the Parsonage. There, shut into her own room,</li>
<li class="L6320" rel="L6320">as soon as their visitor left them, she could think without interruption</li>
<li class="L6321" rel="L6321">of all that she had heard. It was not to be supposed that any other</li>
<li class="L6322" rel="L6322">people could be meant than those with whom she was connected. There</li>
<li class="L6323" rel="L6323">could not exist in the world _two_ men over whom Mr. Darcy could have</li>
<li class="L6324" rel="L6324">such boundless influence. That he had been concerned in the measures</li>
<li class="L6325" rel="L6325">taken to separate Bingley and Jane she had never doubted; but she had</li>
<li class="L6326" rel="L6326">always attributed to Miss Bingley the principal design and arrangement</li>
<li class="L6327" rel="L6327">of them. If his own vanity, however, did not mislead him, _he_ was</li>
<li class="L6328" rel="L6328">the cause, his pride and caprice were the cause, of all that Jane had</li>
<li class="L6329" rel="L6329">suffered, and still continued to suffer. He had ruined for a while</li>
<li class="L6330" rel="L6330">every hope of happiness for the most affectionate, generous heart in the</li>
<li class="L6331" rel="L6331">world; and no one could say how lasting an evil he might have inflicted.</li>
<li class="L6332" rel="L6332"></li>
<li class="L6333" rel="L6333">“There were some very strong objections against the lady,” were Colonel</li>
<li class="L6334" rel="L6334">Fitzwilliam&#39;s words; and those strong objections probably were, her</li>
<li class="L6335" rel="L6335">having one uncle who was a country attorney, and another who was in</li>
<li class="L6336" rel="L6336">business in London.</li>
<li class="L6337" rel="L6337"></li>
<li class="L6338" rel="L6338">“To Jane herself,” she exclaimed, “there could be no possibility of</li>
<li class="L6339" rel="L6339">objection; all loveliness and goodness as she is!--her understanding</li>
<li class="L6340" rel="L6340">excellent, her mind improved, and her manners captivating. Neither</li>
<li class="L6341" rel="L6341">could anything be urged against my father, who, though with some</li>
<li class="L6342" rel="L6342">peculiarities, has abilities Mr. Darcy himself need not disdain, and</li>
<li class="L6343" rel="L6343">respectability which he will probably never reach.” When she thought of</li>
<li class="L6344" rel="L6344">her mother, her confidence gave way a little; but she would not allow</li>
<li class="L6345" rel="L6345">that any objections _there_ had material weight with Mr. Darcy, whose</li>
<li class="L6346" rel="L6346">pride, she was convinced, would receive a deeper wound from the want of</li>
<li class="L6347" rel="L6347">importance in his friend&#39;s connections, than from their want of sense;</li>
<li class="L6348" rel="L6348">and she was quite decided, at last, that he had been partly governed</li>
<li class="L6349" rel="L6349">by this worst kind of pride, and partly by the wish of retaining Mr.</li>
<li class="L6350" rel="L6350">Bingley for his sister.</li>
<li class="L6351" rel="L6351"></li>
<li class="L6352" rel="L6352">The agitation and tears which the subject occasioned, brought on a</li>
<li class="L6353" rel="L6353">headache; and it grew so much worse towards the evening, that, added to</li>
<li class="L6354" rel="L6354">her unwillingness to see Mr. Darcy, it determined her not to attend her</li>
<li class="L6355" rel="L6355">cousins to Rosings, where they were engaged to drink tea. Mrs. Collins,</li>
<li class="L6356" rel="L6356">seeing that she was really unwell, did not press her to go and as much</li>
<li class="L6357" rel="L6357">as possible prevented her husband from pressing her; but Mr. Collins</li>
<li class="L6358" rel="L6358">could not conceal his apprehension of Lady Catherine&#39;s being rather</li>
<li class="L6359" rel="L6359">displeased by her staying at home.</li>
<li class="L6360" rel="L6360"></li>
<li class="L6361" rel="L6361"></li>
<li class="L6362" rel="L6362"></li>
<li class="L6363" rel="L6363">Chapter 34</li>
<li class="L6364" rel="L6364"></li>
<li class="L6365" rel="L6365"></li>
<li class="L6366" rel="L6366">When they were gone, Elizabeth, as if intending to exasperate herself</li>
<li class="L6367" rel="L6367">as much as possible against Mr. Darcy, chose for her employment the</li>
<li class="L6368" rel="L6368">examination of all the letters which Jane had written to her since her</li>
<li class="L6369" rel="L6369">being in Kent. They contained no actual complaint, nor was there any</li>
<li class="L6370" rel="L6370">revival of past occurrences, or any communication of present suffering.</li>
<li class="L6371" rel="L6371">But in all, and in almost every line of each, there was a want of that</li>
<li class="L6372" rel="L6372">cheerfulness which had been used to characterise her style, and which,</li>
<li class="L6373" rel="L6373">proceeding from the serenity of a mind at ease with itself and kindly</li>
<li class="L6374" rel="L6374">disposed towards everyone, had been scarcely ever clouded. Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L6375" rel="L6375">noticed every sentence conveying the idea of uneasiness, with an</li>
<li class="L6376" rel="L6376">attention which it had hardly received on the first perusal. Mr. Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6377" rel="L6377">shameful boast of what misery he had been able to inflict, gave her</li>
<li class="L6378" rel="L6378">a keener sense of her sister&#39;s sufferings. It was some consolation</li>
<li class="L6379" rel="L6379">to think that his visit to Rosings was to end on the day after the</li>
<li class="L6380" rel="L6380">next--and, a still greater, that in less than a fortnight she should</li>
<li class="L6381" rel="L6381">herself be with Jane again, and enabled to contribute to the recovery of</li>
<li class="L6382" rel="L6382">her spirits, by all that affection could do.</li>
<li class="L6383" rel="L6383"></li>
<li class="L6384" rel="L6384">She could not think of Darcy&#39;s leaving Kent without remembering that</li>
<li class="L6385" rel="L6385">his cousin was to go with him; but Colonel Fitzwilliam had made it clear</li>
<li class="L6386" rel="L6386">that he had no intentions at all, and agreeable as he was, she did not</li>
<li class="L6387" rel="L6387">mean to be unhappy about him.</li>
<li class="L6388" rel="L6388"></li>
<li class="L6389" rel="L6389">While settling this point, she was suddenly roused by the sound of the</li>
<li class="L6390" rel="L6390">door-bell, and her spirits were a little fluttered by the idea of its</li>
<li class="L6391" rel="L6391">being Colonel Fitzwilliam himself, who had once before called late in</li>
<li class="L6392" rel="L6392">the evening, and might now come to inquire particularly after her.</li>
<li class="L6393" rel="L6393">But this idea was soon banished, and her spirits were very differently</li>
<li class="L6394" rel="L6394">affected, when, to her utter amazement, she saw Mr. Darcy walk into the</li>
<li class="L6395" rel="L6395">room. In an hurried manner he immediately began an inquiry after her</li>
<li class="L6396" rel="L6396">health, imputing his visit to a wish of hearing that she were better.</li>
<li class="L6397" rel="L6397">She answered him with cold civility. He sat down for a few moments, and</li>
<li class="L6398" rel="L6398">then getting up, walked about the room. Elizabeth was surprised, but</li>
<li class="L6399" rel="L6399">said not a word. After a silence of several minutes, he came towards her</li>
<li class="L6400" rel="L6400">in an agitated manner, and thus began:</li>
<li class="L6401" rel="L6401"></li>
<li class="L6402" rel="L6402">“In vain I have struggled. It will not do. My feelings will not be</li>
<li class="L6403" rel="L6403">repressed. You must allow me to tell you how ardently I admire and love</li>
<li class="L6404" rel="L6404">you.”</li>
<li class="L6405" rel="L6405"></li>
<li class="L6406" rel="L6406">Elizabeth&#39;s astonishment was beyond expression. She stared, coloured,</li>
<li class="L6407" rel="L6407">doubted, and was silent. This he considered sufficient encouragement;</li>
<li class="L6408" rel="L6408">and the avowal of all that he felt, and had long felt for her,</li>
<li class="L6409" rel="L6409">immediately followed. He spoke well; but there were feelings besides</li>
<li class="L6410" rel="L6410">those of the heart to be detailed; and he was not more eloquent on the</li>
<li class="L6411" rel="L6411">subject of tenderness than of pride. His sense of her inferiority--of</li>
<li class="L6412" rel="L6412">its being a degradation--of the family obstacles which had always</li>
<li class="L6413" rel="L6413">opposed to inclination, were dwelt on with a warmth which seemed due to</li>
<li class="L6414" rel="L6414">the consequence he was wounding, but was very unlikely to recommend his</li>
<li class="L6415" rel="L6415">suit.</li>
<li class="L6416" rel="L6416"></li>
<li class="L6417" rel="L6417">In spite of her deeply-rooted dislike, she could not be insensible to</li>
<li class="L6418" rel="L6418">the compliment of such a man&#39;s affection, and though her intentions did</li>
<li class="L6419" rel="L6419">not vary for an instant, she was at first sorry for the pain he was to</li>
<li class="L6420" rel="L6420">receive; till, roused to resentment by his subsequent language, she</li>
<li class="L6421" rel="L6421">lost all compassion in anger. She tried, however, to compose herself to</li>
<li class="L6422" rel="L6422">answer him with patience, when he should have done. He concluded with</li>
<li class="L6423" rel="L6423">representing to her the strength of that attachment which, in spite</li>
<li class="L6424" rel="L6424">of all his endeavours, he had found impossible to conquer; and with</li>
<li class="L6425" rel="L6425">expressing his hope that it would now be rewarded by her acceptance of</li>
<li class="L6426" rel="L6426">his hand. As he said this, she could easily see that he had no doubt</li>
<li class="L6427" rel="L6427">of a favourable answer. He _spoke_ of apprehension and anxiety, but</li>
<li class="L6428" rel="L6428">his countenance expressed real security. Such a circumstance could</li>
<li class="L6429" rel="L6429">only exasperate farther, and, when he ceased, the colour rose into her</li>
<li class="L6430" rel="L6430">cheeks, and she said:</li>
<li class="L6431" rel="L6431"></li>
<li class="L6432" rel="L6432">“In such cases as this, it is, I believe, the established mode to</li>
<li class="L6433" rel="L6433">express a sense of obligation for the sentiments avowed, however</li>
<li class="L6434" rel="L6434">unequally they may be returned. It is natural that obligation should</li>
<li class="L6435" rel="L6435">be felt, and if I could _feel_ gratitude, I would now thank you. But I</li>
<li class="L6436" rel="L6436">cannot--I have never desired your good opinion, and you have certainly</li>
<li class="L6437" rel="L6437">bestowed it most unwillingly. I am sorry to have occasioned pain to</li>
<li class="L6438" rel="L6438">anyone. It has been most unconsciously done, however, and I hope will be</li>
<li class="L6439" rel="L6439">of short duration. The feelings which, you tell me, have long prevented</li>
<li class="L6440" rel="L6440">the acknowledgment of your regard, can have little difficulty in</li>
<li class="L6441" rel="L6441">overcoming it after this explanation.”</li>
<li class="L6442" rel="L6442"></li>
<li class="L6443" rel="L6443">Mr. Darcy, who was leaning against the mantelpiece with his eyes fixed</li>
<li class="L6444" rel="L6444">on her face, seemed to catch her words with no less resentment than</li>
<li class="L6445" rel="L6445">surprise. His complexion became pale with anger, and the disturbance</li>
<li class="L6446" rel="L6446">of his mind was visible in every feature. He was struggling for the</li>
<li class="L6447" rel="L6447">appearance of composure, and would not open his lips till he believed</li>
<li class="L6448" rel="L6448">himself to have attained it. The pause was to Elizabeth&#39;s feelings</li>
<li class="L6449" rel="L6449">dreadful. At length, with a voice of forced calmness, he said:</li>
<li class="L6450" rel="L6450"></li>
<li class="L6451" rel="L6451">“And this is all the reply which I am to have the honour of expecting!</li>
<li class="L6452" rel="L6452">I might, perhaps, wish to be informed why, with so little _endeavour_ at</li>
<li class="L6453" rel="L6453">civility, I am thus rejected. But it is of small importance.”</li>
<li class="L6454" rel="L6454"></li>
<li class="L6455" rel="L6455">“I might as well inquire,” replied she, “why with so evident a desire</li>
<li class="L6456" rel="L6456">of offending and insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me</li>
<li class="L6457" rel="L6457">against your will, against your reason, and even against your character?</li>
<li class="L6458" rel="L6458">Was not this some excuse for incivility, if I _was_ uncivil? But I have</li>
<li class="L6459" rel="L6459">other provocations. You know I have. Had not my feelings decided against</li>
<li class="L6460" rel="L6460">you--had they been indifferent, or had they even been favourable, do you</li>
<li class="L6461" rel="L6461">think that any consideration would tempt me to accept the man who has</li>
<li class="L6462" rel="L6462">been the means of ruining, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most</li>
<li class="L6463" rel="L6463">beloved sister?”</li>
<li class="L6464" rel="L6464"></li>
<li class="L6465" rel="L6465">As she pronounced these words, Mr. Darcy changed colour; but the emotion</li>
<li class="L6466" rel="L6466">was short, and he listened without attempting to interrupt her while she</li>
<li class="L6467" rel="L6467">continued:</li>
<li class="L6468" rel="L6468"></li>
<li class="L6469" rel="L6469">“I have every reason in the world to think ill of you. No motive can</li>
<li class="L6470" rel="L6470">excuse the unjust and ungenerous part you acted _there_. You dare not,</li>
<li class="L6471" rel="L6471">you cannot deny, that you have been the principal, if not the only means</li>
<li class="L6472" rel="L6472">of dividing them from each other--of exposing one to the censure of the</li>
<li class="L6473" rel="L6473">world for caprice and instability, and the other to its derision for</li>
<li class="L6474" rel="L6474">disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest</li>
<li class="L6475" rel="L6475">kind.”</li>
<li class="L6476" rel="L6476"></li>
<li class="L6477" rel="L6477">She paused, and saw with no slight indignation that he was listening</li>
<li class="L6478" rel="L6478">with an air which proved him wholly unmoved by any feeling of remorse.</li>
<li class="L6479" rel="L6479">He even looked at her with a smile of affected incredulity.</li>
<li class="L6480" rel="L6480"></li>
<li class="L6481" rel="L6481">“Can you deny that you have done it?” she repeated.</li>
<li class="L6482" rel="L6482"></li>
<li class="L6483" rel="L6483">With assumed tranquillity he then replied: “I have no wish of denying</li>
<li class="L6484" rel="L6484">that I did everything in my power to separate my friend from your</li>
<li class="L6485" rel="L6485">sister, or that I rejoice in my success. Towards _him_ I have been</li>
<li class="L6486" rel="L6486">kinder than towards myself.”</li>
<li class="L6487" rel="L6487"></li>
<li class="L6488" rel="L6488">Elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection,</li>
<li class="L6489" rel="L6489">but its meaning did not escape, nor was it likely to conciliate her.</li>
<li class="L6490" rel="L6490"></li>
<li class="L6491" rel="L6491">“But it is not merely this affair,” she continued, “on which my dislike</li>
