<li class="L6492" rel="L6492">is founded. Long before it had taken place my opinion of you was</li>
<li class="L6493" rel="L6493">decided. Your character was unfolded in the recital which I received</li>
<li class="L6494" rel="L6494">many months ago from Mr. Wickham. On this subject, what can you have to</li>
<li class="L6495" rel="L6495">say? In what imaginary act of friendship can you here defend yourself?</li>
<li class="L6496" rel="L6496">or under what misrepresentation can you here impose upon others?”</li>
<li class="L6497" rel="L6497"></li>
<li class="L6498" rel="L6498">“You take an eager interest in that gentleman&#39;s concerns,” said Darcy,</li>
<li class="L6499" rel="L6499">in a less tranquil tone, and with a heightened colour.</li>
<li class="L6500" rel="L6500"></li>
<li class="L6501" rel="L6501">“Who that knows what his misfortunes have been, can help feeling an</li>
<li class="L6502" rel="L6502">interest in him?”</li>
<li class="L6503" rel="L6503"></li>
<li class="L6504" rel="L6504">“His misfortunes!” repeated Darcy contemptuously; “yes, his misfortunes</li>
<li class="L6505" rel="L6505">have been great indeed.”</li>
<li class="L6506" rel="L6506"></li>
<li class="L6507" rel="L6507">“And of your infliction,” cried Elizabeth with energy. “You have reduced</li>
<li class="L6508" rel="L6508">him to his present state of poverty--comparative poverty. You have</li>
<li class="L6509" rel="L6509">withheld the advantages which you must know to have been designed for</li>
<li class="L6510" rel="L6510">him. You have deprived the best years of his life of that independence</li>
<li class="L6511" rel="L6511">which was no less his due than his desert. You have done all this!</li>
<li class="L6512" rel="L6512">and yet you can treat the mention of his misfortune with contempt and</li>
<li class="L6513" rel="L6513">ridicule.”</li>
<li class="L6514" rel="L6514"></li>
<li class="L6515" rel="L6515">“And this,” cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room,</li>
<li class="L6516" rel="L6516">“is your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me!</li>
<li class="L6517" rel="L6517">I thank you for explaining it so fully. My faults, according to this</li>
<li class="L6518" rel="L6518">calculation, are heavy indeed! But perhaps,” added he, stopping in</li>
<li class="L6519" rel="L6519">his walk, and turning towards her, “these offenses might have been</li>
<li class="L6520" rel="L6520">overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the</li>
<li class="L6521" rel="L6521">scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design. These</li>
<li class="L6522" rel="L6522">bitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I, with greater</li>
<li class="L6523" rel="L6523">policy, concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of</li>
<li class="L6524" rel="L6524">my being impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by</li>
<li class="L6525" rel="L6525">reflection, by everything. But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence.</li>
<li class="L6526" rel="L6526">Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and</li>
<li class="L6527" rel="L6527">just. Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your</li>
<li class="L6528" rel="L6528">connections?--to congratulate myself on the hope of relations, whose</li>
<li class="L6529" rel="L6529">condition in life is so decidedly beneath my own?”</li>
<li class="L6530" rel="L6530"></li>
<li class="L6531" rel="L6531">Elizabeth felt herself growing more angry every moment; yet she tried to</li>
<li class="L6532" rel="L6532">the utmost to speak with composure when she said:</li>
<li class="L6533" rel="L6533"></li>
<li class="L6534" rel="L6534">“You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that the mode of your</li>
<li class="L6535" rel="L6535">declaration affected me in any other way, than as it spared me the concern</li>
<li class="L6536" rel="L6536">which I might have felt in refusing you, had you behaved in a more</li>
<li class="L6537" rel="L6537">gentlemanlike manner.”</li>
<li class="L6538" rel="L6538"></li>
<li class="L6539" rel="L6539">She saw him start at this, but he said nothing, and she continued:</li>
<li class="L6540" rel="L6540"></li>
<li class="L6541" rel="L6541">“You could not have made the offer of your hand in any possible way that</li>
<li class="L6542" rel="L6542">would have tempted me to accept it.”</li>
<li class="L6543" rel="L6543"></li>
<li class="L6544" rel="L6544">Again his astonishment was obvious; and he looked at her with an</li>
<li class="L6545" rel="L6545">expression of mingled incredulity and mortification. She went on:</li>
<li class="L6546" rel="L6546"></li>
<li class="L6547" rel="L6547">“From the very beginning--from the first moment, I may almost say--of</li>
<li class="L6548" rel="L6548">my acquaintance with you, your manners, impressing me with the fullest</li>
<li class="L6549" rel="L6549">belief of your arrogance, your conceit, and your selfish disdain of</li>
<li class="L6550" rel="L6550">the feelings of others, were such as to form the groundwork of</li>
<li class="L6551" rel="L6551">disapprobation on which succeeding events have built so immovable a</li>
<li class="L6552" rel="L6552">dislike; and I had not known you a month before I felt that you were the</li>
<li class="L6553" rel="L6553">last man in the world whom I could ever be prevailed on to marry.”</li>
<li class="L6554" rel="L6554"></li>
<li class="L6555" rel="L6555">“You have said quite enough, madam. I perfectly comprehend your</li>
<li class="L6556" rel="L6556">feelings, and have now only to be ashamed of what my own have been.</li>
<li class="L6557" rel="L6557">Forgive me for having taken up so much of your time, and accept my best</li>
<li class="L6558" rel="L6558">wishes for your health and happiness.”</li>
<li class="L6559" rel="L6559"></li>
<li class="L6560" rel="L6560">And with these words he hastily left the room, and Elizabeth heard him</li>
<li class="L6561" rel="L6561">the next moment open the front door and quit the house.</li>
<li class="L6562" rel="L6562"></li>
<li class="L6563" rel="L6563">The tumult of her mind, was now painfully great. She knew not how</li>
<li class="L6564" rel="L6564">to support herself, and from actual weakness sat down and cried for</li>
<li class="L6565" rel="L6565">half-an-hour. Her astonishment, as she reflected on what had passed,</li>
<li class="L6566" rel="L6566">was increased by every review of it. That she should receive an offer of</li>
<li class="L6567" rel="L6567">marriage from Mr. Darcy! That he should have been in love with her for</li>
<li class="L6568" rel="L6568">so many months! So much in love as to wish to marry her in spite of</li>
<li class="L6569" rel="L6569">all the objections which had made him prevent his friend&#39;s marrying</li>
<li class="L6570" rel="L6570">her sister, and which must appear at least with equal force in his</li>
<li class="L6571" rel="L6571">own case--was almost incredible! It was gratifying to have inspired</li>
<li class="L6572" rel="L6572">unconsciously so strong an affection. But his pride, his abominable</li>
<li class="L6573" rel="L6573">pride--his shameless avowal of what he had done with respect to</li>
<li class="L6574" rel="L6574">Jane--his unpardonable assurance in acknowledging, though he could</li>
<li class="L6575" rel="L6575">not justify it, and the unfeeling manner in which he had mentioned Mr.</li>
<li class="L6576" rel="L6576">Wickham, his cruelty towards whom he had not attempted to deny, soon</li>
<li class="L6577" rel="L6577">overcame the pity which the consideration of his attachment had for</li>
<li class="L6578" rel="L6578">a moment excited. She continued in very agitated reflections till the</li>
<li class="L6579" rel="L6579">sound of Lady Catherine&#39;s carriage made her feel how unequal she was to</li>
<li class="L6580" rel="L6580">encounter Charlotte&#39;s observation, and hurried her away to her room.</li>
<li class="L6581" rel="L6581"></li>
<li class="L6582" rel="L6582"></li>
<li class="L6583" rel="L6583"></li>
<li class="L6584" rel="L6584">Chapter 35</li>
<li class="L6585" rel="L6585"></li>
<li class="L6586" rel="L6586"></li>
<li class="L6587" rel="L6587">Elizabeth awoke the next morning to the same thoughts and meditations</li>
<li class="L6588" rel="L6588">which had at length closed her eyes. She could not yet recover from the</li>
<li class="L6589" rel="L6589">surprise of what had happened; it was impossible to think of anything</li>
<li class="L6590" rel="L6590">else; and, totally indisposed for employment, she resolved, soon after</li>
<li class="L6591" rel="L6591">breakfast, to indulge herself in air and exercise. She was proceeding</li>
<li class="L6592" rel="L6592">directly to her favourite walk, when the recollection of Mr. Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6593" rel="L6593">sometimes coming there stopped her, and instead of entering the park,</li>
<li class="L6594" rel="L6594">she turned up the lane, which led farther from the turnpike-road. The</li>
<li class="L6595" rel="L6595">park paling was still the boundary on one side, and she soon passed one</li>
<li class="L6596" rel="L6596">of the gates into the ground.</li>
<li class="L6597" rel="L6597"></li>
<li class="L6598" rel="L6598">After walking two or three times along that part of the lane, she was</li>
<li class="L6599" rel="L6599">tempted, by the pleasantness of the morning, to stop at the gates and</li>
<li class="L6600" rel="L6600">look into the park. The five weeks which she had now passed in Kent had</li>
<li class="L6601" rel="L6601">made a great difference in the country, and every day was adding to the</li>
<li class="L6602" rel="L6602">verdure of the early trees. She was on the point of continuing her walk,</li>
<li class="L6603" rel="L6603">when she caught a glimpse of a gentleman within the sort of grove which</li>
<li class="L6604" rel="L6604">edged the park; he was moving that way; and, fearful of its being Mr.</li>
<li class="L6605" rel="L6605">Darcy, she was directly retreating. But the person who advanced was now</li>
<li class="L6606" rel="L6606">near enough to see her, and stepping forward with eagerness, pronounced</li>
<li class="L6607" rel="L6607">her name. She had turned away; but on hearing herself called, though</li>
<li class="L6608" rel="L6608">in a voice which proved it to be Mr. Darcy, she moved again towards the</li>
<li class="L6609" rel="L6609">gate. He had by that time reached it also, and, holding out a letter,</li>
<li class="L6610" rel="L6610">which she instinctively took, said, with a look of haughty composure,</li>
<li class="L6611" rel="L6611">“I have been walking in the grove some time in the hope of meeting you.</li>
<li class="L6612" rel="L6612">Will you do me the honour of reading that letter?” And then, with a</li>
<li class="L6613" rel="L6613">slight bow, turned again into the plantation, and was soon out of sight.</li>
<li class="L6614" rel="L6614"></li>
<li class="L6615" rel="L6615">With no expectation of pleasure, but with the strongest curiosity,</li>
<li class="L6616" rel="L6616">Elizabeth opened the letter, and, to her still increasing wonder,</li>
<li class="L6617" rel="L6617">perceived an envelope containing two sheets of letter-paper, written</li>
<li class="L6618" rel="L6618">quite through, in a very close hand. The envelope itself was likewise</li>
<li class="L6619" rel="L6619">full. Pursuing her way along the lane, she then began it. It was dated</li>
<li class="L6620" rel="L6620">from Rosings, at eight o&#39;clock in the morning, and was as follows:--</li>
<li class="L6621" rel="L6621"></li>
<li class="L6622" rel="L6622">“Be not alarmed, madam, on receiving this letter, by the apprehension</li>
<li class="L6623" rel="L6623">of its containing any repetition of those sentiments or renewal of those</li>
<li class="L6624" rel="L6624">offers which were last night so disgusting to you. I write without any</li>
<li class="L6625" rel="L6625">intention of paining you, or humbling myself, by dwelling on wishes</li>
<li class="L6626" rel="L6626">which, for the happiness of both, cannot be too soon forgotten; and the</li>
<li class="L6627" rel="L6627">effort which the formation and the perusal of this letter must occasion,</li>
<li class="L6628" rel="L6628">should have been spared, had not my character required it to be written</li>
<li class="L6629" rel="L6629">and read. You must, therefore, pardon the freedom with which I demand</li>
<li class="L6630" rel="L6630">your attention; your feelings, I know, will bestow it unwillingly, but I</li>
<li class="L6631" rel="L6631">demand it of your justice.</li>
<li class="L6632" rel="L6632"></li>
<li class="L6633" rel="L6633">“Two offenses of a very different nature, and by no means of equal</li>
<li class="L6634" rel="L6634">magnitude, you last night laid to my charge. The first mentioned was,</li>
<li class="L6635" rel="L6635">that, regardless of the sentiments of either, I had detached Mr. Bingley</li>
<li class="L6636" rel="L6636">from your sister, and the other, that I had, in defiance of various</li>
<li class="L6637" rel="L6637">claims, in defiance of honour and humanity, ruined the immediate</li>
<li class="L6638" rel="L6638">prosperity and blasted the prospects of Mr. Wickham. Wilfully and</li>
<li class="L6639" rel="L6639">wantonly to have thrown off the companion of my youth, the acknowledged</li>
<li class="L6640" rel="L6640">favourite of my father, a young man who had scarcely any other</li>
<li class="L6641" rel="L6641">dependence than on our patronage, and who had been brought up to expect</li>
<li class="L6642" rel="L6642">its exertion, would be a depravity, to which the separation of two young</li>
<li class="L6643" rel="L6643">persons, whose affection could be the growth of only a few weeks, could</li>
<li class="L6644" rel="L6644">bear no comparison. But from the severity of that blame which was last</li>
<li class="L6645" rel="L6645">night so liberally bestowed, respecting each circumstance, I shall hope</li>
<li class="L6646" rel="L6646">to be in the future secured, when the following account of my actions</li>
<li class="L6647" rel="L6647">and their motives has been read. If, in the explanation of them, which</li>
<li class="L6648" rel="L6648">is due to myself, I am under the necessity of relating feelings which</li>
<li class="L6649" rel="L6649">may be offensive to yours, I can only say that I am sorry. The necessity</li>
<li class="L6650" rel="L6650">must be obeyed, and further apology would be absurd.</li>
<li class="L6651" rel="L6651"></li>
<li class="L6652" rel="L6652">“I had not been long in Hertfordshire, before I saw, in common with</li>
<li class="L6653" rel="L6653">others, that Bingley preferred your elder sister to any other young</li>
<li class="L6654" rel="L6654">woman in the country. But it was not till the evening of the dance</li>
<li class="L6655" rel="L6655">at Netherfield that I had any apprehension of his feeling a serious</li>
<li class="L6656" rel="L6656">attachment. I had often seen him in love before. At that ball, while I</li>
<li class="L6657" rel="L6657">had the honour of dancing with you, I was first made acquainted, by Sir</li>
<li class="L6658" rel="L6658">William Lucas&#39;s accidental information, that Bingley&#39;s attentions to</li>
<li class="L6659" rel="L6659">your sister had given rise to a general expectation of their marriage.</li>
<li class="L6660" rel="L6660">He spoke of it as a certain event, of which the time alone could</li>
<li class="L6661" rel="L6661">be undecided. From that moment I observed my friend&#39;s behaviour</li>
<li class="L6662" rel="L6662">attentively; and I could then perceive that his partiality for Miss</li>
<li class="L6663" rel="L6663">Bennet was beyond what I had ever witnessed in him. Your sister I also</li>
<li class="L6664" rel="L6664">watched. Her look and manners were open, cheerful, and engaging as ever,</li>
<li class="L6665" rel="L6665">but without any symptom of peculiar regard, and I remained convinced</li>
<li class="L6666" rel="L6666">from the evening&#39;s scrutiny, that though she received his attentions</li>
<li class="L6667" rel="L6667">with pleasure, she did not invite them by any participation of</li>
<li class="L6668" rel="L6668">sentiment. If _you_ have not been mistaken here, _I_ must have been</li>
<li class="L6669" rel="L6669">in error. Your superior knowledge of your sister must make the latter</li>
<li class="L6670" rel="L6670">probable. If it be so, if I have been misled by such error to inflict</li>
<li class="L6671" rel="L6671">pain on her, your resentment has not been unreasonable. But I shall not</li>
<li class="L6672" rel="L6672">scruple to assert, that the serenity of your sister&#39;s countenance and</li>
<li class="L6673" rel="L6673">air was such as might have given the most acute observer a conviction</li>
<li class="L6674" rel="L6674">that, however amiable her temper, her heart was not likely to be</li>
<li class="L6675" rel="L6675">easily touched. That I was desirous of believing her indifferent is</li>
<li class="L6676" rel="L6676">certain--but I will venture to say that my investigation and decisions</li>
<li class="L6677" rel="L6677">are not usually influenced by my hopes or fears. I did not believe</li>
<li class="L6678" rel="L6678">her to be indifferent because I wished it; I believed it on impartial</li>
<li class="L6679" rel="L6679">conviction, as truly as I wished it in reason. My objections to the</li>
<li class="L6680" rel="L6680">marriage were not merely those which I last night acknowledged to have</li>
<li class="L6681" rel="L6681">the utmost force of passion to put aside, in my own case; the want of</li>
<li class="L6682" rel="L6682">connection could not be so great an evil to my friend as to me. But</li>
<li class="L6683" rel="L6683">there were other causes of repugnance; causes which, though still</li>
<li class="L6684" rel="L6684">existing, and existing to an equal degree in both instances, I had</li>
<li class="L6685" rel="L6685">myself endeavoured to forget, because they were not immediately before</li>
<li class="L6686" rel="L6686">me. These causes must be stated, though briefly. The situation of your</li>
<li class="L6687" rel="L6687">mother&#39;s family, though objectionable, was nothing in comparison to that</li>
<li class="L6688" rel="L6688">total want of propriety so frequently, so almost uniformly betrayed by</li>
<li class="L6689" rel="L6689">herself, by your three younger sisters, and occasionally even by your</li>
<li class="L6690" rel="L6690">father. Pardon me. It pains me to offend you. But amidst your concern</li>
<li class="L6691" rel="L6691">for the defects of your nearest relations, and your displeasure at this</li>
<li class="L6692" rel="L6692">representation of them, let it give you consolation to consider that, to</li>
<li class="L6693" rel="L6693">have conducted yourselves so as to avoid any share of the like censure,</li>
<li class="L6694" rel="L6694">is praise no less generally bestowed on you and your elder sister, than</li>
<li class="L6695" rel="L6695">it is honourable to the sense and disposition of both. I will only say</li>
<li class="L6696" rel="L6696">farther that from what passed that evening, my opinion of all parties</li>
<li class="L6697" rel="L6697">was confirmed, and every inducement heightened which could have led</li>
<li class="L6698" rel="L6698">me before, to preserve my friend from what I esteemed a most unhappy</li>
<li class="L6699" rel="L6699">connection. He left Netherfield for London, on the day following, as</li>
<li class="L6700" rel="L6700">you, I am certain, remember, with the design of soon returning.</li>
<li class="L6701" rel="L6701"></li>
<li class="L6702" rel="L6702">“The part which I acted is now to be explained. His sisters&#39; uneasiness</li>
<li class="L6703" rel="L6703">had been equally excited with my own; our coincidence of feeling was</li>
<li class="L6704" rel="L6704">soon discovered, and, alike sensible that no time was to be lost in</li>
<li class="L6705" rel="L6705">detaching their brother, we shortly resolved on joining him directly in</li>
<li class="L6706" rel="L6706">London. We accordingly went--and there I readily engaged in the office</li>
<li class="L6707" rel="L6707">of pointing out to my friend the certain evils of such a choice. I</li>
<li class="L6708" rel="L6708">described, and enforced them earnestly. But, however this remonstrance</li>
<li class="L6709" rel="L6709">might have staggered or delayed his determination, I do not suppose</li>
<li class="L6710" rel="L6710">that it would ultimately have prevented the marriage, had it not been</li>
<li class="L6711" rel="L6711">seconded by the assurance that I hesitated not in giving, of your</li>
<li class="L6712" rel="L6712">sister&#39;s indifference. He had before believed her to return his</li>
<li class="L6713" rel="L6713">affection with sincere, if not with equal regard. But Bingley has great</li>
<li class="L6714" rel="L6714">natural modesty, with a stronger dependence on my judgement than on his</li>
<li class="L6715" rel="L6715">own. To convince him, therefore, that he had deceived himself, was</li>
<li class="L6716" rel="L6716">no very difficult point. To persuade him against returning into</li>
<li class="L6717" rel="L6717">Hertfordshire, when that conviction had been given, was scarcely the</li>
<li class="L6718" rel="L6718">work of a moment. I cannot blame myself for having done thus much. There</li>
<li class="L6719" rel="L6719">is but one part of my conduct in the whole affair on which I do not</li>
<li class="L6720" rel="L6720">reflect with satisfaction; it is that I condescended to adopt the</li>
<li class="L6721" rel="L6721">measures of art so far as to conceal from him your sister&#39;s being in</li>
<li class="L6722" rel="L6722">town. I knew it myself, as it was known to Miss Bingley; but her</li>
<li class="L6723" rel="L6723">brother is even yet ignorant of it. That they might have met without</li>
<li class="L6724" rel="L6724">ill consequence is perhaps probable; but his regard did not appear to me</li>
<li class="L6725" rel="L6725">enough extinguished for him to see her without some danger. Perhaps this</li>
<li class="L6726" rel="L6726">concealment, this disguise was beneath me; it is done, however, and it</li>
<li class="L6727" rel="L6727">was done for the best. On this subject I have nothing more to say, no</li>
<li class="L6728" rel="L6728">other apology to offer. If I have wounded your sister&#39;s feelings, it</li>
<li class="L6729" rel="L6729">was unknowingly done and though the motives which governed me may to</li>
<li class="L6730" rel="L6730">you very naturally appear insufficient, I have not yet learnt to condemn</li>
<li class="L6731" rel="L6731">them.</li>
<li class="L6732" rel="L6732"></li>
<li class="L6733" rel="L6733">“With respect to that other, more weighty accusation, of having injured</li>
<li class="L6734" rel="L6734">Mr. Wickham, I can only refute it by laying before you the whole of his</li>
<li class="L6735" rel="L6735">connection with my family. Of what he has _particularly_ accused me I</li>
<li class="L6736" rel="L6736">am ignorant; but of the truth of what I shall relate, I can summon more</li>
<li class="L6737" rel="L6737">than one witness of undoubted veracity.</li>
<li class="L6738" rel="L6738"></li>
<li class="L6739" rel="L6739">“Mr. Wickham is the son of a very respectable man, who had for many</li>
<li class="L6740" rel="L6740">years the management of all the Pemberley estates, and whose good</li>
<li class="L6741" rel="L6741">conduct in the discharge of his trust naturally inclined my father to</li>
<li class="L6742" rel="L6742">be of service to him; and on George Wickham, who was his godson, his</li>
<li class="L6743" rel="L6743">kindness was therefore liberally bestowed. My father supported him at</li>
<li class="L6744" rel="L6744">school, and afterwards at Cambridge--most important assistance, as his</li>
<li class="L6745" rel="L6745">own father, always poor from the extravagance of his wife, would have</li>
<li class="L6746" rel="L6746">been unable to give him a gentleman&#39;s education. My father was not only</li>
<li class="L6747" rel="L6747">fond of this young man&#39;s society, whose manners were always engaging; he</li>
<li class="L6748" rel="L6748">had also the highest opinion of him, and hoping the church would be</li>
<li class="L6749" rel="L6749">his profession, intended to provide for him in it. As for myself, it is</li>
<li class="L6750" rel="L6750">many, many years since I first began to think of him in a very different</li>
<li class="L6751" rel="L6751">manner. The vicious propensities--the want of principle, which he was</li>
<li class="L6752" rel="L6752">careful to guard from the knowledge of his best friend, could not escape</li>
<li class="L6753" rel="L6753">the observation of a young man of nearly the same age with himself,</li>
<li class="L6754" rel="L6754">and who had opportunities of seeing him in unguarded moments, which Mr.</li>
<li class="L6755" rel="L6755">Darcy could not have. Here again I shall give you pain--to what degree</li>
<li class="L6756" rel="L6756">you only can tell. But whatever may be the sentiments which Mr. Wickham</li>
<li class="L6757" rel="L6757">has created, a suspicion of their nature shall not prevent me from</li>
<li class="L6758" rel="L6758">unfolding his real character--it adds even another motive.</li>
<li class="L6759" rel="L6759"></li>
<li class="L6760" rel="L6760">“My excellent father died about five years ago; and his attachment to</li>
<li class="L6761" rel="L6761">Mr. Wickham was to the last so steady, that in his will he particularly</li>
<li class="L6762" rel="L6762">recommended it to me, to promote his advancement in the best manner</li>
<li class="L6763" rel="L6763">that his profession might allow--and if he took orders, desired that a</li>
<li class="L6764" rel="L6764">valuable family living might be his as soon as it became vacant. There</li>
<li class="L6765" rel="L6765">was also a legacy of one thousand pounds. His own father did not long</li>
<li class="L6766" rel="L6766">survive mine, and within half a year from these events, Mr. Wickham</li>
<li class="L6767" rel="L6767">wrote to inform me that, having finally resolved against taking orders,</li>
<li class="L6768" rel="L6768">he hoped I should not think it unreasonable for him to expect some more</li>
<li class="L6769" rel="L6769">immediate pecuniary advantage, in lieu of the preferment, by which he</li>
<li class="L6770" rel="L6770">could not be benefited. He had some intention, he added, of studying</li>
<li class="L6771" rel="L6771">law, and I must be aware that the interest of one thousand pounds would</li>
<li class="L6772" rel="L6772">be a very insufficient support therein. I rather wished, than believed</li>
<li class="L6773" rel="L6773">him to be sincere; but, at any rate, was perfectly ready to accede to</li>
<li class="L6774" rel="L6774">his proposal. I knew that Mr. Wickham ought not to be a clergyman; the</li>
<li class="L6775" rel="L6775">business was therefore soon settled--he resigned all claim to assistance</li>
<li class="L6776" rel="L6776">in the church, were it possible that he could ever be in a situation to</li>
<li class="L6777" rel="L6777">receive it, and accepted in return three thousand pounds. All connection</li>
<li class="L6778" rel="L6778">between us seemed now dissolved. I thought too ill of him to invite him</li>
<li class="L6779" rel="L6779">to Pemberley, or admit his society in town. In town I believe he chiefly</li>
<li class="L6780" rel="L6780">lived, but his studying the law was a mere pretence, and being now free</li>
<li class="L6781" rel="L6781">from all restraint, his life was a life of idleness and dissipation.</li>
<li class="L6782" rel="L6782">For about three years I heard little of him; but on the decease of the</li>
<li class="L6783" rel="L6783">incumbent of the living which had been designed for him, he applied to</li>
<li class="L6784" rel="L6784">me again by letter for the presentation. His circumstances, he assured</li>
<li class="L6785" rel="L6785">me, and I had no difficulty in believing it, were exceedingly bad. He</li>
<li class="L6786" rel="L6786">had found the law a most unprofitable study, and was now absolutely</li>
<li class="L6787" rel="L6787">resolved on being ordained, if I would present him to the living in</li>
<li class="L6788" rel="L6788">question--of which he trusted there could be little doubt, as he was</li>
<li class="L6789" rel="L6789">well assured that I had no other person to provide for, and I could not</li>
<li class="L6790" rel="L6790">have forgotten my revered father&#39;s intentions. You will hardly blame</li>
<li class="L6791" rel="L6791">me for refusing to comply with this entreaty, or for resisting every</li>
<li class="L6792" rel="L6792">repetition to it. His resentment was in proportion to the distress of</li>
<li class="L6793" rel="L6793">his circumstances--and he was doubtless as violent in his abuse of me</li>
<li class="L6794" rel="L6794">to others as in his reproaches to myself. After this period every</li>
<li class="L6795" rel="L6795">appearance of acquaintance was dropped. How he lived I know not. But</li>
<li class="L6796" rel="L6796">last summer he was again most painfully obtruded on my notice.</li>
<li class="L6797" rel="L6797"></li>
<li class="L6798" rel="L6798">“I must now mention a circumstance which I would wish to forget myself,</li>
<li class="L6799" rel="L6799">and which no obligation less than the present should induce me to unfold</li>
<li class="L6800" rel="L6800">to any human being. Having said thus much, I feel no doubt of your</li>
<li class="L6801" rel="L6801">secrecy. My sister, who is more than ten years my junior, was left to</li>
<li class="L6802" rel="L6802">the guardianship of my mother&#39;s nephew, Colonel Fitzwilliam, and myself.</li>
<li class="L6803" rel="L6803">About a year ago, she was taken from school, and an establishment formed</li>
<li class="L6804" rel="L6804">for her in London; and last summer she went with the lady who presided</li>
<li class="L6805" rel="L6805">over it, to Ramsgate; and thither also went Mr. Wickham, undoubtedly by</li>
<li class="L6806" rel="L6806">design; for there proved to have been a prior acquaintance between him</li>
<li class="L6807" rel="L6807">and Mrs. Younge, in whose character we were most unhappily deceived; and</li>
<li class="L6808" rel="L6808">by her connivance and aid, he so far recommended himself to Georgiana,</li>
<li class="L6809" rel="L6809">whose affectionate heart retained a strong impression of his kindness to</li>
<li class="L6810" rel="L6810">her as a child, that she was persuaded to believe herself in love, and</li>
<li class="L6811" rel="L6811">to consent to an elopement. She was then but fifteen, which must be her</li>
<li class="L6812" rel="L6812">excuse; and after stating her imprudence, I am happy to add, that I owed</li>
<li class="L6813" rel="L6813">the knowledge of it to herself. I joined them unexpectedly a day or two</li>
<li class="L6814" rel="L6814">before the intended elopement, and then Georgiana, unable to support the</li>
<li class="L6815" rel="L6815">idea of grieving and offending a brother whom she almost looked up to as</li>
<li class="L6816" rel="L6816">a father, acknowledged the whole to me. You may imagine what I felt and</li>
<li class="L6817" rel="L6817">how I acted. Regard for my sister&#39;s credit and feelings prevented</li>
<li class="L6818" rel="L6818">any public exposure; but I wrote to Mr. Wickham, who left the place</li>
<li class="L6819" rel="L6819">immediately, and Mrs. Younge was of course removed from her charge. Mr.</li>
<li class="L6820" rel="L6820">Wickham&#39;s chief object was unquestionably my sister&#39;s fortune, which</li>
<li class="L6821" rel="L6821">is thirty thousand pounds; but I cannot help supposing that the hope of</li>
<li class="L6822" rel="L6822">revenging himself on me was a strong inducement. His revenge would have</li>
<li class="L6823" rel="L6823">been complete indeed.</li>
<li class="L6824" rel="L6824"></li>
<li class="L6825" rel="L6825">“This, madam, is a faithful narrative of every event in which we have</li>
<li class="L6826" rel="L6826">been concerned together; and if you do not absolutely reject it as</li>
<li class="L6827" rel="L6827">false, you will, I hope, acquit me henceforth of cruelty towards Mr.</li>
<li class="L6828" rel="L6828">Wickham. I know not in what manner, under what form of falsehood he</li>
<li class="L6829" rel="L6829">had imposed on you; but his success is not perhaps to be wondered</li>
<li class="L6830" rel="L6830">at. Ignorant as you previously were of everything concerning either,</li>
<li class="L6831" rel="L6831">detection could not be in your power, and suspicion certainly not in</li>
<li class="L6832" rel="L6832">your inclination.</li>
<li class="L6833" rel="L6833"></li>
<li class="L6834" rel="L6834">“You may possibly wonder why all this was not told you last night; but</li>
<li class="L6835" rel="L6835">I was not then master enough of myself to know what could or ought to</li>
<li class="L6836" rel="L6836">be revealed. For the truth of everything here related, I can appeal more</li>
<li class="L6837" rel="L6837">particularly to the testimony of Colonel Fitzwilliam, who, from our</li>
<li class="L6838" rel="L6838">near relationship and constant intimacy, and, still more, as one of</li>
<li class="L6839" rel="L6839">the executors of my father&#39;s will, has been unavoidably acquainted</li>
<li class="L6840" rel="L6840">with every particular of these transactions. If your abhorrence of _me_</li>
<li class="L6841" rel="L6841">should make _my_ assertions valueless, you cannot be prevented by</li>
<li class="L6842" rel="L6842">the same cause from confiding in my cousin; and that there may be</li>
<li class="L6843" rel="L6843">the possibility of consulting him, I shall endeavour to find some</li>
<li class="L6844" rel="L6844">opportunity of putting this letter in your hands in the course of the</li>
<li class="L6845" rel="L6845">morning. I will only add, God bless you.</li>
<li class="L6846" rel="L6846"></li>
<li class="L6847" rel="L6847">“FITZWILLIAM DARCY”</li>
<li class="L6848" rel="L6848"></li>
<li class="L6849" rel="L6849"></li>
<li class="L6850" rel="L6850"></li>
<li class="L6851" rel="L6851">Chapter 36</li>
<li class="L6852" rel="L6852"></li>
<li class="L6853" rel="L6853"></li>
<li class="L6854" rel="L6854">If Elizabeth, when Mr. Darcy gave her the letter, did not expect it to</li>
<li class="L6855" rel="L6855">contain a renewal of his offers, she had formed no expectation at all of</li>
<li class="L6856" rel="L6856">its contents. But such as they were, it may well be supposed how eagerly</li>
<li class="L6857" rel="L6857">she went through them, and what a contrariety of emotion they excited.</li>
<li class="L6858" rel="L6858">Her feelings as she read were scarcely to be defined. With amazement did</li>
<li class="L6859" rel="L6859">she first understand that he believed any apology to be in his power;</li>
<li class="L6860" rel="L6860">and steadfastly was she persuaded, that he could have no explanation</li>
<li class="L6861" rel="L6861">to give, which a just sense of shame would not conceal. With a strong</li>
<li class="L6862" rel="L6862">prejudice against everything he might say, she began his account of what</li>
<li class="L6863" rel="L6863">had happened at Netherfield. She read with an eagerness which hardly</li>
<li class="L6864" rel="L6864">left her power of comprehension, and from impatience of knowing what the</li>
<li class="L6865" rel="L6865">next sentence might bring, was incapable of attending to the sense of</li>
<li class="L6866" rel="L6866">the one before her eyes. His belief of her sister&#39;s insensibility she</li>
<li class="L6867" rel="L6867">instantly resolved to be false; and his account of the real, the worst</li>
<li class="L6868" rel="L6868">objections to the match, made her too angry to have any wish of doing</li>
<li class="L6869" rel="L6869">him justice. He expressed no regret for what he had done which satisfied</li>
<li class="L6870" rel="L6870">her; his style was not penitent, but haughty. It was all pride and</li>
<li class="L6871" rel="L6871">insolence.</li>
<li class="L6872" rel="L6872"></li>
<li class="L6873" rel="L6873">But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham--when</li>
<li class="L6874" rel="L6874">she read with somewhat clearer attention a relation of events which,</li>
<li class="L6875" rel="L6875">if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which</li>
<li class="L6876" rel="L6876">bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself--her</li>
<li class="L6877" rel="L6877">feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition.</li>
<li class="L6878" rel="L6878">Astonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed her. She wished</li>
<li class="L6879" rel="L6879">to discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false!</li>
<li class="L6880" rel="L6880">This cannot be! This must be the grossest falsehood!”--and when she had</li>
<li class="L6881" rel="L6881">gone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the</li>
<li class="L6882" rel="L6882">last page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that she would not</li>
<li class="L6883" rel="L6883">regard it, that she would never look in it again.</li>
<li class="L6884" rel="L6884"></li>
<li class="L6885" rel="L6885">In this perturbed state of mind, with thoughts that could rest on</li>
<li class="L6886" rel="L6886">nothing, she walked on; but it would not do; in half a minute the letter</li>
<li class="L6887" rel="L6887">was unfolded again, and collecting herself as well as she could, she</li>
<li class="L6888" rel="L6888">again began the mortifying perusal of all that related to Wickham, and</li>
<li class="L6889" rel="L6889">commanded herself so far as to examine the meaning of every sentence.</li>
<li class="L6890" rel="L6890">The account of his connection with the Pemberley family was exactly what</li>
<li class="L6891" rel="L6891">he had related himself; and the kindness of the late Mr. Darcy, though</li>
<li class="L6892" rel="L6892">she had not before known its extent, agreed equally well with his own</li>
<li class="L6893" rel="L6893">words. So far each recital confirmed the other; but when she came to the</li>
<li class="L6894" rel="L6894">will, the difference was great. What Wickham had said of the living</li>
<li class="L6895" rel="L6895">was fresh in her memory, and as she recalled his very words, it was</li>
<li class="L6896" rel="L6896">impossible not to feel that there was gross duplicity on one side or the</li>
<li class="L6897" rel="L6897">other; and, for a few moments, she flattered herself that her wishes did</li>
<li class="L6898" rel="L6898">not err. But when she read and re-read with the closest attention, the</li>
<li class="L6899" rel="L6899">particulars immediately following of Wickham&#39;s resigning all pretensions</li>
<li class="L6900" rel="L6900">to the living, of his receiving in lieu so considerable a sum as three</li>
<li class="L6901" rel="L6901">thousand pounds, again was she forced to hesitate. She put down</li>
<li class="L6902" rel="L6902">the letter, weighed every circumstance with what she meant to be</li>
<li class="L6903" rel="L6903">impartiality--deliberated on the probability of each statement--but with</li>
<li class="L6904" rel="L6904">little success. On both sides it was only assertion. Again she read</li>
<li class="L6905" rel="L6905">on; but every line proved more clearly that the affair, which she had</li>
<li class="L6906" rel="L6906">believed it impossible that any contrivance could so represent as to</li>
<li class="L6907" rel="L6907">render Mr. Darcy&#39;s conduct in it less than infamous, was capable of a</li>
<li class="L6908" rel="L6908">turn which must make him entirely blameless throughout the whole.</li>
<li class="L6909" rel="L6909"></li>
<li class="L6910" rel="L6910">The extravagance and general profligacy which he scrupled not to lay at</li>
<li class="L6911" rel="L6911">Mr. Wickham&#39;s charge, exceedingly shocked her; the more so, as she could</li>
<li class="L6912" rel="L6912">bring no proof of its injustice. She had never heard of him before his</li>
<li class="L6913" rel="L6913">entrance into the ----shire Militia, in which he had engaged at the</li>
<li class="L6914" rel="L6914">persuasion of the young man who, on meeting him accidentally in town,</li>
<li class="L6915" rel="L6915">had there renewed a slight acquaintance. Of his former way of life</li>
<li class="L6916" rel="L6916">nothing had been known in Hertfordshire but what he told himself. As</li>
<li class="L6917" rel="L6917">to his real character, had information been in her power, she had</li>
<li class="L6918" rel="L6918">never felt a wish of inquiring. His countenance, voice, and manner had</li>
<li class="L6919" rel="L6919">established him at once in the possession of every virtue. She tried</li>
<li class="L6920" rel="L6920">to recollect some instance of goodness, some distinguished trait of</li>
<li class="L6921" rel="L6921">integrity or benevolence, that might rescue him from the attacks of</li>
<li class="L6922" rel="L6922">Mr. Darcy; or at least, by the predominance of virtue, atone for those</li>
<li class="L6923" rel="L6923">casual errors under which she would endeavour to class what Mr. Darcy</li>
<li class="L6924" rel="L6924">had described as the idleness and vice of many years&#39; continuance. But</li>
<li class="L6925" rel="L6925">no such recollection befriended her. She could see him instantly before</li>
<li class="L6926" rel="L6926">her, in every charm of air and address; but she could remember no more</li>
<li class="L6927" rel="L6927">substantial good than the general approbation of the neighbourhood, and</li>
<li class="L6928" rel="L6928">the regard which his social powers had gained him in the mess. After</li>
<li class="L6929" rel="L6929">pausing on this point a considerable while, she once more continued to</li>
<li class="L6930" rel="L6930">read. But, alas! the story which followed, of his designs on Miss</li>
<li class="L6931" rel="L6931">Darcy, received some confirmation from what had passed between Colonel</li>
<li class="L6932" rel="L6932">Fitzwilliam and herself only the morning before; and at last she was</li>
<li class="L6933" rel="L6933">referred for the truth of every particular to Colonel Fitzwilliam</li>
<li class="L6934" rel="L6934">himself--from whom she had previously received the information of his</li>
<li class="L6935" rel="L6935">near concern in all his cousin&#39;s affairs, and whose character she had no</li>
<li class="L6936" rel="L6936">reason to question. At one time she had almost resolved on applying to</li>
<li class="L6937" rel="L6937">him, but the idea was checked by the awkwardness of the application, and</li>
<li class="L6938" rel="L6938">at length wholly banished by the conviction that Mr. Darcy would never</li>
<li class="L6939" rel="L6939">have hazarded such a proposal, if he had not been well assured of his</li>
<li class="L6940" rel="L6940">cousin&#39;s corroboration.</li>
<li class="L6941" rel="L6941"></li>
<li class="L6942" rel="L6942">She perfectly remembered everything that had passed in conversation</li>
<li class="L6943" rel="L6943">between Wickham and herself, in their first evening at Mr. Phillips&#39;s.</li>
<li class="L6944" rel="L6944">Many of his expressions were still fresh in her memory. She was _now_</li>
<li class="L6945" rel="L6945">struck with the impropriety of such communications to a stranger, and</li>
<li class="L6946" rel="L6946">wondered it had escaped her before. She saw the indelicacy of putting</li>
<li class="L6947" rel="L6947">himself forward as he had done, and the inconsistency of his professions</li>
<li class="L6948" rel="L6948">with his conduct. She remembered that he had boasted of having no fear</li>
<li class="L6949" rel="L6949">of seeing Mr. Darcy--that Mr. Darcy might leave the country, but that</li>
<li class="L6950" rel="L6950">_he_ should stand his ground; yet he had avoided the Netherfield ball</li>
<li class="L6951" rel="L6951">the very next week. She remembered also that, till the Netherfield</li>
<li class="L6952" rel="L6952">family had quitted the country, he had told his story to no one but</li>
<li class="L6953" rel="L6953">herself; but that after their removal it had been everywhere discussed;</li>
<li class="L6954" rel="L6954">that he had then no reserves, no scruples in sinking Mr. Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L6955" rel="L6955">character, though he had assured her that respect for the father would</li>
<li class="L6956" rel="L6956">always prevent his exposing the son.</li>
<li class="L6957" rel="L6957"></li>
<li class="L6958" rel="L6958">How differently did everything now appear in which he was concerned!</li>
<li class="L6959" rel="L6959">His attentions to Miss King were now the consequence of views solely and</li>
<li class="L6960" rel="L6960">hatefully mercenary; and the mediocrity of her fortune proved no longer</li>
<li class="L6961" rel="L6961">the moderation of his wishes, but his eagerness to grasp at anything.</li>
<li class="L6962" rel="L6962">His behaviour to herself could now have had no tolerable motive; he had</li>
<li class="L6963" rel="L6963">either been deceived with regard to her fortune, or had been gratifying</li>
<li class="L6964" rel="L6964">his vanity by encouraging the preference which she believed she had most</li>
<li class="L6965" rel="L6965">incautiously shown. Every lingering struggle in his favour grew fainter</li>
<li class="L6966" rel="L6966">and fainter; and in farther justification of Mr. Darcy, she could not</li>
<li class="L6967" rel="L6967">but allow that Mr. Bingley, when questioned by Jane, had long ago</li>
<li class="L6968" rel="L6968">asserted his blamelessness in the affair; that proud and repulsive as</li>
<li class="L6969" rel="L6969">were his manners, she had never, in the whole course of their</li>
<li class="L6970" rel="L6970">acquaintance--an acquaintance which had latterly brought them much</li>
<li class="L6971" rel="L6971">together, and given her a sort of intimacy with his ways--seen anything</li>
<li class="L6972" rel="L6972">that betrayed him to be unprincipled or unjust--anything that spoke him</li>
<li class="L6973" rel="L6973">of irreligious or immoral habits; that among his own connections he was</li>
<li class="L6974" rel="L6974">esteemed and valued--that even Wickham had allowed him merit as a</li>
<li class="L6975" rel="L6975">brother, and that she had often heard him speak so affectionately of his</li>
<li class="L6976" rel="L6976">sister as to prove him capable of _some_ amiable feeling; that had his</li>
<li class="L6977" rel="L6977">actions been what Mr. Wickham represented them, so gross a violation of</li>
<li class="L6978" rel="L6978">everything right could hardly have been concealed from the world; and</li>
<li class="L6979" rel="L6979">that friendship between a person capable of it, and such an amiable man</li>
<li class="L6980" rel="L6980">as Mr. Bingley, was incomprehensible.</li>
<li class="L6981" rel="L6981"></li>
<li class="L6982" rel="L6982">She grew absolutely ashamed of herself. Of neither Darcy nor Wickham</li>
<li class="L6983" rel="L6983">could she think without feeling she had been blind, partial, prejudiced,</li>
<li class="L6984" rel="L6984">absurd.</li>
<li class="L6985" rel="L6985"></li>
<li class="L6986" rel="L6986">“How despicably I have acted!” she cried; “I, who have prided myself</li>
<li class="L6987" rel="L6987">on my discernment! I, who have valued myself on my abilities! who have</li>
<li class="L6988" rel="L6988">often disdained the generous candour of my sister, and gratified</li>
<li class="L6989" rel="L6989">my vanity in useless or blameable mistrust! How humiliating is this</li>
<li class="L6990" rel="L6990">discovery! Yet, how just a humiliation! Had I been in love, I could</li>
<li class="L6991" rel="L6991">not have been more wretchedly blind! But vanity, not love, has been my</li>
<li class="L6992" rel="L6992">folly. Pleased with the preference of one, and offended by the neglect</li>
<li class="L6993" rel="L6993">of the other, on the very beginning of our acquaintance, I have courted</li>
<li class="L6994" rel="L6994">prepossession and ignorance, and driven reason away, where either were</li>
<li class="L6995" rel="L6995">concerned. Till this moment I never knew myself.”</li>
<li class="L6996" rel="L6996"></li>
<li class="L6997" rel="L6997">From herself to Jane--from Jane to Bingley, her thoughts were in a line</li>
<li class="L6998" rel="L6998">which soon brought to her recollection that Mr. Darcy&#39;s explanation</li>
<li class="L6999" rel="L6999">_there_ had appeared very insufficient, and she read it again. Widely</li>
<li class="L7000" rel="L7000">different was the effect of a second perusal. How could she deny that</li>
<li class="L7001" rel="L7001">credit to his assertions in one instance, which she had been obliged to</li>
<li class="L7002" rel="L7002">give in the other? He declared himself to be totally unsuspicious of her</li>
<li class="L7003" rel="L7003">sister&#39;s attachment; and she could not help remembering what Charlotte&#39;s</li>
<li class="L7004" rel="L7004">opinion had always been. Neither could she deny the justice of his</li>
<li class="L7005" rel="L7005">description of Jane. She felt that Jane&#39;s feelings, though fervent, were</li>
<li class="L7006" rel="L7006">little displayed, and that there was a constant complacency in her air</li>
<li class="L7007" rel="L7007">and manner not often united with great sensibility.</li>
<li class="L7008" rel="L7008"></li>
<li class="L7009" rel="L7009">When she came to that part of the letter in which her family were</li>
<li class="L7010" rel="L7010">mentioned in terms of such mortifying, yet merited reproach, her sense</li>
<li class="L7011" rel="L7011">of shame was severe. The justice of the charge struck her too forcibly</li>
<li class="L7012" rel="L7012">for denial, and the circumstances to which he particularly alluded as</li>
<li class="L7013" rel="L7013">having passed at the Netherfield ball, and as confirming all his first</li>
<li class="L7014" rel="L7014">disapprobation, could not have made a stronger impression on his mind</li>
<li class="L7015" rel="L7015">than on hers.</li>
<li class="L7016" rel="L7016"></li>
<li class="L7017" rel="L7017">The compliment to herself and her sister was not unfelt. It soothed,</li>
<li class="L7018" rel="L7018">but it could not console her for the contempt which had thus been</li>
<li class="L7019" rel="L7019">self-attracted by the rest of her family; and as she considered</li>
<li class="L7020" rel="L7020">that Jane&#39;s disappointment had in fact been the work of her nearest</li>
<li class="L7021" rel="L7021">relations, and reflected how materially the credit of both must be hurt</li>
<li class="L7022" rel="L7022">by such impropriety of conduct, she felt depressed beyond anything she</li>
<li class="L7023" rel="L7023">had ever known before.</li>
<li class="L7024" rel="L7024"></li>
<li class="L7025" rel="L7025">After wandering along the lane for two hours, giving way to every</li>
<li class="L7026" rel="L7026">variety of thought--re-considering events, determining probabilities,</li>
<li class="L7027" rel="L7027">and reconciling herself, as well as she could, to a change so sudden and</li>
<li class="L7028" rel="L7028">so important, fatigue, and a recollection of her long absence, made</li>
<li class="L7029" rel="L7029">her at length return home; and she entered the house with the wish</li>
<li class="L7030" rel="L7030">of appearing cheerful as usual, and the resolution of repressing such</li>
<li class="L7031" rel="L7031">reflections as must make her unfit for conversation.</li>
<li class="L7032" rel="L7032"></li>
<li class="L7033" rel="L7033">She was immediately told that the two gentlemen from Rosings had each</li>
<li class="L7034" rel="L7034">called during her absence; Mr. Darcy, only for a few minutes, to take</li>
<li class="L7035" rel="L7035">leave--but that Colonel Fitzwilliam had been sitting with them at least</li>
<li class="L7036" rel="L7036">an hour, hoping for her return, and almost resolving to walk after her</li>
<li class="L7037" rel="L7037">till she could be found. Elizabeth could but just _affect_ concern</li>
<li class="L7038" rel="L7038">in missing him; she really rejoiced at it. Colonel Fitzwilliam was no</li>
<li class="L7039" rel="L7039">longer an object; she could think only of her letter.</li>
<li class="L7040" rel="L7040"></li>
<li class="L7041" rel="L7041"></li>
<li class="L7042" rel="L7042"></li>
<li class="L7043" rel="L7043">Chapter 37</li>
<li class="L7044" rel="L7044"></li>
<li class="L7045" rel="L7045"></li>
<li class="L7046" rel="L7046">The two gentlemen left Rosings the next morning, and Mr. Collins having</li>
<li class="L7047" rel="L7047">been in waiting near the lodges, to make them his parting obeisance, was</li>
<li class="L7048" rel="L7048">able to bring home the pleasing intelligence, of their appearing in very</li>
<li class="L7049" rel="L7049">good health, and in as tolerable spirits as could be expected, after the</li>
<li class="L7050" rel="L7050">melancholy scene so lately gone through at Rosings. To Rosings he then</li>
<li class="L7051" rel="L7051">hastened, to console Lady Catherine and her daughter; and on his return</li>
<li class="L7052" rel="L7052">brought back, with great satisfaction, a message from her ladyship,</li>
<li class="L7053" rel="L7053">importing that she felt herself so dull as to make her very desirous of</li>
<li class="L7054" rel="L7054">having them all to dine with her.</li>
<li class="L7055" rel="L7055"></li>
<li class="L7056" rel="L7056">Elizabeth could not see Lady Catherine without recollecting that, had</li>
<li class="L7057" rel="L7057">she chosen it, she might by this time have been presented to her as</li>
<li class="L7058" rel="L7058">her future niece; nor could she think, without a smile, of what her</li>
<li class="L7059" rel="L7059">ladyship&#39;s indignation would have been. “What would she have said? how</li>
<li class="L7060" rel="L7060">would she have behaved?” were questions with which she amused herself.</li>
<li class="L7061" rel="L7061"></li>
<li class="L7062" rel="L7062">Their first subject was the diminution of the Rosings party. “I assure</li>
<li class="L7063" rel="L7063">you, I feel it exceedingly,” said Lady Catherine; “I believe no one</li>
<li class="L7064" rel="L7064">feels the loss of friends so much as I do. But I am particularly</li>
<li class="L7065" rel="L7065">attached to these young men, and know them to be so much attached to</li>
<li class="L7066" rel="L7066">me! They were excessively sorry to go! But so they always are. The</li>
<li class="L7067" rel="L7067">dear Colonel rallied his spirits tolerably till just at last; but Darcy</li>
<li class="L7068" rel="L7068">seemed to feel it most acutely, more, I think, than last year. His</li>
<li class="L7069" rel="L7069">attachment to Rosings certainly increases.”</li>
<li class="L7070" rel="L7070"></li>
<li class="L7071" rel="L7071">Mr. Collins had a compliment, and an allusion to throw in here, which</li>
<li class="L7072" rel="L7072">were kindly smiled on by the mother and daughter.</li>
<li class="L7073" rel="L7073"></li>
<li class="L7074" rel="L7074">Lady Catherine observed, after dinner, that Miss Bennet seemed out of</li>
<li class="L7075" rel="L7075">spirits, and immediately accounting for it by herself, by supposing that</li>
<li class="L7076" rel="L7076">she did not like to go home again so soon, she added:</li>
<li class="L7077" rel="L7077"></li>
<li class="L7078" rel="L7078">“But if that is the case, you must write to your mother and beg that</li>
<li class="L7079" rel="L7079">you may stay a little longer. Mrs. Collins will be very glad of your</li>
<li class="L7080" rel="L7080">company, I am sure.”</li>
<li class="L7081" rel="L7081"></li>
<li class="L7082" rel="L7082">“I am much obliged to your ladyship for your kind invitation,” replied</li>
<li class="L7083" rel="L7083">Elizabeth, “but it is not in my power to accept it. I must be in town</li>
<li class="L7084" rel="L7084">next Saturday.”</li>
<li class="L7085" rel="L7085"></li>
<li class="L7086" rel="L7086">“Why, at that rate, you will have been here only six weeks. I expected</li>
<li class="L7087" rel="L7087">you to stay two months. I told Mrs. Collins so before you came. There</li>
<li class="L7088" rel="L7088">can be no occasion for your going so soon. Mrs. Bennet could certainly</li>
<li class="L7089" rel="L7089">spare you for another fortnight.”</li>
<li class="L7090" rel="L7090"></li>
<li class="L7091" rel="L7091">“But my father cannot. He wrote last week to hurry my return.”</li>
<li class="L7092" rel="L7092"></li>
<li class="L7093" rel="L7093">“Oh! your father of course may spare you, if your mother can. Daughters</li>
<li class="L7094" rel="L7094">are never of so much consequence to a father. And if you will stay</li>
<li class="L7095" rel="L7095">another _month_ complete, it will be in my power to take one of you as</li>
<li class="L7096" rel="L7096">far as London, for I am going there early in June, for a week; and as</li>
<li class="L7097" rel="L7097">Dawson does not object to the barouche-box, there will be very good room</li>
<li class="L7098" rel="L7098">for one of you--and indeed, if the weather should happen to be cool, I</li>
<li class="L7099" rel="L7099">should not object to taking you both, as you are neither of you large.”</li>
<li class="L7100" rel="L7100"></li>
<li class="L7101" rel="L7101">“You are all kindness, madam; but I believe we must abide by our</li>
<li class="L7102" rel="L7102">original plan.”</li>
<li class="L7103" rel="L7103"></li>
<li class="L7104" rel="L7104">Lady Catherine seemed resigned. “Mrs. Collins, you must send a servant</li>
<li class="L7105" rel="L7105">with them. You know I always speak my mind, and I cannot bear the idea</li>
<li class="L7106" rel="L7106">of two young women travelling post by themselves. It is highly improper.</li>
<li class="L7107" rel="L7107">You must contrive to send somebody. I have the greatest dislike in</li>
<li class="L7108" rel="L7108">the world to that sort of thing. Young women should always be properly</li>
<li class="L7109" rel="L7109">guarded and attended, according to their situation in life. When my</li>
<li class="L7110" rel="L7110">niece Georgiana went to Ramsgate last summer, I made a point of her</li>
<li class="L7111" rel="L7111">having two men-servants go with her. Miss Darcy, the daughter of</li>
<li class="L7112" rel="L7112">Mr. Darcy, of Pemberley, and Lady Anne, could not have appeared with</li>
<li class="L7113" rel="L7113">propriety in a different manner. I am excessively attentive to all those</li>
<li class="L7114" rel="L7114">things. You must send John with the young ladies, Mrs. Collins. I</li>
<li class="L7115" rel="L7115">am glad it occurred to me to mention it; for it would really be</li>
<li class="L7116" rel="L7116">discreditable to _you_ to let them go alone.”</li>
<li class="L7117" rel="L7117"></li>
<li class="L7118" rel="L7118">“My uncle is to send a servant for us.”</li>
<li class="L7119" rel="L7119"></li>
<li class="L7120" rel="L7120">“Oh! Your uncle! He keeps a man-servant, does he? I am very glad you</li>
<li class="L7121" rel="L7121">have somebody who thinks of these things. Where shall you change horses?</li>
<li class="L7122" rel="L7122">Oh! Bromley, of course. If you mention my name at the Bell, you will be</li>
<li class="L7123" rel="L7123">attended to.”</li>
<li class="L7124" rel="L7124"></li>
<li class="L7125" rel="L7125">Lady Catherine had many other questions to ask respecting their journey,</li>
<li class="L7126" rel="L7126">and as she did not answer them all herself, attention was necessary,</li>
<li class="L7127" rel="L7127">which Elizabeth believed to be lucky for her; or, with a mind so</li>
<li class="L7128" rel="L7128">occupied, she might have forgotten where she was. Reflection must be</li>
<li class="L7129" rel="L7129">reserved for solitary hours; whenever she was alone, she gave way to it</li>
<li class="L7130" rel="L7130">as the greatest relief; and not a day went by without a solitary</li>
<li class="L7131" rel="L7131">walk, in which she might indulge in all the delight of unpleasant</li>
<li class="L7132" rel="L7132">recollections.</li>
<li class="L7133" rel="L7133"></li>
<li class="L7134" rel="L7134">Mr. Darcy&#39;s letter she was in a fair way of soon knowing by heart. She</li>
<li class="L7135" rel="L7135">studied every sentence; and her feelings towards its writer were at</li>
<li class="L7136" rel="L7136">times widely different. When she remembered the style of his address,</li>
<li class="L7137" rel="L7137">she was still full of indignation; but when she considered how unjustly</li>
<li class="L7138" rel="L7138">she had condemned and upbraided him, her anger was turned against</li>
<li class="L7139" rel="L7139">herself; and his disappointed feelings became the object of compassion.</li>
<li class="L7140" rel="L7140">His attachment excited gratitude, his general character respect; but she</li>
<li class="L7141" rel="L7141">could not approve him; nor could she for a moment repent her refusal,</li>
<li class="L7142" rel="L7142">or feel the slightest inclination ever to see him again. In her own past</li>
<li class="L7143" rel="L7143">behaviour, there was a constant source of vexation and regret; and in</li>
<li class="L7144" rel="L7144">the unhappy defects of her family, a subject of yet heavier chagrin.</li>
<li class="L7145" rel="L7145">They were hopeless of remedy. Her father, contented with laughing at</li>
<li class="L7146" rel="L7146">them, would never exert himself to restrain the wild giddiness of his</li>
<li class="L7147" rel="L7147">youngest daughters; and her mother, with manners so far from right</li>
<li class="L7148" rel="L7148">herself, was entirely insensible of the evil. Elizabeth had frequently</li>
<li class="L7149" rel="L7149">united with Jane in an endeavour to check the imprudence of Catherine</li>
<li class="L7150" rel="L7150">and Lydia; but while they were supported by their mother&#39;s indulgence,</li>
<li class="L7151" rel="L7151">what chance could there be of improvement? Catherine, weak-spirited,</li>
<li class="L7152" rel="L7152">irritable, and completely under Lydia&#39;s guidance, had been always</li>
<li class="L7153" rel="L7153">affronted by their advice; and Lydia, self-willed and careless, would</li>
<li class="L7154" rel="L7154">scarcely give them a hearing. They were ignorant, idle, and vain. While</li>
<li class="L7155" rel="L7155">there was an officer in Meryton, they would flirt with him; and while</li>
<li class="L7156" rel="L7156">Meryton was within a walk of Longbourn, they would be going there</li>
<li class="L7157" rel="L7157">forever.</li>
<li class="L7158" rel="L7158"></li>
<li class="L7159" rel="L7159">Anxiety on Jane&#39;s behalf was another prevailing concern; and Mr. Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L7160" rel="L7160">explanation, by restoring Bingley to all her former good opinion,</li>
<li class="L7161" rel="L7161">heightened the sense of what Jane had lost. His affection was proved</li>
<li class="L7162" rel="L7162">to have been sincere, and his conduct cleared of all blame, unless any</li>
<li class="L7163" rel="L7163">could attach to the implicitness of his confidence in his friend. How</li>
<li class="L7164" rel="L7164">grievous then was the thought that, of a situation so desirable in every</li>
<li class="L7165" rel="L7165">respect, so replete with advantage, so promising for happiness, Jane had</li>
<li class="L7166" rel="L7166">been deprived, by the folly and indecorum of her own family!</li>
<li class="L7167" rel="L7167"></li>
<li class="L7168" rel="L7168">When to these recollections was added the development of Wickham&#39;s</li>
<li class="L7169" rel="L7169">character, it may be easily believed that the happy spirits which had</li>
<li class="L7170" rel="L7170">seldom been depressed before, were now so much affected as to make it</li>
<li class="L7171" rel="L7171">almost impossible for her to appear tolerably cheerful.</li>
<li class="L7172" rel="L7172"></li>
<li class="L7173" rel="L7173">Their engagements at Rosings were as frequent during the last week of</li>
<li class="L7174" rel="L7174">her stay as they had been at first. The very last evening was spent</li>
<li class="L7175" rel="L7175">there; and her ladyship again inquired minutely into the particulars of</li>
<li class="L7176" rel="L7176">their journey, gave them directions as to the best method of packing,</li>
<li class="L7177" rel="L7177">and was so urgent on the necessity of placing gowns in the only right</li>
<li class="L7178" rel="L7178">way, that Maria thought herself obliged, on her return, to undo all the</li>
<li class="L7179" rel="L7179">work of the morning, and pack her trunk afresh.</li>
<li class="L7180" rel="L7180"></li>
<li class="L7181" rel="L7181">When they parted, Lady Catherine, with great condescension, wished them</li>
<li class="L7182" rel="L7182">a good journey, and invited them to come to Hunsford again next year;</li>
<li class="L7183" rel="L7183">and Miss de Bourgh exerted herself so far as to curtsey and hold out her</li>
<li class="L7184" rel="L7184">hand to both.</li>
<li class="L7185" rel="L7185"></li>
<li class="L7186" rel="L7186"></li>
<li class="L7187" rel="L7187"></li>
<li class="L7188" rel="L7188">Chapter 38</li>
<li class="L7189" rel="L7189"></li>
<li class="L7190" rel="L7190"></li>
<li class="L7191" rel="L7191">On Saturday morning Elizabeth and Mr. Collins met for breakfast a few</li>
<li class="L7192" rel="L7192">minutes before the others appeared; and he took the opportunity of</li>
<li class="L7193" rel="L7193">paying the parting civilities which he deemed indispensably necessary.</li>
<li class="L7194" rel="L7194"></li>
<li class="L7195" rel="L7195">“I know not, Miss Elizabeth,” said he, “whether Mrs. Collins has yet</li>
<li class="L7196" rel="L7196">expressed her sense of your kindness in coming to us; but I am very</li>
<li class="L7197" rel="L7197">certain you will not leave the house without receiving her thanks for</li>
<li class="L7198" rel="L7198">it. The favour of your company has been much felt, I assure you. We</li>
<li class="L7199" rel="L7199">know how little there is to tempt anyone to our humble abode. Our plain</li>
<li class="L7200" rel="L7200">manner of living, our small rooms and few domestics, and the little we</li>
<li class="L7201" rel="L7201">see of the world, must make Hunsford extremely dull to a young lady like</li>
<li class="L7202" rel="L7202">yourself; but I hope you will believe us grateful for the condescension,</li>
<li class="L7203" rel="L7203">and that we have done everything in our power to prevent your spending</li>
<li class="L7204" rel="L7204">your time unpleasantly.”</li>
<li class="L7205" rel="L7205"></li>
<li class="L7206" rel="L7206">Elizabeth was eager with her thanks and assurances of happiness. She</li>
<li class="L7207" rel="L7207">had spent six weeks with great enjoyment; and the pleasure of being with</li>
<li class="L7208" rel="L7208">Charlotte, and the kind attentions she had received, must make _her_</li>
<li class="L7209" rel="L7209">feel the obliged. Mr. Collins was gratified, and with a more smiling</li>
<li class="L7210" rel="L7210">solemnity replied:</li>
<li class="L7211" rel="L7211"></li>
<li class="L7212" rel="L7212">“It gives me great pleasure to hear that you have passed your time not</li>
<li class="L7213" rel="L7213">disagreeably. We have certainly done our best; and most fortunately</li>
<li class="L7214" rel="L7214">having it in our power to introduce you to very superior society, and,</li>
<li class="L7215" rel="L7215">from our connection with Rosings, the frequent means of varying the</li>
<li class="L7216" rel="L7216">humble home scene, I think we may flatter ourselves that your Hunsford</li>
<li class="L7217" rel="L7217">visit cannot have been entirely irksome. Our situation with regard to</li>
<li class="L7218" rel="L7218">Lady Catherine&#39;s family is indeed the sort of extraordinary advantage</li>
<li class="L7219" rel="L7219">and blessing which few can boast. You see on what a footing we are. You</li>
<li class="L7220" rel="L7220">see how continually we are engaged there. In truth I must acknowledge</li>
<li class="L7221" rel="L7221">that, with all the disadvantages of this humble parsonage, I should</li>
<li class="L7222" rel="L7222">not think anyone abiding in it an object of compassion, while they are</li>
<li class="L7223" rel="L7223">sharers of our intimacy at Rosings.”</li>
<li class="L7224" rel="L7224"></li>
<li class="L7225" rel="L7225">Words were insufficient for the elevation of his feelings; and he was</li>
<li class="L7226" rel="L7226">obliged to walk about the room, while Elizabeth tried to unite civility</li>
<li class="L7227" rel="L7227">and truth in a few short sentences.</li>
<li class="L7228" rel="L7228"></li>
<li class="L7229" rel="L7229">“You may, in fact, carry a very favourable report of us into</li>
<li class="L7230" rel="L7230">Hertfordshire, my dear cousin. I flatter myself at least that you will</li>
<li class="L7231" rel="L7231">be able to do so. Lady Catherine&#39;s great attentions to Mrs. Collins you</li>
<li class="L7232" rel="L7232">have been a daily witness of; and altogether I trust it does not appear</li>
<li class="L7233" rel="L7233">that your friend has drawn an unfortunate--but on this point it will be</li>
<li class="L7234" rel="L7234">as well to be silent. Only let me assure you, my dear Miss Elizabeth,</li>
<li class="L7235" rel="L7235">that I can from my heart most cordially wish you equal felicity in</li>
<li class="L7236" rel="L7236">marriage. My dear Charlotte and I have but one mind and one way of</li>
<li class="L7237" rel="L7237">thinking. There is in everything a most remarkable resemblance of</li>
<li class="L7238" rel="L7238">character and ideas between us. We seem to have been designed for each</li>
<li class="L7239" rel="L7239">other.”</li>
<li class="L7240" rel="L7240"></li>
<li class="L7241" rel="L7241">Elizabeth could safely say that it was a great happiness where that was</li>
<li class="L7242" rel="L7242">the case, and with equal sincerity could add, that she firmly believed</li>
<li class="L7243" rel="L7243">and rejoiced in his domestic comforts. She was not sorry, however, to</li>
<li class="L7244" rel="L7244">have the recital of them interrupted by the lady from whom they sprang.</li>
<li class="L7245" rel="L7245">Poor Charlotte! it was melancholy to leave her to such society! But she</li>
<li class="L7246" rel="L7246">had chosen it with her eyes open; and though evidently regretting that</li>
<li class="L7247" rel="L7247">her visitors were to go, she did not seem to ask for compassion. Her</li>
<li class="L7248" rel="L7248">home and her housekeeping, her parish and her poultry, and all their</li>
<li class="L7249" rel="L7249">dependent concerns, had not yet lost their charms.</li>
<li class="L7250" rel="L7250"></li>
<li class="L7251" rel="L7251">At length the chaise arrived, the trunks were fastened on, the parcels</li>
<li class="L7252" rel="L7252">placed within, and it was pronounced to be ready. After an affectionate</li>
<li class="L7253" rel="L7253">parting between the friends, Elizabeth was attended to the carriage by</li>
<li class="L7254" rel="L7254">Mr. Collins, and as they walked down the garden he was commissioning her</li>
<li class="L7255" rel="L7255">with his best respects to all her family, not forgetting his thanks</li>
<li class="L7256" rel="L7256">for the kindness he had received at Longbourn in the winter, and his</li>
<li class="L7257" rel="L7257">compliments to Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, though unknown. He then handed her</li>
<li class="L7258" rel="L7258">in, Maria followed, and the door was on the point of being closed,</li>
<li class="L7259" rel="L7259">when he suddenly reminded them, with some consternation, that they had</li>
<li class="L7260" rel="L7260">hitherto forgotten to leave any message for the ladies at Rosings.</li>
<li class="L7261" rel="L7261"></li>
<li class="L7262" rel="L7262">“But,” he added, “you will of course wish to have your humble respects</li>
<li class="L7263" rel="L7263">delivered to them, with your grateful thanks for their kindness to you</li>
<li class="L7264" rel="L7264">while you have been here.”</li>
<li class="L7265" rel="L7265"></li>
<li class="L7266" rel="L7266">Elizabeth made no objection; the door was then allowed to be shut, and</li>
<li class="L7267" rel="L7267">the carriage drove off.</li>
<li class="L7268" rel="L7268"></li>
<li class="L7269" rel="L7269">“Good gracious!” cried Maria, after a few minutes&#39; silence, “it seems</li>
<li class="L7270" rel="L7270">but a day or two since we first came! and yet how many things have</li>
<li class="L7271" rel="L7271">happened!”</li>
<li class="L7272" rel="L7272"></li>
<li class="L7273" rel="L7273">“A great many indeed,” said her companion with a sigh.</li>
<li class="L7274" rel="L7274"></li>
<li class="L7275" rel="L7275">“We have dined nine times at Rosings, besides drinking tea there twice!</li>
<li class="L7276" rel="L7276">How much I shall have to tell!”</li>
<li class="L7277" rel="L7277"></li>
<li class="L7278" rel="L7278">Elizabeth added privately, “And how much I shall have to conceal!”</li>
<li class="L7279" rel="L7279"></li>
<li class="L7280" rel="L7280">Their journey was performed without much conversation, or any alarm; and</li>
<li class="L7281" rel="L7281">within four hours of their leaving Hunsford they reached Mr. Gardiner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L7282" rel="L7282">house, where they were to remain a few days.</li>
<li class="L7283" rel="L7283"></li>
<li class="L7284" rel="L7284">Jane looked well, and Elizabeth had little opportunity of studying her</li>
<li class="L7285" rel="L7285">spirits, amidst the various engagements which the kindness of her</li>
<li class="L7286" rel="L7286">aunt had reserved for them. But Jane was to go home with her, and at</li>
<li class="L7287" rel="L7287">Longbourn there would be leisure enough for observation.</li>
<li class="L7288" rel="L7288"></li>
<li class="L7289" rel="L7289">It was not without an effort, meanwhile, that she could wait even for</li>
<li class="L7290" rel="L7290">Longbourn, before she told her sister of Mr. Darcy&#39;s proposals. To know</li>
<li class="L7291" rel="L7291">that she had the power of revealing what would so exceedingly astonish</li>
<li class="L7292" rel="L7292">Jane, and must, at the same time, so highly gratify whatever of her own</li>
<li class="L7293" rel="L7293">vanity she had not yet been able to reason away, was such a temptation</li>
<li class="L7294" rel="L7294">to openness as nothing could have conquered but the state of indecision</li>
<li class="L7295" rel="L7295">in which she remained as to the extent of what she should communicate;</li>
<li class="L7296" rel="L7296">and her fear, if she once entered on the subject, of being hurried</li>
<li class="L7297" rel="L7297">into repeating something of Bingley which might only grieve her sister</li>
<li class="L7298" rel="L7298">further.</li>
<li class="L7299" rel="L7299"></li>
<li class="L7300" rel="L7300"></li>
<li class="L7301" rel="L7301"></li>
<li class="L7302" rel="L7302">Chapter 39</li>
<li class="L7303" rel="L7303"></li>
<li class="L7304" rel="L7304"></li>
<li class="L7305" rel="L7305">It was the second week in May, in which the three young ladies set out</li>
<li class="L7306" rel="L7306">together from Gracechurch Street for the town of ----, in Hertfordshire;</li>
<li class="L7307" rel="L7307">and, as they drew near the appointed inn where Mr. Bennet&#39;s carriage</li>
<li class="L7308" rel="L7308">was to meet them, they quickly perceived, in token of the coachman&#39;s</li>
<li class="L7309" rel="L7309">punctuality, both Kitty and Lydia looking out of a dining-room up stairs.</li>
<li class="L7310" rel="L7310">These two girls had been above an hour in the place, happily employed</li>
<li class="L7311" rel="L7311">in visiting an opposite milliner, watching the sentinel on guard, and</li>
<li class="L7312" rel="L7312">dressing a salad and cucumber.</li>
<li class="L7313" rel="L7313"></li>
<li class="L7314" rel="L7314">After welcoming their sisters, they triumphantly displayed a table set</li>
<li class="L7315" rel="L7315">out with such cold meat as an inn larder usually affords, exclaiming,</li>
<li class="L7316" rel="L7316">“Is not this nice? Is not this an agreeable surprise?”</li>
<li class="L7317" rel="L7317"></li>
<li class="L7318" rel="L7318">“And we mean to treat you all,” added Lydia, “but you must lend us the</li>
<li class="L7319" rel="L7319">money, for we have just spent ours at the shop out there.” Then, showing</li>
<li class="L7320" rel="L7320">her purchases--“Look here, I have bought this bonnet. I do not think</li>
<li class="L7321" rel="L7321">it is very pretty; but I thought I might as well buy it as not. I shall</li>
<li class="L7322" rel="L7322">pull it to pieces as soon as I get home, and see if I can make it up any</li>
<li class="L7323" rel="L7323">better.”</li>
<li class="L7324" rel="L7324"></li>
<li class="L7325" rel="L7325">And when her sisters abused it as ugly, she added, with perfect</li>
<li class="L7326" rel="L7326">unconcern, “Oh! but there were two or three much uglier in the shop; and</li>
<li class="L7327" rel="L7327">when I have bought some prettier-coloured satin to trim it with fresh, I</li>
<li class="L7328" rel="L7328">think it will be very tolerable. Besides, it will not much signify what</li>
<li class="L7329" rel="L7329">one wears this summer, after the ----shire have left Meryton, and they</li>
<li class="L7330" rel="L7330">are going in a fortnight.”</li>
<li class="L7331" rel="L7331"></li>
<li class="L7332" rel="L7332">“Are they indeed!” cried Elizabeth, with the greatest satisfaction.</li>
<li class="L7333" rel="L7333"></li>
<li class="L7334" rel="L7334">“They are going to be encamped near Brighton; and I do so want papa to</li>
<li class="L7335" rel="L7335">take us all there for the summer! It would be such a delicious scheme;</li>
<li class="L7336" rel="L7336">and I dare say would hardly cost anything at all. Mamma would like to</li>
<li class="L7337" rel="L7337">go too of all things! Only think what a miserable summer else we shall</li>
<li class="L7338" rel="L7338">have!”</li>
<li class="L7339" rel="L7339"></li>
<li class="L7340" rel="L7340">“Yes,” thought Elizabeth, “_that_ would be a delightful scheme indeed,</li>
<li class="L7341" rel="L7341">and completely do for us at once. Good Heaven! Brighton, and a whole</li>
<li class="L7342" rel="L7342">campful of soldiers, to us, who have been overset already by one poor</li>
<li class="L7343" rel="L7343">regiment of militia, and the monthly balls of Meryton!”</li>
<li class="L7344" rel="L7344"></li>
<li class="L7345" rel="L7345">“Now I have got some news for you,” said Lydia, as they sat down at</li>
<li class="L7346" rel="L7346">table. “What do you think? It is excellent news--capital news--and about</li>
<li class="L7347" rel="L7347">a certain person we all like!”</li>
<li class="L7348" rel="L7348"></li>
<li class="L7349" rel="L7349">Jane and Elizabeth looked at each other, and the waiter was told he need</li>
