<li class="L7350" rel="L7350">not stay. Lydia laughed, and said:</li>
<li class="L7351" rel="L7351"></li>
<li class="L7352" rel="L7352">“Aye, that is just like your formality and discretion. You thought the</li>
<li class="L7353" rel="L7353">waiter must not hear, as if he cared! I dare say he often hears worse</li>
<li class="L7354" rel="L7354">things said than I am going to say. But he is an ugly fellow! I am glad</li>
<li class="L7355" rel="L7355">he is gone. I never saw such a long chin in my life. Well, but now for</li>
<li class="L7356" rel="L7356">my news; it is about dear Wickham; too good for the waiter, is it not?</li>
<li class="L7357" rel="L7357">There is no danger of Wickham&#39;s marrying Mary King. There&#39;s for you! She</li>
<li class="L7358" rel="L7358">is gone down to her uncle at Liverpool: gone to stay. Wickham is safe.”</li>
<li class="L7359" rel="L7359"></li>
<li class="L7360" rel="L7360">“And Mary King is safe!” added Elizabeth; “safe from a connection</li>
<li class="L7361" rel="L7361">imprudent as to fortune.”</li>
<li class="L7362" rel="L7362"></li>
<li class="L7363" rel="L7363">“She is a great fool for going away, if she liked him.”</li>
<li class="L7364" rel="L7364"></li>
<li class="L7365" rel="L7365">“But I hope there is no strong attachment on either side,” said Jane.</li>
<li class="L7366" rel="L7366"></li>
<li class="L7367" rel="L7367">“I am sure there is not on _his_. I will answer for it, he never cared</li>
<li class="L7368" rel="L7368">three straws about her--who could about such a nasty little freckled</li>
<li class="L7369" rel="L7369">thing?”</li>
<li class="L7370" rel="L7370"></li>
<li class="L7371" rel="L7371">Elizabeth was shocked to think that, however incapable of such</li>
<li class="L7372" rel="L7372">coarseness of _expression_ herself, the coarseness of the _sentiment_</li>
<li class="L7373" rel="L7373">was little other than her own breast had harboured and fancied liberal!</li>
<li class="L7374" rel="L7374"></li>
<li class="L7375" rel="L7375">As soon as all had ate, and the elder ones paid, the carriage was</li>
<li class="L7376" rel="L7376">ordered; and after some contrivance, the whole party, with all their</li>
<li class="L7377" rel="L7377">boxes, work-bags, and parcels, and the unwelcome addition of Kitty&#39;s and</li>
<li class="L7378" rel="L7378">Lydia&#39;s purchases, were seated in it.</li>
<li class="L7379" rel="L7379"></li>
<li class="L7380" rel="L7380">“How nicely we are all crammed in,” cried Lydia. “I am glad I bought my</li>
<li class="L7381" rel="L7381">bonnet, if it is only for the fun of having another bandbox! Well, now</li>
<li class="L7382" rel="L7382">let us be quite comfortable and snug, and talk and laugh all the way</li>
<li class="L7383" rel="L7383">home. And in the first place, let us hear what has happened to you all</li>
<li class="L7384" rel="L7384">since you went away. Have you seen any pleasant men? Have you had any</li>
<li class="L7385" rel="L7385">flirting? I was in great hopes that one of you would have got a husband</li>
<li class="L7386" rel="L7386">before you came back. Jane will be quite an old maid soon, I declare.</li>
<li class="L7387" rel="L7387">She is almost three-and-twenty! Lord, how ashamed I should be of not</li>
<li class="L7388" rel="L7388">being married before three-and-twenty! My aunt Phillips wants you so to</li>
<li class="L7389" rel="L7389">get husbands, you can&#39;t think. She says Lizzy had better have taken Mr.</li>
<li class="L7390" rel="L7390">Collins; but _I_ do not think there would have been any fun in it. Lord!</li>
<li class="L7391" rel="L7391">how I should like to be married before any of you; and then I would</li>
<li class="L7392" rel="L7392">chaperon you about to all the balls. Dear me! we had such a good piece</li>
<li class="L7393" rel="L7393">of fun the other day at Colonel Forster&#39;s. Kitty and me were to spend</li>
<li class="L7394" rel="L7394">the day there, and Mrs. Forster promised to have a little dance in the</li>
<li class="L7395" rel="L7395">evening; (by the bye, Mrs. Forster and me are _such_ friends!) and so</li>
<li class="L7396" rel="L7396">she asked the two Harringtons to come, but Harriet was ill, and so Pen</li>
<li class="L7397" rel="L7397">was forced to come by herself; and then, what do you think we did? We</li>
<li class="L7398" rel="L7398">dressed up Chamberlayne in woman&#39;s clothes on purpose to pass for a</li>
<li class="L7399" rel="L7399">lady, only think what fun! Not a soul knew of it, but Colonel and Mrs.</li>
<li class="L7400" rel="L7400">Forster, and Kitty and me, except my aunt, for we were forced to borrow</li>
<li class="L7401" rel="L7401">one of her gowns; and you cannot imagine how well he looked! When Denny,</li>
<li class="L7402" rel="L7402">and Wickham, and Pratt, and two or three more of the men came in, they</li>
<li class="L7403" rel="L7403">did not know him in the least. Lord! how I laughed! and so did Mrs.</li>
<li class="L7404" rel="L7404">Forster. I thought I should have died. And _that_ made the men suspect</li>
<li class="L7405" rel="L7405">something, and then they soon found out what was the matter.”</li>
<li class="L7406" rel="L7406"></li>
<li class="L7407" rel="L7407">With such kinds of histories of their parties and good jokes, did</li>
<li class="L7408" rel="L7408">Lydia, assisted by Kitty&#39;s hints and additions, endeavour to amuse her</li>
<li class="L7409" rel="L7409">companions all the way to Longbourn. Elizabeth listened as little as she</li>
<li class="L7410" rel="L7410">could, but there was no escaping the frequent mention of Wickham&#39;s name.</li>
<li class="L7411" rel="L7411"></li>
<li class="L7412" rel="L7412">Their reception at home was most kind. Mrs. Bennet rejoiced to see Jane</li>
<li class="L7413" rel="L7413">in undiminished beauty; and more than once during dinner did Mr. Bennet</li>
<li class="L7414" rel="L7414">say voluntarily to Elizabeth:</li>
<li class="L7415" rel="L7415"></li>
<li class="L7416" rel="L7416">“I am glad you are come back, Lizzy.”</li>
<li class="L7417" rel="L7417"></li>
<li class="L7418" rel="L7418">Their party in the dining-room was large, for almost all the Lucases</li>
<li class="L7419" rel="L7419">came to meet Maria and hear the news; and various were the subjects that</li>
<li class="L7420" rel="L7420">occupied them: Lady Lucas was inquiring of Maria, after the welfare and</li>
<li class="L7421" rel="L7421">poultry of her eldest daughter; Mrs. Bennet was doubly engaged, on one</li>
<li class="L7422" rel="L7422">hand collecting an account of the present fashions from Jane, who sat</li>
<li class="L7423" rel="L7423">some way below her, and, on the other, retailing them all to the younger</li>
<li class="L7424" rel="L7424">Lucases; and Lydia, in a voice rather louder than any other person&#39;s,</li>
<li class="L7425" rel="L7425">was enumerating the various pleasures of the morning to anybody who</li>
<li class="L7426" rel="L7426">would hear her.</li>
<li class="L7427" rel="L7427"></li>
<li class="L7428" rel="L7428">“Oh! Mary,” said she, “I wish you had gone with us, for we had such fun!</li>
<li class="L7429" rel="L7429">As we went along, Kitty and I drew up the blinds, and pretended there</li>
<li class="L7430" rel="L7430">was nobody in the coach; and I should have gone so all the way, if Kitty</li>
<li class="L7431" rel="L7431">had not been sick; and when we got to the George, I do think we behaved</li>
<li class="L7432" rel="L7432">very handsomely, for we treated the other three with the nicest cold</li>
<li class="L7433" rel="L7433">luncheon in the world, and if you would have gone, we would have treated</li>
<li class="L7434" rel="L7434">you too. And then when we came away it was such fun! I thought we never</li>
<li class="L7435" rel="L7435">should have got into the coach. I was ready to die of laughter. And then</li>
<li class="L7436" rel="L7436">we were so merry all the way home! we talked and laughed so loud, that</li>
<li class="L7437" rel="L7437">anybody might have heard us ten miles off!”</li>
<li class="L7438" rel="L7438"></li>
<li class="L7439" rel="L7439">To this Mary very gravely replied, “Far be it from me, my dear sister,</li>
<li class="L7440" rel="L7440">to depreciate such pleasures! They would doubtless be congenial with the</li>
<li class="L7441" rel="L7441">generality of female minds. But I confess they would have no charms for</li>
<li class="L7442" rel="L7442">_me_--I should infinitely prefer a book.”</li>
<li class="L7443" rel="L7443"></li>
<li class="L7444" rel="L7444">But of this answer Lydia heard not a word. She seldom listened to</li>
<li class="L7445" rel="L7445">anybody for more than half a minute, and never attended to Mary at all.</li>
<li class="L7446" rel="L7446"></li>
<li class="L7447" rel="L7447">In the afternoon Lydia was urgent with the rest of the girls to walk</li>
<li class="L7448" rel="L7448">to Meryton, and to see how everybody went on; but Elizabeth steadily</li>
<li class="L7449" rel="L7449">opposed the scheme. It should not be said that the Miss Bennets could</li>
<li class="L7450" rel="L7450">not be at home half a day before they were in pursuit of the officers.</li>
<li class="L7451" rel="L7451">There was another reason too for her opposition. She dreaded seeing Mr.</li>
<li class="L7452" rel="L7452">Wickham again, and was resolved to avoid it as long as possible. The</li>
<li class="L7453" rel="L7453">comfort to _her_ of the regiment&#39;s approaching removal was indeed beyond</li>
<li class="L7454" rel="L7454">expression. In a fortnight they were to go--and once gone, she hoped</li>
<li class="L7455" rel="L7455">there could be nothing more to plague her on his account.</li>
<li class="L7456" rel="L7456"></li>
<li class="L7457" rel="L7457">She had not been many hours at home before she found that the Brighton</li>
<li class="L7458" rel="L7458">scheme, of which Lydia had given them a hint at the inn, was under</li>
<li class="L7459" rel="L7459">frequent discussion between her parents. Elizabeth saw directly that her</li>
<li class="L7460" rel="L7460">father had not the smallest intention of yielding; but his answers were</li>
<li class="L7461" rel="L7461">at the same time so vague and equivocal, that her mother, though often</li>
<li class="L7462" rel="L7462">disheartened, had never yet despaired of succeeding at last.</li>
<li class="L7463" rel="L7463"></li>
<li class="L7464" rel="L7464"></li>
<li class="L7465" rel="L7465"></li>
<li class="L7466" rel="L7466">Chapter 40</li>
<li class="L7467" rel="L7467"></li>
<li class="L7468" rel="L7468"></li>
<li class="L7469" rel="L7469">Elizabeth&#39;s impatience to acquaint Jane with what had happened could</li>
<li class="L7470" rel="L7470">no longer be overcome; and at length, resolving to suppress every</li>
<li class="L7471" rel="L7471">particular in which her sister was concerned, and preparing her to be</li>
<li class="L7472" rel="L7472">surprised, she related to her the next morning the chief of the scene</li>
<li class="L7473" rel="L7473">between Mr. Darcy and herself.</li>
<li class="L7474" rel="L7474"></li>
<li class="L7475" rel="L7475">Miss Bennet&#39;s astonishment was soon lessened by the strong sisterly</li>
<li class="L7476" rel="L7476">partiality which made any admiration of Elizabeth appear perfectly</li>
<li class="L7477" rel="L7477">natural; and all surprise was shortly lost in other feelings. She was</li>
<li class="L7478" rel="L7478">sorry that Mr. Darcy should have delivered his sentiments in a manner so</li>
<li class="L7479" rel="L7479">little suited to recommend them; but still more was she grieved for the</li>
<li class="L7480" rel="L7480">unhappiness which her sister&#39;s refusal must have given him.</li>
<li class="L7481" rel="L7481"></li>
<li class="L7482" rel="L7482">“His being so sure of succeeding was wrong,” said she, “and certainly</li>
<li class="L7483" rel="L7483">ought not to have appeared; but consider how much it must increase his</li>
<li class="L7484" rel="L7484">disappointment!”</li>
<li class="L7485" rel="L7485"></li>
<li class="L7486" rel="L7486">“Indeed,” replied Elizabeth, “I am heartily sorry for him; but he has</li>
<li class="L7487" rel="L7487">other feelings, which will probably soon drive away his regard for me.</li>
<li class="L7488" rel="L7488">You do not blame me, however, for refusing him?”</li>
<li class="L7489" rel="L7489"></li>
<li class="L7490" rel="L7490">“Blame you! Oh, no.”</li>
<li class="L7491" rel="L7491"></li>
<li class="L7492" rel="L7492">“But you blame me for having spoken so warmly of Wickham?”</li>
<li class="L7493" rel="L7493"></li>
<li class="L7494" rel="L7494">“No--I do not know that you were wrong in saying what you did.”</li>
<li class="L7495" rel="L7495"></li>
<li class="L7496" rel="L7496">“But you _will_ know it, when I tell you what happened the very next</li>
<li class="L7497" rel="L7497">day.”</li>
<li class="L7498" rel="L7498"></li>
<li class="L7499" rel="L7499">She then spoke of the letter, repeating the whole of its contents as far</li>
<li class="L7500" rel="L7500">as they concerned George Wickham. What a stroke was this for poor Jane!</li>
<li class="L7501" rel="L7501">who would willingly have gone through the world without believing that</li>
<li class="L7502" rel="L7502">so much wickedness existed in the whole race of mankind, as was here</li>
<li class="L7503" rel="L7503">collected in one individual. Nor was Darcy&#39;s vindication, though</li>
<li class="L7504" rel="L7504">grateful to her feelings, capable of consoling her for such discovery.</li>
<li class="L7505" rel="L7505">Most earnestly did she labour to prove the probability of error, and</li>
<li class="L7506" rel="L7506">seek to clear the one without involving the other.</li>
<li class="L7507" rel="L7507"></li>
<li class="L7508" rel="L7508">“This will not do,” said Elizabeth; “you never will be able to make both</li>
<li class="L7509" rel="L7509">of them good for anything. Take your choice, but you must be satisfied</li>
<li class="L7510" rel="L7510">with only one. There is but such a quantity of merit between them; just</li>
<li class="L7511" rel="L7511">enough to make one good sort of man; and of late it has been shifting</li>
<li class="L7512" rel="L7512">about pretty much. For my part, I am inclined to believe it all Darcy&#39;s;</li>
<li class="L7513" rel="L7513">but you shall do as you choose.”</li>
<li class="L7514" rel="L7514"></li>
<li class="L7515" rel="L7515">It was some time, however, before a smile could be extorted from Jane.</li>
<li class="L7516" rel="L7516"></li>
<li class="L7517" rel="L7517">“I do not know when I have been more shocked,” said she. “Wickham so</li>
<li class="L7518" rel="L7518">very bad! It is almost past belief. And poor Mr. Darcy! Dear Lizzy, only</li>
<li class="L7519" rel="L7519">consider what he must have suffered. Such a disappointment! and with the</li>
<li class="L7520" rel="L7520">knowledge of your ill opinion, too! and having to relate such a thing</li>
<li class="L7521" rel="L7521">of his sister! It is really too distressing. I am sure you must feel it</li>
<li class="L7522" rel="L7522">so.”</li>
<li class="L7523" rel="L7523"></li>
<li class="L7524" rel="L7524">“Oh! no, my regret and compassion are all done away by seeing you so</li>
<li class="L7525" rel="L7525">full of both. I know you will do him such ample justice, that I am</li>
<li class="L7526" rel="L7526">growing every moment more unconcerned and indifferent. Your profusion</li>
<li class="L7527" rel="L7527">makes me saving; and if you lament over him much longer, my heart will</li>
<li class="L7528" rel="L7528">be as light as a feather.”</li>
<li class="L7529" rel="L7529"></li>
<li class="L7530" rel="L7530">“Poor Wickham! there is such an expression of goodness in his</li>
<li class="L7531" rel="L7531">countenance! such an openness and gentleness in his manner!”</li>
<li class="L7532" rel="L7532"></li>
<li class="L7533" rel="L7533">“There certainly was some great mismanagement in the education of those</li>
<li class="L7534" rel="L7534">two young men. One has got all the goodness, and the other all the</li>
<li class="L7535" rel="L7535">appearance of it.”</li>
<li class="L7536" rel="L7536"></li>
<li class="L7537" rel="L7537">“I never thought Mr. Darcy so deficient in the _appearance_ of it as you</li>
<li class="L7538" rel="L7538">used to do.”</li>
<li class="L7539" rel="L7539"></li>
<li class="L7540" rel="L7540">“And yet I meant to be uncommonly clever in taking so decided a dislike</li>
<li class="L7541" rel="L7541">to him, without any reason. It is such a spur to one&#39;s genius, such an</li>
<li class="L7542" rel="L7542">opening for wit, to have a dislike of that kind. One may be continually</li>
<li class="L7543" rel="L7543">abusive without saying anything just; but one cannot always be laughing</li>
<li class="L7544" rel="L7544">at a man without now and then stumbling on something witty.”</li>
<li class="L7545" rel="L7545"></li>
<li class="L7546" rel="L7546">“Lizzy, when you first read that letter, I am sure you could not treat</li>
<li class="L7547" rel="L7547">the matter as you do now.”</li>
<li class="L7548" rel="L7548"></li>
<li class="L7549" rel="L7549">“Indeed, I could not. I was uncomfortable enough, I may say unhappy. And</li>
<li class="L7550" rel="L7550">with no one to speak to about what I felt, no Jane to comfort me and say</li>
<li class="L7551" rel="L7551">that I had not been so very weak and vain and nonsensical as I knew I</li>
<li class="L7552" rel="L7552">had! Oh! how I wanted you!”</li>
<li class="L7553" rel="L7553"></li>
<li class="L7554" rel="L7554">“How unfortunate that you should have used such very strong expressions</li>
<li class="L7555" rel="L7555">in speaking of Wickham to Mr. Darcy, for now they _do_ appear wholly</li>
<li class="L7556" rel="L7556">undeserved.”</li>
<li class="L7557" rel="L7557"></li>
<li class="L7558" rel="L7558">“Certainly. But the misfortune of speaking with bitterness is a most</li>
<li class="L7559" rel="L7559">natural consequence of the prejudices I had been encouraging. There</li>
<li class="L7560" rel="L7560">is one point on which I want your advice. I want to be told whether I</li>
<li class="L7561" rel="L7561">ought, or ought not, to make our acquaintances in general understand</li>
<li class="L7562" rel="L7562">Wickham&#39;s character.”</li>
<li class="L7563" rel="L7563"></li>
<li class="L7564" rel="L7564">Miss Bennet paused a little, and then replied, “Surely there can be no</li>
<li class="L7565" rel="L7565">occasion for exposing him so dreadfully. What is your opinion?”</li>
<li class="L7566" rel="L7566"></li>
<li class="L7567" rel="L7567">“That it ought not to be attempted. Mr. Darcy has not authorised me</li>
<li class="L7568" rel="L7568">to make his communication public. On the contrary, every particular</li>
<li class="L7569" rel="L7569">relative to his sister was meant to be kept as much as possible to</li>
<li class="L7570" rel="L7570">myself; and if I endeavour to undeceive people as to the rest of his</li>
<li class="L7571" rel="L7571">conduct, who will believe me? The general prejudice against Mr. Darcy</li>
<li class="L7572" rel="L7572">is so violent, that it would be the death of half the good people in</li>
<li class="L7573" rel="L7573">Meryton to attempt to place him in an amiable light. I am not equal</li>
<li class="L7574" rel="L7574">to it. Wickham will soon be gone; and therefore it will not signify to</li>
<li class="L7575" rel="L7575">anyone here what he really is. Some time hence it will be all found out,</li>
<li class="L7576" rel="L7576">and then we may laugh at their stupidity in not knowing it before. At</li>
<li class="L7577" rel="L7577">present I will say nothing about it.”</li>
<li class="L7578" rel="L7578"></li>
<li class="L7579" rel="L7579">“You are quite right. To have his errors made public might ruin him for</li>
<li class="L7580" rel="L7580">ever. He is now, perhaps, sorry for what he has done, and anxious to</li>
<li class="L7581" rel="L7581">re-establish a character. We must not make him desperate.”</li>
<li class="L7582" rel="L7582"></li>
<li class="L7583" rel="L7583">The tumult of Elizabeth&#39;s mind was allayed by this conversation. She had</li>
<li class="L7584" rel="L7584">got rid of two of the secrets which had weighed on her for a fortnight,</li>
<li class="L7585" rel="L7585">and was certain of a willing listener in Jane, whenever she might wish</li>
<li class="L7586" rel="L7586">to talk again of either. But there was still something lurking behind,</li>
<li class="L7587" rel="L7587">of which prudence forbade the disclosure. She dared not relate the other</li>
<li class="L7588" rel="L7588">half of Mr. Darcy&#39;s letter, nor explain to her sister how sincerely she</li>
<li class="L7589" rel="L7589">had been valued by her friend. Here was knowledge in which no one</li>
<li class="L7590" rel="L7590">could partake; and she was sensible that nothing less than a perfect</li>
<li class="L7591" rel="L7591">understanding between the parties could justify her in throwing off</li>
<li class="L7592" rel="L7592">this last encumbrance of mystery. “And then,” said she, “if that very</li>
<li class="L7593" rel="L7593">improbable event should ever take place, I shall merely be able to</li>
<li class="L7594" rel="L7594">tell what Bingley may tell in a much more agreeable manner himself. The</li>
<li class="L7595" rel="L7595">liberty of communication cannot be mine till it has lost all its value!”</li>
<li class="L7596" rel="L7596"></li>
<li class="L7597" rel="L7597">She was now, on being settled at home, at leisure to observe the real</li>
<li class="L7598" rel="L7598">state of her sister&#39;s spirits. Jane was not happy. She still cherished a</li>
<li class="L7599" rel="L7599">very tender affection for Bingley. Having never even fancied herself</li>
<li class="L7600" rel="L7600">in love before, her regard had all the warmth of first attachment,</li>
<li class="L7601" rel="L7601">and, from her age and disposition, greater steadiness than most first</li>
<li class="L7602" rel="L7602">attachments often boast; and so fervently did she value his remembrance,</li>
<li class="L7603" rel="L7603">and prefer him to every other man, that all her good sense, and all her</li>
<li class="L7604" rel="L7604">attention to the feelings of her friends, were requisite to check the</li>
<li class="L7605" rel="L7605">indulgence of those regrets which must have been injurious to her own</li>
<li class="L7606" rel="L7606">health and their tranquillity.</li>
<li class="L7607" rel="L7607"></li>
<li class="L7608" rel="L7608">“Well, Lizzy,” said Mrs. Bennet one day, “what is your opinion _now_ of</li>
<li class="L7609" rel="L7609">this sad business of Jane&#39;s? For my part, I am determined never to speak</li>
<li class="L7610" rel="L7610">of it again to anybody. I told my sister Phillips so the other day. But</li>
<li class="L7611" rel="L7611">I cannot find out that Jane saw anything of him in London. Well, he is</li>
<li class="L7612" rel="L7612">a very undeserving young man--and I do not suppose there&#39;s the least</li>
<li class="L7613" rel="L7613">chance in the world of her ever getting him now. There is no talk of</li>
<li class="L7614" rel="L7614">his coming to Netherfield again in the summer; and I have inquired of</li>
<li class="L7615" rel="L7615">everybody, too, who is likely to know.”</li>
<li class="L7616" rel="L7616"></li>
<li class="L7617" rel="L7617">“I do not believe he will ever live at Netherfield any more.”</li>
<li class="L7618" rel="L7618"></li>
<li class="L7619" rel="L7619">“Oh well! it is just as he chooses. Nobody wants him to come. Though I</li>
<li class="L7620" rel="L7620">shall always say he used my daughter extremely ill; and if I was her, I</li>
<li class="L7621" rel="L7621">would not have put up with it. Well, my comfort is, I am sure Jane will</li>
<li class="L7622" rel="L7622">die of a broken heart; and then he will be sorry for what he has done.”</li>
<li class="L7623" rel="L7623"></li>
<li class="L7624" rel="L7624">But as Elizabeth could not receive comfort from any such expectation,</li>
<li class="L7625" rel="L7625">she made no answer.</li>
<li class="L7626" rel="L7626"></li>
<li class="L7627" rel="L7627">“Well, Lizzy,” continued her mother, soon afterwards, “and so the</li>
<li class="L7628" rel="L7628">Collinses live very comfortable, do they? Well, well, I only hope</li>
<li class="L7629" rel="L7629">it will last. And what sort of table do they keep? Charlotte is an</li>
<li class="L7630" rel="L7630">excellent manager, I dare say. If she is half as sharp as her</li>
<li class="L7631" rel="L7631">mother, she is saving enough. There is nothing extravagant in _their_</li>
<li class="L7632" rel="L7632">housekeeping, I dare say.”</li>
<li class="L7633" rel="L7633"></li>
<li class="L7634" rel="L7634">“No, nothing at all.”</li>
<li class="L7635" rel="L7635"></li>
<li class="L7636" rel="L7636">“A great deal of good management, depend upon it. Yes, yes, _they_ will</li>
<li class="L7637" rel="L7637">take care not to outrun their income. _They_ will never be distressed</li>
<li class="L7638" rel="L7638">for money. Well, much good may it do them! And so, I suppose, they often</li>
<li class="L7639" rel="L7639">talk of having Longbourn when your father is dead. They look upon it as</li>
<li class="L7640" rel="L7640">quite their own, I dare say, whenever that happens.”</li>
<li class="L7641" rel="L7641"></li>
<li class="L7642" rel="L7642">“It was a subject which they could not mention before me.”</li>
<li class="L7643" rel="L7643"></li>
<li class="L7644" rel="L7644">“No; it would have been strange if they had; but I make no doubt they</li>
<li class="L7645" rel="L7645">often talk of it between themselves. Well, if they can be easy with an</li>
<li class="L7646" rel="L7646">estate that is not lawfully their own, so much the better. I should be</li>
<li class="L7647" rel="L7647">ashamed of having one that was only entailed on me.”</li>
<li class="L7648" rel="L7648"></li>
<li class="L7649" rel="L7649"></li>
<li class="L7650" rel="L7650"></li>
<li class="L7651" rel="L7651">Chapter 41</li>
<li class="L7652" rel="L7652"></li>
<li class="L7653" rel="L7653"></li>
<li class="L7654" rel="L7654">The first week of their return was soon gone. The second began. It was</li>
<li class="L7655" rel="L7655">the last of the regiment&#39;s stay in Meryton, and all the young ladies</li>
<li class="L7656" rel="L7656">in the neighbourhood were drooping apace. The dejection was almost</li>
<li class="L7657" rel="L7657">universal. The elder Miss Bennets alone were still able to eat, drink,</li>
<li class="L7658" rel="L7658">and sleep, and pursue the usual course of their employments. Very</li>
<li class="L7659" rel="L7659">frequently were they reproached for this insensibility by Kitty and</li>
<li class="L7660" rel="L7660">Lydia, whose own misery was extreme, and who could not comprehend such</li>
<li class="L7661" rel="L7661">hard-heartedness in any of the family.</li>
<li class="L7662" rel="L7662"></li>
<li class="L7663" rel="L7663">“Good Heaven! what is to become of us? What are we to do?” would they</li>
<li class="L7664" rel="L7664">often exclaim in the bitterness of woe. “How can you be smiling so,</li>
<li class="L7665" rel="L7665">Lizzy?”</li>
<li class="L7666" rel="L7666"></li>
<li class="L7667" rel="L7667">Their affectionate mother shared all their grief; she remembered what</li>
<li class="L7668" rel="L7668">she had herself endured on a similar occasion, five-and-twenty years</li>
<li class="L7669" rel="L7669">ago.</li>
<li class="L7670" rel="L7670"></li>
<li class="L7671" rel="L7671">“I am sure,” said she, “I cried for two days together when Colonel</li>
<li class="L7672" rel="L7672">Miller&#39;s regiment went away. I thought I should have broken my heart.”</li>
<li class="L7673" rel="L7673"></li>
<li class="L7674" rel="L7674">“I am sure I shall break _mine_,” said Lydia.</li>
<li class="L7675" rel="L7675"></li>
<li class="L7676" rel="L7676">“If one could but go to Brighton!” observed Mrs. Bennet.</li>
<li class="L7677" rel="L7677"></li>
<li class="L7678" rel="L7678">“Oh, yes!--if one could but go to Brighton! But papa is so</li>
<li class="L7679" rel="L7679">disagreeable.”</li>
<li class="L7680" rel="L7680"></li>
<li class="L7681" rel="L7681">“A little sea-bathing would set me up forever.”</li>
<li class="L7682" rel="L7682"></li>
<li class="L7683" rel="L7683">“And my aunt Phillips is sure it would do _me_ a great deal of good,”</li>
<li class="L7684" rel="L7684"> added Kitty.</li>
<li class="L7685" rel="L7685"></li>
<li class="L7686" rel="L7686">Such were the kind of lamentations resounding perpetually through</li>
<li class="L7687" rel="L7687">Longbourn House. Elizabeth tried to be diverted by them; but all sense</li>
<li class="L7688" rel="L7688">of pleasure was lost in shame. She felt anew the justice of Mr. Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L7689" rel="L7689">objections; and never had she been so much disposed to pardon his</li>
<li class="L7690" rel="L7690">interference in the views of his friend.</li>
<li class="L7691" rel="L7691"></li>
<li class="L7692" rel="L7692">But the gloom of Lydia&#39;s prospect was shortly cleared away; for she</li>
<li class="L7693" rel="L7693">received an invitation from Mrs. Forster, the wife of the colonel of</li>
<li class="L7694" rel="L7694">the regiment, to accompany her to Brighton. This invaluable friend was a</li>
<li class="L7695" rel="L7695">very young woman, and very lately married. A resemblance in good humour</li>
<li class="L7696" rel="L7696">and good spirits had recommended her and Lydia to each other, and out of</li>
<li class="L7697" rel="L7697">their _three_ months&#39; acquaintance they had been intimate _two_.</li>
<li class="L7698" rel="L7698"></li>
<li class="L7699" rel="L7699">The rapture of Lydia on this occasion, her adoration of Mrs. Forster,</li>
<li class="L7700" rel="L7700">the delight of Mrs. Bennet, and the mortification of Kitty, are scarcely</li>
<li class="L7701" rel="L7701">to be described. Wholly inattentive to her sister&#39;s feelings, Lydia</li>
<li class="L7702" rel="L7702">flew about the house in restless ecstasy, calling for everyone&#39;s</li>
<li class="L7703" rel="L7703">congratulations, and laughing and talking with more violence than ever;</li>
<li class="L7704" rel="L7704">whilst the luckless Kitty continued in the parlour repined at her fate</li>
<li class="L7705" rel="L7705">in terms as unreasonable as her accent was peevish.</li>
<li class="L7706" rel="L7706"></li>
<li class="L7707" rel="L7707">“I cannot see why Mrs. Forster should not ask _me_ as well as Lydia,”</li>
<li class="L7708" rel="L7708"> said she, “Though I am _not_ her particular friend. I have just as much</li>
<li class="L7709" rel="L7709">right to be asked as she has, and more too, for I am two years older.”</li>
<li class="L7710" rel="L7710"></li>
<li class="L7711" rel="L7711">In vain did Elizabeth attempt to make her reasonable, and Jane to make</li>
<li class="L7712" rel="L7712">her resigned. As for Elizabeth herself, this invitation was so far from</li>
<li class="L7713" rel="L7713">exciting in her the same feelings as in her mother and Lydia, that she</li>
<li class="L7714" rel="L7714">considered it as the death warrant of all possibility of common sense</li>
<li class="L7715" rel="L7715">for the latter; and detestable as such a step must make her were it</li>
<li class="L7716" rel="L7716">known, she could not help secretly advising her father not to let her</li>
<li class="L7717" rel="L7717">go. She represented to him all the improprieties of Lydia&#39;s general</li>
<li class="L7718" rel="L7718">behaviour, the little advantage she could derive from the friendship of</li>
<li class="L7719" rel="L7719">such a woman as Mrs. Forster, and the probability of her being yet more</li>
<li class="L7720" rel="L7720">imprudent with such a companion at Brighton, where the temptations must</li>
<li class="L7721" rel="L7721">be greater than at home. He heard her attentively, and then said:</li>
<li class="L7722" rel="L7722"></li>
<li class="L7723" rel="L7723">“Lydia will never be easy until she has exposed herself in some public</li>
<li class="L7724" rel="L7724">place or other, and we can never expect her to do it with so</li>
<li class="L7725" rel="L7725">little expense or inconvenience to her family as under the present</li>
<li class="L7726" rel="L7726">circumstances.”</li>
<li class="L7727" rel="L7727"></li>
<li class="L7728" rel="L7728">“If you were aware,” said Elizabeth, “of the very great disadvantage to</li>
<li class="L7729" rel="L7729">us all which must arise from the public notice of Lydia&#39;s unguarded and</li>
<li class="L7730" rel="L7730">imprudent manner--nay, which has already arisen from it, I am sure you</li>
<li class="L7731" rel="L7731">would judge differently in the affair.”</li>
<li class="L7732" rel="L7732"></li>
<li class="L7733" rel="L7733">“Already arisen?” repeated Mr. Bennet. “What, has she frightened away</li>
<li class="L7734" rel="L7734">some of your lovers? Poor little Lizzy! But do not be cast down. Such</li>
<li class="L7735" rel="L7735">squeamish youths as cannot bear to be connected with a little absurdity</li>
<li class="L7736" rel="L7736">are not worth a regret. Come, let me see the list of pitiful fellows who</li>
<li class="L7737" rel="L7737">have been kept aloof by Lydia&#39;s folly.”</li>
<li class="L7738" rel="L7738"></li>
<li class="L7739" rel="L7739">“Indeed you are mistaken. I have no such injuries to resent. It is not</li>
<li class="L7740" rel="L7740">of particular, but of general evils, which I am now complaining. Our</li>
<li class="L7741" rel="L7741">importance, our respectability in the world must be affected by the</li>
<li class="L7742" rel="L7742">wild volatility, the assurance and disdain of all restraint which mark</li>
<li class="L7743" rel="L7743">Lydia&#39;s character. Excuse me, for I must speak plainly. If you, my dear</li>
<li class="L7744" rel="L7744">father, will not take the trouble of checking her exuberant spirits, and</li>
<li class="L7745" rel="L7745">of teaching her that her present pursuits are not to be the business of</li>
<li class="L7746" rel="L7746">her life, she will soon be beyond the reach of amendment. Her character</li>
<li class="L7747" rel="L7747">will be fixed, and she will, at sixteen, be the most determined flirt</li>
<li class="L7748" rel="L7748">that ever made herself or her family ridiculous; a flirt, too, in the</li>
<li class="L7749" rel="L7749">worst and meanest degree of flirtation; without any attraction beyond</li>
<li class="L7750" rel="L7750">youth and a tolerable person; and, from the ignorance and emptiness</li>
<li class="L7751" rel="L7751">of her mind, wholly unable to ward off any portion of that universal</li>
<li class="L7752" rel="L7752">contempt which her rage for admiration will excite. In this danger</li>
<li class="L7753" rel="L7753">Kitty also is comprehended. She will follow wherever Lydia leads. Vain,</li>
<li class="L7754" rel="L7754">ignorant, idle, and absolutely uncontrolled! Oh! my dear father, can you</li>
<li class="L7755" rel="L7755">suppose it possible that they will not be censured and despised wherever</li>
<li class="L7756" rel="L7756">they are known, and that their sisters will not be often involved in the</li>
<li class="L7757" rel="L7757">disgrace?”</li>
<li class="L7758" rel="L7758"></li>
<li class="L7759" rel="L7759">Mr. Bennet saw that her whole heart was in the subject, and</li>
<li class="L7760" rel="L7760">affectionately taking her hand said in reply:</li>
<li class="L7761" rel="L7761"></li>
<li class="L7762" rel="L7762">“Do not make yourself uneasy, my love. Wherever you and Jane are known</li>
<li class="L7763" rel="L7763">you must be respected and valued; and you will not appear to less</li>
<li class="L7764" rel="L7764">advantage for having a couple of--or I may say, three--very silly</li>
<li class="L7765" rel="L7765">sisters. We shall have no peace at Longbourn if Lydia does not go to</li>
<li class="L7766" rel="L7766">Brighton. Let her go, then. Colonel Forster is a sensible man, and will</li>
<li class="L7767" rel="L7767">keep her out of any real mischief; and she is luckily too poor to be an</li>
<li class="L7768" rel="L7768">object of prey to anybody. At Brighton she will be of less importance</li>
<li class="L7769" rel="L7769">even as a common flirt than she has been here. The officers will find</li>
<li class="L7770" rel="L7770">women better worth their notice. Let us hope, therefore, that her being</li>
<li class="L7771" rel="L7771">there may teach her her own insignificance. At any rate, she cannot grow</li>
<li class="L7772" rel="L7772">many degrees worse, without authorising us to lock her up for the rest</li>
<li class="L7773" rel="L7773">of her life.”</li>
<li class="L7774" rel="L7774"></li>
<li class="L7775" rel="L7775">With this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content; but her own opinion</li>
<li class="L7776" rel="L7776">continued the same, and she left him disappointed and sorry. It was not</li>
<li class="L7777" rel="L7777">in her nature, however, to increase her vexations by dwelling on</li>
<li class="L7778" rel="L7778">them. She was confident of having performed her duty, and to fret</li>
<li class="L7779" rel="L7779">over unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of her</li>
<li class="L7780" rel="L7780">disposition.</li>
<li class="L7781" rel="L7781"></li>
<li class="L7782" rel="L7782">Had Lydia and her mother known the substance of her conference with her</li>
<li class="L7783" rel="L7783">father, their indignation would hardly have found expression in their</li>
<li class="L7784" rel="L7784">united volubility. In Lydia&#39;s imagination, a visit to Brighton comprised</li>
<li class="L7785" rel="L7785">every possibility of earthly happiness. She saw, with the creative eye</li>
<li class="L7786" rel="L7786">of fancy, the streets of that gay bathing-place covered with officers.</li>
<li class="L7787" rel="L7787">She saw herself the object of attention, to tens and to scores of them</li>
<li class="L7788" rel="L7788">at present unknown. She saw all the glories of the camp--its tents</li>
<li class="L7789" rel="L7789">stretched forth in beauteous uniformity of lines, crowded with the young</li>
<li class="L7790" rel="L7790">and the gay, and dazzling with scarlet; and, to complete the view, she</li>
<li class="L7791" rel="L7791">saw herself seated beneath a tent, tenderly flirting with at least six</li>
<li class="L7792" rel="L7792">officers at once.</li>
<li class="L7793" rel="L7793"></li>
<li class="L7794" rel="L7794">Had she known her sister sought to tear her from such prospects and such</li>
<li class="L7795" rel="L7795">realities as these, what would have been her sensations? They could have</li>
<li class="L7796" rel="L7796">been understood only by her mother, who might have felt nearly the same.</li>
<li class="L7797" rel="L7797">Lydia&#39;s going to Brighton was all that consoled her for her melancholy</li>
<li class="L7798" rel="L7798">conviction of her husband&#39;s never intending to go there himself.</li>
<li class="L7799" rel="L7799"></li>
<li class="L7800" rel="L7800">But they were entirely ignorant of what had passed; and their raptures</li>
<li class="L7801" rel="L7801">continued, with little intermission, to the very day of Lydia&#39;s leaving</li>
<li class="L7802" rel="L7802">home.</li>
<li class="L7803" rel="L7803"></li>
<li class="L7804" rel="L7804">Elizabeth was now to see Mr. Wickham for the last time. Having been</li>
<li class="L7805" rel="L7805">frequently in company with him since her return, agitation was pretty</li>
<li class="L7806" rel="L7806">well over; the agitations of former partiality entirely so. She had even</li>
<li class="L7807" rel="L7807">learnt to detect, in the very gentleness which had first delighted</li>
<li class="L7808" rel="L7808">her, an affectation and a sameness to disgust and weary. In his present</li>
<li class="L7809" rel="L7809">behaviour to herself, moreover, she had a fresh source of displeasure,</li>
<li class="L7810" rel="L7810">for the inclination he soon testified of renewing those intentions which</li>
<li class="L7811" rel="L7811">had marked the early part of their acquaintance could only serve, after</li>
<li class="L7812" rel="L7812">what had since passed, to provoke her. She lost all concern for him in</li>
<li class="L7813" rel="L7813">finding herself thus selected as the object of such idle and frivolous</li>
<li class="L7814" rel="L7814">gallantry; and while she steadily repressed it, could not but feel the</li>
<li class="L7815" rel="L7815">reproof contained in his believing, that however long, and for whatever</li>
<li class="L7816" rel="L7816">cause, his attentions had been withdrawn, her vanity would be gratified,</li>
<li class="L7817" rel="L7817">and her preference secured at any time by their renewal.</li>
<li class="L7818" rel="L7818"></li>
<li class="L7819" rel="L7819">On the very last day of the regiment&#39;s remaining at Meryton, he dined,</li>
<li class="L7820" rel="L7820">with other of the officers, at Longbourn; and so little was Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L7821" rel="L7821">disposed to part from him in good humour, that on his making some</li>
<li class="L7822" rel="L7822">inquiry as to the manner in which her time had passed at Hunsford, she</li>
<li class="L7823" rel="L7823">mentioned Colonel Fitzwilliam&#39;s and Mr. Darcy&#39;s having both spent three</li>
<li class="L7824" rel="L7824">weeks at Rosings, and asked him, if he was acquainted with the former.</li>
<li class="L7825" rel="L7825"></li>
<li class="L7826" rel="L7826">He looked surprised, displeased, alarmed; but with a moment&#39;s</li>
<li class="L7827" rel="L7827">recollection and a returning smile, replied, that he had formerly seen</li>
<li class="L7828" rel="L7828">him often; and, after observing that he was a very gentlemanlike man,</li>
<li class="L7829" rel="L7829">asked her how she had liked him. Her answer was warmly in his favour.</li>
<li class="L7830" rel="L7830">With an air of indifference he soon afterwards added:</li>
<li class="L7831" rel="L7831"></li>
<li class="L7832" rel="L7832">“How long did you say he was at Rosings?”</li>
<li class="L7833" rel="L7833"></li>
<li class="L7834" rel="L7834">“Nearly three weeks.”</li>
<li class="L7835" rel="L7835"></li>
<li class="L7836" rel="L7836">“And you saw him frequently?”</li>
<li class="L7837" rel="L7837"></li>
<li class="L7838" rel="L7838">“Yes, almost every day.”</li>
<li class="L7839" rel="L7839"></li>
<li class="L7840" rel="L7840">“His manners are very different from his cousin&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L7841" rel="L7841"></li>
<li class="L7842" rel="L7842">“Yes, very different. But I think Mr. Darcy improves upon acquaintance.”</li>
<li class="L7843" rel="L7843"></li>
<li class="L7844" rel="L7844">“Indeed!” cried Mr. Wickham with a look which did not escape her. “And</li>
<li class="L7845" rel="L7845">pray, may I ask?--” But checking himself, he added, in a gayer tone, “Is</li>
<li class="L7846" rel="L7846">it in address that he improves? Has he deigned to add aught of civility</li>
<li class="L7847" rel="L7847">to his ordinary style?--for I dare not hope,” he continued in a lower</li>
<li class="L7848" rel="L7848">and more serious tone, “that he is improved in essentials.”</li>
<li class="L7849" rel="L7849"></li>
<li class="L7850" rel="L7850">“Oh, no!” said Elizabeth. “In essentials, I believe, he is very much</li>
<li class="L7851" rel="L7851">what he ever was.”</li>
<li class="L7852" rel="L7852"></li>
<li class="L7853" rel="L7853">While she spoke, Wickham looked as if scarcely knowing whether to</li>
<li class="L7854" rel="L7854">rejoice over her words, or to distrust their meaning. There was a</li>
<li class="L7855" rel="L7855">something in her countenance which made him listen with an apprehensive</li>
<li class="L7856" rel="L7856">and anxious attention, while she added:</li>
<li class="L7857" rel="L7857"></li>
<li class="L7858" rel="L7858">“When I said that he improved on acquaintance, I did not mean that</li>
<li class="L7859" rel="L7859">his mind or his manners were in a state of improvement, but that, from</li>
<li class="L7860" rel="L7860">knowing him better, his disposition was better understood.”</li>
<li class="L7861" rel="L7861"></li>
<li class="L7862" rel="L7862">Wickham&#39;s alarm now appeared in a heightened complexion and agitated</li>
<li class="L7863" rel="L7863">look; for a few minutes he was silent, till, shaking off his</li>
<li class="L7864" rel="L7864">embarrassment, he turned to her again, and said in the gentlest of</li>
<li class="L7865" rel="L7865">accents:</li>
<li class="L7866" rel="L7866"></li>
<li class="L7867" rel="L7867">“You, who so well know my feeling towards Mr. Darcy, will readily</li>
<li class="L7868" rel="L7868">comprehend how sincerely I must rejoice that he is wise enough to assume</li>
<li class="L7869" rel="L7869">even the _appearance_ of what is right. His pride, in that direction,</li>
<li class="L7870" rel="L7870">may be of service, if not to himself, to many others, for it must only</li>
<li class="L7871" rel="L7871">deter him from such foul misconduct as I have suffered by. I only</li>
<li class="L7872" rel="L7872">fear that the sort of cautiousness to which you, I imagine, have been</li>
<li class="L7873" rel="L7873">alluding, is merely adopted on his visits to his aunt, of whose good</li>
<li class="L7874" rel="L7874">opinion and judgement he stands much in awe. His fear of her has always</li>
<li class="L7875" rel="L7875">operated, I know, when they were together; and a good deal is to be</li>
<li class="L7876" rel="L7876">imputed to his wish of forwarding the match with Miss de Bourgh, which I</li>
<li class="L7877" rel="L7877">am certain he has very much at heart.”</li>
<li class="L7878" rel="L7878"></li>
<li class="L7879" rel="L7879">Elizabeth could not repress a smile at this, but she answered only by a</li>
<li class="L7880" rel="L7880">slight inclination of the head. She saw that he wanted to engage her on</li>
<li class="L7881" rel="L7881">the old subject of his grievances, and she was in no humour to indulge</li>
<li class="L7882" rel="L7882">him. The rest of the evening passed with the _appearance_, on his</li>
<li class="L7883" rel="L7883">side, of usual cheerfulness, but with no further attempt to distinguish</li>
<li class="L7884" rel="L7884">Elizabeth; and they parted at last with mutual civility, and possibly a</li>
<li class="L7885" rel="L7885">mutual desire of never meeting again.</li>
<li class="L7886" rel="L7886"></li>
<li class="L7887" rel="L7887">When the party broke up, Lydia returned with Mrs. Forster to Meryton,</li>
<li class="L7888" rel="L7888">from whence they were to set out early the next morning. The separation</li>
<li class="L7889" rel="L7889">between her and her family was rather noisy than pathetic. Kitty was the</li>
<li class="L7890" rel="L7890">only one who shed tears; but she did weep from vexation and envy. Mrs.</li>
<li class="L7891" rel="L7891">Bennet was diffuse in her good wishes for the felicity of her daughter,</li>
<li class="L7892" rel="L7892">and impressive in her injunctions that she should not miss the</li>
<li class="L7893" rel="L7893">opportunity of enjoying herself as much as possible--advice which</li>
<li class="L7894" rel="L7894">there was every reason to believe would be well attended to; and in</li>
<li class="L7895" rel="L7895">the clamorous happiness of Lydia herself in bidding farewell, the more</li>
<li class="L7896" rel="L7896">gentle adieus of her sisters were uttered without being heard.</li>
<li class="L7897" rel="L7897"></li>
<li class="L7898" rel="L7898"></li>
<li class="L7899" rel="L7899"></li>
<li class="L7900" rel="L7900">Chapter 42</li>
<li class="L7901" rel="L7901"></li>
<li class="L7902" rel="L7902"></li>
<li class="L7903" rel="L7903">Had Elizabeth&#39;s opinion been all drawn from her own family, she could</li>
<li class="L7904" rel="L7904">not have formed a very pleasing opinion of conjugal felicity or domestic</li>
<li class="L7905" rel="L7905">comfort. Her father, captivated by youth and beauty, and that appearance</li>
<li class="L7906" rel="L7906">of good humour which youth and beauty generally give, had married a</li>
<li class="L7907" rel="L7907">woman whose weak understanding and illiberal mind had very early in</li>
<li class="L7908" rel="L7908">their marriage put an end to all real affection for her. Respect,</li>
<li class="L7909" rel="L7909">esteem, and confidence had vanished for ever; and all his views</li>
<li class="L7910" rel="L7910">of domestic happiness were overthrown. But Mr. Bennet was not of</li>
<li class="L7911" rel="L7911">a disposition to seek comfort for the disappointment which his own</li>
<li class="L7912" rel="L7912">imprudence had brought on, in any of those pleasures which too often</li>
<li class="L7913" rel="L7913">console the unfortunate for their folly or their vice. He was fond of</li>
<li class="L7914" rel="L7914">the country and of books; and from these tastes had arisen his principal</li>
<li class="L7915" rel="L7915">enjoyments. To his wife he was very little otherwise indebted, than as</li>
<li class="L7916" rel="L7916">her ignorance and folly had contributed to his amusement. This is not</li>
<li class="L7917" rel="L7917">the sort of happiness which a man would in general wish to owe to his</li>
<li class="L7918" rel="L7918">wife; but where other powers of entertainment are wanting, the true</li>
<li class="L7919" rel="L7919">philosopher will derive benefit from such as are given.</li>
<li class="L7920" rel="L7920"></li>
<li class="L7921" rel="L7921">Elizabeth, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her</li>
<li class="L7922" rel="L7922">father&#39;s behaviour as a husband. She had always seen it with pain; but</li>
<li class="L7923" rel="L7923">respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of</li>
<li class="L7924" rel="L7924">herself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to</li>
<li class="L7925" rel="L7925">banish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation</li>
<li class="L7926" rel="L7926">and decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own</li>
<li class="L7927" rel="L7927">children, was so highly reprehensible. But she had never felt so</li>
<li class="L7928" rel="L7928">strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so</li>
<li class="L7929" rel="L7929">unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising</li>
<li class="L7930" rel="L7930">from so ill-judged a direction of talents; talents, which, rightly used,</li>
<li class="L7931" rel="L7931">might at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even</li>
<li class="L7932" rel="L7932">if incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.</li>
<li class="L7933" rel="L7933"></li>
<li class="L7934" rel="L7934">When Elizabeth had rejoiced over Wickham&#39;s departure she found little</li>
<li class="L7935" rel="L7935">other cause for satisfaction in the loss of the regiment. Their parties</li>
<li class="L7936" rel="L7936">abroad were less varied than before, and at home she had a mother and</li>
<li class="L7937" rel="L7937">sister whose constant repinings at the dullness of everything around</li>
<li class="L7938" rel="L7938">them threw a real gloom over their domestic circle; and, though Kitty</li>
<li class="L7939" rel="L7939">might in time regain her natural degree of sense, since the disturbers</li>
<li class="L7940" rel="L7940">of her brain were removed, her other sister, from whose disposition</li>
<li class="L7941" rel="L7941">greater evil might be apprehended, was likely to be hardened in all</li>
<li class="L7942" rel="L7942">her folly and assurance by a situation of such double danger as a</li>
<li class="L7943" rel="L7943">watering-place and a camp. Upon the whole, therefore, she found, what</li>
<li class="L7944" rel="L7944">has been sometimes found before, that an event to which she had been</li>
<li class="L7945" rel="L7945">looking with impatient desire did not, in taking place, bring all the</li>
<li class="L7946" rel="L7946">satisfaction she had promised herself. It was consequently necessary to</li>
<li class="L7947" rel="L7947">name some other period for the commencement of actual felicity--to have</li>
<li class="L7948" rel="L7948">some other point on which her wishes and hopes might be fixed, and by</li>
<li class="L7949" rel="L7949">again enjoying the pleasure of anticipation, console herself for the</li>
<li class="L7950" rel="L7950">present, and prepare for another disappointment. Her tour to the Lakes</li>
<li class="L7951" rel="L7951">was now the object of her happiest thoughts; it was her best consolation</li>
<li class="L7952" rel="L7952">for all the uncomfortable hours which the discontentedness of her mother</li>
<li class="L7953" rel="L7953">and Kitty made inevitable; and could she have included Jane in the</li>
<li class="L7954" rel="L7954">scheme, every part of it would have been perfect.</li>
<li class="L7955" rel="L7955"></li>
<li class="L7956" rel="L7956">“But it is fortunate,” thought she, “that I have something to wish for.</li>
<li class="L7957" rel="L7957">Were the whole arrangement complete, my disappointment would be certain.</li>
<li class="L7958" rel="L7958">But here, by carrying with me one ceaseless source of regret in my</li>
<li class="L7959" rel="L7959">sister&#39;s absence, I may reasonably hope to have all my expectations of</li>
<li class="L7960" rel="L7960">pleasure realised. A scheme of which every part promises delight can</li>
<li class="L7961" rel="L7961">never be successful; and general disappointment is only warded off by</li>
<li class="L7962" rel="L7962">the defence of some little peculiar vexation.”</li>
<li class="L7963" rel="L7963"></li>
<li class="L7964" rel="L7964">When Lydia went away she promised to write very often and very minutely</li>
<li class="L7965" rel="L7965">to her mother and Kitty; but her letters were always long expected, and</li>
<li class="L7966" rel="L7966">always very short. Those to her mother contained little else than that</li>
<li class="L7967" rel="L7967">they were just returned from the library, where such and such officers</li>
<li class="L7968" rel="L7968">had attended them, and where she had seen such beautiful ornaments as</li>
<li class="L7969" rel="L7969">made her quite wild; that she had a new gown, or a new parasol, which</li>
<li class="L7970" rel="L7970">she would have described more fully, but was obliged to leave off in a</li>
<li class="L7971" rel="L7971">violent hurry, as Mrs. Forster called her, and they were going off to</li>
<li class="L7972" rel="L7972">the camp; and from her correspondence with her sister, there was still</li>
<li class="L7973" rel="L7973">less to be learnt--for her letters to Kitty, though rather longer, were</li>
<li class="L7974" rel="L7974">much too full of lines under the words to be made public.</li>
<li class="L7975" rel="L7975"></li>
<li class="L7976" rel="L7976">After the first fortnight or three weeks of her absence, health, good</li>
<li class="L7977" rel="L7977">humour, and cheerfulness began to reappear at Longbourn. Everything wore</li>
<li class="L7978" rel="L7978">a happier aspect. The families who had been in town for the winter came</li>
<li class="L7979" rel="L7979">back again, and summer finery and summer engagements arose. Mrs. Bennet</li>
<li class="L7980" rel="L7980">was restored to her usual querulous serenity; and, by the middle of</li>
<li class="L7981" rel="L7981">June, Kitty was so much recovered as to be able to enter Meryton without</li>
<li class="L7982" rel="L7982">tears; an event of such happy promise as to make Elizabeth hope that by</li>
<li class="L7983" rel="L7983">the following Christmas she might be so tolerably reasonable as not to</li>
<li class="L7984" rel="L7984">mention an officer above once a day, unless, by some cruel and malicious</li>
<li class="L7985" rel="L7985">arrangement at the War Office, another regiment should be quartered in</li>
<li class="L7986" rel="L7986">Meryton.</li>
<li class="L7987" rel="L7987"></li>
<li class="L7988" rel="L7988">The time fixed for the beginning of their northern tour was now fast</li>
<li class="L7989" rel="L7989">approaching, and a fortnight only was wanting of it, when a letter</li>
<li class="L7990" rel="L7990">arrived from Mrs. Gardiner, which at once delayed its commencement and</li>
<li class="L7991" rel="L7991">curtailed its extent. Mr. Gardiner would be prevented by business from</li>
<li class="L7992" rel="L7992">setting out till a fortnight later in July, and must be in London again</li>
<li class="L7993" rel="L7993">within a month, and as that left too short a period for them to go so</li>
<li class="L7994" rel="L7994">far, and see so much as they had proposed, or at least to see it with</li>
<li class="L7995" rel="L7995">the leisure and comfort they had built on, they were obliged to give up</li>
<li class="L7996" rel="L7996">the Lakes, and substitute a more contracted tour, and, according to the</li>
<li class="L7997" rel="L7997">present plan, were to go no farther northwards than Derbyshire. In that</li>
<li class="L7998" rel="L7998">county there was enough to be seen to occupy the chief of their three</li>
<li class="L7999" rel="L7999">weeks; and to Mrs. Gardiner it had a peculiarly strong attraction. The</li>
<li class="L8000" rel="L8000">town where she had formerly passed some years of her life, and where</li>
<li class="L8001" rel="L8001">they were now to spend a few days, was probably as great an object of</li>
<li class="L8002" rel="L8002">her curiosity as all the celebrated beauties of Matlock, Chatsworth,</li>
<li class="L8003" rel="L8003">Dovedale, or the Peak.</li>
<li class="L8004" rel="L8004"></li>
<li class="L8005" rel="L8005">Elizabeth was excessively disappointed; she had set her heart on seeing</li>
<li class="L8006" rel="L8006">the Lakes, and still thought there might have been time enough. But it</li>
<li class="L8007" rel="L8007">was her business to be satisfied--and certainly her temper to be happy;</li>
<li class="L8008" rel="L8008">and all was soon right again.</li>
<li class="L8009" rel="L8009"></li>
<li class="L8010" rel="L8010">With the mention of Derbyshire there were many ideas connected. It was</li>
<li class="L8011" rel="L8011">impossible for her to see the word without thinking of Pemberley and its</li>
<li class="L8012" rel="L8012">owner. “But surely,” said she, “I may enter his county with impunity,</li>
<li class="L8013" rel="L8013">and rob it of a few petrified spars without his perceiving me.”</li>
<li class="L8014" rel="L8014"></li>
<li class="L8015" rel="L8015">The period of expectation was now doubled. Four weeks were to pass away</li>
<li class="L8016" rel="L8016">before her uncle and aunt&#39;s arrival. But they did pass away, and Mr.</li>
<li class="L8017" rel="L8017">and Mrs. Gardiner, with their four children, did at length appear at</li>
<li class="L8018" rel="L8018">Longbourn. The children, two girls of six and eight years old, and two</li>
<li class="L8019" rel="L8019">younger boys, were to be left under the particular care of their</li>
<li class="L8020" rel="L8020">cousin Jane, who was the general favourite, and whose steady sense and</li>
<li class="L8021" rel="L8021">sweetness of temper exactly adapted her for attending to them in every</li>
<li class="L8022" rel="L8022">way--teaching them, playing with them, and loving them.</li>
<li class="L8023" rel="L8023"></li>
<li class="L8024" rel="L8024">The Gardiners stayed only one night at Longbourn, and set off the</li>
<li class="L8025" rel="L8025">next morning with Elizabeth in pursuit of novelty and amusement.</li>
<li class="L8026" rel="L8026">One enjoyment was certain--that of suitableness of companions;</li>
<li class="L8027" rel="L8027">a suitableness which comprehended health and temper to bear</li>
<li class="L8028" rel="L8028">inconveniences--cheerfulness to enhance every pleasure--and affection</li>
<li class="L8029" rel="L8029">and intelligence, which might supply it among themselves if there were</li>
<li class="L8030" rel="L8030">disappointments abroad.</li>
<li class="L8031" rel="L8031"></li>
<li class="L8032" rel="L8032">It is not the object of this work to give a description of Derbyshire,</li>
<li class="L8033" rel="L8033">nor of any of the remarkable places through which their route thither</li>
<li class="L8034" rel="L8034">lay; Oxford, Blenheim, Warwick, Kenilworth, Birmingham, etc. are</li>
<li class="L8035" rel="L8035">sufficiently known. A small part of Derbyshire is all the present</li>
<li class="L8036" rel="L8036">concern. To the little town of Lambton, the scene of Mrs. Gardiner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8037" rel="L8037">former residence, and where she had lately learned some acquaintance</li>
<li class="L8038" rel="L8038">still remained, they bent their steps, after having seen all the</li>
<li class="L8039" rel="L8039">principal wonders of the country; and within five miles of Lambton,</li>
<li class="L8040" rel="L8040">Elizabeth found from her aunt that Pemberley was situated. It was not</li>
<li class="L8041" rel="L8041">in their direct road, nor more than a mile or two out of it. In</li>
<li class="L8042" rel="L8042">talking over their route the evening before, Mrs. Gardiner expressed</li>
<li class="L8043" rel="L8043">an inclination to see the place again. Mr. Gardiner declared his</li>
<li class="L8044" rel="L8044">willingness, and Elizabeth was applied to for her approbation.</li>
<li class="L8045" rel="L8045"></li>
<li class="L8046" rel="L8046">“My love, should not you like to see a place of which you have heard</li>
<li class="L8047" rel="L8047">so much?” said her aunt; “a place, too, with which so many of your</li>
<li class="L8048" rel="L8048">acquaintances are connected. Wickham passed all his youth there, you</li>
<li class="L8049" rel="L8049">know.”</li>
<li class="L8050" rel="L8050"></li>
<li class="L8051" rel="L8051">Elizabeth was distressed. She felt that she had no business at</li>
<li class="L8052" rel="L8052">Pemberley, and was obliged to assume a disinclination for seeing it. She</li>
<li class="L8053" rel="L8053">must own that she was tired of seeing great houses; after going over so</li>
<li class="L8054" rel="L8054">many, she really had no pleasure in fine carpets or satin curtains.</li>
<li class="L8055" rel="L8055"></li>
<li class="L8056" rel="L8056">Mrs. Gardiner abused her stupidity. “If it were merely a fine house</li>
<li class="L8057" rel="L8057">richly furnished,” said she, “I should not care about it myself; but</li>
<li class="L8058" rel="L8058">the grounds are delightful. They have some of the finest woods in the</li>
<li class="L8059" rel="L8059">country.”</li>
<li class="L8060" rel="L8060"></li>
<li class="L8061" rel="L8061">Elizabeth said no more--but her mind could not acquiesce. The</li>
<li class="L8062" rel="L8062">possibility of meeting Mr. Darcy, while viewing the place, instantly</li>
<li class="L8063" rel="L8063">occurred. It would be dreadful! She blushed at the very idea, and</li>
<li class="L8064" rel="L8064">thought it would be better to speak openly to her aunt than to run such</li>
<li class="L8065" rel="L8065">a risk. But against this there were objections; and she finally resolved</li>
<li class="L8066" rel="L8066">that it could be the last resource, if her private inquiries to the</li>
<li class="L8067" rel="L8067">absence of the family were unfavourably answered.</li>
<li class="L8068" rel="L8068"></li>
<li class="L8069" rel="L8069">Accordingly, when she retired at night, she asked the chambermaid</li>
<li class="L8070" rel="L8070">whether Pemberley were not a very fine place? what was the name of its</li>
<li class="L8071" rel="L8071">proprietor? and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for</li>
<li class="L8072" rel="L8072">the summer? A most welcome negative followed the last question--and her</li>
<li class="L8073" rel="L8073">alarms now being removed, she was at leisure to feel a great deal of</li>
<li class="L8074" rel="L8074">curiosity to see the house herself; and when the subject was revived the</li>
<li class="L8075" rel="L8075">next morning, and she was again applied to, could readily answer, and</li>
<li class="L8076" rel="L8076">with a proper air of indifference, that she had not really any dislike</li>
<li class="L8077" rel="L8077">to the scheme. To Pemberley, therefore, they were to go.</li>
<li class="L8078" rel="L8078"></li>
<li class="L8079" rel="L8079"></li>
<li class="L8080" rel="L8080"></li>
<li class="L8081" rel="L8081">Chapter 43</li>
<li class="L8082" rel="L8082"></li>
<li class="L8083" rel="L8083"></li>
<li class="L8084" rel="L8084">Elizabeth, as they drove along, watched for the first appearance of</li>
<li class="L8085" rel="L8085">Pemberley Woods with some perturbation; and when at length they turned</li>
<li class="L8086" rel="L8086">in at the lodge, her spirits were in a high flutter.</li>
<li class="L8087" rel="L8087"></li>
<li class="L8088" rel="L8088">The park was very large, and contained great variety of ground. They</li>
<li class="L8089" rel="L8089">entered it in one of its lowest points, and drove for some time through</li>
<li class="L8090" rel="L8090">a beautiful wood stretching over a wide extent.</li>
<li class="L8091" rel="L8091"></li>
<li class="L8092" rel="L8092">Elizabeth&#39;s mind was too full for conversation, but she saw and admired</li>
<li class="L8093" rel="L8093">every remarkable spot and point of view. They gradually ascended for</li>
<li class="L8094" rel="L8094">half-a-mile, and then found themselves at the top of a considerable</li>
<li class="L8095" rel="L8095">eminence, where the wood ceased, and the eye was instantly caught by</li>
<li class="L8096" rel="L8096">Pemberley House, situated on the opposite side of a valley, into which</li>
<li class="L8097" rel="L8097">the road with some abruptness wound. It was a large, handsome stone</li>
<li class="L8098" rel="L8098">building, standing well on rising ground, and backed by a ridge of</li>
<li class="L8099" rel="L8099">high woody hills; and in front, a stream of some natural importance was</li>
<li class="L8100" rel="L8100">swelled into greater, but without any artificial appearance. Its banks</li>
<li class="L8101" rel="L8101">were neither formal nor falsely adorned. Elizabeth was delighted. She</li>
<li class="L8102" rel="L8102">had never seen a place for which nature had done more, or where natural</li>
<li class="L8103" rel="L8103">beauty had been so little counteracted by an awkward taste. They were</li>
<li class="L8104" rel="L8104">all of them warm in their admiration; and at that moment she felt that</li>
<li class="L8105" rel="L8105">to be mistress of Pemberley might be something!</li>
<li class="L8106" rel="L8106"></li>
<li class="L8107" rel="L8107">They descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and,</li>
<li class="L8108" rel="L8108">while examining the nearer aspect of the house, all her apprehension of</li>
<li class="L8109" rel="L8109">meeting its owner returned. She dreaded lest the chambermaid had been</li>
<li class="L8110" rel="L8110">mistaken. On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the</li>
<li class="L8111" rel="L8111">hall; and Elizabeth, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to</li>
<li class="L8112" rel="L8112">wonder at her being where she was.</li>
<li class="L8113" rel="L8113"></li>
<li class="L8114" rel="L8114">The housekeeper came; a respectable-looking elderly woman, much less</li>
<li class="L8115" rel="L8115">fine, and more civil, than she had any notion of finding her. They</li>
<li class="L8116" rel="L8116">followed her into the dining-parlour. It was a large, well proportioned</li>
<li class="L8117" rel="L8117">room, handsomely fitted up. Elizabeth, after slightly surveying it, went</li>
<li class="L8118" rel="L8118">to a window to enjoy its prospect. The hill, crowned with wood, which</li>
<li class="L8119" rel="L8119">they had descended, receiving increased abruptness from the distance,</li>
<li class="L8120" rel="L8120">was a beautiful object. Every disposition of the ground was good; and</li>
<li class="L8121" rel="L8121">she looked on the whole scene, the river, the trees scattered on its</li>
<li class="L8122" rel="L8122">banks and the winding of the valley, as far as she could trace it,</li>
<li class="L8123" rel="L8123">with delight. As they passed into other rooms these objects were taking</li>
<li class="L8124" rel="L8124">different positions; but from every window there were beauties to be</li>
<li class="L8125" rel="L8125">seen. The rooms were lofty and handsome, and their furniture suitable to</li>
<li class="L8126" rel="L8126">the fortune of its proprietor; but Elizabeth saw, with admiration of</li>
<li class="L8127" rel="L8127">his taste, that it was neither gaudy nor uselessly fine; with less of</li>
<li class="L8128" rel="L8128">splendour, and more real elegance, than the furniture of Rosings.</li>
<li class="L8129" rel="L8129"></li>
<li class="L8130" rel="L8130">“And of this place,” thought she, “I might have been mistress! With</li>
<li class="L8131" rel="L8131">these rooms I might now have been familiarly acquainted! Instead of</li>
<li class="L8132" rel="L8132">viewing them as a stranger, I might have rejoiced in them as my own, and</li>
<li class="L8133" rel="L8133">welcomed to them as visitors my uncle and aunt. But no,”--recollecting</li>
<li class="L8134" rel="L8134">herself--“that could never be; my uncle and aunt would have been lost to</li>
<li class="L8135" rel="L8135">me; I should not have been allowed to invite them.”</li>
<li class="L8136" rel="L8136"></li>
<li class="L8137" rel="L8137">This was a lucky recollection--it saved her from something very like</li>
<li class="L8138" rel="L8138">regret.</li>
<li class="L8139" rel="L8139"></li>
<li class="L8140" rel="L8140">She longed to inquire of the housekeeper whether her master was really</li>
<li class="L8141" rel="L8141">absent, but had not the courage for it. At length however, the question</li>
<li class="L8142" rel="L8142">was asked by her uncle; and she turned away with alarm, while Mrs.</li>
<li class="L8143" rel="L8143">Reynolds replied that he was, adding, “But we expect him to-morrow, with</li>
<li class="L8144" rel="L8144">a large party of friends.” How rejoiced was Elizabeth that their own</li>
<li class="L8145" rel="L8145">journey had not by any circumstance been delayed a day!</li>
<li class="L8146" rel="L8146"></li>
<li class="L8147" rel="L8147">Her aunt now called her to look at a picture. She approached and saw the</li>
<li class="L8148" rel="L8148">likeness of Mr. Wickham, suspended, amongst several other miniatures,</li>
<li class="L8149" rel="L8149">over the mantelpiece. Her aunt asked her, smilingly, how she liked it.</li>
<li class="L8150" rel="L8150">The housekeeper came forward, and told them it was a picture of a young</li>
<li class="L8151" rel="L8151">gentleman, the son of her late master&#39;s steward, who had been brought</li>
<li class="L8152" rel="L8152">up by him at his own expense. “He is now gone into the army,” she added;</li>
<li class="L8153" rel="L8153">“but I am afraid he has turned out very wild.”</li>
<li class="L8154" rel="L8154"></li>
<li class="L8155" rel="L8155">Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece with a smile, but Elizabeth could not</li>
<li class="L8156" rel="L8156">return it.</li>
<li class="L8157" rel="L8157"></li>
<li class="L8158" rel="L8158">“And that,” said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures,</li>
<li class="L8159" rel="L8159">“is my master--and very like him. It was drawn at the same time as the</li>
<li class="L8160" rel="L8160">other--about eight years ago.”</li>
<li class="L8161" rel="L8161"></li>
<li class="L8162" rel="L8162">“I have heard much of your master&#39;s fine person,” said Mrs. Gardiner,</li>
<li class="L8163" rel="L8163">looking at the picture; “it is a handsome face. But, Lizzy, you can tell</li>
<li class="L8164" rel="L8164">us whether it is like or not.”</li>
<li class="L8165" rel="L8165"></li>
<li class="L8166" rel="L8166">Mrs. Reynolds respect for Elizabeth seemed to increase on this</li>
<li class="L8167" rel="L8167">intimation of her knowing her master.</li>
<li class="L8168" rel="L8168"></li>
<li class="L8169" rel="L8169">“Does that young lady know Mr. Darcy?”</li>
<li class="L8170" rel="L8170"></li>
<li class="L8171" rel="L8171">Elizabeth coloured, and said: “A little.”</li>
<li class="L8172" rel="L8172"></li>
<li class="L8173" rel="L8173">“And do not you think him a very handsome gentleman, ma&#39;am?”</li>
<li class="L8174" rel="L8174"></li>
<li class="L8175" rel="L8175">“Yes, very handsome.”</li>
<li class="L8176" rel="L8176"></li>
<li class="L8177" rel="L8177">“I am sure I know none so handsome; but in the gallery up stairs you</li>
<li class="L8178" rel="L8178">will see a finer, larger picture of him than this. This room was my late</li>
<li class="L8179" rel="L8179">master&#39;s favourite room, and these miniatures are just as they used to</li>
<li class="L8180" rel="L8180">be then. He was very fond of them.”</li>
<li class="L8181" rel="L8181"></li>
<li class="L8182" rel="L8182">This accounted to Elizabeth for Mr. Wickham&#39;s being among them.</li>
<li class="L8183" rel="L8183"></li>
<li class="L8184" rel="L8184">Mrs. Reynolds then directed their attention to one of Miss Darcy, drawn</li>
<li class="L8185" rel="L8185">when she was only eight years old.</li>
<li class="L8186" rel="L8186"></li>
<li class="L8187" rel="L8187">“And is Miss Darcy as handsome as her brother?” said Mrs. Gardiner.</li>
<li class="L8188" rel="L8188"></li>
<li class="L8189" rel="L8189">“Oh! yes--the handsomest young lady that ever was seen; and so</li>
<li class="L8190" rel="L8190">accomplished!--She plays and sings all day long. In the next room is</li>
<li class="L8191" rel="L8191">a new instrument just come down for her--a present from my master; she</li>
<li class="L8192" rel="L8192">comes here to-morrow with him.”</li>
<li class="L8193" rel="L8193"></li>
<li class="L8194" rel="L8194">Mr. Gardiner, whose manners were very easy and pleasant, encouraged her</li>
<li class="L8195" rel="L8195">communicativeness by his questions and remarks; Mrs. Reynolds, either</li>
<li class="L8196" rel="L8196">by pride or attachment, had evidently great pleasure in talking of her</li>
<li class="L8197" rel="L8197">master and his sister.</li>
<li class="L8198" rel="L8198"></li>
<li class="L8199" rel="L8199">“Is your master much at Pemberley in the course of the year?”</li>
<li class="L8200" rel="L8200"></li>
<li class="L8201" rel="L8201">“Not so much as I could wish, sir; but I dare say he may spend half his</li>
<li class="L8202" rel="L8202">time here; and Miss Darcy is always down for the summer months.”</li>
<li class="L8203" rel="L8203"></li>
<li class="L8204" rel="L8204">“Except,” thought Elizabeth, “when she goes to Ramsgate.”</li>
<li class="L8205" rel="L8205"></li>
<li class="L8206" rel="L8206">“If your master would marry, you might see more of him.”</li>
<li class="L8207" rel="L8207"></li>
<li class="L8208" rel="L8208">“Yes, sir; but I do not know when _that_ will be. I do not know who is</li>
<li class="L8209" rel="L8209">good enough for him.”</li>
<li class="L8210" rel="L8210"></li>
<li class="L8211" rel="L8211">Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner smiled. Elizabeth could not help saying, “It is</li>
<li class="L8212" rel="L8212">very much to his credit, I am sure, that you should think so.”</li>
<li class="L8213" rel="L8213"></li>
<li class="L8214" rel="L8214">“I say no more than the truth, and everybody will say that knows him,”</li>
<li class="L8215" rel="L8215"> replied the other. Elizabeth thought this was going pretty far; and she</li>
<li class="L8216" rel="L8216">listened with increasing astonishment as the housekeeper added, “I have</li>
<li class="L8217" rel="L8217">never known a cross word from him in my life, and I have known him ever</li>
<li class="L8218" rel="L8218">since he was four years old.”</li>
<li class="L8219" rel="L8219"></li>
<li class="L8220" rel="L8220">This was praise, of all others most extraordinary, most opposite to her</li>
<li class="L8221" rel="L8221">ideas. That he was not a good-tempered man had been her firmest opinion.</li>
<li class="L8222" rel="L8222">Her keenest attention was awakened; she longed to hear more, and was</li>
<li class="L8223" rel="L8223">grateful to her uncle for saying:</li>
<li class="L8224" rel="L8224"></li>
<li class="L8225" rel="L8225">“There are very few people of whom so much can be said. You are lucky in</li>
<li class="L8226" rel="L8226">having such a master.”</li>
<li class="L8227" rel="L8227"></li>
<li class="L8228" rel="L8228">“Yes, sir, I know I am. If I were to go through the world, I could</li>
<li class="L8229" rel="L8229">not meet with a better. But I have always observed, that they who are</li>
<li class="L8230" rel="L8230">good-natured when children, are good-natured when they grow up; and</li>
<li class="L8231" rel="L8231">he was always the sweetest-tempered, most generous-hearted boy in the</li>
<li class="L8232" rel="L8232">world.”</li>
<li class="L8233" rel="L8233"></li>
<li class="L8234" rel="L8234">Elizabeth almost stared at her. “Can this be Mr. Darcy?” thought she.</li>
<li class="L8235" rel="L8235"></li>
<li class="L8236" rel="L8236">“His father was an excellent man,” said Mrs. Gardiner.</li>
<li class="L8237" rel="L8237"></li>
<li class="L8238" rel="L8238">“Yes, ma&#39;am, that he was indeed; and his son will be just like him--just</li>
<li class="L8239" rel="L8239">as affable to the poor.”</li>
<li class="L8240" rel="L8240"></li>
<li class="L8241" rel="L8241">Elizabeth listened, wondered, doubted, and was impatient for more. Mrs.</li>
<li class="L8242" rel="L8242">Reynolds could interest her on no other point. She related the subjects</li>
<li class="L8243" rel="L8243">of the pictures, the dimensions of the rooms, and the price of the</li>
<li class="L8244" rel="L8244">furniture, in vain. Mr. Gardiner, highly amused by the kind of family</li>
<li class="L8245" rel="L8245">prejudice to which he attributed her excessive commendation of her</li>
<li class="L8246" rel="L8246">master, soon led again to the subject; and she dwelt with energy on his</li>
<li class="L8247" rel="L8247">many merits as they proceeded together up the great staircase.</li>
<li class="L8248" rel="L8248"></li>
<li class="L8249" rel="L8249">“He is the best landlord, and the best master,” said she, “that ever</li>
<li class="L8250" rel="L8250">lived; not like the wild young men nowadays, who think of nothing but</li>
<li class="L8251" rel="L8251">themselves. There is not one of his tenants or servants but will give</li>
<li class="L8252" rel="L8252">him a good name. Some people call him proud; but I am sure I never saw</li>
<li class="L8253" rel="L8253">anything of it. To my fancy, it is only because he does not rattle away</li>
<li class="L8254" rel="L8254">like other young men.”</li>
<li class="L8255" rel="L8255"></li>
<li class="L8256" rel="L8256">“In what an amiable light does this place him!” thought Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L8257" rel="L8257"></li>
<li class="L8258" rel="L8258">“This fine account of him,” whispered her aunt as they walked, “is not</li>
<li class="L8259" rel="L8259">quite consistent with his behaviour to our poor friend.”</li>
<li class="L8260" rel="L8260"></li>
