<li class="L8261" rel="L8261">“Perhaps we might be deceived.”</li>
<li class="L8262" rel="L8262"></li>
<li class="L8263" rel="L8263">“That is not very likely; our authority was too good.”</li>
<li class="L8264" rel="L8264"></li>
<li class="L8265" rel="L8265">On reaching the spacious lobby above they were shown into a very pretty</li>
<li class="L8266" rel="L8266">sitting-room, lately fitted up with greater elegance and lightness than</li>
<li class="L8267" rel="L8267">the apartments below; and were informed that it was but just done to</li>
<li class="L8268" rel="L8268">give pleasure to Miss Darcy, who had taken a liking to the room when</li>
<li class="L8269" rel="L8269">last at Pemberley.</li>
<li class="L8270" rel="L8270"></li>
<li class="L8271" rel="L8271">“He is certainly a good brother,” said Elizabeth, as she walked towards</li>
<li class="L8272" rel="L8272">one of the windows.</li>
<li class="L8273" rel="L8273"></li>
<li class="L8274" rel="L8274">Mrs. Reynolds anticipated Miss Darcy&#39;s delight, when she should enter</li>
<li class="L8275" rel="L8275">the room. “And this is always the way with him,” she added. “Whatever</li>
<li class="L8276" rel="L8276">can give his sister any pleasure is sure to be done in a moment. There</li>
<li class="L8277" rel="L8277">is nothing he would not do for her.”</li>
<li class="L8278" rel="L8278"></li>
<li class="L8279" rel="L8279">The picture-gallery, and two or three of the principal bedrooms, were</li>
<li class="L8280" rel="L8280">all that remained to be shown. In the former were many good paintings;</li>
<li class="L8281" rel="L8281">but Elizabeth knew nothing of the art; and from such as had been already</li>
<li class="L8282" rel="L8282">visible below, she had willingly turned to look at some drawings of Miss</li>
<li class="L8283" rel="L8283">Darcy&#39;s, in crayons, whose subjects were usually more interesting, and</li>
<li class="L8284" rel="L8284">also more intelligible.</li>
<li class="L8285" rel="L8285"></li>
<li class="L8286" rel="L8286">In the gallery there were many family portraits, but they could have</li>
<li class="L8287" rel="L8287">little to fix the attention of a stranger. Elizabeth walked in quest of</li>
<li class="L8288" rel="L8288">the only face whose features would be known to her. At last it arrested</li>
<li class="L8289" rel="L8289">her--and she beheld a striking resemblance to Mr. Darcy, with such a</li>
<li class="L8290" rel="L8290">smile over the face as she remembered to have sometimes seen when he</li>
<li class="L8291" rel="L8291">looked at her. She stood several minutes before the picture, in earnest</li>
<li class="L8292" rel="L8292">contemplation, and returned to it again before they quitted the gallery.</li>
<li class="L8293" rel="L8293">Mrs. Reynolds informed them that it had been taken in his father&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8294" rel="L8294">lifetime.</li>
<li class="L8295" rel="L8295"></li>
<li class="L8296" rel="L8296">There was certainly at this moment, in Elizabeth&#39;s mind, a more gentle</li>
<li class="L8297" rel="L8297">sensation towards the original than she had ever felt at the height of</li>
<li class="L8298" rel="L8298">their acquaintance. The commendation bestowed on him by Mrs. Reynolds</li>
<li class="L8299" rel="L8299">was of no trifling nature. What praise is more valuable than the praise</li>
<li class="L8300" rel="L8300">of an intelligent servant? As a brother, a landlord, a master, she</li>
<li class="L8301" rel="L8301">considered how many people&#39;s happiness were in his guardianship!--how</li>
<li class="L8302" rel="L8302">much of pleasure or pain was it in his power to bestow!--how much of</li>
<li class="L8303" rel="L8303">good or evil must be done by him! Every idea that had been brought</li>
<li class="L8304" rel="L8304">forward by the housekeeper was favourable to his character, and as she</li>
<li class="L8305" rel="L8305">stood before the canvas on which he was represented, and fixed his</li>
<li class="L8306" rel="L8306">eyes upon herself, she thought of his regard with a deeper sentiment of</li>
<li class="L8307" rel="L8307">gratitude than it had ever raised before; she remembered its warmth, and</li>
<li class="L8308" rel="L8308">softened its impropriety of expression.</li>
<li class="L8309" rel="L8309"></li>
<li class="L8310" rel="L8310">When all of the house that was open to general inspection had been seen,</li>
<li class="L8311" rel="L8311">they returned downstairs, and, taking leave of the housekeeper, were</li>
<li class="L8312" rel="L8312">consigned over to the gardener, who met them at the hall-door.</li>
<li class="L8313" rel="L8313"></li>
<li class="L8314" rel="L8314">As they walked across the hall towards the river, Elizabeth turned back</li>
<li class="L8315" rel="L8315">to look again; her uncle and aunt stopped also, and while the former</li>
<li class="L8316" rel="L8316">was conjecturing as to the date of the building, the owner of it himself</li>
<li class="L8317" rel="L8317">suddenly came forward from the road, which led behind it to the stables.</li>
<li class="L8318" rel="L8318"></li>
<li class="L8319" rel="L8319">They were within twenty yards of each other, and so abrupt was his</li>
<li class="L8320" rel="L8320">appearance, that it was impossible to avoid his sight. Their eyes</li>
<li class="L8321" rel="L8321">instantly met, and the cheeks of both were overspread with the deepest</li>
<li class="L8322" rel="L8322">blush. He absolutely started, and for a moment seemed immovable from</li>
<li class="L8323" rel="L8323">surprise; but shortly recovering himself, advanced towards the party,</li>
<li class="L8324" rel="L8324">and spoke to Elizabeth, if not in terms of perfect composure, at least</li>
<li class="L8325" rel="L8325">of perfect civility.</li>
<li class="L8326" rel="L8326"></li>
<li class="L8327" rel="L8327">She had instinctively turned away; but stopping on his approach,</li>
<li class="L8328" rel="L8328">received his compliments with an embarrassment impossible to be</li>
<li class="L8329" rel="L8329">overcome. Had his first appearance, or his resemblance to the picture</li>
<li class="L8330" rel="L8330">they had just been examining, been insufficient to assure the other two</li>
<li class="L8331" rel="L8331">that they now saw Mr. Darcy, the gardener&#39;s expression of surprise, on</li>
<li class="L8332" rel="L8332">beholding his master, must immediately have told it. They stood a little</li>
<li class="L8333" rel="L8333">aloof while he was talking to their niece, who, astonished and confused,</li>
<li class="L8334" rel="L8334">scarcely dared lift her eyes to his face, and knew not what answer</li>
<li class="L8335" rel="L8335">she returned to his civil inquiries after her family. Amazed at the</li>
<li class="L8336" rel="L8336">alteration of his manner since they last parted, every sentence that</li>
<li class="L8337" rel="L8337">he uttered was increasing her embarrassment; and every idea of the</li>
<li class="L8338" rel="L8338">impropriety of her being found there recurring to her mind, the few</li>
<li class="L8339" rel="L8339">minutes in which they continued were some of the most uncomfortable in</li>
<li class="L8340" rel="L8340">her life. Nor did he seem much more at ease; when he spoke, his accent</li>
<li class="L8341" rel="L8341">had none of its usual sedateness; and he repeated his inquiries as</li>
<li class="L8342" rel="L8342">to the time of her having left Longbourn, and of her having stayed in</li>
<li class="L8343" rel="L8343">Derbyshire, so often, and in so hurried a way, as plainly spoke the</li>
<li class="L8344" rel="L8344">distraction of his thoughts.</li>
<li class="L8345" rel="L8345"></li>
<li class="L8346" rel="L8346">At length every idea seemed to fail him; and, after standing a few</li>
<li class="L8347" rel="L8347">moments without saying a word, he suddenly recollected himself, and took</li>
<li class="L8348" rel="L8348">leave.</li>
<li class="L8349" rel="L8349"></li>
<li class="L8350" rel="L8350">The others then joined her, and expressed admiration of his figure; but</li>
<li class="L8351" rel="L8351">Elizabeth heard not a word, and wholly engrossed by her own feelings,</li>
<li class="L8352" rel="L8352">followed them in silence. She was overpowered by shame and vexation. Her</li>
<li class="L8353" rel="L8353">coming there was the most unfortunate, the most ill-judged thing in the</li>
<li class="L8354" rel="L8354">world! How strange it must appear to him! In what a disgraceful light</li>
<li class="L8355" rel="L8355">might it not strike so vain a man! It might seem as if she had purposely</li>
<li class="L8356" rel="L8356">thrown herself in his way again! Oh! why did she come? Or, why did he</li>
<li class="L8357" rel="L8357">thus come a day before he was expected? Had they been only ten minutes</li>
<li class="L8358" rel="L8358">sooner, they should have been beyond the reach of his discrimination;</li>
<li class="L8359" rel="L8359">for it was plain that he was that moment arrived--that moment alighted</li>
<li class="L8360" rel="L8360">from his horse or his carriage. She blushed again and again over</li>
<li class="L8361" rel="L8361">the perverseness of the meeting. And his behaviour, so strikingly</li>
<li class="L8362" rel="L8362">altered--what could it mean? That he should even speak to her was</li>
<li class="L8363" rel="L8363">amazing!--but to speak with such civility, to inquire after her family!</li>
<li class="L8364" rel="L8364">Never in her life had she seen his manners so little dignified, never</li>
<li class="L8365" rel="L8365">had he spoken with such gentleness as on this unexpected meeting. What</li>
<li class="L8366" rel="L8366">a contrast did it offer to his last address in Rosings Park, when he put</li>
<li class="L8367" rel="L8367">his letter into her hand! She knew not what to think, or how to account</li>
<li class="L8368" rel="L8368">for it.</li>
<li class="L8369" rel="L8369"></li>
<li class="L8370" rel="L8370">They had now entered a beautiful walk by the side of the water, and</li>
<li class="L8371" rel="L8371">every step was bringing forward a nobler fall of ground, or a finer</li>
<li class="L8372" rel="L8372">reach of the woods to which they were approaching; but it was some time</li>
<li class="L8373" rel="L8373">before Elizabeth was sensible of any of it; and, though she answered</li>
<li class="L8374" rel="L8374">mechanically to the repeated appeals of her uncle and aunt, and</li>
<li class="L8375" rel="L8375">seemed to direct her eyes to such objects as they pointed out, she</li>
<li class="L8376" rel="L8376">distinguished no part of the scene. Her thoughts were all fixed on that</li>
<li class="L8377" rel="L8377">one spot of Pemberley House, whichever it might be, where Mr. Darcy then</li>
<li class="L8378" rel="L8378">was. She longed to know what at the moment was passing in his mind--in</li>
<li class="L8379" rel="L8379">what manner he thought of her, and whether, in defiance of everything,</li>
<li class="L8380" rel="L8380">she was still dear to him. Perhaps he had been civil only because he</li>
<li class="L8381" rel="L8381">felt himself at ease; yet there had been _that_ in his voice which was</li>
<li class="L8382" rel="L8382">not like ease. Whether he had felt more of pain or of pleasure in</li>
<li class="L8383" rel="L8383">seeing her she could not tell, but he certainly had not seen her with</li>
<li class="L8384" rel="L8384">composure.</li>
<li class="L8385" rel="L8385"></li>
<li class="L8386" rel="L8386">At length, however, the remarks of her companions on her absence of mind</li>
<li class="L8387" rel="L8387">aroused her, and she felt the necessity of appearing more like herself.</li>
<li class="L8388" rel="L8388"></li>
<li class="L8389" rel="L8389">They entered the woods, and bidding adieu to the river for a while,</li>
<li class="L8390" rel="L8390">ascended some of the higher grounds; when, in spots where the opening of</li>
<li class="L8391" rel="L8391">the trees gave the eye power to wander, were many charming views of the</li>
<li class="L8392" rel="L8392">valley, the opposite hills, with the long range of woods overspreading</li>
<li class="L8393" rel="L8393">many, and occasionally part of the stream. Mr. Gardiner expressed a wish</li>
<li class="L8394" rel="L8394">of going round the whole park, but feared it might be beyond a walk.</li>
<li class="L8395" rel="L8395">With a triumphant smile they were told that it was ten miles round.</li>
<li class="L8396" rel="L8396">It settled the matter; and they pursued the accustomed circuit; which</li>
<li class="L8397" rel="L8397">brought them again, after some time, in a descent among hanging woods,</li>
<li class="L8398" rel="L8398">to the edge of the water, and one of its narrowest parts. They crossed</li>
<li class="L8399" rel="L8399">it by a simple bridge, in character with the general air of the scene;</li>
<li class="L8400" rel="L8400">it was a spot less adorned than any they had yet visited; and the</li>
<li class="L8401" rel="L8401">valley, here contracted into a glen, allowed room only for the stream,</li>
<li class="L8402" rel="L8402">and a narrow walk amidst the rough coppice-wood which bordered it.</li>
<li class="L8403" rel="L8403">Elizabeth longed to explore its windings; but when they had crossed the</li>
<li class="L8404" rel="L8404">bridge, and perceived their distance from the house, Mrs. Gardiner,</li>
<li class="L8405" rel="L8405">who was not a great walker, could go no farther, and thought only</li>
<li class="L8406" rel="L8406">of returning to the carriage as quickly as possible. Her niece was,</li>
<li class="L8407" rel="L8407">therefore, obliged to submit, and they took their way towards the house</li>
<li class="L8408" rel="L8408">on the opposite side of the river, in the nearest direction; but their</li>
<li class="L8409" rel="L8409">progress was slow, for Mr. Gardiner, though seldom able to indulge the</li>
<li class="L8410" rel="L8410">taste, was very fond of fishing, and was so much engaged in watching the</li>
<li class="L8411" rel="L8411">occasional appearance of some trout in the water, and talking to the</li>
<li class="L8412" rel="L8412">man about them, that he advanced but little. Whilst wandering on in this</li>
<li class="L8413" rel="L8413">slow manner, they were again surprised, and Elizabeth&#39;s astonishment</li>
<li class="L8414" rel="L8414">was quite equal to what it had been at first, by the sight of Mr. Darcy</li>
<li class="L8415" rel="L8415">approaching them, and at no great distance. The walk being here</li>
<li class="L8416" rel="L8416">less sheltered than on the other side, allowed them to see him before</li>
<li class="L8417" rel="L8417">they met. Elizabeth, however astonished, was at least more prepared</li>
<li class="L8418" rel="L8418">for an interview than before, and resolved to appear and to speak with</li>
<li class="L8419" rel="L8419">calmness, if he really intended to meet them. For a few moments, indeed,</li>
<li class="L8420" rel="L8420">she felt that he would probably strike into some other path. The idea</li>
<li class="L8421" rel="L8421">lasted while a turning in the walk concealed him from their view; the</li>
<li class="L8422" rel="L8422">turning past, he was immediately before them. With a glance, she saw</li>
<li class="L8423" rel="L8423">that he had lost none of his recent civility; and, to imitate his</li>
<li class="L8424" rel="L8424">politeness, she began, as they met, to admire the beauty of the place;</li>
<li class="L8425" rel="L8425">but she had not got beyond the words “delightful,” and “charming,” when</li>
<li class="L8426" rel="L8426">some unlucky recollections obtruded, and she fancied that praise of</li>
<li class="L8427" rel="L8427">Pemberley from her might be mischievously construed. Her colour changed,</li>
<li class="L8428" rel="L8428">and she said no more.</li>
<li class="L8429" rel="L8429"></li>
<li class="L8430" rel="L8430">Mrs. Gardiner was standing a little behind; and on her pausing, he asked</li>
<li class="L8431" rel="L8431">her if she would do him the honour of introducing him to her friends.</li>
<li class="L8432" rel="L8432">This was a stroke of civility for which she was quite unprepared;</li>
<li class="L8433" rel="L8433">and she could hardly suppress a smile at his being now seeking the</li>
<li class="L8434" rel="L8434">acquaintance of some of those very people against whom his pride had</li>
<li class="L8435" rel="L8435">revolted in his offer to herself. “What will be his surprise,” thought</li>
<li class="L8436" rel="L8436">she, “when he knows who they are? He takes them now for people of</li>
<li class="L8437" rel="L8437">fashion.”</li>
<li class="L8438" rel="L8438"></li>
<li class="L8439" rel="L8439">The introduction, however, was immediately made; and as she named their</li>
<li class="L8440" rel="L8440">relationship to herself, she stole a sly look at him, to see how he bore</li>
<li class="L8441" rel="L8441">it, and was not without the expectation of his decamping as fast as he</li>
<li class="L8442" rel="L8442">could from such disgraceful companions. That he was _surprised_ by the</li>
<li class="L8443" rel="L8443">connection was evident; he sustained it, however, with fortitude, and</li>
<li class="L8444" rel="L8444">so far from going away, turned back with them, and entered into</li>
<li class="L8445" rel="L8445">conversation with Mr. Gardiner. Elizabeth could not but be pleased,</li>
<li class="L8446" rel="L8446">could not but triumph. It was consoling that he should know she had</li>
<li class="L8447" rel="L8447">some relations for whom there was no need to blush. She listened most</li>
<li class="L8448" rel="L8448">attentively to all that passed between them, and gloried in every</li>
<li class="L8449" rel="L8449">expression, every sentence of her uncle, which marked his intelligence,</li>
<li class="L8450" rel="L8450">his taste, or his good manners.</li>
<li class="L8451" rel="L8451"></li>
<li class="L8452" rel="L8452">The conversation soon turned upon fishing; and she heard Mr. Darcy</li>
<li class="L8453" rel="L8453">invite him, with the greatest civility, to fish there as often as he</li>
<li class="L8454" rel="L8454">chose while he continued in the neighbourhood, offering at the same time</li>
<li class="L8455" rel="L8455">to supply him with fishing tackle, and pointing out those parts of</li>
<li class="L8456" rel="L8456">the stream where there was usually most sport. Mrs. Gardiner, who was</li>
<li class="L8457" rel="L8457">walking arm-in-arm with Elizabeth, gave her a look expressive of wonder.</li>
<li class="L8458" rel="L8458">Elizabeth said nothing, but it gratified her exceedingly; the compliment</li>
<li class="L8459" rel="L8459">must be all for herself. Her astonishment, however, was extreme, and</li>
<li class="L8460" rel="L8460">continually was she repeating, “Why is he so altered? From what can</li>
<li class="L8461" rel="L8461">it proceed? It cannot be for _me_--it cannot be for _my_ sake that his</li>
<li class="L8462" rel="L8462">manners are thus softened. My reproofs at Hunsford could not work such a</li>
<li class="L8463" rel="L8463">change as this. It is impossible that he should still love me.”</li>
<li class="L8464" rel="L8464"></li>
<li class="L8465" rel="L8465">After walking some time in this way, the two ladies in front, the two</li>
<li class="L8466" rel="L8466">gentlemen behind, on resuming their places, after descending to</li>
<li class="L8467" rel="L8467">the brink of the river for the better inspection of some curious</li>
<li class="L8468" rel="L8468">water-plant, there chanced to be a little alteration. It originated</li>
<li class="L8469" rel="L8469">in Mrs. Gardiner, who, fatigued by the exercise of the morning, found</li>
<li class="L8470" rel="L8470">Elizabeth&#39;s arm inadequate to her support, and consequently preferred</li>
<li class="L8471" rel="L8471">her husband&#39;s. Mr. Darcy took her place by her niece, and they walked on</li>
<li class="L8472" rel="L8472">together. After a short silence, the lady first spoke. She wished him</li>
<li class="L8473" rel="L8473">to know that she had been assured of his absence before she came to the</li>
<li class="L8474" rel="L8474">place, and accordingly began by observing, that his arrival had been</li>
<li class="L8475" rel="L8475">very unexpected--“for your housekeeper,” she added, “informed us that</li>
<li class="L8476" rel="L8476">you would certainly not be here till to-morrow; and indeed, before we</li>
<li class="L8477" rel="L8477">left Bakewell, we understood that you were not immediately expected</li>
<li class="L8478" rel="L8478">in the country.” He acknowledged the truth of it all, and said that</li>
<li class="L8479" rel="L8479">business with his steward had occasioned his coming forward a few hours</li>
<li class="L8480" rel="L8480">before the rest of the party with whom he had been travelling. “They</li>
<li class="L8481" rel="L8481">will join me early to-morrow,” he continued, “and among them are some</li>
<li class="L8482" rel="L8482">who will claim an acquaintance with you--Mr. Bingley and his sisters.”</li>
<li class="L8483" rel="L8483"></li>
<li class="L8484" rel="L8484">Elizabeth answered only by a slight bow. Her thoughts were instantly</li>
<li class="L8485" rel="L8485">driven back to the time when Mr. Bingley&#39;s name had been the last</li>
<li class="L8486" rel="L8486">mentioned between them; and, if she might judge by his complexion, _his_</li>
<li class="L8487" rel="L8487">mind was not very differently engaged.</li>
<li class="L8488" rel="L8488"></li>
<li class="L8489" rel="L8489">“There is also one other person in the party,” he continued after a</li>
<li class="L8490" rel="L8490">pause, “who more particularly wishes to be known to you. Will you allow</li>
<li class="L8491" rel="L8491">me, or do I ask too much, to introduce my sister to your acquaintance</li>
<li class="L8492" rel="L8492">during your stay at Lambton?”</li>
<li class="L8493" rel="L8493"></li>
<li class="L8494" rel="L8494">The surprise of such an application was great indeed; it was too great</li>
<li class="L8495" rel="L8495">for her to know in what manner she acceded to it. She immediately felt</li>
<li class="L8496" rel="L8496">that whatever desire Miss Darcy might have of being acquainted with her</li>
<li class="L8497" rel="L8497">must be the work of her brother, and, without looking farther, it was</li>
<li class="L8498" rel="L8498">satisfactory; it was gratifying to know that his resentment had not made</li>
<li class="L8499" rel="L8499">him think really ill of her.</li>
<li class="L8500" rel="L8500"></li>
<li class="L8501" rel="L8501">They now walked on in silence, each of them deep in thought. Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L8502" rel="L8502">was not comfortable; that was impossible; but she was flattered and</li>
<li class="L8503" rel="L8503">pleased. His wish of introducing his sister to her was a compliment of</li>
<li class="L8504" rel="L8504">the highest kind. They soon outstripped the others, and when they had</li>
<li class="L8505" rel="L8505">reached the carriage, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were half a quarter of a</li>
<li class="L8506" rel="L8506">mile behind.</li>
<li class="L8507" rel="L8507"></li>
<li class="L8508" rel="L8508">He then asked her to walk into the house--but she declared herself not</li>
<li class="L8509" rel="L8509">tired, and they stood together on the lawn. At such a time much might</li>
<li class="L8510" rel="L8510">have been said, and silence was very awkward. She wanted to talk, but</li>
<li class="L8511" rel="L8511">there seemed to be an embargo on every subject. At last she recollected</li>
<li class="L8512" rel="L8512">that she had been travelling, and they talked of Matlock and Dove Dale</li>
<li class="L8513" rel="L8513">with great perseverance. Yet time and her aunt moved slowly--and her</li>
<li class="L8514" rel="L8514">patience and her ideas were nearly worn out before the tete-a-tete was</li>
<li class="L8515" rel="L8515">over. On Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner&#39;s coming up they were all pressed to go</li>
<li class="L8516" rel="L8516">into the house and take some refreshment; but this was declined, and</li>
<li class="L8517" rel="L8517">they parted on each side with utmost politeness. Mr. Darcy handed the</li>
<li class="L8518" rel="L8518">ladies into the carriage; and when it drove off, Elizabeth saw him</li>
<li class="L8519" rel="L8519">walking slowly towards the house.</li>
<li class="L8520" rel="L8520"></li>
<li class="L8521" rel="L8521">The observations of her uncle and aunt now began; and each of them</li>
<li class="L8522" rel="L8522">pronounced him to be infinitely superior to anything they had expected.</li>
<li class="L8523" rel="L8523">“He is perfectly well behaved, polite, and unassuming,” said her uncle.</li>
<li class="L8524" rel="L8524"></li>
<li class="L8525" rel="L8525">“There _is_ something a little stately in him, to be sure,” replied her</li>
<li class="L8526" rel="L8526">aunt, “but it is confined to his air, and is not unbecoming. I can now</li>
<li class="L8527" rel="L8527">say with the housekeeper, that though some people may call him proud, I</li>
<li class="L8528" rel="L8528">have seen nothing of it.”</li>
<li class="L8529" rel="L8529"></li>
<li class="L8530" rel="L8530">“I was never more surprised than by his behaviour to us. It was more</li>
<li class="L8531" rel="L8531">than civil; it was really attentive; and there was no necessity for such</li>
<li class="L8532" rel="L8532">attention. His acquaintance with Elizabeth was very trifling.”</li>
<li class="L8533" rel="L8533"></li>
<li class="L8534" rel="L8534">“To be sure, Lizzy,” said her aunt, “he is not so handsome as Wickham;</li>
<li class="L8535" rel="L8535">or, rather, he has not Wickham&#39;s countenance, for his features</li>
<li class="L8536" rel="L8536">are perfectly good. But how came you to tell me that he was so</li>
<li class="L8537" rel="L8537">disagreeable?”</li>
<li class="L8538" rel="L8538"></li>
<li class="L8539" rel="L8539">Elizabeth excused herself as well as she could; said that she had liked</li>
<li class="L8540" rel="L8540">him better when they had met in Kent than before, and that she had never</li>
<li class="L8541" rel="L8541">seen him so pleasant as this morning.</li>
<li class="L8542" rel="L8542"></li>
<li class="L8543" rel="L8543">“But perhaps he may be a little whimsical in his civilities,” replied</li>
<li class="L8544" rel="L8544">her uncle. “Your great men often are; and therefore I shall not take him</li>
<li class="L8545" rel="L8545">at his word, as he might change his mind another day, and warn me off</li>
<li class="L8546" rel="L8546">his grounds.”</li>
<li class="L8547" rel="L8547"></li>
<li class="L8548" rel="L8548">Elizabeth felt that they had entirely misunderstood his character, but</li>
<li class="L8549" rel="L8549">said nothing.</li>
<li class="L8550" rel="L8550"></li>
<li class="L8551" rel="L8551">“From what we have seen of him,” continued Mrs. Gardiner, “I really</li>
<li class="L8552" rel="L8552">should not have thought that he could have behaved in so cruel a way by</li>
<li class="L8553" rel="L8553">anybody as he has done by poor Wickham. He has not an ill-natured look.</li>
<li class="L8554" rel="L8554">On the contrary, there is something pleasing about his mouth when he</li>
<li class="L8555" rel="L8555">speaks. And there is something of dignity in his countenance that would</li>
<li class="L8556" rel="L8556">not give one an unfavourable idea of his heart. But, to be sure, the</li>
<li class="L8557" rel="L8557">good lady who showed us his house did give him a most flaming character!</li>
<li class="L8558" rel="L8558">I could hardly help laughing aloud sometimes. But he is a liberal</li>
<li class="L8559" rel="L8559">master, I suppose, and _that_ in the eye of a servant comprehends every</li>
<li class="L8560" rel="L8560">virtue.”</li>
<li class="L8561" rel="L8561"></li>
<li class="L8562" rel="L8562">Elizabeth here felt herself called on to say something in vindication of</li>
<li class="L8563" rel="L8563">his behaviour to Wickham; and therefore gave them to understand, in</li>
<li class="L8564" rel="L8564">as guarded a manner as she could, that by what she had heard from</li>
<li class="L8565" rel="L8565">his relations in Kent, his actions were capable of a very different</li>
<li class="L8566" rel="L8566">construction; and that his character was by no means so faulty, nor</li>
<li class="L8567" rel="L8567">Wickham&#39;s so amiable, as they had been considered in Hertfordshire. In</li>
<li class="L8568" rel="L8568">confirmation of this, she related the particulars of all the pecuniary</li>
<li class="L8569" rel="L8569">transactions in which they had been connected, without actually naming</li>
<li class="L8570" rel="L8570">her authority, but stating it to be such as might be relied on.</li>
<li class="L8571" rel="L8571"></li>
<li class="L8572" rel="L8572">Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and concerned; but as they were now</li>
<li class="L8573" rel="L8573">approaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to</li>
<li class="L8574" rel="L8574">the charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out</li>
<li class="L8575" rel="L8575">to her husband all the interesting spots in its environs to think of</li>
<li class="L8576" rel="L8576">anything else. Fatigued as she had been by the morning&#39;s walk they</li>
<li class="L8577" rel="L8577">had no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former</li>
<li class="L8578" rel="L8578">acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of a</li>
<li class="L8579" rel="L8579">intercourse renewed after many years&#39; discontinuance.</li>
<li class="L8580" rel="L8580"></li>
<li class="L8581" rel="L8581">The occurrences of the day were too full of interest to leave Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L8582" rel="L8582">much attention for any of these new friends; and she could do nothing</li>
<li class="L8583" rel="L8583">but think, and think with wonder, of Mr. Darcy&#39;s civility, and, above</li>
<li class="L8584" rel="L8584">all, of his wishing her to be acquainted with his sister.</li>
<li class="L8585" rel="L8585"></li>
<li class="L8586" rel="L8586"></li>
<li class="L8587" rel="L8587"></li>
<li class="L8588" rel="L8588">Chapter 44</li>
<li class="L8589" rel="L8589"></li>
<li class="L8590" rel="L8590"></li>
<li class="L8591" rel="L8591">Elizabeth had settled it that Mr. Darcy would bring his sister to visit</li>
<li class="L8592" rel="L8592">her the very day after her reaching Pemberley; and was consequently</li>
<li class="L8593" rel="L8593">resolved not to be out of sight of the inn the whole of that morning.</li>
<li class="L8594" rel="L8594">But her conclusion was false; for on the very morning after their</li>
<li class="L8595" rel="L8595">arrival at Lambton, these visitors came. They had been walking about the</li>
<li class="L8596" rel="L8596">place with some of their new friends, and were just returning to the inn</li>
<li class="L8597" rel="L8597">to dress themselves for dining with the same family, when the sound of a</li>
<li class="L8598" rel="L8598">carriage drew them to a window, and they saw a gentleman and a lady in</li>
<li class="L8599" rel="L8599">a curricle driving up the street. Elizabeth immediately recognizing</li>
<li class="L8600" rel="L8600">the livery, guessed what it meant, and imparted no small degree of her</li>
<li class="L8601" rel="L8601">surprise to her relations by acquainting them with the honour which she</li>
<li class="L8602" rel="L8602">expected. Her uncle and aunt were all amazement; and the embarrassment</li>
<li class="L8603" rel="L8603">of her manner as she spoke, joined to the circumstance itself, and many</li>
<li class="L8604" rel="L8604">of the circumstances of the preceding day, opened to them a new idea on</li>
<li class="L8605" rel="L8605">the business. Nothing had ever suggested it before, but they felt that</li>
<li class="L8606" rel="L8606">there was no other way of accounting for such attentions from such a</li>
<li class="L8607" rel="L8607">quarter than by supposing a partiality for their niece. While these</li>
<li class="L8608" rel="L8608">newly-born notions were passing in their heads, the perturbation of</li>
<li class="L8609" rel="L8609">Elizabeth&#39;s feelings was at every moment increasing. She was quite</li>
<li class="L8610" rel="L8610">amazed at her own discomposure; but amongst other causes of disquiet,</li>
<li class="L8611" rel="L8611">she dreaded lest the partiality of the brother should have said too much</li>
<li class="L8612" rel="L8612">in her favour; and, more than commonly anxious to please, she naturally</li>
<li class="L8613" rel="L8613">suspected that every power of pleasing would fail her.</li>
<li class="L8614" rel="L8614"></li>
<li class="L8615" rel="L8615">She retreated from the window, fearful of being seen; and as she walked</li>
<li class="L8616" rel="L8616">up and down the room, endeavouring to compose herself, saw such looks of</li>
<li class="L8617" rel="L8617">inquiring surprise in her uncle and aunt as made everything worse.</li>
<li class="L8618" rel="L8618"></li>
<li class="L8619" rel="L8619">Miss Darcy and her brother appeared, and this formidable introduction</li>
<li class="L8620" rel="L8620">took place. With astonishment did Elizabeth see that her new</li>
<li class="L8621" rel="L8621">acquaintance was at least as much embarrassed as herself. Since her</li>
<li class="L8622" rel="L8622">being at Lambton, she had heard that Miss Darcy was exceedingly proud;</li>
<li class="L8623" rel="L8623">but the observation of a very few minutes convinced her that she was</li>
<li class="L8624" rel="L8624">only exceedingly shy. She found it difficult to obtain even a word from</li>
<li class="L8625" rel="L8625">her beyond a monosyllable.</li>
<li class="L8626" rel="L8626"></li>
<li class="L8627" rel="L8627">Miss Darcy was tall, and on a larger scale than Elizabeth; and, though</li>
<li class="L8628" rel="L8628">little more than sixteen, her figure was formed, and her appearance</li>
<li class="L8629" rel="L8629">womanly and graceful. She was less handsome than her brother; but there</li>
<li class="L8630" rel="L8630">was sense and good humour in her face, and her manners were perfectly</li>
<li class="L8631" rel="L8631">unassuming and gentle. Elizabeth, who had expected to find in her as</li>
<li class="L8632" rel="L8632">acute and unembarrassed an observer as ever Mr. Darcy had been, was much</li>
<li class="L8633" rel="L8633">relieved by discerning such different feelings.</li>
<li class="L8634" rel="L8634"></li>
<li class="L8635" rel="L8635">They had not long been together before Mr. Darcy told her that Bingley</li>
<li class="L8636" rel="L8636">was also coming to wait on her; and she had barely time to express her</li>
<li class="L8637" rel="L8637">satisfaction, and prepare for such a visitor, when Bingley&#39;s quick</li>
<li class="L8638" rel="L8638">step was heard on the stairs, and in a moment he entered the room. All</li>
<li class="L8639" rel="L8639">Elizabeth&#39;s anger against him had been long done away; but had she still</li>
<li class="L8640" rel="L8640">felt any, it could hardly have stood its ground against the unaffected</li>
<li class="L8641" rel="L8641">cordiality with which he expressed himself on seeing her again. He</li>
<li class="L8642" rel="L8642">inquired in a friendly, though general way, after her family, and looked</li>
<li class="L8643" rel="L8643">and spoke with the same good-humoured ease that he had ever done.</li>
<li class="L8644" rel="L8644"></li>
<li class="L8645" rel="L8645">To Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner he was scarcely a less interesting personage</li>
<li class="L8646" rel="L8646">than to herself. They had long wished to see him. The whole party before</li>
<li class="L8647" rel="L8647">them, indeed, excited a lively attention. The suspicions which had just</li>
<li class="L8648" rel="L8648">arisen of Mr. Darcy and their niece directed their observation towards</li>
<li class="L8649" rel="L8649">each with an earnest though guarded inquiry; and they soon drew from</li>
<li class="L8650" rel="L8650">those inquiries the full conviction that one of them at least knew</li>
<li class="L8651" rel="L8651">what it was to love. Of the lady&#39;s sensations they remained a little</li>
<li class="L8652" rel="L8652">in doubt; but that the gentleman was overflowing with admiration was</li>
<li class="L8653" rel="L8653">evident enough.</li>
<li class="L8654" rel="L8654"></li>
<li class="L8655" rel="L8655">Elizabeth, on her side, had much to do. She wanted to ascertain the</li>
<li class="L8656" rel="L8656">feelings of each of her visitors; she wanted to compose her own, and</li>
<li class="L8657" rel="L8657">to make herself agreeable to all; and in the latter object, where she</li>
<li class="L8658" rel="L8658">feared most to fail, she was most sure of success, for those to whom she</li>
<li class="L8659" rel="L8659">endeavoured to give pleasure were prepossessed in her favour. Bingley</li>
<li class="L8660" rel="L8660">was ready, Georgiana was eager, and Darcy determined, to be pleased.</li>
<li class="L8661" rel="L8661"></li>
<li class="L8662" rel="L8662">In seeing Bingley, her thoughts naturally flew to her sister; and, oh!</li>
<li class="L8663" rel="L8663">how ardently did she long to know whether any of his were directed in</li>
<li class="L8664" rel="L8664">a like manner. Sometimes she could fancy that he talked less than on</li>
<li class="L8665" rel="L8665">former occasions, and once or twice pleased herself with the notion</li>
<li class="L8666" rel="L8666">that, as he looked at her, he was trying to trace a resemblance. But,</li>
<li class="L8667" rel="L8667">though this might be imaginary, she could not be deceived as to his</li>
<li class="L8668" rel="L8668">behaviour to Miss Darcy, who had been set up as a rival to Jane. No look</li>
<li class="L8669" rel="L8669">appeared on either side that spoke particular regard. Nothing occurred</li>
<li class="L8670" rel="L8670">between them that could justify the hopes of his sister. On this point</li>
<li class="L8671" rel="L8671">she was soon satisfied; and two or three little circumstances occurred</li>
<li class="L8672" rel="L8672">ere they parted, which, in her anxious interpretation, denoted a</li>
<li class="L8673" rel="L8673">recollection of Jane not untinctured by tenderness, and a wish of saying</li>
<li class="L8674" rel="L8674">more that might lead to the mention of her, had he dared. He observed</li>
<li class="L8675" rel="L8675">to her, at a moment when the others were talking together, and in a tone</li>
<li class="L8676" rel="L8676">which had something of real regret, that it “was a very long time since</li>
<li class="L8677" rel="L8677">he had had the pleasure of seeing her;” and, before she could reply,</li>
<li class="L8678" rel="L8678">he added, “It is above eight months. We have not met since the 26th of</li>
<li class="L8679" rel="L8679">November, when we were all dancing together at Netherfield.”</li>
<li class="L8680" rel="L8680"></li>
<li class="L8681" rel="L8681">Elizabeth was pleased to find his memory so exact; and he afterwards</li>
<li class="L8682" rel="L8682">took occasion to ask her, when unattended to by any of the rest, whether</li>
<li class="L8683" rel="L8683">_all_ her sisters were at Longbourn. There was not much in the question,</li>
<li class="L8684" rel="L8684">nor in the preceding remark; but there was a look and a manner which</li>
<li class="L8685" rel="L8685">gave them meaning.</li>
<li class="L8686" rel="L8686"></li>
<li class="L8687" rel="L8687">It was not often that she could turn her eyes on Mr. Darcy himself;</li>
<li class="L8688" rel="L8688">but, whenever she did catch a glimpse, she saw an expression of general</li>
<li class="L8689" rel="L8689">complaisance, and in all that he said she heard an accent so removed</li>
<li class="L8690" rel="L8690">from _hauteur_ or disdain of his companions, as convinced her that</li>
<li class="L8691" rel="L8691">the improvement of manners which she had yesterday witnessed however</li>
<li class="L8692" rel="L8692">temporary its existence might prove, had at least outlived one day. When</li>
<li class="L8693" rel="L8693">she saw him thus seeking the acquaintance and courting the good opinion</li>
<li class="L8694" rel="L8694">of people with whom any intercourse a few months ago would have been a</li>
<li class="L8695" rel="L8695">disgrace--when she saw him thus civil, not only to herself, but to the</li>
<li class="L8696" rel="L8696">very relations whom he had openly disdained, and recollected their last</li>
<li class="L8697" rel="L8697">lively scene in Hunsford Parsonage--the difference, the change was</li>
<li class="L8698" rel="L8698">so great, and struck so forcibly on her mind, that she could hardly</li>
<li class="L8699" rel="L8699">restrain her astonishment from being visible. Never, even in the company</li>
<li class="L8700" rel="L8700">of his dear friends at Netherfield, or his dignified relations</li>
<li class="L8701" rel="L8701">at Rosings, had she seen him so desirous to please, so free from</li>
<li class="L8702" rel="L8702">self-consequence or unbending reserve, as now, when no importance</li>
<li class="L8703" rel="L8703">could result from the success of his endeavours, and when even the</li>
<li class="L8704" rel="L8704">acquaintance of those to whom his attentions were addressed would draw</li>
<li class="L8705" rel="L8705">down the ridicule and censure of the ladies both of Netherfield and</li>
<li class="L8706" rel="L8706">Rosings.</li>
<li class="L8707" rel="L8707"></li>
<li class="L8708" rel="L8708">Their visitors stayed with them above half-an-hour; and when they arose</li>
<li class="L8709" rel="L8709">to depart, Mr. Darcy called on his sister to join him in expressing</li>
<li class="L8710" rel="L8710">their wish of seeing Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner, and Miss Bennet, to dinner</li>
<li class="L8711" rel="L8711">at Pemberley, before they left the country. Miss Darcy, though with a</li>
<li class="L8712" rel="L8712">diffidence which marked her little in the habit of giving invitations,</li>
<li class="L8713" rel="L8713">readily obeyed. Mrs. Gardiner looked at her niece, desirous of knowing</li>
<li class="L8714" rel="L8714">how _she_, whom the invitation most concerned, felt disposed as to its</li>
<li class="L8715" rel="L8715">acceptance, but Elizabeth had turned away her head. Presuming however,</li>
<li class="L8716" rel="L8716">that this studied avoidance spoke rather a momentary embarrassment than</li>
<li class="L8717" rel="L8717">any dislike of the proposal, and seeing in her husband, who was fond of</li>
<li class="L8718" rel="L8718">society, a perfect willingness to accept it, she ventured to engage for</li>
<li class="L8719" rel="L8719">her attendance, and the day after the next was fixed on.</li>
<li class="L8720" rel="L8720"></li>
<li class="L8721" rel="L8721">Bingley expressed great pleasure in the certainty of seeing Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L8722" rel="L8722">again, having still a great deal to say to her, and many inquiries to</li>
<li class="L8723" rel="L8723">make after all their Hertfordshire friends. Elizabeth, construing all</li>
<li class="L8724" rel="L8724">this into a wish of hearing her speak of her sister, was pleased, and on</li>
<li class="L8725" rel="L8725">this account, as well as some others, found herself, when their</li>
<li class="L8726" rel="L8726">visitors left them, capable of considering the last half-hour with some</li>
<li class="L8727" rel="L8727">satisfaction, though while it was passing, the enjoyment of it had been</li>
<li class="L8728" rel="L8728">little. Eager to be alone, and fearful of inquiries or hints from her</li>
<li class="L8729" rel="L8729">uncle and aunt, she stayed with them only long enough to hear their</li>
<li class="L8730" rel="L8730">favourable opinion of Bingley, and then hurried away to dress.</li>
<li class="L8731" rel="L8731"></li>
<li class="L8732" rel="L8732">But she had no reason to fear Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner&#39;s curiosity; it was</li>
<li class="L8733" rel="L8733">not their wish to force her communication. It was evident that she was</li>
<li class="L8734" rel="L8734">much better acquainted with Mr. Darcy than they had before any idea of;</li>
<li class="L8735" rel="L8735">it was evident that he was very much in love with her. They saw much to</li>
<li class="L8736" rel="L8736">interest, but nothing to justify inquiry.</li>
<li class="L8737" rel="L8737"></li>
<li class="L8738" rel="L8738">Of Mr. Darcy it was now a matter of anxiety to think well; and, as far</li>
<li class="L8739" rel="L8739">as their acquaintance reached, there was no fault to find. They could</li>
<li class="L8740" rel="L8740">not be untouched by his politeness; and had they drawn his character</li>
<li class="L8741" rel="L8741">from their own feelings and his servant&#39;s report, without any reference</li>
<li class="L8742" rel="L8742">to any other account, the circle in Hertfordshire to which he was known</li>
<li class="L8743" rel="L8743">would not have recognized it for Mr. Darcy. There was now an interest,</li>
<li class="L8744" rel="L8744">however, in believing the housekeeper; and they soon became sensible</li>
<li class="L8745" rel="L8745">that the authority of a servant who had known him since he was four</li>
<li class="L8746" rel="L8746">years old, and whose own manners indicated respectability, was not to be</li>
<li class="L8747" rel="L8747">hastily rejected. Neither had anything occurred in the intelligence of</li>
<li class="L8748" rel="L8748">their Lambton friends that could materially lessen its weight. They had</li>
<li class="L8749" rel="L8749">nothing to accuse him of but pride; pride he probably had, and if not,</li>
<li class="L8750" rel="L8750">it would certainly be imputed by the inhabitants of a small market-town</li>
<li class="L8751" rel="L8751">where the family did not visit. It was acknowledged, however, that he</li>
<li class="L8752" rel="L8752">was a liberal man, and did much good among the poor.</li>
<li class="L8753" rel="L8753"></li>
<li class="L8754" rel="L8754">With respect to Wickham, the travellers soon found that he was not held</li>
<li class="L8755" rel="L8755">there in much estimation; for though the chief of his concerns with the</li>
<li class="L8756" rel="L8756">son of his patron were imperfectly understood, it was yet a well-known</li>
<li class="L8757" rel="L8757">fact that, on his quitting Derbyshire, he had left many debts behind</li>
<li class="L8758" rel="L8758">him, which Mr. Darcy afterwards discharged.</li>
<li class="L8759" rel="L8759"></li>
<li class="L8760" rel="L8760">As for Elizabeth, her thoughts were at Pemberley this evening more than</li>
<li class="L8761" rel="L8761">the last; and the evening, though as it passed it seemed long, was not</li>
<li class="L8762" rel="L8762">long enough to determine her feelings towards _one_ in that mansion;</li>
<li class="L8763" rel="L8763">and she lay awake two whole hours endeavouring to make them out. She</li>
<li class="L8764" rel="L8764">certainly did not hate him. No; hatred had vanished long ago, and she</li>
<li class="L8765" rel="L8765">had almost as long been ashamed of ever feeling a dislike against him,</li>
<li class="L8766" rel="L8766">that could be so called. The respect created by the conviction of his</li>
<li class="L8767" rel="L8767">valuable qualities, though at first unwillingly admitted, had for some</li>
<li class="L8768" rel="L8768">time ceased to be repugnant to her feeling; and it was now heightened</li>
<li class="L8769" rel="L8769">into somewhat of a friendlier nature, by the testimony so highly in</li>
<li class="L8770" rel="L8770">his favour, and bringing forward his disposition in so amiable a light,</li>
<li class="L8771" rel="L8771">which yesterday had produced. But above all, above respect and esteem,</li>
<li class="L8772" rel="L8772">there was a motive within her of goodwill which could not be overlooked.</li>
<li class="L8773" rel="L8773">It was gratitude; gratitude, not merely for having once loved her,</li>
<li class="L8774" rel="L8774">but for loving her still well enough to forgive all the petulance and</li>
<li class="L8775" rel="L8775">acrimony of her manner in rejecting him, and all the unjust accusations</li>
<li class="L8776" rel="L8776">accompanying her rejection. He who, she had been persuaded, would avoid</li>
<li class="L8777" rel="L8777">her as his greatest enemy, seemed, on this accidental meeting, most</li>
<li class="L8778" rel="L8778">eager to preserve the acquaintance, and without any indelicate display</li>
<li class="L8779" rel="L8779">of regard, or any peculiarity of manner, where their two selves only</li>
<li class="L8780" rel="L8780">were concerned, was soliciting the good opinion of her friends, and bent</li>
<li class="L8781" rel="L8781">on making her known to his sister. Such a change in a man of so much</li>
<li class="L8782" rel="L8782">pride exciting not only astonishment but gratitude--for to love, ardent</li>
<li class="L8783" rel="L8783">love, it must be attributed; and as such its impression on her was of a</li>
<li class="L8784" rel="L8784">sort to be encouraged, as by no means unpleasing, though it could not be</li>
<li class="L8785" rel="L8785">exactly defined. She respected, she esteemed, she was grateful to him,</li>
<li class="L8786" rel="L8786">she felt a real interest in his welfare; and she only wanted to know how</li>
<li class="L8787" rel="L8787">far she wished that welfare to depend upon herself, and how far it would</li>
<li class="L8788" rel="L8788">be for the happiness of both that she should employ the power, which her</li>
<li class="L8789" rel="L8789">fancy told her she still possessed, of bringing on her the renewal of</li>
<li class="L8790" rel="L8790">his addresses.</li>
<li class="L8791" rel="L8791"></li>
<li class="L8792" rel="L8792">It had been settled in the evening between the aunt and the niece, that</li>
<li class="L8793" rel="L8793">such a striking civility as Miss Darcy&#39;s in coming to see them on the</li>
<li class="L8794" rel="L8794">very day of her arrival at Pemberley, for she had reached it only to a</li>
<li class="L8795" rel="L8795">late breakfast, ought to be imitated, though it could not be equalled,</li>
<li class="L8796" rel="L8796">by some exertion of politeness on their side; and, consequently, that</li>
<li class="L8797" rel="L8797">it would be highly expedient to wait on her at Pemberley the following</li>
<li class="L8798" rel="L8798">morning. They were, therefore, to go. Elizabeth was pleased; though when</li>
<li class="L8799" rel="L8799">she asked herself the reason, she had very little to say in reply.</li>
<li class="L8800" rel="L8800"></li>
<li class="L8801" rel="L8801">Mr. Gardiner left them soon after breakfast. The fishing scheme had been</li>
<li class="L8802" rel="L8802">renewed the day before, and a positive engagement made of his meeting</li>
<li class="L8803" rel="L8803">some of the gentlemen at Pemberley before noon.</li>
<li class="L8804" rel="L8804"></li>
<li class="L8805" rel="L8805"></li>
<li class="L8806" rel="L8806"></li>
<li class="L8807" rel="L8807">Chapter 45</li>
<li class="L8808" rel="L8808"></li>
<li class="L8809" rel="L8809"></li>
<li class="L8810" rel="L8810">Convinced as Elizabeth now was that Miss Bingley&#39;s dislike of her had</li>
<li class="L8811" rel="L8811">originated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how unwelcome her</li>
<li class="L8812" rel="L8812">appearance at Pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know with how</li>
<li class="L8813" rel="L8813">much civility on that lady&#39;s side the acquaintance would now be renewed.</li>
<li class="L8814" rel="L8814"></li>
<li class="L8815" rel="L8815">On reaching the house, they were shown through the hall into the saloon,</li>
<li class="L8816" rel="L8816">whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer. Its windows</li>
<li class="L8817" rel="L8817">opening to the ground, admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody</li>
<li class="L8818" rel="L8818">hills behind the house, and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts</li>
<li class="L8819" rel="L8819">which were scattered over the intermediate lawn.</li>
<li class="L8820" rel="L8820"></li>
<li class="L8821" rel="L8821">In this house they were received by Miss Darcy, who was sitting there</li>
<li class="L8822" rel="L8822">with Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in</li>
<li class="L8823" rel="L8823">London. Georgiana&#39;s reception of them was very civil, but attended with</li>
<li class="L8824" rel="L8824">all the embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the fear</li>
<li class="L8825" rel="L8825">of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves inferior</li>
<li class="L8826" rel="L8826">the belief of her being proud and reserved. Mrs. Gardiner and her niece,</li>
<li class="L8827" rel="L8827">however, did her justice, and pitied her.</li>
<li class="L8828" rel="L8828"></li>
<li class="L8829" rel="L8829">By Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley they were noticed only by a curtsey; and,</li>
<li class="L8830" rel="L8830">on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be,</li>
<li class="L8831" rel="L8831">succeeded for a few moments. It was first broken by Mrs. Annesley, a</li>
<li class="L8832" rel="L8832">genteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind</li>
<li class="L8833" rel="L8833">of discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the</li>
<li class="L8834" rel="L8834">others; and between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from</li>
<li class="L8835" rel="L8835">Elizabeth, the conversation was carried on. Miss Darcy looked as if she</li>
<li class="L8836" rel="L8836">wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a</li>
<li class="L8837" rel="L8837">short sentence when there was least danger of its being heard.</li>
<li class="L8838" rel="L8838"></li>
<li class="L8839" rel="L8839">Elizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by Miss Bingley,</li>
<li class="L8840" rel="L8840">and that she could not speak a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without</li>
<li class="L8841" rel="L8841">calling her attention. This observation would not have prevented her</li>
<li class="L8842" rel="L8842">from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an</li>
<li class="L8843" rel="L8843">inconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity</li>
<li class="L8844" rel="L8844">of saying much. Her own thoughts were employing her. She expected every</li>
<li class="L8845" rel="L8845">moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room. She wished, she</li>
<li class="L8846" rel="L8846">feared that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether</li>
<li class="L8847" rel="L8847">she wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine. After</li>
<li class="L8848" rel="L8848">sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour without hearing Miss</li>
<li class="L8849" rel="L8849">Bingley&#39;s voice, Elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold</li>
<li class="L8850" rel="L8850">inquiry after the health of her family. She answered with equal</li>
<li class="L8851" rel="L8851">indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.</li>
<li class="L8852" rel="L8852"></li>
<li class="L8853" rel="L8853">The next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the</li>
<li class="L8854" rel="L8854">entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the</li>
<li class="L8855" rel="L8855">finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many</li>
<li class="L8856" rel="L8856">a significant look and smile from Mrs. Annesley to Miss Darcy had been</li>
<li class="L8857" rel="L8857">given, to remind her of her post. There was now employment for the whole</li>
<li class="L8858" rel="L8858">party--for though they could not all talk, they could all eat; and the</li>
<li class="L8859" rel="L8859">beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches soon collected</li>
<li class="L8860" rel="L8860">them round the table.</li>
<li class="L8861" rel="L8861"></li>
<li class="L8862" rel="L8862">While thus engaged, Elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether</li>
<li class="L8863" rel="L8863">she most feared or wished for the appearance of Mr. Darcy, by the</li>
<li class="L8864" rel="L8864">feelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but</li>
<li class="L8865" rel="L8865">a moment before she had believed her wishes to predominate, she began to</li>
<li class="L8866" rel="L8866">regret that he came.</li>
<li class="L8867" rel="L8867"></li>
<li class="L8868" rel="L8868">He had been some time with Mr. Gardiner, who, with two or three other</li>
<li class="L8869" rel="L8869">gentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river, and had left him</li>
<li class="L8870" rel="L8870">only on learning that the ladies of the family intended a visit to</li>
<li class="L8871" rel="L8871">Georgiana that morning. No sooner did he appear than Elizabeth wisely</li>
<li class="L8872" rel="L8872">resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed; a resolution the more</li>
<li class="L8873" rel="L8873">necessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because she</li>
<li class="L8874" rel="L8874">saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them,</li>
<li class="L8875" rel="L8875">and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour</li>
<li class="L8876" rel="L8876">when he first came into the room. In no countenance was attentive</li>
<li class="L8877" rel="L8877">curiosity so strongly marked as in Miss Bingley&#39;s, in spite of the</li>
<li class="L8878" rel="L8878">smiles which overspread her face whenever she spoke to one of its</li>
<li class="L8879" rel="L8879">objects; for jealousy had not yet made her desperate, and her attentions</li>
<li class="L8880" rel="L8880">to Mr. Darcy were by no means over. Miss Darcy, on her brother&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8881" rel="L8881">entrance, exerted herself much more to talk, and Elizabeth saw that he</li>
<li class="L8882" rel="L8882">was anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded</li>
<li class="L8883" rel="L8883">as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side. Miss</li>
<li class="L8884" rel="L8884">Bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the</li>
<li class="L8885" rel="L8885">first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility:</li>
<li class="L8886" rel="L8886"></li>
<li class="L8887" rel="L8887">“Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ----shire Militia removed from Meryton?</li>
<li class="L8888" rel="L8888">They must be a great loss to _your_ family.”</li>
<li class="L8889" rel="L8889"></li>
<li class="L8890" rel="L8890">In Darcy&#39;s presence she dared not mention Wickham&#39;s name; but Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L8891" rel="L8891">instantly comprehended that he was uppermost in her thoughts; and the</li>
<li class="L8892" rel="L8892">various recollections connected with him gave her a moment&#39;s distress;</li>
<li class="L8893" rel="L8893">but exerting herself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, she</li>
<li class="L8894" rel="L8894">presently answered the question in a tolerably detached tone. While</li>
<li class="L8895" rel="L8895">she spoke, an involuntary glance showed her Darcy, with a heightened</li>
<li class="L8896" rel="L8896">complexion, earnestly looking at her, and his sister overcome with</li>
<li class="L8897" rel="L8897">confusion, and unable to lift up her eyes. Had Miss Bingley known what</li>
<li class="L8898" rel="L8898">pain she was then giving her beloved friend, she undoubtedly would</li>
<li class="L8899" rel="L8899">have refrained from the hint; but she had merely intended to discompose</li>
<li class="L8900" rel="L8900">Elizabeth by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom she believed</li>
<li class="L8901" rel="L8901">her partial, to make her betray a sensibility which might injure her in</li>
<li class="L8902" rel="L8902">Darcy&#39;s opinion, and, perhaps, to remind the latter of all the follies</li>
<li class="L8903" rel="L8903">and absurdities by which some part of her family were connected</li>
<li class="L8904" rel="L8904">with that corps. Not a syllable had ever reached her of Miss Darcy&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8905" rel="L8905">meditated elopement. To no creature had it been revealed, where secrecy</li>
<li class="L8906" rel="L8906">was possible, except to Elizabeth; and from all Bingley&#39;s connections</li>
<li class="L8907" rel="L8907">her brother was particularly anxious to conceal it, from the very</li>
<li class="L8908" rel="L8908">wish which Elizabeth had long ago attributed to him, of their becoming</li>
<li class="L8909" rel="L8909">hereafter her own. He had certainly formed such a plan, and without</li>
<li class="L8910" rel="L8910">meaning that it should affect his endeavour to separate him from Miss</li>
<li class="L8911" rel="L8911">Bennet, it is probable that it might add something to his lively concern</li>
<li class="L8912" rel="L8912">for the welfare of his friend.</li>
<li class="L8913" rel="L8913"></li>
<li class="L8914" rel="L8914">Elizabeth&#39;s collected behaviour, however, soon quieted his emotion; and</li>
<li class="L8915" rel="L8915">as Miss Bingley, vexed and disappointed, dared not approach nearer to</li>
<li class="L8916" rel="L8916">Wickham, Georgiana also recovered in time, though not enough to be able</li>
<li class="L8917" rel="L8917">to speak any more. Her brother, whose eye she feared to meet, scarcely</li>
<li class="L8918" rel="L8918">recollected her interest in the affair, and the very circumstance which</li>
<li class="L8919" rel="L8919">had been designed to turn his thoughts from Elizabeth seemed to have</li>
<li class="L8920" rel="L8920">fixed them on her more and more cheerfully.</li>
<li class="L8921" rel="L8921"></li>
<li class="L8922" rel="L8922">Their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above</li>
<li class="L8923" rel="L8923">mentioned; and while Mr. Darcy was attending them to their carriage Miss</li>
<li class="L8924" rel="L8924">Bingley was venting her feelings in criticisms on Elizabeth&#39;s person,</li>
<li class="L8925" rel="L8925">behaviour, and dress. But Georgiana would not join her. Her brother&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8926" rel="L8926">recommendation was enough to ensure her favour; his judgement could not</li>
<li class="L8927" rel="L8927">err. And he had spoken in such terms of Elizabeth as to leave Georgiana</li>
<li class="L8928" rel="L8928">without the power of finding her otherwise than lovely and amiable. When</li>
<li class="L8929" rel="L8929">Darcy returned to the saloon, Miss Bingley could not help repeating to</li>
<li class="L8930" rel="L8930">him some part of what she had been saying to his sister.</li>
<li class="L8931" rel="L8931"></li>
<li class="L8932" rel="L8932">“How very ill Miss Eliza Bennet looks this morning, Mr. Darcy,” she</li>
<li class="L8933" rel="L8933">cried; “I never in my life saw anyone so much altered as she is since</li>
<li class="L8934" rel="L8934">the winter. She is grown so brown and coarse! Louisa and I were agreeing</li>
<li class="L8935" rel="L8935">that we should not have known her again.”</li>
<li class="L8936" rel="L8936"></li>
<li class="L8937" rel="L8937">However little Mr. Darcy might have liked such an address, he contented</li>
<li class="L8938" rel="L8938">himself with coolly replying that he perceived no other alteration than</li>
<li class="L8939" rel="L8939">her being rather tanned, no miraculous consequence of travelling in the</li>
<li class="L8940" rel="L8940">summer.</li>
<li class="L8941" rel="L8941"></li>
<li class="L8942" rel="L8942">“For my own part,” she rejoined, “I must confess that I never could</li>
<li class="L8943" rel="L8943">see any beauty in her. Her face is too thin; her complexion has no</li>
<li class="L8944" rel="L8944">brilliancy; and her features are not at all handsome. Her nose</li>
<li class="L8945" rel="L8945">wants character--there is nothing marked in its lines. Her teeth are</li>
<li class="L8946" rel="L8946">tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes,</li>
<li class="L8947" rel="L8947">which have sometimes been called so fine, I could never see anything</li>
<li class="L8948" rel="L8948">extraordinary in them. They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do</li>
<li class="L8949" rel="L8949">not like at all; and in her air altogether there is a self-sufficiency</li>
<li class="L8950" rel="L8950">without fashion, which is intolerable.”</li>
<li class="L8951" rel="L8951"></li>
<li class="L8952" rel="L8952">Persuaded as Miss Bingley was that Darcy admired Elizabeth, this was not</li>
<li class="L8953" rel="L8953">the best method of recommending herself; but angry people are not always</li>
<li class="L8954" rel="L8954">wise; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, she had all the</li>
<li class="L8955" rel="L8955">success she expected. He was resolutely silent, however, and, from a</li>
<li class="L8956" rel="L8956">determination of making him speak, she continued:</li>
<li class="L8957" rel="L8957"></li>
<li class="L8958" rel="L8958">“I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all</li>
<li class="L8959" rel="L8959">were to find that she was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect</li>
<li class="L8960" rel="L8960">your saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield, &#39;_She_</li>
<li class="L8961" rel="L8961">a beauty!--I should as soon call her mother a wit.&#39; But afterwards she</li>
<li class="L8962" rel="L8962">seemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought her rather pretty at</li>
<li class="L8963" rel="L8963">one time.”</li>
<li class="L8964" rel="L8964"></li>
<li class="L8965" rel="L8965">“Yes,” replied Darcy, who could contain himself no longer, “but _that_</li>
<li class="L8966" rel="L8966">was only when I first saw her, for it is many months since I have</li>
<li class="L8967" rel="L8967">considered her as one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance.”</li>
<li class="L8968" rel="L8968"></li>
<li class="L8969" rel="L8969">He then went away, and Miss Bingley was left to all the satisfaction of</li>
<li class="L8970" rel="L8970">having forced him to say what gave no one any pain but herself.</li>
<li class="L8971" rel="L8971"></li>
<li class="L8972" rel="L8972">Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth talked of all that had occurred during their</li>
<li class="L8973" rel="L8973">visit, as they returned, except what had particularly interested them</li>
<li class="L8974" rel="L8974">both. The look and behaviour of everybody they had seen were discussed,</li>
<li class="L8975" rel="L8975">except of the person who had mostly engaged their attention. They talked</li>
<li class="L8976" rel="L8976">of his sister, his friends, his house, his fruit--of everything but</li>
<li class="L8977" rel="L8977">himself; yet Elizabeth was longing to know what Mrs. Gardiner thought of</li>
<li class="L8978" rel="L8978">him, and Mrs. Gardiner would have been highly gratified by her niece&#39;s</li>
<li class="L8979" rel="L8979">beginning the subject.</li>
<li class="L8980" rel="L8980"></li>
<li class="L8981" rel="L8981"></li>
<li class="L8982" rel="L8982"></li>
<li class="L8983" rel="L8983">Chapter 46</li>
<li class="L8984" rel="L8984"></li>
<li class="L8985" rel="L8985"></li>
<li class="L8986" rel="L8986">Elizabeth had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from</li>
<li class="L8987" rel="L8987">Jane on their first arrival at Lambton; and this disappointment had been</li>
<li class="L8988" rel="L8988">renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent there; but</li>
<li class="L8989" rel="L8989">on the third her repining was over, and her sister justified, by the</li>
<li class="L8990" rel="L8990">receipt of two letters from her at once, on one of which was marked that</li>
<li class="L8991" rel="L8991">it had been missent elsewhere. Elizabeth was not surprised at it, as</li>
<li class="L8992" rel="L8992">Jane had written the direction remarkably ill.</li>
<li class="L8993" rel="L8993"></li>
<li class="L8994" rel="L8994">They had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and</li>
<li class="L8995" rel="L8995">her uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by</li>
<li class="L8996" rel="L8996">themselves. The one missent must first be attended to; it had been</li>
<li class="L8997" rel="L8997">written five days ago. The beginning contained an account of all their</li>
<li class="L8998" rel="L8998">little parties and engagements, with such news as the country afforded;</li>
<li class="L8999" rel="L8999">but the latter half, which was dated a day later, and written in evident</li>
<li class="L9000" rel="L9000">agitation, gave more important intelligence. It was to this effect:</li>
<li class="L9001" rel="L9001"></li>
<li class="L9002" rel="L9002">“Since writing the above, dearest Lizzy, something has occurred of a</li>
<li class="L9003" rel="L9003">most unexpected and serious nature; but I am afraid of alarming you--be</li>
<li class="L9004" rel="L9004">assured that we are all well. What I have to say relates to poor Lydia.</li>
<li class="L9005" rel="L9005">An express came at twelve last night, just as we were all gone to bed,</li>
<li class="L9006" rel="L9006">from Colonel Forster, to inform us that she was gone off to Scotland</li>
<li class="L9007" rel="L9007">with one of his officers; to own the truth, with Wickham! Imagine our</li>
<li class="L9008" rel="L9008">surprise. To Kitty, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected. I am</li>
<li class="L9009" rel="L9009">very, very sorry. So imprudent a match on both sides! But I am willing</li>
<li class="L9010" rel="L9010">to hope the best, and that his character has been misunderstood.</li>
<li class="L9011" rel="L9011">Thoughtless and indiscreet I can easily believe him, but this step</li>
<li class="L9012" rel="L9012">(and let us rejoice over it) marks nothing bad at heart. His choice is</li>
<li class="L9013" rel="L9013">disinterested at least, for he must know my father can give her nothing.</li>
<li class="L9014" rel="L9014">Our poor mother is sadly grieved. My father bears it better. How</li>
<li class="L9015" rel="L9015">thankful am I that we never let them know what has been said against</li>
<li class="L9016" rel="L9016">him; we must forget it ourselves. They were off Saturday night about</li>
<li class="L9017" rel="L9017">twelve, as is conjectured, but were not missed till yesterday morning at</li>
<li class="L9018" rel="L9018">eight. The express was sent off directly. My dear Lizzy, they must have</li>
<li class="L9019" rel="L9019">passed within ten miles of us. Colonel Forster gives us reason to expect</li>
<li class="L9020" rel="L9020">him here soon. Lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of</li>
<li class="L9021" rel="L9021">their intention. I must conclude, for I cannot be long from my poor</li>
<li class="L9022" rel="L9022">mother. I am afraid you will not be able to make it out, but I hardly</li>
<li class="L9023" rel="L9023">know what I have written.”</li>
<li class="L9024" rel="L9024"></li>
<li class="L9025" rel="L9025">Without allowing herself time for consideration, and scarcely knowing</li>
<li class="L9026" rel="L9026">what she felt, Elizabeth on finishing this letter instantly seized the</li>
<li class="L9027" rel="L9027">other, and opening it with the utmost impatience, read as follows: it</li>
<li class="L9028" rel="L9028">had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first.</li>
<li class="L9029" rel="L9029"></li>
<li class="L9030" rel="L9030">“By this time, my dearest sister, you have received my hurried letter; I</li>
<li class="L9031" rel="L9031">wish this may be more intelligible, but though not confined for time, my</li>
<li class="L9032" rel="L9032">head is so bewildered that I cannot answer for being coherent. Dearest</li>
<li class="L9033" rel="L9033">Lizzy, I hardly know what I would write, but I have bad news for you,</li>
<li class="L9034" rel="L9034">and it cannot be delayed. Imprudent as the marriage between Mr. Wickham</li>
<li class="L9035" rel="L9035">and our poor Lydia would be, we are now anxious to be assured it has</li>
<li class="L9036" rel="L9036">taken place, for there is but too much reason to fear they are not gone</li>
<li class="L9037" rel="L9037">to Scotland. Colonel Forster came yesterday, having left Brighton the</li>
<li class="L9038" rel="L9038">day before, not many hours after the express. Though Lydia&#39;s short</li>
<li class="L9039" rel="L9039">letter to Mrs. F. gave them to understand that they were going to Gretna</li>
<li class="L9040" rel="L9040">Green, something was dropped by Denny expressing his belief that W.</li>
<li class="L9041" rel="L9041">never intended to go there, or to marry Lydia at all, which was</li>
<li class="L9042" rel="L9042">repeated to Colonel F., who, instantly taking the alarm, set off from B.</li>
<li class="L9043" rel="L9043">intending to trace their route. He did trace them easily to Clapham,</li>
<li class="L9044" rel="L9044">but no further; for on entering that place, they removed into a hackney</li>
<li class="L9045" rel="L9045">coach, and dismissed the chaise that brought them from Epsom. All that</li>
<li class="L9046" rel="L9046">is known after this is, that they were seen to continue the London road.</li>
<li class="L9047" rel="L9047">I know not what to think. After making every possible inquiry on that</li>
<li class="L9048" rel="L9048">side London, Colonel F. came on into Hertfordshire, anxiously renewing</li>
<li class="L9049" rel="L9049">them at all the turnpikes, and at the inns in Barnet and Hatfield, but</li>
<li class="L9050" rel="L9050">without any success--no such people had been seen to pass through. With</li>
<li class="L9051" rel="L9051">the kindest concern he came on to Longbourn, and broke his apprehensions</li>
<li class="L9052" rel="L9052">to us in a manner most creditable to his heart. I am sincerely grieved</li>
<li class="L9053" rel="L9053">for him and Mrs. F., but no one can throw any blame on them. Our</li>
<li class="L9054" rel="L9054">distress, my dear Lizzy, is very great. My father and mother believe the</li>
<li class="L9055" rel="L9055">worst, but I cannot think so ill of him. Many circumstances might make</li>
<li class="L9056" rel="L9056">it more eligible for them to be married privately in town than to pursue</li>
<li class="L9057" rel="L9057">their first plan; and even if _he_ could form such a design against a</li>
<li class="L9058" rel="L9058">young woman of Lydia&#39;s connections, which is not likely, can I suppose</li>
<li class="L9059" rel="L9059">her so lost to everything? Impossible! I grieve to find, however, that</li>
<li class="L9060" rel="L9060">Colonel F. is not disposed to depend upon their marriage; he shook his</li>
<li class="L9061" rel="L9061">head when I expressed my hopes, and said he feared W. was not a man to</li>
<li class="L9062" rel="L9062">be trusted. My poor mother is really ill, and keeps her room. Could she</li>
<li class="L9063" rel="L9063">exert herself, it would be better; but this is not to be expected. And</li>
<li class="L9064" rel="L9064">as to my father, I never in my life saw him so affected. Poor Kitty has</li>
<li class="L9065" rel="L9065">anger for having concealed their attachment; but as it was a matter of</li>
<li class="L9066" rel="L9066">confidence, one cannot wonder. I am truly glad, dearest Lizzy, that you</li>
<li class="L9067" rel="L9067">have been spared something of these distressing scenes; but now, as the</li>
<li class="L9068" rel="L9068">first shock is over, shall I own that I long for your return? I am not</li>
<li class="L9069" rel="L9069">so selfish, however, as to press for it, if inconvenient. Adieu! I</li>
<li class="L9070" rel="L9070">take up my pen again to do what I have just told you I would not; but</li>
<li class="L9071" rel="L9071">circumstances are such that I cannot help earnestly begging you all to</li>
<li class="L9072" rel="L9072">come here as soon as possible. I know my dear uncle and aunt so well,</li>
<li class="L9073" rel="L9073">that I am not afraid of requesting it, though I have still something</li>
<li class="L9074" rel="L9074">more to ask of the former. My father is going to London with Colonel</li>
<li class="L9075" rel="L9075">Forster instantly, to try to discover her. What he means to do I am sure</li>
<li class="L9076" rel="L9076">I know not; but his excessive distress will not allow him to pursue any</li>
<li class="L9077" rel="L9077">measure in the best and safest way, and Colonel Forster is obliged to</li>
<li class="L9078" rel="L9078">be at Brighton again to-morrow evening. In such an exigence, my</li>
<li class="L9079" rel="L9079">uncle&#39;s advice and assistance would be everything in the world; he will</li>
<li class="L9080" rel="L9080">immediately comprehend what I must feel, and I rely upon his goodness.”</li>
<li class="L9081" rel="L9081"></li>
<li class="L9082" rel="L9082">“Oh! where, where is my uncle?” cried Elizabeth, darting from her seat</li>
<li class="L9083" rel="L9083">as she finished the letter, in eagerness to follow him, without losing</li>
<li class="L9084" rel="L9084">a moment of the time so precious; but as she reached the door it was</li>
<li class="L9085" rel="L9085">opened by a servant, and Mr. Darcy appeared. Her pale face and impetuous</li>
<li class="L9086" rel="L9086">manner made him start, and before he could recover himself to speak,</li>
<li class="L9087" rel="L9087">she, in whose mind every idea was superseded by Lydia&#39;s situation,</li>
<li class="L9088" rel="L9088">hastily exclaimed, “I beg your pardon, but I must leave you. I must find</li>
<li class="L9089" rel="L9089">Mr. Gardiner this moment, on business that cannot be delayed; I have not</li>
<li class="L9090" rel="L9090">an instant to lose.”</li>
<li class="L9091" rel="L9091"></li>
<li class="L9092" rel="L9092">“Good God! what is the matter?” cried he, with more feeling than</li>
<li class="L9093" rel="L9093">politeness; then recollecting himself, “I will not detain you a minute;</li>
<li class="L9094" rel="L9094">but let me, or let the servant go after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner. You are</li>
<li class="L9095" rel="L9095">not well enough; you cannot go yourself.”</li>
<li class="L9096" rel="L9096"></li>
<li class="L9097" rel="L9097">Elizabeth hesitated, but her knees trembled under her and she felt how</li>
<li class="L9098" rel="L9098">little would be gained by her attempting to pursue them. Calling back</li>
<li class="L9099" rel="L9099">the servant, therefore, she commissioned him, though in so breathless</li>
<li class="L9100" rel="L9100">an accent as made her almost unintelligible, to fetch his master and</li>
<li class="L9101" rel="L9101">mistress home instantly.</li>
<li class="L9102" rel="L9102"></li>
<li class="L9103" rel="L9103">On his quitting the room she sat down, unable to support herself, and</li>
<li class="L9104" rel="L9104">looking so miserably ill, that it was impossible for Darcy to leave her,</li>
<li class="L9105" rel="L9105">or to refrain from saying, in a tone of gentleness and commiseration,</li>
<li class="L9106" rel="L9106">“Let me call your maid. Is there nothing you could take to give you</li>
