<li class="L9107" rel="L9107">present relief? A glass of wine; shall I get you one? You are very ill.”</li>
<li class="L9108" rel="L9108"></li>
<li class="L9109" rel="L9109">“No, I thank you,” she replied, endeavouring to recover herself. “There</li>
<li class="L9110" rel="L9110">is nothing the matter with me. I am quite well; I am only distressed by</li>
<li class="L9111" rel="L9111">some dreadful news which I have just received from Longbourn.”</li>
<li class="L9112" rel="L9112"></li>
<li class="L9113" rel="L9113">She burst into tears as she alluded to it, and for a few minutes could</li>
<li class="L9114" rel="L9114">not speak another word. Darcy, in wretched suspense, could only say</li>
<li class="L9115" rel="L9115">something indistinctly of his concern, and observe her in compassionate</li>
<li class="L9116" rel="L9116">silence. At length she spoke again. “I have just had a letter from Jane,</li>
<li class="L9117" rel="L9117">with such dreadful news. It cannot be concealed from anyone. My younger</li>
<li class="L9118" rel="L9118">sister has left all her friends--has eloped; has thrown herself into</li>
<li class="L9119" rel="L9119">the power of--of Mr. Wickham. They are gone off together from Brighton.</li>
<li class="L9120" rel="L9120">_You_ know him too well to doubt the rest. She has no money, no</li>
<li class="L9121" rel="L9121">connections, nothing that can tempt him to--she is lost for ever.”</li>
<li class="L9122" rel="L9122"></li>
<li class="L9123" rel="L9123">Darcy was fixed in astonishment. “When I consider,” she added in a yet</li>
<li class="L9124" rel="L9124">more agitated voice, “that I might have prevented it! I, who knew what</li>
<li class="L9125" rel="L9125">he was. Had I but explained some part of it only--some part of what I</li>
<li class="L9126" rel="L9126">learnt, to my own family! Had his character been known, this could not</li>
<li class="L9127" rel="L9127">have happened. But it is all--all too late now.”</li>
<li class="L9128" rel="L9128"></li>
<li class="L9129" rel="L9129">“I am grieved indeed,” cried Darcy; “grieved--shocked. But is it</li>
<li class="L9130" rel="L9130">certain--absolutely certain?”</li>
<li class="L9131" rel="L9131"></li>
<li class="L9132" rel="L9132">“Oh, yes! They left Brighton together on Sunday night, and were traced</li>
<li class="L9133" rel="L9133">almost to London, but not beyond; they are certainly not gone to</li>
<li class="L9134" rel="L9134">Scotland.”</li>
<li class="L9135" rel="L9135"></li>
<li class="L9136" rel="L9136">“And what has been done, what has been attempted, to recover her?”</li>
<li class="L9137" rel="L9137"></li>
<li class="L9138" rel="L9138">“My father is gone to London, and Jane has written to beg my uncle&#39;s</li>
<li class="L9139" rel="L9139">immediate assistance; and we shall be off, I hope, in half-an-hour. But</li>
<li class="L9140" rel="L9140">nothing can be done--I know very well that nothing can be done. How is</li>
<li class="L9141" rel="L9141">such a man to be worked on? How are they even to be discovered? I have</li>
<li class="L9142" rel="L9142">not the smallest hope. It is every way horrible!”</li>
<li class="L9143" rel="L9143"></li>
<li class="L9144" rel="L9144">Darcy shook his head in silent acquiescence.</li>
<li class="L9145" rel="L9145"></li>
<li class="L9146" rel="L9146">“When _my_ eyes were opened to his real character--Oh! had I known what</li>
<li class="L9147" rel="L9147">I ought, what I dared to do! But I knew not--I was afraid of doing too</li>
<li class="L9148" rel="L9148">much. Wretched, wretched mistake!”</li>
<li class="L9149" rel="L9149"></li>
<li class="L9150" rel="L9150">Darcy made no answer. He seemed scarcely to hear her, and was walking</li>
<li class="L9151" rel="L9151">up and down the room in earnest meditation, his brow contracted, his air</li>
<li class="L9152" rel="L9152">gloomy. Elizabeth soon observed, and instantly understood it. Her</li>
<li class="L9153" rel="L9153">power was sinking; everything _must_ sink under such a proof of family</li>
<li class="L9154" rel="L9154">weakness, such an assurance of the deepest disgrace. She could neither</li>
<li class="L9155" rel="L9155">wonder nor condemn, but the belief of his self-conquest brought nothing</li>
<li class="L9156" rel="L9156">consolatory to her bosom, afforded no palliation of her distress. It</li>
<li class="L9157" rel="L9157">was, on the contrary, exactly calculated to make her understand her own</li>
<li class="L9158" rel="L9158">wishes; and never had she so honestly felt that she could have loved</li>
<li class="L9159" rel="L9159">him, as now, when all love must be vain.</li>
<li class="L9160" rel="L9160"></li>
<li class="L9161" rel="L9161">But self, though it would intrude, could not engross her. Lydia--the</li>
<li class="L9162" rel="L9162">humiliation, the misery she was bringing on them all, soon swallowed</li>
<li class="L9163" rel="L9163">up every private care; and covering her face with her handkerchief,</li>
<li class="L9164" rel="L9164">Elizabeth was soon lost to everything else; and, after a pause of</li>
<li class="L9165" rel="L9165">several minutes, was only recalled to a sense of her situation by</li>
<li class="L9166" rel="L9166">the voice of her companion, who, in a manner which, though it spoke</li>
<li class="L9167" rel="L9167">compassion, spoke likewise restraint, said, “I am afraid you have been</li>
<li class="L9168" rel="L9168">long desiring my absence, nor have I anything to plead in excuse of my</li>
<li class="L9169" rel="L9169">stay, but real, though unavailing concern. Would to Heaven that anything</li>
<li class="L9170" rel="L9170">could be either said or done on my part that might offer consolation to</li>
<li class="L9171" rel="L9171">such distress! But I will not torment you with vain wishes, which may</li>
<li class="L9172" rel="L9172">seem purposely to ask for your thanks. This unfortunate affair will, I</li>
<li class="L9173" rel="L9173">fear, prevent my sister&#39;s having the pleasure of seeing you at Pemberley</li>
<li class="L9174" rel="L9174">to-day.”</li>
<li class="L9175" rel="L9175"></li>
<li class="L9176" rel="L9176">“Oh, yes. Be so kind as to apologise for us to Miss Darcy. Say that</li>
<li class="L9177" rel="L9177">urgent business calls us home immediately. Conceal the unhappy truth as</li>
<li class="L9178" rel="L9178">long as it is possible, I know it cannot be long.”</li>
<li class="L9179" rel="L9179"></li>
<li class="L9180" rel="L9180">He readily assured her of his secrecy; again expressed his sorrow for</li>
<li class="L9181" rel="L9181">her distress, wished it a happier conclusion than there was at present</li>
<li class="L9182" rel="L9182">reason to hope, and leaving his compliments for her relations, with only</li>
<li class="L9183" rel="L9183">one serious, parting look, went away.</li>
<li class="L9184" rel="L9184"></li>
<li class="L9185" rel="L9185">As he quitted the room, Elizabeth felt how improbable it was that they</li>
<li class="L9186" rel="L9186">should ever see each other again on such terms of cordiality as</li>
<li class="L9187" rel="L9187">had marked their several meetings in Derbyshire; and as she threw a</li>
<li class="L9188" rel="L9188">retrospective glance over the whole of their acquaintance, so full</li>
<li class="L9189" rel="L9189">of contradictions and varieties, sighed at the perverseness of those</li>
<li class="L9190" rel="L9190">feelings which would now have promoted its continuance, and would</li>
<li class="L9191" rel="L9191">formerly have rejoiced in its termination.</li>
<li class="L9192" rel="L9192"></li>
<li class="L9193" rel="L9193">If gratitude and esteem are good foundations of affection, Elizabeth&#39;s</li>
<li class="L9194" rel="L9194">change of sentiment will be neither improbable nor faulty. But if</li>
<li class="L9195" rel="L9195">otherwise--if regard springing from such sources is unreasonable or</li>
<li class="L9196" rel="L9196">unnatural, in comparison of what is so often described as arising on</li>
<li class="L9197" rel="L9197">a first interview with its object, and even before two words have been</li>
<li class="L9198" rel="L9198">exchanged, nothing can be said in her defence, except that she had given</li>
<li class="L9199" rel="L9199">somewhat of a trial to the latter method in her partiality for Wickham,</li>
<li class="L9200" rel="L9200">and that its ill success might, perhaps, authorise her to seek the other</li>
<li class="L9201" rel="L9201">less interesting mode of attachment. Be that as it may, she saw him</li>
<li class="L9202" rel="L9202">go with regret; and in this early example of what Lydia&#39;s infamy must</li>
<li class="L9203" rel="L9203">produce, found additional anguish as she reflected on that wretched</li>
<li class="L9204" rel="L9204">business. Never, since reading Jane&#39;s second letter, had she entertained</li>
<li class="L9205" rel="L9205">a hope of Wickham&#39;s meaning to marry her. No one but Jane, she thought,</li>
<li class="L9206" rel="L9206">could flatter herself with such an expectation. Surprise was the least</li>
<li class="L9207" rel="L9207">of her feelings on this development. While the contents of the first</li>
<li class="L9208" rel="L9208">letter remained in her mind, she was all surprise--all astonishment that</li>
<li class="L9209" rel="L9209">Wickham should marry a girl whom it was impossible he could marry</li>
<li class="L9210" rel="L9210">for money; and how Lydia could ever have attached him had appeared</li>
<li class="L9211" rel="L9211">incomprehensible. But now it was all too natural. For such an attachment</li>
<li class="L9212" rel="L9212">as this she might have sufficient charms; and though she did not suppose</li>
<li class="L9213" rel="L9213">Lydia to be deliberately engaging in an elopement without the intention</li>
<li class="L9214" rel="L9214">of marriage, she had no difficulty in believing that neither her virtue</li>
<li class="L9215" rel="L9215">nor her understanding would preserve her from falling an easy prey.</li>
<li class="L9216" rel="L9216"></li>
<li class="L9217" rel="L9217">She had never perceived, while the regiment was in Hertfordshire, that</li>
<li class="L9218" rel="L9218">Lydia had any partiality for him; but she was convinced that Lydia</li>
<li class="L9219" rel="L9219">wanted only encouragement to attach herself to anybody. Sometimes one</li>
<li class="L9220" rel="L9220">officer, sometimes another, had been her favourite, as their attentions</li>
<li class="L9221" rel="L9221">raised them in her opinion. Her affections had continually been</li>
<li class="L9222" rel="L9222">fluctuating but never without an object. The mischief of neglect and</li>
<li class="L9223" rel="L9223">mistaken indulgence towards such a girl--oh! how acutely did she now</li>
<li class="L9224" rel="L9224">feel it!</li>
<li class="L9225" rel="L9225"></li>
<li class="L9226" rel="L9226">She was wild to be at home--to hear, to see, to be upon the spot to</li>
<li class="L9227" rel="L9227">share with Jane in the cares that must now fall wholly upon her, in a</li>
<li class="L9228" rel="L9228">family so deranged, a father absent, a mother incapable of exertion, and</li>
<li class="L9229" rel="L9229">requiring constant attendance; and though almost persuaded that nothing</li>
<li class="L9230" rel="L9230">could be done for Lydia, her uncle&#39;s interference seemed of the utmost</li>
<li class="L9231" rel="L9231">importance, and till he entered the room her impatience was severe. Mr.</li>
<li class="L9232" rel="L9232">and Mrs. Gardiner had hurried back in alarm, supposing by the servant&#39;s</li>
<li class="L9233" rel="L9233">account that their niece was taken suddenly ill; but satisfying them</li>
<li class="L9234" rel="L9234">instantly on that head, she eagerly communicated the cause of their</li>
<li class="L9235" rel="L9235">summons, reading the two letters aloud, and dwelling on the postscript</li>
<li class="L9236" rel="L9236">of the last with trembling energy.--Though Lydia had never been a</li>
<li class="L9237" rel="L9237">favourite with them, Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner could not but be deeply</li>
<li class="L9238" rel="L9238">afflicted. Not Lydia only, but all were concerned in it; and after the</li>
<li class="L9239" rel="L9239">first exclamations of surprise and horror, Mr. Gardiner promised every</li>
<li class="L9240" rel="L9240">assistance in his power. Elizabeth, though expecting no less, thanked</li>
<li class="L9241" rel="L9241">him with tears of gratitude; and all three being actuated by one spirit,</li>
<li class="L9242" rel="L9242">everything relating to their journey was speedily settled. They were to</li>
<li class="L9243" rel="L9243">be off as soon as possible. “But what is to be done about Pemberley?”</li>
<li class="L9244" rel="L9244"> cried Mrs. Gardiner. “John told us Mr. Darcy was here when you sent for</li>
<li class="L9245" rel="L9245">us; was it so?”</li>
<li class="L9246" rel="L9246"></li>
<li class="L9247" rel="L9247">“Yes; and I told him we should not be able to keep our engagement.</li>
<li class="L9248" rel="L9248">_That_ is all settled.”</li>
<li class="L9249" rel="L9249"></li>
<li class="L9250" rel="L9250">“What is all settled?” repeated the other, as she ran into her room to</li>
<li class="L9251" rel="L9251">prepare. “And are they upon such terms as for her to disclose the real</li>
<li class="L9252" rel="L9252">truth? Oh, that I knew how it was!”</li>
<li class="L9253" rel="L9253"></li>
<li class="L9254" rel="L9254">But wishes were vain, or at least could only serve to amuse her in the</li>
<li class="L9255" rel="L9255">hurry and confusion of the following hour. Had Elizabeth been at leisure</li>
<li class="L9256" rel="L9256">to be idle, she would have remained certain that all employment was</li>
<li class="L9257" rel="L9257">impossible to one so wretched as herself; but she had her share of</li>
<li class="L9258" rel="L9258">business as well as her aunt, and amongst the rest there were notes to</li>
<li class="L9259" rel="L9259">be written to all their friends at Lambton, with false excuses for their</li>
<li class="L9260" rel="L9260">sudden departure. An hour, however, saw the whole completed; and Mr.</li>
<li class="L9261" rel="L9261">Gardiner meanwhile having settled his account at the inn, nothing</li>
<li class="L9262" rel="L9262">remained to be done but to go; and Elizabeth, after all the misery of</li>
<li class="L9263" rel="L9263">the morning, found herself, in a shorter space of time than she could</li>
<li class="L9264" rel="L9264">have supposed, seated in the carriage, and on the road to Longbourn.</li>
<li class="L9265" rel="L9265"></li>
<li class="L9266" rel="L9266"></li>
<li class="L9267" rel="L9267"></li>
<li class="L9268" rel="L9268">Chapter 47</li>
<li class="L9269" rel="L9269"></li>
<li class="L9270" rel="L9270"></li>
<li class="L9271" rel="L9271">“I have been thinking it over again, Elizabeth,” said her uncle, as they</li>
<li class="L9272" rel="L9272">drove from the town; “and really, upon serious consideration, I am much</li>
<li class="L9273" rel="L9273">more inclined than I was to judge as your eldest sister does on the</li>
<li class="L9274" rel="L9274">matter. It appears to me so very unlikely that any young man should</li>
<li class="L9275" rel="L9275">form such a design against a girl who is by no means unprotected or</li>
<li class="L9276" rel="L9276">friendless, and who was actually staying in his colonel&#39;s family, that I</li>
<li class="L9277" rel="L9277">am strongly inclined to hope the best. Could he expect that her friends</li>
<li class="L9278" rel="L9278">would not step forward? Could he expect to be noticed again by the</li>
<li class="L9279" rel="L9279">regiment, after such an affront to Colonel Forster? His temptation is</li>
<li class="L9280" rel="L9280">not adequate to the risk!”</li>
<li class="L9281" rel="L9281"></li>
<li class="L9282" rel="L9282">“Do you really think so?” cried Elizabeth, brightening up for a moment.</li>
<li class="L9283" rel="L9283"></li>
<li class="L9284" rel="L9284">“Upon my word,” said Mrs. Gardiner, “I begin to be of your uncle&#39;s</li>
<li class="L9285" rel="L9285">opinion. It is really too great a violation of decency, honour, and</li>
<li class="L9286" rel="L9286">interest, for him to be guilty of. I cannot think so very ill of</li>
<li class="L9287" rel="L9287">Wickham. Can you yourself, Lizzy, so wholly give him up, as to believe</li>
<li class="L9288" rel="L9288">him capable of it?”</li>
<li class="L9289" rel="L9289"></li>
<li class="L9290" rel="L9290">“Not, perhaps, of neglecting his own interest; but of every other</li>
<li class="L9291" rel="L9291">neglect I can believe him capable. If, indeed, it should be so! But I</li>
<li class="L9292" rel="L9292">dare not hope it. Why should they not go on to Scotland if that had been</li>
<li class="L9293" rel="L9293">the case?”</li>
<li class="L9294" rel="L9294"></li>
<li class="L9295" rel="L9295">“In the first place,” replied Mr. Gardiner, “there is no absolute proof</li>
<li class="L9296" rel="L9296">that they are not gone to Scotland.”</li>
<li class="L9297" rel="L9297"></li>
<li class="L9298" rel="L9298">“Oh! but their removing from the chaise into a hackney coach is such</li>
<li class="L9299" rel="L9299">a presumption! And, besides, no traces of them were to be found on the</li>
<li class="L9300" rel="L9300">Barnet road.”</li>
<li class="L9301" rel="L9301"></li>
<li class="L9302" rel="L9302">“Well, then--supposing them to be in London. They may be there, though</li>
<li class="L9303" rel="L9303">for the purpose of concealment, for no more exceptional purpose. It is</li>
<li class="L9304" rel="L9304">not likely that money should be very abundant on either side; and it</li>
<li class="L9305" rel="L9305">might strike them that they could be more economically, though less</li>
<li class="L9306" rel="L9306">expeditiously, married in London than in Scotland.”</li>
<li class="L9307" rel="L9307"></li>
<li class="L9308" rel="L9308">“But why all this secrecy? Why any fear of detection? Why must their</li>
<li class="L9309" rel="L9309">marriage be private? Oh, no, no--this is not likely. His most particular</li>
<li class="L9310" rel="L9310">friend, you see by Jane&#39;s account, was persuaded of his never intending</li>
<li class="L9311" rel="L9311">to marry her. Wickham will never marry a woman without some money. He</li>
<li class="L9312" rel="L9312">cannot afford it. And what claims has Lydia--what attraction has she</li>
<li class="L9313" rel="L9313">beyond youth, health, and good humour that could make him, for her sake,</li>
<li class="L9314" rel="L9314">forego every chance of benefiting himself by marrying well? As to what</li>
<li class="L9315" rel="L9315">restraint the apprehensions of disgrace in the corps might throw on a</li>
<li class="L9316" rel="L9316">dishonourable elopement with her, I am not able to judge; for I know</li>
<li class="L9317" rel="L9317">nothing of the effects that such a step might produce. But as to your</li>
<li class="L9318" rel="L9318">other objection, I am afraid it will hardly hold good. Lydia has</li>
<li class="L9319" rel="L9319">no brothers to step forward; and he might imagine, from my father&#39;s</li>
<li class="L9320" rel="L9320">behaviour, from his indolence and the little attention he has ever</li>
<li class="L9321" rel="L9321">seemed to give to what was going forward in his family, that _he_ would</li>
<li class="L9322" rel="L9322">do as little, and think as little about it, as any father could do, in</li>
<li class="L9323" rel="L9323">such a matter.”</li>
<li class="L9324" rel="L9324"></li>
<li class="L9325" rel="L9325">“But can you think that Lydia is so lost to everything but love of him</li>
<li class="L9326" rel="L9326">as to consent to live with him on any terms other than marriage?”</li>
<li class="L9327" rel="L9327"></li>
<li class="L9328" rel="L9328">“It does seem, and it is most shocking indeed,” replied Elizabeth, with</li>
<li class="L9329" rel="L9329">tears in her eyes, “that a sister&#39;s sense of decency and virtue in such</li>
<li class="L9330" rel="L9330">a point should admit of doubt. But, really, I know not what to say.</li>
<li class="L9331" rel="L9331">Perhaps I am not doing her justice. But she is very young; she has never</li>
<li class="L9332" rel="L9332">been taught to think on serious subjects; and for the last half-year,</li>
<li class="L9333" rel="L9333">nay, for a twelvemonth--she has been given up to nothing but amusement</li>
<li class="L9334" rel="L9334">and vanity. She has been allowed to dispose of her time in the most idle</li>
<li class="L9335" rel="L9335">and frivolous manner, and to adopt any opinions that came in her way.</li>
<li class="L9336" rel="L9336">Since the ----shire were first quartered in Meryton, nothing but love,</li>
<li class="L9337" rel="L9337">flirtation, and officers have been in her head. She has been doing</li>
<li class="L9338" rel="L9338">everything in her power by thinking and talking on the subject, to give</li>
<li class="L9339" rel="L9339">greater--what shall I call it? susceptibility to her feelings; which are</li>
<li class="L9340" rel="L9340">naturally lively enough. And we all know that Wickham has every charm of</li>
<li class="L9341" rel="L9341">person and address that can captivate a woman.”</li>
<li class="L9342" rel="L9342"></li>
<li class="L9343" rel="L9343">“But you see that Jane,” said her aunt, “does not think so very ill of</li>
<li class="L9344" rel="L9344">Wickham as to believe him capable of the attempt.”</li>
<li class="L9345" rel="L9345"></li>
<li class="L9346" rel="L9346">“Of whom does Jane ever think ill? And who is there, whatever might be</li>
<li class="L9347" rel="L9347">their former conduct, that she would think capable of such an attempt,</li>
<li class="L9348" rel="L9348">till it were proved against them? But Jane knows, as well as I do, what</li>
<li class="L9349" rel="L9349">Wickham really is. We both know that he has been profligate in every</li>
<li class="L9350" rel="L9350">sense of the word; that he has neither integrity nor honour; that he is</li>
<li class="L9351" rel="L9351">as false and deceitful as he is insinuating.”</li>
<li class="L9352" rel="L9352"></li>
<li class="L9353" rel="L9353">“And do you really know all this?” cried Mrs. Gardiner, whose curiosity</li>
<li class="L9354" rel="L9354">as to the mode of her intelligence was all alive.</li>
<li class="L9355" rel="L9355"></li>
<li class="L9356" rel="L9356">“I do indeed,” replied Elizabeth, colouring. “I told you, the other day,</li>
<li class="L9357" rel="L9357">of his infamous behaviour to Mr. Darcy; and you yourself, when last at</li>
<li class="L9358" rel="L9358">Longbourn, heard in what manner he spoke of the man who had behaved</li>
<li class="L9359" rel="L9359">with such forbearance and liberality towards him. And there are other</li>
<li class="L9360" rel="L9360">circumstances which I am not at liberty--which it is not worth while to</li>
<li class="L9361" rel="L9361">relate; but his lies about the whole Pemberley family are endless. From</li>
<li class="L9362" rel="L9362">what he said of Miss Darcy I was thoroughly prepared to see a proud,</li>
<li class="L9363" rel="L9363">reserved, disagreeable girl. Yet he knew to the contrary himself. He</li>
<li class="L9364" rel="L9364">must know that she was as amiable and unpretending as we have found</li>
<li class="L9365" rel="L9365">her.”</li>
<li class="L9366" rel="L9366"></li>
<li class="L9367" rel="L9367">“But does Lydia know nothing of this? can she be ignorant of what you</li>
<li class="L9368" rel="L9368">and Jane seem so well to understand?”</li>
<li class="L9369" rel="L9369"></li>
<li class="L9370" rel="L9370">“Oh, yes!--that, that is the worst of all. Till I was in Kent, and saw</li>
<li class="L9371" rel="L9371">so much both of Mr. Darcy and his relation Colonel Fitzwilliam, I was</li>
<li class="L9372" rel="L9372">ignorant of the truth myself. And when I returned home, the ----shire</li>
<li class="L9373" rel="L9373">was to leave Meryton in a week or fortnight&#39;s time. As that was the</li>
<li class="L9374" rel="L9374">case, neither Jane, to whom I related the whole, nor I, thought it</li>
<li class="L9375" rel="L9375">necessary to make our knowledge public; for of what use could</li>
<li class="L9376" rel="L9376">it apparently be to any one, that the good opinion which all the</li>
<li class="L9377" rel="L9377">neighbourhood had of him should then be overthrown? And even when it was</li>
<li class="L9378" rel="L9378">settled that Lydia should go with Mrs. Forster, the necessity of opening</li>
<li class="L9379" rel="L9379">her eyes to his character never occurred to me. That _she_ could be</li>
<li class="L9380" rel="L9380">in any danger from the deception never entered my head. That such a</li>
<li class="L9381" rel="L9381">consequence as _this_ could ensue, you may easily believe, was far</li>
<li class="L9382" rel="L9382">enough from my thoughts.”</li>
<li class="L9383" rel="L9383"></li>
<li class="L9384" rel="L9384">“When they all removed to Brighton, therefore, you had no reason, I</li>
<li class="L9385" rel="L9385">suppose, to believe them fond of each other?”</li>
<li class="L9386" rel="L9386"></li>
<li class="L9387" rel="L9387">“Not the slightest. I can remember no symptom of affection on either</li>
<li class="L9388" rel="L9388">side; and had anything of the kind been perceptible, you must be aware</li>
<li class="L9389" rel="L9389">that ours is not a family on which it could be thrown away. When first</li>
<li class="L9390" rel="L9390">he entered the corps, she was ready enough to admire him; but so we all</li>
<li class="L9391" rel="L9391">were. Every girl in or near Meryton was out of her senses about him for</li>
<li class="L9392" rel="L9392">the first two months; but he never distinguished _her_ by any particular</li>
<li class="L9393" rel="L9393">attention; and, consequently, after a moderate period of extravagant and</li>
<li class="L9394" rel="L9394">wild admiration, her fancy for him gave way, and others of the regiment,</li>
<li class="L9395" rel="L9395">who treated her with more distinction, again became her favourites.”</li>
<li class="L9396" rel="L9396"></li>
<li class="L9397" rel="L9397">                          * * * * *</li>
<li class="L9398" rel="L9398"></li>
<li class="L9399" rel="L9399">It may be easily believed, that however little of novelty could be added</li>
<li class="L9400" rel="L9400">to their fears, hopes, and conjectures, on this interesting subject, by</li>
<li class="L9401" rel="L9401">its repeated discussion, no other could detain them from it long, during</li>
<li class="L9402" rel="L9402">the whole of the journey. From Elizabeth&#39;s thoughts it was never absent.</li>
<li class="L9403" rel="L9403">Fixed there by the keenest of all anguish, self-reproach, she could find</li>
<li class="L9404" rel="L9404">no interval of ease or forgetfulness.</li>
<li class="L9405" rel="L9405"></li>
<li class="L9406" rel="L9406">They travelled as expeditiously as possible, and, sleeping one night</li>
<li class="L9407" rel="L9407">on the road, reached Longbourn by dinner time the next day. It was a</li>
<li class="L9408" rel="L9408">comfort to Elizabeth to consider that Jane could not have been wearied</li>
<li class="L9409" rel="L9409">by long expectations.</li>
<li class="L9410" rel="L9410"></li>
<li class="L9411" rel="L9411">The little Gardiners, attracted by the sight of a chaise, were standing</li>
<li class="L9412" rel="L9412">on the steps of the house as they entered the paddock; and, when the</li>
<li class="L9413" rel="L9413">carriage drove up to the door, the joyful surprise that lighted up their</li>
<li class="L9414" rel="L9414">faces, and displayed itself over their whole bodies, in a variety of</li>
<li class="L9415" rel="L9415">capers and frisks, was the first pleasing earnest of their welcome.</li>
<li class="L9416" rel="L9416"></li>
<li class="L9417" rel="L9417">Elizabeth jumped out; and, after giving each of them a hasty kiss,</li>
<li class="L9418" rel="L9418">hurried into the vestibule, where Jane, who came running down from her</li>
<li class="L9419" rel="L9419">mother&#39;s apartment, immediately met her.</li>
<li class="L9420" rel="L9420"></li>
<li class="L9421" rel="L9421">Elizabeth, as she affectionately embraced her, whilst tears filled the</li>
<li class="L9422" rel="L9422">eyes of both, lost not a moment in asking whether anything had been</li>
<li class="L9423" rel="L9423">heard of the fugitives.</li>
<li class="L9424" rel="L9424"></li>
<li class="L9425" rel="L9425">“Not yet,” replied Jane. “But now that my dear uncle is come, I hope</li>
<li class="L9426" rel="L9426">everything will be well.”</li>
<li class="L9427" rel="L9427"></li>
<li class="L9428" rel="L9428">“Is my father in town?”</li>
<li class="L9429" rel="L9429"></li>
<li class="L9430" rel="L9430">“Yes, he went on Tuesday, as I wrote you word.”</li>
<li class="L9431" rel="L9431"></li>
<li class="L9432" rel="L9432">“And have you heard from him often?”</li>
<li class="L9433" rel="L9433"></li>
<li class="L9434" rel="L9434">“We have heard only twice. He wrote me a few lines on Wednesday to say</li>
<li class="L9435" rel="L9435">that he had arrived in safety, and to give me his directions, which I</li>
<li class="L9436" rel="L9436">particularly begged him to do. He merely added that he should not write</li>
<li class="L9437" rel="L9437">again till he had something of importance to mention.”</li>
<li class="L9438" rel="L9438"></li>
<li class="L9439" rel="L9439">“And my mother--how is she? How are you all?”</li>
<li class="L9440" rel="L9440"></li>
<li class="L9441" rel="L9441">“My mother is tolerably well, I trust; though her spirits are greatly</li>
<li class="L9442" rel="L9442">shaken. She is up stairs and will have great satisfaction in seeing you</li>
<li class="L9443" rel="L9443">all. She does not yet leave her dressing-room. Mary and Kitty, thank</li>
<li class="L9444" rel="L9444">Heaven, are quite well.”</li>
<li class="L9445" rel="L9445"></li>
<li class="L9446" rel="L9446">“But you--how are you?” cried Elizabeth. “You look pale. How much you</li>
<li class="L9447" rel="L9447">must have gone through!”</li>
<li class="L9448" rel="L9448"></li>
<li class="L9449" rel="L9449">Her sister, however, assured her of her being perfectly well; and their</li>
<li class="L9450" rel="L9450">conversation, which had been passing while Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner were</li>
<li class="L9451" rel="L9451">engaged with their children, was now put an end to by the approach</li>
<li class="L9452" rel="L9452">of the whole party. Jane ran to her uncle and aunt, and welcomed and</li>
<li class="L9453" rel="L9453">thanked them both, with alternate smiles and tears.</li>
<li class="L9454" rel="L9454"></li>
<li class="L9455" rel="L9455">When they were all in the drawing-room, the questions which Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L9456" rel="L9456">had already asked were of course repeated by the others, and they soon</li>
<li class="L9457" rel="L9457">found that Jane had no intelligence to give. The sanguine hope of</li>
<li class="L9458" rel="L9458">good, however, which the benevolence of her heart suggested had not yet</li>
<li class="L9459" rel="L9459">deserted her; she still expected that it would all end well, and that</li>
<li class="L9460" rel="L9460">every morning would bring some letter, either from Lydia or her father,</li>
<li class="L9461" rel="L9461">to explain their proceedings, and, perhaps, announce their marriage.</li>
<li class="L9462" rel="L9462"></li>
<li class="L9463" rel="L9463">Mrs. Bennet, to whose apartment they all repaired, after a few minutes&#39;</li>
<li class="L9464" rel="L9464">conversation together, received them exactly as might be expected; with</li>
<li class="L9465" rel="L9465">tears and lamentations of regret, invectives against the villainous</li>
<li class="L9466" rel="L9466">conduct of Wickham, and complaints of her own sufferings and ill-usage;</li>
<li class="L9467" rel="L9467">blaming everybody but the person to whose ill-judging indulgence the</li>
<li class="L9468" rel="L9468">errors of her daughter must principally be owing.</li>
<li class="L9469" rel="L9469"></li>
<li class="L9470" rel="L9470">“If I had been able,” said she, “to carry my point in going to Brighton,</li>
<li class="L9471" rel="L9471">with all my family, _this_ would not have happened; but poor dear Lydia</li>
<li class="L9472" rel="L9472">had nobody to take care of her. Why did the Forsters ever let her go out</li>
<li class="L9473" rel="L9473">of their sight? I am sure there was some great neglect or other on their</li>
<li class="L9474" rel="L9474">side, for she is not the kind of girl to do such a thing if she had been</li>
<li class="L9475" rel="L9475">well looked after. I always thought they were very unfit to have the</li>
<li class="L9476" rel="L9476">charge of her; but I was overruled, as I always am. Poor dear child!</li>
<li class="L9477" rel="L9477">And now here&#39;s Mr. Bennet gone away, and I know he will fight Wickham,</li>
<li class="L9478" rel="L9478">wherever he meets him and then he will be killed, and what is to become</li>
<li class="L9479" rel="L9479">of us all? The Collinses will turn us out before he is cold in his</li>
<li class="L9480" rel="L9480">grave, and if you are not kind to us, brother, I do not know what we</li>
<li class="L9481" rel="L9481">shall do.”</li>
<li class="L9482" rel="L9482"></li>
<li class="L9483" rel="L9483">They all exclaimed against such terrific ideas; and Mr. Gardiner, after</li>
<li class="L9484" rel="L9484">general assurances of his affection for her and all her family, told her</li>
<li class="L9485" rel="L9485">that he meant to be in London the very next day, and would assist Mr.</li>
<li class="L9486" rel="L9486">Bennet in every endeavour for recovering Lydia.</li>
<li class="L9487" rel="L9487"></li>
<li class="L9488" rel="L9488">“Do not give way to useless alarm,” added he; “though it is right to be</li>
<li class="L9489" rel="L9489">prepared for the worst, there is no occasion to look on it as certain.</li>
<li class="L9490" rel="L9490">It is not quite a week since they left Brighton. In a few days more we</li>
<li class="L9491" rel="L9491">may gain some news of them; and till we know that they are not married,</li>
<li class="L9492" rel="L9492">and have no design of marrying, do not let us give the matter over as</li>
<li class="L9493" rel="L9493">lost. As soon as I get to town I shall go to my brother, and make</li>
<li class="L9494" rel="L9494">him come home with me to Gracechurch Street; and then we may consult</li>
<li class="L9495" rel="L9495">together as to what is to be done.”</li>
<li class="L9496" rel="L9496"></li>
<li class="L9497" rel="L9497">“Oh! my dear brother,” replied Mrs. Bennet, “that is exactly what I</li>
<li class="L9498" rel="L9498">could most wish for. And now do, when you get to town, find them out,</li>
<li class="L9499" rel="L9499">wherever they may be; and if they are not married already, _make_ them</li>
<li class="L9500" rel="L9500">marry. And as for wedding clothes, do not let them wait for that, but</li>
<li class="L9501" rel="L9501">tell Lydia she shall have as much money as she chooses to buy them,</li>
<li class="L9502" rel="L9502">after they are married. And, above all, keep Mr. Bennet from fighting.</li>
<li class="L9503" rel="L9503">Tell him what a dreadful state I am in, that I am frighted out of my</li>
<li class="L9504" rel="L9504">wits--and have such tremblings, such flutterings, all over me--such</li>
<li class="L9505" rel="L9505">spasms in my side and pains in my head, and such beatings at heart, that</li>
<li class="L9506" rel="L9506">I can get no rest by night nor by day. And tell my dear Lydia not to</li>
<li class="L9507" rel="L9507">give any directions about her clothes till she has seen me, for she does</li>
<li class="L9508" rel="L9508">not know which are the best warehouses. Oh, brother, how kind you are! I</li>
<li class="L9509" rel="L9509">know you will contrive it all.”</li>
<li class="L9510" rel="L9510"></li>
<li class="L9511" rel="L9511">But Mr. Gardiner, though he assured her again of his earnest endeavours</li>
<li class="L9512" rel="L9512">in the cause, could not avoid recommending moderation to her, as well</li>
<li class="L9513" rel="L9513">in her hopes as her fear; and after talking with her in this manner till</li>
<li class="L9514" rel="L9514">dinner was on the table, they all left her to vent all her feelings on</li>
<li class="L9515" rel="L9515">the housekeeper, who attended in the absence of her daughters.</li>
<li class="L9516" rel="L9516"></li>
<li class="L9517" rel="L9517">Though her brother and sister were persuaded that there was no real</li>
<li class="L9518" rel="L9518">occasion for such a seclusion from the family, they did not attempt to</li>
<li class="L9519" rel="L9519">oppose it, for they knew that she had not prudence enough to hold her</li>
<li class="L9520" rel="L9520">tongue before the servants, while they waited at table, and judged it</li>
<li class="L9521" rel="L9521">better that _one_ only of the household, and the one whom they could</li>
<li class="L9522" rel="L9522">most trust should comprehend all her fears and solicitude on the</li>
<li class="L9523" rel="L9523">subject.</li>
<li class="L9524" rel="L9524"></li>
<li class="L9525" rel="L9525">In the dining-room they were soon joined by Mary and Kitty, who had been</li>
<li class="L9526" rel="L9526">too busily engaged in their separate apartments to make their appearance</li>
<li class="L9527" rel="L9527">before. One came from her books, and the other from her toilette. The</li>
<li class="L9528" rel="L9528">faces of both, however, were tolerably calm; and no change was visible</li>
<li class="L9529" rel="L9529">in either, except that the loss of her favourite sister, or the anger</li>
<li class="L9530" rel="L9530">which she had herself incurred in this business, had given more of</li>
<li class="L9531" rel="L9531">fretfulness than usual to the accents of Kitty. As for Mary, she was</li>
<li class="L9532" rel="L9532">mistress enough of herself to whisper to Elizabeth, with a countenance</li>
<li class="L9533" rel="L9533">of grave reflection, soon after they were seated at table:</li>
<li class="L9534" rel="L9534"></li>
<li class="L9535" rel="L9535">“This is a most unfortunate affair, and will probably be much talked of.</li>
<li class="L9536" rel="L9536">But we must stem the tide of malice, and pour into the wounded bosoms of</li>
<li class="L9537" rel="L9537">each other the balm of sisterly consolation.”</li>
<li class="L9538" rel="L9538"></li>
<li class="L9539" rel="L9539">Then, perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying, she added,</li>
<li class="L9540" rel="L9540">“Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful</li>
<li class="L9541" rel="L9541">lesson: that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable; that one</li>
<li class="L9542" rel="L9542">false step involves her in endless ruin; that her reputation is no less</li>
<li class="L9543" rel="L9543">brittle than it is beautiful; and that she cannot be too much guarded in</li>
<li class="L9544" rel="L9544">her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.”</li>
<li class="L9545" rel="L9545"></li>
<li class="L9546" rel="L9546">Elizabeth lifted up her eyes in amazement, but was too much oppressed</li>
<li class="L9547" rel="L9547">to make any reply. Mary, however, continued to console herself with such</li>
<li class="L9548" rel="L9548">kind of moral extractions from the evil before them.</li>
<li class="L9549" rel="L9549"></li>
<li class="L9550" rel="L9550">In the afternoon, the two elder Miss Bennets were able to be for</li>
<li class="L9551" rel="L9551">half-an-hour by themselves; and Elizabeth instantly availed herself of</li>
<li class="L9552" rel="L9552">the opportunity of making any inquiries, which Jane was equally eager to</li>
<li class="L9553" rel="L9553">satisfy. After joining in general lamentations over the dreadful sequel</li>
<li class="L9554" rel="L9554">of this event, which Elizabeth considered as all but certain, and Miss</li>
<li class="L9555" rel="L9555">Bennet could not assert to be wholly impossible, the former continued</li>
<li class="L9556" rel="L9556">the subject, by saying, “But tell me all and everything about it which</li>
<li class="L9557" rel="L9557">I have not already heard. Give me further particulars. What did Colonel</li>
<li class="L9558" rel="L9558">Forster say? Had they no apprehension of anything before the elopement</li>
<li class="L9559" rel="L9559">took place? They must have seen them together for ever.”</li>
<li class="L9560" rel="L9560"></li>
<li class="L9561" rel="L9561">“Colonel Forster did own that he had often suspected some partiality,</li>
<li class="L9562" rel="L9562">especially on Lydia&#39;s side, but nothing to give him any alarm. I am so</li>
<li class="L9563" rel="L9563">grieved for him! His behaviour was attentive and kind to the utmost. He</li>
<li class="L9564" rel="L9564">_was_ coming to us, in order to assure us of his concern, before he had</li>
<li class="L9565" rel="L9565">any idea of their not being gone to Scotland: when that apprehension</li>
<li class="L9566" rel="L9566">first got abroad, it hastened his journey.”</li>
<li class="L9567" rel="L9567"></li>
<li class="L9568" rel="L9568">“And was Denny convinced that Wickham would not marry? Did he know of</li>
<li class="L9569" rel="L9569">their intending to go off? Had Colonel Forster seen Denny himself?”</li>
<li class="L9570" rel="L9570"></li>
<li class="L9571" rel="L9571">“Yes; but, when questioned by _him_, Denny denied knowing anything of</li>
<li class="L9572" rel="L9572">their plans, and would not give his real opinion about it. He did not</li>
<li class="L9573" rel="L9573">repeat his persuasion of their not marrying--and from _that_, I am</li>
<li class="L9574" rel="L9574">inclined to hope, he might have been misunderstood before.”</li>
<li class="L9575" rel="L9575"></li>
<li class="L9576" rel="L9576">“And till Colonel Forster came himself, not one of you entertained a</li>
<li class="L9577" rel="L9577">doubt, I suppose, of their being really married?”</li>
<li class="L9578" rel="L9578"></li>
<li class="L9579" rel="L9579">“How was it possible that such an idea should enter our brains? I felt</li>
<li class="L9580" rel="L9580">a little uneasy--a little fearful of my sister&#39;s happiness with him</li>
<li class="L9581" rel="L9581">in marriage, because I knew that his conduct had not been always quite</li>
<li class="L9582" rel="L9582">right. My father and mother knew nothing of that; they only felt how</li>
<li class="L9583" rel="L9583">imprudent a match it must be. Kitty then owned, with a very natural</li>
<li class="L9584" rel="L9584">triumph on knowing more than the rest of us, that in Lydia&#39;s last letter</li>
<li class="L9585" rel="L9585">she had prepared her for such a step. She had known, it seems, of their</li>
<li class="L9586" rel="L9586">being in love with each other, many weeks.”</li>
<li class="L9587" rel="L9587"></li>
<li class="L9588" rel="L9588">“But not before they went to Brighton?”</li>
<li class="L9589" rel="L9589"></li>
<li class="L9590" rel="L9590">“No, I believe not.”</li>
<li class="L9591" rel="L9591"></li>
<li class="L9592" rel="L9592">“And did Colonel Forster appear to think well of Wickham himself? Does</li>
<li class="L9593" rel="L9593">he know his real character?”</li>
<li class="L9594" rel="L9594"></li>
<li class="L9595" rel="L9595">“I must confess that he did not speak so well of Wickham as he formerly</li>
<li class="L9596" rel="L9596">did. He believed him to be imprudent and extravagant. And since this sad</li>
<li class="L9597" rel="L9597">affair has taken place, it is said that he left Meryton greatly in debt;</li>
<li class="L9598" rel="L9598">but I hope this may be false.”</li>
<li class="L9599" rel="L9599"></li>
<li class="L9600" rel="L9600">“Oh, Jane, had we been less secret, had we told what we knew of him,</li>
<li class="L9601" rel="L9601">this could not have happened!”</li>
<li class="L9602" rel="L9602"></li>
<li class="L9603" rel="L9603">“Perhaps it would have been better,” replied her sister. “But to expose</li>
<li class="L9604" rel="L9604">the former faults of any person without knowing what their present</li>
<li class="L9605" rel="L9605">feelings were, seemed unjustifiable. We acted with the best intentions.”</li>
<li class="L9606" rel="L9606"></li>
<li class="L9607" rel="L9607">“Could Colonel Forster repeat the particulars of Lydia&#39;s note to his</li>
<li class="L9608" rel="L9608">wife?”</li>
<li class="L9609" rel="L9609"></li>
<li class="L9610" rel="L9610">“He brought it with him for us to see.”</li>
<li class="L9611" rel="L9611"></li>
<li class="L9612" rel="L9612">Jane then took it from her pocket-book, and gave it to Elizabeth. These</li>
<li class="L9613" rel="L9613">were the contents:</li>
<li class="L9614" rel="L9614"></li>
<li class="L9615" rel="L9615">“MY DEAR HARRIET,</li>
<li class="L9616" rel="L9616"></li>
<li class="L9617" rel="L9617">“You will laugh when you know where I am gone, and I cannot help</li>
<li class="L9618" rel="L9618">laughing myself at your surprise to-morrow morning, as soon as I am</li>
<li class="L9619" rel="L9619">missed. I am going to Gretna Green, and if you cannot guess with who,</li>
<li class="L9620" rel="L9620">I shall think you a simpleton, for there is but one man in the world I</li>
<li class="L9621" rel="L9621">love, and he is an angel. I should never be happy without him, so think</li>
<li class="L9622" rel="L9622">it no harm to be off. You need not send them word at Longbourn of my</li>
<li class="L9623" rel="L9623">going, if you do not like it, for it will make the surprise the greater,</li>
<li class="L9624" rel="L9624">when I write to them and sign my name &#39;Lydia Wickham.&#39; What a good joke</li>
<li class="L9625" rel="L9625">it will be! I can hardly write for laughing. Pray make my excuses to</li>
<li class="L9626" rel="L9626">Pratt for not keeping my engagement, and dancing with him to-night.</li>
<li class="L9627" rel="L9627">Tell him I hope he will excuse me when he knows all; and tell him I will</li>
<li class="L9628" rel="L9628">dance with him at the next ball we meet, with great pleasure. I shall</li>
<li class="L9629" rel="L9629">send for my clothes when I get to Longbourn; but I wish you would tell</li>
<li class="L9630" rel="L9630">Sally to mend a great slit in my worked muslin gown before they are</li>
<li class="L9631" rel="L9631">packed up. Good-bye. Give my love to Colonel Forster. I hope you will</li>
<li class="L9632" rel="L9632">drink to our good journey.</li>
<li class="L9633" rel="L9633"></li>
<li class="L9634" rel="L9634">“Your affectionate friend,</li>
<li class="L9635" rel="L9635"></li>
<li class="L9636" rel="L9636">“LYDIA BENNET.”</li>
<li class="L9637" rel="L9637"></li>
<li class="L9638" rel="L9638">“Oh! thoughtless, thoughtless Lydia!” cried Elizabeth when she had</li>
<li class="L9639" rel="L9639">finished it. “What a letter is this, to be written at such a moment!</li>
<li class="L9640" rel="L9640">But at least it shows that _she_ was serious on the subject of their</li>
<li class="L9641" rel="L9641">journey. Whatever he might afterwards persuade her to, it was not on her</li>
<li class="L9642" rel="L9642">side a _scheme_ of infamy. My poor father! how he must have felt it!”</li>
<li class="L9643" rel="L9643"></li>
<li class="L9644" rel="L9644">“I never saw anyone so shocked. He could not speak a word for full ten</li>
<li class="L9645" rel="L9645">minutes. My mother was taken ill immediately, and the whole house in</li>
<li class="L9646" rel="L9646">such confusion!”</li>
<li class="L9647" rel="L9647"></li>
<li class="L9648" rel="L9648">“Oh! Jane,” cried Elizabeth, “was there a servant belonging to it who</li>
<li class="L9649" rel="L9649">did not know the whole story before the end of the day?”</li>
<li class="L9650" rel="L9650"></li>
<li class="L9651" rel="L9651">“I do not know. I hope there was. But to be guarded at such a time is</li>
<li class="L9652" rel="L9652">very difficult. My mother was in hysterics, and though I endeavoured to</li>
<li class="L9653" rel="L9653">give her every assistance in my power, I am afraid I did not do so</li>
<li class="L9654" rel="L9654">much as I might have done! But the horror of what might possibly happen</li>
<li class="L9655" rel="L9655">almost took from me my faculties.”</li>
<li class="L9656" rel="L9656"></li>
<li class="L9657" rel="L9657">“Your attendance upon her has been too much for you. You do not look</li>
<li class="L9658" rel="L9658">well. Oh that I had been with you! you have had every care and anxiety</li>
<li class="L9659" rel="L9659">upon yourself alone.”</li>
<li class="L9660" rel="L9660"></li>
<li class="L9661" rel="L9661">“Mary and Kitty have been very kind, and would have shared in every</li>
<li class="L9662" rel="L9662">fatigue, I am sure; but I did not think it right for either of them.</li>
<li class="L9663" rel="L9663">Kitty is slight and delicate; and Mary studies so much, that her hours</li>
<li class="L9664" rel="L9664">of repose should not be broken in on. My aunt Phillips came to Longbourn</li>
<li class="L9665" rel="L9665">on Tuesday, after my father went away; and was so good as to stay till</li>
<li class="L9666" rel="L9666">Thursday with me. She was of great use and comfort to us all. And</li>
<li class="L9667" rel="L9667">Lady Lucas has been very kind; she walked here on Wednesday morning to</li>
<li class="L9668" rel="L9668">condole with us, and offered her services, or any of her daughters&#39;, if</li>
<li class="L9669" rel="L9669">they should be of use to us.”</li>
<li class="L9670" rel="L9670"></li>
<li class="L9671" rel="L9671">“She had better have stayed at home,” cried Elizabeth; “perhaps she</li>
<li class="L9672" rel="L9672">_meant_ well, but, under such a misfortune as this, one cannot see</li>
<li class="L9673" rel="L9673">too little of one&#39;s neighbours. Assistance is impossible; condolence</li>
<li class="L9674" rel="L9674">insufferable. Let them triumph over us at a distance, and be satisfied.”</li>
<li class="L9675" rel="L9675"></li>
<li class="L9676" rel="L9676">She then proceeded to inquire into the measures which her father had</li>
<li class="L9677" rel="L9677">intended to pursue, while in town, for the recovery of his daughter.</li>
<li class="L9678" rel="L9678"></li>
<li class="L9679" rel="L9679">“He meant I believe,” replied Jane, “to go to Epsom, the place where</li>
<li class="L9680" rel="L9680">they last changed horses, see the postilions and try if anything could</li>
<li class="L9681" rel="L9681">be made out from them. His principal object must be to discover the</li>
<li class="L9682" rel="L9682">number of the hackney coach which took them from Clapham. It had come</li>
<li class="L9683" rel="L9683">with a fare from London; and as he thought that the circumstance of a</li>
<li class="L9684" rel="L9684">gentleman and lady&#39;s removing from one carriage into another might</li>
<li class="L9685" rel="L9685">be remarked he meant to make inquiries at Clapham. If he could anyhow</li>
<li class="L9686" rel="L9686">discover at what house the coachman had before set down his fare, he</li>
<li class="L9687" rel="L9687">determined to make inquiries there, and hoped it might not be impossible</li>
<li class="L9688" rel="L9688">to find out the stand and number of the coach. I do not know of any</li>
<li class="L9689" rel="L9689">other designs that he had formed; but he was in such a hurry to be gone,</li>
<li class="L9690" rel="L9690">and his spirits so greatly discomposed, that I had difficulty in finding</li>
<li class="L9691" rel="L9691">out even so much as this.”</li>
<li class="L9692" rel="L9692"></li>
<li class="L9693" rel="L9693"></li>
<li class="L9694" rel="L9694"></li>
<li class="L9695" rel="L9695">Chapter 48</li>
<li class="L9696" rel="L9696"></li>
<li class="L9697" rel="L9697"></li>
<li class="L9698" rel="L9698">The whole party were in hopes of a letter from Mr. Bennet the next</li>
<li class="L9699" rel="L9699">morning, but the post came in without bringing a single line from him.</li>
<li class="L9700" rel="L9700">His family knew him to be, on all common occasions, a most negligent and</li>
<li class="L9701" rel="L9701">dilatory correspondent; but at such a time they had hoped for exertion.</li>
<li class="L9702" rel="L9702">They were forced to conclude that he had no pleasing intelligence to</li>
<li class="L9703" rel="L9703">send; but even of _that_ they would have been glad to be certain. Mr.</li>
<li class="L9704" rel="L9704">Gardiner had waited only for the letters before he set off.</li>
<li class="L9705" rel="L9705"></li>
<li class="L9706" rel="L9706">When he was gone, they were certain at least of receiving constant</li>
<li class="L9707" rel="L9707">information of what was going on, and their uncle promised, at parting,</li>
<li class="L9708" rel="L9708">to prevail on Mr. Bennet to return to Longbourn, as soon as he could,</li>
<li class="L9709" rel="L9709">to the great consolation of his sister, who considered it as the only</li>
<li class="L9710" rel="L9710">security for her husband&#39;s not being killed in a duel.</li>
<li class="L9711" rel="L9711"></li>
<li class="L9712" rel="L9712">Mrs. Gardiner and the children were to remain in Hertfordshire a few</li>
<li class="L9713" rel="L9713">days longer, as the former thought her presence might be serviceable</li>
<li class="L9714" rel="L9714">to her nieces. She shared in their attendance on Mrs. Bennet, and was a</li>
<li class="L9715" rel="L9715">great comfort to them in their hours of freedom. Their other aunt also</li>
<li class="L9716" rel="L9716">visited them frequently, and always, as she said, with the design of</li>
<li class="L9717" rel="L9717">cheering and heartening them up--though, as she never came without</li>
<li class="L9718" rel="L9718">reporting some fresh instance of Wickham&#39;s extravagance or irregularity,</li>
<li class="L9719" rel="L9719">she seldom went away without leaving them more dispirited than she found</li>
<li class="L9720" rel="L9720">them.</li>
<li class="L9721" rel="L9721"></li>
<li class="L9722" rel="L9722">All Meryton seemed striving to blacken the man who, but three months</li>
<li class="L9723" rel="L9723">before, had been almost an angel of light. He was declared to be in debt</li>
<li class="L9724" rel="L9724">to every tradesman in the place, and his intrigues, all honoured with</li>
<li class="L9725" rel="L9725">the title of seduction, had been extended into every tradesman&#39;s family.</li>
<li class="L9726" rel="L9726">Everybody declared that he was the wickedest young man in the world;</li>
<li class="L9727" rel="L9727">and everybody began to find out that they had always distrusted the</li>
<li class="L9728" rel="L9728">appearance of his goodness. Elizabeth, though she did not credit above</li>
<li class="L9729" rel="L9729">half of what was said, believed enough to make her former assurance of</li>
<li class="L9730" rel="L9730">her sister&#39;s ruin more certain; and even Jane, who believed still less</li>
<li class="L9731" rel="L9731">of it, became almost hopeless, more especially as the time was now come</li>
<li class="L9732" rel="L9732">when, if they had gone to Scotland, which she had never before entirely</li>
<li class="L9733" rel="L9733">despaired of, they must in all probability have gained some news of</li>
<li class="L9734" rel="L9734">them.</li>
<li class="L9735" rel="L9735"></li>
<li class="L9736" rel="L9736">Mr. Gardiner left Longbourn on Sunday; on Tuesday his wife received a</li>
<li class="L9737" rel="L9737">letter from him; it told them that, on his arrival, he had immediately</li>
<li class="L9738" rel="L9738">found out his brother, and persuaded him to come to Gracechurch Street;</li>
<li class="L9739" rel="L9739">that Mr. Bennet had been to Epsom and Clapham, before his arrival,</li>
<li class="L9740" rel="L9740">but without gaining any satisfactory information; and that he was now</li>
<li class="L9741" rel="L9741">determined to inquire at all the principal hotels in town, as Mr. Bennet</li>
<li class="L9742" rel="L9742">thought it possible they might have gone to one of them, on their first</li>
<li class="L9743" rel="L9743">coming to London, before they procured lodgings. Mr. Gardiner himself</li>
<li class="L9744" rel="L9744">did not expect any success from this measure, but as his brother was</li>
<li class="L9745" rel="L9745">eager in it, he meant to assist him in pursuing it. He added that Mr.</li>
<li class="L9746" rel="L9746">Bennet seemed wholly disinclined at present to leave London and promised</li>
<li class="L9747" rel="L9747">to write again very soon. There was also a postscript to this effect:</li>
<li class="L9748" rel="L9748"></li>
<li class="L9749" rel="L9749">“I have written to Colonel Forster to desire him to find out, if</li>
<li class="L9750" rel="L9750">possible, from some of the young man&#39;s intimates in the regiment,</li>
<li class="L9751" rel="L9751">whether Wickham has any relations or connections who would be likely to</li>
<li class="L9752" rel="L9752">know in what part of town he has now concealed himself. If there were</li>
<li class="L9753" rel="L9753">anyone that one could apply to with a probability of gaining such a</li>
<li class="L9754" rel="L9754">clue as that, it might be of essential consequence. At present we have</li>
<li class="L9755" rel="L9755">nothing to guide us. Colonel Forster will, I dare say, do everything in</li>
<li class="L9756" rel="L9756">his power to satisfy us on this head. But, on second thoughts, perhaps,</li>
<li class="L9757" rel="L9757">Lizzy could tell us what relations he has now living, better than any</li>
<li class="L9758" rel="L9758">other person.”</li>
<li class="L9759" rel="L9759"></li>
<li class="L9760" rel="L9760">Elizabeth was at no loss to understand from whence this deference to her</li>
<li class="L9761" rel="L9761">authority proceeded; but it was not in her power to give any information</li>
<li class="L9762" rel="L9762">of so satisfactory a nature as the compliment deserved. She had never</li>
<li class="L9763" rel="L9763">heard of his having had any relations, except a father and mother, both</li>
<li class="L9764" rel="L9764">of whom had been dead many years. It was possible, however, that some of</li>
<li class="L9765" rel="L9765">his companions in the ----shire might be able to give more information;</li>
<li class="L9766" rel="L9766">and though she was not very sanguine in expecting it, the application</li>
<li class="L9767" rel="L9767">was a something to look forward to.</li>
<li class="L9768" rel="L9768"></li>
<li class="L9769" rel="L9769">Every day at Longbourn was now a day of anxiety; but the most anxious</li>
<li class="L9770" rel="L9770">part of each was when the post was expected. The arrival of letters</li>
<li class="L9771" rel="L9771">was the grand object of every morning&#39;s impatience. Through letters,</li>
<li class="L9772" rel="L9772">whatever of good or bad was to be told would be communicated, and every</li>
<li class="L9773" rel="L9773">succeeding day was expected to bring some news of importance.</li>
<li class="L9774" rel="L9774"></li>
<li class="L9775" rel="L9775">But before they heard again from Mr. Gardiner, a letter arrived for</li>
<li class="L9776" rel="L9776">their father, from a different quarter, from Mr. Collins; which, as Jane</li>
<li class="L9777" rel="L9777">had received directions to open all that came for him in his absence,</li>
<li class="L9778" rel="L9778">she accordingly read; and Elizabeth, who knew what curiosities his</li>
<li class="L9779" rel="L9779">letters always were, looked over her, and read it likewise. It was as</li>
<li class="L9780" rel="L9780">follows:</li>
<li class="L9781" rel="L9781"></li>
<li class="L9782" rel="L9782">“MY DEAR SIR,</li>
<li class="L9783" rel="L9783"></li>
<li class="L9784" rel="L9784">“I feel myself called upon, by our relationship, and my situation</li>
<li class="L9785" rel="L9785">in life, to condole with you on the grievous affliction you are now</li>
<li class="L9786" rel="L9786">suffering under, of which we were yesterday informed by a letter from</li>
<li class="L9787" rel="L9787">Hertfordshire. Be assured, my dear sir, that Mrs. Collins and myself</li>
<li class="L9788" rel="L9788">sincerely sympathise with you and all your respectable family, in</li>
<li class="L9789" rel="L9789">your present distress, which must be of the bitterest kind, because</li>
<li class="L9790" rel="L9790">proceeding from a cause which no time can remove. No arguments shall be</li>
<li class="L9791" rel="L9791">wanting on my part that can alleviate so severe a misfortune--or that</li>
<li class="L9792" rel="L9792">may comfort you, under a circumstance that must be of all others the</li>
<li class="L9793" rel="L9793">most afflicting to a parent&#39;s mind. The death of your daughter would</li>
<li class="L9794" rel="L9794">have been a blessing in comparison of this. And it is the more to</li>
<li class="L9795" rel="L9795">be lamented, because there is reason to suppose as my dear Charlotte</li>
<li class="L9796" rel="L9796">informs me, that this licentiousness of behaviour in your daughter has</li>
<li class="L9797" rel="L9797">proceeded from a faulty degree of indulgence; though, at the same time,</li>
<li class="L9798" rel="L9798">for the consolation of yourself and Mrs. Bennet, I am inclined to think</li>
<li class="L9799" rel="L9799">that her own disposition must be naturally bad, or she could not be</li>
<li class="L9800" rel="L9800">guilty of such an enormity, at so early an age. Howsoever that may be,</li>
<li class="L9801" rel="L9801">you are grievously to be pitied; in which opinion I am not only joined</li>
<li class="L9802" rel="L9802">by Mrs. Collins, but likewise by Lady Catherine and her daughter, to</li>
<li class="L9803" rel="L9803">whom I have related the affair. They agree with me in apprehending that</li>
<li class="L9804" rel="L9804">this false step in one daughter will be injurious to the fortunes of</li>
<li class="L9805" rel="L9805">all the others; for who, as Lady Catherine herself condescendingly says,</li>
<li class="L9806" rel="L9806">will connect themselves with such a family? And this consideration leads</li>
<li class="L9807" rel="L9807">me moreover to reflect, with augmented satisfaction, on a certain event</li>
<li class="L9808" rel="L9808">of last November; for had it been otherwise, I must have been involved</li>
<li class="L9809" rel="L9809">in all your sorrow and disgrace. Let me then advise you, dear sir, to</li>
<li class="L9810" rel="L9810">console yourself as much as possible, to throw off your unworthy child</li>
<li class="L9811" rel="L9811">from your affection for ever, and leave her to reap the fruits of her</li>
<li class="L9812" rel="L9812">own heinous offense.</li>
<li class="L9813" rel="L9813"></li>
<li class="L9814" rel="L9814">“I am, dear sir, etc., etc.”</li>
<li class="L9815" rel="L9815"></li>
<li class="L9816" rel="L9816">Mr. Gardiner did not write again till he had received an answer from</li>
<li class="L9817" rel="L9817">Colonel Forster; and then he had nothing of a pleasant nature to send.</li>
<li class="L9818" rel="L9818">It was not known that Wickham had a single relationship with whom he</li>
<li class="L9819" rel="L9819">kept up any connection, and it was certain that he had no near one</li>
<li class="L9820" rel="L9820">living. His former acquaintances had been numerous; but since he</li>
<li class="L9821" rel="L9821">had been in the militia, it did not appear that he was on terms of</li>
<li class="L9822" rel="L9822">particular friendship with any of them. There was no one, therefore,</li>
<li class="L9823" rel="L9823">who could be pointed out as likely to give any news of him. And in the</li>
<li class="L9824" rel="L9824">wretched state of his own finances, there was a very powerful motive for</li>
<li class="L9825" rel="L9825">secrecy, in addition to his fear of discovery by Lydia&#39;s relations, for</li>
<li class="L9826" rel="L9826">it had just transpired that he had left gaming debts behind him to a</li>
<li class="L9827" rel="L9827">very considerable amount. Colonel Forster believed that more than a</li>
<li class="L9828" rel="L9828">thousand pounds would be necessary to clear his expenses at Brighton.</li>
<li class="L9829" rel="L9829">He owed a good deal in town, but his debts of honour were still more</li>
<li class="L9830" rel="L9830">formidable. Mr. Gardiner did not attempt to conceal these particulars</li>
<li class="L9831" rel="L9831">from the Longbourn family. Jane heard them with horror. “A gamester!”</li>
<li class="L9832" rel="L9832"> she cried. “This is wholly unexpected. I had not an idea of it.”</li>
<li class="L9833" rel="L9833"></li>
<li class="L9834" rel="L9834">Mr. Gardiner added in his letter, that they might expect to see their</li>
<li class="L9835" rel="L9835">father at home on the following day, which was Saturday. Rendered</li>
<li class="L9836" rel="L9836">spiritless by the ill-success of all their endeavours, he had yielded</li>
<li class="L9837" rel="L9837">to his brother-in-law&#39;s entreaty that he would return to his family, and</li>
<li class="L9838" rel="L9838">leave it to him to do whatever occasion might suggest to be advisable</li>
<li class="L9839" rel="L9839">for continuing their pursuit. When Mrs. Bennet was told of this, she did</li>
<li class="L9840" rel="L9840">not express so much satisfaction as her children expected, considering</li>
<li class="L9841" rel="L9841">what her anxiety for his life had been before.</li>
<li class="L9842" rel="L9842"></li>
<li class="L9843" rel="L9843">“What, is he coming home, and without poor Lydia?” she cried. “Sure he</li>
<li class="L9844" rel="L9844">will not leave London before he has found them. Who is to fight Wickham,</li>
<li class="L9845" rel="L9845">and make him marry her, if he comes away?”</li>
<li class="L9846" rel="L9846"></li>
<li class="L9847" rel="L9847">As Mrs. Gardiner began to wish to be at home, it was settled that she</li>
<li class="L9848" rel="L9848">and the children should go to London, at the same time that Mr. Bennet</li>
<li class="L9849" rel="L9849">came from it. The coach, therefore, took them the first stage of their</li>
<li class="L9850" rel="L9850">journey, and brought its master back to Longbourn.</li>
<li class="L9851" rel="L9851"></li>
<li class="L9852" rel="L9852">Mrs. Gardiner went away in all the perplexity about Elizabeth and her</li>
<li class="L9853" rel="L9853">Derbyshire friend that had attended her from that part of the world. His</li>
<li class="L9854" rel="L9854">name had never been voluntarily mentioned before them by her niece; and</li>
<li class="L9855" rel="L9855">the kind of half-expectation which Mrs. Gardiner had formed, of their</li>
<li class="L9856" rel="L9856">being followed by a letter from him, had ended in nothing. Elizabeth had</li>
<li class="L9857" rel="L9857">received none since her return that could come from Pemberley.</li>
<li class="L9858" rel="L9858"></li>
<li class="L9859" rel="L9859">The present unhappy state of the family rendered any other excuse for</li>
<li class="L9860" rel="L9860">the lowness of her spirits unnecessary; nothing, therefore, could be</li>
<li class="L9861" rel="L9861">fairly conjectured from _that_, though Elizabeth, who was by this time</li>
<li class="L9862" rel="L9862">tolerably well acquainted with her own feelings, was perfectly aware</li>
<li class="L9863" rel="L9863">that, had she known nothing of Darcy, she could have borne the dread of</li>
<li class="L9864" rel="L9864">Lydia&#39;s infamy somewhat better. It would have spared her, she thought,</li>
<li class="L9865" rel="L9865">one sleepless night out of two.</li>
<li class="L9866" rel="L9866"></li>
<li class="L9867" rel="L9867">When Mr. Bennet arrived, he had all the appearance of his usual</li>
<li class="L9868" rel="L9868">philosophic composure. He said as little as he had ever been in the</li>
<li class="L9869" rel="L9869">habit of saying; made no mention of the business that had taken him</li>
<li class="L9870" rel="L9870">away, and it was some time before his daughters had courage to speak of</li>
<li class="L9871" rel="L9871">it.</li>
<li class="L9872" rel="L9872"></li>
<li class="L9873" rel="L9873">It was not till the afternoon, when he had joined them at tea, that</li>
<li class="L9874" rel="L9874">Elizabeth ventured to introduce the subject; and then, on her briefly</li>
<li class="L9875" rel="L9875">expressing her sorrow for what he must have endured, he replied, “Say</li>
<li class="L9876" rel="L9876">nothing of that. Who should suffer but myself? It has been my own doing,</li>
<li class="L9877" rel="L9877">and I ought to feel it.”</li>
<li class="L9878" rel="L9878"></li>
<li class="L9879" rel="L9879">“You must not be too severe upon yourself,” replied Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L9880" rel="L9880"></li>
<li class="L9881" rel="L9881">“You may well warn me against such an evil. Human nature is so prone</li>
<li class="L9882" rel="L9882">to fall into it! No, Lizzy, let me once in my life feel how much I have</li>
<li class="L9883" rel="L9883">been to blame. I am not afraid of being overpowered by the impression.</li>
<li class="L9884" rel="L9884">It will pass away soon enough.”</li>
<li class="L9885" rel="L9885"></li>
<li class="L9886" rel="L9886">“Do you suppose them to be in London?”</li>
<li class="L9887" rel="L9887"></li>
<li class="L9888" rel="L9888">“Yes; where else can they be so well concealed?”</li>
<li class="L9889" rel="L9889"></li>
<li class="L9890" rel="L9890">“And Lydia used to want to go to London,” added Kitty.</li>
<li class="L9891" rel="L9891"></li>
<li class="L9892" rel="L9892">“She is happy then,” said her father drily; “and her residence there</li>
<li class="L9893" rel="L9893">will probably be of some duration.”</li>
<li class="L9894" rel="L9894"></li>
<li class="L9895" rel="L9895">Then after a short silence he continued:</li>
<li class="L9896" rel="L9896"></li>
<li class="L9897" rel="L9897">“Lizzy, I bear you no ill-will for being justified in your advice to me</li>
<li class="L9898" rel="L9898">last May, which, considering the event, shows some greatness of mind.”</li>
<li class="L9899" rel="L9899"></li>
<li class="L9900" rel="L9900">They were interrupted by Miss Bennet, who came to fetch her mother&#39;s</li>
<li class="L9901" rel="L9901">tea.</li>
<li class="L9902" rel="L9902"></li>
<li class="L9903" rel="L9903">“This is a parade,” he cried, “which does one good; it gives such an</li>
<li class="L9904" rel="L9904">elegance to misfortune! Another day I will do the same; I will sit in my</li>
<li class="L9905" rel="L9905">library, in my nightcap and powdering gown, and give as much trouble as</li>
<li class="L9906" rel="L9906">I can; or, perhaps, I may defer it till Kitty runs away.”</li>
<li class="L9907" rel="L9907"></li>
<li class="L9908" rel="L9908">“I am not going to run away, papa,” said Kitty fretfully. “If I should</li>
<li class="L9909" rel="L9909">ever go to Brighton, I would behave better than Lydia.”</li>
<li class="L9910" rel="L9910"></li>
<li class="L9911" rel="L9911">“_You_ go to Brighton. I would not trust you so near it as Eastbourne</li>
<li class="L9912" rel="L9912">for fifty pounds! No, Kitty, I have at last learnt to be cautious, and</li>
<li class="L9913" rel="L9913">you will feel the effects of it. No officer is ever to enter into</li>
<li class="L9914" rel="L9914">my house again, nor even to pass through the village. Balls will be</li>
<li class="L9915" rel="L9915">absolutely prohibited, unless you stand up with one of your sisters.</li>
<li class="L9916" rel="L9916">And you are never to stir out of doors till you can prove that you have</li>
<li class="L9917" rel="L9917">spent ten minutes of every day in a rational manner.”</li>
<li class="L9918" rel="L9918"></li>
<li class="L9919" rel="L9919">Kitty, who took all these threats in a serious light, began to cry.</li>
<li class="L9920" rel="L9920"></li>
<li class="L9921" rel="L9921">“Well, well,” said he, “do not make yourself unhappy. If you are a good</li>
<li class="L9922" rel="L9922">girl for the next ten years, I will take you to a review at the end of</li>
<li class="L9923" rel="L9923">them.”</li>
<li class="L9924" rel="L9924"></li>
<li class="L9925" rel="L9925"></li>
<li class="L9926" rel="L9926"></li>
<li class="L9927" rel="L9927">Chapter 49</li>
<li class="L9928" rel="L9928"></li>
<li class="L9929" rel="L9929"></li>
<li class="L9930" rel="L9930">Two days after Mr. Bennet&#39;s return, as Jane and Elizabeth were walking</li>
<li class="L9931" rel="L9931">together in the shrubbery behind the house, they saw the housekeeper</li>
<li class="L9932" rel="L9932">coming towards them, and, concluding that she came to call them to their</li>
<li class="L9933" rel="L9933">mother, went forward to meet her; but, instead of the expected summons,</li>
<li class="L9934" rel="L9934">when they approached her, she said to Miss Bennet, “I beg your pardon,</li>
<li class="L9935" rel="L9935">madam, for interrupting you, but I was in hopes you might have got some</li>
<li class="L9936" rel="L9936">good news from town, so I took the liberty of coming to ask.”</li>
<li class="L9937" rel="L9937"></li>
<li class="L9938" rel="L9938">“What do you mean, Hill? We have heard nothing from town.”</li>
<li class="L9939" rel="L9939"></li>
<li class="L9940" rel="L9940">“Dear madam,” cried Mrs. Hill, in great astonishment, “don&#39;t you know</li>
<li class="L9941" rel="L9941">there is an express come for master from Mr. Gardiner? He has been here</li>
<li class="L9942" rel="L9942">this half-hour, and master has had a letter.”</li>
<li class="L9943" rel="L9943"></li>
<li class="L9944" rel="L9944">Away ran the girls, too eager to get in to have time for speech. They</li>
<li class="L9945" rel="L9945">ran through the vestibule into the breakfast-room; from thence to the</li>
<li class="L9946" rel="L9946">library; their father was in neither; and they were on the point of</li>
<li class="L9947" rel="L9947">seeking him up stairs with their mother, when they were met by the</li>
<li class="L9948" rel="L9948">butler, who said:</li>
<li class="L9949" rel="L9949"></li>
<li class="L9950" rel="L9950">“If you are looking for my master, ma&#39;am, he is walking towards the</li>
<li class="L9951" rel="L9951">little copse.”</li>
<li class="L9952" rel="L9952"></li>
<li class="L9953" rel="L9953">Upon this information, they instantly passed through the hall once</li>
<li class="L9954" rel="L9954">more, and ran across the lawn after their father, who was deliberately</li>
<li class="L9955" rel="L9955">pursuing his way towards a small wood on one side of the paddock.</li>
<li class="L9956" rel="L9956"></li>
<li class="L9957" rel="L9957">Jane, who was not so light nor so much in the habit of running as</li>
<li class="L9958" rel="L9958">Elizabeth, soon lagged behind, while her sister, panting for breath,</li>
<li class="L9959" rel="L9959">came up with him, and eagerly cried out:</li>
<li class="L9960" rel="L9960"></li>
<li class="L9961" rel="L9961">“Oh, papa, what news--what news? Have you heard from my uncle?”</li>
<li class="L9962" rel="L9962"></li>
<li class="L9963" rel="L9963">“Yes I have had a letter from him by express.”</li>
<li class="L9964" rel="L9964"></li>
<li class="L9965" rel="L9965">“Well, and what news does it bring--good or bad?”</li>
<li class="L9966" rel="L9966"></li>
<li class="L9967" rel="L9967">“What is there of good to be expected?” said he, taking the letter from</li>
<li class="L9968" rel="L9968">his pocket. “But perhaps you would like to read it.”</li>
<li class="L9969" rel="L9969"></li>
<li class="L9970" rel="L9970">Elizabeth impatiently caught it from his hand. Jane now came up.</li>
<li class="L9971" rel="L9971"></li>
<li class="L9972" rel="L9972">“Read it aloud,” said their father, “for I hardly know myself what it is</li>
<li class="L9973" rel="L9973">about.”</li>
<li class="L9974" rel="L9974"></li>
<li class="L9975" rel="L9975">“Gracechurch Street, Monday, August 2.</li>
<li class="L9976" rel="L9976"></li>
<li class="L9977" rel="L9977">“MY DEAR BROTHER,</li>
<li class="L9978" rel="L9978"></li>
<li class="L9979" rel="L9979">“At last I am able to send you some tidings of my niece, and such as,</li>
<li class="L9980" rel="L9980">upon the whole, I hope it will give you satisfaction. Soon after you</li>
<li class="L9981" rel="L9981">left me on Saturday, I was fortunate enough to find out in what part of</li>
<li class="L9982" rel="L9982">London they were. The particulars I reserve till we meet; it is enough</li>
<li class="L9983" rel="L9983">to know they are discovered. I have seen them both--”</li>
<li class="L9984" rel="L9984"></li>
<li class="L9985" rel="L9985">“Then it is as I always hoped,” cried Jane; “they are married!”</li>
<li class="L9986" rel="L9986"></li>
<li class="L9987" rel="L9987">Elizabeth read on:</li>
<li class="L9988" rel="L9988"></li>
<li class="L9989" rel="L9989">“I have seen them both. They are not married, nor can I find there</li>
<li class="L9990" rel="L9990">was any intention of being so; but if you are willing to perform the</li>
<li class="L9991" rel="L9991">engagements which I have ventured to make on your side, I hope it will</li>
<li class="L9992" rel="L9992">not be long before they are. All that is required of you is, to assure</li>
<li class="L9993" rel="L9993">to your daughter, by settlement, her equal share of the five thousand</li>
<li class="L9994" rel="L9994">pounds secured among your children after the decease of yourself and</li>
<li class="L9995" rel="L9995">my sister; and, moreover, to enter into an engagement of allowing her,</li>
<li class="L9996" rel="L9996">during your life, one hundred pounds per annum. These are conditions</li>
<li class="L9997" rel="L9997">which, considering everything, I had no hesitation in complying with,</li>
<li class="L9998" rel="L9998">as far as I thought myself privileged, for you. I shall send this by</li>
<li class="L9999" rel="L9999">express, that no time may be lost in bringing me your answer. You</li>
<li class="L10000" rel="L10000">will easily comprehend, from these particulars, that Mr. Wickham&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10001" rel="L10001">circumstances are not so hopeless as they are generally believed to be.</li>
<li class="L10002" rel="L10002">The world has been deceived in that respect; and I am happy to say there</li>
<li class="L10003" rel="L10003">will be some little money, even when all his debts are discharged, to</li>
<li class="L10004" rel="L10004">settle on my niece, in addition to her own fortune. If, as I conclude</li>
<li class="L10005" rel="L10005">will be the case, you send me full powers to act in your name throughout</li>
<li class="L10006" rel="L10006">the whole of this business, I will immediately give directions to</li>
<li class="L10007" rel="L10007">Haggerston for preparing a proper settlement. There will not be the</li>
<li class="L10008" rel="L10008">smallest occasion for your coming to town again; therefore stay quiet at</li>
<li class="L10009" rel="L10009">Longbourn, and depend on my diligence and care. Send back your answer as</li>
<li class="L10010" rel="L10010">fast as you can, and be careful to write explicitly. We have judged it</li>
<li class="L10011" rel="L10011">best that my niece should be married from this house, of which I hope</li>
