<li class="L10012" rel="L10012">you will approve. She comes to us to-day. I shall write again as soon as</li>
<li class="L10013" rel="L10013">anything more is determined on. Yours, etc.,</li>
<li class="L10014" rel="L10014"></li>
<li class="L10015" rel="L10015">“EDW. GARDINER.”</li>
<li class="L10016" rel="L10016"></li>
<li class="L10017" rel="L10017">“Is it possible?” cried Elizabeth, when she had finished. “Can it be</li>
<li class="L10018" rel="L10018">possible that he will marry her?”</li>
<li class="L10019" rel="L10019"></li>
<li class="L10020" rel="L10020">“Wickham is not so undeserving, then, as we thought him,” said her</li>
<li class="L10021" rel="L10021">sister. “My dear father, I congratulate you.”</li>
<li class="L10022" rel="L10022"></li>
<li class="L10023" rel="L10023">“And have you answered the letter?” cried Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L10024" rel="L10024"></li>
<li class="L10025" rel="L10025">“No; but it must be done soon.”</li>
<li class="L10026" rel="L10026"></li>
<li class="L10027" rel="L10027">Most earnestly did she then entreat him to lose no more time before he</li>
<li class="L10028" rel="L10028">wrote.</li>
<li class="L10029" rel="L10029"></li>
<li class="L10030" rel="L10030">“Oh! my dear father,” she cried, “come back and write immediately.</li>
<li class="L10031" rel="L10031">Consider how important every moment is in such a case.”</li>
<li class="L10032" rel="L10032"></li>
<li class="L10033" rel="L10033">“Let me write for you,” said Jane, “if you dislike the trouble</li>
<li class="L10034" rel="L10034">yourself.”</li>
<li class="L10035" rel="L10035"></li>
<li class="L10036" rel="L10036">“I dislike it very much,” he replied; “but it must be done.”</li>
<li class="L10037" rel="L10037"></li>
<li class="L10038" rel="L10038">And so saying, he turned back with them, and walked towards the house.</li>
<li class="L10039" rel="L10039"></li>
<li class="L10040" rel="L10040">“And may I ask--” said Elizabeth; “but the terms, I suppose, must be</li>
<li class="L10041" rel="L10041">complied with.”</li>
<li class="L10042" rel="L10042"></li>
<li class="L10043" rel="L10043">“Complied with! I am only ashamed of his asking so little.”</li>
<li class="L10044" rel="L10044"></li>
<li class="L10045" rel="L10045">“And they _must_ marry! Yet he is _such_ a man!”</li>
<li class="L10046" rel="L10046"></li>
<li class="L10047" rel="L10047">“Yes, yes, they must marry. There is nothing else to be done. But there</li>
<li class="L10048" rel="L10048">are two things that I want very much to know; one is, how much money</li>
<li class="L10049" rel="L10049">your uncle has laid down to bring it about; and the other, how am I ever</li>
<li class="L10050" rel="L10050">to pay him.”</li>
<li class="L10051" rel="L10051"></li>
<li class="L10052" rel="L10052">“Money! My uncle!” cried Jane, “what do you mean, sir?”</li>
<li class="L10053" rel="L10053"></li>
<li class="L10054" rel="L10054">“I mean, that no man in his senses would marry Lydia on so slight a</li>
<li class="L10055" rel="L10055">temptation as one hundred a year during my life, and fifty after I am</li>
<li class="L10056" rel="L10056">gone.”</li>
<li class="L10057" rel="L10057"></li>
<li class="L10058" rel="L10058">“That is very true,” said Elizabeth; “though it had not occurred to me</li>
<li class="L10059" rel="L10059">before. His debts to be discharged, and something still to remain! Oh!</li>
<li class="L10060" rel="L10060">it must be my uncle&#39;s doings! Generous, good man, I am afraid he has</li>
<li class="L10061" rel="L10061">distressed himself. A small sum could not do all this.”</li>
<li class="L10062" rel="L10062"></li>
<li class="L10063" rel="L10063">“No,” said her father; “Wickham&#39;s a fool if he takes her with a farthing</li>
<li class="L10064" rel="L10064">less than ten thousand pounds. I should be sorry to think so ill of him,</li>
<li class="L10065" rel="L10065">in the very beginning of our relationship.”</li>
<li class="L10066" rel="L10066"></li>
<li class="L10067" rel="L10067">“Ten thousand pounds! Heaven forbid! How is half such a sum to be</li>
<li class="L10068" rel="L10068">repaid?”</li>
<li class="L10069" rel="L10069"></li>
<li class="L10070" rel="L10070">Mr. Bennet made no answer, and each of them, deep in thought, continued</li>
<li class="L10071" rel="L10071">silent till they reached the house. Their father then went on to the</li>
<li class="L10072" rel="L10072">library to write, and the girls walked into the breakfast-room.</li>
<li class="L10073" rel="L10073"></li>
<li class="L10074" rel="L10074">“And they are really to be married!” cried Elizabeth, as soon as they</li>
<li class="L10075" rel="L10075">were by themselves. “How strange this is! And for _this_ we are to be</li>
<li class="L10076" rel="L10076">thankful. That they should marry, small as is their chance of happiness,</li>
<li class="L10077" rel="L10077">and wretched as is his character, we are forced to rejoice. Oh, Lydia!”</li>
<li class="L10078" rel="L10078"></li>
<li class="L10079" rel="L10079">“I comfort myself with thinking,” replied Jane, “that he certainly would</li>
<li class="L10080" rel="L10080">not marry Lydia if he had not a real regard for her. Though our kind</li>
<li class="L10081" rel="L10081">uncle has done something towards clearing him, I cannot believe that ten</li>
<li class="L10082" rel="L10082">thousand pounds, or anything like it, has been advanced. He has children</li>
<li class="L10083" rel="L10083">of his own, and may have more. How could he spare half ten thousand</li>
<li class="L10084" rel="L10084">pounds?”</li>
<li class="L10085" rel="L10085"></li>
<li class="L10086" rel="L10086">“If he were ever able to learn what Wickham&#39;s debts have been,” said</li>
<li class="L10087" rel="L10087">Elizabeth, “and how much is settled on his side on our sister, we shall</li>
<li class="L10088" rel="L10088">exactly know what Mr. Gardiner has done for them, because Wickham has</li>
<li class="L10089" rel="L10089">not sixpence of his own. The kindness of my uncle and aunt can never</li>
<li class="L10090" rel="L10090">be requited. Their taking her home, and affording her their personal</li>
<li class="L10091" rel="L10091">protection and countenance, is such a sacrifice to her advantage as</li>
<li class="L10092" rel="L10092">years of gratitude cannot enough acknowledge. By this time she is</li>
<li class="L10093" rel="L10093">actually with them! If such goodness does not make her miserable now,</li>
<li class="L10094" rel="L10094">she will never deserve to be happy! What a meeting for her, when she</li>
<li class="L10095" rel="L10095">first sees my aunt!”</li>
<li class="L10096" rel="L10096"></li>
<li class="L10097" rel="L10097">“We must endeavour to forget all that has passed on either side,” said</li>
<li class="L10098" rel="L10098">Jane: “I hope and trust they will yet be happy. His consenting to</li>
<li class="L10099" rel="L10099">marry her is a proof, I will believe, that he is come to a right way of</li>
<li class="L10100" rel="L10100">thinking. Their mutual affection will steady them; and I flatter myself</li>
<li class="L10101" rel="L10101">they will settle so quietly, and live in so rational a manner, as may in</li>
<li class="L10102" rel="L10102">time make their past imprudence forgotten.”</li>
<li class="L10103" rel="L10103"></li>
<li class="L10104" rel="L10104">“Their conduct has been such,” replied Elizabeth, “as neither you, nor</li>
<li class="L10105" rel="L10105">I, nor anybody can ever forget. It is useless to talk of it.”</li>
<li class="L10106" rel="L10106"></li>
<li class="L10107" rel="L10107">It now occurred to the girls that their mother was in all likelihood</li>
<li class="L10108" rel="L10108">perfectly ignorant of what had happened. They went to the library,</li>
<li class="L10109" rel="L10109">therefore, and asked their father whether he would not wish them to make</li>
<li class="L10110" rel="L10110">it known to her. He was writing and, without raising his head, coolly</li>
<li class="L10111" rel="L10111">replied:</li>
<li class="L10112" rel="L10112"></li>
<li class="L10113" rel="L10113">“Just as you please.”</li>
<li class="L10114" rel="L10114"></li>
<li class="L10115" rel="L10115">“May we take my uncle&#39;s letter to read to her?”</li>
<li class="L10116" rel="L10116"></li>
<li class="L10117" rel="L10117">“Take whatever you like, and get away.”</li>
<li class="L10118" rel="L10118"></li>
<li class="L10119" rel="L10119">Elizabeth took the letter from his writing-table, and they went up stairs</li>
<li class="L10120" rel="L10120">together. Mary and Kitty were both with Mrs. Bennet: one communication</li>
<li class="L10121" rel="L10121">would, therefore, do for all. After a slight preparation for good news,</li>
<li class="L10122" rel="L10122">the letter was read aloud. Mrs. Bennet could hardly contain herself. As</li>
<li class="L10123" rel="L10123">soon as Jane had read Mr. Gardiner&#39;s hope of Lydia&#39;s being soon</li>
<li class="L10124" rel="L10124">married, her joy burst forth, and every following sentence added to its</li>
<li class="L10125" rel="L10125">exuberance. She was now in an irritation as violent from delight, as she</li>
<li class="L10126" rel="L10126">had ever been fidgety from alarm and vexation. To know that her daughter</li>
<li class="L10127" rel="L10127">would be married was enough. She was disturbed by no fear for her</li>
<li class="L10128" rel="L10128">felicity, nor humbled by any remembrance of her misconduct.</li>
<li class="L10129" rel="L10129"></li>
<li class="L10130" rel="L10130">“My dear, dear Lydia!” she cried. “This is delightful indeed! She will</li>
<li class="L10131" rel="L10131">be married! I shall see her again! She will be married at sixteen!</li>
<li class="L10132" rel="L10132">My good, kind brother! I knew how it would be. I knew he would manage</li>
<li class="L10133" rel="L10133">everything! How I long to see her! and to see dear Wickham too! But the</li>
<li class="L10134" rel="L10134">clothes, the wedding clothes! I will write to my sister Gardiner about</li>
<li class="L10135" rel="L10135">them directly. Lizzy, my dear, run down to your father, and ask him</li>
<li class="L10136" rel="L10136">how much he will give her. Stay, stay, I will go myself. Ring the bell,</li>
<li class="L10137" rel="L10137">Kitty, for Hill. I will put on my things in a moment. My dear, dear</li>
<li class="L10138" rel="L10138">Lydia! How merry we shall be together when we meet!”</li>
<li class="L10139" rel="L10139"></li>
<li class="L10140" rel="L10140">Her eldest daughter endeavoured to give some relief to the violence of</li>
<li class="L10141" rel="L10141">these transports, by leading her thoughts to the obligations which Mr.</li>
<li class="L10142" rel="L10142">Gardiner&#39;s behaviour laid them all under.</li>
<li class="L10143" rel="L10143"></li>
<li class="L10144" rel="L10144">“For we must attribute this happy conclusion,” she added, “in a great</li>
<li class="L10145" rel="L10145">measure to his kindness. We are persuaded that he has pledged himself to</li>
<li class="L10146" rel="L10146">assist Mr. Wickham with money.”</li>
<li class="L10147" rel="L10147"></li>
<li class="L10148" rel="L10148">“Well,” cried her mother, “it is all very right; who should do it but</li>
<li class="L10149" rel="L10149">her own uncle? If he had not had a family of his own, I and my children</li>
<li class="L10150" rel="L10150">must have had all his money, you know; and it is the first time we have</li>
<li class="L10151" rel="L10151">ever had anything from him, except a few presents. Well! I am so happy!</li>
<li class="L10152" rel="L10152">In a short time I shall have a daughter married. Mrs. Wickham! How well</li>
<li class="L10153" rel="L10153">it sounds! And she was only sixteen last June. My dear Jane, I am in</li>
<li class="L10154" rel="L10154">such a flutter, that I am sure I can&#39;t write; so I will dictate, and</li>
<li class="L10155" rel="L10155">you write for me. We will settle with your father about the money</li>
<li class="L10156" rel="L10156">afterwards; but the things should be ordered immediately.”</li>
<li class="L10157" rel="L10157"></li>
<li class="L10158" rel="L10158">She was then proceeding to all the particulars of calico, muslin, and</li>
<li class="L10159" rel="L10159">cambric, and would shortly have dictated some very plentiful orders, had</li>
<li class="L10160" rel="L10160">not Jane, though with some difficulty, persuaded her to wait till her</li>
<li class="L10161" rel="L10161">father was at leisure to be consulted. One day&#39;s delay, she observed,</li>
<li class="L10162" rel="L10162">would be of small importance; and her mother was too happy to be quite</li>
<li class="L10163" rel="L10163">so obstinate as usual. Other schemes, too, came into her head.</li>
<li class="L10164" rel="L10164"></li>
<li class="L10165" rel="L10165">“I will go to Meryton,” said she, “as soon as I am dressed, and tell the</li>
<li class="L10166" rel="L10166">good, good news to my sister Philips. And as I come back, I can call</li>
<li class="L10167" rel="L10167">on Lady Lucas and Mrs. Long. Kitty, run down and order the carriage.</li>
<li class="L10168" rel="L10168">An airing would do me a great deal of good, I am sure. Girls, can I do</li>
<li class="L10169" rel="L10169">anything for you in Meryton? Oh! Here comes Hill! My dear Hill, have you</li>
<li class="L10170" rel="L10170">heard the good news? Miss Lydia is going to be married; and you shall</li>
<li class="L10171" rel="L10171">all have a bowl of punch to make merry at her wedding.”</li>
<li class="L10172" rel="L10172"></li>
<li class="L10173" rel="L10173">Mrs. Hill began instantly to express her joy. Elizabeth received her</li>
<li class="L10174" rel="L10174">congratulations amongst the rest, and then, sick of this folly, took</li>
<li class="L10175" rel="L10175">refuge in her own room, that she might think with freedom.</li>
<li class="L10176" rel="L10176"></li>
<li class="L10177" rel="L10177">Poor Lydia&#39;s situation must, at best, be bad enough; but that it was</li>
<li class="L10178" rel="L10178">no worse, she had need to be thankful. She felt it so; and though, in</li>
<li class="L10179" rel="L10179">looking forward, neither rational happiness nor worldly prosperity could</li>
<li class="L10180" rel="L10180">be justly expected for her sister, in looking back to what they had</li>
<li class="L10181" rel="L10181">feared, only two hours ago, she felt all the advantages of what they had</li>
<li class="L10182" rel="L10182">gained.</li>
<li class="L10183" rel="L10183"></li>
<li class="L10184" rel="L10184"></li>
<li class="L10185" rel="L10185"></li>
<li class="L10186" rel="L10186">Chapter 50</li>
<li class="L10187" rel="L10187"></li>
<li class="L10188" rel="L10188"></li>
<li class="L10189" rel="L10189">Mr. Bennet had very often wished before this period of his life that,</li>
<li class="L10190" rel="L10190">instead of spending his whole income, he had laid by an annual sum for</li>
<li class="L10191" rel="L10191">the better provision of his children, and of his wife, if she survived</li>
<li class="L10192" rel="L10192">him. He now wished it more than ever. Had he done his duty in that</li>
<li class="L10193" rel="L10193">respect, Lydia need not have been indebted to her uncle for whatever</li>
<li class="L10194" rel="L10194">of honour or credit could now be purchased for her. The satisfaction of</li>
<li class="L10195" rel="L10195">prevailing on one of the most worthless young men in Great Britain to be</li>
<li class="L10196" rel="L10196">her husband might then have rested in its proper place.</li>
<li class="L10197" rel="L10197"></li>
<li class="L10198" rel="L10198">He was seriously concerned that a cause of so little advantage to anyone</li>
<li class="L10199" rel="L10199">should be forwarded at the sole expense of his brother-in-law, and he</li>
<li class="L10200" rel="L10200">was determined, if possible, to find out the extent of his assistance,</li>
<li class="L10201" rel="L10201">and to discharge the obligation as soon as he could.</li>
<li class="L10202" rel="L10202"></li>
<li class="L10203" rel="L10203">When first Mr. Bennet had married, economy was held to be perfectly</li>
<li class="L10204" rel="L10204">useless, for, of course, they were to have a son. The son was to join</li>
<li class="L10205" rel="L10205">in cutting off the entail, as soon as he should be of age, and the widow</li>
<li class="L10206" rel="L10206">and younger children would by that means be provided for. Five daughters</li>
<li class="L10207" rel="L10207">successively entered the world, but yet the son was to come; and Mrs.</li>
<li class="L10208" rel="L10208">Bennet, for many years after Lydia&#39;s birth, had been certain that he</li>
<li class="L10209" rel="L10209">would. This event had at last been despaired of, but it was then</li>
<li class="L10210" rel="L10210">too late to be saving. Mrs. Bennet had no turn for economy, and her</li>
<li class="L10211" rel="L10211">husband&#39;s love of independence had alone prevented their exceeding their</li>
<li class="L10212" rel="L10212">income.</li>
<li class="L10213" rel="L10213"></li>
<li class="L10214" rel="L10214">Five thousand pounds was settled by marriage articles on Mrs. Bennet and</li>
<li class="L10215" rel="L10215">the children. But in what proportions it should be divided amongst the</li>
<li class="L10216" rel="L10216">latter depended on the will of the parents. This was one point, with</li>
<li class="L10217" rel="L10217">regard to Lydia, at least, which was now to be settled, and Mr. Bennet</li>
<li class="L10218" rel="L10218">could have no hesitation in acceding to the proposal before him. In</li>
<li class="L10219" rel="L10219">terms of grateful acknowledgment for the kindness of his brother,</li>
<li class="L10220" rel="L10220">though expressed most concisely, he then delivered on paper his perfect</li>
<li class="L10221" rel="L10221">approbation of all that was done, and his willingness to fulfil the</li>
<li class="L10222" rel="L10222">engagements that had been made for him. He had never before supposed</li>
<li class="L10223" rel="L10223">that, could Wickham be prevailed on to marry his daughter, it would</li>
<li class="L10224" rel="L10224">be done with so little inconvenience to himself as by the present</li>
<li class="L10225" rel="L10225">arrangement. He would scarcely be ten pounds a year the loser by the</li>
<li class="L10226" rel="L10226">hundred that was to be paid them; for, what with her board and pocket</li>
<li class="L10227" rel="L10227">allowance, and the continual presents in money which passed to her</li>
<li class="L10228" rel="L10228">through her mother&#39;s hands, Lydia&#39;s expenses had been very little within</li>
<li class="L10229" rel="L10229">that sum.</li>
<li class="L10230" rel="L10230"></li>
<li class="L10231" rel="L10231">That it would be done with such trifling exertion on his side, too, was</li>
<li class="L10232" rel="L10232">another very welcome surprise; for his wish at present was to have as</li>
<li class="L10233" rel="L10233">little trouble in the business as possible. When the first transports</li>
<li class="L10234" rel="L10234">of rage which had produced his activity in seeking her were over, he</li>
<li class="L10235" rel="L10235">naturally returned to all his former indolence. His letter was soon</li>
<li class="L10236" rel="L10236">dispatched; for, though dilatory in undertaking business, he was quick</li>
<li class="L10237" rel="L10237">in its execution. He begged to know further particulars of what he</li>
<li class="L10238" rel="L10238">was indebted to his brother, but was too angry with Lydia to send any</li>
<li class="L10239" rel="L10239">message to her.</li>
<li class="L10240" rel="L10240"></li>
<li class="L10241" rel="L10241">The good news spread quickly through the house, and with proportionate</li>
<li class="L10242" rel="L10242">speed through the neighbourhood. It was borne in the latter with decent</li>
<li class="L10243" rel="L10243">philosophy. To be sure, it would have been more for the advantage</li>
<li class="L10244" rel="L10244">of conversation had Miss Lydia Bennet come upon the town; or, as the</li>
<li class="L10245" rel="L10245">happiest alternative, been secluded from the world, in some distant</li>
<li class="L10246" rel="L10246">farmhouse. But there was much to be talked of in marrying her; and the</li>
<li class="L10247" rel="L10247">good-natured wishes for her well-doing which had proceeded before from</li>
<li class="L10248" rel="L10248">all the spiteful old ladies in Meryton lost but a little of their spirit</li>
<li class="L10249" rel="L10249">in this change of circumstances, because with such an husband her misery</li>
<li class="L10250" rel="L10250">was considered certain.</li>
<li class="L10251" rel="L10251"></li>
<li class="L10252" rel="L10252">It was a fortnight since Mrs. Bennet had been downstairs; but on this</li>
<li class="L10253" rel="L10253">happy day she again took her seat at the head of her table, and in</li>
<li class="L10254" rel="L10254">spirits oppressively high. No sentiment of shame gave a damp to her</li>
<li class="L10255" rel="L10255">triumph. The marriage of a daughter, which had been the first object</li>
<li class="L10256" rel="L10256">of her wishes since Jane was sixteen, was now on the point of</li>
<li class="L10257" rel="L10257">accomplishment, and her thoughts and her words ran wholly on those</li>
<li class="L10258" rel="L10258">attendants of elegant nuptials, fine muslins, new carriages, and</li>
<li class="L10259" rel="L10259">servants. She was busily searching through the neighbourhood for a</li>
<li class="L10260" rel="L10260">proper situation for her daughter, and, without knowing or considering</li>
<li class="L10261" rel="L10261">what their income might be, rejected many as deficient in size and</li>
<li class="L10262" rel="L10262">importance.</li>
<li class="L10263" rel="L10263"></li>
<li class="L10264" rel="L10264">“Haye Park might do,” said she, “if the Gouldings could quit it--or the</li>
<li class="L10265" rel="L10265">great house at Stoke, if the drawing-room were larger; but Ashworth is</li>
<li class="L10266" rel="L10266">too far off! I could not bear to have her ten miles from me; and as for</li>
<li class="L10267" rel="L10267">Pulvis Lodge, the attics are dreadful.”</li>
<li class="L10268" rel="L10268"></li>
<li class="L10269" rel="L10269">Her husband allowed her to talk on without interruption while the</li>
<li class="L10270" rel="L10270">servants remained. But when they had withdrawn, he said to her: “Mrs.</li>
<li class="L10271" rel="L10271">Bennet, before you take any or all of these houses for your son and</li>
<li class="L10272" rel="L10272">daughter, let us come to a right understanding. Into _one_ house in this</li>
<li class="L10273" rel="L10273">neighbourhood they shall never have admittance. I will not encourage the</li>
<li class="L10274" rel="L10274">impudence of either, by receiving them at Longbourn.”</li>
<li class="L10275" rel="L10275"></li>
<li class="L10276" rel="L10276">A long dispute followed this declaration; but Mr. Bennet was firm. It</li>
<li class="L10277" rel="L10277">soon led to another; and Mrs. Bennet found, with amazement and horror,</li>
<li class="L10278" rel="L10278">that her husband would not advance a guinea to buy clothes for his</li>
<li class="L10279" rel="L10279">daughter. He protested that she should receive from him no mark of</li>
<li class="L10280" rel="L10280">affection whatever on the occasion. Mrs. Bennet could hardly comprehend</li>
<li class="L10281" rel="L10281">it. That his anger could be carried to such a point of inconceivable</li>
<li class="L10282" rel="L10282">resentment as to refuse his daughter a privilege without which her</li>
<li class="L10283" rel="L10283">marriage would scarcely seem valid, exceeded all she could believe</li>
<li class="L10284" rel="L10284">possible. She was more alive to the disgrace which her want of new</li>
<li class="L10285" rel="L10285">clothes must reflect on her daughter&#39;s nuptials, than to any sense of</li>
<li class="L10286" rel="L10286">shame at her eloping and living with Wickham a fortnight before they</li>
<li class="L10287" rel="L10287">took place.</li>
<li class="L10288" rel="L10288"></li>
<li class="L10289" rel="L10289">Elizabeth was now most heartily sorry that she had, from the distress of</li>
<li class="L10290" rel="L10290">the moment, been led to make Mr. Darcy acquainted with their fears for</li>
<li class="L10291" rel="L10291">her sister; for since her marriage would so shortly give the</li>
<li class="L10292" rel="L10292">proper termination to the elopement, they might hope to conceal its</li>
<li class="L10293" rel="L10293">unfavourable beginning from all those who were not immediately on the</li>
<li class="L10294" rel="L10294">spot.</li>
<li class="L10295" rel="L10295"></li>
<li class="L10296" rel="L10296">She had no fear of its spreading farther through his means. There were</li>
<li class="L10297" rel="L10297">few people on whose secrecy she would have more confidently depended;</li>
<li class="L10298" rel="L10298">but, at the same time, there was no one whose knowledge of a sister&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10299" rel="L10299">frailty would have mortified her so much--not, however, from any fear</li>
<li class="L10300" rel="L10300">of disadvantage from it individually to herself, for, at any rate,</li>
<li class="L10301" rel="L10301">there seemed a gulf impassable between them. Had Lydia&#39;s marriage been</li>
<li class="L10302" rel="L10302">concluded on the most honourable terms, it was not to be supposed that</li>
<li class="L10303" rel="L10303">Mr. Darcy would connect himself with a family where, to every other</li>
<li class="L10304" rel="L10304">objection, would now be added an alliance and relationship of the</li>
<li class="L10305" rel="L10305">nearest kind with a man whom he so justly scorned.</li>
<li class="L10306" rel="L10306"></li>
<li class="L10307" rel="L10307">From such a connection she could not wonder that he would shrink. The</li>
<li class="L10308" rel="L10308">wish of procuring her regard, which she had assured herself of his</li>
<li class="L10309" rel="L10309">feeling in Derbyshire, could not in rational expectation survive such a</li>
<li class="L10310" rel="L10310">blow as this. She was humbled, she was grieved; she repented, though she</li>
<li class="L10311" rel="L10311">hardly knew of what. She became jealous of his esteem, when she could no</li>
<li class="L10312" rel="L10312">longer hope to be benefited by it. She wanted to hear of him, when there</li>
<li class="L10313" rel="L10313">seemed the least chance of gaining intelligence. She was convinced that</li>
<li class="L10314" rel="L10314">she could have been happy with him, when it was no longer likely they</li>
<li class="L10315" rel="L10315">should meet.</li>
<li class="L10316" rel="L10316"></li>
<li class="L10317" rel="L10317">What a triumph for him, as she often thought, could he know that the</li>
<li class="L10318" rel="L10318">proposals which she had proudly spurned only four months ago, would now</li>
<li class="L10319" rel="L10319">have been most gladly and gratefully received! He was as generous, she</li>
<li class="L10320" rel="L10320">doubted not, as the most generous of his sex; but while he was mortal,</li>
<li class="L10321" rel="L10321">there must be a triumph.</li>
<li class="L10322" rel="L10322"></li>
<li class="L10323" rel="L10323">She began now to comprehend that he was exactly the man who, in</li>
<li class="L10324" rel="L10324">disposition and talents, would most suit her. His understanding and</li>
<li class="L10325" rel="L10325">temper, though unlike her own, would have answered all her wishes. It</li>
<li class="L10326" rel="L10326">was an union that must have been to the advantage of both; by her ease</li>
<li class="L10327" rel="L10327">and liveliness, his mind might have been softened, his manners improved;</li>
<li class="L10328" rel="L10328">and from his judgement, information, and knowledge of the world, she</li>
<li class="L10329" rel="L10329">must have received benefit of greater importance.</li>
<li class="L10330" rel="L10330"></li>
<li class="L10331" rel="L10331">But no such happy marriage could now teach the admiring multitude what</li>
<li class="L10332" rel="L10332">connubial felicity really was. An union of a different tendency, and</li>
<li class="L10333" rel="L10333">precluding the possibility of the other, was soon to be formed in their</li>
<li class="L10334" rel="L10334">family.</li>
<li class="L10335" rel="L10335"></li>
<li class="L10336" rel="L10336">How Wickham and Lydia were to be supported in tolerable independence,</li>
<li class="L10337" rel="L10337">she could not imagine. But how little of permanent happiness could</li>
<li class="L10338" rel="L10338">belong to a couple who were only brought together because their passions</li>
<li class="L10339" rel="L10339">were stronger than their virtue, she could easily conjecture.</li>
<li class="L10340" rel="L10340"></li>
<li class="L10341" rel="L10341">                          * * * * *</li>
<li class="L10342" rel="L10342"></li>
<li class="L10343" rel="L10343">Mr. Gardiner soon wrote again to his brother. To Mr. Bennet&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10344" rel="L10344">acknowledgments he briefly replied, with assurance of his eagerness to</li>
<li class="L10345" rel="L10345">promote the welfare of any of his family; and concluded with entreaties</li>
<li class="L10346" rel="L10346">that the subject might never be mentioned to him again. The principal</li>
<li class="L10347" rel="L10347">purport of his letter was to inform them that Mr. Wickham had resolved</li>
<li class="L10348" rel="L10348">on quitting the militia.</li>
<li class="L10349" rel="L10349"></li>
<li class="L10350" rel="L10350">“It was greatly my wish that he should do so,” he added, “as soon as</li>
<li class="L10351" rel="L10351">his marriage was fixed on. And I think you will agree with me, in</li>
<li class="L10352" rel="L10352">considering the removal from that corps as highly advisable, both on</li>
<li class="L10353" rel="L10353">his account and my niece&#39;s. It is Mr. Wickham&#39;s intention to go into</li>
<li class="L10354" rel="L10354">the regulars; and among his former friends, there are still some who</li>
<li class="L10355" rel="L10355">are able and willing to assist him in the army. He has the promise of an</li>
<li class="L10356" rel="L10356">ensigncy in General ----&#39;s regiment, now quartered in the North. It</li>
<li class="L10357" rel="L10357">is an advantage to have it so far from this part of the kingdom. He</li>
<li class="L10358" rel="L10358">promises fairly; and I hope among different people, where they may each</li>
<li class="L10359" rel="L10359">have a character to preserve, they will both be more prudent. I have</li>
<li class="L10360" rel="L10360">written to Colonel Forster, to inform him of our present arrangements,</li>
<li class="L10361" rel="L10361">and to request that he will satisfy the various creditors of Mr. Wickham</li>
<li class="L10362" rel="L10362">in and near Brighton, with assurances of speedy payment, for which I</li>
<li class="L10363" rel="L10363">have pledged myself. And will you give yourself the trouble of carrying</li>
<li class="L10364" rel="L10364">similar assurances to his creditors in Meryton, of whom I shall subjoin</li>
<li class="L10365" rel="L10365">a list according to his information? He has given in all his debts; I</li>
<li class="L10366" rel="L10366">hope at least he has not deceived us. Haggerston has our directions,</li>
<li class="L10367" rel="L10367">and all will be completed in a week. They will then join his regiment,</li>
<li class="L10368" rel="L10368">unless they are first invited to Longbourn; and I understand from Mrs.</li>
<li class="L10369" rel="L10369">Gardiner, that my niece is very desirous of seeing you all before she</li>
<li class="L10370" rel="L10370">leaves the South. She is well, and begs to be dutifully remembered to</li>
<li class="L10371" rel="L10371">you and her mother.--Yours, etc.,</li>
<li class="L10372" rel="L10372"></li>
<li class="L10373" rel="L10373">“E. GARDINER.”</li>
<li class="L10374" rel="L10374"></li>
<li class="L10375" rel="L10375">Mr. Bennet and his daughters saw all the advantages of Wickham&#39;s removal</li>
<li class="L10376" rel="L10376">from the ----shire as clearly as Mr. Gardiner could do. But Mrs. Bennet</li>
<li class="L10377" rel="L10377">was not so well pleased with it. Lydia&#39;s being settled in the North,</li>
<li class="L10378" rel="L10378">just when she had expected most pleasure and pride in her company,</li>
<li class="L10379" rel="L10379">for she had by no means given up her plan of their residing in</li>
<li class="L10380" rel="L10380">Hertfordshire, was a severe disappointment; and, besides, it was such a</li>
<li class="L10381" rel="L10381">pity that Lydia should be taken from a regiment where she was acquainted</li>
<li class="L10382" rel="L10382">with everybody, and had so many favourites.</li>
<li class="L10383" rel="L10383"></li>
<li class="L10384" rel="L10384">“She is so fond of Mrs. Forster,” said she, “it will be quite shocking</li>
<li class="L10385" rel="L10385">to send her away! And there are several of the young men, too, that she</li>
<li class="L10386" rel="L10386">likes very much. The officers may not be so pleasant in General ----&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10387" rel="L10387">regiment.”</li>
<li class="L10388" rel="L10388"></li>
<li class="L10389" rel="L10389">His daughter&#39;s request, for such it might be considered, of being</li>
<li class="L10390" rel="L10390">admitted into her family again before she set off for the North,</li>
<li class="L10391" rel="L10391">received at first an absolute negative. But Jane and Elizabeth,</li>
<li class="L10392" rel="L10392">who agreed in wishing, for the sake of their sister&#39;s feelings and</li>
<li class="L10393" rel="L10393">consequence, that she should be noticed on her marriage by her parents,</li>
<li class="L10394" rel="L10394">urged him so earnestly yet so rationally and so mildly, to receive her</li>
<li class="L10395" rel="L10395">and her husband at Longbourn, as soon as they were married, that he was</li>
<li class="L10396" rel="L10396">prevailed on to think as they thought, and act as they wished. And their</li>
<li class="L10397" rel="L10397">mother had the satisfaction of knowing that she would be able to show</li>
<li class="L10398" rel="L10398">her married daughter in the neighbourhood before she was banished to the</li>
<li class="L10399" rel="L10399">North. When Mr. Bennet wrote again to his brother, therefore, he sent</li>
<li class="L10400" rel="L10400">his permission for them to come; and it was settled, that as soon as</li>
<li class="L10401" rel="L10401">the ceremony was over, they should proceed to Longbourn. Elizabeth was</li>
<li class="L10402" rel="L10402">surprised, however, that Wickham should consent to such a scheme, and</li>
<li class="L10403" rel="L10403">had she consulted only her own inclination, any meeting with him would</li>
<li class="L10404" rel="L10404">have been the last object of her wishes.</li>
<li class="L10405" rel="L10405"></li>
<li class="L10406" rel="L10406"></li>
<li class="L10407" rel="L10407"></li>
<li class="L10408" rel="L10408">Chapter 51</li>
<li class="L10409" rel="L10409"></li>
<li class="L10410" rel="L10410"></li>
<li class="L10411" rel="L10411">Their sister&#39;s wedding day arrived; and Jane and Elizabeth felt for her</li>
<li class="L10412" rel="L10412">probably more than she felt for herself. The carriage was sent to</li>
<li class="L10413" rel="L10413">meet them at ----, and they were to return in it by dinner-time. Their</li>
<li class="L10414" rel="L10414">arrival was dreaded by the elder Miss Bennets, and Jane more especially,</li>
<li class="L10415" rel="L10415">who gave Lydia the feelings which would have attended herself, had she</li>
<li class="L10416" rel="L10416">been the culprit, and was wretched in the thought of what her sister</li>
<li class="L10417" rel="L10417">must endure.</li>
<li class="L10418" rel="L10418"></li>
<li class="L10419" rel="L10419">They came. The family were assembled in the breakfast room to receive</li>
<li class="L10420" rel="L10420">them. Smiles decked the face of Mrs. Bennet as the carriage drove up to</li>
<li class="L10421" rel="L10421">the door; her husband looked impenetrably grave; her daughters, alarmed,</li>
<li class="L10422" rel="L10422">anxious, uneasy.</li>
<li class="L10423" rel="L10423"></li>
<li class="L10424" rel="L10424">Lydia&#39;s voice was heard in the vestibule; the door was thrown open, and</li>
<li class="L10425" rel="L10425">she ran into the room. Her mother stepped forwards, embraced her, and</li>
<li class="L10426" rel="L10426">welcomed her with rapture; gave her hand, with an affectionate smile,</li>
<li class="L10427" rel="L10427">to Wickham, who followed his lady; and wished them both joy with an</li>
<li class="L10428" rel="L10428">alacrity which shewed no doubt of their happiness.</li>
<li class="L10429" rel="L10429"></li>
<li class="L10430" rel="L10430">Their reception from Mr. Bennet, to whom they then turned, was not quite</li>
<li class="L10431" rel="L10431">so cordial. His countenance rather gained in austerity; and he scarcely</li>
<li class="L10432" rel="L10432">opened his lips. The easy assurance of the young couple, indeed, was</li>
<li class="L10433" rel="L10433">enough to provoke him. Elizabeth was disgusted, and even Miss Bennet</li>
<li class="L10434" rel="L10434">was shocked. Lydia was Lydia still; untamed, unabashed, wild, noisy,</li>
<li class="L10435" rel="L10435">and fearless. She turned from sister to sister, demanding their</li>
<li class="L10436" rel="L10436">congratulations; and when at length they all sat down, looked eagerly</li>
<li class="L10437" rel="L10437">round the room, took notice of some little alteration in it, and</li>
<li class="L10438" rel="L10438">observed, with a laugh, that it was a great while since she had been</li>
<li class="L10439" rel="L10439">there.</li>
<li class="L10440" rel="L10440"></li>
<li class="L10441" rel="L10441">Wickham was not at all more distressed than herself, but his manners</li>
<li class="L10442" rel="L10442">were always so pleasing, that had his character and his marriage been</li>
<li class="L10443" rel="L10443">exactly what they ought, his smiles and his easy address, while he</li>
<li class="L10444" rel="L10444">claimed their relationship, would have delighted them all. Elizabeth had</li>
<li class="L10445" rel="L10445">not before believed him quite equal to such assurance; but she sat down,</li>
<li class="L10446" rel="L10446">resolving within herself to draw no limits in future to the impudence</li>
<li class="L10447" rel="L10447">of an impudent man. She blushed, and Jane blushed; but the cheeks of the</li>
<li class="L10448" rel="L10448">two who caused their confusion suffered no variation of colour.</li>
<li class="L10449" rel="L10449"></li>
<li class="L10450" rel="L10450">There was no want of discourse. The bride and her mother could neither</li>
<li class="L10451" rel="L10451">of them talk fast enough; and Wickham, who happened to sit near</li>
<li class="L10452" rel="L10452">Elizabeth, began inquiring after his acquaintance in that neighbourhood,</li>
<li class="L10453" rel="L10453">with a good humoured ease which she felt very unable to equal in her</li>
<li class="L10454" rel="L10454">replies. They seemed each of them to have the happiest memories in the</li>
<li class="L10455" rel="L10455">world. Nothing of the past was recollected with pain; and Lydia led</li>
<li class="L10456" rel="L10456">voluntarily to subjects which her sisters would not have alluded to for</li>
<li class="L10457" rel="L10457">the world.</li>
<li class="L10458" rel="L10458"></li>
<li class="L10459" rel="L10459">“Only think of its being three months,” she cried, “since I went away;</li>
<li class="L10460" rel="L10460">it seems but a fortnight I declare; and yet there have been things</li>
<li class="L10461" rel="L10461">enough happened in the time. Good gracious! when I went away, I am sure</li>
<li class="L10462" rel="L10462">I had no more idea of being married till I came back again! though I</li>
<li class="L10463" rel="L10463">thought it would be very good fun if I was.”</li>
<li class="L10464" rel="L10464"></li>
<li class="L10465" rel="L10465">Her father lifted up his eyes. Jane was distressed. Elizabeth looked</li>
<li class="L10466" rel="L10466">expressively at Lydia; but she, who never heard nor saw anything of</li>
<li class="L10467" rel="L10467">which she chose to be insensible, gaily continued, “Oh! mamma, do the</li>
<li class="L10468" rel="L10468">people hereabouts know I am married to-day? I was afraid they might not;</li>
<li class="L10469" rel="L10469">and we overtook William Goulding in his curricle, so I was determined he</li>
<li class="L10470" rel="L10470">should know it, and so I let down the side-glass next to him, and took</li>
<li class="L10471" rel="L10471">off my glove, and let my hand just rest upon the window frame, so that</li>
<li class="L10472" rel="L10472">he might see the ring, and then I bowed and smiled like anything.”</li>
<li class="L10473" rel="L10473"></li>
<li class="L10474" rel="L10474">Elizabeth could bear it no longer. She got up, and ran out of the room;</li>
<li class="L10475" rel="L10475">and returned no more, till she heard them passing through the hall to</li>
<li class="L10476" rel="L10476">the dining parlour. She then joined them soon enough to see Lydia, with</li>
<li class="L10477" rel="L10477">anxious parade, walk up to her mother&#39;s right hand, and hear her say</li>
<li class="L10478" rel="L10478">to her eldest sister, “Ah! Jane, I take your place now, and you must go</li>
<li class="L10479" rel="L10479">lower, because I am a married woman.”</li>
<li class="L10480" rel="L10480"></li>
<li class="L10481" rel="L10481">It was not to be supposed that time would give Lydia that embarrassment</li>
<li class="L10482" rel="L10482">from which she had been so wholly free at first. Her ease and good</li>
<li class="L10483" rel="L10483">spirits increased. She longed to see Mrs. Phillips, the Lucases, and</li>
<li class="L10484" rel="L10484">all their other neighbours, and to hear herself called “Mrs. Wickham”</li>
<li class="L10485" rel="L10485"> by each of them; and in the mean time, she went after dinner to show her</li>
<li class="L10486" rel="L10486">ring, and boast of being married, to Mrs. Hill and the two housemaids.</li>
<li class="L10487" rel="L10487"></li>
<li class="L10488" rel="L10488">“Well, mamma,” said she, when they were all returned to the breakfast</li>
<li class="L10489" rel="L10489">room, “and what do you think of my husband? Is not he a charming man? I</li>
<li class="L10490" rel="L10490">am sure my sisters must all envy me. I only hope they may have half</li>
<li class="L10491" rel="L10491">my good luck. They must all go to Brighton. That is the place to get</li>
<li class="L10492" rel="L10492">husbands. What a pity it is, mamma, we did not all go.”</li>
<li class="L10493" rel="L10493"></li>
<li class="L10494" rel="L10494">“Very true; and if I had my will, we should. But my dear Lydia, I don&#39;t</li>
<li class="L10495" rel="L10495">at all like your going such a way off. Must it be so?”</li>
<li class="L10496" rel="L10496"></li>
<li class="L10497" rel="L10497">“Oh, lord! yes;--there is nothing in that. I shall like it of all</li>
<li class="L10498" rel="L10498">things. You and papa, and my sisters, must come down and see us. We</li>
<li class="L10499" rel="L10499">shall be at Newcastle all the winter, and I dare say there will be some</li>
<li class="L10500" rel="L10500">balls, and I will take care to get good partners for them all.”</li>
<li class="L10501" rel="L10501"></li>
<li class="L10502" rel="L10502">“I should like it beyond anything!” said her mother.</li>
<li class="L10503" rel="L10503"></li>
<li class="L10504" rel="L10504">“And then when you go away, you may leave one or two of my sisters</li>
<li class="L10505" rel="L10505">behind you; and I dare say I shall get husbands for them before the</li>
<li class="L10506" rel="L10506">winter is over.”</li>
<li class="L10507" rel="L10507"></li>
<li class="L10508" rel="L10508">“I thank you for my share of the favour,” said Elizabeth; “but I do not</li>
<li class="L10509" rel="L10509">particularly like your way of getting husbands.”</li>
<li class="L10510" rel="L10510"></li>
<li class="L10511" rel="L10511">Their visitors were not to remain above ten days with them. Mr. Wickham</li>
<li class="L10512" rel="L10512">had received his commission before he left London, and he was to join</li>
<li class="L10513" rel="L10513">his regiment at the end of a fortnight.</li>
<li class="L10514" rel="L10514"></li>
<li class="L10515" rel="L10515">No one but Mrs. Bennet regretted that their stay would be so short; and</li>
<li class="L10516" rel="L10516">she made the most of the time by visiting about with her daughter, and</li>
<li class="L10517" rel="L10517">having very frequent parties at home. These parties were acceptable to</li>
<li class="L10518" rel="L10518">all; to avoid a family circle was even more desirable to such as did</li>
<li class="L10519" rel="L10519">think, than such as did not.</li>
<li class="L10520" rel="L10520"></li>
<li class="L10521" rel="L10521">Wickham&#39;s affection for Lydia was just what Elizabeth had expected</li>
<li class="L10522" rel="L10522">to find it; not equal to Lydia&#39;s for him. She had scarcely needed her</li>
<li class="L10523" rel="L10523">present observation to be satisfied, from the reason of things, that</li>
<li class="L10524" rel="L10524">their elopement had been brought on by the strength of her love, rather</li>
<li class="L10525" rel="L10525">than by his; and she would have wondered why, without violently caring</li>
<li class="L10526" rel="L10526">for her, he chose to elope with her at all, had she not felt certain</li>
<li class="L10527" rel="L10527">that his flight was rendered necessary by distress of circumstances; and</li>
<li class="L10528" rel="L10528">if that were the case, he was not the young man to resist an opportunity</li>
<li class="L10529" rel="L10529">of having a companion.</li>
<li class="L10530" rel="L10530"></li>
<li class="L10531" rel="L10531">Lydia was exceedingly fond of him. He was her dear Wickham on every</li>
<li class="L10532" rel="L10532">occasion; no one was to be put in competition with him. He did every</li>
<li class="L10533" rel="L10533">thing best in the world; and she was sure he would kill more birds on</li>
<li class="L10534" rel="L10534">the first of September, than any body else in the country.</li>
<li class="L10535" rel="L10535"></li>
<li class="L10536" rel="L10536">One morning, soon after their arrival, as she was sitting with her two</li>
<li class="L10537" rel="L10537">elder sisters, she said to Elizabeth:</li>
<li class="L10538" rel="L10538"></li>
<li class="L10539" rel="L10539">“Lizzy, I never gave _you_ an account of my wedding, I believe. You</li>
<li class="L10540" rel="L10540">were not by, when I told mamma and the others all about it. Are not you</li>
<li class="L10541" rel="L10541">curious to hear how it was managed?”</li>
<li class="L10542" rel="L10542"></li>
<li class="L10543" rel="L10543">“No really,” replied Elizabeth; “I think there cannot be too little said</li>
<li class="L10544" rel="L10544">on the subject.”</li>
<li class="L10545" rel="L10545"></li>
<li class="L10546" rel="L10546">“La! You are so strange! But I must tell you how it went off. We were</li>
<li class="L10547" rel="L10547">married, you know, at St. Clement&#39;s, because Wickham&#39;s lodgings were in</li>
<li class="L10548" rel="L10548">that parish. And it was settled that we should all be there by eleven</li>
<li class="L10549" rel="L10549">o&#39;clock. My uncle and aunt and I were to go together; and the others</li>
<li class="L10550" rel="L10550">were to meet us at the church. Well, Monday morning came, and I was in</li>
<li class="L10551" rel="L10551">such a fuss! I was so afraid, you know, that something would happen to</li>
<li class="L10552" rel="L10552">put it off, and then I should have gone quite distracted. And there was</li>
<li class="L10553" rel="L10553">my aunt, all the time I was dressing, preaching and talking away just as</li>
<li class="L10554" rel="L10554">if she was reading a sermon. However, I did not hear above one word in</li>
<li class="L10555" rel="L10555">ten, for I was thinking, you may suppose, of my dear Wickham. I longed</li>
<li class="L10556" rel="L10556">to know whether he would be married in his blue coat.”</li>
<li class="L10557" rel="L10557"></li>
<li class="L10558" rel="L10558">“Well, and so we breakfasted at ten as usual; I thought it would never</li>
<li class="L10559" rel="L10559">be over; for, by the bye, you are to understand, that my uncle and aunt</li>
<li class="L10560" rel="L10560">were horrid unpleasant all the time I was with them. If you&#39;ll believe</li>
<li class="L10561" rel="L10561">me, I did not once put my foot out of doors, though I was there a</li>
<li class="L10562" rel="L10562">fortnight. Not one party, or scheme, or anything. To be sure London was</li>
<li class="L10563" rel="L10563">rather thin, but, however, the Little Theatre was open. Well, and so</li>
<li class="L10564" rel="L10564">just as the carriage came to the door, my uncle was called away upon</li>
<li class="L10565" rel="L10565">business to that horrid man Mr. Stone. And then, you know, when once</li>
<li class="L10566" rel="L10566">they get together, there is no end of it. Well, I was so frightened I</li>
<li class="L10567" rel="L10567">did not know what to do, for my uncle was to give me away; and if we</li>
<li class="L10568" rel="L10568">were beyond the hour, we could not be married all day. But, luckily, he</li>
<li class="L10569" rel="L10569">came back again in ten minutes&#39; time, and then we all set out. However,</li>
<li class="L10570" rel="L10570">I recollected afterwards that if he had been prevented going, the</li>
<li class="L10571" rel="L10571">wedding need not be put off, for Mr. Darcy might have done as well.”</li>
<li class="L10572" rel="L10572"></li>
<li class="L10573" rel="L10573">“Mr. Darcy!” repeated Elizabeth, in utter amazement.</li>
<li class="L10574" rel="L10574"></li>
<li class="L10575" rel="L10575">“Oh, yes!--he was to come there with Wickham, you know. But gracious</li>
<li class="L10576" rel="L10576">me! I quite forgot! I ought not to have said a word about it. I promised</li>
<li class="L10577" rel="L10577">them so faithfully! What will Wickham say? It was to be such a secret!”</li>
<li class="L10578" rel="L10578"></li>
<li class="L10579" rel="L10579">“If it was to be secret,” said Jane, “say not another word on the</li>
<li class="L10580" rel="L10580">subject. You may depend upon my seeking no further.”</li>
<li class="L10581" rel="L10581"></li>
<li class="L10582" rel="L10582">“Oh! certainly,” said Elizabeth, though burning with curiosity; “we will</li>
<li class="L10583" rel="L10583">ask you no questions.”</li>
<li class="L10584" rel="L10584"></li>
<li class="L10585" rel="L10585">“Thank you,” said Lydia, “for if you did, I should certainly tell you</li>
<li class="L10586" rel="L10586">all, and then Wickham would be angry.”</li>
<li class="L10587" rel="L10587"></li>
<li class="L10588" rel="L10588">On such encouragement to ask, Elizabeth was forced to put it out of her</li>
<li class="L10589" rel="L10589">power, by running away.</li>
<li class="L10590" rel="L10590"></li>
<li class="L10591" rel="L10591">But to live in ignorance on such a point was impossible; or at least</li>
<li class="L10592" rel="L10592">it was impossible not to try for information. Mr. Darcy had been at</li>
<li class="L10593" rel="L10593">her sister&#39;s wedding. It was exactly a scene, and exactly among people,</li>
<li class="L10594" rel="L10594">where he had apparently least to do, and least temptation to go.</li>
<li class="L10595" rel="L10595">Conjectures as to the meaning of it, rapid and wild, hurried into her</li>
<li class="L10596" rel="L10596">brain; but she was satisfied with none. Those that best pleased her, as</li>
<li class="L10597" rel="L10597">placing his conduct in the noblest light, seemed most improbable. She</li>
<li class="L10598" rel="L10598">could not bear such suspense; and hastily seizing a sheet of paper,</li>
<li class="L10599" rel="L10599">wrote a short letter to her aunt, to request an explanation of what</li>
<li class="L10600" rel="L10600">Lydia had dropt, if it were compatible with the secrecy which had been</li>
<li class="L10601" rel="L10601">intended.</li>
<li class="L10602" rel="L10602"></li>
<li class="L10603" rel="L10603">“You may readily comprehend,” she added, “what my curiosity must be</li>
<li class="L10604" rel="L10604">to know how a person unconnected with any of us, and (comparatively</li>
<li class="L10605" rel="L10605">speaking) a stranger to our family, should have been amongst you at such</li>
<li class="L10606" rel="L10606">a time. Pray write instantly, and let me understand it--unless it is,</li>
<li class="L10607" rel="L10607">for very cogent reasons, to remain in the secrecy which Lydia seems</li>
<li class="L10608" rel="L10608">to think necessary; and then I must endeavour to be satisfied with</li>
<li class="L10609" rel="L10609">ignorance.”</li>
<li class="L10610" rel="L10610"></li>
<li class="L10611" rel="L10611">“Not that I _shall_, though,” she added to herself, as she finished</li>
<li class="L10612" rel="L10612">the letter; “and my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable</li>
<li class="L10613" rel="L10613">manner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it</li>
<li class="L10614" rel="L10614">out.”</li>
<li class="L10615" rel="L10615"></li>
<li class="L10616" rel="L10616">Jane&#39;s delicate sense of honour would not allow her to speak to</li>
<li class="L10617" rel="L10617">Elizabeth privately of what Lydia had let fall; Elizabeth was glad</li>
<li class="L10618" rel="L10618">of it;--till it appeared whether her inquiries would receive any</li>
<li class="L10619" rel="L10619">satisfaction, she had rather be without a confidante.</li>
<li class="L10620" rel="L10620"></li>
<li class="L10621" rel="L10621"></li>
<li class="L10622" rel="L10622"></li>
<li class="L10623" rel="L10623">Chapter 52</li>
<li class="L10624" rel="L10624"></li>
<li class="L10625" rel="L10625"></li>
<li class="L10626" rel="L10626">Elizabeth had the satisfaction of receiving an answer to her letter as</li>
<li class="L10627" rel="L10627">soon as she possibly could. She was no sooner in possession of it</li>
<li class="L10628" rel="L10628">than, hurrying into the little copse, where she was least likely to</li>
<li class="L10629" rel="L10629">be interrupted, she sat down on one of the benches and prepared to</li>
<li class="L10630" rel="L10630">be happy; for the length of the letter convinced her that it did not</li>
<li class="L10631" rel="L10631">contain a denial.</li>
<li class="L10632" rel="L10632"></li>
<li class="L10633" rel="L10633">“Gracechurch street, Sept. 6.</li>
<li class="L10634" rel="L10634"></li>
<li class="L10635" rel="L10635">“MY DEAR NIECE,</li>
<li class="L10636" rel="L10636"></li>
<li class="L10637" rel="L10637">“I have just received your letter, and shall devote this whole morning</li>
<li class="L10638" rel="L10638">to answering it, as I foresee that a _little_ writing will not comprise</li>
<li class="L10639" rel="L10639">what I have to tell you. I must confess myself surprised by your</li>
<li class="L10640" rel="L10640">application; I did not expect it from _you_. Don&#39;t think me angry,</li>
<li class="L10641" rel="L10641">however, for I only mean to let you know that I had not imagined such</li>
<li class="L10642" rel="L10642">inquiries to be necessary on _your_ side. If you do not choose to</li>
<li class="L10643" rel="L10643">understand me, forgive my impertinence. Your uncle is as much surprised</li>
<li class="L10644" rel="L10644">as I am--and nothing but the belief of your being a party concerned</li>
<li class="L10645" rel="L10645">would have allowed him to act as he has done. But if you are really</li>
<li class="L10646" rel="L10646">innocent and ignorant, I must be more explicit.</li>
<li class="L10647" rel="L10647"></li>
<li class="L10648" rel="L10648">“On the very day of my coming home from Longbourn, your uncle had a most</li>
<li class="L10649" rel="L10649">unexpected visitor. Mr. Darcy called, and was shut up with him several</li>
<li class="L10650" rel="L10650">hours. It was all over before I arrived; so my curiosity was not so</li>
<li class="L10651" rel="L10651">dreadfully racked as _yours_ seems to have been. He came to tell Mr.</li>
<li class="L10652" rel="L10652">Gardiner that he had found out where your sister and Mr. Wickham were,</li>
<li class="L10653" rel="L10653">and that he had seen and talked with them both; Wickham repeatedly,</li>
<li class="L10654" rel="L10654">Lydia once. From what I can collect, he left Derbyshire only one day</li>
<li class="L10655" rel="L10655">after ourselves, and came to town with the resolution of hunting for</li>
<li class="L10656" rel="L10656">them. The motive professed was his conviction of its being owing to</li>
<li class="L10657" rel="L10657">himself that Wickham&#39;s worthlessness had not been so well known as to</li>
<li class="L10658" rel="L10658">make it impossible for any young woman of character to love or confide</li>
<li class="L10659" rel="L10659">in him. He generously imputed the whole to his mistaken pride, and</li>
<li class="L10660" rel="L10660">confessed that he had before thought it beneath him to lay his private</li>
<li class="L10661" rel="L10661">actions open to the world. His character was to speak for itself. He</li>
<li class="L10662" rel="L10662">called it, therefore, his duty to step forward, and endeavour to remedy</li>
<li class="L10663" rel="L10663">an evil which had been brought on by himself. If he _had another_</li>
<li class="L10664" rel="L10664">motive, I am sure it would never disgrace him. He had been some days</li>
<li class="L10665" rel="L10665">in town, before he was able to discover them; but he had something to</li>
<li class="L10666" rel="L10666">direct his search, which was more than _we_ had; and the consciousness</li>
<li class="L10667" rel="L10667">of this was another reason for his resolving to follow us.</li>
<li class="L10668" rel="L10668"></li>
<li class="L10669" rel="L10669">“There is a lady, it seems, a Mrs. Younge, who was some time ago</li>
<li class="L10670" rel="L10670">governess to Miss Darcy, and was dismissed from her charge on some cause</li>
<li class="L10671" rel="L10671">of disapprobation, though he did not say what. She then took a large</li>
<li class="L10672" rel="L10672">house in Edward-street, and has since maintained herself by letting</li>
<li class="L10673" rel="L10673">lodgings. This Mrs. Younge was, he knew, intimately acquainted with</li>
<li class="L10674" rel="L10674">Wickham; and he went to her for intelligence of him as soon as he got to</li>
<li class="L10675" rel="L10675">town. But it was two or three days before he could get from her what he</li>
<li class="L10676" rel="L10676">wanted. She would not betray her trust, I suppose, without bribery and</li>
<li class="L10677" rel="L10677">corruption, for she really did know where her friend was to be found.</li>
<li class="L10678" rel="L10678">Wickham indeed had gone to her on their first arrival in London, and had</li>
<li class="L10679" rel="L10679">she been able to receive them into her house, they would have taken up</li>
<li class="L10680" rel="L10680">their abode with her. At length, however, our kind friend procured the</li>
<li class="L10681" rel="L10681">wished-for direction. They were in ---- street. He saw Wickham, and</li>
<li class="L10682" rel="L10682">afterwards insisted on seeing Lydia. His first object with her, he</li>
<li class="L10683" rel="L10683">acknowledged, had been to persuade her to quit her present disgraceful</li>
<li class="L10684" rel="L10684">situation, and return to her friends as soon as they could be prevailed</li>
<li class="L10685" rel="L10685">on to receive her, offering his assistance, as far as it would go. But</li>
<li class="L10686" rel="L10686">he found Lydia absolutely resolved on remaining where she was. She cared</li>
<li class="L10687" rel="L10687">for none of her friends; she wanted no help of his; she would not hear</li>
<li class="L10688" rel="L10688">of leaving Wickham. She was sure they should be married some time or</li>
<li class="L10689" rel="L10689">other, and it did not much signify when. Since such were her feelings,</li>
<li class="L10690" rel="L10690">it only remained, he thought, to secure and expedite a marriage, which,</li>
<li class="L10691" rel="L10691">in his very first conversation with Wickham, he easily learnt had never</li>
<li class="L10692" rel="L10692">been _his_ design. He confessed himself obliged to leave the regiment,</li>
<li class="L10693" rel="L10693">on account of some debts of honour, which were very pressing; and</li>
<li class="L10694" rel="L10694">scrupled not to lay all the ill-consequences of Lydia&#39;s flight on her</li>
<li class="L10695" rel="L10695">own folly alone. He meant to resign his commission immediately; and as</li>
<li class="L10696" rel="L10696">to his future situation, he could conjecture very little about it. He</li>
<li class="L10697" rel="L10697">must go somewhere, but he did not know where, and he knew he should have</li>
<li class="L10698" rel="L10698">nothing to live on.</li>
<li class="L10699" rel="L10699"></li>
<li class="L10700" rel="L10700">“Mr. Darcy asked him why he had not married your sister at once. Though</li>
<li class="L10701" rel="L10701">Mr. Bennet was not imagined to be very rich, he would have been able</li>
<li class="L10702" rel="L10702">to do something for him, and his situation must have been benefited by</li>
<li class="L10703" rel="L10703">marriage. But he found, in reply to this question, that Wickham still</li>
<li class="L10704" rel="L10704">cherished the hope of more effectually making his fortune by marriage in</li>
<li class="L10705" rel="L10705">some other country. Under such circumstances, however, he was not likely</li>
<li class="L10706" rel="L10706">to be proof against the temptation of immediate relief.</li>
<li class="L10707" rel="L10707"></li>
<li class="L10708" rel="L10708">“They met several times, for there was much to be discussed. Wickham of</li>
<li class="L10709" rel="L10709">course wanted more than he could get; but at length was reduced to be</li>
<li class="L10710" rel="L10710">reasonable.</li>
<li class="L10711" rel="L10711"></li>
<li class="L10712" rel="L10712">“Every thing being settled between _them_, Mr. Darcy&#39;s next step was to</li>
<li class="L10713" rel="L10713">make your uncle acquainted with it, and he first called in Gracechurch</li>
<li class="L10714" rel="L10714">street the evening before I came home. But Mr. Gardiner could not be</li>
<li class="L10715" rel="L10715">seen, and Mr. Darcy found, on further inquiry, that your father was</li>
<li class="L10716" rel="L10716">still with him, but would quit town the next morning. He did not judge</li>
<li class="L10717" rel="L10717">your father to be a person whom he could so properly consult as your</li>
<li class="L10718" rel="L10718">uncle, and therefore readily postponed seeing him till after the</li>
<li class="L10719" rel="L10719">departure of the former. He did not leave his name, and till the next</li>
<li class="L10720" rel="L10720">day it was only known that a gentleman had called on business.</li>
<li class="L10721" rel="L10721"></li>
<li class="L10722" rel="L10722">“On Saturday he came again. Your father was gone, your uncle at home,</li>
<li class="L10723" rel="L10723">and, as I said before, they had a great deal of talk together.</li>
<li class="L10724" rel="L10724"></li>
<li class="L10725" rel="L10725">“They met again on Sunday, and then _I_ saw him too. It was not all</li>
<li class="L10726" rel="L10726">settled before Monday: as soon as it was, the express was sent off to</li>
<li class="L10727" rel="L10727">Longbourn. But our visitor was very obstinate. I fancy, Lizzy, that</li>
<li class="L10728" rel="L10728">obstinacy is the real defect of his character, after all. He has been</li>
<li class="L10729" rel="L10729">accused of many faults at different times, but _this_ is the true one.</li>
<li class="L10730" rel="L10730">Nothing was to be done that he did not do himself; though I am sure (and</li>
<li class="L10731" rel="L10731">I do not speak it to be thanked, therefore say nothing about it), your</li>
<li class="L10732" rel="L10732">uncle would most readily have settled the whole.</li>
<li class="L10733" rel="L10733"></li>
<li class="L10734" rel="L10734">“They battled it together for a long time, which was more than either</li>
<li class="L10735" rel="L10735">the gentleman or lady concerned in it deserved. But at last your uncle</li>
<li class="L10736" rel="L10736">was forced to yield, and instead of being allowed to be of use to his</li>
<li class="L10737" rel="L10737">niece, was forced to put up with only having the probable credit of it,</li>
<li class="L10738" rel="L10738">which went sorely against the grain; and I really believe your letter</li>
<li class="L10739" rel="L10739">this morning gave him great pleasure, because it required an explanation</li>
<li class="L10740" rel="L10740">that would rob him of his borrowed feathers, and give the praise where</li>
<li class="L10741" rel="L10741">it was due. But, Lizzy, this must go no farther than yourself, or Jane</li>
<li class="L10742" rel="L10742">at most.</li>
<li class="L10743" rel="L10743"></li>
<li class="L10744" rel="L10744">“You know pretty well, I suppose, what has been done for the young</li>
<li class="L10745" rel="L10745">people. His debts are to be paid, amounting, I believe, to considerably</li>
<li class="L10746" rel="L10746">more than a thousand pounds, another thousand in addition to her own</li>
<li class="L10747" rel="L10747">settled upon _her_, and his commission purchased. The reason why all</li>
<li class="L10748" rel="L10748">this was to be done by him alone, was such as I have given above. It</li>
<li class="L10749" rel="L10749">was owing to him, to his reserve and want of proper consideration, that</li>
<li class="L10750" rel="L10750">Wickham&#39;s character had been so misunderstood, and consequently that he</li>
<li class="L10751" rel="L10751">had been received and noticed as he was. Perhaps there was some truth</li>
<li class="L10752" rel="L10752">in _this_; though I doubt whether _his_ reserve, or _anybody&#39;s_ reserve,</li>
<li class="L10753" rel="L10753">can be answerable for the event. But in spite of all this fine talking,</li>
<li class="L10754" rel="L10754">my dear Lizzy, you may rest perfectly assured that your uncle would</li>
<li class="L10755" rel="L10755">never have yielded, if we had not given him credit for _another</li>
<li class="L10756" rel="L10756">interest_ in the affair.</li>
<li class="L10757" rel="L10757"></li>
<li class="L10758" rel="L10758">“When all this was resolved on, he returned again to his friends, who</li>
<li class="L10759" rel="L10759">were still staying at Pemberley; but it was agreed that he should be in</li>
<li class="L10760" rel="L10760">London once more when the wedding took place, and all money matters were</li>
<li class="L10761" rel="L10761">then to receive the last finish.</li>
<li class="L10762" rel="L10762"></li>
<li class="L10763" rel="L10763">“I believe I have now told you every thing. It is a relation which</li>
<li class="L10764" rel="L10764">you tell me is to give you great surprise; I hope at least it will not</li>
<li class="L10765" rel="L10765">afford you any displeasure. Lydia came to us; and Wickham had constant</li>
<li class="L10766" rel="L10766">admission to the house. _He_ was exactly what he had been, when I</li>
<li class="L10767" rel="L10767">knew him in Hertfordshire; but I would not tell you how little I was</li>
<li class="L10768" rel="L10768">satisfied with her behaviour while she staid with us, if I had not</li>
<li class="L10769" rel="L10769">perceived, by Jane&#39;s letter last Wednesday, that her conduct on coming</li>
<li class="L10770" rel="L10770">home was exactly of a piece with it, and therefore what I now tell</li>
<li class="L10771" rel="L10771">you can give you no fresh pain. I talked to her repeatedly in the most</li>
<li class="L10772" rel="L10772">serious manner, representing to her all the wickedness of what she had</li>
<li class="L10773" rel="L10773">done, and all the unhappiness she had brought on her family. If she</li>
<li class="L10774" rel="L10774">heard me, it was by good luck, for I am sure she did not listen. I was</li>
<li class="L10775" rel="L10775">sometimes quite provoked, but then I recollected my dear Elizabeth and</li>
<li class="L10776" rel="L10776">Jane, and for their sakes had patience with her.</li>
<li class="L10777" rel="L10777"></li>
<li class="L10778" rel="L10778">“Mr. Darcy was punctual in his return, and as Lydia informed you,</li>
<li class="L10779" rel="L10779">attended the wedding. He dined with us the next day, and was to leave</li>
<li class="L10780" rel="L10780">town again on Wednesday or Thursday. Will you be very angry with me, my</li>
<li class="L10781" rel="L10781">dear Lizzy, if I take this opportunity of saying (what I was never bold</li>
<li class="L10782" rel="L10782">enough to say before) how much I like him. His behaviour to us has,</li>
<li class="L10783" rel="L10783">in every respect, been as pleasing as when we were in Derbyshire. His</li>
<li class="L10784" rel="L10784">understanding and opinions all please me; he wants nothing but a little</li>
<li class="L10785" rel="L10785">more liveliness, and _that_, if he marry _prudently_, his wife may teach</li>
<li class="L10786" rel="L10786">him. I thought him very sly;--he hardly ever mentioned your name. But</li>
<li class="L10787" rel="L10787">slyness seems the fashion.</li>
<li class="L10788" rel="L10788"></li>
<li class="L10789" rel="L10789">“Pray forgive me if I have been very presuming, or at least do not</li>
<li class="L10790" rel="L10790">punish me so far as to exclude me from P. I shall never be quite happy</li>
<li class="L10791" rel="L10791">till I have been all round the park. A low phaeton, with a nice little</li>
<li class="L10792" rel="L10792">pair of ponies, would be the very thing.</li>
<li class="L10793" rel="L10793"></li>
<li class="L10794" rel="L10794">“But I must write no more. The children have been wanting me this half</li>
<li class="L10795" rel="L10795">hour.</li>
<li class="L10796" rel="L10796"></li>
<li class="L10797" rel="L10797">“Yours, very sincerely,</li>
<li class="L10798" rel="L10798"></li>
<li class="L10799" rel="L10799">“M. GARDINER.”</li>
<li class="L10800" rel="L10800"></li>
<li class="L10801" rel="L10801">The contents of this letter threw Elizabeth into a flutter of spirits,</li>
<li class="L10802" rel="L10802">in which it was difficult to determine whether pleasure or pain bore the</li>
<li class="L10803" rel="L10803">greatest share. The vague and unsettled suspicions which uncertainty had</li>
<li class="L10804" rel="L10804">produced of what Mr. Darcy might have been doing to forward her sister&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10805" rel="L10805">match, which she had feared to encourage as an exertion of goodness too</li>
<li class="L10806" rel="L10806">great to be probable, and at the same time dreaded to be just, from the</li>
<li class="L10807" rel="L10807">pain of obligation, were proved beyond their greatest extent to be true!</li>
<li class="L10808" rel="L10808">He had followed them purposely to town, he had taken on himself all</li>
<li class="L10809" rel="L10809">the trouble and mortification attendant on such a research; in which</li>
<li class="L10810" rel="L10810">supplication had been necessary to a woman whom he must abominate and</li>
<li class="L10811" rel="L10811">despise, and where he was reduced to meet, frequently meet, reason</li>
<li class="L10812" rel="L10812">with, persuade, and finally bribe, the man whom he always most wished to</li>
<li class="L10813" rel="L10813">avoid, and whose very name it was punishment to him to pronounce. He had</li>
<li class="L10814" rel="L10814">done all this for a girl whom he could neither regard nor esteem. Her</li>
<li class="L10815" rel="L10815">heart did whisper that he had done it for her. But it was a hope shortly</li>
<li class="L10816" rel="L10816">checked by other considerations, and she soon felt that even her vanity</li>
<li class="L10817" rel="L10817">was insufficient, when required to depend on his affection for her--for</li>
<li class="L10818" rel="L10818">a woman who had already refused him--as able to overcome a sentiment so</li>
<li class="L10819" rel="L10819">natural as abhorrence against relationship with Wickham. Brother-in-law</li>
<li class="L10820" rel="L10820">of Wickham! Every kind of pride must revolt from the connection. He had,</li>
<li class="L10821" rel="L10821">to be sure, done much. She was ashamed to think how much. But he had</li>
<li class="L10822" rel="L10822">given a reason for his interference, which asked no extraordinary</li>
<li class="L10823" rel="L10823">stretch of belief. It was reasonable that he should feel he had been</li>
<li class="L10824" rel="L10824">wrong; he had liberality, and he had the means of exercising it; and</li>
<li class="L10825" rel="L10825">though she would not place herself as his principal inducement, she</li>
<li class="L10826" rel="L10826">could, perhaps, believe that remaining partiality for her might assist</li>
<li class="L10827" rel="L10827">his endeavours in a cause where her peace of mind must be materially</li>
<li class="L10828" rel="L10828">concerned. It was painful, exceedingly painful, to know that they were</li>
<li class="L10829" rel="L10829">under obligations to a person who could never receive a return. They</li>
<li class="L10830" rel="L10830">owed the restoration of Lydia, her character, every thing, to him. Oh!</li>
<li class="L10831" rel="L10831">how heartily did she grieve over every ungracious sensation she had ever</li>
<li class="L10832" rel="L10832">encouraged, every saucy speech she had ever directed towards him. For</li>
<li class="L10833" rel="L10833">herself she was humbled; but she was proud of him. Proud that in a cause</li>
<li class="L10834" rel="L10834">of compassion and honour, he had been able to get the better of himself.</li>
<li class="L10835" rel="L10835">She read over her aunt&#39;s commendation of him again and again. It</li>
<li class="L10836" rel="L10836">was hardly enough; but it pleased her. She was even sensible of some</li>
<li class="L10837" rel="L10837">pleasure, though mixed with regret, on finding how steadfastly both she</li>
<li class="L10838" rel="L10838">and her uncle had been persuaded that affection and confidence subsisted</li>
<li class="L10839" rel="L10839">between Mr. Darcy and herself.</li>
<li class="L10840" rel="L10840"></li>
<li class="L10841" rel="L10841">She was roused from her seat, and her reflections, by some one&#39;s</li>
<li class="L10842" rel="L10842">approach; and before she could strike into another path, she was</li>
<li class="L10843" rel="L10843">overtaken by Wickham.</li>
<li class="L10844" rel="L10844"></li>
<li class="L10845" rel="L10845">“I am afraid I interrupt your solitary ramble, my dear sister?” said he,</li>
<li class="L10846" rel="L10846">as he joined her.</li>
<li class="L10847" rel="L10847"></li>
<li class="L10848" rel="L10848">“You certainly do,” she replied with a smile; “but it does not follow</li>
<li class="L10849" rel="L10849">that the interruption must be unwelcome.”</li>
<li class="L10850" rel="L10850"></li>
<li class="L10851" rel="L10851">“I should be sorry indeed, if it were. We were always good friends; and</li>
<li class="L10852" rel="L10852">now we are better.”</li>
<li class="L10853" rel="L10853"></li>
<li class="L10854" rel="L10854">“True. Are the others coming out?”</li>
<li class="L10855" rel="L10855"></li>
<li class="L10856" rel="L10856">“I do not know. Mrs. Bennet and Lydia are going in the carriage to</li>
<li class="L10857" rel="L10857">Meryton. And so, my dear sister, I find, from our uncle and aunt, that</li>
<li class="L10858" rel="L10858">you have actually seen Pemberley.”</li>
<li class="L10859" rel="L10859"></li>
<li class="L10860" rel="L10860">She replied in the affirmative.</li>
<li class="L10861" rel="L10861"></li>
<li class="L10862" rel="L10862">“I almost envy you the pleasure, and yet I believe it would be too much</li>
<li class="L10863" rel="L10863">for me, or else I could take it in my way to Newcastle. And you saw the</li>
<li class="L10864" rel="L10864">old housekeeper, I suppose? Poor Reynolds, she was always very fond of</li>
<li class="L10865" rel="L10865">me. But of course she did not mention my name to you.”</li>
<li class="L10866" rel="L10866"></li>
<li class="L10867" rel="L10867">“Yes, she did.”</li>
<li class="L10868" rel="L10868"></li>
<li class="L10869" rel="L10869">“And what did she say?”</li>
<li class="L10870" rel="L10870"></li>
<li class="L10871" rel="L10871">“That you were gone into the army, and she was afraid had--not turned</li>
<li class="L10872" rel="L10872">out well. At such a distance as _that_, you know, things are strangely</li>
<li class="L10873" rel="L10873">misrepresented.”</li>
<li class="L10874" rel="L10874"></li>
<li class="L10875" rel="L10875">“Certainly,” he replied, biting his lips. Elizabeth hoped she had</li>
<li class="L10876" rel="L10876">silenced him; but he soon afterwards said:</li>
<li class="L10877" rel="L10877"></li>
<li class="L10878" rel="L10878">“I was surprised to see Darcy in town last month. We passed each other</li>
<li class="L10879" rel="L10879">several times. I wonder what he can be doing there.”</li>
<li class="L10880" rel="L10880"></li>
<li class="L10881" rel="L10881">“Perhaps preparing for his marriage with Miss de Bourgh,” said</li>
<li class="L10882" rel="L10882">Elizabeth. “It must be something particular, to take him there at this</li>
<li class="L10883" rel="L10883">time of year.”</li>
<li class="L10884" rel="L10884"></li>
<li class="L10885" rel="L10885">“Undoubtedly. Did you see him while you were at Lambton? I thought I</li>
<li class="L10886" rel="L10886">understood from the Gardiners that you had.”</li>
<li class="L10887" rel="L10887"></li>
<li class="L10888" rel="L10888">“Yes; he introduced us to his sister.”</li>
<li class="L10889" rel="L10889"></li>
<li class="L10890" rel="L10890">“And do you like her?”</li>
<li class="L10891" rel="L10891"></li>
<li class="L10892" rel="L10892">“Very much.”</li>
<li class="L10893" rel="L10893"></li>
<li class="L10894" rel="L10894">“I have heard, indeed, that she is uncommonly improved within this year</li>
<li class="L10895" rel="L10895">or two. When I last saw her, she was not very promising. I am very glad</li>
<li class="L10896" rel="L10896">you liked her. I hope she will turn out well.”</li>
<li class="L10897" rel="L10897"></li>
<li class="L10898" rel="L10898">“I dare say she will; she has got over the most trying age.”</li>
<li class="L10899" rel="L10899"></li>
<li class="L10900" rel="L10900">“Did you go by the village of Kympton?”</li>
