<li class="L10901" rel="L10901"></li>
<li class="L10902" rel="L10902">“I do not recollect that we did.”</li>
<li class="L10903" rel="L10903"></li>
<li class="L10904" rel="L10904">“I mention it, because it is the living which I ought to have had. A</li>
<li class="L10905" rel="L10905">most delightful place!--Excellent Parsonage House! It would have suited</li>
<li class="L10906" rel="L10906">me in every respect.”</li>
<li class="L10907" rel="L10907"></li>
<li class="L10908" rel="L10908">“How should you have liked making sermons?”</li>
<li class="L10909" rel="L10909"></li>
<li class="L10910" rel="L10910">“Exceedingly well. I should have considered it as part of my duty,</li>
<li class="L10911" rel="L10911">and the exertion would soon have been nothing. One ought not to</li>
<li class="L10912" rel="L10912">repine;--but, to be sure, it would have been such a thing for me! The</li>
<li class="L10913" rel="L10913">quiet, the retirement of such a life would have answered all my ideas</li>
<li class="L10914" rel="L10914">of happiness! But it was not to be. Did you ever hear Darcy mention the</li>
<li class="L10915" rel="L10915">circumstance, when you were in Kent?”</li>
<li class="L10916" rel="L10916"></li>
<li class="L10917" rel="L10917">“I have heard from authority, which I thought _as good_, that it was</li>
<li class="L10918" rel="L10918">left you conditionally only, and at the will of the present patron.”</li>
<li class="L10919" rel="L10919"></li>
<li class="L10920" rel="L10920">“You have. Yes, there was something in _that_; I told you so from the</li>
<li class="L10921" rel="L10921">first, you may remember.”</li>
<li class="L10922" rel="L10922"></li>
<li class="L10923" rel="L10923">“I _did_ hear, too, that there was a time, when sermon-making was not</li>
<li class="L10924" rel="L10924">so palatable to you as it seems to be at present; that you actually</li>
<li class="L10925" rel="L10925">declared your resolution of never taking orders, and that the business</li>
<li class="L10926" rel="L10926">had been compromised accordingly.”</li>
<li class="L10927" rel="L10927"></li>
<li class="L10928" rel="L10928">“You did! and it was not wholly without foundation. You may remember</li>
<li class="L10929" rel="L10929">what I told you on that point, when first we talked of it.”</li>
<li class="L10930" rel="L10930"></li>
<li class="L10931" rel="L10931">They were now almost at the door of the house, for she had walked fast</li>
<li class="L10932" rel="L10932">to get rid of him; and unwilling, for her sister&#39;s sake, to provoke him,</li>
<li class="L10933" rel="L10933">she only said in reply, with a good-humoured smile:</li>
<li class="L10934" rel="L10934"></li>
<li class="L10935" rel="L10935">“Come, Mr. Wickham, we are brother and sister, you know. Do not let</li>
<li class="L10936" rel="L10936">us quarrel about the past. In future, I hope we shall be always of one</li>
<li class="L10937" rel="L10937">mind.”</li>
<li class="L10938" rel="L10938"></li>
<li class="L10939" rel="L10939">She held out her hand; he kissed it with affectionate gallantry, though</li>
<li class="L10940" rel="L10940">he hardly knew how to look, and they entered the house.</li>
<li class="L10941" rel="L10941"></li>
<li class="L10942" rel="L10942"></li>
<li class="L10943" rel="L10943"></li>
<li class="L10944" rel="L10944">Chapter 53</li>
<li class="L10945" rel="L10945"></li>
<li class="L10946" rel="L10946"></li>
<li class="L10947" rel="L10947">Mr. Wickham was so perfectly satisfied with this conversation that he</li>
<li class="L10948" rel="L10948">never again distressed himself, or provoked his dear sister Elizabeth,</li>
<li class="L10949" rel="L10949">by introducing the subject of it; and she was pleased to find that she</li>
<li class="L10950" rel="L10950">had said enough to keep him quiet.</li>
<li class="L10951" rel="L10951"></li>
<li class="L10952" rel="L10952">The day of his and Lydia&#39;s departure soon came, and Mrs. Bennet was</li>
<li class="L10953" rel="L10953">forced to submit to a separation, which, as her husband by no means</li>
<li class="L10954" rel="L10954">entered into her scheme of their all going to Newcastle, was likely to</li>
<li class="L10955" rel="L10955">continue at least a twelvemonth.</li>
<li class="L10956" rel="L10956"></li>
<li class="L10957" rel="L10957">“Oh! my dear Lydia,” she cried, “when shall we meet again?”</li>
<li class="L10958" rel="L10958"></li>
<li class="L10959" rel="L10959">“Oh, lord! I don&#39;t know. Not these two or three years, perhaps.”</li>
<li class="L10960" rel="L10960"></li>
<li class="L10961" rel="L10961">“Write to me very often, my dear.”</li>
<li class="L10962" rel="L10962"></li>
<li class="L10963" rel="L10963">“As often as I can. But you know married women have never much time for</li>
<li class="L10964" rel="L10964">writing. My sisters may write to _me_. They will have nothing else to</li>
<li class="L10965" rel="L10965">do.”</li>
<li class="L10966" rel="L10966"></li>
<li class="L10967" rel="L10967">Mr. Wickham&#39;s adieus were much more affectionate than his wife&#39;s. He</li>
<li class="L10968" rel="L10968">smiled, looked handsome, and said many pretty things.</li>
<li class="L10969" rel="L10969"></li>
<li class="L10970" rel="L10970">“He is as fine a fellow,” said Mr. Bennet, as soon as they were out of</li>
<li class="L10971" rel="L10971">the house, “as ever I saw. He simpers, and smirks, and makes love to</li>
<li class="L10972" rel="L10972">us all. I am prodigiously proud of him. I defy even Sir William Lucas</li>
<li class="L10973" rel="L10973">himself to produce a more valuable son-in-law.”</li>
<li class="L10974" rel="L10974"></li>
<li class="L10975" rel="L10975">The loss of her daughter made Mrs. Bennet very dull for several days.</li>
<li class="L10976" rel="L10976"></li>
<li class="L10977" rel="L10977">“I often think,” said she, “that there is nothing so bad as parting with</li>
<li class="L10978" rel="L10978">one&#39;s friends. One seems so forlorn without them.”</li>
<li class="L10979" rel="L10979"></li>
<li class="L10980" rel="L10980">“This is the consequence, you see, Madam, of marrying a daughter,” said</li>
<li class="L10981" rel="L10981">Elizabeth. “It must make you better satisfied that your other four are</li>
<li class="L10982" rel="L10982">single.”</li>
<li class="L10983" rel="L10983"></li>
<li class="L10984" rel="L10984">“It is no such thing. Lydia does not leave me because she is married,</li>
<li class="L10985" rel="L10985">but only because her husband&#39;s regiment happens to be so far off. If</li>
<li class="L10986" rel="L10986">that had been nearer, she would not have gone so soon.”</li>
<li class="L10987" rel="L10987"></li>
<li class="L10988" rel="L10988">But the spiritless condition which this event threw her into was shortly</li>
<li class="L10989" rel="L10989">relieved, and her mind opened again to the agitation of hope, by an</li>
<li class="L10990" rel="L10990">article of news which then began to be in circulation. The housekeeper</li>
<li class="L10991" rel="L10991">at Netherfield had received orders to prepare for the arrival of her</li>
<li class="L10992" rel="L10992">master, who was coming down in a day or two, to shoot there for several</li>
<li class="L10993" rel="L10993">weeks. Mrs. Bennet was quite in the fidgets. She looked at Jane, and</li>
<li class="L10994" rel="L10994">smiled and shook her head by turns.</li>
<li class="L10995" rel="L10995"></li>
<li class="L10996" rel="L10996">“Well, well, and so Mr. Bingley is coming down, sister,” (for Mrs.</li>
<li class="L10997" rel="L10997">Phillips first brought her the news). “Well, so much the better. Not</li>
<li class="L10998" rel="L10998">that I care about it, though. He is nothing to us, you know, and I am</li>
<li class="L10999" rel="L10999">sure _I_ never want to see him again. But, however, he is very welcome</li>
<li class="L11000" rel="L11000">to come to Netherfield, if he likes it. And who knows what _may_ happen?</li>
<li class="L11001" rel="L11001">But that is nothing to us. You know, sister, we agreed long ago never to</li>
<li class="L11002" rel="L11002">mention a word about it. And so, is it quite certain he is coming?”</li>
<li class="L11003" rel="L11003"></li>
<li class="L11004" rel="L11004">“You may depend on it,” replied the other, “for Mrs. Nicholls was in</li>
<li class="L11005" rel="L11005">Meryton last night; I saw her passing by, and went out myself on purpose</li>
<li class="L11006" rel="L11006">to know the truth of it; and she told me that it was certain true. He</li>
<li class="L11007" rel="L11007">comes down on Thursday at the latest, very likely on Wednesday. She was</li>
<li class="L11008" rel="L11008">going to the butcher&#39;s, she told me, on purpose to order in some meat on</li>
<li class="L11009" rel="L11009">Wednesday, and she has got three couple of ducks just fit to be killed.”</li>
<li class="L11010" rel="L11010"></li>
<li class="L11011" rel="L11011">Miss Bennet had not been able to hear of his coming without changing</li>
<li class="L11012" rel="L11012">colour. It was many months since she had mentioned his name to</li>
<li class="L11013" rel="L11013">Elizabeth; but now, as soon as they were alone together, she said:</li>
<li class="L11014" rel="L11014"></li>
<li class="L11015" rel="L11015">“I saw you look at me to-day, Lizzy, when my aunt told us of the present</li>
<li class="L11016" rel="L11016">report; and I know I appeared distressed. But don&#39;t imagine it was from</li>
<li class="L11017" rel="L11017">any silly cause. I was only confused for the moment, because I felt that</li>
<li class="L11018" rel="L11018">I _should_ be looked at. I do assure you that the news does not affect</li>
<li class="L11019" rel="L11019">me either with pleasure or pain. I am glad of one thing, that he comes</li>
<li class="L11020" rel="L11020">alone; because we shall see the less of him. Not that I am afraid of</li>
<li class="L11021" rel="L11021">_myself_, but I dread other people&#39;s remarks.”</li>
<li class="L11022" rel="L11022"></li>
<li class="L11023" rel="L11023">Elizabeth did not know what to make of it. Had she not seen him in</li>
<li class="L11024" rel="L11024">Derbyshire, she might have supposed him capable of coming there with no</li>
<li class="L11025" rel="L11025">other view than what was acknowledged; but she still thought him partial</li>
<li class="L11026" rel="L11026">to Jane, and she wavered as to the greater probability of his coming</li>
<li class="L11027" rel="L11027">there _with_ his friend&#39;s permission, or being bold enough to come</li>
<li class="L11028" rel="L11028">without it.</li>
<li class="L11029" rel="L11029"></li>
<li class="L11030" rel="L11030">“Yet it is hard,” she sometimes thought, “that this poor man cannot</li>
<li class="L11031" rel="L11031">come to a house which he has legally hired, without raising all this</li>
<li class="L11032" rel="L11032">speculation! I _will_ leave him to himself.”</li>
<li class="L11033" rel="L11033"></li>
<li class="L11034" rel="L11034">In spite of what her sister declared, and really believed to be her</li>
<li class="L11035" rel="L11035">feelings in the expectation of his arrival, Elizabeth could easily</li>
<li class="L11036" rel="L11036">perceive that her spirits were affected by it. They were more disturbed,</li>
<li class="L11037" rel="L11037">more unequal, than she had often seen them.</li>
<li class="L11038" rel="L11038"></li>
<li class="L11039" rel="L11039">The subject which had been so warmly canvassed between their parents,</li>
<li class="L11040" rel="L11040">about a twelvemonth ago, was now brought forward again.</li>
<li class="L11041" rel="L11041"></li>
<li class="L11042" rel="L11042">“As soon as ever Mr. Bingley comes, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “you</li>
<li class="L11043" rel="L11043">will wait on him of course.”</li>
<li class="L11044" rel="L11044"></li>
<li class="L11045" rel="L11045">“No, no. You forced me into visiting him last year, and promised, if I</li>
<li class="L11046" rel="L11046">went to see him, he should marry one of my daughters. But it ended in</li>
<li class="L11047" rel="L11047">nothing, and I will not be sent on a fool&#39;s errand again.”</li>
<li class="L11048" rel="L11048"></li>
<li class="L11049" rel="L11049">His wife represented to him how absolutely necessary such an attention</li>
<li class="L11050" rel="L11050">would be from all the neighbouring gentlemen, on his returning to</li>
<li class="L11051" rel="L11051">Netherfield.</li>
<li class="L11052" rel="L11052"></li>
<li class="L11053" rel="L11053">“&#39;Tis an etiquette I despise,” said he. “If he wants our society,</li>
<li class="L11054" rel="L11054">let him seek it. He knows where we live. I will not spend my hours</li>
<li class="L11055" rel="L11055">in running after my neighbours every time they go away and come back</li>
<li class="L11056" rel="L11056">again.”</li>
<li class="L11057" rel="L11057"></li>
<li class="L11058" rel="L11058">“Well, all I know is, that it will be abominably rude if you do not wait</li>
<li class="L11059" rel="L11059">on him. But, however, that shan&#39;t prevent my asking him to dine here, I</li>
<li class="L11060" rel="L11060">am determined. We must have Mrs. Long and the Gouldings soon. That will</li>
<li class="L11061" rel="L11061">make thirteen with ourselves, so there will be just room at table for</li>
<li class="L11062" rel="L11062">him.”</li>
<li class="L11063" rel="L11063"></li>
<li class="L11064" rel="L11064">Consoled by this resolution, she was the better able to bear her</li>
<li class="L11065" rel="L11065">husband&#39;s incivility; though it was very mortifying to know that her</li>
<li class="L11066" rel="L11066">neighbours might all see Mr. Bingley, in consequence of it, before</li>
<li class="L11067" rel="L11067">_they_ did. As the day of his arrival drew near,--</li>
<li class="L11068" rel="L11068"></li>
<li class="L11069" rel="L11069">“I begin to be sorry that he comes at all,” said Jane to her sister. “It</li>
<li class="L11070" rel="L11070">would be nothing; I could see him with perfect indifference, but I can</li>
<li class="L11071" rel="L11071">hardly bear to hear it thus perpetually talked of. My mother means well;</li>
<li class="L11072" rel="L11072">but she does not know, no one can know, how much I suffer from what she</li>
<li class="L11073" rel="L11073">says. Happy shall I be, when his stay at Netherfield is over!”</li>
<li class="L11074" rel="L11074"></li>
<li class="L11075" rel="L11075">“I wish I could say anything to comfort you,” replied Elizabeth; “but it</li>
<li class="L11076" rel="L11076">is wholly out of my power. You must feel it; and the usual satisfaction</li>
<li class="L11077" rel="L11077">of preaching patience to a sufferer is denied me, because you have</li>
<li class="L11078" rel="L11078">always so much.”</li>
<li class="L11079" rel="L11079"></li>
<li class="L11080" rel="L11080">Mr. Bingley arrived. Mrs. Bennet, through the assistance of servants,</li>
<li class="L11081" rel="L11081">contrived to have the earliest tidings of it, that the period of anxiety</li>
<li class="L11082" rel="L11082">and fretfulness on her side might be as long as it could. She counted</li>
<li class="L11083" rel="L11083">the days that must intervene before their invitation could be sent;</li>
<li class="L11084" rel="L11084">hopeless of seeing him before. But on the third morning after his</li>
<li class="L11085" rel="L11085">arrival in Hertfordshire, she saw him, from her dressing-room window,</li>
<li class="L11086" rel="L11086">enter the paddock and ride towards the house.</li>
<li class="L11087" rel="L11087"></li>
<li class="L11088" rel="L11088">Her daughters were eagerly called to partake of her joy. Jane resolutely</li>
<li class="L11089" rel="L11089">kept her place at the table; but Elizabeth, to satisfy her mother, went</li>
<li class="L11090" rel="L11090">to the window--she looked,--she saw Mr. Darcy with him, and sat down</li>
<li class="L11091" rel="L11091">again by her sister.</li>
<li class="L11092" rel="L11092"></li>
<li class="L11093" rel="L11093">“There is a gentleman with him, mamma,” said Kitty; “who can it be?”</li>
<li class="L11094" rel="L11094"></li>
<li class="L11095" rel="L11095">“Some acquaintance or other, my dear, I suppose; I am sure I do not</li>
<li class="L11096" rel="L11096">know.”</li>
<li class="L11097" rel="L11097"></li>
<li class="L11098" rel="L11098">“La!” replied Kitty, “it looks just like that man that used to be with</li>
<li class="L11099" rel="L11099">him before. Mr. what&#39;s-his-name. That tall, proud man.”</li>
<li class="L11100" rel="L11100"></li>
<li class="L11101" rel="L11101">“Good gracious! Mr. Darcy!--and so it does, I vow. Well, any friend of</li>
<li class="L11102" rel="L11102">Mr. Bingley&#39;s will always be welcome here, to be sure; but else I must</li>
<li class="L11103" rel="L11103">say that I hate the very sight of him.”</li>
<li class="L11104" rel="L11104"></li>
<li class="L11105" rel="L11105">Jane looked at Elizabeth with surprise and concern. She knew but little</li>
<li class="L11106" rel="L11106">of their meeting in Derbyshire, and therefore felt for the awkwardness</li>
<li class="L11107" rel="L11107">which must attend her sister, in seeing him almost for the first time</li>
<li class="L11108" rel="L11108">after receiving his explanatory letter. Both sisters were uncomfortable</li>
<li class="L11109" rel="L11109">enough. Each felt for the other, and of course for themselves; and their</li>
<li class="L11110" rel="L11110">mother talked on, of her dislike of Mr. Darcy, and her resolution to be</li>
<li class="L11111" rel="L11111">civil to him only as Mr. Bingley&#39;s friend, without being heard by either</li>
<li class="L11112" rel="L11112">of them. But Elizabeth had sources of uneasiness which could not be</li>
<li class="L11113" rel="L11113">suspected by Jane, to whom she had never yet had courage to shew Mrs.</li>
<li class="L11114" rel="L11114">Gardiner&#39;s letter, or to relate her own change of sentiment towards him.</li>
<li class="L11115" rel="L11115">To Jane, he could be only a man whose proposals she had refused,</li>
<li class="L11116" rel="L11116">and whose merit she had undervalued; but to her own more extensive</li>
<li class="L11117" rel="L11117">information, he was the person to whom the whole family were indebted</li>
<li class="L11118" rel="L11118">for the first of benefits, and whom she regarded herself with an</li>
<li class="L11119" rel="L11119">interest, if not quite so tender, at least as reasonable and just as</li>
<li class="L11120" rel="L11120">what Jane felt for Bingley. Her astonishment at his coming--at his</li>
<li class="L11121" rel="L11121">coming to Netherfield, to Longbourn, and voluntarily seeking her again,</li>
<li class="L11122" rel="L11122">was almost equal to what she had known on first witnessing his altered</li>
<li class="L11123" rel="L11123">behaviour in Derbyshire.</li>
<li class="L11124" rel="L11124"></li>
<li class="L11125" rel="L11125">The colour which had been driven from her face, returned for half a</li>
<li class="L11126" rel="L11126">minute with an additional glow, and a smile of delight added lustre to</li>
<li class="L11127" rel="L11127">her eyes, as she thought for that space of time that his affection and</li>
<li class="L11128" rel="L11128">wishes must still be unshaken. But she would not be secure.</li>
<li class="L11129" rel="L11129"></li>
<li class="L11130" rel="L11130">“Let me first see how he behaves,” said she; “it will then be early</li>
<li class="L11131" rel="L11131">enough for expectation.”</li>
<li class="L11132" rel="L11132"></li>
<li class="L11133" rel="L11133">She sat intently at work, striving to be composed, and without daring to</li>
<li class="L11134" rel="L11134">lift up her eyes, till anxious curiosity carried them to the face of</li>
<li class="L11135" rel="L11135">her sister as the servant was approaching the door. Jane looked a little</li>
<li class="L11136" rel="L11136">paler than usual, but more sedate than Elizabeth had expected. On the</li>
<li class="L11137" rel="L11137">gentlemen&#39;s appearing, her colour increased; yet she received them with</li>
<li class="L11138" rel="L11138">tolerable ease, and with a propriety of behaviour equally free from any</li>
<li class="L11139" rel="L11139">symptom of resentment or any unnecessary complaisance.</li>
<li class="L11140" rel="L11140"></li>
<li class="L11141" rel="L11141">Elizabeth said as little to either as civility would allow, and sat down</li>
<li class="L11142" rel="L11142">again to her work, with an eagerness which it did not often command. She</li>
<li class="L11143" rel="L11143">had ventured only one glance at Darcy. He looked serious, as usual; and,</li>
<li class="L11144" rel="L11144">she thought, more as he had been used to look in Hertfordshire, than as</li>
<li class="L11145" rel="L11145">she had seen him at Pemberley. But, perhaps he could not in her mother&#39;s</li>
<li class="L11146" rel="L11146">presence be what he was before her uncle and aunt. It was a painful, but</li>
<li class="L11147" rel="L11147">not an improbable, conjecture.</li>
<li class="L11148" rel="L11148"></li>
<li class="L11149" rel="L11149">Bingley, she had likewise seen for an instant, and in that short period</li>
<li class="L11150" rel="L11150">saw him looking both pleased and embarrassed. He was received by Mrs.</li>
<li class="L11151" rel="L11151">Bennet with a degree of civility which made her two daughters ashamed,</li>
<li class="L11152" rel="L11152">especially when contrasted with the cold and ceremonious politeness of</li>
<li class="L11153" rel="L11153">her curtsey and address to his friend.</li>
<li class="L11154" rel="L11154"></li>
<li class="L11155" rel="L11155">Elizabeth, particularly, who knew that her mother owed to the latter</li>
<li class="L11156" rel="L11156">the preservation of her favourite daughter from irremediable infamy,</li>
<li class="L11157" rel="L11157">was hurt and distressed to a most painful degree by a distinction so ill</li>
<li class="L11158" rel="L11158">applied.</li>
<li class="L11159" rel="L11159"></li>
<li class="L11160" rel="L11160">Darcy, after inquiring of her how Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner did, a question</li>
<li class="L11161" rel="L11161">which she could not answer without confusion, said scarcely anything. He</li>
<li class="L11162" rel="L11162">was not seated by her; perhaps that was the reason of his silence; but</li>
<li class="L11163" rel="L11163">it had not been so in Derbyshire. There he had talked to her friends,</li>
<li class="L11164" rel="L11164">when he could not to herself. But now several minutes elapsed without</li>
<li class="L11165" rel="L11165">bringing the sound of his voice; and when occasionally, unable to resist</li>
<li class="L11166" rel="L11166">the impulse of curiosity, she raised her eyes to his face, she as often</li>
<li class="L11167" rel="L11167">found him looking at Jane as at herself, and frequently on no object but</li>
<li class="L11168" rel="L11168">the ground. More thoughtfulness and less anxiety to please, than when</li>
<li class="L11169" rel="L11169">they last met, were plainly expressed. She was disappointed, and angry</li>
<li class="L11170" rel="L11170">with herself for being so.</li>
<li class="L11171" rel="L11171"></li>
<li class="L11172" rel="L11172">“Could I expect it to be otherwise!” said she. “Yet why did he come?”</li>
<li class="L11173" rel="L11173"></li>
<li class="L11174" rel="L11174">She was in no humour for conversation with anyone but himself; and to</li>
<li class="L11175" rel="L11175">him she had hardly courage to speak.</li>
<li class="L11176" rel="L11176"></li>
<li class="L11177" rel="L11177">She inquired after his sister, but could do no more.</li>
<li class="L11178" rel="L11178"></li>
<li class="L11179" rel="L11179">“It is a long time, Mr. Bingley, since you went away,” said Mrs. Bennet.</li>
<li class="L11180" rel="L11180"></li>
<li class="L11181" rel="L11181">He readily agreed to it.</li>
<li class="L11182" rel="L11182"></li>
<li class="L11183" rel="L11183">“I began to be afraid you would never come back again. People _did_ say</li>
<li class="L11184" rel="L11184">you meant to quit the place entirely at Michaelmas; but, however, I hope</li>
<li class="L11185" rel="L11185">it is not true. A great many changes have happened in the neighbourhood,</li>
<li class="L11186" rel="L11186">since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled. And one of my</li>
<li class="L11187" rel="L11187">own daughters. I suppose you have heard of it; indeed, you must have</li>
<li class="L11188" rel="L11188">seen it in the papers. It was in The Times and The Courier, I know;</li>
<li class="L11189" rel="L11189">though it was not put in as it ought to be. It was only said, &#39;Lately,</li>
<li class="L11190" rel="L11190">George Wickham, Esq. to Miss Lydia Bennet,&#39; without there being a</li>
<li class="L11191" rel="L11191">syllable said of her father, or the place where she lived, or anything.</li>
<li class="L11192" rel="L11192">It was my brother Gardiner&#39;s drawing up too, and I wonder how he came to</li>
<li class="L11193" rel="L11193">make such an awkward business of it. Did you see it?”</li>
<li class="L11194" rel="L11194"></li>
<li class="L11195" rel="L11195">Bingley replied that he did, and made his congratulations. Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L11196" rel="L11196">dared not lift up her eyes. How Mr. Darcy looked, therefore, she could</li>
<li class="L11197" rel="L11197">not tell.</li>
<li class="L11198" rel="L11198"></li>
<li class="L11199" rel="L11199">“It is a delightful thing, to be sure, to have a daughter well married,”</li>
<li class="L11200" rel="L11200"> continued her mother, “but at the same time, Mr. Bingley, it is very</li>
<li class="L11201" rel="L11201">hard to have her taken such a way from me. They are gone down to</li>
<li class="L11202" rel="L11202">Newcastle, a place quite northward, it seems, and there they are to stay</li>
<li class="L11203" rel="L11203">I do not know how long. His regiment is there; for I suppose you have</li>
<li class="L11204" rel="L11204">heard of his leaving the ----shire, and of his being gone into the</li>
<li class="L11205" rel="L11205">regulars. Thank Heaven! he has _some_ friends, though perhaps not so</li>
<li class="L11206" rel="L11206">many as he deserves.”</li>
<li class="L11207" rel="L11207"></li>
<li class="L11208" rel="L11208">Elizabeth, who knew this to be levelled at Mr. Darcy, was in such</li>
<li class="L11209" rel="L11209">misery of shame, that she could hardly keep her seat. It drew from her,</li>
<li class="L11210" rel="L11210">however, the exertion of speaking, which nothing else had so effectually</li>
<li class="L11211" rel="L11211">done before; and she asked Bingley whether he meant to make any stay in</li>
<li class="L11212" rel="L11212">the country at present. A few weeks, he believed.</li>
<li class="L11213" rel="L11213"></li>
<li class="L11214" rel="L11214">“When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley,” said her mother,</li>
<li class="L11215" rel="L11215">“I beg you will come here, and shoot as many as you please on Mr.</li>
<li class="L11216" rel="L11216">Bennet&#39;s manor. I am sure he will be vastly happy to oblige you, and</li>
<li class="L11217" rel="L11217">will save all the best of the covies for you.”</li>
<li class="L11218" rel="L11218"></li>
<li class="L11219" rel="L11219">Elizabeth&#39;s misery increased, at such unnecessary, such officious</li>
<li class="L11220" rel="L11220">attention! Were the same fair prospect to arise at present as had</li>
<li class="L11221" rel="L11221">flattered them a year ago, every thing, she was persuaded, would be</li>
<li class="L11222" rel="L11222">hastening to the same vexatious conclusion. At that instant, she felt</li>
<li class="L11223" rel="L11223">that years of happiness could not make Jane or herself amends for</li>
<li class="L11224" rel="L11224">moments of such painful confusion.</li>
<li class="L11225" rel="L11225"></li>
<li class="L11226" rel="L11226">“The first wish of my heart,” said she to herself, “is never more to</li>
<li class="L11227" rel="L11227">be in company with either of them. Their society can afford no pleasure</li>
<li class="L11228" rel="L11228">that will atone for such wretchedness as this! Let me never see either</li>
<li class="L11229" rel="L11229">one or the other again!”</li>
<li class="L11230" rel="L11230"></li>
<li class="L11231" rel="L11231">Yet the misery, for which years of happiness were to offer no</li>
<li class="L11232" rel="L11232">compensation, received soon afterwards material relief, from observing</li>
<li class="L11233" rel="L11233">how much the beauty of her sister re-kindled the admiration of her</li>
<li class="L11234" rel="L11234">former lover. When first he came in, he had spoken to her but little;</li>
<li class="L11235" rel="L11235">but every five minutes seemed to be giving her more of his attention. He</li>
<li class="L11236" rel="L11236">found her as handsome as she had been last year; as good natured, and</li>
<li class="L11237" rel="L11237">as unaffected, though not quite so chatty. Jane was anxious that no</li>
<li class="L11238" rel="L11238">difference should be perceived in her at all, and was really persuaded</li>
<li class="L11239" rel="L11239">that she talked as much as ever. But her mind was so busily engaged,</li>
<li class="L11240" rel="L11240">that she did not always know when she was silent.</li>
<li class="L11241" rel="L11241"></li>
<li class="L11242" rel="L11242">When the gentlemen rose to go away, Mrs. Bennet was mindful of her</li>
<li class="L11243" rel="L11243">intended civility, and they were invited and engaged to dine at</li>
<li class="L11244" rel="L11244">Longbourn in a few days time.</li>
<li class="L11245" rel="L11245"></li>
<li class="L11246" rel="L11246">“You are quite a visit in my debt, Mr. Bingley,” she added, “for when</li>
<li class="L11247" rel="L11247">you went to town last winter, you promised to take a family dinner with</li>
<li class="L11248" rel="L11248">us, as soon as you returned. I have not forgot, you see; and I assure</li>
<li class="L11249" rel="L11249">you, I was very much disappointed that you did not come back and keep</li>
<li class="L11250" rel="L11250">your engagement.”</li>
<li class="L11251" rel="L11251"></li>
<li class="L11252" rel="L11252">Bingley looked a little silly at this reflection, and said something of</li>
<li class="L11253" rel="L11253">his concern at having been prevented by business. They then went away.</li>
<li class="L11254" rel="L11254"></li>
<li class="L11255" rel="L11255">Mrs. Bennet had been strongly inclined to ask them to stay and dine</li>
<li class="L11256" rel="L11256">there that day; but, though she always kept a very good table, she did</li>
<li class="L11257" rel="L11257">not think anything less than two courses could be good enough for a man</li>
<li class="L11258" rel="L11258">on whom she had such anxious designs, or satisfy the appetite and pride</li>
<li class="L11259" rel="L11259">of one who had ten thousand a year.</li>
<li class="L11260" rel="L11260"></li>
<li class="L11261" rel="L11261"></li>
<li class="L11262" rel="L11262"></li>
<li class="L11263" rel="L11263">Chapter 54</li>
<li class="L11264" rel="L11264"></li>
<li class="L11265" rel="L11265"></li>
<li class="L11266" rel="L11266">As soon as they were gone, Elizabeth walked out to recover her spirits;</li>
<li class="L11267" rel="L11267">or in other words, to dwell without interruption on those subjects that</li>
<li class="L11268" rel="L11268">must deaden them more. Mr. Darcy&#39;s behaviour astonished and vexed her.</li>
<li class="L11269" rel="L11269"></li>
<li class="L11270" rel="L11270">“Why, if he came only to be silent, grave, and indifferent,” said she,</li>
<li class="L11271" rel="L11271">“did he come at all?”</li>
<li class="L11272" rel="L11272"></li>
<li class="L11273" rel="L11273">She could settle it in no way that gave her pleasure.</li>
<li class="L11274" rel="L11274"></li>
<li class="L11275" rel="L11275">“He could be still amiable, still pleasing, to my uncle and aunt, when</li>
<li class="L11276" rel="L11276">he was in town; and why not to me? If he fears me, why come hither? If</li>
<li class="L11277" rel="L11277">he no longer cares for me, why silent? Teasing, teasing, man! I will</li>
<li class="L11278" rel="L11278">think no more about him.”</li>
<li class="L11279" rel="L11279"></li>
<li class="L11280" rel="L11280">Her resolution was for a short time involuntarily kept by the approach</li>
<li class="L11281" rel="L11281">of her sister, who joined her with a cheerful look, which showed her</li>
<li class="L11282" rel="L11282">better satisfied with their visitors, than Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L11283" rel="L11283"></li>
<li class="L11284" rel="L11284">“Now,” said she, “that this first meeting is over, I feel perfectly</li>
<li class="L11285" rel="L11285">easy. I know my own strength, and I shall never be embarrassed again by</li>
<li class="L11286" rel="L11286">his coming. I am glad he dines here on Tuesday. It will then be publicly</li>
<li class="L11287" rel="L11287">seen that, on both sides, we meet only as common and indifferent</li>
<li class="L11288" rel="L11288">acquaintance.”</li>
<li class="L11289" rel="L11289"></li>
<li class="L11290" rel="L11290">“Yes, very indifferent indeed,” said Elizabeth, laughingly. “Oh, Jane,</li>
<li class="L11291" rel="L11291">take care.”</li>
<li class="L11292" rel="L11292"></li>
<li class="L11293" rel="L11293">“My dear Lizzy, you cannot think me so weak, as to be in danger now?”</li>
<li class="L11294" rel="L11294"></li>
<li class="L11295" rel="L11295">“I think you are in very great danger of making him as much in love with</li>
<li class="L11296" rel="L11296">you as ever.”</li>
<li class="L11297" rel="L11297"></li>
<li class="L11298" rel="L11298">                          * * * * *</li>
<li class="L11299" rel="L11299"></li>
<li class="L11300" rel="L11300">They did not see the gentlemen again till Tuesday; and Mrs. Bennet, in</li>
<li class="L11301" rel="L11301">the meanwhile, was giving way to all the happy schemes, which the good</li>
<li class="L11302" rel="L11302">humour and common politeness of Bingley, in half an hour&#39;s visit, had</li>
<li class="L11303" rel="L11303">revived.</li>
<li class="L11304" rel="L11304"></li>
<li class="L11305" rel="L11305">On Tuesday there was a large party assembled at Longbourn; and the two</li>
<li class="L11306" rel="L11306">who were most anxiously expected, to the credit of their punctuality</li>
<li class="L11307" rel="L11307">as sportsmen, were in very good time. When they repaired to the</li>
<li class="L11308" rel="L11308">dining-room, Elizabeth eagerly watched to see whether Bingley would take</li>
<li class="L11309" rel="L11309">the place, which, in all their former parties, had belonged to him, by</li>
<li class="L11310" rel="L11310">her sister. Her prudent mother, occupied by the same ideas, forbore</li>
<li class="L11311" rel="L11311">to invite him to sit by herself. On entering the room, he seemed to</li>
<li class="L11312" rel="L11312">hesitate; but Jane happened to look round, and happened to smile: it was</li>
<li class="L11313" rel="L11313">decided. He placed himself by her.</li>
<li class="L11314" rel="L11314"></li>
<li class="L11315" rel="L11315">Elizabeth, with a triumphant sensation, looked towards his friend.</li>
<li class="L11316" rel="L11316">He bore it with noble indifference, and she would have imagined that</li>
<li class="L11317" rel="L11317">Bingley had received his sanction to be happy, had she not seen his eyes</li>
<li class="L11318" rel="L11318">likewise turned towards Mr. Darcy, with an expression of half-laughing</li>
<li class="L11319" rel="L11319">alarm.</li>
<li class="L11320" rel="L11320"></li>
<li class="L11321" rel="L11321">His behaviour to her sister was such, during dinner time, as showed an</li>
<li class="L11322" rel="L11322">admiration of her, which, though more guarded than formerly, persuaded</li>
<li class="L11323" rel="L11323">Elizabeth, that if left wholly to himself, Jane&#39;s happiness, and his</li>
<li class="L11324" rel="L11324">own, would be speedily secured. Though she dared not depend upon the</li>
<li class="L11325" rel="L11325">consequence, she yet received pleasure from observing his behaviour. It</li>
<li class="L11326" rel="L11326">gave her all the animation that her spirits could boast; for she was in</li>
<li class="L11327" rel="L11327">no cheerful humour. Mr. Darcy was almost as far from her as the table</li>
<li class="L11328" rel="L11328">could divide them. He was on one side of her mother. She knew how little</li>
<li class="L11329" rel="L11329">such a situation would give pleasure to either, or make either appear to</li>
<li class="L11330" rel="L11330">advantage. She was not near enough to hear any of their discourse, but</li>
<li class="L11331" rel="L11331">she could see how seldom they spoke to each other, and how formal and</li>
<li class="L11332" rel="L11332">cold was their manner whenever they did. Her mother&#39;s ungraciousness,</li>
<li class="L11333" rel="L11333">made the sense of what they owed him more painful to Elizabeth&#39;s mind;</li>
<li class="L11334" rel="L11334">and she would, at times, have given anything to be privileged to tell</li>
<li class="L11335" rel="L11335">him that his kindness was neither unknown nor unfelt by the whole of the</li>
<li class="L11336" rel="L11336">family.</li>
<li class="L11337" rel="L11337"></li>
<li class="L11338" rel="L11338">She was in hopes that the evening would afford some opportunity of</li>
<li class="L11339" rel="L11339">bringing them together; that the whole of the visit would not pass away</li>
<li class="L11340" rel="L11340">without enabling them to enter into something more of conversation than</li>
<li class="L11341" rel="L11341">the mere ceremonious salutation attending his entrance. Anxious</li>
<li class="L11342" rel="L11342">and uneasy, the period which passed in the drawing-room, before the</li>
<li class="L11343" rel="L11343">gentlemen came, was wearisome and dull to a degree that almost made her</li>
<li class="L11344" rel="L11344">uncivil. She looked forward to their entrance as the point on which all</li>
<li class="L11345" rel="L11345">her chance of pleasure for the evening must depend.</li>
<li class="L11346" rel="L11346"></li>
<li class="L11347" rel="L11347">“If he does not come to me, _then_,” said she, “I shall give him up for</li>
<li class="L11348" rel="L11348">ever.”</li>
<li class="L11349" rel="L11349"></li>
<li class="L11350" rel="L11350">The gentlemen came; and she thought he looked as if he would have</li>
<li class="L11351" rel="L11351">answered her hopes; but, alas! the ladies had crowded round the table,</li>
<li class="L11352" rel="L11352">where Miss Bennet was making tea, and Elizabeth pouring out the coffee,</li>
<li class="L11353" rel="L11353">in so close a confederacy that there was not a single vacancy near her</li>
<li class="L11354" rel="L11354">which would admit of a chair. And on the gentlemen&#39;s approaching, one of</li>
<li class="L11355" rel="L11355">the girls moved closer to her than ever, and said, in a whisper:</li>
<li class="L11356" rel="L11356"></li>
<li class="L11357" rel="L11357">“The men shan&#39;t come and part us, I am determined. We want none of them;</li>
<li class="L11358" rel="L11358">do we?”</li>
<li class="L11359" rel="L11359"></li>
<li class="L11360" rel="L11360">Darcy had walked away to another part of the room. She followed him with</li>
<li class="L11361" rel="L11361">her eyes, envied everyone to whom he spoke, had scarcely patience enough</li>
<li class="L11362" rel="L11362">to help anybody to coffee; and then was enraged against herself for</li>
<li class="L11363" rel="L11363">being so silly!</li>
<li class="L11364" rel="L11364"></li>
<li class="L11365" rel="L11365">“A man who has once been refused! How could I ever be foolish enough to</li>
<li class="L11366" rel="L11366">expect a renewal of his love? Is there one among the sex, who would not</li>
<li class="L11367" rel="L11367">protest against such a weakness as a second proposal to the same woman?</li>
<li class="L11368" rel="L11368">There is no indignity so abhorrent to their feelings!”</li>
<li class="L11369" rel="L11369"></li>
<li class="L11370" rel="L11370">She was a little revived, however, by his bringing back his coffee cup</li>
<li class="L11371" rel="L11371">himself; and she seized the opportunity of saying:</li>
<li class="L11372" rel="L11372"></li>
<li class="L11373" rel="L11373">“Is your sister at Pemberley still?”</li>
<li class="L11374" rel="L11374"></li>
<li class="L11375" rel="L11375">“Yes, she will remain there till Christmas.”</li>
<li class="L11376" rel="L11376"></li>
<li class="L11377" rel="L11377">“And quite alone? Have all her friends left her?”</li>
<li class="L11378" rel="L11378"></li>
<li class="L11379" rel="L11379">“Mrs. Annesley is with her. The others have been gone on to Scarborough,</li>
<li class="L11380" rel="L11380">these three weeks.”</li>
<li class="L11381" rel="L11381"></li>
<li class="L11382" rel="L11382">She could think of nothing more to say; but if he wished to converse</li>
<li class="L11383" rel="L11383">with her, he might have better success. He stood by her, however, for</li>
<li class="L11384" rel="L11384">some minutes, in silence; and, at last, on the young lady&#39;s whispering</li>
<li class="L11385" rel="L11385">to Elizabeth again, he walked away.</li>
<li class="L11386" rel="L11386"></li>
<li class="L11387" rel="L11387">When the tea-things were removed, and the card-tables placed, the ladies</li>
<li class="L11388" rel="L11388">all rose, and Elizabeth was then hoping to be soon joined by him,</li>
<li class="L11389" rel="L11389">when all her views were overthrown by seeing him fall a victim to her</li>
<li class="L11390" rel="L11390">mother&#39;s rapacity for whist players, and in a few moments after seated</li>
<li class="L11391" rel="L11391">with the rest of the party. She now lost every expectation of pleasure.</li>
<li class="L11392" rel="L11392">They were confined for the evening at different tables, and she had</li>
<li class="L11393" rel="L11393">nothing to hope, but that his eyes were so often turned towards her side</li>
<li class="L11394" rel="L11394">of the room, as to make him play as unsuccessfully as herself.</li>
<li class="L11395" rel="L11395"></li>
<li class="L11396" rel="L11396">Mrs. Bennet had designed to keep the two Netherfield gentlemen to</li>
<li class="L11397" rel="L11397">supper; but their carriage was unluckily ordered before any of the</li>
<li class="L11398" rel="L11398">others, and she had no opportunity of detaining them.</li>
<li class="L11399" rel="L11399"></li>
<li class="L11400" rel="L11400">“Well girls,” said she, as soon as they were left to themselves, “What</li>
<li class="L11401" rel="L11401">say you to the day? I think every thing has passed off uncommonly well,</li>
<li class="L11402" rel="L11402">I assure you. The dinner was as well dressed as any I ever saw. The</li>
<li class="L11403" rel="L11403">venison was roasted to a turn--and everybody said they never saw so</li>
<li class="L11404" rel="L11404">fat a haunch. The soup was fifty times better than what we had at the</li>
<li class="L11405" rel="L11405">Lucases&#39; last week; and even Mr. Darcy acknowledged, that the partridges</li>
<li class="L11406" rel="L11406">were remarkably well done; and I suppose he has two or three French</li>
<li class="L11407" rel="L11407">cooks at least. And, my dear Jane, I never saw you look in greater</li>
<li class="L11408" rel="L11408">beauty. Mrs. Long said so too, for I asked her whether you did not. And</li>
<li class="L11409" rel="L11409">what do you think she said besides? &#39;Ah! Mrs. Bennet, we shall have her</li>
<li class="L11410" rel="L11410">at Netherfield at last.&#39; She did indeed. I do think Mrs. Long is as good</li>
<li class="L11411" rel="L11411">a creature as ever lived--and her nieces are very pretty behaved girls,</li>
<li class="L11412" rel="L11412">and not at all handsome: I like them prodigiously.”</li>
<li class="L11413" rel="L11413"></li>
<li class="L11414" rel="L11414">Mrs. Bennet, in short, was in very great spirits; she had seen enough of</li>
<li class="L11415" rel="L11415">Bingley&#39;s behaviour to Jane, to be convinced that she would get him at</li>
<li class="L11416" rel="L11416">last; and her expectations of advantage to her family, when in a happy</li>
<li class="L11417" rel="L11417">humour, were so far beyond reason, that she was quite disappointed at</li>
<li class="L11418" rel="L11418">not seeing him there again the next day, to make his proposals.</li>
<li class="L11419" rel="L11419"></li>
<li class="L11420" rel="L11420">“It has been a very agreeable day,” said Miss Bennet to Elizabeth. “The</li>
<li class="L11421" rel="L11421">party seemed so well selected, so suitable one with the other. I hope we</li>
<li class="L11422" rel="L11422">may often meet again.”</li>
<li class="L11423" rel="L11423"></li>
<li class="L11424" rel="L11424">Elizabeth smiled.</li>
<li class="L11425" rel="L11425"></li>
<li class="L11426" rel="L11426">“Lizzy, you must not do so. You must not suspect me. It mortifies me.</li>
<li class="L11427" rel="L11427">I assure you that I have now learnt to enjoy his conversation as an</li>
<li class="L11428" rel="L11428">agreeable and sensible young man, without having a wish beyond it. I am</li>
<li class="L11429" rel="L11429">perfectly satisfied, from what his manners now are, that he never had</li>
<li class="L11430" rel="L11430">any design of engaging my affection. It is only that he is blessed</li>
<li class="L11431" rel="L11431">with greater sweetness of address, and a stronger desire of generally</li>
<li class="L11432" rel="L11432">pleasing, than any other man.”</li>
<li class="L11433" rel="L11433"></li>
<li class="L11434" rel="L11434">“You are very cruel,” said her sister, “you will not let me smile, and</li>
<li class="L11435" rel="L11435">are provoking me to it every moment.”</li>
<li class="L11436" rel="L11436"></li>
<li class="L11437" rel="L11437">“How hard it is in some cases to be believed!”</li>
<li class="L11438" rel="L11438"></li>
<li class="L11439" rel="L11439">“And how impossible in others!”</li>
<li class="L11440" rel="L11440"></li>
<li class="L11441" rel="L11441">“But why should you wish to persuade me that I feel more than I</li>
<li class="L11442" rel="L11442">acknowledge?”</li>
<li class="L11443" rel="L11443"></li>
<li class="L11444" rel="L11444">“That is a question which I hardly know how to answer. We all love to</li>
<li class="L11445" rel="L11445">instruct, though we can teach only what is not worth knowing. Forgive</li>
<li class="L11446" rel="L11446">me; and if you persist in indifference, do not make me your confidante.”</li>
<li class="L11447" rel="L11447"></li>
<li class="L11448" rel="L11448"></li>
<li class="L11449" rel="L11449"></li>
<li class="L11450" rel="L11450">Chapter 55</li>
<li class="L11451" rel="L11451"></li>
<li class="L11452" rel="L11452"></li>
<li class="L11453" rel="L11453">A few days after this visit, Mr. Bingley called again, and alone. His</li>
<li class="L11454" rel="L11454">friend had left him that morning for London, but was to return home in</li>
<li class="L11455" rel="L11455">ten days time. He sat with them above an hour, and was in remarkably</li>
<li class="L11456" rel="L11456">good spirits. Mrs. Bennet invited him to dine with them; but, with many</li>
<li class="L11457" rel="L11457">expressions of concern, he confessed himself engaged elsewhere.</li>
<li class="L11458" rel="L11458"></li>
<li class="L11459" rel="L11459">“Next time you call,” said she, “I hope we shall be more lucky.”</li>
<li class="L11460" rel="L11460"></li>
<li class="L11461" rel="L11461">He should be particularly happy at any time, etc. etc.; and if she would</li>
<li class="L11462" rel="L11462">give him leave, would take an early opportunity of waiting on them.</li>
<li class="L11463" rel="L11463"></li>
<li class="L11464" rel="L11464">“Can you come to-morrow?”</li>
<li class="L11465" rel="L11465"></li>
<li class="L11466" rel="L11466">Yes, he had no engagement at all for to-morrow; and her invitation was</li>
<li class="L11467" rel="L11467">accepted with alacrity.</li>
<li class="L11468" rel="L11468"></li>
<li class="L11469" rel="L11469">He came, and in such very good time that the ladies were none of them</li>
<li class="L11470" rel="L11470">dressed. In ran Mrs. Bennet to her daughter&#39;s room, in her dressing</li>
<li class="L11471" rel="L11471">gown, and with her hair half finished, crying out:</li>
<li class="L11472" rel="L11472"></li>
<li class="L11473" rel="L11473">“My dear Jane, make haste and hurry down. He is come--Mr. Bingley is</li>
<li class="L11474" rel="L11474">come. He is, indeed. Make haste, make haste. Here, Sarah, come to Miss</li>
<li class="L11475" rel="L11475">Bennet this moment, and help her on with her gown. Never mind Miss</li>
<li class="L11476" rel="L11476">Lizzy&#39;s hair.”</li>
<li class="L11477" rel="L11477"></li>
<li class="L11478" rel="L11478">“We will be down as soon as we can,” said Jane; “but I dare say Kitty is</li>
<li class="L11479" rel="L11479">forwarder than either of us, for she went up stairs half an hour ago.”</li>
<li class="L11480" rel="L11480"></li>
<li class="L11481" rel="L11481">“Oh! hang Kitty! what has she to do with it? Come be quick, be quick!</li>
<li class="L11482" rel="L11482">Where is your sash, my dear?”</li>
<li class="L11483" rel="L11483"></li>
<li class="L11484" rel="L11484">But when her mother was gone, Jane would not be prevailed on to go down</li>
<li class="L11485" rel="L11485">without one of her sisters.</li>
<li class="L11486" rel="L11486"></li>
<li class="L11487" rel="L11487">The same anxiety to get them by themselves was visible again in the</li>
<li class="L11488" rel="L11488">evening. After tea, Mr. Bennet retired to the library, as was his</li>
<li class="L11489" rel="L11489">custom, and Mary went up stairs to her instrument. Two obstacles of</li>
<li class="L11490" rel="L11490">the five being thus removed, Mrs. Bennet sat looking and winking at</li>
<li class="L11491" rel="L11491">Elizabeth and Catherine for a considerable time, without making any</li>
<li class="L11492" rel="L11492">impression on them. Elizabeth would not observe her; and when at last</li>
<li class="L11493" rel="L11493">Kitty did, she very innocently said, “What is the matter mamma? What do</li>
<li class="L11494" rel="L11494">you keep winking at me for? What am I to do?”</li>
<li class="L11495" rel="L11495"></li>
<li class="L11496" rel="L11496">“Nothing child, nothing. I did not wink at you.” She then sat still</li>
<li class="L11497" rel="L11497">five minutes longer; but unable to waste such a precious occasion, she</li>
<li class="L11498" rel="L11498">suddenly got up, and saying to Kitty, “Come here, my love, I want to</li>
<li class="L11499" rel="L11499">speak to you,” took her out of the room. Jane instantly gave a look</li>
<li class="L11500" rel="L11500">at Elizabeth which spoke her distress at such premeditation, and her</li>
<li class="L11501" rel="L11501">entreaty that _she_ would not give in to it. In a few minutes, Mrs.</li>
<li class="L11502" rel="L11502">Bennet half-opened the door and called out:</li>
<li class="L11503" rel="L11503"></li>
<li class="L11504" rel="L11504">“Lizzy, my dear, I want to speak with you.”</li>
<li class="L11505" rel="L11505"></li>
<li class="L11506" rel="L11506">Elizabeth was forced to go.</li>
<li class="L11507" rel="L11507"></li>
<li class="L11508" rel="L11508">“We may as well leave them by themselves you know;” said her mother, as</li>
<li class="L11509" rel="L11509">soon as she was in the hall. “Kitty and I are going up stairs to sit in</li>
<li class="L11510" rel="L11510">my dressing-room.”</li>
<li class="L11511" rel="L11511"></li>
<li class="L11512" rel="L11512">Elizabeth made no attempt to reason with her mother, but remained</li>
<li class="L11513" rel="L11513">quietly in the hall, till she and Kitty were out of sight, then returned</li>
<li class="L11514" rel="L11514">into the drawing-room.</li>
<li class="L11515" rel="L11515"></li>
<li class="L11516" rel="L11516">Mrs. Bennet&#39;s schemes for this day were ineffectual. Bingley was every</li>
<li class="L11517" rel="L11517">thing that was charming, except the professed lover of her daughter. His</li>
<li class="L11518" rel="L11518">ease and cheerfulness rendered him a most agreeable addition to their</li>
<li class="L11519" rel="L11519">evening party; and he bore with the ill-judged officiousness of the</li>
<li class="L11520" rel="L11520">mother, and heard all her silly remarks with a forbearance and command</li>
<li class="L11521" rel="L11521">of countenance particularly grateful to the daughter.</li>
<li class="L11522" rel="L11522"></li>
<li class="L11523" rel="L11523">He scarcely needed an invitation to stay supper; and before he went</li>
<li class="L11524" rel="L11524">away, an engagement was formed, chiefly through his own and Mrs.</li>
<li class="L11525" rel="L11525">Bennet&#39;s means, for his coming next morning to shoot with her husband.</li>
<li class="L11526" rel="L11526"></li>
<li class="L11527" rel="L11527">After this day, Jane said no more of her indifference. Not a word passed</li>
<li class="L11528" rel="L11528">between the sisters concerning Bingley; but Elizabeth went to bed in</li>
<li class="L11529" rel="L11529">the happy belief that all must speedily be concluded, unless Mr. Darcy</li>
<li class="L11530" rel="L11530">returned within the stated time. Seriously, however, she felt tolerably</li>
<li class="L11531" rel="L11531">persuaded that all this must have taken place with that gentleman&#39;s</li>
<li class="L11532" rel="L11532">concurrence.</li>
<li class="L11533" rel="L11533"></li>
<li class="L11534" rel="L11534">Bingley was punctual to his appointment; and he and Mr. Bennet spent</li>
<li class="L11535" rel="L11535">the morning together, as had been agreed on. The latter was much more</li>
<li class="L11536" rel="L11536">agreeable than his companion expected. There was nothing of presumption</li>
<li class="L11537" rel="L11537">or folly in Bingley that could provoke his ridicule, or disgust him into</li>
<li class="L11538" rel="L11538">silence; and he was more communicative, and less eccentric, than the</li>
<li class="L11539" rel="L11539">other had ever seen him. Bingley of course returned with him to dinner;</li>
<li class="L11540" rel="L11540">and in the evening Mrs. Bennet&#39;s invention was again at work to get</li>
<li class="L11541" rel="L11541">every body away from him and her daughter. Elizabeth, who had a letter</li>
<li class="L11542" rel="L11542">to write, went into the breakfast room for that purpose soon after tea;</li>
<li class="L11543" rel="L11543">for as the others were all going to sit down to cards, she could not be</li>
<li class="L11544" rel="L11544">wanted to counteract her mother&#39;s schemes.</li>
<li class="L11545" rel="L11545"></li>
<li class="L11546" rel="L11546">But on returning to the drawing-room, when her letter was finished, she</li>
<li class="L11547" rel="L11547">saw, to her infinite surprise, there was reason to fear that her mother</li>
<li class="L11548" rel="L11548">had been too ingenious for her. On opening the door, she perceived her</li>
<li class="L11549" rel="L11549">sister and Bingley standing together over the hearth, as if engaged in</li>
<li class="L11550" rel="L11550">earnest conversation; and had this led to no suspicion, the faces of</li>
<li class="L11551" rel="L11551">both, as they hastily turned round and moved away from each other, would</li>
<li class="L11552" rel="L11552">have told it all. Their situation was awkward enough; but _hers_ she</li>
<li class="L11553" rel="L11553">thought was still worse. Not a syllable was uttered by either; and</li>
<li class="L11554" rel="L11554">Elizabeth was on the point of going away again, when Bingley, who as</li>
<li class="L11555" rel="L11555">well as the other had sat down, suddenly rose, and whispering a few</li>
<li class="L11556" rel="L11556">words to her sister, ran out of the room.</li>
<li class="L11557" rel="L11557"></li>
<li class="L11558" rel="L11558">Jane could have no reserves from Elizabeth, where confidence would give</li>
<li class="L11559" rel="L11559">pleasure; and instantly embracing her, acknowledged, with the liveliest</li>
<li class="L11560" rel="L11560">emotion, that she was the happiest creature in the world.</li>
<li class="L11561" rel="L11561"></li>
<li class="L11562" rel="L11562">“&#39;Tis too much!” she added, “by far too much. I do not deserve it. Oh!</li>
<li class="L11563" rel="L11563">why is not everybody as happy?”</li>
<li class="L11564" rel="L11564"></li>
<li class="L11565" rel="L11565">Elizabeth&#39;s congratulations were given with a sincerity, a warmth,</li>
<li class="L11566" rel="L11566">a delight, which words could but poorly express. Every sentence of</li>
<li class="L11567" rel="L11567">kindness was a fresh source of happiness to Jane. But she would not</li>
<li class="L11568" rel="L11568">allow herself to stay with her sister, or say half that remained to be</li>
<li class="L11569" rel="L11569">said for the present.</li>
<li class="L11570" rel="L11570"></li>
<li class="L11571" rel="L11571">“I must go instantly to my mother;” she cried. “I would not on any</li>
<li class="L11572" rel="L11572">account trifle with her affectionate solicitude; or allow her to hear it</li>
<li class="L11573" rel="L11573">from anyone but myself. He is gone to my father already. Oh! Lizzy, to</li>
<li class="L11574" rel="L11574">know that what I have to relate will give such pleasure to all my dear</li>
<li class="L11575" rel="L11575">family! how shall I bear so much happiness!”</li>
<li class="L11576" rel="L11576"></li>
<li class="L11577" rel="L11577">She then hastened away to her mother, who had purposely broken up the</li>
<li class="L11578" rel="L11578">card party, and was sitting up stairs with Kitty.</li>
<li class="L11579" rel="L11579"></li>
<li class="L11580" rel="L11580">Elizabeth, who was left by herself, now smiled at the rapidity and ease</li>
<li class="L11581" rel="L11581">with which an affair was finally settled, that had given them so many</li>
<li class="L11582" rel="L11582">previous months of suspense and vexation.</li>
<li class="L11583" rel="L11583"></li>
<li class="L11584" rel="L11584">“And this,” said she, “is the end of all his friend&#39;s anxious</li>
<li class="L11585" rel="L11585">circumspection! of all his sister&#39;s falsehood and contrivance! the</li>
<li class="L11586" rel="L11586">happiest, wisest, most reasonable end!”</li>
<li class="L11587" rel="L11587"></li>
<li class="L11588" rel="L11588">In a few minutes she was joined by Bingley, whose conference with her</li>
<li class="L11589" rel="L11589">father had been short and to the purpose.</li>
<li class="L11590" rel="L11590"></li>
<li class="L11591" rel="L11591">“Where is your sister?” said he hastily, as he opened the door.</li>
<li class="L11592" rel="L11592"></li>
<li class="L11593" rel="L11593">“With my mother up stairs. She will be down in a moment, I dare say.”</li>
<li class="L11594" rel="L11594"></li>
<li class="L11595" rel="L11595">He then shut the door, and, coming up to her, claimed the good wishes</li>
<li class="L11596" rel="L11596">and affection of a sister. Elizabeth honestly and heartily expressed</li>
<li class="L11597" rel="L11597">her delight in the prospect of their relationship. They shook hands with</li>
<li class="L11598" rel="L11598">great cordiality; and then, till her sister came down, she had to listen</li>
<li class="L11599" rel="L11599">to all he had to say of his own happiness, and of Jane&#39;s perfections;</li>
<li class="L11600" rel="L11600">and in spite of his being a lover, Elizabeth really believed all his</li>
<li class="L11601" rel="L11601">expectations of felicity to be rationally founded, because they had for</li>
<li class="L11602" rel="L11602">basis the excellent understanding, and super-excellent disposition of</li>
<li class="L11603" rel="L11603">Jane, and a general similarity of feeling and taste between her and</li>
<li class="L11604" rel="L11604">himself.</li>
<li class="L11605" rel="L11605"></li>
<li class="L11606" rel="L11606">It was an evening of no common delight to them all; the satisfaction of</li>
<li class="L11607" rel="L11607">Miss Bennet&#39;s mind gave a glow of such sweet animation to her face, as</li>
<li class="L11608" rel="L11608">made her look handsomer than ever. Kitty simpered and smiled, and hoped</li>
<li class="L11609" rel="L11609">her turn was coming soon. Mrs. Bennet could not give her consent or</li>
<li class="L11610" rel="L11610">speak her approbation in terms warm enough to satisfy her feelings,</li>
<li class="L11611" rel="L11611">though she talked to Bingley of nothing else for half an hour; and when</li>
<li class="L11612" rel="L11612">Mr. Bennet joined them at supper, his voice and manner plainly showed</li>
<li class="L11613" rel="L11613">how really happy he was.</li>
<li class="L11614" rel="L11614"></li>
<li class="L11615" rel="L11615">Not a word, however, passed his lips in allusion to it, till their</li>
<li class="L11616" rel="L11616">visitor took his leave for the night; but as soon as he was gone, he</li>
<li class="L11617" rel="L11617">turned to his daughter, and said:</li>
<li class="L11618" rel="L11618"></li>
<li class="L11619" rel="L11619">“Jane, I congratulate you. You will be a very happy woman.”</li>
<li class="L11620" rel="L11620"></li>
<li class="L11621" rel="L11621">Jane went to him instantly, kissed him, and thanked him for his</li>
<li class="L11622" rel="L11622">goodness.</li>
<li class="L11623" rel="L11623"></li>
<li class="L11624" rel="L11624">“You are a good girl;” he replied, “and I have great pleasure in</li>
<li class="L11625" rel="L11625">thinking you will be so happily settled. I have not a doubt of your</li>
<li class="L11626" rel="L11626">doing very well together. Your tempers are by no means unlike. You are</li>
<li class="L11627" rel="L11627">each of you so complying, that nothing will ever be resolved on; so</li>
<li class="L11628" rel="L11628">easy, that every servant will cheat you; and so generous, that you will</li>
<li class="L11629" rel="L11629">always exceed your income.”</li>
<li class="L11630" rel="L11630"></li>
<li class="L11631" rel="L11631">“I hope not so. Imprudence or thoughtlessness in money matters would be</li>
<li class="L11632" rel="L11632">unpardonable in me.”</li>
<li class="L11633" rel="L11633"></li>
<li class="L11634" rel="L11634">“Exceed their income! My dear Mr. Bennet,” cried his wife, “what are you</li>
<li class="L11635" rel="L11635">talking of? Why, he has four or five thousand a year, and very likely</li>
<li class="L11636" rel="L11636">more.” Then addressing her daughter, “Oh! my dear, dear Jane, I am so</li>
<li class="L11637" rel="L11637">happy! I am sure I shan&#39;t get a wink of sleep all night. I knew how it</li>
<li class="L11638" rel="L11638">would be. I always said it must be so, at last. I was sure you could not</li>
<li class="L11639" rel="L11639">be so beautiful for nothing! I remember, as soon as ever I saw him, when</li>
<li class="L11640" rel="L11640">he first came into Hertfordshire last year, I thought how likely it was</li>
<li class="L11641" rel="L11641">that you should come together. Oh! he is the handsomest young man that</li>
<li class="L11642" rel="L11642">ever was seen!”</li>
<li class="L11643" rel="L11643"></li>
<li class="L11644" rel="L11644">Wickham, Lydia, were all forgotten. Jane was beyond competition her</li>
<li class="L11645" rel="L11645">favourite child. At that moment, she cared for no other. Her younger</li>
<li class="L11646" rel="L11646">sisters soon began to make interest with her for objects of happiness</li>
<li class="L11647" rel="L11647">which she might in future be able to dispense.</li>
<li class="L11648" rel="L11648"></li>
<li class="L11649" rel="L11649">Mary petitioned for the use of the library at Netherfield; and Kitty</li>
<li class="L11650" rel="L11650">begged very hard for a few balls there every winter.</li>
<li class="L11651" rel="L11651"></li>
<li class="L11652" rel="L11652">Bingley, from this time, was of course a daily visitor at Longbourn;</li>
<li class="L11653" rel="L11653">coming frequently before breakfast, and always remaining till after</li>
<li class="L11654" rel="L11654">supper; unless when some barbarous neighbour, who could not be enough</li>
<li class="L11655" rel="L11655">detested, had given him an invitation to dinner which he thought himself</li>
<li class="L11656" rel="L11656">obliged to accept.</li>
<li class="L11657" rel="L11657"></li>
<li class="L11658" rel="L11658">Elizabeth had now but little time for conversation with her sister; for</li>
<li class="L11659" rel="L11659">while he was present, Jane had no attention to bestow on anyone else;</li>
<li class="L11660" rel="L11660">but she found herself considerably useful to both of them in those hours</li>
<li class="L11661" rel="L11661">of separation that must sometimes occur. In the absence of Jane, he</li>
<li class="L11662" rel="L11662">always attached himself to Elizabeth, for the pleasure of talking of</li>
<li class="L11663" rel="L11663">her; and when Bingley was gone, Jane constantly sought the same means of</li>
<li class="L11664" rel="L11664">relief.</li>
<li class="L11665" rel="L11665"></li>
<li class="L11666" rel="L11666">“He has made me so happy,” said she, one evening, “by telling me that he</li>
<li class="L11667" rel="L11667">was totally ignorant of my being in town last spring! I had not believed</li>
<li class="L11668" rel="L11668">it possible.”</li>
<li class="L11669" rel="L11669"></li>
<li class="L11670" rel="L11670">“I suspected as much,” replied Elizabeth. “But how did he account for</li>
<li class="L11671" rel="L11671">it?”</li>
<li class="L11672" rel="L11672"></li>
<li class="L11673" rel="L11673">“It must have been his sister&#39;s doing. They were certainly no friends to</li>
<li class="L11674" rel="L11674">his acquaintance with me, which I cannot wonder at, since he might have</li>
<li class="L11675" rel="L11675">chosen so much more advantageously in many respects. But when they see,</li>
<li class="L11676" rel="L11676">as I trust they will, that their brother is happy with me, they will</li>
<li class="L11677" rel="L11677">learn to be contented, and we shall be on good terms again; though we</li>
<li class="L11678" rel="L11678">can never be what we once were to each other.”</li>
<li class="L11679" rel="L11679"></li>
<li class="L11680" rel="L11680">“That is the most unforgiving speech,” said Elizabeth, “that I ever</li>
<li class="L11681" rel="L11681">heard you utter. Good girl! It would vex me, indeed, to see you again</li>
<li class="L11682" rel="L11682">the dupe of Miss Bingley&#39;s pretended regard.”</li>
<li class="L11683" rel="L11683"></li>
<li class="L11684" rel="L11684">“Would you believe it, Lizzy, that when he went to town last November,</li>
<li class="L11685" rel="L11685">he really loved me, and nothing but a persuasion of _my_ being</li>
<li class="L11686" rel="L11686">indifferent would have prevented his coming down again!”</li>
<li class="L11687" rel="L11687"></li>
<li class="L11688" rel="L11688">“He made a little mistake to be sure; but it is to the credit of his</li>
<li class="L11689" rel="L11689">modesty.”</li>
<li class="L11690" rel="L11690"></li>
<li class="L11691" rel="L11691">This naturally introduced a panegyric from Jane on his diffidence, and</li>
<li class="L11692" rel="L11692">the little value he put on his own good qualities. Elizabeth was pleased</li>
<li class="L11693" rel="L11693">to find that he had not betrayed the interference of his friend; for,</li>
<li class="L11694" rel="L11694">though Jane had the most generous and forgiving heart in the world, she</li>
<li class="L11695" rel="L11695">knew it was a circumstance which must prejudice her against him.</li>
<li class="L11696" rel="L11696"></li>
<li class="L11697" rel="L11697">“I am certainly the most fortunate creature that ever existed!” cried</li>
<li class="L11698" rel="L11698">Jane. “Oh! Lizzy, why am I thus singled from my family, and blessed</li>
<li class="L11699" rel="L11699">above them all! If I could but see _you_ as happy! If there _were_ but</li>
<li class="L11700" rel="L11700">such another man for you!”</li>
<li class="L11701" rel="L11701"></li>
<li class="L11702" rel="L11702">“If you were to give me forty such men, I never could be so happy as</li>
<li class="L11703" rel="L11703">you. Till I have your disposition, your goodness, I never can have your</li>
<li class="L11704" rel="L11704">happiness. No, no, let me shift for myself; and, perhaps, if I have very</li>
<li class="L11705" rel="L11705">good luck, I may meet with another Mr. Collins in time.”</li>
<li class="L11706" rel="L11706"></li>
<li class="L11707" rel="L11707">The situation of affairs in the Longbourn family could not be long a</li>
<li class="L11708" rel="L11708">secret. Mrs. Bennet was privileged to whisper it to Mrs. Phillips,</li>
<li class="L11709" rel="L11709">and she ventured, without any permission, to do the same by all her</li>
<li class="L11710" rel="L11710">neighbours in Meryton.</li>
<li class="L11711" rel="L11711"></li>
<li class="L11712" rel="L11712">The Bennets were speedily pronounced to be the luckiest family in the</li>
<li class="L11713" rel="L11713">world, though only a few weeks before, when Lydia had first run away,</li>
<li class="L11714" rel="L11714">they had been generally proved to be marked out for misfortune.</li>
<li class="L11715" rel="L11715"></li>
<li class="L11716" rel="L11716"></li>
<li class="L11717" rel="L11717"></li>
<li class="L11718" rel="L11718">Chapter 56</li>
<li class="L11719" rel="L11719"></li>
<li class="L11720" rel="L11720"></li>
<li class="L11721" rel="L11721">One morning, about a week after Bingley&#39;s engagement with Jane had been</li>
<li class="L11722" rel="L11722">formed, as he and the females of the family were sitting together in the</li>
<li class="L11723" rel="L11723">dining-room, their attention was suddenly drawn to the window, by the</li>
<li class="L11724" rel="L11724">sound of a carriage; and they perceived a chaise and four driving up</li>
<li class="L11725" rel="L11725">the lawn. It was too early in the morning for visitors, and besides, the</li>
<li class="L11726" rel="L11726">equipage did not answer to that of any of their neighbours. The horses</li>
<li class="L11727" rel="L11727">were post; and neither the carriage, nor the livery of the servant who</li>
<li class="L11728" rel="L11728">preceded it, were familiar to them. As it was certain, however, that</li>
<li class="L11729" rel="L11729">somebody was coming, Bingley instantly prevailed on Miss Bennet to avoid</li>
<li class="L11730" rel="L11730">the confinement of such an intrusion, and walk away with him into the</li>
<li class="L11731" rel="L11731">shrubbery. They both set off, and the conjectures of the remaining three</li>
<li class="L11732" rel="L11732">continued, though with little satisfaction, till the door was thrown</li>
<li class="L11733" rel="L11733">open and their visitor entered. It was Lady Catherine de Bourgh.</li>
<li class="L11734" rel="L11734"></li>
<li class="L11735" rel="L11735">They were of course all intending to be surprised; but their</li>
<li class="L11736" rel="L11736">astonishment was beyond their expectation; and on the part of Mrs.</li>
<li class="L11737" rel="L11737">Bennet and Kitty, though she was perfectly unknown to them, even</li>
<li class="L11738" rel="L11738">inferior to what Elizabeth felt.</li>
<li class="L11739" rel="L11739"></li>
<li class="L11740" rel="L11740">She entered the room with an air more than usually ungracious, made no</li>
<li class="L11741" rel="L11741">other reply to Elizabeth&#39;s salutation than a slight inclination of the</li>
<li class="L11742" rel="L11742">head, and sat down without saying a word. Elizabeth had mentioned her</li>
<li class="L11743" rel="L11743">name to her mother on her ladyship&#39;s entrance, though no request of</li>
<li class="L11744" rel="L11744">introduction had been made.</li>
<li class="L11745" rel="L11745"></li>
<li class="L11746" rel="L11746">Mrs. Bennet, all amazement, though flattered by having a guest of such</li>
<li class="L11747" rel="L11747">high importance, received her with the utmost politeness. After sitting</li>
<li class="L11748" rel="L11748">for a moment in silence, she said very stiffly to Elizabeth,</li>
<li class="L11749" rel="L11749"></li>
<li class="L11750" rel="L11750">“I hope you are well, Miss Bennet. That lady, I suppose, is your</li>
<li class="L11751" rel="L11751">mother.”</li>
<li class="L11752" rel="L11752"></li>
<li class="L11753" rel="L11753">Elizabeth replied very concisely that she was.</li>
<li class="L11754" rel="L11754"></li>
<li class="L11755" rel="L11755">“And _that_ I suppose is one of your sisters.”</li>
<li class="L11756" rel="L11756"></li>
<li class="L11757" rel="L11757">“Yes, madam,” said Mrs. Bennet, delighted to speak to Lady Catherine.</li>
<li class="L11758" rel="L11758">“She is my youngest girl but one. My youngest of all is lately married,</li>
<li class="L11759" rel="L11759">and my eldest is somewhere about the grounds, walking with a young man</li>
<li class="L11760" rel="L11760">who, I believe, will soon become a part of the family.”</li>
<li class="L11761" rel="L11761"></li>
<li class="L11762" rel="L11762">“You have a very small park here,” returned Lady Catherine after a short</li>
<li class="L11763" rel="L11763">silence.</li>
<li class="L11764" rel="L11764"></li>
<li class="L11765" rel="L11765">“It is nothing in comparison of Rosings, my lady, I dare say; but I</li>
<li class="L11766" rel="L11766">assure you it is much larger than Sir William Lucas&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L11767" rel="L11767"></li>
<li class="L11768" rel="L11768">“This must be a most inconvenient sitting room for the evening, in</li>
<li class="L11769" rel="L11769">summer; the windows are full west.”</li>
<li class="L11770" rel="L11770"></li>
<li class="L11771" rel="L11771">Mrs. Bennet assured her that they never sat there after dinner, and then</li>
<li class="L11772" rel="L11772">added:</li>
<li class="L11773" rel="L11773"></li>
<li class="L11774" rel="L11774">“May I take the liberty of asking your ladyship whether you left Mr. and</li>
<li class="L11775" rel="L11775">Mrs. Collins well.”</li>
<li class="L11776" rel="L11776"></li>
<li class="L11777" rel="L11777">“Yes, very well. I saw them the night before last.”</li>
<li class="L11778" rel="L11778"></li>
<li class="L11779" rel="L11779">Elizabeth now expected that she would produce a letter for her from</li>
<li class="L11780" rel="L11780">Charlotte, as it seemed the only probable motive for her calling. But no</li>
<li class="L11781" rel="L11781">letter appeared, and she was completely puzzled.</li>
<li class="L11782" rel="L11782"></li>
<li class="L11783" rel="L11783">Mrs. Bennet, with great civility, begged her ladyship to take some</li>
<li class="L11784" rel="L11784">refreshment; but Lady Catherine very resolutely, and not very politely,</li>
<li class="L11785" rel="L11785">declined eating anything; and then, rising up, said to Elizabeth,</li>
<li class="L11786" rel="L11786"></li>
<li class="L11787" rel="L11787">“Miss Bennet, there seemed to be a prettyish kind of a little wilderness</li>
<li class="L11788" rel="L11788">on one side of your lawn. I should be glad to take a turn in it, if you</li>
<li class="L11789" rel="L11789">will favour me with your company.”</li>
<li class="L11790" rel="L11790"></li>
<li class="L11791" rel="L11791">“Go, my dear,” cried her mother, “and show her ladyship about the</li>
<li class="L11792" rel="L11792">different walks. I think she will be pleased with the hermitage.”</li>
<li class="L11793" rel="L11793"></li>
<li class="L11794" rel="L11794">Elizabeth obeyed, and running into her own room for her parasol,</li>
<li class="L11795" rel="L11795">attended her noble guest downstairs. As they passed through the</li>
<li class="L11796" rel="L11796">hall, Lady Catherine opened the doors into the dining-parlour and</li>
<li class="L11797" rel="L11797">drawing-room, and pronouncing them, after a short survey, to be decent</li>
<li class="L11798" rel="L11798">looking rooms, walked on.</li>
<li class="L11799" rel="L11799"></li>
<li class="L11800" rel="L11800">Her carriage remained at the door, and Elizabeth saw that her</li>
<li class="L11801" rel="L11801">waiting-woman was in it. They proceeded in silence along the gravel walk</li>
<li class="L11802" rel="L11802">that led to the copse; Elizabeth was determined to make no effort for</li>
<li class="L11803" rel="L11803">conversation with a woman who was now more than usually insolent and</li>
<li class="L11804" rel="L11804">disagreeable.</li>
<li class="L11805" rel="L11805"></li>
<li class="L11806" rel="L11806">“How could I ever think her like her nephew?” said she, as she looked in</li>
<li class="L11807" rel="L11807">her face.</li>
<li class="L11808" rel="L11808"></li>
<li class="L11809" rel="L11809">As soon as they entered the copse, Lady Catherine began in the following</li>
<li class="L11810" rel="L11810">manner:--</li>
<li class="L11811" rel="L11811"></li>
<li class="L11812" rel="L11812">“You can be at no loss, Miss Bennet, to understand the reason of my</li>
<li class="L11813" rel="L11813">journey hither. Your own heart, your own conscience, must tell you why I</li>
<li class="L11814" rel="L11814">come.”</li>
<li class="L11815" rel="L11815"></li>
<li class="L11816" rel="L11816">Elizabeth looked with unaffected astonishment.</li>
<li class="L11817" rel="L11817"></li>
<li class="L11818" rel="L11818">“Indeed, you are mistaken, Madam. I have not been at all able to account</li>
<li class="L11819" rel="L11819">for the honour of seeing you here.”</li>
<li class="L11820" rel="L11820"></li>
<li class="L11821" rel="L11821">“Miss Bennet,” replied her ladyship, in an angry tone, “you ought to</li>
<li class="L11822" rel="L11822">know, that I am not to be trifled with. But however insincere _you_ may</li>
<li class="L11823" rel="L11823">choose to be, you shall not find _me_ so. My character has ever been</li>
<li class="L11824" rel="L11824">celebrated for its sincerity and frankness, and in a cause of such</li>
<li class="L11825" rel="L11825">moment as this, I shall certainly not depart from it. A report of a most</li>
<li class="L11826" rel="L11826">alarming nature reached me two days ago. I was told that not only your</li>
<li class="L11827" rel="L11827">sister was on the point of being most advantageously married, but that</li>
<li class="L11828" rel="L11828">you, that Miss Elizabeth Bennet, would, in all likelihood, be soon</li>
<li class="L11829" rel="L11829">afterwards united to my nephew, my own nephew, Mr. Darcy. Though I</li>
<li class="L11830" rel="L11830">_know_ it must be a scandalous falsehood, though I would not injure him</li>
<li class="L11831" rel="L11831">so much as to suppose the truth of it possible, I instantly resolved</li>
<li class="L11832" rel="L11832">on setting off for this place, that I might make my sentiments known to</li>
<li class="L11833" rel="L11833">you.”</li>
<li class="L11834" rel="L11834"></li>
<li class="L11835" rel="L11835">“If you believed it impossible to be true,” said Elizabeth, colouring</li>
