<li class="L11836" rel="L11836">with astonishment and disdain, “I wonder you took the trouble of coming</li>
<li class="L11837" rel="L11837">so far. What could your ladyship propose by it?”</li>
<li class="L11838" rel="L11838"></li>
<li class="L11839" rel="L11839">“At once to insist upon having such a report universally contradicted.”</li>
<li class="L11840" rel="L11840"></li>
<li class="L11841" rel="L11841">“Your coming to Longbourn, to see me and my family,” said Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L11842" rel="L11842">coolly, “will be rather a confirmation of it; if, indeed, such a report</li>
<li class="L11843" rel="L11843">is in existence.”</li>
<li class="L11844" rel="L11844"></li>
<li class="L11845" rel="L11845">“If! Do you then pretend to be ignorant of it? Has it not been</li>
<li class="L11846" rel="L11846">industriously circulated by yourselves? Do you not know that such a</li>
<li class="L11847" rel="L11847">report is spread abroad?”</li>
<li class="L11848" rel="L11848"></li>
<li class="L11849" rel="L11849">“I never heard that it was.”</li>
<li class="L11850" rel="L11850"></li>
<li class="L11851" rel="L11851">“And can you likewise declare, that there is no foundation for it?”</li>
<li class="L11852" rel="L11852"></li>
<li class="L11853" rel="L11853">“I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your ladyship. You may</li>
<li class="L11854" rel="L11854">ask questions which I shall not choose to answer.”</li>
<li class="L11855" rel="L11855"></li>
<li class="L11856" rel="L11856">“This is not to be borne. Miss Bennet, I insist on being satisfied. Has</li>
<li class="L11857" rel="L11857">he, has my nephew, made you an offer of marriage?”</li>
<li class="L11858" rel="L11858"></li>
<li class="L11859" rel="L11859">“Your ladyship has declared it to be impossible.”</li>
<li class="L11860" rel="L11860"></li>
<li class="L11861" rel="L11861">“It ought to be so; it must be so, while he retains the use of his</li>
<li class="L11862" rel="L11862">reason. But your arts and allurements may, in a moment of infatuation,</li>
<li class="L11863" rel="L11863">have made him forget what he owes to himself and to all his family. You</li>
<li class="L11864" rel="L11864">may have drawn him in.”</li>
<li class="L11865" rel="L11865"></li>
<li class="L11866" rel="L11866">“If I have, I shall be the last person to confess it.”</li>
<li class="L11867" rel="L11867"></li>
<li class="L11868" rel="L11868">“Miss Bennet, do you know who I am? I have not been accustomed to such</li>
<li class="L11869" rel="L11869">language as this. I am almost the nearest relation he has in the world,</li>
<li class="L11870" rel="L11870">and am entitled to know all his dearest concerns.”</li>
<li class="L11871" rel="L11871"></li>
<li class="L11872" rel="L11872">“But you are not entitled to know mine; nor will such behaviour as this,</li>
<li class="L11873" rel="L11873">ever induce me to be explicit.”</li>
<li class="L11874" rel="L11874"></li>
<li class="L11875" rel="L11875">“Let me be rightly understood. This match, to which you have the</li>
<li class="L11876" rel="L11876">presumption to aspire, can never take place. No, never. Mr. Darcy is</li>
<li class="L11877" rel="L11877">engaged to my daughter. Now what have you to say?”</li>
<li class="L11878" rel="L11878"></li>
<li class="L11879" rel="L11879">“Only this; that if he is so, you can have no reason to suppose he will</li>
<li class="L11880" rel="L11880">make an offer to me.”</li>
<li class="L11881" rel="L11881"></li>
<li class="L11882" rel="L11882">Lady Catherine hesitated for a moment, and then replied:</li>
<li class="L11883" rel="L11883"></li>
<li class="L11884" rel="L11884">“The engagement between them is of a peculiar kind. From their infancy,</li>
<li class="L11885" rel="L11885">they have been intended for each other. It was the favourite wish of</li>
<li class="L11886" rel="L11886">_his_ mother, as well as of hers. While in their cradles, we planned</li>
<li class="L11887" rel="L11887">the union: and now, at the moment when the wishes of both sisters would</li>
<li class="L11888" rel="L11888">be accomplished in their marriage, to be prevented by a young woman of</li>
<li class="L11889" rel="L11889">inferior birth, of no importance in the world, and wholly unallied to</li>
<li class="L11890" rel="L11890">the family! Do you pay no regard to the wishes of his friends? To his</li>
<li class="L11891" rel="L11891">tacit engagement with Miss de Bourgh? Are you lost to every feeling of</li>
<li class="L11892" rel="L11892">propriety and delicacy? Have you not heard me say that from his earliest</li>
<li class="L11893" rel="L11893">hours he was destined for his cousin?”</li>
<li class="L11894" rel="L11894"></li>
<li class="L11895" rel="L11895">“Yes, and I had heard it before. But what is that to me? If there is</li>
<li class="L11896" rel="L11896">no other objection to my marrying your nephew, I shall certainly not</li>
<li class="L11897" rel="L11897">be kept from it by knowing that his mother and aunt wished him to</li>
<li class="L11898" rel="L11898">marry Miss de Bourgh. You both did as much as you could in planning the</li>
<li class="L11899" rel="L11899">marriage. Its completion depended on others. If Mr. Darcy is neither</li>
<li class="L11900" rel="L11900">by honour nor inclination confined to his cousin, why is not he to make</li>
<li class="L11901" rel="L11901">another choice? And if I am that choice, why may not I accept him?”</li>
<li class="L11902" rel="L11902"></li>
<li class="L11903" rel="L11903">“Because honour, decorum, prudence, nay, interest, forbid it. Yes,</li>
<li class="L11904" rel="L11904">Miss Bennet, interest; for do not expect to be noticed by his family or</li>
<li class="L11905" rel="L11905">friends, if you wilfully act against the inclinations of all. You will</li>
<li class="L11906" rel="L11906">be censured, slighted, and despised, by everyone connected with him.</li>
<li class="L11907" rel="L11907">Your alliance will be a disgrace; your name will never even be mentioned</li>
<li class="L11908" rel="L11908">by any of us.”</li>
<li class="L11909" rel="L11909"></li>
<li class="L11910" rel="L11910">“These are heavy misfortunes,” replied Elizabeth. “But the wife of Mr.</li>
<li class="L11911" rel="L11911">Darcy must have such extraordinary sources of happiness necessarily</li>
<li class="L11912" rel="L11912">attached to her situation, that she could, upon the whole, have no cause</li>
<li class="L11913" rel="L11913">to repine.”</li>
<li class="L11914" rel="L11914"></li>
<li class="L11915" rel="L11915">“Obstinate, headstrong girl! I am ashamed of you! Is this your gratitude</li>
<li class="L11916" rel="L11916">for my attentions to you last spring? Is nothing due to me on that</li>
<li class="L11917" rel="L11917">score? Let us sit down. You are to understand, Miss Bennet, that I came</li>
<li class="L11918" rel="L11918">here with the determined resolution of carrying my purpose; nor will</li>
<li class="L11919" rel="L11919">I be dissuaded from it. I have not been used to submit to any person&#39;s</li>
<li class="L11920" rel="L11920">whims. I have not been in the habit of brooking disappointment.”</li>
<li class="L11921" rel="L11921"></li>
<li class="L11922" rel="L11922">“_That_ will make your ladyship&#39;s situation at present more pitiable;</li>
<li class="L11923" rel="L11923">but it will have no effect on me.”</li>
<li class="L11924" rel="L11924"></li>
<li class="L11925" rel="L11925">“I will not be interrupted. Hear me in silence. My daughter and my</li>
<li class="L11926" rel="L11926">nephew are formed for each other. They are descended, on the maternal</li>
<li class="L11927" rel="L11927">side, from the same noble line; and, on the father&#39;s, from respectable,</li>
<li class="L11928" rel="L11928">honourable, and ancient--though untitled--families. Their fortune on</li>
<li class="L11929" rel="L11929">both sides is splendid. They are destined for each other by the voice of</li>
<li class="L11930" rel="L11930">every member of their respective houses; and what is to divide them?</li>
<li class="L11931" rel="L11931">The upstart pretensions of a young woman without family, connections,</li>
<li class="L11932" rel="L11932">or fortune. Is this to be endured! But it must not, shall not be. If you</li>
<li class="L11933" rel="L11933">were sensible of your own good, you would not wish to quit the sphere in</li>
<li class="L11934" rel="L11934">which you have been brought up.”</li>
<li class="L11935" rel="L11935"></li>
<li class="L11936" rel="L11936">“In marrying your nephew, I should not consider myself as quitting that</li>
<li class="L11937" rel="L11937">sphere. He is a gentleman; I am a gentleman&#39;s daughter; so far we are</li>
<li class="L11938" rel="L11938">equal.”</li>
<li class="L11939" rel="L11939"></li>
<li class="L11940" rel="L11940">“True. You _are_ a gentleman&#39;s daughter. But who was your mother?</li>
<li class="L11941" rel="L11941">Who are your uncles and aunts? Do not imagine me ignorant of their</li>
<li class="L11942" rel="L11942">condition.”</li>
<li class="L11943" rel="L11943"></li>
<li class="L11944" rel="L11944">“Whatever my connections may be,” said Elizabeth, “if your nephew does</li>
<li class="L11945" rel="L11945">not object to them, they can be nothing to _you_.”</li>
<li class="L11946" rel="L11946"></li>
<li class="L11947" rel="L11947">“Tell me once for all, are you engaged to him?”</li>
<li class="L11948" rel="L11948"></li>
<li class="L11949" rel="L11949">Though Elizabeth would not, for the mere purpose of obliging Lady</li>
<li class="L11950" rel="L11950">Catherine, have answered this question, she could not but say, after a</li>
<li class="L11951" rel="L11951">moment&#39;s deliberation:</li>
<li class="L11952" rel="L11952"></li>
<li class="L11953" rel="L11953">“I am not.”</li>
<li class="L11954" rel="L11954"></li>
<li class="L11955" rel="L11955">Lady Catherine seemed pleased.</li>
<li class="L11956" rel="L11956"></li>
<li class="L11957" rel="L11957">“And will you promise me, never to enter into such an engagement?”</li>
<li class="L11958" rel="L11958"></li>
<li class="L11959" rel="L11959">“I will make no promise of the kind.”</li>
<li class="L11960" rel="L11960"></li>
<li class="L11961" rel="L11961">“Miss Bennet I am shocked and astonished. I expected to find a more</li>
<li class="L11962" rel="L11962">reasonable young woman. But do not deceive yourself into a belief that</li>
<li class="L11963" rel="L11963">I will ever recede. I shall not go away till you have given me the</li>
<li class="L11964" rel="L11964">assurance I require.”</li>
<li class="L11965" rel="L11965"></li>
<li class="L11966" rel="L11966">“And I certainly _never_ shall give it. I am not to be intimidated into</li>
<li class="L11967" rel="L11967">anything so wholly unreasonable. Your ladyship wants Mr. Darcy to marry</li>
<li class="L11968" rel="L11968">your daughter; but would my giving you the wished-for promise make their</li>
<li class="L11969" rel="L11969">marriage at all more probable? Supposing him to be attached to me, would</li>
<li class="L11970" rel="L11970">my refusing to accept his hand make him wish to bestow it on his cousin?</li>
<li class="L11971" rel="L11971">Allow me to say, Lady Catherine, that the arguments with which you have</li>
<li class="L11972" rel="L11972">supported this extraordinary application have been as frivolous as the</li>
<li class="L11973" rel="L11973">application was ill-judged. You have widely mistaken my character, if</li>
<li class="L11974" rel="L11974">you think I can be worked on by such persuasions as these. How far your</li>
<li class="L11975" rel="L11975">nephew might approve of your interference in his affairs, I cannot tell;</li>
<li class="L11976" rel="L11976">but you have certainly no right to concern yourself in mine. I must beg,</li>
<li class="L11977" rel="L11977">therefore, to be importuned no farther on the subject.”</li>
<li class="L11978" rel="L11978"></li>
<li class="L11979" rel="L11979">“Not so hasty, if you please. I have by no means done. To all the</li>
<li class="L11980" rel="L11980">objections I have already urged, I have still another to add. I am</li>
<li class="L11981" rel="L11981">no stranger to the particulars of your youngest sister&#39;s infamous</li>
<li class="L11982" rel="L11982">elopement. I know it all; that the young man&#39;s marrying her was a</li>
<li class="L11983" rel="L11983">patched-up business, at the expence of your father and uncles. And is</li>
<li class="L11984" rel="L11984">such a girl to be my nephew&#39;s sister? Is her husband, is the son of his</li>
<li class="L11985" rel="L11985">late father&#39;s steward, to be his brother? Heaven and earth!--of what are</li>
<li class="L11986" rel="L11986">you thinking? Are the shades of Pemberley to be thus polluted?”</li>
<li class="L11987" rel="L11987"></li>
<li class="L11988" rel="L11988">“You can now have nothing further to say,” she resentfully answered.</li>
<li class="L11989" rel="L11989">“You have insulted me in every possible method. I must beg to return to</li>
<li class="L11990" rel="L11990">the house.”</li>
<li class="L11991" rel="L11991"></li>
<li class="L11992" rel="L11992">And she rose as she spoke. Lady Catherine rose also, and they turned</li>
<li class="L11993" rel="L11993">back. Her ladyship was highly incensed.</li>
<li class="L11994" rel="L11994"></li>
<li class="L11995" rel="L11995">“You have no regard, then, for the honour and credit of my nephew!</li>
<li class="L11996" rel="L11996">Unfeeling, selfish girl! Do you not consider that a connection with you</li>
<li class="L11997" rel="L11997">must disgrace him in the eyes of everybody?”</li>
<li class="L11998" rel="L11998"></li>
<li class="L11999" rel="L11999">“Lady Catherine, I have nothing further to say. You know my sentiments.”</li>
<li class="L12000" rel="L12000"></li>
<li class="L12001" rel="L12001">“You are then resolved to have him?”</li>
<li class="L12002" rel="L12002"></li>
<li class="L12003" rel="L12003">“I have said no such thing. I am only resolved to act in that manner,</li>
<li class="L12004" rel="L12004">which will, in my own opinion, constitute my happiness, without</li>
<li class="L12005" rel="L12005">reference to _you_, or to any person so wholly unconnected with me.”</li>
<li class="L12006" rel="L12006"></li>
<li class="L12007" rel="L12007">“It is well. You refuse, then, to oblige me. You refuse to obey the</li>
<li class="L12008" rel="L12008">claims of duty, honour, and gratitude. You are determined to ruin him in</li>
<li class="L12009" rel="L12009">the opinion of all his friends, and make him the contempt of the world.”</li>
<li class="L12010" rel="L12010"></li>
<li class="L12011" rel="L12011">“Neither duty, nor honour, nor gratitude,” replied Elizabeth, “have any</li>
<li class="L12012" rel="L12012">possible claim on me, in the present instance. No principle of either</li>
<li class="L12013" rel="L12013">would be violated by my marriage with Mr. Darcy. And with regard to the</li>
<li class="L12014" rel="L12014">resentment of his family, or the indignation of the world, if the former</li>
<li class="L12015" rel="L12015">_were_ excited by his marrying me, it would not give me one moment&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12016" rel="L12016">concern--and the world in general would have too much sense to join in</li>
<li class="L12017" rel="L12017">the scorn.”</li>
<li class="L12018" rel="L12018"></li>
<li class="L12019" rel="L12019">“And this is your real opinion! This is your final resolve! Very well.</li>
<li class="L12020" rel="L12020">I shall now know how to act. Do not imagine, Miss Bennet, that your</li>
<li class="L12021" rel="L12021">ambition will ever be gratified. I came to try you. I hoped to find you</li>
<li class="L12022" rel="L12022">reasonable; but, depend upon it, I will carry my point.”</li>
<li class="L12023" rel="L12023"></li>
<li class="L12024" rel="L12024">In this manner Lady Catherine talked on, till they were at the door of</li>
<li class="L12025" rel="L12025">the carriage, when, turning hastily round, she added, “I take no leave</li>
<li class="L12026" rel="L12026">of you, Miss Bennet. I send no compliments to your mother. You deserve</li>
<li class="L12027" rel="L12027">no such attention. I am most seriously displeased.”</li>
<li class="L12028" rel="L12028"></li>
<li class="L12029" rel="L12029">Elizabeth made no answer; and without attempting to persuade her</li>
<li class="L12030" rel="L12030">ladyship to return into the house, walked quietly into it herself. She</li>
<li class="L12031" rel="L12031">heard the carriage drive away as she proceeded up stairs. Her mother</li>
<li class="L12032" rel="L12032">impatiently met her at the door of the dressing-room, to ask why Lady</li>
<li class="L12033" rel="L12033">Catherine would not come in again and rest herself.</li>
<li class="L12034" rel="L12034"></li>
<li class="L12035" rel="L12035">“She did not choose it,” said her daughter, “she would go.”</li>
<li class="L12036" rel="L12036"></li>
<li class="L12037" rel="L12037">“She is a very fine-looking woman! and her calling here was prodigiously</li>
<li class="L12038" rel="L12038">civil! for she only came, I suppose, to tell us the Collinses were</li>
<li class="L12039" rel="L12039">well. She is on her road somewhere, I dare say, and so, passing through</li>
<li class="L12040" rel="L12040">Meryton, thought she might as well call on you. I suppose she had</li>
<li class="L12041" rel="L12041">nothing particular to say to you, Lizzy?”</li>
<li class="L12042" rel="L12042"></li>
<li class="L12043" rel="L12043">Elizabeth was forced to give into a little falsehood here; for to</li>
<li class="L12044" rel="L12044">acknowledge the substance of their conversation was impossible.</li>
<li class="L12045" rel="L12045"></li>
<li class="L12046" rel="L12046"></li>
<li class="L12047" rel="L12047"></li>
<li class="L12048" rel="L12048">Chapter 57</li>
<li class="L12049" rel="L12049"></li>
<li class="L12050" rel="L12050"></li>
<li class="L12051" rel="L12051">The discomposure of spirits which this extraordinary visit threw</li>
<li class="L12052" rel="L12052">Elizabeth into, could not be easily overcome; nor could she, for many</li>
<li class="L12053" rel="L12053">hours, learn to think of it less than incessantly. Lady Catherine, it</li>
<li class="L12054" rel="L12054">appeared, had actually taken the trouble of this journey from Rosings,</li>
<li class="L12055" rel="L12055">for the sole purpose of breaking off her supposed engagement with Mr.</li>
<li class="L12056" rel="L12056">Darcy. It was a rational scheme, to be sure! but from what the report</li>
<li class="L12057" rel="L12057">of their engagement could originate, Elizabeth was at a loss to imagine;</li>
<li class="L12058" rel="L12058">till she recollected that _his_ being the intimate friend of Bingley,</li>
<li class="L12059" rel="L12059">and _her_ being the sister of Jane, was enough, at a time when the</li>
<li class="L12060" rel="L12060">expectation of one wedding made everybody eager for another, to supply</li>
<li class="L12061" rel="L12061">the idea. She had not herself forgotten to feel that the marriage of her</li>
<li class="L12062" rel="L12062">sister must bring them more frequently together. And her neighbours</li>
<li class="L12063" rel="L12063">at Lucas Lodge, therefore (for through their communication with the</li>
<li class="L12064" rel="L12064">Collinses, the report, she concluded, had reached Lady Catherine), had</li>
<li class="L12065" rel="L12065">only set that down as almost certain and immediate, which she had looked</li>
<li class="L12066" rel="L12066">forward to as possible at some future time.</li>
<li class="L12067" rel="L12067"></li>
<li class="L12068" rel="L12068">In revolving Lady Catherine&#39;s expressions, however, she could not help</li>
<li class="L12069" rel="L12069">feeling some uneasiness as to the possible consequence of her persisting</li>
<li class="L12070" rel="L12070">in this interference. From what she had said of her resolution to</li>
<li class="L12071" rel="L12071">prevent their marriage, it occurred to Elizabeth that she must meditate</li>
<li class="L12072" rel="L12072">an application to her nephew; and how _he_ might take a similar</li>
<li class="L12073" rel="L12073">representation of the evils attached to a connection with her, she dared</li>
<li class="L12074" rel="L12074">not pronounce. She knew not the exact degree of his affection for his</li>
<li class="L12075" rel="L12075">aunt, or his dependence on her judgment, but it was natural to suppose</li>
<li class="L12076" rel="L12076">that he thought much higher of her ladyship than _she_ could do; and it</li>
<li class="L12077" rel="L12077">was certain that, in enumerating the miseries of a marriage with _one_,</li>
<li class="L12078" rel="L12078">whose immediate connections were so unequal to his own, his aunt would</li>
<li class="L12079" rel="L12079">address him on his weakest side. With his notions of dignity, he would</li>
<li class="L12080" rel="L12080">probably feel that the arguments, which to Elizabeth had appeared weak</li>
<li class="L12081" rel="L12081">and ridiculous, contained much good sense and solid reasoning.</li>
<li class="L12082" rel="L12082"></li>
<li class="L12083" rel="L12083">If he had been wavering before as to what he should do, which had often</li>
<li class="L12084" rel="L12084">seemed likely, the advice and entreaty of so near a relation might</li>
<li class="L12085" rel="L12085">settle every doubt, and determine him at once to be as happy as dignity</li>
<li class="L12086" rel="L12086">unblemished could make him. In that case he would return no more. Lady</li>
<li class="L12087" rel="L12087">Catherine might see him in her way through town; and his engagement to</li>
<li class="L12088" rel="L12088">Bingley of coming again to Netherfield must give way.</li>
<li class="L12089" rel="L12089"></li>
<li class="L12090" rel="L12090">“If, therefore, an excuse for not keeping his promise should come to his</li>
<li class="L12091" rel="L12091">friend within a few days,” she added, “I shall know how to understand</li>
<li class="L12092" rel="L12092">it. I shall then give over every expectation, every wish of his</li>
<li class="L12093" rel="L12093">constancy. If he is satisfied with only regretting me, when he might</li>
<li class="L12094" rel="L12094">have obtained my affections and hand, I shall soon cease to regret him</li>
<li class="L12095" rel="L12095">at all.”</li>
<li class="L12096" rel="L12096"></li>
<li class="L12097" rel="L12097">                          * * * * *</li>
<li class="L12098" rel="L12098"></li>
<li class="L12099" rel="L12099">The surprise of the rest of the family, on hearing who their visitor had</li>
<li class="L12100" rel="L12100">been, was very great; but they obligingly satisfied it, with the same</li>
<li class="L12101" rel="L12101">kind of supposition which had appeased Mrs. Bennet&#39;s curiosity; and</li>
<li class="L12102" rel="L12102">Elizabeth was spared from much teasing on the subject.</li>
<li class="L12103" rel="L12103"></li>
<li class="L12104" rel="L12104">The next morning, as she was going downstairs, she was met by her</li>
<li class="L12105" rel="L12105">father, who came out of his library with a letter in his hand.</li>
<li class="L12106" rel="L12106"></li>
<li class="L12107" rel="L12107">“Lizzy,” said he, “I was going to look for you; come into my room.”</li>
<li class="L12108" rel="L12108"></li>
<li class="L12109" rel="L12109">She followed him thither; and her curiosity to know what he had to</li>
<li class="L12110" rel="L12110">tell her was heightened by the supposition of its being in some manner</li>
<li class="L12111" rel="L12111">connected with the letter he held. It suddenly struck her that it</li>
<li class="L12112" rel="L12112">might be from Lady Catherine; and she anticipated with dismay all the</li>
<li class="L12113" rel="L12113">consequent explanations.</li>
<li class="L12114" rel="L12114"></li>
<li class="L12115" rel="L12115">She followed her father to the fire place, and they both sat down. He</li>
<li class="L12116" rel="L12116">then said,</li>
<li class="L12117" rel="L12117"></li>
<li class="L12118" rel="L12118">“I have received a letter this morning that has astonished me</li>
<li class="L12119" rel="L12119">exceedingly. As it principally concerns yourself, you ought to know its</li>
<li class="L12120" rel="L12120">contents. I did not know before, that I had two daughters on the brink</li>
<li class="L12121" rel="L12121">of matrimony. Let me congratulate you on a very important conquest.”</li>
<li class="L12122" rel="L12122"></li>
<li class="L12123" rel="L12123">The colour now rushed into Elizabeth&#39;s cheeks in the instantaneous</li>
<li class="L12124" rel="L12124">conviction of its being a letter from the nephew, instead of the aunt;</li>
<li class="L12125" rel="L12125">and she was undetermined whether most to be pleased that he explained</li>
<li class="L12126" rel="L12126">himself at all, or offended that his letter was not rather addressed to</li>
<li class="L12127" rel="L12127">herself; when her father continued:</li>
<li class="L12128" rel="L12128"></li>
<li class="L12129" rel="L12129">“You look conscious. Young ladies have great penetration in such matters</li>
<li class="L12130" rel="L12130">as these; but I think I may defy even _your_ sagacity, to discover the</li>
<li class="L12131" rel="L12131">name of your admirer. This letter is from Mr. Collins.”</li>
<li class="L12132" rel="L12132"></li>
<li class="L12133" rel="L12133">“From Mr. Collins! and what can _he_ have to say?”</li>
<li class="L12134" rel="L12134"></li>
<li class="L12135" rel="L12135">“Something very much to the purpose of course. He begins with</li>
<li class="L12136" rel="L12136">congratulations on the approaching nuptials of my eldest daughter, of</li>
<li class="L12137" rel="L12137">which, it seems, he has been told by some of the good-natured, gossiping</li>
<li class="L12138" rel="L12138">Lucases. I shall not sport with your impatience, by reading what he says</li>
<li class="L12139" rel="L12139">on that point. What relates to yourself, is as follows: &#39;Having thus</li>
<li class="L12140" rel="L12140">offered you the sincere congratulations of Mrs. Collins and myself on</li>
<li class="L12141" rel="L12141">this happy event, let me now add a short hint on the subject of another;</li>
<li class="L12142" rel="L12142">of which we have been advertised by the same authority. Your daughter</li>
<li class="L12143" rel="L12143">Elizabeth, it is presumed, will not long bear the name of Bennet, after</li>
<li class="L12144" rel="L12144">her elder sister has resigned it, and the chosen partner of her fate may</li>
<li class="L12145" rel="L12145">be reasonably looked up to as one of the most illustrious personages in</li>
<li class="L12146" rel="L12146">this land.&#39;</li>
<li class="L12147" rel="L12147"></li>
<li class="L12148" rel="L12148">“Can you possibly guess, Lizzy, who is meant by this? &#39;This young</li>
<li class="L12149" rel="L12149">gentleman is blessed, in a peculiar way, with every thing the heart of</li>
<li class="L12150" rel="L12150">mortal can most desire,--splendid property, noble kindred, and extensive</li>
<li class="L12151" rel="L12151">patronage. Yet in spite of all these temptations, let me warn my cousin</li>
<li class="L12152" rel="L12152">Elizabeth, and yourself, of what evils you may incur by a precipitate</li>
<li class="L12153" rel="L12153">closure with this gentleman&#39;s proposals, which, of course, you will be</li>
<li class="L12154" rel="L12154">inclined to take immediate advantage of.&#39;</li>
<li class="L12155" rel="L12155"></li>
<li class="L12156" rel="L12156">“Have you any idea, Lizzy, who this gentleman is? But now it comes out:</li>
<li class="L12157" rel="L12157"></li>
<li class="L12158" rel="L12158">“&#39;My motive for cautioning you is as follows. We have reason to imagine</li>
<li class="L12159" rel="L12159">that his aunt, Lady Catherine de Bourgh, does not look on the match with</li>
<li class="L12160" rel="L12160">a friendly eye.&#39;</li>
<li class="L12161" rel="L12161"></li>
<li class="L12162" rel="L12162">“_Mr. Darcy_, you see, is the man! Now, Lizzy, I think I _have_</li>
<li class="L12163" rel="L12163">surprised you. Could he, or the Lucases, have pitched on any man within</li>
<li class="L12164" rel="L12164">the circle of our acquaintance, whose name would have given the lie</li>
<li class="L12165" rel="L12165">more effectually to what they related? Mr. Darcy, who never looks at any</li>
<li class="L12166" rel="L12166">woman but to see a blemish, and who probably never looked at you in his</li>
<li class="L12167" rel="L12167">life! It is admirable!”</li>
<li class="L12168" rel="L12168"></li>
<li class="L12169" rel="L12169">Elizabeth tried to join in her father&#39;s pleasantry, but could only force</li>
<li class="L12170" rel="L12170">one most reluctant smile. Never had his wit been directed in a manner so</li>
<li class="L12171" rel="L12171">little agreeable to her.</li>
<li class="L12172" rel="L12172"></li>
<li class="L12173" rel="L12173">“Are you not diverted?”</li>
<li class="L12174" rel="L12174"></li>
<li class="L12175" rel="L12175">“Oh! yes. Pray read on.”</li>
<li class="L12176" rel="L12176"></li>
<li class="L12177" rel="L12177">“&#39;After mentioning the likelihood of this marriage to her ladyship last</li>
<li class="L12178" rel="L12178">night, she immediately, with her usual condescension, expressed what she</li>
<li class="L12179" rel="L12179">felt on the occasion; when it became apparent, that on the score of some</li>
<li class="L12180" rel="L12180">family objections on the part of my cousin, she would never give her</li>
<li class="L12181" rel="L12181">consent to what she termed so disgraceful a match. I thought it my duty</li>
<li class="L12182" rel="L12182">to give the speediest intelligence of this to my cousin, that she and</li>
<li class="L12183" rel="L12183">her noble admirer may be aware of what they are about, and not run</li>
<li class="L12184" rel="L12184">hastily into a marriage which has not been properly sanctioned.&#39; Mr.</li>
<li class="L12185" rel="L12185">Collins moreover adds, &#39;I am truly rejoiced that my cousin Lydia&#39;s sad</li>
<li class="L12186" rel="L12186">business has been so well hushed up, and am only concerned that their</li>
<li class="L12187" rel="L12187">living together before the marriage took place should be so generally</li>
<li class="L12188" rel="L12188">known. I must not, however, neglect the duties of my station, or refrain</li>
<li class="L12189" rel="L12189">from declaring my amazement at hearing that you received the young</li>
<li class="L12190" rel="L12190">couple into your house as soon as they were married. It was an</li>
<li class="L12191" rel="L12191">encouragement of vice; and had I been the rector of Longbourn, I should</li>
<li class="L12192" rel="L12192">very strenuously have opposed it. You ought certainly to forgive them,</li>
<li class="L12193" rel="L12193">as a Christian, but never to admit them in your sight, or allow their</li>
<li class="L12194" rel="L12194">names to be mentioned in your hearing.&#39; That is his notion of Christian</li>
<li class="L12195" rel="L12195">forgiveness! The rest of his letter is only about his dear Charlotte&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12196" rel="L12196">situation, and his expectation of a young olive-branch. But, Lizzy, you</li>
<li class="L12197" rel="L12197">look as if you did not enjoy it. You are not going to be _missish_,</li>
<li class="L12198" rel="L12198">I hope, and pretend to be affronted at an idle report. For what do we</li>
<li class="L12199" rel="L12199">live, but to make sport for our neighbours, and laugh at them in our</li>
<li class="L12200" rel="L12200">turn?”</li>
<li class="L12201" rel="L12201"></li>
<li class="L12202" rel="L12202">“Oh!” cried Elizabeth, “I am excessively diverted. But it is so</li>
<li class="L12203" rel="L12203">strange!”</li>
<li class="L12204" rel="L12204"></li>
<li class="L12205" rel="L12205">“Yes--_that_ is what makes it amusing. Had they fixed on any other man</li>
<li class="L12206" rel="L12206">it would have been nothing; but _his_ perfect indifference, and _your_</li>
<li class="L12207" rel="L12207">pointed dislike, make it so delightfully absurd! Much as I abominate</li>
<li class="L12208" rel="L12208">writing, I would not give up Mr. Collins&#39;s correspondence for any</li>
<li class="L12209" rel="L12209">consideration. Nay, when I read a letter of his, I cannot help giving</li>
<li class="L12210" rel="L12210">him the preference even over Wickham, much as I value the impudence and</li>
<li class="L12211" rel="L12211">hypocrisy of my son-in-law. And pray, Lizzy, what said Lady Catherine</li>
<li class="L12212" rel="L12212">about this report? Did she call to refuse her consent?”</li>
<li class="L12213" rel="L12213"></li>
<li class="L12214" rel="L12214">To this question his daughter replied only with a laugh; and as it had</li>
<li class="L12215" rel="L12215">been asked without the least suspicion, she was not distressed by</li>
<li class="L12216" rel="L12216">his repeating it. Elizabeth had never been more at a loss to make her</li>
<li class="L12217" rel="L12217">feelings appear what they were not. It was necessary to laugh, when she</li>
<li class="L12218" rel="L12218">would rather have cried. Her father had most cruelly mortified her, by</li>
<li class="L12219" rel="L12219">what he said of Mr. Darcy&#39;s indifference, and she could do nothing but</li>
<li class="L12220" rel="L12220">wonder at such a want of penetration, or fear that perhaps, instead of</li>
<li class="L12221" rel="L12221">his seeing too little, she might have fancied too much.</li>
<li class="L12222" rel="L12222"></li>
<li class="L12223" rel="L12223"></li>
<li class="L12224" rel="L12224"></li>
<li class="L12225" rel="L12225">Chapter 58</li>
<li class="L12226" rel="L12226"></li>
<li class="L12227" rel="L12227"></li>
<li class="L12228" rel="L12228">Instead of receiving any such letter of excuse from his friend, as</li>
<li class="L12229" rel="L12229">Elizabeth half expected Mr. Bingley to do, he was able to bring Darcy</li>
<li class="L12230" rel="L12230">with him to Longbourn before many days had passed after Lady Catherine&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12231" rel="L12231">visit. The gentlemen arrived early; and, before Mrs. Bennet had time</li>
<li class="L12232" rel="L12232">to tell him of their having seen his aunt, of which her daughter sat</li>
<li class="L12233" rel="L12233">in momentary dread, Bingley, who wanted to be alone with Jane, proposed</li>
<li class="L12234" rel="L12234">their all walking out. It was agreed to. Mrs. Bennet was not in the</li>
<li class="L12235" rel="L12235">habit of walking; Mary could never spare time; but the remaining five</li>
<li class="L12236" rel="L12236">set off together. Bingley and Jane, however, soon allowed the others</li>
<li class="L12237" rel="L12237">to outstrip them. They lagged behind, while Elizabeth, Kitty, and Darcy</li>
<li class="L12238" rel="L12238">were to entertain each other. Very little was said by either; Kitty</li>
<li class="L12239" rel="L12239">was too much afraid of him to talk; Elizabeth was secretly forming a</li>
<li class="L12240" rel="L12240">desperate resolution; and perhaps he might be doing the same.</li>
<li class="L12241" rel="L12241"></li>
<li class="L12242" rel="L12242">They walked towards the Lucases, because Kitty wished to call upon</li>
<li class="L12243" rel="L12243">Maria; and as Elizabeth saw no occasion for making it a general concern,</li>
<li class="L12244" rel="L12244">when Kitty left them she went boldly on with him alone. Now was the</li>
<li class="L12245" rel="L12245">moment for her resolution to be executed, and, while her courage was</li>
<li class="L12246" rel="L12246">high, she immediately said:</li>
<li class="L12247" rel="L12247"></li>
<li class="L12248" rel="L12248">“Mr. Darcy, I am a very selfish creature; and, for the sake of giving</li>
<li class="L12249" rel="L12249">relief to my own feelings, care not how much I may be wounding yours. I</li>
<li class="L12250" rel="L12250">can no longer help thanking you for your unexampled kindness to my</li>
<li class="L12251" rel="L12251">poor sister. Ever since I have known it, I have been most anxious to</li>
<li class="L12252" rel="L12252">acknowledge to you how gratefully I feel it. Were it known to the rest</li>
<li class="L12253" rel="L12253">of my family, I should not have merely my own gratitude to express.”</li>
<li class="L12254" rel="L12254"></li>
<li class="L12255" rel="L12255">“I am sorry, exceedingly sorry,” replied Darcy, in a tone of surprise</li>
<li class="L12256" rel="L12256">and emotion, “that you have ever been informed of what may, in a</li>
<li class="L12257" rel="L12257">mistaken light, have given you uneasiness. I did not think Mrs. Gardiner</li>
<li class="L12258" rel="L12258">was so little to be trusted.”</li>
<li class="L12259" rel="L12259"></li>
<li class="L12260" rel="L12260">“You must not blame my aunt. Lydia&#39;s thoughtlessness first betrayed to</li>
<li class="L12261" rel="L12261">me that you had been concerned in the matter; and, of course, I could</li>
<li class="L12262" rel="L12262">not rest till I knew the particulars. Let me thank you again and again,</li>
<li class="L12263" rel="L12263">in the name of all my family, for that generous compassion which induced</li>
<li class="L12264" rel="L12264">you to take so much trouble, and bear so many mortifications, for the</li>
<li class="L12265" rel="L12265">sake of discovering them.”</li>
<li class="L12266" rel="L12266"></li>
<li class="L12267" rel="L12267">“If you _will_ thank me,” he replied, “let it be for yourself alone.</li>
<li class="L12268" rel="L12268">That the wish of giving happiness to you might add force to the other</li>
<li class="L12269" rel="L12269">inducements which led me on, I shall not attempt to deny. But your</li>
<li class="L12270" rel="L12270">_family_ owe me nothing. Much as I respect them, I believe I thought</li>
<li class="L12271" rel="L12271">only of _you_.”</li>
<li class="L12272" rel="L12272"></li>
<li class="L12273" rel="L12273">Elizabeth was too much embarrassed to say a word. After a short pause,</li>
<li class="L12274" rel="L12274">her companion added, “You are too generous to trifle with me. If your</li>
<li class="L12275" rel="L12275">feelings are still what they were last April, tell me so at once. _My_</li>
<li class="L12276" rel="L12276">affections and wishes are unchanged, but one word from you will silence</li>
<li class="L12277" rel="L12277">me on this subject for ever.”</li>
<li class="L12278" rel="L12278"></li>
<li class="L12279" rel="L12279">Elizabeth, feeling all the more than common awkwardness and anxiety of</li>
<li class="L12280" rel="L12280">his situation, now forced herself to speak; and immediately, though not</li>
<li class="L12281" rel="L12281">very fluently, gave him to understand that her sentiments had undergone</li>
<li class="L12282" rel="L12282">so material a change, since the period to which he alluded, as to make</li>
<li class="L12283" rel="L12283">her receive with gratitude and pleasure his present assurances. The</li>
<li class="L12284" rel="L12284">happiness which this reply produced, was such as he had probably never</li>
<li class="L12285" rel="L12285">felt before; and he expressed himself on the occasion as sensibly and as</li>
<li class="L12286" rel="L12286">warmly as a man violently in love can be supposed to do. Had Elizabeth</li>
<li class="L12287" rel="L12287">been able to encounter his eye, she might have seen how well the</li>
<li class="L12288" rel="L12288">expression of heartfelt delight, diffused over his face, became him;</li>
<li class="L12289" rel="L12289">but, though she could not look, she could listen, and he told her of</li>
<li class="L12290" rel="L12290">feelings, which, in proving of what importance she was to him, made his</li>
<li class="L12291" rel="L12291">affection every moment more valuable.</li>
<li class="L12292" rel="L12292"></li>
<li class="L12293" rel="L12293">They walked on, without knowing in what direction. There was too much to</li>
<li class="L12294" rel="L12294">be thought, and felt, and said, for attention to any other objects. She</li>
<li class="L12295" rel="L12295">soon learnt that they were indebted for their present good understanding</li>
<li class="L12296" rel="L12296">to the efforts of his aunt, who did call on him in her return through</li>
<li class="L12297" rel="L12297">London, and there relate her journey to Longbourn, its motive, and the</li>
<li class="L12298" rel="L12298">substance of her conversation with Elizabeth; dwelling emphatically on</li>
<li class="L12299" rel="L12299">every expression of the latter which, in her ladyship&#39;s apprehension,</li>
<li class="L12300" rel="L12300">peculiarly denoted her perverseness and assurance; in the belief that</li>
<li class="L12301" rel="L12301">such a relation must assist her endeavours to obtain that promise</li>
<li class="L12302" rel="L12302">from her nephew which she had refused to give. But, unluckily for her</li>
<li class="L12303" rel="L12303">ladyship, its effect had been exactly contrariwise.</li>
<li class="L12304" rel="L12304"></li>
<li class="L12305" rel="L12305">“It taught me to hope,” said he, “as I had scarcely ever allowed myself</li>
<li class="L12306" rel="L12306">to hope before. I knew enough of your disposition to be certain that,</li>
<li class="L12307" rel="L12307">had you been absolutely, irrevocably decided against me, you would have</li>
<li class="L12308" rel="L12308">acknowledged it to Lady Catherine, frankly and openly.”</li>
<li class="L12309" rel="L12309"></li>
<li class="L12310" rel="L12310">Elizabeth coloured and laughed as she replied, “Yes, you know enough</li>
<li class="L12311" rel="L12311">of my frankness to believe me capable of _that_. After abusing you so</li>
<li class="L12312" rel="L12312">abominably to your face, I could have no scruple in abusing you to all</li>
<li class="L12313" rel="L12313">your relations.”</li>
<li class="L12314" rel="L12314"></li>
<li class="L12315" rel="L12315">“What did you say of me, that I did not deserve? For, though your</li>
<li class="L12316" rel="L12316">accusations were ill-founded, formed on mistaken premises, my</li>
<li class="L12317" rel="L12317">behaviour to you at the time had merited the severest reproof. It was</li>
<li class="L12318" rel="L12318">unpardonable. I cannot think of it without abhorrence.”</li>
<li class="L12319" rel="L12319"></li>
<li class="L12320" rel="L12320">“We will not quarrel for the greater share of blame annexed to that</li>
<li class="L12321" rel="L12321">evening,” said Elizabeth. “The conduct of neither, if strictly examined,</li>
<li class="L12322" rel="L12322">will be irreproachable; but since then, we have both, I hope, improved</li>
<li class="L12323" rel="L12323">in civility.”</li>
<li class="L12324" rel="L12324"></li>
<li class="L12325" rel="L12325">“I cannot be so easily reconciled to myself. The recollection of what I</li>
<li class="L12326" rel="L12326">then said, of my conduct, my manners, my expressions during the whole of</li>
<li class="L12327" rel="L12327">it, is now, and has been many months, inexpressibly painful to me. Your</li>
<li class="L12328" rel="L12328">reproof, so well applied, I shall never forget: &#39;had you behaved in a</li>
<li class="L12329" rel="L12329">more gentlemanlike manner.&#39; Those were your words. You know not, you can</li>
<li class="L12330" rel="L12330">scarcely conceive, how they have tortured me;--though it was some time,</li>
<li class="L12331" rel="L12331">I confess, before I was reasonable enough to allow their justice.”</li>
<li class="L12332" rel="L12332"></li>
<li class="L12333" rel="L12333">“I was certainly very far from expecting them to make so strong an</li>
<li class="L12334" rel="L12334">impression. I had not the smallest idea of their being ever felt in such</li>
<li class="L12335" rel="L12335">a way.”</li>
<li class="L12336" rel="L12336"></li>
<li class="L12337" rel="L12337">“I can easily believe it. You thought me then devoid of every proper</li>
<li class="L12338" rel="L12338">feeling, I am sure you did. The turn of your countenance I shall never</li>
<li class="L12339" rel="L12339">forget, as you said that I could not have addressed you in any possible</li>
<li class="L12340" rel="L12340">way that would induce you to accept me.”</li>
<li class="L12341" rel="L12341"></li>
<li class="L12342" rel="L12342">“Oh! do not repeat what I then said. These recollections will not do at</li>
<li class="L12343" rel="L12343">all. I assure you that I have long been most heartily ashamed of it.”</li>
<li class="L12344" rel="L12344"></li>
<li class="L12345" rel="L12345">Darcy mentioned his letter. “Did it,” said he, “did it soon make you</li>
<li class="L12346" rel="L12346">think better of me? Did you, on reading it, give any credit to its</li>
<li class="L12347" rel="L12347">contents?”</li>
<li class="L12348" rel="L12348"></li>
<li class="L12349" rel="L12349">She explained what its effect on her had been, and how gradually all her</li>
<li class="L12350" rel="L12350">former prejudices had been removed.</li>
<li class="L12351" rel="L12351"></li>
<li class="L12352" rel="L12352">“I knew,” said he, “that what I wrote must give you pain, but it was</li>
<li class="L12353" rel="L12353">necessary. I hope you have destroyed the letter. There was one part</li>
<li class="L12354" rel="L12354">especially, the opening of it, which I should dread your having the</li>
<li class="L12355" rel="L12355">power of reading again. I can remember some expressions which might</li>
<li class="L12356" rel="L12356">justly make you hate me.”</li>
<li class="L12357" rel="L12357"></li>
<li class="L12358" rel="L12358">“The letter shall certainly be burnt, if you believe it essential to the</li>
<li class="L12359" rel="L12359">preservation of my regard; but, though we have both reason to think my</li>
<li class="L12360" rel="L12360">opinions not entirely unalterable, they are not, I hope, quite so easily</li>
<li class="L12361" rel="L12361">changed as that implies.”</li>
<li class="L12362" rel="L12362"></li>
<li class="L12363" rel="L12363">“When I wrote that letter,” replied Darcy, “I believed myself perfectly</li>
<li class="L12364" rel="L12364">calm and cool, but I am since convinced that it was written in a</li>
<li class="L12365" rel="L12365">dreadful bitterness of spirit.”</li>
<li class="L12366" rel="L12366"></li>
<li class="L12367" rel="L12367">“The letter, perhaps, began in bitterness, but it did not end so. The</li>
<li class="L12368" rel="L12368">adieu is charity itself. But think no more of the letter. The feelings</li>
<li class="L12369" rel="L12369">of the person who wrote, and the person who received it, are now</li>
<li class="L12370" rel="L12370">so widely different from what they were then, that every unpleasant</li>
<li class="L12371" rel="L12371">circumstance attending it ought to be forgotten. You must learn some</li>
<li class="L12372" rel="L12372">of my philosophy. Think only of the past as its remembrance gives you</li>
<li class="L12373" rel="L12373">pleasure.”</li>
<li class="L12374" rel="L12374"></li>
<li class="L12375" rel="L12375">“I cannot give you credit for any philosophy of the kind. Your</li>
<li class="L12376" rel="L12376">retrospections must be so totally void of reproach, that the contentment</li>
<li class="L12377" rel="L12377">arising from them is not of philosophy, but, what is much better, of</li>
<li class="L12378" rel="L12378">innocence. But with me, it is not so. Painful recollections will intrude</li>
<li class="L12379" rel="L12379">which cannot, which ought not, to be repelled. I have been a selfish</li>
<li class="L12380" rel="L12380">being all my life, in practice, though not in principle. As a child I</li>
<li class="L12381" rel="L12381">was taught what was right, but I was not taught to correct my temper. I</li>
<li class="L12382" rel="L12382">was given good principles, but left to follow them in pride and conceit.</li>
<li class="L12383" rel="L12383">Unfortunately an only son (for many years an only child), I was spoilt</li>
<li class="L12384" rel="L12384">by my parents, who, though good themselves (my father, particularly, all</li>
<li class="L12385" rel="L12385">that was benevolent and amiable), allowed, encouraged, almost taught</li>
<li class="L12386" rel="L12386">me to be selfish and overbearing; to care for none beyond my own family</li>
<li class="L12387" rel="L12387">circle; to think meanly of all the rest of the world; to wish at least</li>
<li class="L12388" rel="L12388">to think meanly of their sense and worth compared with my own. Such I</li>
<li class="L12389" rel="L12389">was, from eight to eight and twenty; and such I might still have been</li>
<li class="L12390" rel="L12390">but for you, dearest, loveliest Elizabeth! What do I not owe you! You</li>
<li class="L12391" rel="L12391">taught me a lesson, hard indeed at first, but most advantageous. By you,</li>
<li class="L12392" rel="L12392">I was properly humbled. I came to you without a doubt of my reception.</li>
<li class="L12393" rel="L12393">You showed me how insufficient were all my pretensions to please a woman</li>
<li class="L12394" rel="L12394">worthy of being pleased.”</li>
<li class="L12395" rel="L12395"></li>
<li class="L12396" rel="L12396">“Had you then persuaded yourself that I should?”</li>
<li class="L12397" rel="L12397"></li>
<li class="L12398" rel="L12398">“Indeed I had. What will you think of my vanity? I believed you to be</li>
<li class="L12399" rel="L12399">wishing, expecting my addresses.”</li>
<li class="L12400" rel="L12400"></li>
<li class="L12401" rel="L12401">“My manners must have been in fault, but not intentionally, I assure</li>
<li class="L12402" rel="L12402">you. I never meant to deceive you, but my spirits might often lead me</li>
<li class="L12403" rel="L12403">wrong. How you must have hated me after _that_ evening?”</li>
<li class="L12404" rel="L12404"></li>
<li class="L12405" rel="L12405">“Hate you! I was angry perhaps at first, but my anger soon began to take</li>
<li class="L12406" rel="L12406">a proper direction.”</li>
<li class="L12407" rel="L12407"></li>
<li class="L12408" rel="L12408">“I am almost afraid of asking what you thought of me, when we met at</li>
<li class="L12409" rel="L12409">Pemberley. You blamed me for coming?”</li>
<li class="L12410" rel="L12410"></li>
<li class="L12411" rel="L12411">“No indeed; I felt nothing but surprise.”</li>
<li class="L12412" rel="L12412"></li>
<li class="L12413" rel="L12413">“Your surprise could not be greater than _mine_ in being noticed by you.</li>
<li class="L12414" rel="L12414">My conscience told me that I deserved no extraordinary politeness, and I</li>
<li class="L12415" rel="L12415">confess that I did not expect to receive _more_ than my due.”</li>
<li class="L12416" rel="L12416"></li>
<li class="L12417" rel="L12417">“My object then,” replied Darcy, “was to show you, by every civility in</li>
<li class="L12418" rel="L12418">my power, that I was not so mean as to resent the past; and I hoped to</li>
<li class="L12419" rel="L12419">obtain your forgiveness, to lessen your ill opinion, by letting you</li>
<li class="L12420" rel="L12420">see that your reproofs had been attended to. How soon any other wishes</li>
<li class="L12421" rel="L12421">introduced themselves I can hardly tell, but I believe in about half an</li>
<li class="L12422" rel="L12422">hour after I had seen you.”</li>
<li class="L12423" rel="L12423"></li>
<li class="L12424" rel="L12424">He then told her of Georgiana&#39;s delight in her acquaintance, and of her</li>
<li class="L12425" rel="L12425">disappointment at its sudden interruption; which naturally leading to</li>
<li class="L12426" rel="L12426">the cause of that interruption, she soon learnt that his resolution of</li>
<li class="L12427" rel="L12427">following her from Derbyshire in quest of her sister had been formed</li>
<li class="L12428" rel="L12428">before he quitted the inn, and that his gravity and thoughtfulness</li>
<li class="L12429" rel="L12429">there had arisen from no other struggles than what such a purpose must</li>
<li class="L12430" rel="L12430">comprehend.</li>
<li class="L12431" rel="L12431"></li>
<li class="L12432" rel="L12432">She expressed her gratitude again, but it was too painful a subject to</li>
<li class="L12433" rel="L12433">each, to be dwelt on farther.</li>
<li class="L12434" rel="L12434"></li>
<li class="L12435" rel="L12435">After walking several miles in a leisurely manner, and too busy to know</li>
<li class="L12436" rel="L12436">anything about it, they found at last, on examining their watches, that</li>
<li class="L12437" rel="L12437">it was time to be at home.</li>
<li class="L12438" rel="L12438"></li>
<li class="L12439" rel="L12439">“What could become of Mr. Bingley and Jane!” was a wonder which</li>
<li class="L12440" rel="L12440">introduced the discussion of their affairs. Darcy was delighted with</li>
<li class="L12441" rel="L12441">their engagement; his friend had given him the earliest information of</li>
<li class="L12442" rel="L12442">it.</li>
<li class="L12443" rel="L12443"></li>
<li class="L12444" rel="L12444">“I must ask whether you were surprised?” said Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L12445" rel="L12445"></li>
<li class="L12446" rel="L12446">“Not at all. When I went away, I felt that it would soon happen.”</li>
<li class="L12447" rel="L12447"></li>
<li class="L12448" rel="L12448">“That is to say, you had given your permission. I guessed as much.” And</li>
<li class="L12449" rel="L12449">though he exclaimed at the term, she found that it had been pretty much</li>
<li class="L12450" rel="L12450">the case.</li>
<li class="L12451" rel="L12451"></li>
<li class="L12452" rel="L12452">“On the evening before my going to London,” said he, “I made a</li>
<li class="L12453" rel="L12453">confession to him, which I believe I ought to have made long ago. I</li>
<li class="L12454" rel="L12454">told him of all that had occurred to make my former interference in his</li>
<li class="L12455" rel="L12455">affairs absurd and impertinent. His surprise was great. He had never had</li>
<li class="L12456" rel="L12456">the slightest suspicion. I told him, moreover, that I believed myself</li>
<li class="L12457" rel="L12457">mistaken in supposing, as I had done, that your sister was indifferent</li>
<li class="L12458" rel="L12458">to him; and as I could easily perceive that his attachment to her was</li>
<li class="L12459" rel="L12459">unabated, I felt no doubt of their happiness together.”</li>
<li class="L12460" rel="L12460"></li>
<li class="L12461" rel="L12461">Elizabeth could not help smiling at his easy manner of directing his</li>
<li class="L12462" rel="L12462">friend.</li>
<li class="L12463" rel="L12463"></li>
<li class="L12464" rel="L12464">“Did you speak from your own observation,” said she, “when you told him</li>
<li class="L12465" rel="L12465">that my sister loved him, or merely from my information last spring?”</li>
<li class="L12466" rel="L12466"></li>
<li class="L12467" rel="L12467">“From the former. I had narrowly observed her during the two visits</li>
<li class="L12468" rel="L12468">which I had lately made here; and I was convinced of her affection.”</li>
<li class="L12469" rel="L12469"></li>
<li class="L12470" rel="L12470">“And your assurance of it, I suppose, carried immediate conviction to</li>
<li class="L12471" rel="L12471">him.”</li>
<li class="L12472" rel="L12472"></li>
<li class="L12473" rel="L12473">“It did. Bingley is most unaffectedly modest. His diffidence had</li>
<li class="L12474" rel="L12474">prevented his depending on his own judgment in so anxious a case, but</li>
<li class="L12475" rel="L12475">his reliance on mine made every thing easy. I was obliged to confess</li>
<li class="L12476" rel="L12476">one thing, which for a time, and not unjustly, offended him. I could not</li>
<li class="L12477" rel="L12477">allow myself to conceal that your sister had been in town three months</li>
<li class="L12478" rel="L12478">last winter, that I had known it, and purposely kept it from him. He was</li>
<li class="L12479" rel="L12479">angry. But his anger, I am persuaded, lasted no longer than he remained</li>
<li class="L12480" rel="L12480">in any doubt of your sister&#39;s sentiments. He has heartily forgiven me</li>
<li class="L12481" rel="L12481">now.”</li>
<li class="L12482" rel="L12482"></li>
<li class="L12483" rel="L12483">Elizabeth longed to observe that Mr. Bingley had been a most delightful</li>
<li class="L12484" rel="L12484">friend; so easily guided that his worth was invaluable; but she checked</li>
<li class="L12485" rel="L12485">herself. She remembered that he had yet to learn to be laughed at,</li>
<li class="L12486" rel="L12486">and it was rather too early to begin. In anticipating the happiness</li>
<li class="L12487" rel="L12487">of Bingley, which of course was to be inferior only to his own, he</li>
<li class="L12488" rel="L12488">continued the conversation till they reached the house. In the hall they</li>
<li class="L12489" rel="L12489">parted.</li>
<li class="L12490" rel="L12490"></li>
<li class="L12491" rel="L12491"></li>
<li class="L12492" rel="L12492"></li>
<li class="L12493" rel="L12493">Chapter 59</li>
<li class="L12494" rel="L12494"></li>
<li class="L12495" rel="L12495"></li>
<li class="L12496" rel="L12496">“My dear Lizzy, where can you have been walking to?” was a question</li>
<li class="L12497" rel="L12497">which Elizabeth received from Jane as soon as she entered their room,</li>
<li class="L12498" rel="L12498">and from all the others when they sat down to table. She had only to</li>
<li class="L12499" rel="L12499">say in reply, that they had wandered about, till she was beyond her own</li>
<li class="L12500" rel="L12500">knowledge. She coloured as she spoke; but neither that, nor anything</li>
<li class="L12501" rel="L12501">else, awakened a suspicion of the truth.</li>
<li class="L12502" rel="L12502"></li>
<li class="L12503" rel="L12503">The evening passed quietly, unmarked by anything extraordinary. The</li>
<li class="L12504" rel="L12504">acknowledged lovers talked and laughed, the unacknowledged were silent.</li>
<li class="L12505" rel="L12505">Darcy was not of a disposition in which happiness overflows in mirth;</li>
<li class="L12506" rel="L12506">and Elizabeth, agitated and confused, rather _knew_ that she was happy</li>
<li class="L12507" rel="L12507">than _felt_ herself to be so; for, besides the immediate embarrassment,</li>
<li class="L12508" rel="L12508">there were other evils before her. She anticipated what would be felt</li>
<li class="L12509" rel="L12509">in the family when her situation became known; she was aware that no</li>
<li class="L12510" rel="L12510">one liked him but Jane; and even feared that with the others it was a</li>
<li class="L12511" rel="L12511">dislike which not all his fortune and consequence might do away.</li>
<li class="L12512" rel="L12512"></li>
<li class="L12513" rel="L12513">At night she opened her heart to Jane. Though suspicion was very far</li>
<li class="L12514" rel="L12514">from Miss Bennet&#39;s general habits, she was absolutely incredulous here.</li>
<li class="L12515" rel="L12515"></li>
<li class="L12516" rel="L12516">“You are joking, Lizzy. This cannot be!--engaged to Mr. Darcy! No, no,</li>
<li class="L12517" rel="L12517">you shall not deceive me. I know it to be impossible.”</li>
<li class="L12518" rel="L12518"></li>
<li class="L12519" rel="L12519">“This is a wretched beginning indeed! My sole dependence was on you; and</li>
<li class="L12520" rel="L12520">I am sure nobody else will believe me, if you do not. Yet, indeed, I am</li>
<li class="L12521" rel="L12521">in earnest. I speak nothing but the truth. He still loves me, and we are</li>
<li class="L12522" rel="L12522">engaged.”</li>
<li class="L12523" rel="L12523"></li>
<li class="L12524" rel="L12524">Jane looked at her doubtingly. “Oh, Lizzy! it cannot be. I know how much</li>
<li class="L12525" rel="L12525">you dislike him.”</li>
<li class="L12526" rel="L12526"></li>
<li class="L12527" rel="L12527">“You know nothing of the matter. _That_ is all to be forgot. Perhaps I</li>
<li class="L12528" rel="L12528">did not always love him so well as I do now. But in such cases as</li>
<li class="L12529" rel="L12529">these, a good memory is unpardonable. This is the last time I shall ever</li>
<li class="L12530" rel="L12530">remember it myself.”</li>
<li class="L12531" rel="L12531"></li>
<li class="L12532" rel="L12532">Miss Bennet still looked all amazement. Elizabeth again, and more</li>
<li class="L12533" rel="L12533">seriously assured her of its truth.</li>
<li class="L12534" rel="L12534"></li>
<li class="L12535" rel="L12535">“Good Heaven! can it be really so! Yet now I must believe you,” cried</li>
<li class="L12536" rel="L12536">Jane. “My dear, dear Lizzy, I would--I do congratulate you--but are you</li>
<li class="L12537" rel="L12537">certain? forgive the question--are you quite certain that you can be</li>
<li class="L12538" rel="L12538">happy with him?”</li>
<li class="L12539" rel="L12539"></li>
<li class="L12540" rel="L12540">“There can be no doubt of that. It is settled between us already, that</li>
<li class="L12541" rel="L12541">we are to be the happiest couple in the world. But are you pleased,</li>
<li class="L12542" rel="L12542">Jane? Shall you like to have such a brother?”</li>
<li class="L12543" rel="L12543"></li>
<li class="L12544" rel="L12544">“Very, very much. Nothing could give either Bingley or myself more</li>
<li class="L12545" rel="L12545">delight. But we considered it, we talked of it as impossible. And do you</li>
<li class="L12546" rel="L12546">really love him quite well enough? Oh, Lizzy! do anything rather than</li>
<li class="L12547" rel="L12547">marry without affection. Are you quite sure that you feel what you ought</li>
<li class="L12548" rel="L12548">to do?”</li>
<li class="L12549" rel="L12549"></li>
<li class="L12550" rel="L12550">“Oh, yes! You will only think I feel _more_ than I ought to do, when I</li>
<li class="L12551" rel="L12551">tell you all.”</li>
<li class="L12552" rel="L12552"></li>
<li class="L12553" rel="L12553">“What do you mean?”</li>
<li class="L12554" rel="L12554"></li>
<li class="L12555" rel="L12555">“Why, I must confess that I love him better than I do Bingley. I am</li>
<li class="L12556" rel="L12556">afraid you will be angry.”</li>
<li class="L12557" rel="L12557"></li>
<li class="L12558" rel="L12558">“My dearest sister, now _be_ serious. I want to talk very seriously. Let</li>
<li class="L12559" rel="L12559">me know every thing that I am to know, without delay. Will you tell me</li>
<li class="L12560" rel="L12560">how long you have loved him?”</li>
<li class="L12561" rel="L12561"></li>
<li class="L12562" rel="L12562">“It has been coming on so gradually, that I hardly know when it began.</li>
<li class="L12563" rel="L12563">But I believe I must date it from my first seeing his beautiful grounds</li>
<li class="L12564" rel="L12564">at Pemberley.”</li>
<li class="L12565" rel="L12565"></li>
<li class="L12566" rel="L12566">Another entreaty that she would be serious, however, produced the</li>
<li class="L12567" rel="L12567">desired effect; and she soon satisfied Jane by her solemn assurances</li>
<li class="L12568" rel="L12568">of attachment. When convinced on that article, Miss Bennet had nothing</li>
<li class="L12569" rel="L12569">further to wish.</li>
<li class="L12570" rel="L12570"></li>
<li class="L12571" rel="L12571">“Now I am quite happy,” said she, “for you will be as happy as myself.</li>
<li class="L12572" rel="L12572">I always had a value for him. Were it for nothing but his love of you,</li>
<li class="L12573" rel="L12573">I must always have esteemed him; but now, as Bingley&#39;s friend and your</li>
<li class="L12574" rel="L12574">husband, there can be only Bingley and yourself more dear to me. But</li>
<li class="L12575" rel="L12575">Lizzy, you have been very sly, very reserved with me. How little did you</li>
<li class="L12576" rel="L12576">tell me of what passed at Pemberley and Lambton! I owe all that I know</li>
<li class="L12577" rel="L12577">of it to another, not to you.”</li>
<li class="L12578" rel="L12578"></li>
<li class="L12579" rel="L12579">Elizabeth told her the motives of her secrecy. She had been unwilling</li>
<li class="L12580" rel="L12580">to mention Bingley; and the unsettled state of her own feelings had made</li>
<li class="L12581" rel="L12581">her equally avoid the name of his friend. But now she would no longer</li>
<li class="L12582" rel="L12582">conceal from her his share in Lydia&#39;s marriage. All was acknowledged,</li>
<li class="L12583" rel="L12583">and half the night spent in conversation.</li>
<li class="L12584" rel="L12584"></li>
<li class="L12585" rel="L12585">                          * * * * *</li>
<li class="L12586" rel="L12586"></li>
<li class="L12587" rel="L12587">“Good gracious!” cried Mrs. Bennet, as she stood at a window the next</li>
<li class="L12588" rel="L12588">morning, “if that disagreeable Mr. Darcy is not coming here again with</li>
<li class="L12589" rel="L12589">our dear Bingley! What can he mean by being so tiresome as to be always</li>
<li class="L12590" rel="L12590">coming here? I had no notion but he would go a-shooting, or something or</li>
<li class="L12591" rel="L12591">other, and not disturb us with his company. What shall we do with him?</li>
<li class="L12592" rel="L12592">Lizzy, you must walk out with him again, that he may not be in Bingley&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12593" rel="L12593">way.”</li>
<li class="L12594" rel="L12594"></li>
<li class="L12595" rel="L12595">Elizabeth could hardly help laughing at so convenient a proposal; yet</li>
<li class="L12596" rel="L12596">was really vexed that her mother should be always giving him such an</li>
<li class="L12597" rel="L12597">epithet.</li>
<li class="L12598" rel="L12598"></li>
<li class="L12599" rel="L12599">As soon as they entered, Bingley looked at her so expressively, and</li>
<li class="L12600" rel="L12600">shook hands with such warmth, as left no doubt of his good information;</li>
<li class="L12601" rel="L12601">and he soon afterwards said aloud, “Mrs. Bennet, have you no more lanes</li>
<li class="L12602" rel="L12602">hereabouts in which Lizzy may lose her way again to-day?”</li>
<li class="L12603" rel="L12603"></li>
<li class="L12604" rel="L12604">“I advise Mr. Darcy, and Lizzy, and Kitty,” said Mrs. Bennet, “to walk</li>
<li class="L12605" rel="L12605">to Oakham Mount this morning. It is a nice long walk, and Mr. Darcy has</li>
<li class="L12606" rel="L12606">never seen the view.”</li>
<li class="L12607" rel="L12607"></li>
<li class="L12608" rel="L12608">“It may do very well for the others,” replied Mr. Bingley; “but I am</li>
<li class="L12609" rel="L12609">sure it will be too much for Kitty. Won&#39;t it, Kitty?” Kitty owned that</li>
<li class="L12610" rel="L12610">she had rather stay at home. Darcy professed a great curiosity to see</li>
<li class="L12611" rel="L12611">the view from the Mount, and Elizabeth silently consented. As she went</li>
<li class="L12612" rel="L12612">up stairs to get ready, Mrs. Bennet followed her, saying:</li>
<li class="L12613" rel="L12613"></li>
<li class="L12614" rel="L12614">“I am quite sorry, Lizzy, that you should be forced to have that</li>
<li class="L12615" rel="L12615">disagreeable man all to yourself. But I hope you will not mind it: it is</li>
<li class="L12616" rel="L12616">all for Jane&#39;s sake, you know; and there is no occasion for talking</li>
<li class="L12617" rel="L12617">to him, except just now and then. So, do not put yourself to</li>
<li class="L12618" rel="L12618">inconvenience.”</li>
<li class="L12619" rel="L12619"></li>
<li class="L12620" rel="L12620">During their walk, it was resolved that Mr. Bennet&#39;s consent should be</li>
<li class="L12621" rel="L12621">asked in the course of the evening. Elizabeth reserved to herself the</li>
<li class="L12622" rel="L12622">application for her mother&#39;s. She could not determine how her mother</li>
<li class="L12623" rel="L12623">would take it; sometimes doubting whether all his wealth and grandeur</li>
<li class="L12624" rel="L12624">would be enough to overcome her abhorrence of the man. But whether she</li>
<li class="L12625" rel="L12625">were violently set against the match, or violently delighted with it, it</li>
<li class="L12626" rel="L12626">was certain that her manner would be equally ill adapted to do credit</li>
<li class="L12627" rel="L12627">to her sense; and she could no more bear that Mr. Darcy should hear</li>
<li class="L12628" rel="L12628">the first raptures of her joy, than the first vehemence of her</li>
<li class="L12629" rel="L12629">disapprobation.</li>
<li class="L12630" rel="L12630"></li>
<li class="L12631" rel="L12631">                          * * * * *</li>
<li class="L12632" rel="L12632"></li>
<li class="L12633" rel="L12633">In the evening, soon after Mr. Bennet withdrew to the library, she saw</li>
<li class="L12634" rel="L12634">Mr. Darcy rise also and follow him, and her agitation on seeing it was</li>
<li class="L12635" rel="L12635">extreme. She did not fear her father&#39;s opposition, but he was going to</li>
<li class="L12636" rel="L12636">be made unhappy; and that it should be through her means--that _she_,</li>
<li class="L12637" rel="L12637">his favourite child, should be distressing him by her choice, should be</li>
<li class="L12638" rel="L12638">filling him with fears and regrets in disposing of her--was a wretched</li>
<li class="L12639" rel="L12639">reflection, and she sat in misery till Mr. Darcy appeared again, when,</li>
<li class="L12640" rel="L12640">looking at him, she was a little relieved by his smile. In a few minutes</li>
<li class="L12641" rel="L12641">he approached the table where she was sitting with Kitty; and, while</li>
<li class="L12642" rel="L12642">pretending to admire her work said in a whisper, “Go to your father, he</li>
<li class="L12643" rel="L12643">wants you in the library.” She was gone directly.</li>
<li class="L12644" rel="L12644"></li>
<li class="L12645" rel="L12645">Her father was walking about the room, looking grave and anxious.</li>
<li class="L12646" rel="L12646">“Lizzy,” said he, “what are you doing? Are you out of your senses, to be</li>
<li class="L12647" rel="L12647">accepting this man? Have not you always hated him?”</li>
<li class="L12648" rel="L12648"></li>
<li class="L12649" rel="L12649">How earnestly did she then wish that her former opinions had been more</li>
<li class="L12650" rel="L12650">reasonable, her expressions more moderate! It would have spared her from</li>
<li class="L12651" rel="L12651">explanations and professions which it was exceedingly awkward to give;</li>
<li class="L12652" rel="L12652">but they were now necessary, and she assured him, with some confusion,</li>
<li class="L12653" rel="L12653">of her attachment to Mr. Darcy.</li>
<li class="L12654" rel="L12654"></li>
<li class="L12655" rel="L12655">“Or, in other words, you are determined to have him. He is rich, to be</li>
<li class="L12656" rel="L12656">sure, and you may have more fine clothes and fine carriages than Jane.</li>
<li class="L12657" rel="L12657">But will they make you happy?”</li>
<li class="L12658" rel="L12658"></li>
<li class="L12659" rel="L12659">“Have you any other objection,” said Elizabeth, “than your belief of my</li>
<li class="L12660" rel="L12660">indifference?”</li>
<li class="L12661" rel="L12661"></li>
<li class="L12662" rel="L12662">“None at all. We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of man; but</li>
<li class="L12663" rel="L12663">this would be nothing if you really liked him.”</li>
<li class="L12664" rel="L12664"></li>
<li class="L12665" rel="L12665">“I do, I do like him,” she replied, with tears in her eyes, “I love him.</li>
<li class="L12666" rel="L12666">Indeed he has no improper pride. He is perfectly amiable. You do not</li>
<li class="L12667" rel="L12667">know what he really is; then pray do not pain me by speaking of him in</li>
<li class="L12668" rel="L12668">such terms.”</li>
<li class="L12669" rel="L12669"></li>
<li class="L12670" rel="L12670">“Lizzy,” said her father, “I have given him my consent. He is the kind</li>
<li class="L12671" rel="L12671">of man, indeed, to whom I should never dare refuse anything, which he</li>
<li class="L12672" rel="L12672">condescended to ask. I now give it to _you_, if you are resolved on</li>
<li class="L12673" rel="L12673">having him. But let me advise you to think better of it. I know</li>
<li class="L12674" rel="L12674">your disposition, Lizzy. I know that you could be neither happy nor</li>
<li class="L12675" rel="L12675">respectable, unless you truly esteemed your husband; unless you looked</li>
<li class="L12676" rel="L12676">up to him as a superior. Your lively talents would place you in the</li>
<li class="L12677" rel="L12677">greatest danger in an unequal marriage. You could scarcely escape</li>
<li class="L12678" rel="L12678">discredit and misery. My child, let me not have the grief of seeing</li>
<li class="L12679" rel="L12679">_you_ unable to respect your partner in life. You know not what you are</li>
<li class="L12680" rel="L12680">about.”</li>
<li class="L12681" rel="L12681"></li>
<li class="L12682" rel="L12682">Elizabeth, still more affected, was earnest and solemn in her reply; and</li>
<li class="L12683" rel="L12683">at length, by repeated assurances that Mr. Darcy was really the object</li>
<li class="L12684" rel="L12684">of her choice, by explaining the gradual change which her estimation of</li>
<li class="L12685" rel="L12685">him had undergone, relating her absolute certainty that his affection</li>
<li class="L12686" rel="L12686">was not the work of a day, but had stood the test of many months&#39;</li>
<li class="L12687" rel="L12687">suspense, and enumerating with energy all his good qualities, she did</li>
<li class="L12688" rel="L12688">conquer her father&#39;s incredulity, and reconcile him to the match.</li>
<li class="L12689" rel="L12689"></li>
<li class="L12690" rel="L12690">“Well, my dear,” said he, when she ceased speaking, “I have no more to</li>
<li class="L12691" rel="L12691">say. If this be the case, he deserves you. I could not have parted with</li>
<li class="L12692" rel="L12692">you, my Lizzy, to anyone less worthy.”</li>
<li class="L12693" rel="L12693"></li>
<li class="L12694" rel="L12694">To complete the favourable impression, she then told him what Mr. Darcy</li>
<li class="L12695" rel="L12695">had voluntarily done for Lydia. He heard her with astonishment.</li>
<li class="L12696" rel="L12696"></li>
<li class="L12697" rel="L12697">“This is an evening of wonders, indeed! And so, Darcy did every thing;</li>
<li class="L12698" rel="L12698">made up the match, gave the money, paid the fellow&#39;s debts, and got him</li>
<li class="L12699" rel="L12699">his commission! So much the better. It will save me a world of trouble</li>
<li class="L12700" rel="L12700">and economy. Had it been your uncle&#39;s doing, I must and _would_ have</li>
<li class="L12701" rel="L12701">paid him; but these violent young lovers carry every thing their own</li>
<li class="L12702" rel="L12702">way. I shall offer to pay him to-morrow; he will rant and storm about</li>
<li class="L12703" rel="L12703">his love for you, and there will be an end of the matter.”</li>
<li class="L12704" rel="L12704"></li>
<li class="L12705" rel="L12705">He then recollected her embarrassment a few days before, on his reading</li>
<li class="L12706" rel="L12706">Mr. Collins&#39;s letter; and after laughing at her some time, allowed her</li>
<li class="L12707" rel="L12707">at last to go--saying, as she quitted the room, “If any young men come</li>
<li class="L12708" rel="L12708">for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at leisure.”</li>
<li class="L12709" rel="L12709"></li>
<li class="L12710" rel="L12710">Elizabeth&#39;s mind was now relieved from a very heavy weight; and, after</li>
<li class="L12711" rel="L12711">half an hour&#39;s quiet reflection in her own room, she was able to join</li>
<li class="L12712" rel="L12712">the others with tolerable composure. Every thing was too recent for</li>
<li class="L12713" rel="L12713">gaiety, but the evening passed tranquilly away; there was no longer</li>
<li class="L12714" rel="L12714">anything material to be dreaded, and the comfort of ease and familiarity</li>
<li class="L12715" rel="L12715">would come in time.</li>
<li class="L12716" rel="L12716"></li>
<li class="L12717" rel="L12717">When her mother went up to her dressing-room at night, she followed her,</li>
<li class="L12718" rel="L12718">and made the important communication. Its effect was most extraordinary;</li>
<li class="L12719" rel="L12719">for on first hearing it, Mrs. Bennet sat quite still, and unable to</li>
<li class="L12720" rel="L12720">utter a syllable. Nor was it under many, many minutes that she could</li>
<li class="L12721" rel="L12721">comprehend what she heard; though not in general backward to credit</li>
<li class="L12722" rel="L12722">what was for the advantage of her family, or that came in the shape of a</li>
<li class="L12723" rel="L12723">lover to any of them. She began at length to recover, to fidget about in</li>
<li class="L12724" rel="L12724">her chair, get up, sit down again, wonder, and bless herself.</li>
<li class="L12725" rel="L12725"></li>
<li class="L12726" rel="L12726">“Good gracious! Lord bless me! only think! dear me! Mr. Darcy! Who would</li>
<li class="L12727" rel="L12727">have thought it! And is it really true? Oh! my sweetest Lizzy! how rich</li>
<li class="L12728" rel="L12728">and how great you will be! What pin-money, what jewels, what carriages</li>
<li class="L12729" rel="L12729">you will have! Jane&#39;s is nothing to it--nothing at all. I am so</li>
<li class="L12730" rel="L12730">pleased--so happy. Such a charming man!--so handsome! so tall!--Oh, my</li>
<li class="L12731" rel="L12731">dear Lizzy! pray apologise for my having disliked him so much before. I</li>
<li class="L12732" rel="L12732">hope he will overlook it. Dear, dear Lizzy. A house in town! Every thing</li>
<li class="L12733" rel="L12733">that is charming! Three daughters married! Ten thousand a year! Oh,</li>
<li class="L12734" rel="L12734">Lord! What will become of me. I shall go distracted.”</li>
<li class="L12735" rel="L12735"></li>
<li class="L12736" rel="L12736">This was enough to prove that her approbation need not be doubted: and</li>
<li class="L12737" rel="L12737">Elizabeth, rejoicing that such an effusion was heard only by herself,</li>
<li class="L12738" rel="L12738">soon went away. But before she had been three minutes in her own room,</li>
<li class="L12739" rel="L12739">her mother followed her.</li>
<li class="L12740" rel="L12740"></li>
<li class="L12741" rel="L12741">“My dearest child,” she cried, “I can think of nothing else! Ten</li>
<li class="L12742" rel="L12742">thousand a year, and very likely more! &#39;Tis as good as a Lord! And a</li>
<li class="L12743" rel="L12743">special licence. You must and shall be married by a special licence. But</li>
<li class="L12744" rel="L12744">my dearest love, tell me what dish Mr. Darcy is particularly fond of,</li>
<li class="L12745" rel="L12745">that I may have it to-morrow.”</li>
<li class="L12746" rel="L12746"></li>
<li class="L12747" rel="L12747">This was a sad omen of what her mother&#39;s behaviour to the gentleman</li>
