<li class="L12748" rel="L12748">himself might be; and Elizabeth found that, though in the certain</li>
<li class="L12749" rel="L12749">possession of his warmest affection, and secure of her relations&#39;</li>
<li class="L12750" rel="L12750">consent, there was still something to be wished for. But the morrow</li>
<li class="L12751" rel="L12751">passed off much better than she expected; for Mrs. Bennet luckily stood</li>
<li class="L12752" rel="L12752">in such awe of her intended son-in-law that she ventured not to speak to</li>
<li class="L12753" rel="L12753">him, unless it was in her power to offer him any attention, or mark her</li>
<li class="L12754" rel="L12754">deference for his opinion.</li>
<li class="L12755" rel="L12755"></li>
<li class="L12756" rel="L12756">Elizabeth had the satisfaction of seeing her father taking pains to get</li>
<li class="L12757" rel="L12757">acquainted with him; and Mr. Bennet soon assured her that he was rising</li>
<li class="L12758" rel="L12758">every hour in his esteem.</li>
<li class="L12759" rel="L12759"></li>
<li class="L12760" rel="L12760">“I admire all my three sons-in-law highly,” said he. “Wickham, perhaps,</li>
<li class="L12761" rel="L12761">is my favourite; but I think I shall like _your_ husband quite as well</li>
<li class="L12762" rel="L12762">as Jane&#39;s.”</li>
<li class="L12763" rel="L12763"></li>
<li class="L12764" rel="L12764"></li>
<li class="L12765" rel="L12765"></li>
<li class="L12766" rel="L12766">Chapter 60</li>
<li class="L12767" rel="L12767"></li>
<li class="L12768" rel="L12768"></li>
<li class="L12769" rel="L12769">Elizabeth&#39;s spirits soon rising to playfulness again, she wanted Mr.</li>
<li class="L12770" rel="L12770">Darcy to account for his having ever fallen in love with her. “How could</li>
<li class="L12771" rel="L12771">you begin?” said she. “I can comprehend your going on charmingly, when</li>
<li class="L12772" rel="L12772">you had once made a beginning; but what could set you off in the first</li>
<li class="L12773" rel="L12773">place?”</li>
<li class="L12774" rel="L12774"></li>
<li class="L12775" rel="L12775">“I cannot fix on the hour, or the spot, or the look, or the words, which</li>
<li class="L12776" rel="L12776">laid the foundation. It is too long ago. I was in the middle before I</li>
<li class="L12777" rel="L12777">knew that I _had_ begun.”</li>
<li class="L12778" rel="L12778"></li>
<li class="L12779" rel="L12779">“My beauty you had early withstood, and as for my manners--my behaviour</li>
<li class="L12780" rel="L12780">to _you_ was at least always bordering on the uncivil, and I never spoke</li>
<li class="L12781" rel="L12781">to you without rather wishing to give you pain than not. Now be sincere;</li>
<li class="L12782" rel="L12782">did you admire me for my impertinence?”</li>
<li class="L12783" rel="L12783"></li>
<li class="L12784" rel="L12784">“For the liveliness of your mind, I did.”</li>
<li class="L12785" rel="L12785"></li>
<li class="L12786" rel="L12786">“You may as well call it impertinence at once. It was very little less.</li>
<li class="L12787" rel="L12787">The fact is, that you were sick of civility, of deference, of officious</li>
<li class="L12788" rel="L12788">attention. You were disgusted with the women who were always speaking,</li>
<li class="L12789" rel="L12789">and looking, and thinking for _your_ approbation alone. I roused, and</li>
<li class="L12790" rel="L12790">interested you, because I was so unlike _them_. Had you not been really</li>
<li class="L12791" rel="L12791">amiable, you would have hated me for it; but in spite of the pains you</li>
<li class="L12792" rel="L12792">took to disguise yourself, your feelings were always noble and just; and</li>
<li class="L12793" rel="L12793">in your heart, you thoroughly despised the persons who so assiduously</li>
<li class="L12794" rel="L12794">courted you. There--I have saved you the trouble of accounting for</li>
<li class="L12795" rel="L12795">it; and really, all things considered, I begin to think it perfectly</li>
<li class="L12796" rel="L12796">reasonable. To be sure, you knew no actual good of me--but nobody thinks</li>
<li class="L12797" rel="L12797">of _that_ when they fall in love.”</li>
<li class="L12798" rel="L12798"></li>
<li class="L12799" rel="L12799">“Was there no good in your affectionate behaviour to Jane while she was</li>
<li class="L12800" rel="L12800">ill at Netherfield?”</li>
<li class="L12801" rel="L12801"></li>
<li class="L12802" rel="L12802">“Dearest Jane! who could have done less for her? But make a virtue of it</li>
<li class="L12803" rel="L12803">by all means. My good qualities are under your protection, and you are</li>
<li class="L12804" rel="L12804">to exaggerate them as much as possible; and, in return, it belongs to me</li>
<li class="L12805" rel="L12805">to find occasions for teasing and quarrelling with you as often as may</li>
<li class="L12806" rel="L12806">be; and I shall begin directly by asking you what made you so unwilling</li>
<li class="L12807" rel="L12807">to come to the point at last. What made you so shy of me, when you first</li>
<li class="L12808" rel="L12808">called, and afterwards dined here? Why, especially, when you called, did</li>
<li class="L12809" rel="L12809">you look as if you did not care about me?”</li>
<li class="L12810" rel="L12810"></li>
<li class="L12811" rel="L12811">“Because you were grave and silent, and gave me no encouragement.”</li>
<li class="L12812" rel="L12812"></li>
<li class="L12813" rel="L12813">“But I was embarrassed.”</li>
<li class="L12814" rel="L12814"></li>
<li class="L12815" rel="L12815">“And so was I.”</li>
<li class="L12816" rel="L12816"></li>
<li class="L12817" rel="L12817">“You might have talked to me more when you came to dinner.”</li>
<li class="L12818" rel="L12818"></li>
<li class="L12819" rel="L12819">“A man who had felt less, might.”</li>
<li class="L12820" rel="L12820"></li>
<li class="L12821" rel="L12821">“How unlucky that you should have a reasonable answer to give, and that</li>
<li class="L12822" rel="L12822">I should be so reasonable as to admit it! But I wonder how long you</li>
<li class="L12823" rel="L12823">_would_ have gone on, if you had been left to yourself. I wonder when</li>
<li class="L12824" rel="L12824">you _would_ have spoken, if I had not asked you! My resolution of</li>
<li class="L12825" rel="L12825">thanking you for your kindness to Lydia had certainly great effect.</li>
<li class="L12826" rel="L12826">_Too much_, I am afraid; for what becomes of the moral, if our comfort</li>
<li class="L12827" rel="L12827">springs from a breach of promise? for I ought not to have mentioned the</li>
<li class="L12828" rel="L12828">subject. This will never do.”</li>
<li class="L12829" rel="L12829"></li>
<li class="L12830" rel="L12830">“You need not distress yourself. The moral will be perfectly fair. Lady</li>
<li class="L12831" rel="L12831">Catherine&#39;s unjustifiable endeavours to separate us were the means of</li>
<li class="L12832" rel="L12832">removing all my doubts. I am not indebted for my present happiness to</li>
<li class="L12833" rel="L12833">your eager desire of expressing your gratitude. I was not in a humour</li>
<li class="L12834" rel="L12834">to wait for any opening of yours. My aunt&#39;s intelligence had given me</li>
<li class="L12835" rel="L12835">hope, and I was determined at once to know every thing.”</li>
<li class="L12836" rel="L12836"></li>
<li class="L12837" rel="L12837">“Lady Catherine has been of infinite use, which ought to make her happy,</li>
<li class="L12838" rel="L12838">for she loves to be of use. But tell me, what did you come down to</li>
<li class="L12839" rel="L12839">Netherfield for? Was it merely to ride to Longbourn and be embarrassed?</li>
<li class="L12840" rel="L12840">or had you intended any more serious consequence?”</li>
<li class="L12841" rel="L12841"></li>
<li class="L12842" rel="L12842">“My real purpose was to see _you_, and to judge, if I could, whether I</li>
<li class="L12843" rel="L12843">might ever hope to make you love me. My avowed one, or what I avowed to</li>
<li class="L12844" rel="L12844">myself, was to see whether your sister were still partial to Bingley,</li>
<li class="L12845" rel="L12845">and if she were, to make the confession to him which I have since made.”</li>
<li class="L12846" rel="L12846"></li>
<li class="L12847" rel="L12847">“Shall you ever have courage to announce to Lady Catherine what is to</li>
<li class="L12848" rel="L12848">befall her?”</li>
<li class="L12849" rel="L12849"></li>
<li class="L12850" rel="L12850">“I am more likely to want more time than courage, Elizabeth. But it</li>
<li class="L12851" rel="L12851">ought to be done, and if you will give me a sheet of paper, it shall be</li>
<li class="L12852" rel="L12852">done directly.”</li>
<li class="L12853" rel="L12853"></li>
<li class="L12854" rel="L12854">“And if I had not a letter to write myself, I might sit by you and</li>
<li class="L12855" rel="L12855">admire the evenness of your writing, as another young lady once did. But</li>
<li class="L12856" rel="L12856">I have an aunt, too, who must not be longer neglected.”</li>
<li class="L12857" rel="L12857"></li>
<li class="L12858" rel="L12858">From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy</li>
<li class="L12859" rel="L12859">had been over-rated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12860" rel="L12860">long letter; but now, having _that_ to communicate which she knew would</li>
<li class="L12861" rel="L12861">be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and</li>
<li class="L12862" rel="L12862">aunt had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as</li>
<li class="L12863" rel="L12863">follows:</li>
<li class="L12864" rel="L12864"></li>
<li class="L12865" rel="L12865">“I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done,</li>
<li class="L12866" rel="L12866">for your long, kind, satisfactory, detail of particulars; but to say the</li>
<li class="L12867" rel="L12867">truth, I was too cross to write. You supposed more than really existed.</li>
<li class="L12868" rel="L12868">But _now_ suppose as much as you choose; give a loose rein to your</li>
<li class="L12869" rel="L12869">fancy, indulge your imagination in every possible flight which the</li>
<li class="L12870" rel="L12870">subject will afford, and unless you believe me actually married, you</li>
<li class="L12871" rel="L12871">cannot greatly err. You must write again very soon, and praise him a</li>
<li class="L12872" rel="L12872">great deal more than you did in your last. I thank you, again and again,</li>
<li class="L12873" rel="L12873">for not going to the Lakes. How could I be so silly as to wish it! Your</li>
<li class="L12874" rel="L12874">idea of the ponies is delightful. We will go round the Park every day. I</li>
<li class="L12875" rel="L12875">am the happiest creature in the world. Perhaps other people have said so</li>
<li class="L12876" rel="L12876">before, but not one with such justice. I am happier even than Jane; she</li>
<li class="L12877" rel="L12877">only smiles, I laugh. Mr. Darcy sends you all the love in the world that</li>
<li class="L12878" rel="L12878">he can spare from me. You are all to come to Pemberley at Christmas.</li>
<li class="L12879" rel="L12879">Yours, etc.”</li>
<li class="L12880" rel="L12880"></li>
<li class="L12881" rel="L12881">Mr. Darcy&#39;s letter to Lady Catherine was in a different style; and still</li>
<li class="L12882" rel="L12882">different from either was what Mr. Bennet sent to Mr. Collins, in reply</li>
<li class="L12883" rel="L12883">to his last.</li>
<li class="L12884" rel="L12884"></li>
<li class="L12885" rel="L12885">“DEAR SIR,</li>
<li class="L12886" rel="L12886"></li>
<li class="L12887" rel="L12887">“I must trouble you once more for congratulations. Elizabeth will soon</li>
<li class="L12888" rel="L12888">be the wife of Mr. Darcy. Console Lady Catherine as well as you can.</li>
<li class="L12889" rel="L12889">But, if I were you, I would stand by the nephew. He has more to give.</li>
<li class="L12890" rel="L12890"></li>
<li class="L12891" rel="L12891">“Yours sincerely, etc.”</li>
<li class="L12892" rel="L12892"></li>
<li class="L12893" rel="L12893">Miss Bingley&#39;s congratulations to her brother, on his approaching</li>
<li class="L12894" rel="L12894">marriage, were all that was affectionate and insincere. She wrote even</li>
<li class="L12895" rel="L12895">to Jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her</li>
<li class="L12896" rel="L12896">former professions of regard. Jane was not deceived, but she was</li>
<li class="L12897" rel="L12897">affected; and though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing</li>
<li class="L12898" rel="L12898">her a much kinder answer than she knew was deserved.</li>
<li class="L12899" rel="L12899"></li>
<li class="L12900" rel="L12900">The joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information,</li>
<li class="L12901" rel="L12901">was as sincere as her brother&#39;s in sending it. Four sides of paper were</li>
<li class="L12902" rel="L12902">insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of</li>
<li class="L12903" rel="L12903">being loved by her sister.</li>
<li class="L12904" rel="L12904"></li>
<li class="L12905" rel="L12905">Before any answer could arrive from Mr. Collins, or any congratulations</li>
<li class="L12906" rel="L12906">to Elizabeth from his wife, the Longbourn family heard that the</li>
<li class="L12907" rel="L12907">Collinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge. The reason of this</li>
<li class="L12908" rel="L12908">sudden removal was soon evident. Lady Catherine had been rendered</li>
<li class="L12909" rel="L12909">so exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew&#39;s letter, that</li>
<li class="L12910" rel="L12910">Charlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till</li>
<li class="L12911" rel="L12911">the storm was blown over. At such a moment, the arrival of her friend</li>
<li class="L12912" rel="L12912">was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth, though in the course of their</li>
<li class="L12913" rel="L12913">meetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she</li>
<li class="L12914" rel="L12914">saw Mr. Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of</li>
<li class="L12915" rel="L12915">her husband. He bore it, however, with admirable calmness. He could even</li>
<li class="L12916" rel="L12916">listen to Sir William Lucas, when he complimented him on carrying away</li>
<li class="L12917" rel="L12917">the brightest jewel of the country, and expressed his hopes of their all</li>
<li class="L12918" rel="L12918">meeting frequently at St. James&#39;s, with very decent composure. If he did</li>
<li class="L12919" rel="L12919">shrug his shoulders, it was not till Sir William was out of sight.</li>
<li class="L12920" rel="L12920"></li>
<li class="L12921" rel="L12921">Mrs. Phillips&#39;s vulgarity was another, and perhaps a greater, tax on his</li>
<li class="L12922" rel="L12922">forbearance; and though Mrs. Phillips, as well as her sister, stood in</li>
<li class="L12923" rel="L12923">too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley&#39;s good</li>
<li class="L12924" rel="L12924">humour encouraged, yet, whenever she _did_ speak, she must be vulgar.</li>
<li class="L12925" rel="L12925">Nor was her respect for him, though it made her more quiet, at all</li>
<li class="L12926" rel="L12926">likely to make her more elegant. Elizabeth did all she could to shield</li>
<li class="L12927" rel="L12927">him from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to keep</li>
<li class="L12928" rel="L12928">him to herself, and to those of her family with whom he might converse</li>
<li class="L12929" rel="L12929">without mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising</li>
<li class="L12930" rel="L12930">from all this took from the season of courtship much of its pleasure, it</li>
<li class="L12931" rel="L12931">added to the hope of the future; and she looked forward with delight to</li>
<li class="L12932" rel="L12932">the time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing</li>
<li class="L12933" rel="L12933">to either, to all the comfort and elegance of their family party at</li>
<li class="L12934" rel="L12934">Pemberley.</li>
<li class="L12935" rel="L12935"></li>
<li class="L12936" rel="L12936"></li>
<li class="L12937" rel="L12937"></li>
<li class="L12938" rel="L12938">Chapter 61</li>
<li class="L12939" rel="L12939"></li>
<li class="L12940" rel="L12940"></li>
<li class="L12941" rel="L12941">Happy for all her maternal feelings was the day on which Mrs. Bennet got</li>
<li class="L12942" rel="L12942">rid of her two most deserving daughters. With what delighted pride</li>
<li class="L12943" rel="L12943">she afterwards visited Mrs. Bingley, and talked of Mrs. Darcy, may</li>
<li class="L12944" rel="L12944">be guessed. I wish I could say, for the sake of her family, that the</li>
<li class="L12945" rel="L12945">accomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many</li>
<li class="L12946" rel="L12946">of her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible,</li>
<li class="L12947" rel="L12947">amiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though perhaps it</li>
<li class="L12948" rel="L12948">was lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic felicity</li>
<li class="L12949" rel="L12949">in so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous and</li>
<li class="L12950" rel="L12950">invariably silly.</li>
<li class="L12951" rel="L12951"></li>
<li class="L12952" rel="L12952">Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly; his affection for her</li>
<li class="L12953" rel="L12953">drew him oftener from home than anything else could do. He delighted in</li>
<li class="L12954" rel="L12954">going to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.</li>
<li class="L12955" rel="L12955"></li>
<li class="L12956" rel="L12956">Mr. Bingley and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth. So near</li>
<li class="L12957" rel="L12957">a vicinity to her mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to</li>
<li class="L12958" rel="L12958">_his_ easy temper, or _her_ affectionate heart. The darling wish of his</li>
<li class="L12959" rel="L12959">sisters was then gratified; he bought an estate in a neighbouring county</li>
<li class="L12960" rel="L12960">to Derbyshire, and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source</li>
<li class="L12961" rel="L12961">of happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.</li>
<li class="L12962" rel="L12962"></li>
<li class="L12963" rel="L12963">Kitty, to her very material advantage, spent the chief of her time with</li>
<li class="L12964" rel="L12964">her two elder sisters. In society so superior to what she had generally</li>
<li class="L12965" rel="L12965">known, her improvement was great. She was not of so ungovernable a</li>
<li class="L12966" rel="L12966">temper as Lydia; and, removed from the influence of Lydia&#39;s example,</li>
<li class="L12967" rel="L12967">she became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less</li>
<li class="L12968" rel="L12968">ignorant, and less insipid. From the further disadvantage of Lydia&#39;s</li>
<li class="L12969" rel="L12969">society she was of course carefully kept, and though Mrs. Wickham</li>
<li class="L12970" rel="L12970">frequently invited her to come and stay with her, with the promise of</li>
<li class="L12971" rel="L12971">balls and young men, her father would never consent to her going.</li>
<li class="L12972" rel="L12972"></li>
<li class="L12973" rel="L12973">Mary was the only daughter who remained at home; and she was necessarily</li>
<li class="L12974" rel="L12974">drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mrs. Bennet&#39;s being quite</li>
<li class="L12975" rel="L12975">unable to sit alone. Mary was obliged to mix more with the world, but</li>
<li class="L12976" rel="L12976">she could still moralize over every morning visit; and as she was no</li>
<li class="L12977" rel="L12977">longer mortified by comparisons between her sisters&#39; beauty and her own,</li>
<li class="L12978" rel="L12978">it was suspected by her father that she submitted to the change without</li>
<li class="L12979" rel="L12979">much reluctance.</li>
<li class="L12980" rel="L12980"></li>
<li class="L12981" rel="L12981">As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from</li>
<li class="L12982" rel="L12982">the marriage of her sisters. He bore with philosophy the conviction that</li>
<li class="L12983" rel="L12983">Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude</li>
<li class="L12984" rel="L12984">and falsehood had before been unknown to her; and in spite of every</li>
<li class="L12985" rel="L12985">thing, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be prevailed on</li>
<li class="L12986" rel="L12986">to make his fortune. The congratulatory letter which Elizabeth received</li>
<li class="L12987" rel="L12987">from Lydia on her marriage, explained to her that, by his wife at least,</li>
<li class="L12988" rel="L12988">if not by himself, such a hope was cherished. The letter was to this</li>
<li class="L12989" rel="L12989">effect:</li>
<li class="L12990" rel="L12990"></li>
<li class="L12991" rel="L12991">“MY DEAR LIZZY,</li>
<li class="L12992" rel="L12992"></li>
<li class="L12993" rel="L12993">“I wish you joy. If you love Mr. Darcy half as well as I do my dear</li>
<li class="L12994" rel="L12994">Wickham, you must be very happy. It is a great comfort to have you so</li>
<li class="L12995" rel="L12995">rich, and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will think of us.</li>
<li class="L12996" rel="L12996">I am sure Wickham would like a place at court very much, and I do not</li>
<li class="L12997" rel="L12997">think we shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help.</li>
<li class="L12998" rel="L12998">Any place would do, of about three or four hundred a year; but however,</li>
<li class="L12999" rel="L12999">do not speak to Mr. Darcy about it, if you had rather not.</li>
<li class="L13000" rel="L13000"></li>
<li class="L13001" rel="L13001">“Yours, etc.”</li>
<li class="L13002" rel="L13002"></li>
<li class="L13003" rel="L13003">As it happened that Elizabeth had _much_ rather not, she endeavoured in</li>
<li class="L13004" rel="L13004">her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.</li>
<li class="L13005" rel="L13005">Such relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice</li>
<li class="L13006" rel="L13006">of what might be called economy in her own private expences, she</li>
<li class="L13007" rel="L13007">frequently sent them. It had always been evident to her that such an</li>
<li class="L13008" rel="L13008">income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in</li>
<li class="L13009" rel="L13009">their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to</li>
<li class="L13010" rel="L13010">their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either Jane or</li>
<li class="L13011" rel="L13011">herself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance</li>
<li class="L13012" rel="L13012">towards discharging their bills. Their manner of living, even when the</li>
<li class="L13013" rel="L13013">restoration of peace dismissed them to a home, was unsettled in the</li>
<li class="L13014" rel="L13014">extreme. They were always moving from place to place in quest of a cheap</li>
<li class="L13015" rel="L13015">situation, and always spending more than they ought. His affection for</li>
<li class="L13016" rel="L13016">her soon sunk into indifference; hers lasted a little longer; and</li>
<li class="L13017" rel="L13017">in spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to</li>
<li class="L13018" rel="L13018">reputation which her marriage had given her.</li>
<li class="L13019" rel="L13019"></li>
<li class="L13020" rel="L13020">Though Darcy could never receive _him_ at Pemberley, yet, for</li>
<li class="L13021" rel="L13021">Elizabeth&#39;s sake, he assisted him further in his profession. Lydia was</li>
<li class="L13022" rel="L13022">occasionally a visitor there, when her husband was gone to enjoy himself</li>
<li class="L13023" rel="L13023">in London or Bath; and with the Bingleys they both of them frequently</li>
<li class="L13024" rel="L13024">staid so long, that even Bingley&#39;s good humour was overcome, and he</li>
<li class="L13025" rel="L13025">proceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone.</li>
<li class="L13026" rel="L13026"></li>
<li class="L13027" rel="L13027">Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy&#39;s marriage; but as she</li>
<li class="L13028" rel="L13028">thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she</li>
<li class="L13029" rel="L13029">dropt all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as</li>
<li class="L13030" rel="L13030">attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility</li>
<li class="L13031" rel="L13031">to Elizabeth.</li>
<li class="L13032" rel="L13032"></li>
<li class="L13033" rel="L13033">Pemberley was now Georgiana&#39;s home; and the attachment of the sisters</li>
<li class="L13034" rel="L13034">was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see. They were able to love each</li>
<li class="L13035" rel="L13035">other even as well as they intended. Georgiana had the highest opinion</li>
<li class="L13036" rel="L13036">in the world of Elizabeth; though at first she often listened with</li>
<li class="L13037" rel="L13037">an astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive, manner of</li>
<li class="L13038" rel="L13038">talking to her brother. He, who had always inspired in herself a respect</li>
<li class="L13039" rel="L13039">which almost overcame her affection, she now saw the object of open</li>
<li class="L13040" rel="L13040">pleasantry. Her mind received knowledge which had never before fallen</li>
<li class="L13041" rel="L13041">in her way. By Elizabeth&#39;s instructions, she began to comprehend that</li>
<li class="L13042" rel="L13042">a woman may take liberties with her husband which a brother will not</li>
<li class="L13043" rel="L13043">always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than himself.</li>
<li class="L13044" rel="L13044"></li>
<li class="L13045" rel="L13045">Lady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew;</li>
<li class="L13046" rel="L13046">and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character in</li>
<li class="L13047" rel="L13047">her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him</li>
<li class="L13048" rel="L13048">language so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time</li>
<li class="L13049" rel="L13049">all intercourse was at an end. But at length, by Elizabeth&#39;s persuasion,</li>
<li class="L13050" rel="L13050">he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation;</li>
<li class="L13051" rel="L13051">and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her</li>
<li class="L13052" rel="L13052">resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity</li>
<li class="L13053" rel="L13053">to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait</li>
<li class="L13054" rel="L13054">on them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had</li>
<li class="L13055" rel="L13055">received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the</li>
<li class="L13056" rel="L13056">visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.</li>
<li class="L13057" rel="L13057"></li>
<li class="L13058" rel="L13058">With the Gardiners, they were always on the most intimate terms.</li>
<li class="L13059" rel="L13059">Darcy, as well as Elizabeth, really loved them; and they were both ever</li>
<li class="L13060" rel="L13060">sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing</li>
<li class="L13061" rel="L13061">her into Derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.</li>
<li class="L13062" rel="L13062"></li>
<li class="L13063" rel="L13063"></li>
<li class="L13064" rel="L13064"></li>
<li class="L13065" rel="L13065"></li>
<li class="L13066" rel="L13066"></li>
<li class="L13067" rel="L13067">End of the Project Gutenberg EBook of Pride and Prejudice, by Jane Austen</li>
<li class="L13068" rel="L13068"></li>
<li class="L13069" rel="L13069">*** END OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK PRIDE AND PREJUDICE ***</li>

<li class="L13281" rel="L13281">PROVIDED IN PARAGRAPH F3.  YOU AGREE THAT THE FOUNDATION, THE</li>
<li class="L13282" rel="L13282">TRADEMARK OWNER, AND ANY DISTRIBUTOR UNDER THIS AGREEMENT WILL NOT BE</li>
<li class="L13283" rel="L13283">LIABLE TO YOU FOR ACTUAL, DIRECT, INDIRECT, CONSEQUENTIAL, PUNITIVE OR</li>
<li class="L13284" rel="L13284">INCIDENTAL DAMAGES EVEN IF YOU GIVE NOTICE OF THE POSSIBILITY OF SUCH</li>
<li class="L13285" rel="L13285">DAMAGE.</li>
<li class="L13286" rel="L13286"></li>
<li class="L13287" rel="L13287">1.F.3.  LIMITED RIGHT OF REPLACEMENT OR REFUND - If you discover a</li>
<li class="L13288" rel="L13288">defect in this electronic work within 90 days of receiving it, you can</li>
<li class="L13289" rel="L13289">receive a refund of the money (if any) you paid for it by sending a</li>
<li class="L13290" rel="L13290">written explanation to the person you received the work from.  If you</li>
<li class="L13291" rel="L13291">received the work on a physical medium, you must return the medium with</li>
<li class="L13292" rel="L13292">your written explanation.  The person or entity that provided you with</li>
<li class="L13293" rel="L13293">the defective work may elect to provide a replacement copy in lieu of a</li>
<li class="L13294" rel="L13294">refund.  If you received the work electronically, the person or entity</li>
<li class="L13295" rel="L13295">providing it to you may choose to give you a second opportunity to</li>
<li class="L13296" rel="L13296">receive the work electronically in lieu of a refund.  If the second copy</li>
<li class="L13297" rel="L13297">is also defective, you may demand a refund in writing without further</li>
<li class="L13298" rel="L13298">opportunities to fix the problem.</li>
<li class="L13299" rel="L13299"></li>
<li class="L13300" rel="L13300">1.F.4.  Except for the limited right of replacement or refund set forth</li>
<li class="L13301" rel="L13301">in paragraph 1.F.3, this work is provided to you &#39;AS-IS&#39; WITH NO OTHER</li>
<li class="L13302" rel="L13302">WARRANTIES OF ANY KIND, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO</li>
<li class="L13303" rel="L13303">WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTIBILITY OR FITNESS FOR ANY PURPOSE.</li>
<li class="L13304" rel="L13304"></li>
<li class="L13305" rel="L13305">1.F.5.  Some states do not allow disclaimers of certain implied</li>
<li class="L13306" rel="L13306">warranties or the exclusion or limitation of certain types of damages.</li>
<li class="L13307" rel="L13307">If any disclaimer or limitation set forth in this agreement violates the</li>
<li class="L13308" rel="L13308">law of the state applicable to this agreement, the agreement shall be</li>
<li class="L13309" rel="L13309">interpreted to make the maximum disclaimer or limitation permitted by</li>
<li class="L13310" rel="L13310">the applicable state law.  The invalidity or unenforceability of any</li>
<li class="L13311" rel="L13311">provision of this agreement shall not void the remaining provisions.</li>
<li class="L13312" rel="L13312"></li>
<li class="L13313" rel="L13313">1.F.6.  INDEMNITY - You agree to indemnify and hold the Foundation, the</li>
<li class="L13314" rel="L13314">trademark owner, any agent or employee of the Foundation, anyone</li>
<li class="L13315" rel="L13315">providing copies of Project Gutenberg-tm electronic works in accordance</li>
<li class="L13316" rel="L13316">with this agreement, and any volunteers associated with the production,</li>
<li class="L13317" rel="L13317">promotion and distribution of Project Gutenberg-tm electronic works,</li>
<li class="L13318" rel="L13318">harmless from all liability, costs and expenses, including legal fees,</li>
<li class="L13319" rel="L13319">that arise directly or indirectly from any of the following which you do</li>
<li class="L13320" rel="L13320">or cause to occur: (a) distribution of this or any Project Gutenberg-tm</li>
<li class="L13321" rel="L13321">work, (b) alteration, modification, or additions or deletions to any</li>
<li class="L13322" rel="L13322">Project Gutenberg-tm work, and (c) any Defect you cause.</li>
<li class="L13323" rel="L13323"></li>
<li class="L13324" rel="L13324"></li>
<li class="L13325" rel="L13325">Section  2.  Information about the Mission of Project Gutenberg-tm</li>
<li class="L13326" rel="L13326"></li>
<li class="L13327" rel="L13327">Project Gutenberg-tm is synonymous with the free distribution of</li>
<li class="L13328" rel="L13328">electronic works in formats readable by the widest variety of computers</li>
<li class="L13329" rel="L13329">including obsolete, old, middle-aged and new computers.  It exists</li>
<li class="L13330" rel="L13330">because of the efforts of hundreds of volunteers and donations from</li>

<li class="L13336" rel="L13336">remain freely available for generations to come.  In 2001, the Project</li>
<li class="L13337" rel="L13337">Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation was created to provide a secure</li>
<li class="L13338" rel="L13338">and permanent future for Project Gutenberg-tm and future generations.</li>
<li class="L13339" rel="L13339">To learn more about the Project Gutenberg Literary Archive Foundation</li>
<li class="L13340" rel="L13340">and how your efforts and donations can help, see Sections 3 and 4</li>
<li class="L13341" rel="L13341">and the Foundation web page at http://www.pglaf.org.</li>
<li class="L13342" rel="L13342"></li>
<li class="L13343" rel="L13343"></li>

function submitDeleteForm() {
    var message = prompt("delete_confirm_message\n\ndelete_commit_summary", "Delete ''");
    if (message != null) {
        $("#delete-message").val(message);
        $("#delete-file-form").submit()
    }
}
</script>
